name: Martin SCHULZ
text: I warmly welcome the Members present here in this House to our early morning sitting. I also welcome the representatives of the Council and the Commission.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the preparation of the European Council (18-19 December 2014) (2013/2706 (RSP).

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, I wanted to take this opportunity on behalf of the Council, also to congratulate you on the Charlemagne Prize you have received. Ladies and gentlemen, at the December European Council meeting, two main items will be on the agenda: investment and Ukraine. The financial and debt crisis has led the European Union to rethink its economic strategy. The European Council is at the heart of this strategy, just as investment will be at the heart of the European Council.  Europe needs investment. There is a considerable pool of investment projects that can be exploited, but ambitious projects do not always find funding even when their European potential is enormous. Of course, there are reasons behind this situation. The crisis has had an impact on everyone's behaviour: sovereign operators, economic operators and, above all, private investors, who have taken a cautious stance, not being certain of the expected profits. But this situation cannot and must not continue. One of the main objectives of the European Council will therefore be to restore confidence. Investment must be stimulated and the investment framework in Europe improved. The European Council will provide guidance and guidance in three main areas. Firstly, through the establishment of a European Fund for Strategic Investments, which will mobilise new investments between 2015 and 2017. The joint help of our two institutions will be needed. As co-legislators, we will have to act quickly on the future legislative proposal so that new investments can start as early as the first half of 2015. At the same time, the EIB will start its activities from its own funds. Secondly, by actively continuing structural reforms and growth-friendly fiscal consolidation. These are preconditions for growth. There can be no investment without sound public finances, the right fiscal framework and regulatory certainty. Thirdly, by creating a favourable and predictable environment for investment. Here, too, our role as co-legislator will be crucial to improving the regulatory framework, including by pursuing an ambitious programme to improve the legislature. Tomorrow's European Council will provide political guidance and set priorities, in accordance with its task and responsibility as defined in the Treaties. But translating these guidelines and priorities into the real economy is our task and our responsibility. It will be necessary for the European Parliament and the Council to work hard and quickly to achieve the results that our citizens expect of us. The Presidency of the Council – and they can also speak on behalf of Latvia, which will succeed us – will do everything possible to make this investment framework a winner. I have no doubt that you will be equally committed to achieving this objective, as demonstrated a few weeks ago during the debate on the investment plan for Europe, proposed by Mr Juncker. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, allow me to conclude with a brief reference to Ukraine, where the situation remains precarious. Developments in the east of the country are a source of continuing serious concern. I am aware that these concerns are also shared by many Members of this House. The European Council will closely monitor developments in this regard and is ready to take further action if necessary. As you know, this week the High Representative, Federica Mogherini, is in Kiew and will certainly share with the Council the experts of her visit. At the same time, the new Ukrainian Government is determined to carry out political and economic reforms. We must all encourage it and further facilitate and support the reform process in the country. Thank you for your attention and I look forward to hearing your views on this matter which – I assure you – will be forwarded to President Tusk before tomorrow's meeting. I have been informed, among other things, that the President will be attending your January part-session.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President. - (DE) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has done so. I am pleased to report to you on the Commission's position for tomorrow's European Council and I would be grateful if you would inform your other colleagues who were unable to take the opportunity this morning to be here earlier before ...

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: We do that, no problem.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President. - No, normally you comment on something you have not listened to, and even if you have listened, you comment on what you wanted to say anyway. and that is why, as I was able to say yesterday, we need ....

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Colleagues are all on their way to announce their messages yesterday around the world, Mr President of the Commission.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Kommissionspräsident. - Ich freue mich über diese Trommler, die Sie im Dienst haben. Two elements stand out when we look ahead to the European Council meeting. Firstly, Europe needs a new approach to investment, and we will have to concentrate on improving the investment climate in Europe. We will also have to help our eastern neighbour, Ukraine, stabilise the situation in the East, master the challenges of the winter and pursue the path of reform. We will have to focus our efforts to successfully implement these objectives. Let me start by making a few remarks on our new approach to investment. On 28 November, the Commission presented its 2015 Annual Growth Survey, which is part of a comprehensive jobs, growth and investment package. The Commission proposes an integrated approach built around three main pillars, all of which must act together and must be pursued in joint action of EU Institutions and Member States to be successful and deliver long-lasting benefits: boosting investment; accelerating structural reforms; and promoting fiscal responsibility by pursuing a responsible growth-friendly fiscal consolidation. Let me briefly go through these three points one by one. First, we need a coordinated boost to investment: generating the right conditions for more and sustainable investment is the first priority for this Commission. Weak investment slows down economic recovery in the short term and hurts growth and competitiveness in the longer run. Investments in Europe are today – on average – 15% below pre-crisis levels, and we must take action to change this. As I mentioned when presenting our Investment Plan to you on 26 November, we will set up a European Fund for Strategic Investment together with the European Investment Bank. The aim is to kick-start a string of public and private investment projects in Europe that would not have happened otherwise. The purpose of this new fund will be to invest in those Member States hit hardest by the economic downturn.  The Fund will work in a wide range of areas and choose the financial instruments most suitable for the project in question: from energy interconnectors to broadband; from education infrastructure to innovative SMEs; from renewable energy to high-tech healthcare. As you will understand, I can certainly not commit to financing of specific projects here and now. All projects have to be screened in light of their economic viability. The list published by the Taskforce on Investments last week contains over 2 000 examples. Obviously, not all of these are new, strategic and economically viable. Nevertheless, there are many interesting examples, like infrastructure for energy-connections in Finland, Poland and the Baltic States, reform of school infrastructure in Italy, or modernisation of regional hospitals in Belgium, just to mention a few examples. To set up the fund, we need one legal act, to be adopted in codecision. The Commission will put forward a proposal in January 2015 and we count on your support for swift adoption during the spring. The common aim is that the Fund is fully operational by mid next year. In order to start delivering on the ground as rapidly as possible, we count on the European Investment Bank to be able to start certain activities using its funds at the beginning of 2015. The European Investment Bank has also agreed with this basic idea. Much has been said about how Member States can contribute to the fund. The new Fund is self-standing. However, its impact would obviously be much greater if Member States contributed to it. Several Member States have signalled their potential interest in doing so, and I am now awaiting concrete proposals to this end. I do hope that the European Council tomorrow will indicate its intention to contribute to these stakes. I need not only words, not only ‘parole parole’ – I need money. For my part, I have signalled the Commission’s intention to take a favourable position towards such capital contributions in the context of the assessment of public finances under the Stability and Growth Pact. We will come forward with detailed guidance on this in January. Let me also assure you that in order to guarantee that projects are chosen on their merits, investment decisions should be based on an independent and expert analysis of the intrinsic merits and economic and social viability of each project. There will be no sectorial or geographic pre-allocations or ‘quotas’. However, technical assistance will be stepped up so that project promoters and relevant authorities in all countries will be able to present viable and investible projects. And a transparent pipeline of projects will allow all interested parties to access potential projects in a quick and efficient way. These efforts will be accompanied by concrete proposals to improve the investment environment by removing regulatory barriers in our single market. Deuxièmement, nous avons besoin de réformes structurelles. Rappelez-vous le triangle vertueux que je vous avais décrit en présentant le plan d'investissement, complété par la consolidation budgétaire et les réformes structurelles. Ces trois éléments du triangle ne s'opposent, mais ils vont de pair. Nous avons été assez efficaces dans notre effort collectif consistant à réduire les déficits budgétaires. Toujours est-il que les niveaux de la dette publique sont trop élevés dans un certain nombre d'États membres et qu'ils constituent des entraves à la volonté – qui peut être celle des investisseurs privés – d'investir en Europe. I expect tomorrow’s European Council to give the Commission full support for taking forward the implementation of all the elements of the Investment Plan. I also expect the European Council to agree to double the overall use of innovative financial instruments under the European Structural Funds for the next programming period. This means a more efficient and more intelligent use of public funds and higher impact on the ground. I am obviously also looking forward to the Parliament’s continued support. The other point on tomorrow’s agenda concerns Ukraine. The new government in Ukraine was elected for its reform agenda. We have seen an ambitious Coalition Agreement and a bold Government Action Plan. We should also welcome the government’s determination to carry out political and economic reforms. The Union and its Member States must continue to facilitate and support the government’s work. The challenges it faces are enormous. First, it must bring peace to Donetsk and Luhansk. Over the past week, we have seen less violence, but the lull must become a ceasefire. Weapons should be withdrawn from the line of contact and the peace process should resume. We must continue to do everything in our power to stabilise the situation in Eastern Ukraine by insisting that all parties implement the Minsk agreement.  Second, Ukraine is experiencing a deep recession. This is the result of long-standing macroeconomic and structural problems. In this difficult context, the European Union has provided unprecedented financial support. We are about to complete implementation of our two Macro-Financial Assistance programmes. A total of EUR 760 million in long-term loans has been disbursed in just the last two months, following on from the EUR 600 million already extended in the summer. Under these programmes, EUR 250 million more can be disbursed early in 2015 if the policy conditions are met. But Ukraine will need more help. The assessment of Ukraine’s financing gap has been completed by the IMF. Ukraine will need USD 15 billion in addition to what is already planned. The European Union can only help within its budget. The relevant EU budget line has been squeezed. There is only a small margin of flexibility for additional financing next year. If we fully use our margin for Ukraine, we will have nothing to address other needs that may arise over the next two years. So, we will need to be able to meet Ukraine’s request for EUR 2 billion. As the European Union is not able to do that, Member States will have to contribute and to give us greater flexibility in the budget. Third, the Government must secure Ukraine’s energy supply. The ‘winter package’ gas agreement reached on 30 October is being implemented. Ukraine has ordered a first consignment of one billion cubic meters of gas, which was prepaid on 5 December. Delivery has begun. The Commission will continue monitoring the implementation of the agreement and will continue to encourage the Ukrainian Government to order sufficient gas from Russia in January and February. These are the main indications I wanted to deliver. We will see during the European Council, and afterwards, what sense of responsibility Member States will show.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work she has done. We are in the Advent season, just before Christmas. We can express our wishes. I would like to express my first wish, with regard to the forthcoming Council, that perhaps we should put behind us the old eternal debate on austerity and flexibility, the battles that we have been fighting in the European Council for months and years, because Jean-Claude Juncker, the new Commission, has put forward good proposals to overcome this debate. Specifically: the Investment Pact. Jean-Claude Juncker, the new Commission, has presented a new method – we have discussed this intensively: not to make new debts, but to mobilise EUR 315 billion of private capital. The GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats supports this proposal. Europe is doing what we as Europeans can do. And now the issue is on the Council table. We are asking for support, and we are asking for support! We need this investment boost for Europe, and the national level is invited to make contributions. I say that I would like as many states as possible to make it clear in the next few days that they are making contributions. I also say to my country, Germany, that it would be good if Germany put its own contributions on the table in order to support the investment pact. It would be an important step that we are taking to create momentum. With to the 2 000 project applications, I would just like to say that it is good that the EIB will decide at the end of the day. Many of the projects put on the table by the Council, by the Member States, correspond more to a wish list than a list of priorities, which is actually needed for the future of Europe. The second part is then the debate, the invitation to those who advocate flexibility, who advocate more time, the offer of Jean-Claude Juncker to give until March to give France, Italy more time to invite to make the necessary reforms. Do not use the outstretched hand from Brussels, but invite you to tackle the structural reforms that are necessary. Here, too, the offer of the new President of the Commission to receive this outstretched hand is on the table. I must say that the second largest country in the European Union, France, is a concern for us. If there is now a debate in France about opening a few Sundays so that we can shop there for longer, only in tourist areas, that certain exceptions are being made for notaries, then it is obvious to everyone that this will not solve France's major structural problems. More commitment and commitment is needed to revitalise Europe's second-largest economic power and prepare for globalisation. We are concerned about this, and I would like to say explicitly that without a strong France, Europe has no future. Let me touch on one more aspect of this, because we have also had the discussions on Greece in the troika over the last few days: when I see what the European partners are now demanding about Greece, a country that has done a great deal, which has been asked a great deal – and also with the support of the Italian Finance Minister and the French Finance Minister – what we are asking for with regard to Greece and what we are asking for France at the moment. , then I wonder whether we are treating all the Member States in this European Union fairly. This is the question we must ask ourselves as Europeans. That is why everyone should now, please, take the outstretched hand of the Commission and tackle it. It would be good – if I may open my wish list – if Germany puts money in the pot and if France tackles committed structural reforms. That would be good for Europe. For us as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, the focus of discussion over the next few months will be on structural reforms, because they will decide the future of Europe. I would just like to say one more thought about our debate this week on the Commission's work programme: we in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats support Frans Timmermans in limiting, prioritising, concentrating on the important tasks of our time. The Social Democrat, Frans Timmermans, has our full support for this. I would also like to make it clear that, when it comes to taxation, which was highly controversial among the Socialists, I believe that the Commission is putting forward good proposals on this. Because we in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats have confidence in the Social Democrat, Mr Moscovici, who is responsible for this issue of taxation. We believe that he will put good proposals on the table on this. I would like the Social Democrats to have as much confidence in their Commissioner Moscovici as we have. I can't say that very clearly Address. I would like to highlight two points. The first is TTIP. I am pleased that, following the debates in Australia with the Americans, the Council is now prepared to give gas, perhaps even a target date, to conclude by the end of 2015. The world is not waiting for us to reach an internal agreement. We need commitment there. We want to uphold the standards that make up us Europeans. But we also want to make progress in world trade. That is why we very much welcome the Council's commitment to move forward there. Finally, the point that probably concerns us the most when we look at the current political situation, namely developments in Ukraine and Russia. With a result of Ukraine, our President of the Commission has said what is necessary. I would like to say a few words about Russia: this week, the Russian Central Bank decided to raise the key interest rate from 6% to 17%. This will also choke off the domestic investment climate in Russia. These key interest rates will not normally be used to invest. The ruble stabilised somewhat yesterday, but is still falling. We could say that the sanctions work. But we are not happy about that. But we hope that the development of Putin and also Moscow will make it clear that the path Moscow is taking is the wrong path, the wrong way to go is the wrong way for his own country. We hope that these developments will make it clear that the outstretched hand of the Europeans still exists, that we want partnership with Russia. We hope that Russia, too, will return to respect for international law and thus also to make sanctions superfluous. (The speaker agreed to answer questions under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, Mr Weber, you are asking for equal treatment for all and I am very much in favour of it. In that case, what do you do with the reform requests that could be made to the countries you know best, for example, on Sunday work, women's work or the fight against poverty? What do you say to Mario Draghi when he asks us about the aggregate demand of the Member States, in particular the ability of those who have surplus to feed this demand which is so lacking at European level?

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I really trust myself to have an overview of the PPE-DE governments that we have in Europe. In recent years, they have carried out the structural reforms, such as the Valdis Dombrovskis in Latvia, colleagues in Ireland, Greece and Portugal – with heavy burdens on the people. But if you look at the growth rates in Europe today, you will see that the countries that have had the courage to reform are now the growth engine in Europe. That is why the question is relatively pointless. Those who fight poverty are the ones who have the courage to invest in tomorrow's structural reforms and to lead their countries into the future, and we will stick to that.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today, 17 December, an anniversary is being celebrated on behalf of the Group of the Party of European People's Party. Four years ago, in 2010, a young Tunisian, Mohamed Bouazizi, set himself on fire. The Arab Spring started from that event. Bouazizi was 26 years old and had lost his job that same day. Without a job, you don't just lose a source of waste, you lose your dignity, your reason for living. Because work is a value that makes sense of our lives. Every hour in Europe, 100 people lose their jobs. It's a real war bulletin. An entire generation is sacrificed. We cannot pretend anything and I do not make cheap rhetoric: either we react strongly or we will be overwhelmed by the despair and anger of those who have nothing left to lose, because they have already lost their dignity. It is to this Europe that it is suffering, and I say this to Mr Beazley, that we are in a state of crisis. Della Vedova, that tomorrow's European Council must speak. The speech you have made is a step in the right direction. The investment plan is heading in the right direction, Mr Juncker. We appreciate the significance of this plan. We appreciate the turnaround. It is important to have a European investment fund. Manfred, that's the real priority. We don't think so much about the figures, the accounts. Think of the people who suffer and why people don't suffer, we need investment, growth, sustainability and work. Now, we need to follow up on this plan. With speed, with clarity of objectives. The new fund must focus on the riskier investments and certain sectors, which have been indicated by Mr Juncker.  The best response to Lima and the fears that we are too timid on the fight against climate change will be to ensure that we finance projects that accompany the energy transition in Europe. We need a more powerful plan with more resources, which is why we need the support of the Member States. We must urge the Member States to inject fresh resources into the fund. Mr Weber was right to appeal to his country. However, we must neutralise Member States' contributions to the fund's capital. Otherwise, none of the Member States will want to compete. We also need to reopen the debate on the neutralisation of Member States' co-financing to projects financed by the investment fund, and the communication on flexibility, which is being prepared, may be an opportunity to address the issue of incentives to be addressed to Member States that undertake to support the investments in the plan. In order to achieve all this, the Commission needs the support of this Parliament and we will not leave you alone and we will not allow us to weaken the European Commission, as some people want, outside this House and also, probably, within this House. But you too must not leave us alone. Parliament must be fully involved in the preparation and approval of the new European Strategic Fund and must be able to have its say on its governance. The European Council must speak to the Europe that is suffering, as I said at the beginning. But I also see some bad signs. It is unacceptable that, as things stand, only a few words should be said in the work programme against tax evasion, while the resources are not found to finance the investments that create jobs. Hundreds of billions are taken from the coffers of the Member States. This is a strong Europe with the weak and weak with the strong. But this is a Europe that we do not want. Europe's opponents are not outside our borders, but it is those companies that do not pay taxes, it is those white-collar companies that are complicit in tax evasion and avoidance. The European Council must address these issues, Mr Della Vedova. The European Commission has included in its work programme the measures we had asked for and we thank Vice-President Timmerman, President Juncker and Mr Moscovici. I note that Mr Weber has become a supporter of Moscovici. Better late than never. We have always been and we will always be supporters of Moscovici and any Commissioner who will do the good of Europe. Mr Juncker said that this is a good start and a new beginning. But for it really to be a new beginning you need a strong, passionate, intense and decisive work. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Giulia MOI
text: Blue card question. Mr President, I would like to address my colleague Mr Pittella. In his speech he said: 'We are asking for more money'. Of course, the public ones, not your own, not your politicians who are friends in the Italian caste. So, in what face you are asking for more money from the Italians or europeans who are slaughtering their jobs in order to pay you and keep you.  A scandal has broken out in Italy where for years his party and others, on the right and on the left, have stolen millions on the backs of poor immigrants. You stole in the Mose in Venice, at the Expo in Milan. Stolen from morning to night and still asking for public money? You're a disgrace.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Answer to a blue card question. The instrumentality of your speech is self-commenting. I shouldn't spend a lot of words. I just want to tell you that when you put all the grass in a bundle, you do the information and the citizens a disea duty. Those who stole must pay, without discounts and mercilessly for anyone. Unfortunately, thieves are everywhere and we have to fight them all together. We are a party and a large political family that is deeply involved in the fight against corruption, in the fight against extortion, in the fight against the Mafia, in the fight against crime. We work for good policy and when we ask the Member States to contribute, we do so in order to invest in growth and job creation.

name: Syed KAMALL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, we in the ECR welcome the fact that this Summit is asking the right questions. First of all: how do we bring investment to the countries of the European Union? But secondly: how do we make sure that we support those in Ukraine who believe in the self-determination of their country, of which my Polish colleague will say more later? We welcome the proposals on the investment fund, not necessarily for its content, but because it helps to kick-start a debate. Not just a debate about EUR 315 billion, but a debate about how we unlock the trillions of euros of private money that could be invested in EU Member States to create jobs and growth. Of course, questions need to be answered. How will the investment fund select and prioritise projects, as Manfred Weber asked? How will the fund leverage private investment? How will the fund avoid a situation where we privatise profits while nationalising losses? But the wider debate now being held in the EU about competition and investment must be turned into action. After all, we are trying to create an EU-wide market in goods, services and capital. In none of these areas have we completed our work. In the last of these – the single market in capital – we have hardly even begun.  But let us not talk about a capital markets union if all it leads to is yet another regulatory union. What we really need are open, transparent and well-functioning capital markets so that firms and others do not rely so much on banks. We need to remove the barriers to private investment across the EU. Not just private investment for infrastructure projects, but private investment for small businesses and entrepreneurs to turn their ideas into goods and services. Why is it that non-bank finance, such as venture capital and crowdfunding, are underused in Europe? Let me give you a specific example: I am a regular lender on a website called Kiva – kiva.org – where entrepreneurs from poorer countries can go to raise loans for their businesses. I and over a million other people lend USD 25 at a time to entrepreneurs in poorer countries which are crowdfunded into larger loans. But why is it that I can lend USD 25 to an entrepreneur in a poorer country but I cannot yet lend GBP 25 to an entrepreneur in a poorer community in my own constituency? Working to solve this problem with others, I have found that we do not need state intervention. We just need to work with entrepreneurs and crowdsourcing websites, such as CrowdPatch or ForCommonCause in the UK, because the money is there. However, the will needs to be there to unlock that money; there needs to be an aggregate of individuals across the EU who are willing to lend small amounts of money. So breaking down the barriers to private investment and competition must be our top priority. However, this cannot be done in isolation. It must be part of a wider economic reform programme. Now the Council will repeat its commitments to addressing Europe’s energy challenges, developing the digital single market and concluding bilateral trade agreements. On all these issues, the European Conservative and Reformist Group has launched working groups that will present new ideas. So where we disagree with you, we will meet those challenges with our own ideas. But it is pointless for European leaders to come to Brussels and call for a culture of competition that will unlock private investment when they then go back home to their capitals and fail to take the tough decisions that are urgently needed. Many of these structural reforms are unpopular, and we know that they will be opposed by vested interests, but there is no other way.  In my country, we adopt resolutions for the New Year. My personal one will be to do more exercise. But let us ask the EU leaders at Council to adopt their own resolution: a resolution to reform their own economies; a resolution to break down the barriers to investment and a resolution to cut red tape so that entrepreneurs can create new jobs. And let us hope that 2015 is a year that we get the EU back to work. Happy New Year! (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – Mr Kamall, would you agree with me that the strongest states in Europe are those which are outside of the euro and which practise entrepreneurial capitalism, which is perhaps a novel concept for this House? Why doesn’t the EU try to do some business, or to bring business rather than state investment? Governments do not create jobs; businesses do. Since the EU does not get that, would we not be better off, Mr Kamall, leaving the EU?

name: Syed KAMALL
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Coburn, I have to say, first of all, that I was wondering when the question would come. Secondly, I was not surprised by the question. Was anyone in the House surprised by that question? Quite frankly, no. The first question you asked, Mr Coburn, was: why is it that countries outside the euro area attract more investment? I know that you are a keen scholar of my previous speeches. (Laughter)  You will have read in my previous speech that I made exactly that point and so the lesson for the euro area is to understand why they attract more investment. Thank you for your question. I look forward to many more in the years to come.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I want in fact to direct my words not to the Commission but to the Council because, let us be honest, the Commission has presented an ambitious programme. What we need now is an ambitious response from the Council on Thursday and Friday.  And I have to tell you, Mr Della Vedova, that I have seen the draft conclusions: I know about Cola Light, you know what that is? Well I would say that these are Council Light. If these are the Council conclusions for tomorrow and the day after, it seems like – not zero but near to zero, Mr Lamberts – and my impression when I read them is that a number of people in the European Council are not even aware that Europe is in crisis. It is all about ʽwe call forʼ, ʽwe supportʼ, ʽwe inviteʼ, ʽwe callʼ, it is a standing invitation to participate by the Council.  I want to be very precise. What you need to do is take key decisions on a number of points that will help the Commission go forward with their ambitious programme and I have seven points to make. The first is that you have to decide with the 28 Member States to enter into the guarantee scheme of the fund. That is a decision to take – not to invite the countries to participate, maybe next year. No! Take the decision: the 28 Member States enter the guarantee scheme. That is the decision to take and you do not need to change the Stability Pact for that, you can do that under the rules in force today. Secondly, to help the fund by saying, maybe at national level, that OK, national states should not put taxation on the income of that fund, so that not just institutional investors but also normal citizens, European citizens, can invest in the future of Europe. Three, you have to decide on conditionality. You have to decide with the European Council tomorrow that the first investments are going to go to those countries which are carrying out positive structural reforms, as a positive incentive to carry out these reforms. The fourth point: the telecoms package. You are asking how we are going to emerge from the crisis? We have a Council. Decide on the telecoms package! It has been on the table of the Council for months already and the only thing you are doing is going backwards: not getting rid of the roaming charges, not in fact establishing net neutrality, not in fact harmonising spectrum policy too. Decide on this! This is a package that has already been more than a year on your table, so that you can create a digital market in Europe. The fifth thing to decide: a second package on digital, because we need as fast as possible one regulator in the digital market. Half of the countries in Europe still cannot use Spotify, cannot use Netflix, because we do not have one regulator and we do not have one copyright regime. Next thing, take the decision finally to launch the energy community. Take that decision so that the Commission is backed by this Council to do the legislative work. And then finally: Mr Kamall was talking about this, it is fine that Mr Kamall has now discovered the advantages of a unified Europe; OK we are on the right track now because he has talked about capital markets. Yes indeed, we do not have one credit market, we do not have one mortgage market in Europe. If you have an asset in one country you cannot use it to have credit in another country from a financial institution. So those are the decisions that you have to take. Not these fake conclusions that we always see after a European Council. If we see how deep this crisis is, if we see the lack of investment that we have seen since the outbreak of the crisis in 2008, what I expect from the Council, not only from the Italian Presidency but from the 28 Member States, is that now for the first time they take firm decisions to help this Commission and to help us emerge from this crisis in the European Union. That is your task and my request to the President of the Council – I know that you are there, Mr President, you are always invited at the beginning of this European Council – is that you spread this key message tomorrow when you start your speech.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Verhofstadt, you are at least the formalleader of the Liberal Party here in Parliament and the Liberal Group. Can you explain to me why you are always calling for the state and for this huge investment programme, which is what the states are supposed to decide, the states that are supposed to create jobs, not the companies? The €315 billion investment programme, why should the EU and the member states decide? Why do states have to guarantee money that private individuals do not invest because they obviously have too high a risk? Why is the state always the solution and especially for you as a so-called liberal?

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: blue-card answer. – In my proposals and in the Commission proposal it is not state money that is invested in this project: it is private money that is invested in this project. So you did not even understand the Commission proposal. The only thing that the European Investment Bank is doing, that the European budget is doing and that the Member States are doing is guaranteeing a first hit if one of these investments goes in the wrong direction. That is the only thing, and that is also needed, because everybody – all the institutional investors – agree on one thing, which is that it is the cooperation between the guarantees of the state and the European Investment Bank on the one hand and private money on the other hand that can get us out of the crisis. So it is not public money at all! I am for private money. I am a Liberal!

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the I would also like to address the Council first.  For me, the question arises as to what has really changed after the meeting of EU finance ministers in view of the Council meeting that is taking place today and tomorrow, because what progress is actually being made? Is it really to be seen here that there is a willingness on the part of government representatives to put real sustainable investments on a strong financial footing and, above all, to set priorities for investment? I don't see that, but it's also a bit of the crux that we're dealing with here. When Mr Juncker took up the post and applied for the Presidency of the Commission, he presented a programme which was primarily intended to promote social, environmental and sustainable economic developments in the Member States.  I have the impression that, although Mrs von Storch has not understood the content of the investment programme, I am quite right, she did not understand it, but for me the absurd ity is that, despite her lack of understanding of the problem, she has hit the nail on the head by saying: 'I am not at all in favour of the public investing heavily here, but everything is to be made private'. And that is exactly the field in which we are moving here.  I still consider it a huge problem that necessary investments, sustainable investments, above all, are not made through public funds. I am in stark contrast to the AfD, or even to the direction of this programme. Now I ask you all: do you have so much confidence in the Heads of Government that they are really in a position not to present their old projects representing yesterday's snow and to say that they are now the big investment providers? Where do we actually take the certainty when, in the end, Minister for Economic Affairs Gabriel of the Federal Republic of Germany declares that the whole thing is voodoo for him?  So I think there is still a lot of work to be done here if we really want to invest in sustainable investments aimed at social and employment needs. I do not believe in it and you will have to work here to convince us that it is indeed the case. We now also know that there is a prank list in connection with this. Now I would like to know what impact on investment conditions, for example, is the deletion of the maternity leave directive? What impact, for example, does the question of whether ecological standards are being scaled back, that something that we have democratically agreed with each other here, for example, is simply taken down from the discussion? I am thinking here of the Clean Air for Europe programmes and on waste management. What impact does this have on this?  Are all those sitting here really aware that this strike list has the least impact, but that the creation of the necessary investment environment means, first and foremost, that environmental, social and employment standards must be dismantled within the national framework?  In the end, no one can answer the question why, for example, for projects such as those that have now been collected, private investment has not been submitted long before. So if I want to make a difference, I want to change conditions at national level. You need to be clear about that. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank the I didn't understand that she had said yes. She obviously had doubts about saying yes. Perhaps you did not fully understand how this investment programme works, nor did Mr Verhofstadt. Eur 21 billion of public funds are needed to provide security for private investors to invest in the first place! Obviously, these private investors don't want to invest and don't want to make money. Probably they are too lazy, or they are simply not interested in making money! How do you explain that we need to provide EUR 21 billion of public funds, which we are pumping up to EUR 66 billion in credit, so that private investors want to come and invest in the first place? Where is the logic?

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mrs Storch, I would like to thank you for her excellent work and for her excellent work. I would ask this question to Mr Juncker, not me.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to make a few speeches back and follow on from what Guy Verhofstadt said. I have also noticed the draft resolution that the Council is entering the new parliamentary term with the inauguration of Donald Tusk with a pronounced bunny-footed approach to the challenges. I have the impression that all the lessons we thought we had learned from the euro crisis are being set aside. I see no sign of the willingness in the Council that we absolutely need in order to keep the euro stable in the long term and to really get out of the crisis, namely all the measures that would serve to really integrate into the economic policy of the European Union. Without a common, clear economic policy, we will not be able to keep the euro stable in the long term. I do not know what you are going to make of it. I know that there is a prevailing view in the Council that we no longer dare to defend these ideas in the public eye. But how do we cope with the loss of trust in the European public? Take the example of LuxLeaks. Here, too, I see a large gap in this motion for a resolution. The consequences of LuxLeaks, an announcement by the Council that we will finally ensure that large companies pay their taxes back where they make the profits – that would be a measure, but you could immediately regain the confidence of European citizens. I have the impression, when I look at this brief Council resolution and, on the other hand, I also see the investment list, which has grown to the level of several source catalogues, that the two organisations – the Commission and the Council – think that we can create lasting work throughout Europe through free trade, the dismantling of social standards, environmental dumping and the investment in well-heeled large-scale projects. I don't think so! And I believe that Mr Juncker and Mr Timmermans are very much in demand to ensure order in the face of this mega-Christmas wish list. You are, of course, regarded as a good cleaner, Mr Timmermans. Make sure that only those projects that are really capable of achieving sustainable economic recovery are really approved under this investment programme! And please also ensure that an industry such as the nuclear industry, which is not competitive after 40 years, suddenly celebrates a resurrection again through these subsidies, which are to be made possible. I actually find it regrettable that the whole investment plan is now so overlaid by projects that seem to be from the past. It was a good idea. I hope it will also be well implemented. On Russia, I think it would be better if the Council document did not keep talking about Ukraine, but about what we actually have, namely a deep crisis between the European Union and Russia. What do we learn from the news of the last day? We are not the only ones who depend on Russian energy imports. Today, unlike in the Cold War, Russia belongs precisely through its interconnection with the international community. Everything That Europe has decided so far has been right with regard to Russia. The Council must not allow itself to be divided, whatever attempts on the part of Moscow. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue kare' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Good morning and Merry Christmas! I noticed that you said you did not want to talk about nuclear industry because it was having to be subsidised. Does that mean that you would agree with me that we should not really be considering all these power generation sources that are so inefficient and so ineffective that they need subsidies, like wind farms and things like that? Because, after all, they are quite clearly a very bad investment. So would you agree with me that maybe we should just stick to what makes money and what works?

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. – If we were to believe in the competitiveness of the nuclear industry in the United Kingdom, then firstly, these projects would not be declared for direct subsidisation here, and secondly, a guaranteed fixed price for the electricity that might be produced at Hinkley Point C, which is guaranteed for 35 years, which is inflation-proof and which is already higher than today, would not be enforced. , which costs wind power on-shore in Germany or other European countries. Competitiveness is different, sir.

name: Paul NUTTALL
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, looking at the agenda of this week’s Council, it would return to the same old themes of growth and jobs. It is as if things get discussed over and over again and nothing ever happens. Spain still has over 50% youth unemployment; France’s economy is tanking; and Greece, quite frankly, just needs to leave the euro to get its economy moving again. And of course, another round of hot air from Europe’s great and good – or indeed bad, if you listen to normal people – will not solve anything. The central feature of the agenda is Mr Juncker’s investment plan, with which, somehow, he will magically turn EUR 21 billion into EUR 315 billion. Well, to get into the festive spirit, this reminds me of the classic Pogues song ‘Fairytale of New York’, because what we are witnessing today is the fairytale of Strasbourg. Now, Mr Juncker, I know you like a drink. I know you like a cigarette, but I do hope that you are a betting man too or, to use a British phrase, you like a flutter on the horses.  If you do, I have come up with a more realistic plan for you to increase your money 15 times over. At Ludlow racecourse today at 15.00, a race called the European Breeders’ Fund is taking place. There is a perfect horse running for you, and it is pricing at 15/1. It is called ‘Dream’. Alternatively, there is another running at Tampa tonight. It has got an even better name, and I think you should go for it: it is called ‘Super Fantasy’.  Now, there is a serious point to all this, Mr Juncker, because your investment plan is an economic dream based on super fantasy economics. The Commission has described the funds forecast leverage as, I quote, ‘prudent estimates from historical experience’. Well, you can excuse me if I say: we do not believe you; because these are the same eurocrats who told us ten years ago that the euro would bring us growth and jobs. Mr Juncker, Europe is sinking under global competition, and the European Union is not the answer. Unfortunately for the European people, your investment plan is the biggest turkey on the table. And on that festive note, I wish you all a very Merry Christmas! (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under rule 162(8))

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: blue card question. – Mr President, the Honourable Member claimed that the Commission's proposals and investment programme are the same as before. Your speech was exactly what we have heard before from your group, namely mockery and bad humour. For example, proposing to participate in a horse race instead of an investment programme. There's something new about you, though, there's one new letter in the group name. So I ask what your alternative is. You are systematically opposed to all the options that are being put forward in order for Europe to take off. What's your alternative?

name: Paul NUTTALL
text: blue-card answer. – Hopefully when people bet on horses sometimes they win. In this place it seems that no one ever wins. You know the fact of the matter is, the alternative is a free democratic Europe made up of nation states which take their own decisions. What it should not be made up by is an organisation which is truly undemocratic, where the decisions are taken by a European Commission that meets in secret, where democracy is bypassed, where referendums are not listened to. What we stand for is democracy, we stand for freedom, and that is why we are the voice of the European people.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: Mr Juncker has come up with a plan to promote EU growth. This plan means that the Netherlands will have to rob another 8 billion of its own citizens in order to put it in a structural pot. There will no doubt be airports where no dog is coming, sound barriers along roads through uninhabited areas and nonsensical energy projects of paid for. Will Mr Juncker also make shadowy backroom deals, as he did as Prime Minister of Luxembourg? Indeed, the initial amount of EUR 21 billion invested by the EU and the ECB should grow to more than 300 billion, mainly from the private sector. Are there good interest advantages for companies again, Mr Juncker? This Commission still believes in the mirage of a large European empire, but the economic differences between EU Member States are too great. The price for this empire is paid by the citizens in the form of hard-hitting austerity, heavy taxes, declining prosperity and growing unemployment. Instead of a nonsensical growth plan, Mr Juncker should argue in the European Council for breaking up the EU and the euro. We must restore national sovereignty so that each Member State can become prosperous again, have its own currency that suits its own economy, close its borders again. Then member states can keep out unwanted immigrants who cost billions a year and jihadists who threaten our security. That is what Mr Juncker should do, or he will have to resign.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: Mr President, I, like many others, will address the Council. This summit is indeed crucial for The European Economic Recovery and I hope that the Member States are aware of this. The peoples of Europe are tired of suffering and not believing in the future. However, the Council's statement today seems to me to be particularly bland and very chilly. It is true that the Council has accustomed us to lead us from disappointment to disappointment, simply because of the lack of ambition, which allows us to move forward, and the absolutely necessary spirit of solidarity within the European Union. The time is no longer for procrastination, but for action. Heads of state and government must provide outspoken and massive political support to the Juncker Commission's strategic investment plan. The tools are on the table. It is now our duty to implement them as soon as possible. But beware of chimeras! Indeed, there will be no sustainable growth without economic and monetary stability. This investment plan, based not on debt but on the stimulation of private capital, is well adapted to the reality of the economic situation. The Commission and the Council will also have to be uncompromising on compliance with the Stability and Growth Pact, because real growth can only come if the Member States finally have the courage to carry out the necessary structural reforms. Those who do not resolve will have to take responsibility for their people. Gone are the days when Europe assumed the lack of courage of national governments. This investment plan is therefore only the first act of the European recovery; I also welcome the new approach that guides the Commission's work programme and is more focused, more focused, less bureaucratic. This should allow us to go to success. Because success will only be there if we restore confidence. In the case of the transatlantic agreements, I really want Europe to be strong, so as not to be marginalized by the new orientation of the United States towards Asia. As far as Ukraine is concerned, the situation is certainly serious and it is absolutely necessary to support Ukraine, but it is equally important that the policy of stick alone does not guide us in our diplomatic relations with this great, unavoidable partner, that is Russia. Finally, we no longer have time for half measures. I would like to remind you that we must come to clear and ambitious conclusions. I repeat President Juncker's conclusion: "We will see the sense of responsibility of the Member States"!

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: Mr President, Mr Presidents of the Commission and of the Council, as drafts rapporteur on duty for humanitarian aid from the European Parliament, I would like to draw attention to a point which many might consider to be minor or marginal to the next European Council, which is the issue of Ebola. But it can never be a marginal issue, something on which thousands of people are losing their lives, even if they are far from us, from the borders of the Union. We have to support the answer that is being given, because we have not contained Ebola. We've slowed down its spread, but Ebola continues to kill thousands of people. We need to support the common framework of the European Union adopted last week and, in connection with Mr Stylianides, we need to deploy doctors, laboratories and medical services to save human lives and to increase our dignity as a European Union, responding to a problem that occurs far from our borders but affects human beings.

name: Andrzej DUDA
text: Dear President, I would like to begin by thanking mr First of all, I would like to express my deep dissatisfaction and disapproval of the small support for Ukraine from the European Council. The sign of this is the failure to invite Prime Minister Poroshenko to the Council. I would like to say one more thing, and with full force, namely, if the Council conclusions include a statement calling on both sides, namely Ukraine and Russia, to respect the Minsk Agreement, this will mean actually equating the situation of the aggressor and the victim of this aggression. And it's going to be a scandal. This is the first thing.  The second issue is the investment plan signalled by President Juncker – more than EUR 300 billion. I would like to say one thing: there have been words here about the need to equate the situation of European countries in relation to the crisis. I would like to remind you that we must also bear in mind the pure cohesion of the countries that joined the European Union after 2004. Many of them today need support more than the countries affected by the crisis, because the situation of their citizens is worse and infrastructure development is lower. I hope that this will be included in these investment plans and that this money will be distributed fairly and equally. Thank you.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Mr President, first of all I regret that the gentleman from UKIP left after his artistic performance because I was going to tell him that I also know some British businesses which have invested abroad; they are looking forward to the investment plan. It is composed of the three pillars the President spoke about and in fact all three of them are absolutely relevant and very much in joint implementation. Included in that regulation is the issue that has been referred to: the development of the internal market, which some Members are also fond of. Let me now just make one remark: I am sure that the investment plan could have been fine-tuned a bit, could have been more inspired by some inputs, including some from our group. I might have certain minor hesitations about some of the elements but it is a good plan and this is what the European Union, our citizens and businesses were looking for. It is not comparable with what the previous Commission was submitting. I am also not yet convinced by some of the elements and I did not really receive yesterday an answer on the better regulation. I suspect the basis is a solid one but I very much hope that we will progress on that. Let me refer now to the Council. Minister, I found your intervention at the very beginning very disappointing. Basically very general, not concrete, not addressing the issues as if the Council is completely unaware of what is really going on in Europe. Mr Verhofstadt has spoken about the telecoms package, something that citizens and businesses have been waiting months for, if not years. What is the progress on roaming, on net neutrality? It is very minor in terms of time. The second issue which has not been referred to – let me finish with that – is the fourth railway package. Where are we on that? We have not really even started and we have a debate that we will be splitting the technical part and the governance part. No. Businesses will invest if we progress on those. I could continue with a number of other sectors but we are not getting a thorough reply. (The speaker agreed to take a blue card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for drawing attention to Paul’s excellent speech earlier. I have no doubt that British business would invest in this. What business would not invest in a no-lose scenario? But can you not see, or would you not agree with me, that the reason why taxpayers are having to back up so many of these schemes is quite simply because they are bad investments? It is as simple as that. If they were not bad investments, private investment would do it without the government having to back it up with all of our taxpayers’ money.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: blue-card answer. – I did not really understand the question of which bad investments you were referring to, but I think that the answer is once again very clear. I very much firmly believe in private investments, but I do appreciate that the plan which is on the table today is to encourage investments. I am telling you once again: I have spoken to a number of British investors and their appreciation is quite high. Obviously they make remarks, but the words they use are completely different from the ones that I heard a few minutes ago from your colleague.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the debate in preparation for this Council we would have liked to hear about a completely different agenda. It would be said that if the views of European citizens were at the heart of your concerns, your agenda should contain only one point: how to redistribute income and how to redistribute work; how to bridge the aggravated inequalities of austerity policies. We would have liked, for example, this Council to take into account the OECD report entitled 'Inequalities damage growth'. The OECD's response is that inequalities do a great deal of damage to growth. In 20 years, rising inequality has resulted in a loss of GDP growth of 8.5 points. This has affected the weakest classes in particular and continues to be not only a very serious social problem but also a macroeconomic one. Therefore, only one thing is needed to revive growth: to combat inequalities; change economic policy; investing in education and welfare; establish a citizenship income at European level. You talk about stability for investment but you give precariousness to citizens. Talk of confidence when the President of the Commission is involved in one of the most serious scandals relating to tax evasion. Talk about an investment plan that looks a lot like monopoly money. Should we have hope in an empty box? Should we believe in EUR 315 billion when we know that, materially, only EUR 21 billion is available? Let me say something about the Italian Presidency during this six-month period. Matteo Renzi often talks about the fact that during the Italian Presidency measures in favour of growth would increase. It seems to me that the assessment of the six months of the Italian Presidency has been given by the best workers who took to the streets in the general strike.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: Mr President, among the many sectors of public life that urgently require investment, I would like to mention two, in particular, which I believe are extremely important. A great investment is needed in the research sector, which must be seen as a pillar of progress and well-being in Europe. Research in all fields, in universities, in major research centres, which, unfortunately, have reduced their capacity. Research must, of course, be promoted in the industrial sector and in favour of alternative energies. A major investment is also needed for a youth policy, particularly in education, vocational training and employment. Social and scientific research and a policy for youth and research are the key to our future, which must be prepared today, because if the crisis strikes tomorrow, it is in fact already today. I want to be concrete not only because these areas seem very important to me, but also because I am surprised and very surprised that the Spanish Government was the only government in the European Union to present half a page of incredibly vague petitions, which favour very flexible interpretations, even absolutely arbitrary policies. I therefore emphasize these two points: research and youth.

name: Giulia MOI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the six months of the Italian Presidency have now expired. Six months that we had long awaited, creating expectations for our citizens and for growth. Of course, Merkel will have her responsibility, as does the European Commission. But the responsibilities of Italy and the Italian Government are certainly the heaviest and most serious. The Italian Government has completely forgotten some priorities. In order to achieve a recovery in the labour market, job opportunities need to be reconstructed and these opportunities will not exist unless some crucial issues are resolved, at least as far as manufacturing-related sectors are concerned. It is certainly useful to reduce the burden on new hires, but it is impossible to create new jobs when small and medium-sized enterprises and the craft sector continue to close. They close because of too much tax and too much, incomprehensible, useless and complex bureaucracy that grips Italy and Europe. The Italian Government has wasted the opportunity to resume the battle over Made in, an essential tool to give European companies breathing space and freedom of choice for consumers. It has wasted the opportunity to talk about counterfeiting and illegality due to the lack of a common customs system in a free market such as the European market. Nothing has been done about the protection and development of the company, just as nothing has been done to deal definitively with the issue of the salvation of immigrants and, on the contrary, you have made a shameful profit for 40 years – and a scandal has now broken out in Rome in this regard – on immigration and on those poor people too, and that will not help us. , will not help Italy, nor will It help Europe. This mismanagement is repeated in all the regional administrations, over which this Presidency should have exercised more control and has not done so. He kept quiet.  These are just some of the most urgent problems that the Italian Government should and could have faced if it had prepared for the six months and not to air the effigy of ministers and the head of government, who is also currently involved in a Mafia-state process and is a disgrace. Jobs cannot be created if there is no job and if you do not create it. You can't play politics, you have to leave. You stole for years, you're a disgrace. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Blue card question. Mr President, I wanted to ask this Member whether she thinks she is in the Italian Parliament or whether she knows she is in the European Parliament. We are talking about the Commission's programme, about which it has told us absolutely nothing. I believe that the Italian Presidency has been excellently successful together with all the other members of the European Union, because we all win together or lose all together, simply by laying the foundations for this plan on which, if I can ever speak, I will also speak. But you have not told us anything about what you are thinking on this subject, which is what we are discussing at the moment.

name: Giulia MOI
text: Answer to a blue card question. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Italy is corrupt, scandals are coming out, the Mafia is coming out in Rome. They have stolen from all sides for years and if it does not solve this problem and if europe is not asked for help, we will not get out of it. Italy is failing, it is in default and if it does not go on, Europe will not go ahead either.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: Mr President, the gang of socialists, I mean the right honourable Members of this Parliament, seem not to understand a very simple thing: to fight unemployment they need money. To get money they impose taxes. With the money they create two jobs and because of the taxes, three jobs are lost. It is as simple as that.  If a company avoids taxes it can produce cheaper, it can sell more and if it sells more it creates jobs, thanks to Mr Juncker, but to Mr Juncker as the Prime Minister of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, not to Mr Juncker as the President of the European Commission. Moreover I think that the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are indeed debating a crucial debate. We have a unique opportunity with the forthcoming Council meeting. This is a debate that we also began within the PPE: I would remind you of the congressional documents that we held in Dublin last spring. Today, we are finally here to give concrete form to the things we have said, to the paths that we have said we want to take. I appeal to Mr Juncker, in whom we have placed our trust, to really give this investment plan the opportunity to become an opportunity to review so many imbalances and asymmetries that are within this Europe of ours and within the eurozone and which would risk, if they are not dealt with face-to-face, cancelling and weakening the effectiveness that this investment plan will have to have. Indeed, the ECB in September reported that 100 billion investments have taken the foreign route because our countries do not attract investment. So I think that's the key point that we need to look at., in addition to the surplus problem that focuses on two eurozone countries. I think it's something we have to face with our faces open today. Our American friends have been asking us this for a long time. I wonder, and I ask you, Mr President, whether it is not also this unwillingness to deal with this mercantilistic aspect of the surplus that makes the Americans wary of the TTIP Treaty with force and speed, because, as you well know, the Americans have not yet given the TPA, that is, the essential requirement for TTIP to become a priority for the United States. , which today are primarily focused on the Transpacific partnership. I would like you to give me an answer to these questions, wishing the Council well in its work so that it can better address the issues on the table and restore public confidence.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Mr. President! Like so many of my fellow Members, I too would like to make an appeal to the Council, a very important appeal to really participate in the future orientation of politics. That is extremely important! However, we must not forget one thing: we must not only focus on growth in general, but also create high-quality jobs and also tackle sustainability. In other words, to concentrate and not to proceed in the way that I think is happening in the governments at the moment, a kind of watering can – a bit for each Member State. No, that cannot be the answer, but it is about focusing on important innovation and tasks for the future, of ensuring that jobs are created in high-quality areas such as the digital agenda, such as sustainability, the energy sector, of concentrating on infrastructures, so that jobs are actually created that our citizens also have something of.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Mr President, I would like to return to the situation in Ukraine. We are pleased that the Council is fully committed to further implementing the Association Agreement. Moreover, it would be good to call on all Member States to ratify this agreement quickly. The country is engaged in war, must safeguard its sovereignty and at the same time reform profoundly as the people have clearly demanded. That is a very difficult task. Ukraine needs our help. In the meantime, we see that the sanctions against the Putin regime are having an effect. We must never accept the illegal annexation of Crimea, and I have a very specific question in this regard. At a hearing on the human rights situation in Crimea recently in the European Parliament in Brussels, the issue of Russian passports which Russia is handing out to the inhabitants of Crimea, or rather forcing them on. Can we just recognise these passports? Because that would implicitly constitute an acknowledgement of that annexation. Is this being given concrete consideration?

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the The Liberals want the success of the European Union – we want the success of this Commission. Three elements are, I believe, crucial: a good work programme. Mr Juncker, your work programme is very good. They have had the courage to unravel, probably with the active help of Frans Timmermans, and to include ambitious new projects in the work programme. The second element, in addition to a Commission work programme, is structural reforms in the Member States. We have great concerns here: in France, in Italy or also in Belgium, where the country is completely paralysed by a general strike even under moderate reforms. I believe that the Member States must become much more ambitious when it comes to helping you and us as Europeans to succeed. The third is the investment programme. Your investment programme has been criticised by many. I think it is wrong to break the bar and say now that all this cannot work, that state guarantee can mobilise private investment. Something like this has worked in the past, maybe it works this time – it would be desirable. One thing is very important: you said that the European Investment Bank will decide on the projects. Werner Hoyer, who sat next to you last time, has great confidence in him. Please do not make the mistake of the Member States putting any projects on you. The Federal Government has seriously recommended that you put European money into this investment ruin at Berlin-Brandenburg Airport. We want the success of the European Union, we do not want our resources to be wasted on projects that are really nonsense and that have completely failed.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Madam President, the neoliberal doctrine that unilateral austerity will increase investment has been being tested, gentlemen of the Council and the Commission, for six years now. And investment has fallen by 15%. So we need a shift in policy with more public resources for development than both the social budget and the Member States. Mr Juncker, the package you have presented to us is almost empty, because only Jesus Christ multiplied fish and breads with the known miracle! Leverage with these economy conditions 1/15 is impossible to achieve. And almost everyone tells you. But, Mr Della Vedova, you mr. Juncker you try with procrastination and wishful meals to empty it completely. What will be the participation of the Member States? By what criteria? How do you ensure that investments ensure sustainable growth and enhance cohesion? You don't tell us anything about all this. And I am afraid that the Summit will simply lead to Christmas wishes.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: Madam President, I would like to speak on the Ebola epidemic and on the European Union's current assistance in this area. Experts say the outbreak is linked to deforestation, gaps in health care systems and political instability in the area. The European Union has deployed EUR 1.1 billion in humanitarian aid for the fight against Ebola, of which EUR 434 million comes from the European Commission, which is a very good thing. It took a while, but it happened! However, on 12 December, ministers signed economic partnership agreements with ACP countries, which are problematic. What for? Because the European Union had previously applied unilateral trade preferences to these countries, particularly its former colonies. It agreed that they would continue to tariff their imports from the European Union, while giving them free access to the European market. It now imposes on them the abolition of their tariffs on 80% of European exports. It is a shame that these countries need a budget to finance infrastructure, but will no longer have the necessary funds because of the imposition of new tariffs. How are they going to do that?

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul Jean-Claude Juncker needs more money, he says. It doesn't surprise me. The responsibility for taxpayers' money is virtually non-existent in this House. Bonuses and severance pay have adopted hair-raising levels. Disdain for the EU is only growing among ordinary people, and this is reflected in the turnout: less than 43% chose to vote in the last European elections.  A shining example is Herman Van Rompuy, who is leaving his post with EUR 730 000 in severance pay. This is only true for the first three years, because there will be more money. What is called the Transitional Allowance assumes no quid pro quo whatsoever and all the money will be paid out with a reduced EU tax that is significantly lower than the tax in his native Belgium. The remuneration received by members of the Commission after leaving the post is completely out of the mind.  Compare that allowance with what ordinary workers and taxpayers in Europe receive after leaving office – ordinary people who have been loyal to their bosses and workplaces for many years. What bonus do these get? Well, that bonus consists of paying, paying and again paying for your jackpot bonuses you draw home. And so Jean-Claude Juncker talks about restoring trust and confidence among ordinary people!  In the way that this House handles taxpayers' money, I would say that this can be called mission impossible. As long as you do not show respect for the people who are actually the source of your very existence in this boastbuilding of houses, you should not expect any confidence or trust from ordinary people.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this week's European Council is full of news: a new President and a new Commission. Let us not delude ourselves, however. We already know what's going to happen. Many words but no courageous choice. Nothing will change for the citizens, for businesses, for the unemployed and for young people out of work and without a future, for our elderly. They are tired of announcements and promises. I'm tired of hearing the usual nice words in here. They have now reached the end of 2014 and the Italian-led European Semester is coming to an end. Speaking of good and useless speeches, President Renzi made one, in here, a few months ago. Speech that you applauded. Tell me one thing now, one thing the Italian citizens, the citizens of Europe, will remember Renzi for? He promised us that he would change this Europe. In May, a few days before the European elections, Renzi said "I want a human Europe, not a Europe that cares about bailing out banks, but cares about saving families." Then he blessed Juncker, President of the Commission. Thank you Matteo Renzi! Ridiculous.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: Madam President, Mr Juncker, the next European Council is very important. I'm going to transfer what my supporters expect of him.  Spanish voters believe it is key to enhance tax coordination to promote investment and ensure a smooth functioning of the single market. We must continue to drive the fight against tax evasion and evasion. Secondly, Spanish voters believe that it is important to continue working for a true Energy Union, which assures our citizens of a competitive and sustainable market with sufficient energy interconnections to ensure a reasonably priced supply. Thirdly, we need Europe to remain a safe and secure place.
