We must intensify the fight against terrorism, solve the problem that will pose us the return of foreign fighters and create our own energies to face new challenges. By the way, Mr President, the European Union must react to the murder of more than a hundred children in Peshawar, a hundred children who have died in a school. Every time a child dies in a school it must be as if a child dies in a school in Europe. Malala's spirit must accompany our struggle for freedom and terrorism always. Fourthly, we need solidarity to develop a common border policy that places irregular immigration as a priority on our external agenda. Now that there are no internal borders, I can say that the city of Melilla or the city of Ceuta are also borders of France, Germany or Sweden: they are borders of all. Finally, Mr President, we must talk about Ukraine, but we must also talk about Russia. We must foresee the consequences that a collapse of the Russian economy could have for the Economy and European jobs next winter. Yesterday's news and today's news should not only worry us, they must also take care of us. And, moreover, my voters wish you, after the Council, when your work is done, merry Christmas. (He agreed to answer two questions posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: "blue card" question. – Mr González Pons, I think very well what you say about the energy industry in Europe. How do you explain that energy in Spain is the most expensive in Europe? Why is the European energy industry protected? Why are almost EUR 1.35 billion given to Mr Florentino Pérez? And you know they paid for it in thirty-three days, not in thirty-five, in six months, not in nine months. In other words, my problem is: why complain about European energy without fixing Spanish energy?

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: "blue card" response. – First of all, I would like to thank the Spanish Member Mr Terricabras for addressing me in Spanish, for once, in this House. Secondly, I will tell you that the Government of Spain is trying to lower the cost of energy, the price of energy for Spaniards, but it is also trying to make energy competitive and an instrument of progress for Spain and for Europe. We would like to be able to link the Iberian Peninsula with the rest of Europe through the Pyrenees so that Algerian gas can compete with the possible lack of Russian gas, next winter, throughout the European Union.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. – Mr Pons, you mentioned in your speech that you attach very serious importance to the fight against tax evasion and tax evasion, and along the way I would like to ask respectfully whether your party, but you personally, are willing to act with the same force against overtraw in certain Member States, which, by the way, opens the door to the black economy, specifically in my country, Hungary, which is, by the way, a particularly significant problem?

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: "blue card" response. – Mr. Szanyi, yes!

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Madam President, I would like to address the Italian Presidency to mobilise it and raise awareness of the issue of the digital economy. Everyone can imagine that this will be one of the major avenues by which the investment plan can multiply the creation of value within the European Union, and we welcome that. But it can only be a success if the fruits of these investments go to the Europeans. The articulation of this investment plan in the digital sector and the issue of taxation - on which we base our ability to tax the profits of the GAFA - is an absolutely critical point, which you must raise during the European Council. In the same way, you need to make progress on data protection, otherwise we will also see a leakage of knowledge and capital that we do not want to finance. Finally, I would like to address the Presidency of the Commission again because, in this Council, you will contribute to the development of the roadmap on the future of the euro area. And when I listen to Manfred Weber, I worry about it. Indeed, I do not believe that it is by stigmatizing each other and insulting each other with bird names that we will move the eurozone forward, which everyone needs. It must define our interdependencies and our solidarity, given what economists around the world recognize as our shortcomings, including the establishment of a collective capacity to respond to problems that cannot be corrected by the tools we have today in the framework of Economic and Monetary Union.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Madam President! We have heard a very remarkable speech by the leader of the Liberal Group, Mr Verhofstadt. Even Mr Verhofstadt has now realised that the eurozone is in a serious, deep crisis – as he has said. And that means something for a Liberal Group leader, whose glasses usually turn soft pink as soon as we talk about Europe. But then he criticised the council for not administering medicine. That is the wrong criticism, ladies and gentlemen. Criticism must be made of the fact that the Council has not presented an analysis of why the eurozone is in this crisis, has not answered the question of why North America is growing, why South America is growing, why Asia is growing, why Australia and Oceania are growing, why countries outside the eurozone are growing in Europe, but the eurozone is not growing. That is what I am asking you now, representatives of the Council: why is the euro area not growing? Why do we have a fabulous internal market, why do we have a fabulous Commission, why do we have a fabulous common European currency, but the euro area is not growing? What is the reason for this? Please think hard about this! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I actually have two questions for Mr Lucke. The first question is: have you missed the fact that structural reforms in key eurozone Member States have failed or been too low to really stimulate growth? I mentioned France and Italy myself in my intervention. France is the country that worries us the most. The second question is: When was the last time you were so close to Guy Verhofstadt that you could see his glasses and their color so accurately to see a delicate pink shimmer there?

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. – (The speaker speaks without a microphone)... and even more intensely than I have been able to perceive it from a distance, I do not want to rule that out. However, as far as structural reforms are concerned, I agree with you that they have not been achieved. And the reason why they have not been used is that you and your friends have repealed the non-assistance clause in Europe. For if there were an obligation that each state would have to pay its own debts, the incentive to carry out internal reforms and ensure a state's solvency would certainly be considerably higher than it is today, when the rules are changed at will.

name: Olli REHN
text: Mr President, Europe needs work and growth. This requires investment, especially private investment. In this respect, Mr Juncker's investment programme is welcome.  At the same time, we must remember that Europe needs to be reformed in order to be able to attract investment. This requires a proper business environment and the internal market must be put in order, especially the digital and services internal market. Growth is condient in many areas. Investments must be directed especially at the bioeconomy, telecommunications and the Arctic. In order to speed them up, member states need to carry out structural reforms. This is particularly important in the large Member States of France and Italy. The Stability and Growth Pact must not be scrapped. At the same time, Germany must use its room for manoeuvre to increase investment. In addition, the European Central Bank must give a real boost to the European economy, if not for Christmas at the latest as a new year's decision. (The speaker promised to answer the blue card question under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, Mr Rehn, these days there is a alarm and a propaganda that the victory of SYRIZA in the most likely upcoming elections in Greece will mean Greece's exit from the euro area and a major disaster for the euro area itself. How do you comment on this fear campaign?

name: Olli REHN
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Papadimoulis, thank you for the question. As we know, Greece has had difficult and tough times. Now it is growing again. I have no intention of interfering in the domestic politics of Greece. However, my understanding is that both the Syriza Party and Mr Tsipras are committed to the membership of Greece in the eurozone. They are very clearly committed to that and that is what counts. I also understand that Greece’s very heavy debt burden has to be somehow restructured and rearranged, for instance by prolonging the maturity of the loans, not necessarily by touching the capital.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Madam President, President Juncker, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his excellent work. In the debate over whether Mr Juncker's investment plan will become an effective departure for sustainable growth, our demand, as the Greens, is, firstly, that all member states of the European Union participate in this investment plan with their own contributions. I would ask the representative of the Council to take this demand, which has been made on several occasions in this House by all sides, seriously! Secondly, as far as the projects that need to be funded are concerned, I believe that there are six crucial criteria: firstly, as Mr Juncker said, there must be no sectoral and geographical quotas. There must be European added value. They must contribute to sustainable growth. They must be selected by EIB experts on the basis of professional qualifications, and they must stimulate private investment and, thirdly, in the Member States, must not let small and medium-sized enterprises stand by.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: The summit will escalate the unpopular offensive, such as the Interventions of the European Union and NATO in Ukraine and elsewhere, which will bring new waves of refugees. The threat of widespread war on the altar of competition for new markets in its energy and transport routes is reinforced. You admit that the weak recovery may be followed by a new economic crisis that neither the defenders of restrictive policy nor relaxation can stop, but who agree with each other on hard work, demolition of rights, uprooting of the farm, unpopular taxes. Permanent memoranda are imposed by suppressing the games. The people are being burdened with debts they do not owe, since state money, such as the EUR 300 billion, is not owed. Juncker package goes into business. The competitions of business groups, governments and parties representing them are not about popular interests. The European Union is not becoming pro-grassroots. It is time for the people to become protagonists and overthrow this barbarity.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. There is agreement between Parliament, the Commission and the Council that the European economy needs to be stimulated. I support the objectives of the investment plan myself. However, I have doubts and comments on how it will be implemented. On the one hand, in fact, outside the EIB resources, there does not seem to be any new money for the investment plan. In fact, the sums transferred from the Connected Europe Facility and Horizon 2020 resources to guarantees are mostly just transfers of money from one pocket to another.  On the other hand, the multiplier effect proposed by the Commission is, in my view, overly optimistic. Unfortunately, on the basis of the information available, estimates of metastases are unrealistic and therefore there is a great need for further involvement by Member States.  Thirdly, taking into account the above concerns, particular attention should be paid to the selection of projects. Only a high-quality project list can result in long-term growth. We can only achieve the desired invigorating effect by supporting projects that serve all aspects of our goals. My fellow Members, I would like to thank you for your support. In my opinion, energy projects are exactly like this. Let us therefore seize the opportunity and take a big step towards solving the issue of security of supply in Europe. The Barroso package has already placed emphasis on energy infrastructure, but we are still talking about dependency and lack of connectivity. The central and eastern European region continues to be at the forefront of vulnerability. European citizens and companies can only be provided with a secure and affordable energy supply through the creation of a single energy market. In the longer term, it is the cheaper energy price that can make Europe more competitive. (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question under Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: István UJHELYI
text: Blue card question. – For the economy to kick-start, you need confidence. Trust, for example, in Europe in the commission's work for the next year, and as a Hungarian, I see that there are countries – not just our country – where parties, such as the Prime Minister himself, regularly inst force the mood against the European Union. That is why I ask you, Congressman, what did you say, for example, that the Prime Minister has now pointed the finger at the European Union because of the introduction of a new tax in Hungary, when we both know that is not true? Is this method permissible?

name: András GYÜRK
text: Blue card answer. - Thank you to the Member for asking the question. It gives me a chance to tell you something. You are reluctant to praise your own horse, but if you have already done so and asked a question, let me also say on this plenum that Hungarian economic growth is now at the forefront of the European Union, at more than 3%. Unemployment is falling steadily in Hungary, as is public debt, while the deficit is stable below 3%. These are indicators of the Hungarian economy. All this after we took over a ruined economy from the government of which you were a representative.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: Madam President, Mr Rajoy, the President of the Spanish Government, said last week that this was going to be christmas of economic recovery. Today Mr Weber said that the countries that have implemented structural reforms have become the locomotive of the European economy. And I tell you both not to know what's going on. That their words are an insult to families who are losing their homes for being evicted. That their words are an insult to young people who have to go outside Europe to find employment. That their words are an insult to families and dependents who are losing their rights. And now the Ecofin decides to decaf the tax on financial transactions. We say more needs to be in place, but we can't do it by drowning the middle classes and working classes. Let us make those at the source of this situation pay and those of us who have never asked for anything, because in this way we will be talking about the possibility of a fairer exit from the crisis. We owe it to citizens. Not voters, European citizenship.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: Mr President, let me briefly comment on the main subject of the December European Council.  There is no doubt that Europe needs to increase investment. Network infrastructure, together with research and innovation, should certainly be borne in mind first. But first we have to ask, why are private investors holding back? In this context, I can only refer to the speech of the chairman of our faction, Syed Kamall, at the last plenary session. As regards the European Commission's investment plan, I can only agree with the ambition of setting a predictable regulatory middle for business. However, I have great doubts about the main two pillars. It is such a magic with numbers – at the entry of 16 billion from the EU and 5 billion from the EIB, and then 315 billion using the multiplier effect of the 15th century. Furthermore, why are we ingote money from programs that we have negotiated intricately? They have barely started, after a year we are withdrawing them, i.e. 3.3 billion from the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF) and 2.7 billion from Horizon 2020. Will all selected projects really meet the return criterion? There are indeed a number of questions.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Madam President, dear ladies and gentlemen! I have the impression that many here are unaware of the seriousness and great drama of our situation. We have unemployment on our continent, which has not been seen in decades. We have a development in the area of poverty that should alert us all. In the area of the currency, we have a situation in which the euro is characterised by the greatest instability and is deprived of prosperity by the permanent withdrawal of purchasing power with a zero interest rate policy of the European Central Bank.  The only proposal made by the EU, the Commission, the Council and also the majority in this House is to bring about a reorganisation here with a financial package that is to be leveraged 15 times. This product has also been disqualified as an alchemy product across the newspapers across Europe, which means that a situation is to be rehabilitated here with a great deal of tricks that cannot be financed and rehabilitated. In times of nation-statehood with national currencies, Europe has worked. Now it doesn't work anymore. I leave it to you to judge what is the better way. For anyone with expertise, it is clear what the better way is. (The speaker agreed to reply to another Member's question in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the CRP).

name: Jörg LEICHTFRIED
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Thank you very much, Madam President, for the work she has It is also a pleasure for me, Mr Vilimsky. Now you have told you what doesn't suit you, which is all bad. But you never manage to show what you are imagining in order for things to change.  You have no ideas at all, you always just say no. What is the point of this? That is of no use at all. The only thing you want is for us to continue on our own – alone against the big corporations, only against the multi-banks operating around the world. Do you know what happens then? Then what we all do not want will happen, that they will get even richer, and those who represent us Social Democrats, namely those who have to draw on their money, will have to pay more and more. That happens when you prevail.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr Leichtfried, I would like to thank mr Leichtfried for his work on What I have heard from you is pure polemics. But the way it could work has manifested itself on this continent – over decades, through a national monetary policy, a national economic policy, where the states have nevertheless cooperated with each other on an equal footing and in friendship. A policy as it is now being used serves purely the corporations, the multinationals. And you yourself know very well, for example in the area of TTIP, where you already know that you will agree today, and will thus open even more doors for the corporations in Europe and will reinforce the disastrous development over our continent.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: Madam President, Presidency of the Council, President Juncker, first of all, of course, I would like to express my support and appreciation for the investment proposal that the Commission is launching and which seems to me to be a great opportunity for us, although I would like to point out that, although Mr Juncker said that he would not pay attention to the regional issue. , not least because it is already dealt with in cohesion policy, I have no doubt that that is also the reason, which is essential to take into account, when making the choice of investments, to take into account the economic and social situation of those countries which have been able to make structural reforms and who now need leverage and support to have greater growth and job creation that attenuates this social situation.  And then I would also like to draw attention to the European Union's external agenda. Of course, for the issue of Ukraine and for the troubling issue of Russia, no doubt, but also already already for an issue that arose this week with great force, which is the issue of Turkey, because our Eastern front is not only the front of the Islamic State, it is not only the Northern Front, which is the front of Ukraine and Russia , it is also, between the two, the Turkish issue, and the question of democracy and rights and freedoms in Turkey is an essential issue for this balance of the Eastern Front, which I would like to draw attention to and on which the Council cannot fail to take a position.

name: Olle LUDVIGSSON
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul I have some questions about the Commission's investment plan. It contains a lot of air and risks having a worse outcome than the calculations indicate. At the same time, however, I am clearly in favour of the general signal that the initiative sends out: that Europe needs more investment. It is indeed high time that this issue was placed at the top of the agenda. After investment has fallen by 15 % since 2007, investment levels must now be substantially increased, otherwise it will be impossible to cope with productivity, competitiveness and an effective green transition. It is important not to see the investment plan as a panacea, but instead as a factor in a broader investment effort, which must now be made. The plan may be part of the solution, but it is not the whole solution.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: Madam President, when you are a small child, you believe in Santa Claus and when you are a big child, you believe in the Juncker plan. This Juncker plan - 21 small billions of funds, a sum obviously ridiculous when compared to the 13 trillion GDP of the European Union - which you yourself call "last chance plan", should, in your opinion, attract 294 billion euros of private investment. How? What for? We don't know much about it. It is very likely that these private investments will not finance public projects, which are by definition less profitable. The reality is that your stimulus plan is a communication plan. The reality is the figures, and in particular the figures for Greece. It is very topical, so I will remind you of these figures, especially those who give moral lessons, there, at the bottom, sitting quietly in their little seat. Greece, with 27.4% fewer civil servants between 2009 and 2013, with 10,000 fewer hospital beds over the same period. The average income fell by 35% between 2009 and 2013, the minimum wage is now 586 euros and 489 euros for the under 25s. In 2014, there were 25.7% unemployed and 49.8% unemployed under 25, while public debt was 174% of GDP. So, yes, gentlemen, congratulations on this result! This result is your economic policy! (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mrs Le Pen, I would like to thank Mrs Le Pen for her work and for After yesterday's reports that it has been decided in Russia to make EUR 40 million available to your party, do you believe that it is a sensible investment to take EUR 40 million from the Russian people now to fight against the European Union?

name: Marine LE PEN
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, as usual, Madam, you are talking nonsense, and it is clearly a full-time job. If we have taken out a loan from a Russian bank , as you know, it is because we are prevented from financing ourselves with the French banks, perhaps because they are at your service, Madam, or that of your party, and they are fighting against those who are not their friends, of which you are a part, both of whom, since the main thing in your policy is to improve the situation of the banks and the financial markets. On the other hand, the essence of our policy is precisely to defend the peoples against these great predators.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Madam President! Our policy is aimed at strengthening the independence of the Member States, respecting human rights, respecting international law and ensuring growth and employment, investment and the competitiveness of the European Union.  Let us return to the summit! I expect this summit to make a concrete commitment to the Member States, rather than constantly defending themselves. I expect this summit to take a serious look at the Commission's proposals and take decisions on the implementation of the Commission's proposals and Parliament's decisions. I expect this summit to allow each country to play its part in making the Juncker programme for growth and jobs concrete. You can double the 21 billion, you can increase the guarantees, you can create tax incentives and you can propose projects that have European added value, instead of nationalising the fund that are sustainable, ecological, social and economic, rather than achieving a one-off effect. That is what I expect! Seriousness and no nationalisation of the fund! In concrete terms, I expect budgetary consolidation to continue with a cash crunch in all Member States, structural reforms to be stepped up so that we have money for investment and deregulation takes the Commission as an example. That is what I expect from this summit. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: "blue card" question. – You have just spoken of respect for human rights, but the report on the European Parliament's memorandum programmes, which you are co-signing, finds that there have been violations of human rights within the framework of the Greek programme. Of course, it is not only the report that sees it, it is also the decisions of the Committee on the European Social Charter, for example. In fact, these programmes oblige Member States to breach their obligations under international law. How do you justify that?

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Firstly, I am very pleased that, even before his election, the President of the Commission pointed out on several occasions that the European Parliament's report on the review of the troika provides him with essential points of reference to policy reform in the European Union. Secondly, we must work – and we also need the Member States to do this – so that all emergency structures are transferred to the ground of Community law in response to the crisis. After all, the Charter of Fundamental Rights of Citizens and Freedoms also applies to the implementation of national law. And that is what we are advocating!

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: Madam President, after the hope brought by the Juncker Commission programme, the council's work programme and the known conclusions are deceitary. The future of the European Union no longer depends on words, it depends on acts. Europeans and the world will be aware of concrete acts, and the deadline for these acts to be on the ground is very clear: the end of the first half of 2015. Whatever is not on the ground at that time will have been lost. At that point we have to have an investment plan on the ground, a concrete investment plan, which is not just a kind of resource fund for projects on file and which did not fit into existing funds. We have to have the energy union, we have to have a clear fiscal transparency and convergence, we have to set the timetable for completing economic and monetary union. Mr. President, the proof of the nine is action - action or disillusionment. That is what is at stake in the next Council, and what we know from the conclusions is not very motivating for the time being.

name: Manolis KEFALOGIANNIS
text: Madam President, if you look at the state of investment at European level in recent years, it will be easy to see that from the old Europe of 10, 15, 28 countries they have actually doubled. But now there is a significant shortfall of EUR 260 billion. Euro. Even if we remove the construction sector, with their explosion in the late 2000s, we will find that EUR 160 billion will be used to cover the construction sector. are missing from the European Union's investment programme. The Juncker package of EUR 315 billion for the period 2007-2013 is the first of its EUR 16 billion, EUR 16 billion, EUR 16 billion, EUR 16 billion, EUR of the Community budget, EUR 5 billion for the period 2000-2006. of the European Central Bank, the leverage of funds but also the supply, the contribution of the Member States will certainly lead to the creation of one million jobs and is the answer to the investment crisis we have in the euro area , . Mr . Juncker and his vice-president, Mr Juncker, have been in office since 2010. Katainen, they have very important work to do. They must launch a global campaign to persuade institutional investors, markets in Europe, Asia, America, to support this investment programme. The EUR 300 billion Investment Fund is the largest in the world. This should be the message to the markets. We need to move from the culture of past funds to the culture of investment and risk-taking.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: Madam President, it is not exactly for this last speaker, it was for the previous speaker that I asked for a blue card and the Bureau refused to admit me. I wanted this to be on the record.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: I was apparently told that too late. I am sorry.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Mr President, President of the Council and the Commission, I would like to start by reading out a title of an article in the newspaper today: 'The EU wasted millions on airports'. This is the basis of a report by the Court of Auditors, including five airports, including one in Italy, but also in Greece, Spain and Poland. 666 million was invested in those airports, which turns out to be quite pointless. It is about investments in airports that were not actually necessary, that were too close together, which are not profitable. Why do I say that? One, because of course it is always terribly embarrassing for people who really have a heart for Europe to read that in the newspapers. I'm not saying that because I don't think we should invest. We have to invest. The Socialists and Democrats group is a very strong supporter of investment policy and wants to give a serious push to it. We are also asking the Council to do more, to invest more, but – and that is my message – not in any way. Not in a prestige project of some minister or of one Member State, but in the future. Let us apply criteria, criteria that have to do with sustainability and jobs, and let us prepare the future. Many have already said it, but let us do so: investing in the digital agenda, human capital and the energy union. Because these are investments that prepare the future, that create jobs and that therefore make sense. So no prestige projects from ministers and Member States that lead to nothing.

name: Seán KELLY
text: Madam President, we may not have certainty but we have more clarity regarding President Juncker’s proposals on his investment plan. I think it behoves all of us to get behind it, because if it is a success, all Europe gains; if it fails, all Europe fails. And particularly the Council has a major responsibility. I think Parliament is going to back it, from what I have heard this morning. It is in some respects rather sad that the President had to come in and ask Council to commit to the proposals and to give the guarantees that are necessary. Member States also have an obligation to carry out the structural reforms which have been committed to. As our leader, Mr Weber, pointed out this morning in answer to Madam Berès, Ireland – which four or five years ago was regarded almost as a basket case – did take the hard medicine, despite the suffering of many people, and is now reaping the rewards of structural reform. We have about 4.8% growth this year. More importantly, Mr Juncker was speaking about trust – that means confidence, it means optimism. 30% of SMEs in Ireland hope to take on at least one extra employee next year. That is what is needed because, as is often said, if every SME took on one extra employee, we would solve the unemployment problem in Europe. So, economic growth that is sustainable; projects that are necessary and not vanity.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: Sinjura President, Sur Kummissarju, hemm bżonn urġenti li l-Ewropa ssib toroq ġodda biex terġa' tniedi l-potenzjal ekonomiku tagħha. L-investiment huwa component kru大jali biex iqanqal żvilupp ekonomiku u so大jali aktar mgħaġel wara l-kriżi, filwaqt li jiżgura tkabbir sostenibbli għħall-Ewropa. Il-pjan il-ġdd ta' investiment huwa l-bidla li tant ilna nistennew? Jew din hija sitwazzjoni he' 'too little, too late'? Dan il-pjan mhuwiex eżattament dak meħtieġ iżda naħseb li huwa definittivament pass li se jgħin i大aqlaq mit-triq mudlama attwali li qiegħda fiha l-Ewropa. Huwa essenzjali fil-ġlieda kontra l-faqar u l-esklużjoni so大jali u biex itaffi l-pressjoni fuq is-sistema tal-għajnuna sojali. Madankollu, għad hemm xi kwistjonijiet tekni大i li hemm bżonn li jiġu kjarifikati mill-Kummissjoni u mill-Kunsill. Dawn jinkludu: it-tip u n-natura tal-kontribuzzjonijiet tal-Istati Membri u tas-settur privat jeħtieġ li jiġu definiti; hemm bżonn li tiġi diskussa il-governanza relatata mal-fondi; l-użu doppju ta' strumenti finanzjarji jeħtieġ li jiġi evitat. Is-suikeikeess tal-pjan ta' investiment se jiddependi fuq il-puntwalità, l-effettività u l-effi大jenza tiegħu.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Madam President, i would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, We are talking today about investment: we need them in Europe. Where to take from? We know that the debts to the Member States are already so high that there is no more money to draw. We only have the private sector to hope for, but the private sector, although there is a lot of money, does not invest money in the European economy. We need to ask the important question of why the private sector is not investing in the European economy. And it must answer (and apparently it is): "For there is a lack of faith!" There is a lack of faith that our economy in Europe will develop, there is too much mending, too hard regulation and too unstable government budgets. The European Commission, in Mr Juncker's person, is now offering us a solution to attract these private investments by attracting private money to the projects in question. But, colleagues, if the Member States do not continue and do not actively create so-called structural reforms, these investments will not come from the private sector. We need to address the birocraticisation, we need to address too heavy regulation and we need to stabilise government budgets so that money that is not spent is not being spent. Thanks for the attention!

name: István UJHELYI
text: Madam President, Mr President, dear colleagues, I would like to thank you for your support. Do you know the term skype grandparent or skype granddaughter? We in Hungary use this for families who have been torn apart by the economic and social crisis. Those who had to move thousands of kilometres from Hungary, young people who, together with their children, are sure to meet their grandparents less often, since they have settled in another country because of the economic crisis. It's not good for anyone. This seems to cause social tensions in richer European countries with a huge number of eastern European workers, but it is not good for us at home either, because we lack nurses, doctors are missing, craftsmen are lacking. 600 000 young people have emigrated from Hungary in the last 4 years. What I am asking the Commission to do is develop a concrete action plan on how we can help these young people find their place and not just keep in touch with their own parents and grandparents via Skype.

name: David CASA
text: Sinjura President, nixtieq nirringrazzja l-ewwel nett flower-President tal-Kummissjoni, Jean-Claude Juncker, għal dan il-pass importanti, li se jkun importanti għat-tkabbir so大joekonomiku tal-Unjoni Ewropea. Però jien illum se jitkellem dwar problema oħra li teżisti fl-Ewropa, ħa nitkellmu wkoll fuq l-Ukraine, għada fil-Kunsill, hemm min semma' anke lir-Russja. Din il-problema i tittrattax flower-President tal-Rubbersjoni, imma lill-Kunsill. Ftit tal-ġranet beauty, kellna espert tan-Nazzjonijiet Uniti f'pajjiżi, ġo Malta, fejn qalilna li se jkollna fix-xhur li ejejjin problema ħafna a gravitata' immigrazzjoni mill-Afrika lejn l-Ewropa. Din mhijiex problema' Malta u tal-Italja, ilna ngħiduh dan, imma hija problema tal-Ewropa kollha. Ma jistax ikun li ħa nibqgħu waħedna f'dal-mumenti fejn nafu li ġejjin problemi serji ta' immigrazzjoni mill-Afrika ta' Fuq, b'mod partikolari. Il-Gumssjoni għamlet ħilitha kollha, il-Parlament Ewropew għamel ħiltu kollha: issa jmiss lill-Kunsill, flower-Istati Membri li mhux iparlaw biss. Jiena jiddispjaini li l-Presidenza Taljana mmexxija mis-So大jal-Demokrati大i i lissnux kelma proprju fl-aħħar mument tagħhom tal-Presidenza. Ma nistgħux nibqgħu ngħaddu lil pajjiżi bl-addo大大大. Irridu naraw solidarjetà vera, għandna traġedja umana, 大imiterju fil-Mediterran, u jmisskom tistħu, bħala Stati Membri, qed tippermettu dan kollu. Issa hu l-mument li nagħmlu azzjoni, mhux paroli!

name: Guillaume BALAS
text: Madam President, Mr Juncker, Mr Council representative, we have been hearing from Mr Weber and Mr Lambsdorff for a while and that France must carry out structural reforms. I hope they understand that focusing on this point only serves to make Mrs Le Pen smile. This is the result of this continuous speech today. But I would like to intervene on the merits, and ask the following questions. We are now seeing a trend towards deflation in Europe and around the world. Is there not a deep link between liberal structural reforms, which are intended to bring down the cost of labour and often labour incomes, and this deflation? Is there not a link today with the wait-and-see attitude of private investors, because they know that there is little public investment, but above all little likely consumption, and that this obviously does not reassure anyone? Mr Juncker, is there not a contradiction between the plan you are presenting - particularly with regard to public investment, which must be a guarantee for private investment - and this call for structural reforms, which today does not reassure the markets or investors?

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: Mr President, Mr Juncker, you have drawn up ambitious investment plans for development and it is necessary to proceed quickly and quickly with their implementation, because the peoples of Europe and especially the poor peoples of the South can no longer afford them. The economies of the Member States are interdependent, while in some countries where societies have been put to hard memories, societies remain suffering, homeless, hungry. Private investment cannot be made without political and social stability and the inequalities that exist as a result of the loss of jobs and citizens' incomes create serious political problems, which are evident today in Greece. Cyprus, Spain and Portugal also face serious economic and social problems. Unemployment is galloping and immigration is threatening. Who will invest in conditions of political instability? Greece is facing a new political crisis and some are bringing back the issue of its exit from the eurozone, with implications for all economies. This is reflected in government bonds and stock markets. There will also be a very serious impact in Cyprus, which is also in a memorandum and will be very negatively affected. That is why Greece will now have to rely by all means, otherwise I fear that it will cause a systemic problem, which will threaten to blow up the development programme and the eurozone.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: Madam President, the next European Council will be decisive if we are to have a real turning point in Europe. The S&D Group is available to support the Italian Presidency and the Commission in pushing Member States on the following commitments – and we really need commitments. First, on having a strategic fund for investment which is able to support the crucial investments we need in Europe. We know that for this, we need to have Member States’ contributions on capital and we need these national contributions to be neutralised. This commitment is crucial in the next European Council. The second one concerns tax policy, because here we also need a turning point, not only about transparency, but making sure that taxes will be paid in the countries where profits are made. This is the commitment just made by the President of the Commission. The third is the mandate given to the four Presidents to complete the Economic and Monetary Union (EMU). If there is a central concern regarding the way in which to complete the EMU, it is the concern regarding convergence. Without convergence, there is no future for the eurozone.

name: Jörg LEICHTFRIED
text: Madam President, esteemed colleagues! There is a shadow over Europe. A shadow of injustice. Everyone feels that way. Every citizen is dissatisfied with this injustice in the European Union. We have a situation in which the salaries of the salaried workers, those who have to work hard for their money in most Member States, have de facto not increased in the last twenty years. On the other hand, the super-rich, the big banks, the big corporations are benefiting from our situation that we feel unfair. If we do not succeed in remedying this injustice, we will have an ever-increasing problem. If citizens find their communities unjust, they are not behind it. Then they are not in favour. Then we who want a united Europe, a fair Europe, will have no support. That is a problem, and that must be resolved. And it is also necessary to solve inequality. It is unfair in Europe, and we need to change that. Let me sum it up once again: we have tax injustice. We need to fix that. We must also ensure that there is equality before the law in Europe. This is also one of our fundamental values, and we must also take care of this. We cannot conclude a trade agreement where corporations go to special courts and the ordinary citizen, the ordinary citizen, has to go to normal courts. That is also unfair. We must strive to create a just Europe again, where everyone is equal. Then we will move forward with this Europe. Otherwise there will be a major problem.

name: Paul TANG
text: Mr President, the Juncker Commission's investment plan is a turning point. But it is even more of a shift in political thinking than it is for the European economy. I see the investment plan as a last-ditch effort by the Commission to free up funds within the limited budget. But I see it above all as an invitation to the Member States, to the Council to contribute further to the investment impulse.  What we are now demanding from Member States are not fine words to endorse the plan, but also actions. It requires a reciprocal effort. We are asking countries with the financial space to contribute, from countries that have less financial space, including the effort to reform. And to be clear, the budgetary rules must not stand in the way of this and should promote this. Only then will there be a much-needed boost for private and public investment. Only then will there be a change for the European economy and for Europeans.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Madam President, dear colleagues! Just a few words about what we expect from the Council with regard to Ukraine. We expect clear words and decisive action afterwards, and all support for the elected Ukrainian Government and, above all, for its President Poroshenko. In concrete terms, this means helping to implement the agreed ceasefire, including with Russia. This means support for improving the humanitarian situation, especially in eastern Ukraine. This means supporting the development of a concept of decentralisation, and also helping to implement the extensive reform programme that the government has given itself.  Little has changed yet, but the people of Ukraine will have to feel concrete progress in reform very soon. This costs know-how that we can provide. This costs financial aid, which we offer, so that, in particular, the social distortions that always occur in such a transitional phase can be mitigated, and not just to pay suppliers from East and West. (The speaker agreed to reply to another Member's question in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the CRP).

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". My question is this: you said that you are offering financial assistance. Ukraine is practically bankrupt and will receive financial aid of several tens of billions of euros.  Are you in favour of the European Union bailing out Ukraine as it saved Greece – yes, by no means saved, but an awful lot of money, EUR 140 billion, has been pumped into Greece. Do you want to do the same with Ukraine?

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. The European Union cannot do that on its own.  But, of course, we need financial support if we are to save Ukraine, as you say. Together with the Member States, together with the World Bank, with others, we should succeed in this, to the extent that the reforms there in Ukraine are also successful. Otherwise, it makes no sense for us to put money into it somewhere, so to speak, without any lasting change being made there. I think this House is pretty close to that.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am one of the few who consider the Juncker Plan to be very interesting if it really becomes the instrument for introducing flexibility for the Member States, but using it at European level and therefore in a way that ensures that it is investment. My question is addressed above all to the representative of the Presidency of the European Council. Is the European Council aware of what this means? Is it that the Member States, through relatively limited investment and through the multiplier and accelerator mechanism, are able to do what Europe really needs, namely to increase investment sharply? The investments of EUR 300 billion in the Juncker plan over three years are not enough to close the investment gap, and so it is only through commitment that the problem can also be solved.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Yesterday, instead of making your own criticism of your illegal and brutal interference in the internal political affairs of my country, you argued that, in the name of European politics and because your political identity is known, you supposedly have the right to intervene in the internal affairs of Greece. I would therefore remind you that the Treaty on European Union requires the Commission to respect political neutrality. Finally, Mr Juncker, respect the Treaty of the European Union and stop acting as a representative of the lenders. Stop interfering in Greece's internal affairs, Mr Juncker. Whatever you do, Mr Juncker, you cannot save your memorial political friends in Greece. The campaign of alarmism that you, Moscovici, Schäuble and his gang have been engaged in lately is not going to pass. The Greek people in the next parliamentary elections will throw the Troika and foreign lenders out of our country and proceed to write off the shameful debt, for which you personally are responsible.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Madam President, the next European Council must press Turkey to stop violating international law and the sovereign rights of the Member States, as is the case today with the attack on the exclusive economic zone of Cyprus. It must also stop trampling on both human and democratic rights within it, by arresting its opponents and gagging the press, as well as the sovereign rights of other states. Unfortunately, instead, some Member States are trying to promote turkey's capital opening. All they can achieve is to encourage Turkey to continue in the same illegal and undemocratic direction. Those who really want to make progress on Turkey's accession path must show it that it must implement its contractual obligations, immediately end threats and illegal actions, respect human rights and cooperate in resolving the Cyprus problem.

name: Ana GOMES
text: Madam President, the Mayor of my home town of Sintra is forced now to open school canteens not just to hungry pupils, but also to their unemployed parents. Are you not ashamed, Mr Juncker, that this is happening in a country, Portugal, that some like Mr Weber ridiculously believe to have become the locomotive of growth in the EU? Why do you think there is no money – private or public – to invest in jobs and growth while tax havens in the EU and outside accumulate piles of money which is masked by companies and individuals who evaded and avoided paying tax in the EU Member States? Will you in the Commission and in the Council face your responsibilities – exposed by the LuxLeaks scandal – and put an end to the race to the bottom that is going on among Member States as regards tax dumping, in evident violation of fair competition in the single market, undermining the monetary union and fostering tax criminality, tax injustice and corruption throughout the EU financial system? On the external agenda: do not let the crises in Russia, Ukraine and Turkey continue to overshadow and to block action by the Council on the EU’s security interests, which are put in danger by the insecurity in Libya.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: Madam President, in the Spanish State we already know very well what this is about the Juncker investment plan. No one needs to explain it to us, because we are already suffering, even before it is applied. Because the pilot project of this plan has been the Castor project, an underwater gas warehouse financed from bonds backed by the European Investment Bank. A failed project, which has cost public coffers 1.35 billion euros. 1 350 million euros for Mr Florentino Pérez, president of Real Madrid, but above all, president of the third largest construction company in the world. The champion of public contracts, we could call him. This is the Juncker plan: public money backing up large private investments, in many useless cases. This is a good summary of the Juncker plan. How many more checks do you have ready? In whose name?

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: Mr Juncker, I would like to congratulate you on your fresh ideas and for your fresh energy. You're tired today – it's hard to listen to us for two days.  I would like to express a specific wish on behalf of my constituents. Your investment programme is good and we welcome it, but older people also expect you to come with the programme, with the Commission's response to demographic change in Europe. You haven't talked about it before.  We expect you to also discuss this issue in your next programme performances.

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: Madam President, the European Council, faithful to the principle of robbing peoples of financial capital, is presenting the new programme, which is once again based on the deification of money. We should not be fooled by the fact that the proposed measures are dressed in the suits of democracy, justice and human rights. In fact, the Council is working on ways to protect unpopular governments, such as in Greece, where, while the real power of the government lacks a genuine majority – it has only 106 seats – thanks to the electoral system it steals 50 seats from the other opposition parties and gains a majority to govern. That is why the President of the Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, intervenes with counter-ethical statements; to save his "intimate" government. It was justified yesterday that as a citizen he has the right to... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: I would like to mention two things, although I have already been able to mention one of them in the context of a Blue Card. In fact, I would like to draw Mr Juncker's attention to the fact that tax avoidance and tax evasion, indeed, as two such side-by-side words, do not cover the entire tax problem, the problem of tax crime, because there is the notion that excessive taxation actually causes the economy to become dwindling and deterred. Hungary, in the case of my country, I will give you just one example of where the food trade goes, thanks to the ire high food tax of 27%, to which the government has now added an extra 6%, and, in essence, half of the food trade is lost to the black economy.  Another, it's a shorter sentence. I would like the resources of the investment boost package not to take away the existing funds.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: The coming days will be a difficult debate, especially in two areas. On the security subject, it will be the situation in Ukraine that, despite our huge enthusiasm and rapid accession to the association agreement, has not improved in any way; The latter subject is the deteriorating social situation in our home, in the European Union. In countries like mine, the average wage is still very low. In countries such as mine, unemployment is still relatively high on average in the European Union. These are the topics that must be a challenge for you – for you, as the new Commission, but also for the summit meeting. I believe that you will also use this pre-Christmas time to help citizens in the Member States of the European Union in particular, who urgently need very rapid solutions.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President. - (DE) Madam President, I would like to thank I admire your strong sense of humour, but I prefer to respond to this funny invitation, since I was supposed to leave here at half past eleven and therefore have good reasons, having endured until the bitter end of saying in a minute that most of the questions raised here had already been answered extensively by me yesterday and the day before yesterday and in previous debates. , which actually relieves me of the obligation to answer them again. This is all the more so because many of the questioners have since left the Chamber. I would just like to point out once again – just to make it clear – that in order to be able to implement this investment plan, we urgently need the help of the European Parliament. We will deliver the necessary text documents to Parliament in January. I hope that Parliament will act quickly on this plan. The investment programme itself also needs the active participation of European governments. Newspaper reading – which I sometimes come to, though not regularly enough – tells me that there are at least six Heads of Government who have so far said that Parliament is good, that a first step has been taken, but that the package has been a bit rickety and small. But no one has yet said how many billions they actually want to contribute to this guarantee. I expect that the European Council will collapse tomorrow and the day after tomorrow amid the flood of money that has been set in motion. If everyone adheres to what they have said about the investment plan in recent weeks, then we will have no problem in getting the programme up and running. The programme starts where it needs to start. We do not have public money that we can put into the table without widening deficits and without increasing the debt piles. So it would be intelligent, I think, to bring the mobilizable money from the European budget into the direction of investment and to provide investment in the real economy. Who is to invest in Europe, if not the private capital that is plentiful? (Applause) Should we now put taxpayers back to account, instead of taking on the responsibility of those who have the money they need? The Commission will not select these projects that will be accompanied by itself. I repeat: if the Commission does what many people call on it to do, instead of experts who understand something about the economy and economics, then we will be under constant pressure, every day and every hour, to do this or that programme, because a government or because an MEP would like to do so. (Applause) It is important to me that projects with long-term growth-enhancing potential are supported and financially supported. We should not build new cathedrals, because we are already struggling to fill the churches and chapels with believers, not to build tunnels through mountains that can also be crossed, you do not have to pass them all through. Meaningful projects, not just projects for the sake of projects. That is why I would also like to counter the impression that we have nothing else in mind than to finance the nuclear industry, additional nuclear power stations. That is not the Commission's intention at all. In any case, the energy mix is a national matter and not a matter for the Commission. Pour le reste, Madame la Présidente, je ne suis pas du tout impressionné par ceux qui, depuis quelques jours, m'enjoignent de me taire lorsque d'autres m'invitent prendre la parole. Pourquoi le président de la Commission serait-il le seul ne pas avoir le droit de donner son opinion et d'exposer ses convictions? On m'invite ici. Vous discutez tr s souvent non pas comme un Parlement européen, mais comme des parlementaires nationaux qui s'affrontent. Moi, je suis un homme politique; n'essayez pas de m'enlever la parole! Je dirai ce que j'ai dire. Et si cela concerne un pays en particulier, cela concerne un pays en particulier. Tout le monde peut critiquer la Commission, mais la Commission devrait se taire? Non, elle ne se taira pas! (Applaudissements)

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to thank you for this morning's debate. I would also like to refer to the comments that have just been made by the Commission. I am not anticipating the results of tomorrow's Council but, as I said in my introductory remarks, I will certainly pass on your comments, your expectations, the criticisms that have been made, the encouragement that has largely come, both in general and in terms of, let us say sectorally, the part of the debate on the investment plan, the so-called Juncker Plan. As you know, this European Council will be the first under the leadership of the new President, Donald Tusk, and will also be the first for the new President of the Commission, Jean Claude Juncker. Although both are new to their respective posts, they have important experience gained at previous Meetings of the European Council, as do some of the Members of this Parliament, moreover. As the end of the Italian Presidency approaches, I would therefore like to wish them well, not only for tomorrow's European Council, which I am sure will be very constructive but also for the future.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. – In the light of what the Commission and the Council have said about the European investment plan in the course of the debate on the European Council, I would like to state: (1) Since the start of the crisis in 2007-2008, the GDP growth differential between the European Union and the eurozone, and the United States, has been higher by average by one percentage point per year , as a result of failed ultra-nza structural adjustment policies. The European Investment Plan will not be effective unless at least the Stability and Growth Pact (which will need to be reformed in any case) is not at least more flexible. It is therefore necessary to review the economic governance package sooner anytime soon to make it a useful tool for growth and employment. (2) The European Investment Plan envisages catalyzing EUR 252 billion of private investment with EUR 63 billion in public loans, with only EUR 21 billion in public guarantees. These estimates have been questioned by various experts. In addition to national contributions, the Commission should make a proposal to link the financial transaction tax to the European Fund for Strategic Investments.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The European Council must address the key issue of Jean-Claude Juncker's recovery plan. Unfortunately, the lack of ambition of this plan was confirmed a few days ago by the disappointing long-term investment figures proposed by the ECB to encourage private investment. Despite the extremely favourable conditions, only 219 billion have found a buyer while the ECB wanted to reach the 400 billion loans. This probably definitively demonstrates the need to promote public investment in the recovery plan and job creation and thus get out of austerity that does not solve anything socially and economically. Several important steps can be taken in this regard. First, finance this investment on very favourable terms. Second, neutralize the impact of productive public investment in debt assessment. But we must go further here than immunizing investments that would pass through the European Strategic Investment Fund. Finally, to remain consistent, the brakes on these public investments will have to be questioned as the strict application of the SEC2010 accounting standard. Where is the logic of wanting to encourage public participation and, on the other hand, imposing an accounting standard that will prevent many local and regional actors from developing their investment capacity?

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – In view of what the Commission and the Council have said about the European investment plan in the course of the debate on the European Council, I would like to say that, since the beginning of the crisis in 2007-2008, the SPREAD of GDP growth between the European Union and the eurozone, and the United States, has been higher by average by one percentage point per year , as a result of failed ultra-nza structural adjustment policies. The European Investment Plan will not be effective unless at least the Stability and Growth Pact (which will need to be reformed in any case) is not at least more flexible. It is therefore necessary to review the economic governance package sooner anytime soon to make it a useful tool for growth and employment. The European Investment Plan envisages catalyzing EUR 252 billion of private investment with EUR 63 billion in public loans, with only EUR 21 billion in public guarantees. These estimates have been questioned by various experts. In addition to national contributions, the Commission should make a proposal to link the financial transaction tax to the European Fund for Strategic Investments.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. – In the light of what the Commission and the Council have said about the European investment plan in the course of the debate on the European Council, I would like to state: (1) Since the start of the crisis in 2007-2008, the spread of GDP growth between the European Union and the eurozone, and the United States, has been, on average, , more than one percentage point per year, as a result of failed ultra-nza structural adjustment policies. The European investment plan will not be effective unless at least the Stability and Growth Pact (which will need to be reformed in any case) is not at least more flexible. It is therefore necessary to review the economic governance package sooner anytime soon to make it a useful tool for growth and employment. (2) The European Investment Plan envisages catalyzing EUR 252 billion of private investment with EUR 63 billion in public loans, with only EUR 21 billion in public guarantees. These estimates have been questioned by various experts. In addition to national contributions, the Commission should make a proposal to link the financial transaction tax to the European Fund for Strategic Investments.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. – In the light of what the Commission and the Council have said about the European investment plan in the course of the debate on the European Council, I would like to state: (1) Since the start of the crisis in 2007-2008, the GDP growth differential between the European Union and the eurozone, and the United States, has been higher by average by one percentage point per year , as a result of failed ultra-nza structural adjustment policies. The European Investment Plan will not be effective unless at least the Stability and Growth Pact (which will need to be reformed in any case) is not at least more flexible. It is therefore necessary to review the economic governance package sooner anytime soon to make it a useful tool for growth and employment. (2) The European Investment Plan envisages catalyzing EUR 252 billion of private investment with EUR 63 billion in public loans, with only EUR 21 billion in public guarantees. These estimates have been questioned by various experts. In addition to national contributions, the Commission should make a proposal to link the financial transaction tax to the European Fund for Strategic Investments.

name: Georgios KATROUGKALOS
text: in writing. – The Council should reverse its course and abandon the neoliberal agenda of austerity; it results in economic stagnation and rising unemployment – the ‘Great Malaise’ in J. Stiglitz’s words – and it undermines the European Social Model. In contrast, the opposite expansionist strategy of quantitative easing has led the USA to an imposing growth of 3,8% and a significant decrease in unemployment. Similarly, ‘Abenomics’, an effort to increase wages in order to boost the economy, has reversed Japan’s long-term downward trajectory. These policies failed to deal with and remedy the basic cause of the EU crisis, which is the imbalance between economic integration and monetary union in the Eurozone. Without huge fiscal transfers, the euro inevitably leads to persistent trade imbalances between the more competitive core countries and the less competitive countries of the South. Therefore, the deficits of the latter are just the flipside of the coin of the surpluses of the former. This structural deficit should be corrected by some kind of mutualisation of the debt.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. – Europe needs an investment plan that stimulates the regions most affected by unemployment, develops its welfare state and finances a new industrial policy. It should allocate public funding to support the diversification of the productive structure of each State, facilitating its adaptation towards an environmentally and socially sustainable model. The Juncker plan is something very different. It offers not new money, but a huge public subsidy to the investment of large private companies in transport and energy infrastructures, and a lever for the privatization of the management of social services, health, education or housing. A group of technocrats will be responsible for ensuring markets so that the main decisions on the productive and social model are not made by peoples, but by markets. We also regret the lack of concreteness and transparency of the projects that the Government of Spain wishes to support under the Juncker plan. We do not forget the experience of the Beaver project, with which the State imposed, against the criterion of the population and in the absolute opacity, a hugely controversial infrastructure whose failure we have paid for among all. Without public control and democratic oversight, these will be the tragic consequences of the plan they present to the Council.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. – Hungarian competitiveness will have an examination in the next period of how much of the €300-330 billion investment package announced by the European Commission can be brought to Hungary by the hungarian government, which is so urases. The government is good at representing Hungarian interests when we receive 10 billion euros of investment equivalent to about three percent of the package, which is about the same proportion of the EU budget. If there is less investment in hungary creating fewer jobs, the government has not been able to represent Hungarian interests well.  The test of the Hungarian Government's success propaganda is whether the company, which has been in regional competition since 2010 Hungary be able to propose competitive projects to investors. The Hungarian Government must propose programmes that reduce our country's energy dependency. We need projects that take advantage of the traditionally good Hungarian grey matter, for example by further developing the laser centre in Szeged. The Juncker package will be an objective measure of the competitiveness of the Hungarian economy and the socially insensitive economic policy of the Hungarian Government. Hungary must attract as much investment as possible, not with cheap labour, but with an innovative, competitive economy. It is untenable and, in the long term, a concern that today only one Hungarian company is on the list of 1 000 European companies that are the most paid for development. The crushing of higher education, the bonding to the nugget and the training of talented Hungarians as skilled workers obviously do not help to reverse this.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - Ten years after Poland's accession to the European Union, I wish former Polish Prime Minister Mr Donald Tusk a successful job in the new post of President of the European Council to strengthen the European economy, which will have a positive impact on the standard of citizens and on restoring their trust in the institutions.  The Commission's first step was to define priorities in the 2015 Work Programme in terms of achieving its objectives of focusing on jobs and economic growth. I believe that during its EV it will confirm the €315 billion Investment Plan for Europe, which is aimed at boosting growth and jobs through three main areas of action: the establishment of a new European Fund for Strategic Investments, the establishment of a transparent portfolio of projects in the EU and the establishment of an action plan to attract investment.  As president of the European Parliament Delegation for Relations with Ukraine, I highly appreciate President Tusk's firm stance on the necessity of withdrawing Russian troops from the east of Ukraine and I believe Ukraine will remain a key subject of EV interests as it represents Europe's most important security issue and a test for the EU's foreign, neighbourhood and energy policy.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. – In the light of what the Commission and the Council have said about the European investment plan in the course of the debate on the European Council, I would like to state: (1) Since the start of the crisis in 2007-2008, the GDP growth differential between the European Union and the eurozone, and the United States, has been higher by average by one percentage point per year , as a result of failed ultra-nza structural adjustment policies. The European Investment Plan will not be effective unless at least the Stability and Growth Pact (which will need to be reformed in any case) is not at least more flexible. It is therefore necessary to review the economic governance package sooner anytime soon to make it a useful tool for growth and employment. (2) The European Investment Plan envisages catalyzing EUR 252 billion of private investment with EUR 63 billion in public loans, with only EUR 21 billion in public guarantees. These estimates have been questioned by various experts. In addition to national contributions, the Commission should make a proposal to link the financial transaction tax to the European Fund for Strategic Investments.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The main topic of discussions between European leaders will be the Juncker Commission's plan to boost investment in Europe, which involves a 15-fold leverage of the initial fund of €23 billion over three years. The Juncker Investment Fund is expected to increase EU GDP by around €400 billion and more than 1 million new jobs. However, there are also sceptical voices indicating that the proposed amount is far too small and that the European economy needs more real money.  The second important topic of the sewing talks is to be the situation in the East. Recently, we have seen russia's monetary and budgetary problems deepen. One of the several sources of this situation is the sanctions introduced by the EU and the US, which at the same time confirms their validity. In the 21st century, there can be no permission to act aggressively in an international environment, born in the 19th century. President Putin must understand that aggression is a high price after the annexation of Crimea and the unleashing of hell in eastern Ukraine. At the same time, however, the total collapse and economic chaos in Russia must not be allowed, as it is not known from today that the country's broken pride is an even greater threat to international security. Russia cannot be completely isolated and oppressed, but it must be talked to and attempted to rebuild relations on special, hard terms.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The main item on the Council's agenda is the Commission's investment plan. The Commission will present the annual growth review that lays the groundwork for the 2015 European Semester. The Council will also discuss the follow-up to the Strategic Agenda adopted at the June European Council. As far as the investment plan is concerned, we continue to have serious doubts about this plan. We were promised $300 billion, here's just over 15 on the table. Beyond the announcement effect that could backfire on the Commission but also against the European institutions in general, if this money is not found, there will be no stimulus. Finally, the holding of this Council is another opportunity for me to highlight the Commission's lack of transparency in the development of its agenda. The confusion is total in terms of the ousted files and the motivations around them. One of my reports, for example, proposes to merge two directives and make effective financial flows important for education and agriculture. The file is already amended and ready for votes: its withdrawal would be ridiculous.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. The European Council has recently shown its total ineffectiveness and futility. Seven years have passed since the start of the crisis and it is still unclear what is to be done to revive growth. The whole structure of the new European governance developed after the crisis has been shown to be totally inefficient, as well as harmful. The rules imposed have forced The Member States to comply with strict rules that have brought European citizens to their knees. The same rules have been applied for everyone indiscriminately, not taking into account the different starting situations.  15 years after the entry of the euro, the European institutions have not yet shown that they are capable of managing the single currency. Fiscal union has never been implemented and a Eurobonds plan has never been launched. Debt mutualisation would have prevented the debt crisis from escalating, thus curbing all the Eurosceptic currents that have spread across Europe. The European Council always repeats the same good intentions, but what it has done in recent years has only been to sacrifice the citizens of Europe to unjustified austerity which has destroyed not only the European production model but also the social model.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is voting time. (For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: Mr President, I really want to make a request for clarification to the Bureau, because when I was reviewing the voting list, I found that Amendment No 30 was not considered admissible for a vote. I would like to ask the Bureau why it was not admissible, since we have already voted on it in the 2014 amending budget. What I am referring to in Amendment No 30, which is an amendment by our group, has to do with the fact that, in the light of the current economic and social crisis, members of Parliament must contribute a solidarity rate of 7 % of their salary, as we have imposed on all officials. It's not a pay cut, it's a solidarity rate of 7%. We voted on this in the 2014 amending budget. Why is it not admissible? I would like to be able to vote on this amendment.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: Chairman of the Committee on Budgets (ALDE). Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I welcome the vote that has just taken place because, in a particularly restrictive context, we are giving the Union the budget it needs. I would like to thank all those who contributed to the trilogue agreement: the Italian Presidency, the Vice-President of the Commission, Mrs Georgieva, our rapporteurs as well as the members of the Committee on Budgets and each of you, ladies and gentlemen. Finally, I would also like to thank the President of the European Parliament, since it is on his behalf that I chaired the delegation in conciliation. This vote inspires three reasons for optimism and confidence. First, the debt relief plan will begin at the beginning of 2015, with a view to revising the multi-year financial framework. It is about preserving the credit and authority of the European Union. Then, we look forward to the amending budget that will pave the way for the $315 billion investment plan. Finally, pending the conclusions of the high-level group chaired by Mario Monti on own resources, the Committee on Budgets will ensure that each of our expenditure has real European added value and that it is the guarantee of competitiveness, growth and employment. Merry Christmas! (Applause)

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr Presidents, Honourable Members of Parliament, Vice-President Georgieva, ladies and gentlemen, briefly just to say that the Council notes with satisfaction that the European Parliament has confirmed the agreement reached at the trialogue of 8 December 2014 and that therefore the 2015 budget and the amending budgets for 2014 are now officially adopted. I would also like to take this opportunity to thank once again the chairman of the Committee on Budgets, Mr Arthuis, like the three rapporteurs, Mr Gardiazabal, Mr Hohlmeier and Mr Deprez, and for the constructive attitude he has shown throughout the budget procedure, which has contributed to the positive outcome achieved, and I would like to join here in wishing you, Mr President, and the honourable Members good holidays.

name: Marek Józef GRÓBARCZYK
text: Dear! The resolution corrects the delegated act because it rejects the proposal to reduce the protective dimension of cod to 35 cm and leaves at the current level of 38 cm. The delegated act is against the conservation of the species, as fish cannot be protected by reducing the conservation dimension. It also lacks environmental protection, because the environment cannot be protected because of the eradication of juveniles.
