Finally, it is against fishing itself, as the conservation dimension of cod is allowed to be reduced due to the collapse of the cod population in the Baltic Sea. I appeal to you to support this resolution.

name: James CARVER
text: Mr President, I am a long-time supporter of recognition for another Islamic country, and that is Somaliland. On 3 September this year I wrote to the Commission – Written Question E-006540/2014. On 4 October the Commission replied. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: James CARVER
text: Mr President, this is an important issue. I put the written question with regard to another Muslim Islamic country, Somaliland.  (Whistles from the floor) Listen! The Commission replied on 4 October 2014 and the answer was that the European Union does not have the competency to recognise states: only individual Member States do, as indeed Sweden has. So Mr President, I ask you, as President of this Parliament, to rule on inadmissibility.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Because we all feel the importance of this issue, I would like to thank all the colleagues who have worked on the cross-party approach. We, as a Parliament, have taken an important decision today. Firstly, we want the two-state solution. We want a democratic, peaceful Israel that is recognised by all Palestinians. And we want an independent Palestine, which is also recognised by Israel and by Europe. Secondly, we have said today that this recognition of Palestine is the end of the process. In other words, there is no immediate and unconditioned recognition, but at the end of the procedure, and this step is being taken by negotiations. This is a great and reasonable success that we have achieved today. I would like to express my thanks for this.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Mr President, I too believe that this is an historic day and that parliament as a whole has taken an important vote to open negotiations free of the constraints of extremists and fundamentalists. My group has worked very hard, patiently, with balance and with passion. But I want to say that this is the victory not of a political group, not of one side, but of the whole of the European Parliament, because that is the victory of peace.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the I, too, would like to say that my group has worked for weeks and months for this vote, that we have decided to vote in favour of this motion here in the interests of a strong vote in favour of the recognition of the State of Palestine, even though we have great pain in the stomach with the fact that this recognition of the State of Palestine has been linked to a precondition. We think that is problematic. We do not think that is a good thing. We believe that the recognition of the State of Palestine is a prerequisite for peace negotiations and not the other way round!

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all I want to thank those who have cooperated in bringing forward this resolution, which saw a big majority of more than 500. I think now is not the time to start giving individual interpretations about this resolution. What is important is that this Parliament has finally taken a position. It gives a clear signal to the outside world that Europe is back in this important matter. Secondly, the most important thing about this resolution is that it gives a clear mandate to Ms Mogherini to go forward with matters.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I would also like to say this on the part of my group: this was a very serious and very exciting voting process until we voted in favour of the compromise yesterday. If we want to achieve this as the European Parliament, which has only symbolic things to say on the whole issue, if we want to achieve what Guy Verhofstadt said, that Europe is returning strongly to this important negotiation process with Mrs Mogherini, then no return to an old ideological confrontation will help. Mr Weber, I believe that we should once again talk to each other about your speech so that we can keep Parliament united behind Mrs Mogherini in the coming weeks and months. Thank you for the vote.

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, it is irrelevant what any of us think about the Palestinian-Israeli issue. That is not the point. You call yourselves a parliament. If you are a parliament, then presumably you believe in rules and the rule of law.  My colleague, Mr Carver,  who was shouted down by the same anti-democratic voices we are hearing now  – and who was, with respect, Mr President, totally ignored by you – did, just a few weeks ago, write to the Commission about the recognition or otherwise of British Somaliland. He was told that the Commission does not have the ability, the power or the right to recognise new Member States. Therefore, the request that was made to you – that this motion was inadmissible – simply has to be true. I am asking you now: will you rule on this? Can we please strike out this vote? We cannot tell Ms Mogherini to press ahead, because the Commission – by its own admission – does not have the power.

name: Syed KAMALL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, my group, like many groups, had an internal debate on this issue. There were many who felt, whatever their personal feelings about the recognition of Palestine or otherwise, that it was actually for Member States and not this European Parliament to recognise the state of Palestine. But we have now voted and we have to be clear that, if we are to achieve a longstanding sustainable peace, all parties to this conflict have to play their role. Fatah have to tackle their corruption, Hamas have to renounce their terrorism, and the Israelis and the Netanyahu government – to be quite clear – have to rein back the settler movement and respect the 1967 borders. Then we can truly move towards a sustainable peace between the two states.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, I would ask my fellow Members to delete the city of Taranto from paragraph 15, because taranto has the most polluting plant in Europe, which continues to transgress European directives, to exacerbate the environmental and health disaster and to burden local economies. It is an economically unsustainable plant. He has already been convicted by the European Court of Justice. It is the cause of infringement proceedings and on trial in various criminal cases. In Taranto, it is not necessary to guarantee the production capacity of the plant but to ensure the relaunch of the entire province of Taranto, economic conversion and reclamation.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Mr President, I am convinced that, although my vote will now lapse, I would like to make that point. I welcome the rapproche with the Republic of Moldova, which I supported as chairman of the Friendship Group between the Czech Republic and Moldova. This convergence already brings significant benefits for the citizens of Moldova, and the agreement now approved on autonomous trade preferences is, in my opinion, the conclusion of this process of convergence. As I mentioned in the debate that followed the conclusion of the association agreement, visa-free travel, the European Union's highest support for Moldova with the Eastern Partnership country, of course, the further elimination of import duties on most products, the expected increase in Moldova's national income by EUR 150 million per year, the increase in investment in Moldova, these are all the benefits that this association agreement and the follow-up agreements offer. I therefore very much welcome them and congratulate Moldove on their success.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: I supported the support efforts for Moldova at this point because I think it is key. It is fair to help this country, especially when the benefits will be much greater than some possible temporary inconveniences. Since the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development has assessed that there will be no tangible negative effect on any Member State, moldova's support is also a matter of political responsibility. Looking at the figures, we can see that these are imports of minimum quantities of agricultural products that would not affect the common European market. On the other hand, with this product, allowing duty-free imports of these agricultural goods, we will help small and medium-sized producers in Moldova who are bearing the effects of the embargo imposed on the country. The financial effect on customs revenue will also be negligible. Moreover, support for Moldova is a clear signal that we are not abandoning our friends and those we consider important. As a representative of Bulgaria, I also consider this gesture to the Bulgarian communities in Moldova, who can see that Bulgaria and the Bulgarian representatives have not forgotten them and have not abandoned them. I think that by voting for this report, we are showing solidarity and an intention to move in the right direction, namely moldova's accession to the European Union.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Mr President, I also support the change in autonomous trade preferences for the Republic of Moldova. I very much welcome the fact that this proposal has received a great deal of support, because we can thus give a clear signal that the Republic of Moldova is not alone in being next to the Russian Federation and that the Russian Federation, when it sanctions a small country for moldova wanting to be a partner of the European Union, clearly responds by opening up its market for agricultural products and thus helping Moldova to prosper economically and survive and to have its own foreign policy independent of the Russian Federation. So I do not see this as just an economic decision, an economic advantage, but I see it as a clear political decision where we are helping a small country against which the Russian Federation is being unfair and penalised and sanctioned for moldova's wanting to have a free, own foreign policy. Thank you, therefore, for em accepting this proposal, and I hope that it will make a significant help to moldova's economy and that Moldova will be a strong partner of the European Union in the future.

name: Seán KELLY
text: A Uachtaráin, ghlacas páirt sa díospóireacht seo aréir, agus bhí díospóireacht an-taitneamhach againn. Anois fáiltím roimh an gcinneadh atá déanta againn, agus dar ndóigh vótálas ina fhabhar – mar aon le 551 Fheisire eile.  Is tromlach an-mhór é sin agus tugann sé dóchas do mhuintir na Moldóive, go háirithe feirmeoirí beaga atá ag brath ar thorthaí agus a bhí go dtí seo ag easpórtáil go dtí an Rúis. Ach tá lámh throm curtha ag an Rúis agus ag Putin orthu agus ní raibh aon mhargaí eile acu. Anois táimid ag tógaint na dtorthaí sin uathu. Ní chuirfidh an méid sin isteach orainn go rómhór agus is maith sin. Ach mar a dúras aréir, mar a deirtear i mBéarla: a friend in need is a friend indeed. Agus táimid tar éis a thaispeáint anseo inniu gur féidir linn teacht i gcabhair ar ár gcomharsa in am an ghátair agus go háirithe ós rud é go bhfuilimid ag teacht chomh cóngarach don Nollaig tá jab an-mhaith déanta againn inniu.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: Mr President, like people on all sides of this Chamber, I am in favour of any measures that strengthen the sovereignty of Moldova and the western orientation of the Bessarabian people, but there is another issue here that goes beyond the political one. We are now extending the common market to the sparse and under-developed farmland on the banks of the Dniestr. I hope this will at last help people to understand the difference between membership of the European Union and free trade with the European Union.  The two issues are repeatedly conflated, not least in my own country, with the implication being that you cannot have access to European markets unless you are part of the political structures in Brussels. As we now know, virtually every country in Europe, Macedonia, the Channel Islands, Norway, Lichtenstein, Andorra are all part of a European market without needing to be part of the European Union. The idea that Britain alone would be the only country not to enjoy unrestricted trade with the EU in the event of our non-membership is a fantasy.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — The Autonomous Trade Preference System (ATP) was awarded to Moldova in January 2008 to December 2015. On 21 July 2014, as a result of the signing of the Moldova-EU Free Trade Agreement, Russia imposed sanctions on Moldovan agricultural products, which are damaging its economy, as agriculture in Moldova accounts for 40% of the economy. This sector employs 250,000 people. That is why the Commission proposes to extend the ATP Regulation to introduce three products: plums, apples and grapes. Considering that the EU can easily absorb imports of these three products, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. - I abstained on autonomous trade preferences for the Republic of Moldova because of wider implications for relations with Russia. On the one hand, this motion involves the inclusion of small quantities of fruits and vegetables which can be easily absorbed in the EU and provides an opportunity to prevent instability in a country which neighbours EU Member States. On the other hand, there is a serious need to consider farmers who are already being hurt by the diplomatic failures between the EU and Russia. We should be reminded by this threat of instability of the real and pressing need for the Commission and Council to act in a more strategic way to effect and deal with this diplomatic crisis.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. — For Moldova, the EU introduced so-called autonomous trade preferences for the first time in 2008, removing all remaining duties on industrial products from Moldova and improving access to the EU market for Moldovan agricultural products. In recent years, the EU and Moldova have further strengthened their political and economic relations, in particular through the conclusion of an association agreement. Unfortunately, in response to this increased cooperation, Russia imposed a ban on imports of agricultural products from Moldova, significantly weakening Moldova's economy. I therefore welcome all the more the fact that, as a gesture of solidarity, the EU has added three new duty-free tariff quotas for fresh apples, fresh table grapes and fresh plums in addition to the existing tariff quotas. This will bring benefits and immediate support to the Moldovan economy, while the impact on the EU market will be manageable.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — I have concerns that this may prove to be counterproductive; action in solidarity with Moldova may serve to exacerbate the current international situation with Russia.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to allow duty-free fruit from Moldova into the European Union. The proposal seeks to temporarily exempt from EU duties a certain amount of fresh apples, grapes and plums coming from Moldova. Under the new proposal, Moldova could export 40,000 tonnes of carbon duty-free to the EU. i.e. fresh apples, 10 000. i.e. fresh grapes and 10 000 tonnes of fresh grapes. i.e. fresh plums. This concession would complement the current EU-Moldova free trade agreement. This measure is intended to alleviate the impact of moldova's ban on imports of its fruit into Russia, which is why I support the proposal.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. To the extent that these trade preferences seem to me to be primarily driven by geopolitical considerations contrary to our economic interests, I am opposed to them.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: in writing. — In view of the Free Trade Treaty with Moldova and in view of the Russian embargo on Moldovan agricultural products, unilateral concessions were granted to moldovan agricultural products on three new tariff lines: apples for 40,000 tonnes, grapes per 10,000 tonnes and plums per 10,000 tonnes for 2015. I am not opposed to the measures taken in this particular case, understanding very well that they are part of a provisional regime given to Moldova to help it. However, I cannot help noticing that these are facilities that have an impact on our producers and on the tax revenues of the Member States and the Union, which we grant unilaterally without obtaining anything in return, but above all without them being accompanied by an appropriate impact study by the Commission or the Member States. I would also like to point out that those who pay for these unilateral concessions are always our farmers, who are already tested by the crisis and brought to their knees by the recent Russian embargo. I have therefore chosen to abstain.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour as an act of solidarity. In recent years, the EU and Moldova have strengthened their relations with an Association Agreement that has been in place since 1 September 2014. As a result of this improved relations, Russia, for political reasons, has decided to ban the importation of products from Moldova, affecting more than 250,000 people from rural areas in small and medium-sized enterprises in the horticultural sector. The Moldovan authorities have asked for help and Parliament has decided to amend the Regulation by introducing three new free tariff quotas for apples, fresh plums and table grapes, hoping that these decisions can improve the Moldovan economy.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. Last June, the European Union and the Republic of Moldova signed an association agreement, including a trade component and, in particular, a free trade area. At a time when the EU and Russia are under geopolitical tensions, this agreement does nothing to help. Worse, it must enable Moldova to avoid russian repercussions by opening up our European market to Moldovan agricultural products, thus further exacerbating the difficulties faced by European producers, particularly French producers, who are already subject to unfair competition from many other countries. The Commission is calling here for changes to the Regulation on Autonomous Trade Preferences to introduce three new zero-duty tariff quotas for fresh apples (40,000 tonnes), table grapes and plums (10,000 tonnes each). In addition to this regulation, it is now clear that the EU is slowly preparing for Moldova's likely accession to the EU and I have therefore voted against the introduction of trade preferences for certain fruits from Moldova.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted against this measure which, at a very special historical moment such as the one we are going through, confirms Europe's desire to continue to ingest areas such as Moldova which are traditionally under Russian influence, in order to further destabilize the political climate.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. — (SV) I have voted in favour of the report. This is because I voted in favour of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement on 13 November this year. However, as then, I would like to stress that the people of Moldova should have had the decisive decision on this important issue. The best form of a populardecision on crucial issues would have been a referendum, then the economic and social consequences of the agreement could also have been discussed in depth, as well as the consequences for relations with Russia.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — In view of the intensification of the EU's political and economic relations with Moldova, which were part of the Association Agreement signed last June 2014, and which also includes a wide-ranging and deep free trade area, Russia has responded with the ban on imports of agricultural products from Moldova, which has been in place since 21 July 2014. Russia's pressure on Moldova materializes in a significant loss of its economic recovery capacity and slowing its reform process.  In order to support Moldova's current reform process with a view to political partnership and greater economic integration with the EU, I voted to temporarily increase the liberalisation of trade access for certain Moldovan products to the EU — namely apples, plums, and table grapes — and thus reduce the economic impact of the Russian ban. Imports of these three types of fruit from Moldova accounted for 0.01% of total EU imports in 2013, so the EU market will have no problem easily absorbing this increase in imports.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted on this report because it supports Parliament's amendment to the Autonomous Trade Preferences Agreement with Moldova. Political and economic ties between the EU and Moldova have intensified in recent years, in particular through the conclusion of an association agreement which creates a comprehensive and comprehensive free trade area in addition to the Autonomous Trade Preferences Agreement. As economic and political relations between the EU and Moldova strengthen, Russia has reportedly imposed a ban on imports of Moldovan agricultural products. This ban is seriously damaging to moldova's economy. In these difficult circumstances, the Moldovan authorities have asked the EU to reduce the negative economic impact of the Russian ban, in particular with regard to moldovan fruit producers' products. In the interests of solidarity, the Commission has therefore proposed to amend the Autonomous Trade Preferences Agreement and to set three additional duty-free tariff quotas for fresh apples, fresh table grapes and fresh plums.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. — I abstained from voting on autonomous trade preferences for the Republic of Moldova because of wider implications for relations with Russia. On the one hand, this motion involves the inclusion of small quantities of fruits and vegetables which can be easily absorbed in the EU and provides an opportunity to prevent instability in a country which neighbours EU Member States. On the other hand, there is a serious need to consider farmers who are already being hurt by the diplomatic failures between the EU and Russia. We should be reminded by this threat of instability of the real and pressing need for the Commission and Council to act in a more strategic way to effect and deal with this diplomatic crisis.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because I think that autonomous economic preferences are good in order to develop the relations between the EU and the Republic of Moldova.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — On 27 June 2014, the European Union and the Republic of Moldova signed an association agreement, including the creation of a free trade area and the implementation of autonomous trade preferences. This policy of economic integration aims in particular to prepare Moldova's accession to the European Union and is not devoid of geopolitical ulterior motives against Russia, Moldova's main economic partner. The Commission has therefore proposed amending the Regulation on Autonomous Trade Preferences to introduce three new zero-duty tariff quotas for fresh apples (40,000 tonnes), table grapes and plums (10,000 tonnes each). These quotas will compete directly with French and European productions, which are already struggling to find markets since Russia issued sanctions against EU agricultural products. That is why I voted against the draft resolution approving the Commission's proposal.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted against because the measure damages the Italian economy and is instrumental to an anti-Russian policy which I do not agree with and which I consider to be harmful to Europe.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. — The S&D Group is in favour of providing economic support to Moldova in order to strengthen its political will in the current reform process and its European trajectory.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — In recent years, the EU and Moldova have intensified their political and economic relations, in particular through the conclusion of an Association Agreement. Due to the intensification of economic and political relations between the EU and Moldova, Russia has imposed a politically motivated ban on imports of Moldovan agricultural products. Moldova's economy is suffering significant negative effects as a result of this ban, in particular the key horticultural sector, which provides employment for some 250,000 people (around 10% of the working population). Eu support is therefore needed to limit the economic impact of the Russian ban by, in particular, granting autonomous trade preferences for the Republic of Moldova and in particular for its horticultural sector. The amendment of the regulation will have a very limited financial impact on the EU market in relation to the benefits that this exemption can bring to Moldova's financial recovery and support for moldova's agricultural reform process, which is trying to move ever closer to European standards.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. — I abstained from voting on autonomous trade preferences for the Republic of Moldova because of wider implications for relations with Russia. On the one hand, this motion involves the inclusion of small quantities of fruits and vegetables which can be easily absorbed in the EU and provides an opportunity to prevent instability in a country which neighbours EU Member States. On the other hand, there is a serious need to consider farmers who are already being hurt by the diplomatic failures which have resulted in the Russian ban. We should be reminded by this threat of instability of the real and pressing need for the Commission and Council to act in a more strategic way to effect and deal with this diplomatic crisis.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — (IT) These measures have a very slight impact on the European economy and unfortunately affect Italian farmers, we abstain because it makes more sense to apply the DCFTA instead of lowering duties selectively.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text because, since 2005, following the Neighbourhood Policy Action Plan, Moldova has shown that it is fulfilling its commitments by reforming its customs legislation and transferring it satisfactorily into its administrative practice. In addition, as also claimed by the European Commission, total imports from Moldova to the EU accounted for 0.1% of total imports into the Union. While around 90% of total imports from the Republic of Moldova are duty-free, imports accounted for less than 0.01% of total imports of these products into the EU from around the world. The corresponding loss of tariff revenue should have a limited impact on the EU's own resources.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) My recent mission to Moldova was very informative because it allowed me to learn a great deal about this country, which is only a three-hour flight from Milan. I have seen very closely how much this country counts on agriculture for a living and how potentially damaging the import blockade that Russia has imposed is. Given that these are absolutely non-significant quantities for the EU, I voted in favour of the temporary total opening up of its fruit and vegetables.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. — I welcome Moldova’s European option, recently reconfirmed by the election won by the pro-European forces, and I encourage the continuation of all necessary reform processes that would bring the country closer to the EU.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the proposal to amend the PCA Regulation, particularly in relation to the introduction of the three new customs extensions relating to imports of products such as apples, pears and grapes. This amendment is entirely in line with what was agreed in the agreement signed on 27 June and with the previous actions introduced by the 2008 PCA Regulation, which gave rise to the creation of a global free trade area and the improvement of political and economic relations between the EU and Moldova. I hope that the economic and trade reforms introduced under the European Neighbourhood Policy will intensify trade and also create regulatory rapprochement with the EU in areas of common interest with a view to progressive economic integration into the internal market.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — In recent years, the EU and Moldova have intensified their political and economic relations, notably through the conclusion of an Association Agreement. For this reason, a politically motivated import ban was imposed by Russia on agricultural products from Moldova. The ban is hurting Moldova’s economy in a significant way. These trade preferences I voted in favour of support reducing the economic impact of the Russian ban, in particular for the most important products of Moldovan fruit growers.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — The Autonomous Trade Preference System (ATP) was awarded to Moldova in January 2008 to December 2015. On 21 July 2014, as a result of the signing of the Moldova-EU Free Trade Agreement, Russia imposed sanctions on Moldovan agricultural products, which are damaging its economy, as agriculture in Moldova accounts for 40% of the economy. This sector employs 250,000 people. That is why the Commission proposes to extend the ATP Regulation to introduce three products: plums, apples and grapes. Considering that the EU can easily absorb imports of these three products, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. — The Republic of Moldova is experiencing severe difficulties due to politically motivated import bans against its agricultural products imposed by the Russian Federation, a traditional market, in response to the intensification of relations with the EU. Such restrictions threaten both economic recovery and the reform process undertaken hitherto with commitment, determination and ambition. The agricultural sector represents around 40% of the economy. The horticultural sector provides employment to some 250 000, that is 10% of the active population.  Acknowledging outstanding reform progress as well as the need for an ambitious agenda for political association and economic integration, the EU and Moldova signed an Association Agreement including a DCFTA. The country has advanced steadily on regulatory approximation leading to convergence with the Union’s laws and standards. The system of controls and certification has improved firmly. The reform of customs legislation was executed successfully and translated into administrative practice. The proposed preferences provide immediate social and economic relief and represent a support measure to the reform process and efforts to implement European standards while improving trade relations, creating new trade opportunities and ultimately benefiting consumers and producers with very limited financial impact on the EU and virtually no additional pressure on its existing market.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — This report aims at supporting Moldova and its citizens who are facing serious economic difficulties, particularly due to the import ban on Moldovan agricultural products, imposed by Russia in July 2014. This would provide immediate relief to the Moldovan economy while having a negligible impact on the EU market. Hence I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. — I welcome the vote on the proposal for a regulation on the introduction of autonomous trade preferences for the Republic of Moldova, which introduces three new duty-free tariff quotas for fresh apples, fresh table grapes and fresh plums, and I believe that this support measure favours Moldovan producers who grow these products on small and medium family farms and who have been most affected in the last period of the country's economic crisis.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. — Last November, the European Parliament voted in favour of the Association Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Moldova, laying the foundations for the creation of an in-depth free trade area (DCFTA). Following the intensification of political and trade relations with the EU, the Republic of Moldova has suffered significant trade restrictions from Moscow. I therefore voted in favour of the temporary extension of the EU's trade preferences scheme, which aims to limit the consequences of the political decisions taken by Russia towards the Republic of Moldova. The granting of these preferences will also have a positive impact on the republic of Moldova's internal reform and economic development process and its approach to the EU.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. In the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy and the Eastern Partnership and the Association Agreement, it is proposed to amend the regulation introducing autonomous trade preferences for the Republic of Moldova to include three new zero-duty tariff quotas for fresh apples, fresh table grapes and fresh plums. The introduction of a self-sustaining trade preference regime will have the advantage of both encouraging the ongoing reform movement in agriculture in Moldova and improving our trade relations without such liberalisation having an impact on the markets of the main fresh fruit producing countries directly affected by the Russian embargo.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. — The Republic of Moldova was granted PCAs (autonomous trade preferences) on certain products from January 2008 until 31 December 2015. Due to the intensification of economic and political relations in that country's last year with the EU, Russia imposed a ban on imports of Moldovan agricultural products on 21 July 2014. As a result of this ban, moldova's economy is suffering significant negative effects as agriculture accounts for about 40% of moldova's economy. With the aim of alleviating the situation and giving them support at this critical time, I voted in favour of amending the PCA Regulation, which will introduce three new duty-free tariff quotas for table grapes, apples and fresh plums. The proposed preferences will offer immediate benefits and relief to the Moldovan economy, while having a very limited impact on the EU market.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. In retaliation for Moldova's rapprochement with the European Union, Russia has put in place an embargo on imports of Moldovan products. It was therefore the responsibility of the European Union to make a gesture in solidarity with our eastern neighbour. The lifting of EU tariffs on Moldovan apples, grapes and plums will help to partly counter the negative effects of this embargo on Moldova's economy, where 10% of the population works in the agricultural sector. These three products will benefit from better market opportunities in Europe. This will not come at the expense of European farmers and horticulturists, since Moldovan production accounts for less than 1% of European production.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. — Increasing quotas for certain fruit with tariff preferences is not acceptable in a context of economic and agricultural crisis in France and Europe. I voted against this text, which reinforces the ultra-liberal and free-trade frenzy of the European Union, in defiance of French and European farmers. The Commission has also failed to verify compliance with the rules established in previous agreements, which nevertheless conditions the maintenance of these preferences.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. — We voted in favour as this agreement will not affect the rest of the European agricultural sector and will help the sector in Moldova, which employs 250 000 people (10% of the working population), who live mainly in rural areas and also work on small and medium-sized farms. These are certain quantities of apples, plums and grapes that will be exported mainly to Romania and which will therefore not have a negative impact on the European agricultural sector. Since the implementation of preferential trade access (ATP) that replaced the GSP+, products originating in Moldova have no tariffs, except for some from the agricultural sector.   But with the embargo imposed by Russia since 21 July 2014 on agricultural products, this sector has been highly damaged. Therefore, in order to alleviate the social impact caused by this embargo, this agreement is proposed, which will allow small and medium-sized farmers to maintain their jobs over the next year (this agreement would apply until December 2015, when preferential trade access expires).

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted against the report, as the granting of exemptions to the import of these products would be a blow to the Greek economy because of the relevance of the products produced.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The EU and Moldova have intensified their political and economic relations, notably by concluding an association agreement in which Moldova will further strengthen its access to the EU market, particularly by bringing relevant EU legislation and standards closer to it. This approach led to Russia's ban on the entry of Moldovan products into its territory. Agriculture accounts for 40% of the country's economy and moves 250,000 people. Seeking assistance and support at this critical time, the Moldovan authorities have turned to the EU to seek urgent help to reduce the economic impact of the ban imposed by Russia, in particular as regards the most important products for Moldovan fruit growers: apples, plums and table grapes which are now duty-free of 40,000 tonnes for fresh apples and 10,000 for fresh table grapes and fresh plums. As this is a question of social and institutional solidarity, I deserve my vote in favour.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — Autonomous trade preferences (PCA) were introduced by the EU in 2008. This concession was foreseen in the 2005 European Neighbourhood Policy Action Plan.  The PCA Regulation abolished all commercial rights for Moldovan industrial products and granted free access to moldovan agricultural products on the EU market, with the exception of some meat, dairy products, maize, barley and sugar.  The signing of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement includes the creation of a comprehensive and in-depth free trade area (FTAA). The European Commission states that in order to support the efforts of the Republic of Moldova, in line with the objectives set out in the European Neighbourhood Policy, the Eastern Partnership and the Association Agreement, and to reduce the economic impact of russia's ban on agricultural products due to Moldova's political rapprochement with the EU, it proposes to amend the PCA Regulation by introducing three new duty-free tariff quotas for apples , table grapes and plums. We are in favour of a policy of cooperation and solidarity with all the countries and peoples of the world. Of course also with Moldova. But this is not the aim of free trade, the EU's Neighbourhood Policy, or the vision that frames this report.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing — After Moldova was granted autonomous trade preferences by the European Union in January 2008, and after political and economic relations between the European Union and Moldova have intensified significantly in recent years, an association agreement has also been concluded. The agreement in question was signed on 27 June 2014 and has been implemented since 1 September 2014, but it is precisely in view of the intensification of economic and political relations that a politically motivated ban on imports of agricultural products from Moldova has been imposed by the Russian Federation, with agriculture accounting for 40% of the Moldovan economy. The Moldovan authorities have contacted the European Union with confidence in assistance and support in this difficult situation. It is our duty to mitigate the economic consequences of the ban on the import of goods of the Russian Federation.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — (IT) We are opposed to continuous trade openings, particularly in the agricultural sector, in the EU and with third countries. That is why I shall be voting against the agreement.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — I am voting against the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. In view of the relevance of the products produced, it is therefore appropriate to grant exemptions to the import of these products.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. — Russia imposed an import ban on Moldova and the EU as a show of ‘solidarity’ wants to increase trade preferences in order to help out Moldova. This would only further inflame Russia and is clearly intended to butter up Moldova for EU membership.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - We voted in favour as this agreement will not affect the rest of the European agricultural sector and will help the sector in Moldova, which employs 250 000 people (10% of the working population), who live mainly in rural areas and also work on small and medium-sized farms. These are certain quantities of apples, plums and grapes that will be exported mainly to Romania and which will therefore not have a negative impact on the European agricultural sector. Since the implementation of preferential trade access (ATP) that replaced the GSP+, products originating in Moldova have no tariffs, except for some from the agricultural sector. But with the embargo imposed by Russia since 21 July 2014 on agricultural products, this sector has been highly damaged. Therefore, in order to alleviate the social impact caused by this embargo, this agreement is proposed, which will allow small and medium-sized farmers to maintain their jobs over the next year (this agreement would apply until December 2015, when preferential trade access expires).

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal to introduce autonomous trade preferences for the Republic of Moldova. Agriculture represents around 40% of the Moldovan economy and it is now highly affected by the politically motivated import ban imposed by Russia. I see this as an act of solidarity and a step forwards the creation of a ‘Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area’.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Written. — The Association Agreement concluded by the EU and the Republic of Moldova in November 2014 has increased tensions in the region. Russia has declared an import freeze on products from Moldova in response. By introducing autonomous trade preferences for the Republic of Moldova, Europe wants to limit the impact on the agricultural sector.  In my view, however, this is not an aid aid but a rash retaliatory action against Russia. The intensification of trade relations with Moldova - and thus the increase in European influence on the region - has major geopolitical consequences. This proposal has been made carelessly and hastily and will further exacerbate the conflict between the European Union and Russia. International security, human rights and democracy are at all times more important than short-sighted trade policy.  That is why I voted in November against the Association Agreement and today against the introduction of autonomous trade preferences for the Republic of Moldova.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. — Ongoing Russian sanctions against Moldova are placing great strains on that country’s economy.  The EU is right to seek to support Moldova and I accordingly voted in favour of this report.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We voted in favour as this agreement will not affect the rest of the European agricultural sector and will help the sector in Moldova, which employs 250 000 people (10% of the working population), who live mainly in rural areas and also work on small and medium-sized farms. These are certain quantities of apples, plums and grapes that will be exported mainly to Romania and which will therefore not have a negative impact on the European agricultural sector. Since the implementation of preferential trade access (ATP) that replaced the GSP+, products originating in Moldova have no tariffs, except for some from the agricultural sector. But with the embargo imposed by Russia since 21 July 2014 on agricultural products, this sector has been highly damaged. Therefore, in order to alleviate the social impact caused by this embargo, this agreement is proposed, which will allow small and medium-sized farmers to maintain their jobs over the next year (this agreement would apply until December 2015, when preferential trade access expires).

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the introduction of autonomous preferences for the Republic of Moldova, as this process will improve market relations between the European Union and the Republic of Moldova. The ban on the importation of agricultural products such as apples, plums and table grapes into Russia has had a very bad impact on the economy of the Republic of Moldova, so it has demanded the introduction of an autonomous trade privilege with the EU. Given that the Republic of Moldova is trying to move closer to European rising standards in agriculture and trade, I believe that such a decision by the European Commission on autonomous trade privilege for the most important export products of the Republic of Moldova can bring a lot of advantages for the financial recovery and functioning of the market in said country, and for bringing the EU closer to standards.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of my colleague Sorin Moisa's report on autonomous trade preferences for Moldova. Following the EU-Moldova Association Agreement adopted last June, Russia applied economic sanctions against Moldova's agricultural sector. In view of these difficulties, the report proposes to temporarily increase market access for Moldovan agricultural products. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I supported the trade measures as they will provide economic relief for the Republic of Moldova, which is affected by the Russian ban on its agricultural products. It also gives a clear sign of solidarity with the people of Moldova and will reinforce its reform process.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Sorin Moisa because I believe it is right that the European Union should support the process of reforming the country's agricultural system. Indeed, the introduction of new tariff quotas providing for an exemption of duties for fresh apples, fresh table grapes and fresh plums is a clear sign of support for the Republic of Moldova, which is experiencing a particularly difficult economic and social condition.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — Tariff preferences were granted to Moldova under the European Neighbourhood Policy in 2008. And last June 2014, the EU and Moldova signed an Association Agreement, which includes a wide and deep free trade area, from which Moldova has adopted an ambitious political agenda for political partnership and greater economic integration with the EU. Unfortunately, in the face of the intensification of the EU's political and economic relations with Moldova, Russia has responded with the ban on imports of agricultural products from Moldova. The S&D Group is in favour of providing economic support to Moldova with the extension of these agreements in order to strengthen its political will in the current reform process and its European trajectory.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — The Autonomous Trade Preference System (ATP) was awarded to Moldova in January 2008 to December 2015. On 21 July 2014, as a result of the signing of the Moldova-EU Free Trade Agreement, Russia imposed sanctions on Moldovan agricultural products, which are damaging its economy, as agriculture in Moldova accounts for 40% of the economy. This sector employs 250,000 people. That is why the Commission proposes to extend the ATP Regulation to introduce three products: plums, apples and grapes. Considering that the EU can easily absorb imports of these three products, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. — Autonomous trade preferences for the Republic of Moldova were originally introduced by the EU by Regulation (EC) No 55/2008 (PCA Regulation) for a period ending on 31 December 2015.  In recent years, the EU and Moldova have intensified their relations by concluded an Association Agreement, which will lead to the creation of a broad and deep free trade area (ZLCAP) between the two sides. As a result, on 21 July 2014 Russia imposed a ban on the importation of Moldovan agricultural products, which is significantly affecting its economy. They have therefore turned to the EU, requesting urgent support to reduce this impact, in particular for three products: apples, plums and table grapes.  The Commission proposed to amend the PCA Regulation by introducing three new duty-free tariff quotas for these products under the PCA Regulation, in addition to the quotas proposed under ZLCAP. Such proposed preferences would provide immediate benefits and relief to the Moldovan economy, while would have a very limited impact on the EU market.  For these reasons, I vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of extending trade preferences, as I am in any case opposed to the EU building up barriers to trade with much poorer countries.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. — I voted on this report on the Commission's proposal for the introduction of autonomous trade preferences for the Republic of Moldova for the three product categories: apples, grapes and plums.  We must take into account the importance of this measure for a state that is in a difficult period of transition from communism to democracy. The share of the agricultural sector in GDP in the Republic of Moldova is about 36%, and the employment of the working population in this sector is very high, with an impact on labour migration. For the Member States, this measure has little impact: total imports from the Republic of Moldova to the European Union in 2013 accounted for 0.1% of total imports into the EU, and imports of fresh apples and plums and fresh table grapes accounted for less than 0.01% of total EU imports of these products. As we know, the Republic of Moldova is the most advanced on the road to the European family and has made the most efforts. We must also show through concrete measures the support we are declaring at political level for the European option of Chisinau after the legislative elections on 30 November and help the Republic of Moldova to cope with the pressures of the Russian Federation.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — I supported this report because the proposed changes aim to improve trade with the Republic of Moldova and thereby contribute to the development of the Moldovan economy, which is currently suffering as a result of bans imposed by Russia. The aim of the proposal is to amend the regulation by introducing three new duty-free tariff rates for fresh apples 40 thousand tons, fresh grapes 10 thousand tons and fresh plums 10 thousand tons. According to Commission data, imports from Moldova to the EU in 2013 amounted to 0.1% of total Union imports. Thus, the loss of the introduction of duty-free tariff rates will not have a significant impact on the EU budget.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. - This is a continuation of Moldova's integration closer to the European Union. These preferences will help Moldova's business to enter the European market, and that is clearly a good thing. I voted in favour.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I voted against the Moisă report on the granting of autonomous trade preferences to the Republic of Moldova, since it includes arrangements for the preferential treatment of Moldovan products competing respectively with Greek agricultural products and therefore any application of this report would have harmful economic consequences for the Poor Greek farmers of the Memorandum.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. — I voted for the European Parliament's proposal to adopt trade preferences for the Republic of Moldova in order to bring this state closer to the EU. The EU has once again expressed its commitment to enhancing political and economic relations, beyond the recent association agreement and the creation of the free trade area. By adopting this decision, the Republic of Moldova will expand its access to the EU market, in particular by approaching relevant EU legislation and standards. At the same time, it is a clear signal to the Russian Federation that will have to review its unfair trade practices and embargo on imports of agricultural and food products from the Republic of Moldova. Specifically, at legislative level, the Commission proposed to amend the Autonomous Trade Preferences Regulation by introducing three new tariff quotas with duty-free duties for apples, grapes and plums. The preferences will provide immediate advantages and support to the Moldovan economy, with a very limited impact on the EU market.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on autonomous trade preferences for the Republic of Moldova. This is an extension granted to Moldova for an extended zero-duty quota system for certain agricultural products from Moldova itself. The proposed preferences will offer immediate benefits to the Moldovan economy. The agreement will, in fact, lead to the creation of a "global free trade area between the parties and Moldova will further strengthen its access to the EU market.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — The introduction of new tariff quotas, providing for an exemption of duties for fresh apples, fresh table grapes and fresh plums, is a clear sign of support for the Republic of Moldova, which is the victim of a difficult economic and social situation.  I voted in favour of this report, as I believe it is right for the EU to support the process of reforming the country's agricultural system.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — Since we have already spoken out against the association agreement with Moldova, it only makes sense to reject the proposal on autonomous trade preferences with the same. Any further step towards the alignment of Moldova with the European Union can have serious consequences for both sides and is therefore unsupported.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — In June 2014, the EU and Moldova signed an association agreement. Negotiated under the Eastern Partnership, the agreement is only intended to weaken Russia. It obviously contains a trade pillar that will lead to the creation of a "deep and comprehensive free trade area" with the European Union, as a result of this agreement, Russia has established an embargo on Moldovan agricultural products. As Moldova's usual economic partner, This has severely unbalanced Moldova's economy. The Commission therefore proposes to introduce three new zero-duty tariff quotas (CTs) for fresh apples (40,000 tonnes), fresh table grapes and fresh plums (10,000 tonnes for each type of product). It would be better to stop the provocations against Russia that are at the origin of these measures. I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — Autonomous trade preferences (PcA) for the Republic of Moldova (hereinafter Moldova) were initially introduced by the EU through Council Regulation (EC) No 55/2008 of 21 January 2008. The granting of these preferences was provided for in the 2005 European Neighbourhood Policy Action Plan, provided that Moldova substantially improved its system of controls and certification of goods. Moldova has fulfilled its commitments by reforming its customs legislation and transposition satisfactory in administrative practice by 2007. This report aims to help Moldova combat the Russian embargo on its agricultural products, specifically for the following products: fresh apples, fresh table grapes and fresh plums.  Tariff-free tariff quotas for the 3 products concerned are very low in volume compared to EU production (0.4 % for apples, 0.7 % for plums and 0.6 % for table grapes), thus not harming European producers. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — In light of the objectives set out in the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), the EU-Moldova ENP Action Plan and the Eastern Partnership I voted in favour of this proposal. The report also highlights that these trade preferences would support the reform process in agriculture in Moldova.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Moldovan apple, grape and plum producers have suffered serious losses as a result of Russia's Russian embargo on Moldovan agricultural products to put pressure on the country in the face of a rapprochement with the EU. The ban hurts Moldova's economy, with Russia being its second largest trading partner, and the horticulture sector employing nearly 10% of the labour force. In this emergency, we have agreed to temporarily open liberalized access to Moldovan fruit imports, in order to limit economic repercussions and address immediate needs by providing a viable market for Moldovan exports. Farmers are victims of the consequences of a political conflict that is beyond them. We owe it to ourselves to compensate for the harm suffered by our partners in neighbourhood policy. We have strengthened our political and economic ties with Moldova in recent years, and it is our duty to support it financially and through targeted actions so that it is not penalized.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of the report on autonomous trade preferences for the Republic of Moldova, which proposes to increase temporarily its fully liberalised market access for imports from Moldova to the EU of the most important products for Moldovan fruit growers: apples, plums and table grapes in order to reinforce its reform process and its European trajectory.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. — The importance of the regulation adopted today goes far beyond some quantities of apples, grapes and plums, serving as a demonstration of solidarity in the face of hardship: it is a breath of fresh air for a sector of vital importance for the Moldovan economy, affected by an irrational Russian ban, just like the EU itself. The Romanian market is amply capable of absorbing the new quantities allowed on the EU market, which are symbolic in relation to EU production, so no distortion whatsoever of the EU market is to be expected.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The European Union and the Republic of Moldova signed an association agreement on 27 June, including the creation of a free trade area and the application of autonomous trade preferences. Through this policy of economic cooperation, Moldova's very accession to the European Union is under way. This is a perfect fit into the European Union's geopolitical manoeuvres against Russia, which until recently was Moldova's main economic partner. The Commission has therefore proposed amending the Regulation on Autonomous Trade Preferences to introduce three new zero-duty tariff quotas for fresh apples (40,000 tonnes), plums and table grapes (10,000 tonnes for each). These volumes will undoubtedly be a source of direct competition for French and European producers, who are already badly battered by the Russian embargo. For all these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. — Autonomous trade preferences for the Republic of Moldova were originally introduced by the European Union as part of the 2005 European Neighbourhood Policy Action Plan and were subject to substantial improvements to the commodity control and certification system. Commitments were honoured through the reform of its customs legislation by 2007 and Moldova was therefore granted new autonomous trade preferences from January 2008 until 31 December 2015. Due to the intensification of economic and political relations with the European Union, on 21 July 2014 Russia imposed a politically motivated ban on the import of Moldovan agricultural products with serious consequences for its economy. Therefore, as an act of solidarity, we welcome the Commission's proposal to amend the PCA Regulation with the introduction of three new duty-free tariff quotas (fresh apples, table grapes and fresh plums) because, according to very detailed forecasts by the Commission itself, the corresponding loss of tariff revenue should have a limited impact on the European Union's own resources. It will not, therefore, put European producers in difficulty because the quantity of products we are talking about will be minimal and such that it will be totally absorbed by the Romanian market.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the report by Mr Beazley on behalf of the Committee on The Protection of human Rights, Research and Energy. Moisa concerning the extension granted to Moldova for a system of extended zero-duty quotas for certain agricultural products such as grapes, plums and apples, so that they can be absorbed by the Romanian market where there was a significant drop in production last year.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - The granting of trade preferences to Moldova is a stone in the mosaic of the separation of that country from its traditional Russian economic area, which we cannot be interested in in the current tensions in the region. I have therefore voted against the motion.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which endorses a more favourable regime in agricultural trade with Moldova, which has been heavily affected by the Russian embargo. These preferences bring several benefits and immediate assistance to the Moldovan economy, while having a very limited impact on the EU market.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the proposal establishing autonomous trade preferences for the Republic of Moldova because it supports moldova's reform processes, promotes trade relations and brings Moldova closer to the European Union step by step.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — The amendment of Council Regulation (EC) No 55/2008 introducing new duty-free tariff quotas for fresh apples, fresh table grapes and fresh plums is a support measure for the Republic of Moldova in its difficult social and financial context. Such a change could support the reform process of agriculture in the Republic of Moldova, which is seeking to move ever closer to European standards and could improve trade relations between the Eu ropean Union and the Republic of Moldova. For these reasons, I would vote in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. — On 27 June 2014, the European Union and the Republic of Moldova signed an association agreement, including the creation of a free trade area and the implementation of autonomous trade preferences. This policy of economic integration aims in particular to prepare Moldova's accession to the European Union and is not devoid of geopolitical ulterior motives against Russia, Moldova's main economic partner. The Commission has therefore proposed amending the Regulation on Autonomous Trade Preferences to introduce three new zero-duty tariff quotas for fresh apples (40,000 tonnes), table grapes and plums (10,000 tonnes each). These quotas will compete directly with French and European productions, which are already struggling to find markets since Russia issued sanctions against EU agricultural products. That is why I voted against the draft resolution approving the Commission's proposal.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — Given that Moldova has recently experienced difficulties in exporting fruit and vegetables and bearing in mind that as much as 40% of moldova's economy with 250 000 employees depends on this market, I believe that the EU must act to help Moldova adapt to difficult market conditions. The EU has an obligation to respond to the recently adopted pro-European and ambitious agenda of reforms on the political and economic agenda of integration with the Union.  Moldova, as a member of the European Neighbourhood Policy and the Eastern Partnership, needs help on its European path and the first step will be to help the Moldovan economy adapt to market conditions through the establishment of autonomous trade preferences with the introduction of three new quotas and the abolition of excise duties for imports of fresh apples, table grapes and fresh plums into the EU market. Establishing trade preferences would send a strong message to the Republic of Moldova, notably through maintaining the country's financial stability and in the upcoming reform process announced by the Moldovan government, in the context of the implementation of the Association Agreement.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — In the light of the increasingly intense political and economic relations between the EU and Moldova and the recent Association Agreement, with the creation of a comprehensive and in-depth free trade area (DCFTA), Moldova has increasingly strengthened its access to the EU market, noting that the 2008 PCAs (autonomous trade preferences) are additional and complementary to the commodity liberalisation regime in the DCFTA. I therefore support the proposal for a regulation introducing new duty-free tariff quotas for fresh apples, fresh table grapes and fresh plums (the main products of Moldovan fruit growers), because it will help the country at a difficult time in the social and financial environment. In addition, the proposed preferences will be of great help to the Moldovan economy but will have a very limited impact on the EU market

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Writing. — By approving this proposal, the EU is abandoning an instrument to initiate reforms in Moldova in the future. Having recently established a roadmap for the implementation of democratic and rule of law standards with the Association Agreement, the means of exerting pressure contained therein are now to be weakened. On the pretext of defending precisely these standards, the incentives for doing so are being discarded. It is an expression of naivety that trade facilitation for Moldova is now being created unilaterally and without consideration in the belief in the adoption of democracy and the rule of law. Since I am convinced that in this deeply corrupt state, where trafficking in human beings is the order of the day, it is only through political and economic pressure that political and economic pressure can be used to take action against it, I cannot vote in favour of the draft vote, because it deprives us of that very means of exerting pressure.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. After Moldova chose to move closer to the European Union, Russia, its largest trading partner, decided to suspend fruit imports. Nevertheless, this represents the majority of the country's economy. I am therefore in favour of a measure allowing the liberalisation of certain products, as the European market can easily absorb such imports and the instability of the region is of increasing concern.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — Since 21 July 2014, the Republic of Moldova has been suffering from a Russian embargo, implemented as a result of the intensification of economic and political relations between Moldova and the European Union (EU). Given that the agricultural sector accounts for 40 % of Moldova's economy, employing 250 000 people, and that the total imports from Moldova into the EU represented 0.1 % of total EU imports in 2013; whereas imports of fresh apples, fresh plums and fresh grapes would constitute a total of 0.01 % of total EU imports, the corresponding loss of tariff revenue would have a severe impact on the EU budget if those three products are tariff-free tariff quotas; and finally, given that the autonomous trade preference sregime will expire at the end of 2015, with the end of the tariff quotas applicable and proposed in this resolution, I voted in favour of market liberalisation between the EU and Moldova, as drawn by the Commission.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: in writing. — As rapporteur for the opinion, appointed in the AGRI Commission, I am fully satisfied with the outcome of today's vote - 551 votes in favour, 67 against and 23 abstentions - for approving the proposal for a regulation on autonomous trade preferences for the Republic of Moldova. The approval of new tariff quotas for apples, plums and grapes for Moldova represents not only a concrete measure on the part of the European Union in support ing rendition of Moldovan farmers in the context of the Russian embargo, a politically motivated embargo with very negative effects on Moldovan products, but also a strong political support in the context of the EU-Republic of Moldova partnership. I believe and hope that this support measure will compensate for a good part of the losses of Moldovan agricultural producers.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — In view of the intensification of the EU's political and economic relations with Moldova, which were part of the Association Agreement signed last June 2014, and which also includes a wide-ranging and deep free trade area, Russia has responded with the ban on imports of agricultural products from Moldova, which has been in place since 21 July 2014. Russia's pressure on Moldova materializes in a significant loss of its economic recovery capacity and slowing its reform process. In order to support Moldova's current reform process with a view to political partnership and greater economic integration with the EU, I voted to temporarily increase the liberalisation of trade access for certain Moldovan products to the EU, namely apples, plums, and table grapes, and thus reduce the economic impact of the Russian ban. Imports of these three types of fruit from Moldova accounted for 0.01% of total EU imports in 2013, so the EU market will have no problem easily absorbing this increase in imports.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - We voted in favour as this agreement will not affect the rest of the European agricultural sector and will help the sector in Moldova, which employs 250 000 people (10% of the working population), who live mainly in rural areas and also work on small and medium-sized farms. These are certain quantities of apples, plums and grapes that will be exported mainly to Romania and which will therefore not have a negative impact on the European agricultural sector. Since the implementation of preferential trade access (ATP) that replaced the GSP+, products originating in Moldova have no tariffs, except for some from the agricultural sector. But with the embargo imposed by Russia since 21 July 2014 on agricultural products, this sector has been highly damaged. Therefore, in order to alleviate the social impact caused by this embargo, this agreement is proposed, which will allow small and medium-sized farmers to maintain their jobs over the next year (this agreement would apply until December 2015, when preferential trade access expires).

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — The agricultural sector accounts for about 40% of Moldova's economy and the horticultural sector is an important part of it, employing some 250,000 people who live mainly in rural areas and cultivate relatively small family plots. However, following the signing of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement on 27 June 2014, Russia banned imports of fruit from that country. Officially for reasons... Phytosanitary. As part of the free trade agreement with Moldova, the European Union has committed to liberalising market access for a number of fresh fruits and vegetables within certain volumes. Taking into account the serious difficulties that Moldova is facing at this time, I have therefore supported the proposal to temporarily increase its access to the European market for imports. The proposed preferences would bring immediate benefits and relief to the Moldovan economy, while having a very limited impact on the EU market.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. — I would like to call on colleagues to support the proposed amendment to Regulation (EC) No 55/2008. Moldova is a country heavily dependent on agricultural production and, by helping its agricultural production to enter the EU, we will also help to strengthen its economy. However, I do not like the fact that autonomous trade preferences are offered for apples. I would like to remind you that apple growers in many Member States have been severely affected by the Russian embargo. By legalating this relief, we will give a strong blow to our apple growers.  I therefore believe that it is not appropriate at this time to introduce such an exemption for apples. The other two sectors mentioned in the Regulation, plums and grapes, have not experienced such a serious impact of sanctions.  When will the Commission, at least in theory, show real work and results in finding new markets for agricultural producers affected by the Russian embargo, such as European apple growers, to defend the common European interest? When we start to look for these new markets, we will be able to talk even about significantly higher tax-free import quotas for products from other agricultural sectors in Moldova.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report granting autonomous trade preferences to the Republic of Moldova on the ground that moldova has substantially improved the system of control and certification of goods, as provided for in the action plan, signed under the 2005 European Neighbourhood Policy, and for also finding that Moldova has fulfilled its commitments by implementing the reform of customs legislation and its satisfactory transposition by 2007. This proposed amendment to Council Regulation (EC) No 55/2008 is complementary to the association agreement signed between the parties on 27 June 2014, which will lead to the creation of a Comprehensive and Deep Free Trade Area, where Moldova will have the opportunity to strengthen access to the European market, particularly by bringing community legislation and standards closer to it. I would also like to point out the solidarity principle inherent in this proposal, which stems from the politically motivated import ban which Russia has applied since 21 July 2014 to Moldova's agricultural products.  To this end, this allocation of tariff-free tariff quotas to three types of fruit products will result in tangible benefits and immediate assistance to the country's economy by the end of 2015, with a limited impact on the Union market.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote against because, in my opinion, it is interference in an area of traditional Russian commercial and political influence, with the aim of further destabilising the region.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. — I voted in favour as this agreement will not affect the rest of the European agricultural sector and will help the sector in Moldova. The agricultural sector in Moldova employs 250,000 people (10% of the working population) who live mainly in rural areas, also working on small and medium-sized farms. Tariff preferences will affect apples, plums and grapes, which will be exported mainly to Romania and therefore will not have a negative impact on the rest of the European sector. Since the application of preferential trade access, which replaced the GSP+, products originating in Moldova have no tariffs, except for certain products from the agricultural sector.  With the embargo imposed by Russia since 21 July 2014 on agricultural products, this sector has been highly damaged. Therefore, in order to alleviate the social impact caused by this embargo, this agreement is proposed, which will allow small and medium-sized farmers to maintain their jobs over the next year (this agreement would apply until December 2015, when preferential trade access expires).

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - The Autonomous Trade Preference System (ATP) was awarded to Moldova in January 2008 until December 2015. On 21 July 2014, as a result of the signing of the Moldova-EU Free Trade Agreement, Russia imposed sanctions on Moldovan agricultural products, which are damaging its economy, as agriculture in Moldova accounts for 40% of the economy. This sector employs 250,000 people. With this argument, the Commission proposes to extend the ATP Regulation to introduce three products: plums, apples and grapes. I voted against this report because it will harm the peasant on both sides; is an agreement to put cheap raw materials to agro-transporters.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — I voted in support of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 55/2008 introducing autonomous trade preferences for the Republic of Moldova. Moldova and its citizens are facing serious economic difficulties, particularly due to the import ban on Moldovan agricultural products, imposed by Russia in July 2014. This proposal by the Commission would grant Moldova additional duty-free tariff quotas for fresh apples, grapes and plums under the existing ATP regime which is due to expire in December 2015. This would provide immediate relief to the Moldovan economy while having a negligible impact on the EU market.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution because it is important for the EU to show a degree of solidarity and to appreciate the Republic of Moldova's efforts to join a common Europe. Russia's sanctions adopted and the ban on imports of agricultural crops from Moldova are of significant concern to moldova's entire economy, as agricultural production accounts for up to 40% of its economy. The introduction of three new duty-free tariff quotas for fresh apples, fresh table grapes and fresh plums will not jeopardise the EU budget and, moreover, will cover the shortfall in the cultivation of these agricultural products in some EU Member States. In the current situation in Ukraine, but also in other former Soviet states that are seeking to join the EU and are threatened with further Russian sanctions, we must clearly show our support for these states and also adopt operationally such resolutions, which will also have retroactive effect.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing — I welcome the next step that will bring Moldova closer to the European Union. I believe that it deserves the chance to participate in a unique European project and will be another success story of European integration.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
