text: Written. — I consider it important, as an act of solidarity towards a country on the road to Membership of the European Family, to support the Commission's proposal to introduce three new products into the free customs regime of imports in the EU within atm regulation. These are fresh apples (40,000 tonnes), fresh table grapes and fresh plums (10,000 tonnes for each item). These measures will have a direct and significant impact on Moldova's economy with a very limited impact on the European market.  It is important to point out that all three products will mostly be imported into the Romanian market, which according to the World Association for the Production of Apples and Plums recorded a five-year decline in production, and in the last year alone there was a 22% drop in production. Furthermore, I would point out that supporting this report leads to the support of the ongoing agricultural reform in Moldova, which is making efforts to reach European standards.  These changes will have a significant societal impact, especially for Moldovan SMEs and improve and improve EU-Moldova trade relations.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — Back in 2008, the European Union introduced autonomous trade preferences for the Republic of Moldova, and since Moldova has met the conditional reforms set out in customs legislation, autonomous trade preferences have been granted by the EU. All products originating in Moldova have been given free access to the EU market, except for certain agricultural products such as beef and pork, poultry, dairy products, maize, barge and sugar. I believe that this proposal will contribute to the system of control and certification of products arriving on the Union market and will ensure stability for the Moldovan economy, which is why I supported this proposal.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — The granting of exemptions to products produced in non-EU countries is an economic blow to EU Member States producing corresponding and related products and should not be implemented.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. — The Republic of Moldova has demonstrated its attachment to European values as well as democratic principles in recent times. The signing by the Republic of Moldova of the Association Agreement represents an opportunity for both the states and societies of the European Union and for the Republic of Moldova itself. However, the signing of the agreement entailed costs, in particular of an economic nature, for the small Eastern European State. Their repercussions can be severe. Russia's imposition of genuine economic sanctions against the Republic of Moldova has affected Moldovan society and economy.  In this context, I support the proposal for the full temporary liberalisation of imports from the Republic of Moldova for a number of agricultural products, especially since the European market can absorb these products. The stated objective of Russian policies is to change the course of moldova's foreign policy. The European Union cannot allow the process of integration and peaceful development of external relations on its borders to be influenced by the policy of force practiced in relation to the Republic of Moldova. I support the adoption of these important provisions for both EU foreign policy and the European future of the Republic of Moldova.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. " We voted in favour of the exchange agreement with Moldova. I did, however, allow myself to point out that it was strange to incorporate a chapter on fruit while we are going through a war with Russia, one of the direct consequences of which is the difficulty of fruit flow under embargo. However, it is highly likely that the additional volumes of these three products entering the European market will mostly be absorbed by the Romanian market, given the cultural and geographical proximity of the two countries, the similarities between their agricultural markets in terms of product packaging and packaging, and the current market situation.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — The PCA Regulation abolished all commercial rights for Moldovan industrial products and granted free access to moldovan agricultural products on the EU market, with the exception of some meat, dairy products, maize, barley and sugar.  The signing of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement includes the creation of a comprehensive and in-depth free trade area (FTAA). The European Commission states that in order to support the efforts of the Republic of Moldova, in line with the objectives set out in the European Neighbourhood Policy, the Eastern Partnership and the Association Agreement, and to reduce the economic impact of russia's ban on agricultural products due to Moldova's political rapprochement with the EU, it proposes to amend the PCA Regulation by introducing three new duty-free tariff quotas for apples , table grapes and plums. We are in favour of a policy of cooperation and solidarity with all the countries and peoples of the world, but this is not the objective of free trade, the EU's neighbourhood policy, or the vision that frames this report.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. - Due to my opposition to the Association Agreement due to unilateral and ill-considered long-term consequences, both from a foreign policy point of view with regard to relations with Russia and the conviction that no guarantees are currently required for such an agreement, but that the EU is taking even more financial risks, I have also rejected the proposal on autonomous trade preferences.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — In January 2008, through Regulation (EC) No 55/2008, autonomous trade preferences (PCA) were introduced by the EU by 31 December 2015. This concession was foreseen in the 2005 European Neighbourhood Policy Action Plan.  The PCA Regulation abolished all commercial rights for Moldovan industrial products and granted free access to moldovan agricultural products, with the exception of beef and pork, poultry, dairy products, maize, barley and sugar.  The signing of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement includes the creation of a comprehensive and in-depth free trade area (FTAA) which will be applied provisionally from 1 September 2014. We are in favour of a policy of cooperation and solidarity with all the countries and peoples of the world. Of course also with Moldova. But this is not the aim of free trade, the EU's neighbourhood policy, or the vision that frames this report.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — In this report we voted to extend the GSP+ for Ecuador from January 2015 on the condition that the EU-Ecuador Free Trade Agreement be signed by 31 December 2016. I cannot vote in favour of this report because, although I am not against prolonging the GSP+, I cannot accept that it will be ready for the signing of the Free Trade Agreement, since I am against it. That's why I abstained.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — I wished to abstain on this matter.  It concerns the application of tariffs concerning Ecuador.  I praise the rapporteur’s concern over too much Commission power. On the other hand, the demands made on Ecuador may be impractical.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to establish a tariff treatment for goods originating in Ecuador. In July 2014, negotiations with Ecuador on its accession to a trade agreement concluded by the EU and Colombia and Peru were concluded. Following these negotiations, the protocol on Ecuador's accession to the agreement was initialled. In order to avoid unnecessary disturbance of trade until the procedures for applying the Accession Protocol have been completed, this proposal maintains the level of the duty rates applicable to Ecuador at the date of initialisation of the Protocol.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. — Negotiations with Ecuador for its accession to the EU trade agreement between the EU and Colombia and Peru ended on 17 July 2014. Furthermore, on 1 January 2015, Ecuador is expected to lose its GSP status as a result of an amendment to the corresponding European regulation. In order to avoid unnecessary disruption of trade pending the implementation of this free trade agreement, on 1 October 2014, the Commission adopted a proposal to ensure that tariffs on the date of the signing of Ecuador's protocol for accession to the EU-Colombia and Peru free trade agreement will not increase and that no new tariffs will hit products from Ecuador. The Commission wants the regulation to apply from 1 January 2015 and has in particular wanted to apply a principle of reciprocity. I have approved the Commission's proposal.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: in writing. — Ecuador has decided to join the free trade area between the European Union, Colombia and Peru. The agreement will enter into force shortly, while for the time being Ecuador is part of a preferential SGP+ system. Since I firmly believe in the role of trade in promoting the development of the poorest countries, I agree with the need to approve an extension of the favour duties now granted to Ecuador so as not to lead to a disruption of trade. However, in addition to promoting the development of the poorest countries, we must also ensure that they comply with the Labour and Human Rights Conventions, and it is equally important that the treaties we sign can be temporarily suspended if they cause serious harm to our producers. The rapporteur had initially proposed, precisely for these purposes, a system of control by the European Parliament, giving him the possibility of suspending this provisional regime, but he unexpectedly abolished this fundamental passage in the final document.  That is why I have chosen to abstain.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. — Negotiations with Ecuador for accession to the EU-Colombia-Peru Trade Agreement were concluded on 17 July. The multilateral agreement will provide a new framework in Ecuador-EU relations. A provisional time has been established ensuring that customs duties will not be increased on the date defined in the Protocol to reduce the burden on EU importers of goods exported by Ecuador. In short, it takes some time to carry out all internal procedures for the EU and also for Ecuador before implementing the Protocol of Accession. That is why I voted in favour of this proposal on the tariff treatment of goods originating in Ecuador.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. Negotiations for Ecuador's accession to the EU-Colombia-Peru trade agreement have recently concluded. Pending the entry into force of the agreement, a proposal has been adopted to ensure that applied tariffs will not increase. However, after an investigation, it is interesting to note that Ecuador is interfering with trade in its internal market. For my country alone, France, the trade balance for 2013 with Ecuador is in deficit of more than 200 million euros. It would therefore be appropriate to immediately abolish any negotiations with Ecuador which do not respect the rules on tariff preferences, and I therefore voted against this agreement.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted against this measure which restores trade preferences in favour of Ecuador. There has been too much pressure from the Italian Presidency of the Council to achieve this vote without the adoption of amendments.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. — (SV) I have voted in favour of the report, which was to maintain the trade rules in force under gsp+, until the entry into force of the new FTA (Free Trade Agreements) between the EU and Ecuador. However, I would like to stress that I am very critical of the FTA that has concluded with Ecuador, as well as with Ecuador's neighbouring countries. In principle, Ecuador had no choice but to conclude its own agreement with the EU because it found it in an unfair situation in terms of trade compared to neighbouring countries. EU trade agreements do not create fair trade, and the effects of the agreements run counter to the EU's fundamental principles of aid and development, as well as, in many cases, environmental considerations.  My 'yes' vote should be seen in this critical context, and not as an endorsement of EU trade policy.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — Negotiations for Ecuador's accession to the EU-Colombia/Peru Trade Agreement concluded on 17 July 2014. However, the entry into force of the EU-Ecuador Agreement will not be effective until the end of 2015 or early 2016, after the authentication and ratification procedures of the text have been completed.  Bearing in mind that Ecuador will lose, as of January 1, 2015, its status as a beneficiary of the Generalized System of Preferences Plus (GSP+) which it has been enjoying to date, having been declared by the World Bank as a high middle income State, it is necessary to freeze the customs duties currently applied and ensure that no new duties are applied on products originating in Ecuador, thus avoiding unnecessary trade disruption until the completion of the procedures necessary for the implementation of the Protocol of Accession. I therefore voted, without amending, on the proposal for a Regulation submitted by the Commission for it to be implemented from 1 January 2015 until six months after the Protocol of Accession enters into force or until 31 December 2016, depending on what happens first.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it involves Parliament participating in the legislative procedure, together with the Adoption of a Regulation on the tariff treatment of goods originating in Ecuador. Negotiations with Ecuador on its accession to a trade agreement concluded between the EU and Colombia and Peru were concluded on 17 July 2014. The Ecuadorian Government took this decision after being under severe pressure, as some of the country's main exports were at a very competitive disadvantage compared to the same products from Colombia and Peru. In order to avoid unnecessary trade disruption prior to the provisional application of the EU-Ecuador Free Trade Agreement, as well as to ease the burden on EU importers importing goods exported by Ecuador, the Commission has adopted a proposal to ensure that the duties imposed on products originating in Ecuador on the date of accession of Ecuador to the Free Trade Agreement between The European Union and Colombia and Peru are not increased and that these products are not subject to any new duties. The aim is to apply this Regulation from 1 January 2015.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. "I voted against it. Indeed, the latter is a matter of free-trade logic that I can only condemn. The European Commission is proposing a draft regulation to ensure that trade preferences remain in Ecuador pending Ecuador's accession to the Free Trade Agreement (FTA). This text is reprehensible in its very principle, as well as in relation to its effects, in particular, for Overseas France.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because I think that we need to integrate Ecuador into the trade agreements we have with many South-American countries in order to create solid and fair economic relations.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — The European Union and Ecuador have just concluded negotiations on an already effective free trade accession agreement with Peru and Colombia. Pending the entry into force of this agreement, the Commission adopted on 1 October 2014 a proposal guaranteeing that the tariffs applied will not increase. It should be noted that France's exports have fallen by almost half in value compared to 2012, due to increasing barriers to ecuador's market access in current trade. As such, the trade balance for France is in deficit of 221 million euros for the year 2013. It is therefore inconsequenty to conduct trade liberalisation agreements when the guarantees of opening up the Ecuadorian market are not met. Once is not customary, France and the countries of the Union are the turkeys of the farce of unbridled globalization. That is why I voted against this agreement on the tariff treatment of goods originating in Ecuador.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted against, since the measure damages certain sectors of the Italian economy.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. — The Spanish Socialist Delegation has defended from the outset, within the S&D Group, the need to give a firm and responsible response to our political commitment to Ecuador and to our companies, above interinstitutional disputes, which could well be resolved in another context.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the tariff treatment of goods originating in Ecuador, which provides for the maintenance of the level of duty rates applicable to Ecuador and applied by Ecuador on the date of initialling of the Accession Protocol. It aims to extend the trade preferences granted to Ecuador under the GSP+ Regulation, which would otherwise expire on 1 January 2015, and is intended to constitute a transitional measure to prepare Ecuador and the EU for the entry into force of the EU-Ecuador Free Trade Agreement. The Multilateral Free Trade Agreement will provide a new legal framework for trade relations between the EU and Ecuador.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — (IT) It is not necessary for goods from Ecuador to be increased and further customs duties: this resolution fills a legislative vacuum which would affect local traders.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) With a view to the trade agreement with Ecuador, which will be negotiated from the second half of next year, I am pleased to have voted in favour of this proposal. In fact, the prerequisite is the country's exit from the Generalized System of Preferences due to the lack of a requirement: per capita income of less than $4,000 per year. It is precisely this that pleases me: the fact that, also thanks to European trade policy, a country is making progress in order to abandon its poverty. Congratulations to Ecuador!

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I am in favour of this regulation, which is intended to constitute a transitional measure to prepare the EU and Ecuador for the entry into force of the Multilateral Free Trade Agreement, which also includes Colombia and Peru. It also seems appropriate to me that the extension of current trade preferences should be conditional on Ecuador complying with certain conditions, such as compliance with the rules relating to the origin of products and refraining from the desire to impose new duties or restrictions on imports from the EU, also out of respect for European producers and investors.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — The Commission adopted this October a proposal ensuring that no new customs duties are applied on products originating in Ecuador, in order to ease the burden for EU importers of Ecuadorian export goods. This tariff treatment proposal introduces an element of reciprocity as well, because Ecuador would also be obliged to maintain its current level of duties for EU imports. The proposal seems to be advantageous and should Ecuador fail to meet the conditions laid down in the regulation proposal, the EU should have a possibility to object to a measure proposing to suspend the trade preferences. For this reason I voted in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — In this report we voted to extend the GSP+ for Ecuador from January 2015 on the condition that the EU-Ecuador Free Trade Agreement be signed by 31 December 2016. I cannot vote in favour of this report because, although I am not against prolonging the GSP+, I cannot accept that it will be ready for the signing of the Free Trade Agreement, since I am against it. That's why I abstained.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — This report deals with the accession of Ecuador to the Trade Agreement concluded between the EU and Colombia/Peru. In order to avoid unnecessary trade disruption until the provisional application of this Free Trade Agreement, the Commission adopted a proposal ensuring that customs duties applied on the date of initialling of the Protocol of Accession of Ecuador to the EU-Colombia/Peru Free Trade Agreement are not increased and that no new customs duties are applied on products originating in Ecuador. The proposed regulation is clearly intended to be a transitional measure preparing Ecuador and the EU for the entry into force of the EU-Ecuador Free Trade Agreement. This is why I voted in favour of this regulation.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. During the trade negotiations for Ecuador's entry into the trade agreement between the European Union (EU) on the one hand and Colombia and Peru on the other, Ecuador has made efforts which, in my view, merit these temporary provisions pending the approval of the EU-Ecuador trade agreement. These measures are aimed at maintaining current levels of tariffs on products imported from Ecuador. This transitional arrangement will allow the Ecuadorian economy to compete with other Importers in Latin America.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. — The text put to the vote is an additional piece in the unlimited free trade system that the European Union feeds. I voted against this report, which calls for aligning itself with the Commission's position.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. "We voted for it. This is not a free trade agreement, but a proposal for a Regulation extending Ecuador's export preferences to the EU under the GSP+, which is lost on 1 January 2015, until the future Free Trade Agreement enters into force. Despite being against the conditionality imposed by the European Commission on Ecuador in the articulation of the text (allows the suspension of tariff preferences if Ecuador adopts "measures" that have any effect on EU imports) and despite considering that the possible decisions that the Commission may take in this regard should be taken under the framework of delegated acts so that Parliament can make effective use of its control functions (both issues to which we tabled amendments, lying in the INTA Commission on the right and far right), we consider it important for the Ecuadorian people to extension these tariff preferences and their urgent implementation.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted against the report, as tariff exemptions to third countries (non-EU members) restrict exports from EU Member States, which exacerbates the economic downturn experienced by the countries of Europe.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - Negotiations with Ecuador with a view to its accession to the TRADE Agreement concluded between the EU and Colombia and Peru were concluded on 17 July 2014. On 1 October 2014, the European Commission adopted a proposal ensuring that customs duties applied on the date of the heading of the Ecuadorean Protocol of Access to the FREE TRADE AGREEMENT between the EU, Colombia and Peru are not increased and also ensures that no customs duties are applied to products originating in Ecuador. To that end, the proposal for a Regulation provides for the maintenance of the level of duties rates applicable to and by Ecuador on the date of the heading of the Protocol of Access. Transitional application by 31 December 2016 appears to be necessary to give the EU and Ecuador sufficient time to carry out all the internal procedures necessary for the implementation of the Protocol of Membership. Safeguard measures taken by the European Union and Ecuador shall remain, irtheisof the application of this Regulation. This proposal deserves my vote in favour.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — Ecuador should lose GSP+ status from 1 January 2015. This Regulation has the effect of extending the trade preferences granted to Ecuador under the GSP+ Regulation. However, this extension is subject to harsh conditions imposed by the EU on Ecuador. By accepting this agreement to extend The GSP+ status, Ecuador, among other constraints, will have to refrain from imposing new duties or restrictions on imports from the EU and continue negotiations with a view to signing and ratifying the Free Trade Agreement. If the Commission considers that Ecuador does not comply with any of the conditions, ecuador may suspend this tariff treatment. In the context of increasing pressure for the liberalisation of international trade, it is noted that the EU uses the end of the GSP+ as a form of blackmail for the acceptance of so-called Free Trade Agreements, through unacceptable diplomatic and economic pressure on several countries.  In order for the GSP+ to become an instrument for development aid, its extension and renegotiation would be required, together with other development support policies, so as effective solidarity, combating economic dependence and exploitation of peoples and their natural resources by EU economic groups.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing — European Union policies also include negotiations and trade agreements with third countries, and it is trade agreements that the European Union must be treated sensitively and politically correctly. It is precisely this situation that arose in relation to the trade agreement concluded between the European Union and Colombia/Peru and the subsequent accession of Ecuador to this trade agreement. Due to the possible unnecessary disruption of trade in the period up to the provisional application of this FTA, the European Commission presented a regulation that would apply from 1 January 2015 and end no later than 31 December 2016, giving us sufficient time to apply all internal procedures in both the European Union and Ecuador. The question remains the delegation of powers to the European Commission, but such agreements should be supported by the European Parliament in agreement with the Council of Ministers.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — I am voting against a measure which restores trade preferences for Ecuador.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — I am voting against the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the tariff treatment of goods originating in Ecuador, as tariff exemptions to third countries (non-EU members) restrict exports from EU Member States, which exacerbates the economic downturn experienced by the countries of Europe.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - We voted for it. This is not a free trade agreement, but a proposal for a Regulation extending Ecuador's export preferences to the EU under the GSP+, which is lost on 1 January 2015, until the future Free Trade Agreement enters into force. Despite being against the conditionality imposed by the European Commission on Ecuador in the articulation of the text (allows the suspension of tariff preferences if Ecuador adopts "measures" that have any effect on EU imports) and despite considering that the possible decisions that the Commission may take in this regard should be taken under the framework of delegated acts so that Parliament can make effective use of its control functions (both issues to which we tabled amendments, lying in the INTA Commission on the right and far right), we consider it important for the Ecuadorian people to extension these tariff preferences and their urgent implementation.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour for the proposal for a regulation on the tariff treatment for goods originating in Ecuador. I see it as clearly intended to be a transitional measure for Ecuador and the European Union before signing an EU-Ecuador Free Trade Agreement.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Written. — The European Union has already concluded free trade agreements with Colombia and Peru, Ecuador's neighbours. As a result, Ecuador's trading position has deteriorated. By giving Ecuador special tariff treatment now, Europe wants to limit the damage to Ecuador.  However, the free trade agreements that Europe is concluding cannot count on my support. European production and safety standards are therefore under pressure, which could include a reduction in European environmental and animal welfare standards. Moreover, the current proposal will increase the power of the European Commission and reduce the influence of Parliament and the Member States. Although I resent ecuador for being the victim of unfair trade relations between Europe and Columbia/Peru, I do not want a short-term solution in the form of tariff treatment of products from Ecuador, when the consequences for animals, nature and the environment are incalculable.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We voted for it. This is not a free trade agreement, but a proposal for a Regulation extending Ecuador's export preferences to the EU under the GSP+, which is lost on 1 January 2015, until the future Free Trade Agreement enters into force. Despite being against the conditionality imposed by the European Commission on Ecuador in the articulation of the text (allows the suspension of tariff preferences if Ecuador adopts "measures" that have any effect on EU imports) and despite considering that the possible decisions that the Commission may take in this regard should be taken under the framework of delegated acts so that Parliament can make effective use of its control functions (both issues to which we tabled amendments, lying in the INTA Commission on the right and far right), we consider it important for the Ecuadorian people to extension these tariff preferences and their urgent implementation.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on tariff treatment for goods originating in Ecuador, the way to extend trade preferences granted to Ecuador within the General System of Preferences (GSP), which would otherwise expire on 1 January 2015, in order to prevent disruption in trading until the Trade Agreement concluded by Ecuador with the European Union enters into force in July 2014. I therefore support this transition period (lasting the longest until 31 December 2016) in order to prepare Ecuador and the European Union for the entry into force of the FTA, while respecting the obligations arising from the GSP legal framework.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of my colleague Helmut Scholz's report on the tariff treatment of goods originating in Ecuador. The report aims to establish a transitional process that allows for the continuity of trade between Ecuador and the EU between the end of the GSP regime and the entry into force of the trade agreement with the EU. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - Free trade is an extremely important source of economic growth, which is why efforts to liberalise world trade are one of the main elements of EU policy. An excellent example of this is the extension of ecuador's existing trade preferences for the period from the beginning of 2015, when it will lose its GSP+ status, until the date of entry into force of the FREE TRADE AGREEMENT with the EU. The absence of changes in the tariff treatment of goods originating in Ecuador will result in mutual benefits, as under the agreement Ecuador undertakes to maintain tariffs and quantitative restrictions on imports from the EU at its current level. The result will be to avoid reversing the upward trend that currently characterizes trade between Ecuador and the EU. However, in order to materialise the common benefits of extending existing trade preferences, they should be subject to several conditions, such as Ecuador's compliance with the rules of origin, cooperation with the European Commission in making information on Ecuador's compliance with these conventions available, and making continuous efforts to sign and ratify a free trade agreement with the EU. I call for these conditions to be carefully monitored by the European Commission.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I supported the resolution as it offers a transitional safety net minimising negative effects on economic operators involved in EU-Ecuador trade.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Helmut Scholz because I believe that this document proposes solutions that we can support because it supports the objective of applying a transitional regime pending the provisional application of the free trade agreement between the European Union and Ecuador. The implementation of intermediate measures will also make it possible to protect the current tariff regime on the basis of the principle of reciprocity.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — In this report we voted to extend the GSP+ for Ecuador from January 2015 on the condition that the EU-Ecuador Free Trade Agreement be signed by 31 December 2016. I cannot vote in favour of this report because, although I am not against prolonging the GSP+, I cannot accept that it will be ready for the signing of the Free Trade Agreement, since I am against it. That's why I abstained.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — In July 2014. The European Commission and Ecuador have concluded a trade agreement for the country's accession to a trade agreement between the European Union and Colombia and Peru.  Ecuador is still a beneficiary country of the preferential scheme (Generalised Scheme of Preferences, GSP + schemes), but these rights will lose out from January 2015 as Ecuador ceases to be an acceptable developing country due to receiving more than $4 thousand per capita over the past three years. In order not to interrupt or disrupt trade between the European Union and Ecuador, this proposal will allow Ecuador to maintain free access to the EU market in accordance with the previous preferential scheme rules, namely the GSP + scheme.  I supported this report because I believe that the efforts made by Ecuador during the negotiations are certainly proof that this country deserves to be the beneficiary of this special measure. This treaty will ensure all the preconditions necessary for strengthening and further advancing Ecuador's economy, so that even after a preferential scheme, Ecuador can maintain the same level of competitiveness with other Latin American importing countries.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. — The South American market is important to the European Union, and the goods on this continent (including ecuador) deserve the respective tariff regime in the Eurpa Union, which was accepted today by the European Parliament. I also voted in favour with my group because that is the right position.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the Scholz report on the tariff treatment of goods originating in Ecuador, because it helps to strengthen the mutual benefit of the EU and Ecuador, a country which dared and succeeded in writing off the shameful debt imposed on it.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the tariff agreement on goods originating in Ecuador. In order to prevent Ecuador from being in a worse position than at present, it is necessary for ecuador to continue to benefit from these preferences, without which its trade and its economy in that country could have serious negative repercussions. It is necessary to ensure that the customs duties applied are not increased and that no new customs duties are applied to products originating in Ecuador.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — (IT) Last July, the negotiations with Ecuador aimed at defining the right conditions for the country's accession to the trade agreement between the European Union and Colombia/Peru came to an end.  The Scholz report supports the objective of applying a transitional regime, pending the application of the free trade agreement between the EU and the South American country. The implementation of intermediate measures will make it possible, on the one hand, to avoid a diversion of trade between the parties, due to higher duty rates, and, on the other, to extend the current tariff system on the basis of the principle of reciprocity. I believe that the document proposes rational and acceptable solutions, so I have decided to support it with my vote in favour.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — (DE) I abstained from voting on the customs treatment of goods originating in Ecuador, as I do not believe that Ecuador can comply with the required amendments in due course or obtain the agreement of Peru and Colombia to the EU-Ecuador free trade agreement. An important point here is compliance with the rules of origin, which will be difficult to implement in Ecuador.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — Negotiations with Ecuador for its accession to the EU trade agreement between the EU and Colombia and Peru ended on 17 July 2014. However, as a result of an amendment to the corresponding EU regulation, Ecuador is expected to lose its status as granted by the Generalized Tariff Preference Scheme (GSP) on 1 January 2015. The regulation proposed by the Commission aims to grant Ecuador trade preferences similar to those it enjoyed with the GSP - over the next two years (January 1, 2015 to December 31, 2016), until the free trade agreement enters into force. I am strongly opposed to any free trade agreement, especially since Ecuador, through its participation in ALBA, promoted an alternative to neoliberal integration. In this context, I abstain.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — On 17 July 2014, negotiations with Ecuador for its accession to the Trade Agreement concluded between the EU and Colombia and Peru were concluded and a protocol was subsequently signed. In order to avoid unnecessary disruption to trade, pending the completion of the procedures for the adoption and application of the Protocol of Adoption, it is necessary to ensure that customs duties applied on the date of the heading of the Protocol of Withdrawal are not increased and that no new customs duties are applied to products originating in Ecuador. To this end, the proposal for a Regulation provides for the maintenance of the level of duties rates applicable to Ecuador on the date of the heading of the Protocol of Access.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report which would mean that both importers and exporters from both the EU and Ecuador would benefit from this agreement and allow for fair competition between Ecuador and neighbours who already have this form of agreement with the EU.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I supported the report on tariff treatment for goods originating from Ecuador. The proposed legislation would effectively prolong the trade preferences granted to Ecuador under the GSP+ regulation, while introducing an element of reciprocity as Ecuador would also be obliged to maintain its current level of duties for EU imports until the FTA is provisionally applied.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. After Peru and Colombia, the European Union has just concluded a free trade accession agreement with Ecuador. Pending the entry into force of this agreement, the Commission on 1 October approved a proposal to guarantee the non-increase in current tariffs. It should be noted, however, that France's exports to Ecuador have fallen (by almost half in value compared to 2012) and this is due to the application by the Ecuadorian authorities of administrative, regulatory and other restrictions. The trade balance for France is in deficit of 221 million euros for 2013. It is therefore surreal to pursue market liberalisation agreements even though we have no guarantee of opening up the Ecuadorian market. This agreement goes even further in the direction of the wildest globalization. For all these reasons, I obviously voted against it.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. — (IT) We welcome this proposal with a view, on the one hand, to avoid unnecessary disruption of trade pending the provisional application of the free trade agreement between the European Union and Ecuador and, on the other, to alleviate the burden on European importers of Ecuadorian export products. In this way, we want to ensure that the customs duties applied on the date of the initialling of the Protocol of Accession of Ecuador to the EU-Colombia/Peru Free Trade Agreement are not increased and that no new customs duties are applied to products originating in Ecuador. Indeed, the proposal has the merit of introducing an element of reciprocity, since Ecuador will also have an obligation to maintain the current level of duties on EU imports until the provisional application of the Free Trade Agreement.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour of the report by Mr Beazley on behalf of the Committee on The Scholz to enable Ecuador to enjoy the GSP+ tariff system in international trade, in order to avoid serious negative repercussions and to find itself in a worse situation than at present.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - It is true that I have no fundamental concerns about providing development aid by granting tariff preferences and of giving states room for help through self-help. However, I do not see in this motion any guarantees for the prevention of child labour or other exploitative production practices which, in my view, could have been linked to it. That is why I abstained.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which provides for a transitional period until the full implementation of the protocol for accession to the trade agreement between the EU, Colombia and Peru, allowing Ecuadorian economic actors to avoid disadvantageous tariffs.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal on tariff treatment of goods originating in Ecuador. If Ecuador is able to meet all the conditions, the trade disruptions that are currently present in the high rates of duty will also disappear. It is not right that export products originating in Ecuador are at a competitive disadvantage on the EU market compared to similar products originating in Colombia and Peru.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. — The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted against the report and the proposal for a regulation on tariff treatment of products originating in Ecuador, because it is directly linked and subject to Ecuador's accession to the Free Trade Agreement already signed by the EU with Peru and Colombia. This is an agreement to the detriment of the people of Ecuador (as well as the peoples of Peru and Colombia), which ensures that the European Union monopolies make unhindered exploitation of its sources of wealth and its people, that any obstacle to the monopolies on the markets of these countries will be eliminated, which will have painful consequences for workers, the self-employed and the poor farmers.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Negotiations with Ecuador on its accession to the EU-Colombia/Peru trade agreement were concluded on 17 July 2014. The Multilateral Free Trade Agreement will provide a new legal framework for trade relations between the EU and Ecuador. The Commission proposes to make the extension of current trade preferences conditional on Ecuador complying with the following five requirements: 1) compliance with the rules of origin, (2) refraining from imposing new duties or restrictions on imports from the EU, 3) maintaining the ratification and effective implementation of a number of GSP-relevant conventions +, 4) cooperation with the European Commission on the request for information on compliance with these conventions and, last but not least, 5) Ecuador's continued commitment to the signing and ratification of the Free Trade Agreement with the EU. In view of the foreave, I would vote in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. — The European Union and Ecuador have just concluded negotiations on an already effective free trade accession agreement with Peru and Colombia. Pending the entry into force of this agreement, the Commission adopted on 1 October 2014 a proposal guaranteeing that the tariffs applied will not increase. It should be noted that France's exports have fallen by almost half in value compared to 2012, due to increasing barriers to ecuador's market access in current trade. As such, the trade balance for France is in deficit of 221 million euros for the year 2013. It is therefore inconsequenty to conduct trade liberalisation agreements when the guarantees of opening up the Ecuadorian market are not met. Once is not customary, France and the countries of the Union are the turkeys of the farce of unbridled globalization. That is why I voted against this agreement on the tariff treatment of goods originating in Ecuador.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — This proposal for a Regulation between the European Parliament and the Council on tariff treatment for goods originating in Ecuador is a logical link between the two customs regimes in which Ecuador will be found in early 2015 with regard to exports of its products to the EU. The fact that per capita income in Ecuador has passed the $4,000 threshold in the past 3 years reflects positive developments in that country's economy, but at the same time this is also the cause of the fact that the General System of Preferences of the European Union can no longer apply to goods produced in Ecuador.  On the other hand, negotiations have concluded this year to which Ecuador would join a trade agreement between the European Union, Colombia and Peru. By the time accession is ratified by EU Member States and Colombia and Peru, this instrument is needed to allow trade relations to continue smoothly. In any case, this proposal deserves support as Ecuador has proven to be a partner open to negotiation and cooperation development.  I consider it very important that, through the application of this regulation, the Commission carefully monitors whether Ecuador complies with its obligations, not only in terms of possible procedures that could directly cause difficulties in the European market for these products, but also in terms of human and labour rights and environmental protection.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — (IT) I welcome the new multilateral free trade agreement between the EU and Ecuador, which will expand trade relations and bring certain benefits for all. In order to carry out all the internal procedures necessary in the EU, but also in Ecuador, for the application of the Accession Protocol, I agree with what has been proposed, namely that the customs duties applied on the date of the initialling of the Protocol of Accession of Ecuador to the Free Trade Agreement should not be increased and that no new customs duties should be applied to products originating in Ecuador, also in order to enable economic operators to adapt to the new customs procedures. I also agree that the extension should be conditional on compliance with the five requirements set out by the Commission.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Writing. — This proposal combines two desirable objectives: on the one hand, it promotes free trade based on equality and state sovereignty. On the other hand, the EU is committed to the enforcement of international human rights, with a particular focus on those of work. It is to be welcomed that, in this case, workers' rights are seen as a condition for free trade. However, one inevitably wonders how the same EU can promote workers' rights in the case of Ecuador, where in the case of TTIP they are presented more as a trade restriction.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — The instrument that allows developing countries to benefit from differentiated and more favourable trade treatment by developed countries, the Generalised System of Preferences (GSS), currently in force for Ecuador, would expire in January 2015. With this, the commercial preferences granted under the Regulation would expire. However, Ecuador has, however, surpassed its previous WTO classification, with the list of vulnerable and developing countries being able to benefit from the instrument, updated for the last three consecutive years, but always excluding Ecuador. In this way, the EU has negotiated in parallel with Ecuador the membership of the Trade Agreement also concluded between the EU and Colombia and Peru. In the interregnum in which the internal procedures necessary for the implementation of the Protocol of Action are carried out, it seems necessary to apply another transitional application of tariff preferences which extends by the end of 2016, the present resolution of which approves, with my vote, in order to avoid commercial deviations due to the increase in customs rights to products originating in Ecuador.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — Negotiations for Ecuador's accession to the EU-Colombia/Peru Trade Agreement were concluded on 17 July 2014. However, the entry into force of the EU-Ecuador Agreement will not be effective until the end of 2015 or early 2016, after the authentication and ratification procedures of the text have been completed. Bearing in mind that Ecuador will lose, as of January 1, 2015, its status as a beneficiary of the Generalized System of Preferences Plus (GSP+) which it has been enjoying to date, having been declared by the World Bank as a high middle income State, it is necessary to freeze the customs duties currently applied and ensure that no new duties are applied on products originating in Ecuador, thus avoiding unnecessary trade disruption until the completion of the procedures necessary for the implementation of the Protocol of Accession. I therefore voted, without amending, on the proposal for a Regulation submitted by the Commission for it to be implemented from 1 January 2015 until six months after the Protocol of Accession enters into force or until 31 December 2016, depending on what happens first.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - We voted for it. This is not a free trade agreement, but a proposal for a Regulation extending Ecuador's export preferences to the EU under the GSP+, which is lost on 1 January 2015, until the future Free Trade Agreement enters into force. Despite being against the conditionality imposed by the European Commission on Ecuador in the articulation of the text (allows the suspension of tariff preferences if Ecuador adopts "measures" that have any effect on EU imports) and despite considering that the possible decisions that the Commission may take in this regard should be taken under the framework of delegated acts so that Parliament can make effective use of its control functions (both issues to which we tabled amendments, lying in the INTA Commission on the right and far right), we consider it important for the Ecuadorian people to extension these tariff preferences and their urgent implementation.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — Ecuador will lose its SPG+ status from 1 January 2015. Meanwhile, negotiations have begun for the accession of this country to the Trade Agreement concluded between the EU and Colombia and Peru, concluded on 17 July last. It should be noted that Ecuador's accession to the EU Trade Agreement with the Andean Community (initially envisaged, but later set aside because Ecuador abandoned the negotiations in 2007) will restore the competitiveness that its export products have lost compared to similar products imported from Colombia and Peru, also giving it a new legal framework for bilateral relations with the EU. This proposal thus aims to ensure, in a harmonious and equitable manner, that customs duties applied on the date of the heading of the Protocol of Agreement on The Agreement of The Agreement on The Agreement on The Free Trade agreement between the EU and the Andean Community are not increased and that customs duties are not temporarily applied to products originating in Ecuador.  I therefore agree with the prolongation, on a transitional basis, of the trade preferences granted under the GSP+ Regulation to Ecuador until the entry into force of the Free Trade Agreement between the EU and that country.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. — Trade negotiations between the European Union and Ecuador were concluded on 14 July and the agreement is currently awaiting ratification; At the same time, given the increase in Ecuador's annual per capita income, Ecuador will no longer be able to benefit from the generalised preference system SPG from 1 January 2015. I have therefore supported the European Commission's proposal and this report so that Ecuador can continue to benefit from the trade preferences it currently enjoys until the free trade agreement comes into force in the future. The aim is to avoid any disruption to trade and to allow legal stability for European and Ecuadorian companies.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. "I voted in favour. This is not a free trade agreement, but a proposal for a Regulation extending Ecuador's export preferences to the EU under the GSP+, which is lost on 1 January 2015, until the future Free Trade Agreement enters into force. Despite being against the conditionality imposed by the European Commission on Ecuador in the articulation of the text (allows the suspension of tariff preferences if Ecuador adopts "measures" that have any effect on EU imports) and despite considering that the possible decisions that the Commission may take in this regard should be taken under the framework of delegated acts so that Parliament can make effective use of its control functions (both issues to which we tabled amendments, lying in the INTA Commission on the right and far right), we consider it important for the Ecuadorian people to extension these tariff preferences and their urgent implementation.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - In this report we voted to extend the GSP+ for Ecuador from January 2015 on the condition that the EU-Ecuador Free Trade Agreement be signed by 31 December 2016. I cannot vote in favour of this report because, although I am not against prolonging the GSP+, I cannot accept that it will be ready for the signing of the Free Trade Agreement, since I am against it. That's why I abstained.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — I voted in support of the proposal for a regulation on the tariff treatment for goods originating from Ecuador. This regulation allows for stable trade flows from 1 January 2015, when Ecuador is due to lose trade preferences it enjoys for accessing the European market through the Generalised System of Preferences (GSP), until the recently concluded free trade agreement between the EU and Ecuador enters into force in 2016. The proposal acts as a desirable step to facilitate a seamless transition from the current trading conditions to the ones established by the trade agreement.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — In July this year, the European Commission and Ecuador concluded negotiations on Ecuador's accession to the EU-Colombia/Peru trade agreement. At the moment Ecuador uses GSP+ benefits that expire in January 2015 due to higher per capita income (over $4,000 over the past three years).  I therefore also call on the Council, following the approval of the proposal in Parliament, to approve the proposal as soon as possible and for it to enter into force so as not to interrupt trade and trade relations. I support the proposal and would highlight the efforts made by Ecuador during the negotiations that deserved these specific EU import measures, which are important for the development and growth of the Ecuadorian economy and economy.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — I supported Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement concluded between the European Union and Peru relating to tariff and tax burdens on Ecuador on goods and goods originating in that Country.  I believe that the agreement will ensure competitiveness and stability for the economy on the one hand, while on the other hand it should increase the protection of human rights and labour rights as well as the level of environmental protection. The agreement also guarantees a new legal framework between the EU and Ecuador in the context of trade relations. Improving the legal framework is also important from the point of view of Croatia, since in 2013 the Republic of Croatia exported goods to Ecuador for 234 000 euros, while at the same time imports from that country were 11 267 000 euros.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — The granting of exemptions to products produced in non-EU countries is an economic blow to EU Member States producing corresponding and related products, therefore they should not exist.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the multi-party trade agreement which will establish a new legal framework for trade relations between Ecuador and the Union. Nevertheless, we must remain vigilant to the human aspect and ensure that the social and environmental aspects of such agreements are guaranteed.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. — I strongly believe in free trade agreements and the potential they have for the EU countries and economies. I support the Commission’s attempts to open new markets and reduce tariffs and other regulatory barriers to facilitate the entry into these markets for EU companies. I believe Europe can only grow through exports and not by creating more public debt in the EU with huge infrastructure projects. In INTA, ALDE decided to vote against the four blocks of Amendments proposed by the rapporteur, as we believed that a lot of these amendments risked delaying the entry into force of this agreement and we do not think this is a positive thing for Ecuador but also for the EU.  The approval of this agreement was important before the end of the year as economic contracts in Ecuador had to be negotiated now for next year. I also believe Ecuador should show a clear commitment that it will open its market to EU companies. As liberals, we always favoured a smooth adoption of this regulation.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. — Supporting the extension of EU tariff preferences to a country like Ecuador should not be a problem, but: - why not do so for other southern countries whose situation is even more difficult? - how can we not see it as a counterpart to his signing of the free trade agreement signed by Chile and Peru? Ecuador has reportedly come under severe pressure from the EU and its neighbours. He is not necessarily the least well-equipped to resist. However, the Ecuadorian government decided to exploit Yasumi oil at the expense of one of the most beautiful Amazonian forest areas and the rights of the indigenous peoples who live there, and to amend its Constitution to allow the cultivation of GMOs. The debate in Ecuador is intense and some see it as a change of economic course for Rafael Correa, far removed from the alternative model supported by Latin American governments and concerned with the issues of sustainable development and "buen vivir". But this government cannot be accused of pursuing purely neoliberal policies. It has achieved impressive results such as improving the country's infrastructure and access to health and education for the vast majority of the population. I have therefore chosen to abstain on this report by my German colleague GUE/NGL, Helmut Scholz.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — This Regulation has the effect of extending the trade preferences granted to Ecuador under the GSP+ Regulation. However, this extension is subject to harsh conditions imposed by the EU on Ecuador. By accepting this agreement to extend The GSP+ status, Ecuador, among other constraints, will have to refrain from imposing new duties or restrictions on imports from the EU and continue negotiations with a view to signing and ratifying the Free Trade Agreement.  In a context of increasing pressure for the liberalisation of international trade, it is noted that the EU uses the end of gSP+ as a form of blackmail for the acceptance of so-called Free Trade Agreements, through unacceptable diplomatic and economic pressure on several countries.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — As I believe that Ecuador cannot meet the required amendments in due course or obtain the agreement of Peru and Colombia to the EU-Ecuador free trade agreement, I voted against this motion.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. — The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted against the report and the proposal for a regulation on tariff treatment of products originating in Ecuador, because it is directly linked and subject to Ecuador's accession to the Free Trade Agreement already signed by the EU with Peru and Colombia. This is an agreement to the detriment of the people of Ecuador (as well as the peoples of Peru and Colombia), which ensures that the European Union monopolies make unhindered exploitation of its sources of wealth and its people, that any obstacle to the monopolies on the markets of these countries will be eliminated, which will have painful consequences for workers, the self-employed and the poor farmers.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr. President! I also wanted to use the next explanations of vote to praise our Committee on Budgets once again and to say that, with the corrections in the 2014 budget, we have, of course, created the conditions for us to be able to adopt a budget for 2015. The procedure as such is necessary on the one hand, and on the other hand it is always annoying because, of course, the European Union itself is well funded. We finance ourselves mainly through membership fees, a low level of VAT and fines. Corrections are needed. What annoys me most, of course, is not the corrections that are necessary, but the same fact that the Member States continue to forget to pay their membership fees on time, and that we keep getting into the situation where unpaid invoices remain unpaid.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I have not been able to vote in favour of this report as, although it proposes a solution to ensure that outstanding payments are made by the EU budget, it does not offer a sustainable solution. The defaults scovered by the EU with this mobilisation of funds are not unforeseen, but are the debt incurred from the past financial year on which it has been decided not to act. In order for the EU to cope with outstanding payments, it must establish a credible budgetary framework and not try to resolve patched crises that will aggravate the problem of defaults in the medium term. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — I do not believe that the Contingency Margin should be needed; the institutions of the European Union should instead be cut down to size.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of all draft amending budgets for 2014 and for the agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council on the 2015 budget. I congratulate the Negotiators of the European Parliament on the eur 4.25 billion allocated to the emergency debts of this year's EU budget. The European Commission would be obliged to draw up a step-by-step plan for the reduction of outstanding bills and to establish a sustainable debt ceiling in the future. Thanks to Parliament, eur 0.5 billion will be allocated to commitments. than the COUNCIL of the EU proposed. More funding will be allocated to horizon 2020 and the Erasmus+ programme for student and youth exchange. It is to be welcomed that the increase in funding for European neighbourhood programmes, humanitarian aid and the common foreign security policy has been increased, which is very relevant in the light of today's situation in Europe. However, I do not support the reduction in funding for the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund, which will affect many EU farmers, who are in a particularly difficult situation because of the protracted Russian embargo and who need EU assistance.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. — The Union currently has extremely large arrears of payment. For cohesion policy alone, more than 23 billion euros of bills were unpaid at the end of 2013. In terms of credibility, it is therefore important to use all the flexibility mechanisms to reduce these unpaid debts. The mobilization of the margin for unforeseen events for the 2014 financial year generates more than 3 billion in payment credits. This is not likely to solve the difficulty in the long term but limits the increase in bills to be honored carried over the next fiscal year.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of mobilizing the contingency margin because, in the implementation of the 2014-2020 MFF, the delay in outstanding payments and invoices increased, with a level of commitments outstanding above the expected amount when the 2007-2013 MFF was approved. This unsustainable situation needs to be resolved and it is necessary to include recourse to the flexibility mechanism so as not to jeopardize the implementation of European policy and programmes and to reduce interest claims for late payments that would make the situation worse.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. At the end of 2014, the European Union is obliged to mobilise a margin for unforeseen events in view of the payment credits committed and the remaining unpaid invoices. I would like to point out that the implementation of the 2014-2020 MFF began with arrears of payment of some EUR 23.4 billion in unpaid invoices at the end of 2013, and with a volume of outstanding commitments (RAL) of EUR 221.7 billion. This mobilization of the margin for unforeseen events will obviously not solve in the long term the recurring problem of payment credits, nor that of the increase in LRAs. So I voted against that request.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted against mobilising EUR 2.8 billion from the contingency margin for 2014 because I believe that, if waste such as that of parliament's dual seat had been eliminated, there would have been no need to use it.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — The implementation of the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020 began with a huge delay in payments, with outstanding invoices of around EUR 23.4 billion at the end of 2013 in cohesion policy alone, while the level of outstanding commitments reached EUR 221.7 billion on the same date, i.e. EUR 41 billion above the amount initially envisaged when the 2007-2013 MFF was approved. This situation requires urgent measures, such as recourse to the flexibility mechanisms covered by the MFF Regulation, so as not to jeopardize the implementation of EU policies and programmes. That is why I voted in favour of mobilizing the contingency margin in 2014 to make available an amount of EUR 3 168 233 715 in payment appropriations above the payment ceiling of the Multiannual Financial Framework.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted for this rapport because we need to finance the European programmes we voted for in the past.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — The financial and budgetary situation of the European Union is such that it is now obliged to use the contingency margin at the end of the year to cover the payment credits committed in 2014 and a share of the unpaid bills. Of course, this mobilization will not solve the structural problem of unpaid debts but will have the effect of weakening the financial instruments of relief. In light of these alarming elements, I voted against it.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the reserve amount for 2014, amounting to EUR 4 026.7 million, in order to react to the budgetary impact of unforeseen circumstances. This fund should be mobilised to supplement payment appropriations in the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2014, above the payment ceiling. It is commendable that this money will be used to cover youth programmes such as Horizon 2020, 'Erasmus' and 'COSME', as well as to cover expenditure on the Youth Initiative for Employment. The European Parliament demonstrates once again that one of its priorities is young people, and the European Parliament funds programmes to encourage them to stay in Europe to study and work here.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — I voted against. The EU has failed economic policies and is still asking states for money from its citizens.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the margin for unforeseen events, in view of the fact that it once again highlights the crucial need for greater flexibility in the Union's budget. This was necessary as the implementation of the EU Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) for the period 2014-2020 began with a huge backlog of payments, amounting to around EUR 23.4 billion, and it was therefore necessary to make use of the various flexibility mechanisms provided for in the MFF Regulation, including the margin for unforeseen events. In addition, in any case, mobilising the margin for unforeseen events in 2014 does not lead to an increase in the overall ceiling on MFF payment appropriations 2014-2020.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — In view of the many natural disasters in various parts of Europe and the many payment commitments not planned during the year, it is necessary to allocate funds to deal with these situations and to have the necessary budgetary flexibility. The vote is in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) This proposal makes it possible to increase the allocation of certain sub-capitals of the budget to deal with emergencies. It therefore goes in the logic of flexibility, which we are calling for loudly, so that this is not the Europe of technocrats. I agree with the proposal and voted in favour.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of mobilising the 2014 unforeseen margin. Although a compromise has been reached, it remains essential to resolve the problem of payment appropriations. My vote was in favour as consequential to the adoption of amending budget No 3/2014, which provides for a request for additional appropriations to make it possible to make good the lack of resources necessary in order to pay for the 2014 expenditure. The negotiations enabled the margin for unforeseen events to be mobilised, for an amount which may be considered as low as possible to cover outstanding invoices.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — It appears necessary to mobilise the full amount of the Contingency Margin available to complement the payment appropriations in the General Budget of the European Union 2014 above the payment ceiling. According to the proposal, this amount will be used to complement payments for the implementation of very important key policies and programmes such as Horizon 2020, Erasmus+ and the Youth Employment Initiative. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — The implementation of the MFF for 2014-2020 began with a huge backlog of payments resulting in unpaid invoices and outstanding commitments, i.e. EUR 41 billion more than initially planned for the 2007-2013 MFF; the situation is unacceptable and requires the adoption of urgent measures, such as the use of the flexibility mechanisms provided for in the MFF Regulation, with a view not to compromising the effectiveness of Union policies and programmes, as agreed unanimously under the MFF, as well as limiting the rights to interest on late payment and avoiding an undue increase in the exposure and economic vulnerability of beneficiaries of the Union budget. I voted in favour of this resolution because we need to try to resolve the payment problem in some way, including by supporting the amending package proposed for 2014. Although it seems a little doubtful to use a tool designed for "unforeseen" to fill widely anticipated and predictable gaps, in any case this seems the only way to try to limit the situation and not further increase previous debts.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — I have not been able to vote in favour of this report as, although it proposes a solution to ensure that outstanding payments are made by the EU budget, it does not offer a sustainable solution. The defaults scovered by the EU with this mobilisation of funds are not unforeseen, but are the debt incurred from the past financial year on which it has been decided not to act. In order for the EU to cope with outstanding payments, it must establish a credible budgetary framework and not try to resolve patched crises that will aggravate the problem of defaults in the medium term. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — The implementation of the MFF 2014-2020 started with a huge backlog in payments. The financing of this mobilisation can take place at virtually no cost to national budgets due to other unexpected additional revenues for the year 2014. Hence I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. By the end of 2013, the implementation of the multi-year financial framework was already experiencing very large arrears of payment. For example, these amounted to about EUR 23.4 billion for cohesion policy alone. Therefore, the voted text provides urgent responses to this situation through the use of flexibility mechanisms, including the margin for unforeseen events. The mobilization of this instrument will help finance certain programmes such as "Erasmus" or the "Youth Employment Initiative" but it leaves the problem of the shortage of payment credits without a lasting response.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. — The European Parliament today adopted by a large majority the EU budget for 2015 and the amendments on surplus resources for 2014. The huge advantage of the agreement is that it will be able to pass the EU budget for 2015 later this year, i.e. next year it would not only be possible to pay 12th of this year's budget per month. By 2014, an additional €4 billion will be mobilised, of which EUR 3.5 billion will be the result of so-called 'fresh money', i.e. not transfers.  The EP only agreed to the adoption of next year's EU budget on the condition that the European Commission draws up a plan to reduce unpaid bills to sustainable levels. In 2014, €23.4 billion will have to be paid from the previous year. To this end, today's vote provides an additional resource of nearly EUR 4 billion. Today's decision by the European Parliament also provided agricultural and cohesion resources for Hungary in this year's and next year's budgets. The Hungarian People's Party delegation, together with the European People's Party, acted responsibly on behalf of the national interests of Hungary and voted in favour of the 2015 EU budget and all the reports contained in the related agreement. The agreement also includes reports mobilising the Solidarity Fund to mitigate the damage caused by natural disasters affecting different regions of Europe.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted against the report because it does not deal sustainably with the recent payment shortfalls and the increasing amount of balances to be cleared.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The implementation of the 2014-2020 MFF began with a very high volume of overdue payments, with outstanding invoices which, for cohesion policy alone, amounted to around EUR 23.4 billion at the end of 2013, and outstanding commitments (ADR) reaching EUR 221.7 billion, 41 billion euros more than the initial forecast. As part of the negotiations on the budget package for 2014 and 2015, the mobilisation of the Margin for Unforeseen Events was agreed to amount to EUR 2818.2 million plus EUR 350 million, i.e. EUR 3168.2 million. It is unacceptable that the Council does not share the interpretation of Parliament and the Commission that the amount of EUR 350 million in payment appropriations mobilised in 2014 with respect to the Special Instruments provided for in the MFF Regulation should not be counted for the ceiling of payments. Mobilising the unforeseen margin in 2014 does not imply any increase in the overall ceiling for payments (EUR 908 billion at 2011 prices) of the 2014-2020 MFF, as it is deducted from the margins of future budgetary years. Flexibility instruments should be used to pay overdue and unpaid invoices. The European Union must apply to itself the same rigour as it asks the Member States and, in addition, must fulfil its commitments, in particular what it has adopted in the multiannual financial framework.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — The Regulatory Unforeseen Margin may reach 0.03 % of EU GNI, used to supplement payment appropriations from the eu general budget, in this case for 2014, above the ceiling for payments.  This report approves the decision to mobilise EUR 3 168 million, which will be allocated to three fractions of the margins below the ceilings for the financial years 2018, 2019 and 2020, leaving this allocation the amount of EUR 350 million from an agreement on payments for other special instruments which, according to the document, should be left to the Commission to draw up a timely proposal on the implementation of this amount.  The Council does not share the view of Parliament and the Commission that the amount of EUR 350 million in payment appropriations mobilised in 2014 with respect to Special Instruments should not be counted towards the ceiling of payments, thus leaving a margin of EUR 711 million to exhaust before resorting to the Margin for Unforeseen Events. In view of the lack of information on the specific items for which payments are intended, we abstained.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing — The Multiannual Financial Framework is, inter alia, an important payment instrument for individual European Union policies. On numerous occasions, both the European Commission and the European Parliament have called on the Member States of the European Union to make effective use of the resources provided to them, whether within the framework of individual funds or common policies. It is unprecedented that at the end of 2013, the outstanding payment claims in cohesion policy alone amounted to EUR 23.4 billion. This situation is totally unacceptable, and the European Union and its institutions are obliged to take urgent measures so as not to jeopardise the implementation of The European Union's policies and programmes, while at the same time limiting requests for payment of default interest, which disproportionately increase the economic risk and vulnerability of the beneficiaries of the European Union budget.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — This mobilisation is unlikely to address in a sustainable way the recent payment shortfalls and the increasing amount of balances to be wound up.
