That is why I am voting against the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the margin for unforeseen needs, in accordance with point 14 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour for the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin in 2014 as this highlights the urgent need for the Union budget to be as flexible as possible.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a motion for a resolution on the proposal by the European Parliament and the Council to mobilise the contingency reserve, notably because this mobilisation will have a very small impact on national budgets thanks to unforeseen additional walkthrouts for 2014. There have been major backlogs in payments and outstanding debts, which need to be resolved as soon as possible through urgent and effective measures, which would prevent the deterioration of the current financial situation. It is also significant to apply a flexibility mechanism and avoid a negative impact on the implementation of programmes and policies in order to contribute positively to the implementation of the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020 by mobilising the reserve.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I voted against an increase in this year’s EU budget. We need to put the principles of added value and efficiency at the heart of budgetary decision-making in Europe. I want to see a real budget reform in the EU with a greater focus on generating growth and jobs, and areas that do not bring any real benefits to our constituents cut.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - The mobilisation of the 2014 consequency margin is consequential to the adoption of amending budget No 3/2014, which provides for a request for additional appropriations to make up for the lack of resources necessary in order to provide for the payment of the 2014 expenditure. The negotiations between Parliament and the Council, which ended on 8 December, enabled the margin for unforeseen events to be mobilised for an amount which may be considered to be the minimum necessary to cover outstanding invoices. Unfortunately, despite the compromise reached, it has not yet been possible to resolve the problem of payment appropriations, a problem which will necessarily have to find a definitive political solution during the parliamentary term.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — The Commission, at the request of parliament, it has submitted a draft amending budget (PPR No 5/2014 of 8.9.2014), with a view to entering in the 2014 budget the corresponding commitment and payment appropriations — EUR 46 998 528 — as provided for in point 26 of the IA, as pursued by the Group of Socialists and Democrats.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — I have not been able to vote in favour of this report as, although it proposes a solution to ensure that outstanding payments are made by the EU budget, it does not offer a sustainable solution. The defaults scovered by the EU with this mobilisation of funds are not unforeseen, but are the debt incurred from the past financial year on which it has been decided not to act. In order for the EU to cope with outstanding payments, it must establish a credible budgetary framework and not try to resolve patched crises that will aggravate the problem of defaults in the medium term. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. — The implementation of the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020 began with a huge delay in payments, which makes the situation unacceptable and requires urgent action, such as recourse to the flexibility mechanisms included in the MFF Regulation, so as not to jeopardize the implementation of EU policies and programmes, and to limit complaints of late interest , avoiding excessively increasing the economic exposure and vulnerability of the beneficiaries of the Union budget. The mobilisation of the contingency margin is approved in 2014, as it does not entail any increase in the overall payment limit of the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020, as stipulated in Article 13(4) of the MFF Regulation, when offset by the margins for future years under Article 13(3) of the MFF Regulation. This will allow the Union budget to become increasingly flexible and the EUR 350 million in payment appropriations mobilized in 2014 to be accounted for outside the payment deadline. I therefore vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — The current level of unpaid bills has reached €23 billion, putting a lot of pressure on the current multiannual financial framework. That is why I supported the 2014 Unforeseen Expenditure Reserve Mobilisation Report, which amounts to €3.16 billion or 0.03 percent of the European Union's gross national income. In my view, this instrument will provide part of the funds to collect part of the commitments.  €3.16 billion will increase the cap on payments under the current Multiannual Financial Framework and provide funding in advance for Horizon 2020, Erasmus+, COSME and youth employment initiative in case of unforeseen expenditure.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. - I voted in favour.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I abstained because the Deprez report on the mobilisation of the margin for unforeseen needs in 2014 does not adequately address the relevant serious issues that it is supposed to be trying to address.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. - (IT) As the European Parliament we represent the citizens, our electors, in the highest echelons of European politics and, as their spokesman, we must adopt concrete positions in their favour. In an economically very difficult historical period, it is not possible to freeze an annual budget that covers 28 countries until the following year; on the contrary, we must be aware of the need for a flexible budget in line with the needs and changes of the economy of our Europe. That is why the mobilisation of the margin for unforeseen events in 2014 set at EUR 350 million in payment appropriations finds my full support, against a Council that has tried to reduce this amount in an attempt to maintain rigour in the Union's accounts.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — Stressing the need to mobilise the margin for unforeseen events, with the aim of supplementing payment appropriations from the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2014 beyond the payment ceiling, mr Deprez's report highlights the need to pursue ever greater flexibility in the Community budget.   By fully agreeing with the demands made in this document, I felt it appropriate to support it with my vote.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — The use of the margin for unforeseen expenditure must be rejected in general, as this shows that the European Union's financial resources are not spent to the best of their knowledge, but largely to maintain political influence in certain unstable regions. The increased use of this margin is already curtailing the ability to act in the coming years.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — The management of the European budget continues to deteriorate in terms of unpaid bills. There are 23 billion unpaid debts accumulated since 2010 on cohesion policies alone. As the 2014-2020 budget is down from the previous period, the commitments already made by the EU under its policies will further increase the level of unpaid debts. This situation is intractable without a comprehensive overhaul of this fiscal framework. But the Commission and the Council prefer to use ever more complex artifices to circumvent this crisis situation without solving it. The mobilization of the "margin for the unexpected" is a perfect example. While the surge in unpaid debts was perfectly foreseeable, it is proposed here to use the "unforeseen margin" to make some additional payments that represent drops of water in the abyss of unpaid debts. At the expense of the real unforeseen, social or ecological, which can only be financed by delay. I disapprove of this aggravated mismanagement and I vote against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report to be able to meet the EU budget, as the implementation of the 2014-2020 MFF began with a very high volume of overdue payments, with outstanding invoices. Mobilising the unforeseen margin for 2014 will free up more than €3 billion, which will help pay outstanding invoices. Although it is not enough to solve the problem, it will be a valuable help in solving it.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because of the need to resolve the growing number of the Union’s outstanding commitments. The report also stresses the need for greater flexibility in the Union budget, which is becoming more important every year.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I am in agreement with the report on mobilisation of the contingency margin in 2014.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The financial and budgetary situation of the European Union is such that it is now obliged to use the contingency margin at the end of the year to cover the payment credits committed in 2014 and a share of the outstanding outstanding invoices pending. Of course, this mobilization does nothing to solve the structural problem of unpaid debts and will obviously not prevent the creation of a "snowball effect". In light of these alarming elements, I voted against it.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. — I believe that the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin, whilst justified, is controversial for a number of reasons. Primarily because there is no sufficient reason to mobilise it, also due to the continuing dispute between the Parliament and Council over whether it should be considered outside of the payment ceiling.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - The request concerns the use of the margin for unforeseen expenditure in the year ending. The focus is on the payment of "old invoices". It is clear to me, as an MEP, that the use of this margin of manoeuvre can only be allowed within very narrow limits, so as not to create a laissez-faire atmosphere. Especially in times of financial crisis, this is not the responsibility of the citizens. I do not see that as a given. Too often, the expenditure to be financed by the application has not been unpredictable. I therefore voted against the motion.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because I support the mobilization of additional resources by the margin for unforeseen events, so that EU money remains available for 2015, and thus make the best use of the instruments of the European budget.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — Today, I supported the proposal to mobilise stocks to cover unforeseen costs. However, in order to avoid such situations, the European Union's budget must be made more flexible in order to avoid such situations. The introduction of a contingency margin is not sustainable and does not reduce payment difficulties and makes financial management unreliable in general.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Council Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013, establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020, allows the mobilisation of the margin for unforeseen events as a tool of last resort to respond to unforeseen circumstances. Political agreement on the 2014-2020 MFF ceilings was reached at European Council level in February 2013 and, during subsequent negotiations with the European Parliament, the margin for unforeseen events was confirmed. The overall margin for payments does not apply to the year 2014 and therefore the mobilisation of the entire margin for unforeseen events for 2014, €4 026.7 million remains the only instrument available to address the budgetary impact of unforeseen circumstances that occurred after the MFF payment ceilings have been set and to reduce the significant gap between the level of authorised payment appropriations and the additional and unforeseen payment requirements for the current year. For these reasons, I would vote in favour.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Writing. — (DE) With this proposal, the Commission wants to tell us that the youth employment programme it has initiated is an 'unforeseen expenditure'. It is an absolute reversal of the word 'unforeseen' that has been put to the vote here. Perhaps we could overlook this if this programme were a success. However, this is by no means the case! The Commission is blindly following those voices in Europe who are advocating that employment can be increased by increasing public spending. Indeed, it can be seen that the unemployment rate, and youth unemployment in particular, is high, especially where the state is shrinking the economy at will. In addition, there is still a lack of recognition that the euro, in the manner of one size fits, has deprived all the distressed countries of their competitiveness with the economically stronger central and northern Europe. Since I strongly oppose this senseless squandering of taxpayers' money, I must also reject this Commission proposal.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — The 2015 budget does not resolve all the missing payments accumulated in previous years. Nevertheless, efforts to contain the Union's debt should be welcomed. I am therefore in favour of a measure allowing the redeployment of margins for unforeseen events in 2014 and certain union revenues in the service of the balance of its budget.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. - The implementation of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2014-2020 began with a very high volume of overdue payments, with outstanding invoices which, for cohesion policy alone, amounted to around EUR 23.4 billion at the end of 2013, and outstanding commitments (ADR) which reached EUR 221.7 billion on the same date, eur 41 billion more than the initial forecast when the 2007-2013 MFF was agreed. This requires urgent measures, with resources to the flexibility mechanisms included in the MFF Regulation, in order not to jeopardise the implementation of EU policies and programmes, limit late payment interest claims and avoid unduly increasing the exposure and economic vulnerability of beneficiaries of the Union budget. Parliament, the Council and the Commission agreed to use the Margin for Unforeseen Events amounting to EUR 3168.2 million, and funding for this mobilisation can take place almost at no cost to national budgets due to other additional revenues from 2014. I voted in favour.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — The implementation of the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020 began with a huge delay in payments, with outstanding invoices amounting to around EUR 23.4 billion at the end of 2013 in cohesion policy alone, while the level of outstanding commitments reached EUR 221.7 billion on the same date alone, i.e. EUR 41 billion above the amount initially envisaged when the 2007-2013 MFF was approved. This situation requires urgent measures, such as recourse to the flexibility mechanisms covered by the MFF Regulation, so as not to jeopardize the implementation of EU policies and programmes. That is why I voted in favour of mobilizing the Contingency Margin in 2014 to make available an amount of EUR 3 168 233 715 in payment appropriations above the payment ceiling of the Multiannual Financial Framework.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. "I supported this text regarding the use of the "contingency margin." It will, in fact, increase payments by more than 4 billion euros compared to the original budget. However, 2014 ends with 23 billion unpaid bills and it is in this sense that Parliament has asked the Commission to submit a comprehensive clean-up plan by the spring.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I have not been able to vote in favour of this report as, although it proposes a solution to ensure that outstanding payments are made by the EU budget, it does not offer a sustainable solution. The defaults scovered by the EU with this mobilisation of funds are not unforeseen, but are the debt incurred from the past financial year on which it has been decided not to act. In order for the EU to cope with outstanding payments, it must establish a credible budgetary framework and not try to resolve patched crises that will aggravate the problem of defaults in the medium term. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — I and my fellow Labour Party MEPs voted against the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on mobilisation of the Contingency Margin, releasing new money in the 2014 budget. In the framework of the negotiations on the 2014-2015 budgets package, it has been agreed to mobilise the Contingency Margin for an amount of EUR 3 168.2 million. This mobilisation is not likely to sustainably address the recent payment shortages and the growing amount of outstanding commitments, but only to limit the increase in outstanding bills rolled over to the following year, which has grown by more than 50% every year since 2010. We must put the principles of added value and efficiency at the heart of budgetary decision making in Europe.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — Having examined all other financial options for responding to unforeseen circumstances that arose after the 2014 payment ceiling was initially set out in February 2013 under the Multiannual Financial Framework, it seems necessary to mobilise the contingency reserve to supplement the payment appropriations in the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2014 above the ceiling for payments. Also, the amount of EUR 350 million in payment appropriations should be included in the mobilisation of the contingency reserve depending on the arrangement of payments for other specific instruments.  Accordingly, I support the report.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — I supported this initiative by providing employment funding, rural development, fisheries development and encouraging other measures focusing on economic and economic recovery and development, recovery from contingencies and crisis situations. It will mean helping people find a better job and social inclusion. If the money is used correctly, there will be exchanges of knowledge and innovation in many areas such as agriculture and forestry, the development of rural areas, the strengthening of the competitiveness of all types of agriculture and the sustainability of the economy.  Although it does not represent a large amount, I fully support it because in crisis situations any assistance and reaction is welcome, and unfortunately crisis situations in the EU are not uncommon today.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — This mobilisation is unlikely to address in a sustainable way the recent payment shortfalls and the increasing amount of balances to be wound up.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — I approved the mobilization of the margin for unforeseen events for the 2014 financial year as presented by Mr Deprez and I therefore voted in favour of his proposal.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. — I agree with the crucial need for the Union budget to be increasingly flexible for the mobilisation of the Contingency Margin for 2014, specially if the financing of this mobilisation can take place at virtually no cost to national budgets due to other unexpected additional revenues for the year 2014. Whereas the implementation of the MFF 2014-2020 started with a huge backlog in payments, with unpaid bills this situation is unacceptable and requires urgent measures, having recourse to the flexibility mechanisms included in the MFF Regulation, with a view to not jeopardising the delivery of EU policies and programmes.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - I have chosen to vote in favour of mobilising the 2014 conforeseen margin in order to unblock the implementation of back payments relating to cohesion policy. Despite the strong reservations about the misuse of this margin, which should be used for emergencies and certainly not to cope with payments that have long been planned in the budget, I can only support this urgent solution, which allows us to pay back invoices totalling EUR 3 168.2 million, for the benefit of citizens and businesses already exhausted by the impact of the crisis. Given that the 2014-2020 programming began with a delay in payments of EUR 23.4 billion, I hope that more appropriate instruments will soon be adopted to deal with this paradoxical situation, which only seriously undermines the credibility of the Union in the eyes of the citizens and the effectiveness of cohesion policies itself.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — The Regulatory Unforeseen Margin may reach 0.03 % of EU GNI, used to supplement payment appropriations from the eu general budget, in this case for 2014, above the ceiling for payments. This report proposes mobilising EUR 3168 million, divided into three fractions for the financial years 2018, 2019 and 2020, with the amount of EUR 350 million remaining in this allocation from an agreement on payments for other special instruments which, according to the document, should be left to the Commission to draw up a timely proposal on the implementation of this amount. The Council does not share the view of Parliament and the Commission that the amount of EUR 350 million in payment appropriations mobilised in 2014 with respect to Special Instruments should not be counted towards the ceiling of payments, thus leaving a margin of EUR 711 million to exhaust before resorting to the Margin for Unforeseen Events.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. - Instead of using the European Union's financial resources to the best of our knowledge and belief, most of them are to be spent on maintaining political influence in certain unstable regions. It is precisely through a greater use of the margin mentioned in the application that the ability to act will already be curtailed in the coming years. That is because of this, I have completely rejected this report.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr. President! I can connect seamlessly to that. I would simply like to ask for this, and with the 2014 budget and then with the 2015 budget, we have created the precondition for all of us – by which I mean the Commission, Parliament and, in particular, the Member States – to focus these on unpaid bills, the backlog that has then accumulated and which is not accumulating because the European Parliament is constantly spending money unchecked. no, it is accumulating because our Member States simply have arrears of contributions. So I would simply like to ask that we reduce this backlog, that we agree on a procedure in which contributions that have been agreed are finally paid on time. This also means that arrears of contributions are paid properly and in a timely manner.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Mr. President, the level of unpaid bills in the European Union has been steadily increasing since 2010, and has now reached as much as €28 billion. The level of illiquidity in the Member States is high and the EU budget must not be an additional generator of illiquidity. If contracting is approved, the payments should not be in doubt. With delays in payouts, we lose credibility.  That is why I supported the amendment to the 2014 budget, which increases the amount to pay liabilities by €4.2 billion, of which €2.4 billion relates to the European Regional Development Fund, where the amounts of unpaid commitments are the largest and projects are important for citizens' daily lives.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I have not been able to vote in favour of the draft amending budget because it is not a sufficient response to the hole in all the European Union budgets. These are defaults on the payrolls of EU officials, a problem that requires an urgent solution; however, these are defaults since the 2010 financial year and, again, these are about resolving patched crises that will aggravate the problem of non-payment by the European institutions in the medium term. We continue to play with the effective payment of millions of euros without proposing a new budgetary framework that will be able to solve the problem. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — This calls for additional payment appropriations, and therefore it is consistent for me to oppose it.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of all draft amending budgets for 2014 and for the agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council on the 2015 budget. I congratulate the Negotiators of the European Parliament on the eur 4.25 billion allocated to the emergency debts of this year's EU budget. The European Commission would be obliged to draw up a step-by-step plan for the reduction of outstanding bills and to establish a sustainable debt ceiling in the future. Thanks to Parliament, eur 0.5 billion will be allocated to commitments. than the COUNCIL of the EU proposed. More funding will be allocated to horizon 2020 and the Erasmus+ programme for student and youth exchange. It is to be welcomed that the increase in funding for European neighbourhood programmes, humanitarian aid and the common foreign security policy has been increased, which is very relevant in the light of today's situation in Europe. However, I do not support the reduction in funding for the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund, which will affect many EU farmers, who are in a particularly difficult situation because of the protracted Russian embargo and who need EU assistance.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. — The Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020 began with a delay in payments and unpaid invoices amounting to EUR 23.4 billion at the end of 2013 and levels of commitment above what had originally been envisaged, as a result of which Parliament, the Council and the Commission decided in November 2013 that the Union should have sufficient and necessary resources to cover the 2014 legal obligations. It is therefore necessary to approve the amending budgets No 3/2014, No 4/2014, No 6/2014 and No 8/2014, which will offset the needs of the additional payments.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This draft amending budget No. 3/2014 initially presented by the Commission proposed an increase in forecasts for revenue from fines and penalties, as well as other revenues, in the order of EUR 1.568 billion and an increase in payment appropriations of EUR 4.738 billion. This does not change the issue of outstanding arrears of payment credits as well as the remaining commitments to Liquid (RAL) and the mobilization of the margin for unforeseen events in 2014 will not be enough to counter the recurring "snowball" effect of unpaid debts. I therefore voted against this corrective project, which merely supports a debt that is growing.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted against this measure, in which the Commission calls for the expenditure ceilings at its disposal for 2014 to be gone. Italy, as a net contributor, that is, as a Member State that pays more to the EU than it receives, cannot support unreasonable and senseless spending policies of this over-spending and waste-conscious Europe.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — After arduous negotiations, an agreement has been reached to allow the payment of outstanding invoices, for which the amount of EUR 4.7 billion has been agreed for the period 2014-2015. In addition, the Commission, the Council and Parliament have agreed on a payment plan aimed at reducing the level of unpaid invoices within the current multiannual framework. An unprecedented level of default has accumulated throughout this year.  The agreed EUR 4.7 billion will enable part of the accumulated invoices to be met, thus helping to alleviate the situation of many SMEs, universities, local authorities and NGOs. It is true that the figure is not sufficient, but the alternative, the non-agreement, would have dire consequences: not having a fully operational budget for 2015, losing the possibility of paying the arrears and putting at risk the investment programme that the Commission has just presented. For 2015, it has been agreed to allocate EUR 145 321.5 million to commitment appropriations and EUR 141 214,040 563 million to payment appropriations. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted for this report because is essential to have an updated budget.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — I voted against this draft amending budget 3/2014 which will of course not solve the structural difficulties of the current and future budgets of the European Union. The European Union should change its motto and replace its "United in Diversity" with a "Give me your watch, I will give you the time!" It is trying here to convince the Member States that they will have to give less in the years to come. How can we believe in such bonuses when we know that the EU is going to have to spend more and more to cover its unpaid bills, a debt that does not say its name and finance its remaining 220 billion commitments.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report on the presentation of the draft amending budget for 2014 because I agreed to the redistribution of payment appropriations from the reserve for partnership agreements in the field of the European Fisheries Fund, as well as the increase of payment appropriations to eur 711.4 million. , so that obligations arising from previous and current commitments can be honoured, financial sanctions are avoided and beneficiaries can receive the financial support provided for by agreed EU policies, for which the European Parliament and the Council have authorised the related commitment appropriations in previous annual budgets.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — I voted against. The Commission has a spending margin of only EUR 0.7 billion, so it has proposed to finance the remaining EUR 4 billion by going beyond the annual ceilings for the 2014 financial year, through the use of the cons contingencies margin. However, the amounts thus mobilised must be fully offset by a reduction in the ceilings for subsequent years in order to keep the total ceilings for 2014-2020 unchanged. It is, in essence, an extraordinary advance measure to be used as a last resort. The United Kingdom, the Netherlands, Denmark, Finland, Austria, Sweden, France and Germany have criticised the Commission's proposal, considering this mobilisation to be legally unfounded and premature and inappropriate. On the other side are the 'net beneficiary' states. The compromise solution reached in the trialogue provides for a total amount of EUR 3.85 billion, consisting as follows: 0.7 margin of expenditure available; 2.8 margin usage for unforeseen events; 0.35 mobilised while postponing the decision on whether to consider them within the margin for unforeseen events.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — In view of the serious backlog of payments, this adjustment to the budget contributes (albeit to a small extent) to improving the situation. Let us remember that the backlog is, however, considerable.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — However unforeseen and unwelcome some people may be, these funds make it possible to pay invoices which would otherwise have been outstanding at the end of the year. I therefore welcome this change and congratulate the Italian Presidency on having reached the conclusion of these negotiations.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I supported, with my vote in favour, amending budget No 3/2014, which relates to higher revenues from fines, interest and repayments. The Commission has requested an increase in payment appropriations of around EUR 4.7 billion, which will be distributed across different budget lines, most of which – around 3.4 billion – will be used to stabilise the phenomenon of unpaid cohesion policy bills, around 0.6 billion for competitiveness, growth and employment in favour of research programmes (Horizon 2020), SMEs (Cosme), youth training (Erasmus) and satellite navigation (Galileo); finally, some EUR 0.7 billion will be allocated to humanitarian aid.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of this report so that the European Union can fulfil its obligations, tackle the payments backlogs and meet the payment shortages. This will bring the EU in a position to continue to affect urgent crises response measures, be in a position to deliver in the field of humanitarian aid and tackle the Erasmus+ insufficient payment levels that may eventually lead to problems in the implementation of the programme.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — Draft amending budget No 3/2014 in the 2014 general budget as initially presented by the Commission proposed to increase the revenue forecasts from fines and penalties, with the aim of covering the remaining requirements until the end of the year, in order to meet the obligations arising from past and current commitments. I could only vote in favour, because I believe that we need to try to solve the problem of payments in some way. This amending amendment is acceptable, inso far as it allows the situation to be buffered in some way, but of course we are still a long way from a stable and concrete solution.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — I have not been able to vote in favour of the draft amending budget because it is not a sufficient response to the hole in all the European Union budgets. These are defaults on the payrolls of EU officials, a problem that requires an urgent solution; however, these are defaults since the 2010 financial year and, again, these are about resolving patched crises that will aggravate the problem of non-payment by the European institutions in the medium term. It continues to play with the effective payment of millions of euros without proposing a new budgetary framework that will be able to solve the problem. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of this proposal since I agree with the Commission proposal for the increase in both the forecast of revenue stemming from fines and penalties, and other revenue. This is aimed at meeting payment needs until the end of the year by covering obligations stemming from past and current commitments.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The vote of this text makes it possible to respond temporarily to the recurring budgetary problems that the Community budget is experiencing. Indeed, if I am satisfied, in the 2014 budget, of the strengthening of the payment appropriations of a series of budget lines of up to EUR 4,246 million, of which EUR 3,168 million will be mobilised by the contingency margin in 2014, these measures will not be enough to stem the phenomenon of unpaid bills from the European Union.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. — The European Parliament today adopted by a large majority the EU budget for 2015 and the amendments on surplus resources for 2014. The huge advantage of the agreement is that it will be able to pass the EU budget for 2015 later this year, i.e. next year it would not only be possible to pay 12th of this year's budget per month. By 2014, an additional €4 billion will be mobilised, of which EUR 3.5 billion will be the result of so-called 'fresh money', i.e. not transfers.  The EP only agreed to the adoption of next year's EU budget on the condition that the European Commission draws up a plan to reduce unpaid bills to sustainable levels. In 2014, €23.4 billion will have to be paid from the previous year. To this end, today's vote provides an additional resource of nearly EUR 4 billion. Today's decision by the European Parliament also provided agricultural and cohesion resources for Hungary in this year's and next year's budgets. The Hungarian People's Party delegation, together with the European People's Party, acted responsibly on behalf of the national interests of Hungary and voted in favour of the 2015 EU budget and all the reports contained in the related agreement. The agreement also includes reports mobilising the Solidarity Fund to mitigate the damage caused by natural disasters affecting different regions of Europe.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted against the report because the use of specific use reserves as aid for funds to repay wrong and frivolous decisions of previous policies distorts the credibility and solvency of the EU.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - Draft amending budget (POR) No 3/2014 to the 2014 general budget originally submitted by the Commission proposed an increase of EUR 1 568 million in revenue forecasts from fines and penalties and other revenues and an increase of EUR 4 738 million in payment appropriations in categories 1a, 1b, 2, and 4 of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) in order to meet payment needs by the end of the financial year, covering obligations arising from previous and current commitments. It should be noted that the implementation of the 2014-2020 MFF began with a huge accumulation of overdue payments, with unpaid bills reaching around €23.4 billion at the end of 2013 for cohesion policy only and the level of outstanding commitments (ADR) was around €221.7 billion at the end of 2013. The Council at great cost agreed with Parliament on 8 December 2014 with a view to forecasting that payments were strengthened in the 2014 budget in some budget lines of up to EUR 4 246 million, of which EUR 3 168 million will be mobilised through the 2014 unforeseen margin.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — Since 2010, there has been an increase in the increasing and cumulative effect of unpaid invoices and projects with suspended payments. This amending budget aims to solve such problems. However, it falls far short of the necessary amounts and, on the other hand, it channels funds to areas which we do not consider the most priority, depending on the urgent situation in the European Union, marked by economic and social inequalities. The letter from the European Parliament's Committee on Regional Development on the subject, which notes late payments in the cohesion category, amounts which already amount to EUR 23.4 billion at the end of 2013, is a demonstration of this. Money is channelled into instruments linked to security and defence policy, of which we strongly disagree. Reasons why we cannot vote in favour of this amending budget.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — The use of specific-use reserves as aid for funds to repay wrong and frivolous decisions of previous policies distorts the credibility and solvency of the EU, which is why I am voting against draft amending budget No 1. 3/2014

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - We can abstain from the amending budget No 3 on the ground that it gives a very insufficient solution to the problem of suspended payments and that it is part of an austericidal and insolidary agreement that includes the 2015 budget that We can reject.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the draft amending budget No 3/2014. However, I would like to highlight that this solves only a short-term problem and contributes to a really small extent to the reduction of the payment backlog in the EU budget. We cannot forget that this problem is structural and political in nature.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We can abstain from the amending budget No 3 on the ground that it gives a very insufficient solution to the problem of suspended payments and that it is part of an austericidal and insolidary agreement that includes the 2015 budget that We can reject.

name: Robert Jarosław IWASZKIEWICZ
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "Those who live beyond the state fall into debt. They are not able to repay their obligations, they reduce production, they try to survive. They often fall as bankrupt. The market is merciless and does not give scammers a chance. Around 4 000 small and medium-sized enterprises will collapse during the current four-day session in Strasbourg. Many of them will collapse because they will not be able to repay their credit obligations, many others because the EU bureaucracy is coming up with new rules that make it difficult for them to live and operate in Europe. The same bureaucracy that has lived beyond the state for years. The budget resolution voted on today perfectly demonstrates this. Already today, the EP wants to determine how many penalties will be added to the budget by all means in an attempt to balance the budget and to dump its funding on the shoulders of nation states and citizens. It's time to wake up. Europe is already waking up, and the time of EU bureaucracy living above state and preying on citizens' taxes is over. The market is fair and soon it will be time to pay bills for continuously borrowing and printing money.  I therefore voted against the budget resolutions.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a motion for a resolution on the Council's position on draft amendments to budget No 1009/2013. 3/2014 as I support the mobilisation of the contingency reserve due to the severe financial crisis the European Union is in. In this context, I also support the increase in payments in the 2014 budget and the increase in payment appropriations for individual titles. While these budget changes will not be enough to resolve all unpaid bills, they will partly alleviate the current situation. Greater accountability and a more competitive European economy are needed to prepare an adequate response to the crisis.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I voted against an increase in this year’s EU budget. We need to put the principles of added value and efficiency at the heart of budgetary decision-making in Europe. I want to see a real budget reform in the EU with a greater focus on generating growth and jobs, and areas that do not bring any real benefits to our constituents cut.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am voting in favour of Mr Deprez's report. With amending budget No 3/2014, which relates to higher revenues from fines, interest and repayments, the Commission has requested a strengthening of payment appropriations of around EUR 4.7 billion. They will be distributed between different budget lines. This proposal was at the heart of this year's negotiations. Most of the funds, some 3.4 billion, will be used to stabilise the phenomenon of outstanding bills under the cohesion policy heading, around EUR 0.6 billion for competitiveness, growth and employment for research programmes (Horizon 2020), SMEs (Cosme), youth training (Erasmus) and satellite navigation (Galileo) and, finally, around EUR 0.7 billion will be allocated to humanitarian aid.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — I have not been able to vote in favour of the draft amending budget because it is not a sufficient response to the hole in all the European Union budgets. These are defaults on the payrolls of EU officials, a problem that requires an urgent solution; however, these are defaults since the 2010 financial year and, again, these are about resolving patched crises that will aggravate the problem of non-payment by the European institutions in the medium term. We continue to play with the effective payment of millions of euros without proposing a new budgetary framework that will be able to solve the problem. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. - I voted in favour because this decision went with the amending budget in 2014.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I abstained because the Deprez report 'Draft amending budget No 1/2004' was adopted by the Committee on Budgetary Control. 3/2014: Revenue from fines, interest, refunds and repayments - Payment appropriations - Staff tables of the Commission, the Committee of the Regions and the European Data Protection Supervisor" does not adequately address the serious issues under consideration.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. - Amending budget No 3/2014 will serve to compensate for some of the late payments accumulated in 2014 and to support growth, employment and competitiveness through the financing of the Horizon 2020, COSME, Erasmus and other programmes. This budget, after lengthy discussions in the Council that have seen the opposition of the rigorist countries of northern Europe, will be taken from the margin for the unforeseen events of 2014, which has been increased on time. The budgetary rule should have enforced the limits set by the Multiannual Financial Framework for 2014, but faced with a balance of payments of EUR 4 billion out of the EUR 700 million provided for, we managed to approve the correction of this budget thanks, precisely, to the use of the 'margin for unforeseen events'.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the Deprez report, since it supports a necessary extension of the margin for payment, amounting to some EUR 4.7 million. I fully agree with the decision to allocate most of these resources to the stabilisation of the phenomenon of outstanding invoices, within the heading dedicated to cohesion policy.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — I rejected draft amending budget No 3 because it legitimises the misuse of member states' fines. These should be held exclusively by the European Union until the Member States have rectified the misconduct and should not be used to finance the European Community. This would lead to a existence on credit and may not succeed in the long run.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. "One hour before the vote, the text was still not available in my language! This shows what value is attached to the votes of European parliamentarians. In any case, the Commission does not care about our votes, as proof the 2015 budget comes back to us without modifications after we have rejected it. In those circumstances, I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — This amending budget is used to accommodate various amounts of order by realising appropriations for various types of funds.   These funds will be used to deal with various rubrics that were without the necessary financial allocation. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report as it emphasises the need to fully mobilise the Contingency Margin due to the outstanding additional payment appropriations required to meet year-end needs across the 2014 additional budget.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I have supported this draft amending budget No 3/2014 on revenue from fines and interest payments – Payment appropriations – Establishment plans of the Commission, the Committee of the Regions and the European Data Protection Supervisor.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. I voted against this draft amending budget 3/2014 which will of course not solve the structural difficulties of the current and future budgets of the European Union. The European Union should change its motto and replace its "Unite in Diversity" with a "Give me your watch, I will give you the time!". It is trying here to convince the Member States that they will have to give less in the years to come. How can we believe in such bonuses when we know that the EU will have to spend more and more to cover its unpaid bills, a debt that does not say its name and finance its remaining 220 billion commitments?

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the report by Mr Beazley on beazley: Deprez to cover the remaining requirements until the end of the year, by increasing the forecasts of revenue from fines and interest in addition to other appropriations, in order to meet the obligations arising from current and past commitments.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - I voted against the motion because, for me in particular, the financial transparency of the European Union and its institutions is a matter of course. It is not acceptable that invoices should also be paid retrospectively in the case of this application, which could have been taken into account at least roughly before.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I abstained on this draft amending budget because, although it allows the financing of a small part of the research programmes or the repayment of some beneficiaries of the European funds, I regret that the Member States have preferred to reduce their commitments to Europe just so as not to aggravate their national debt. This amending budget does nothing to resolve the critical general budgetary situation, nor does it put an end to the snowball effect of the accumulation of unpaid debts.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal to support the regular receipt of payments and that the budget meets the necessary conditions by the end of 2014.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Draft amending budget No 3/2014 in the 2014 general budget proposed to increase the estimates of revenue from fines and penalties and other revenue by EUR 1 568 million and payment appropriations by EUR 4 738 million to cover the remaining requirements until the end of the year in order to meet the obligations arising from past and current commitments. The implementation of the 2014-2020 MFF began with a huge backlog of payments and, of the total amount of PBR No 3/2014, only EUR 99 million is intended to cover the 2014-2020 programmes under cohesion policy. For these reasons, I would vote in favour.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — Budget amendment number 3 is part of a package of amendments that ensure that commitments already made under programmes and projects previously approved by the Council are settled and are already under implementation.  It is undeniable that commitments must be fulfilled and that we must take advantage of the flexibility within the given MFF. This amendment is necessary to pay the bills of programmes that have great strategic importance for the future of the EU. The most significant item in this budget change is the increase in the payment funds of the European Regional Development Fund – convergence, for which the funds for payment by this amendment of the budget have increased by €2.4 billion.  I think it is positive that this item, which aims to strengthen economic and social cohesion and reduce the imbalance of regions in the European Union, ultimately received support for the increase precisely as proposed by the European Commission. I am particularly pleased that the appropriations for the Eastern Partnership have been fully approved and to support cooperation with neighbouring countries where funds are earmarked for programmes to support Ukraine.  Timely approval of payments used in the fight to exercise human rights is essential for their effective use and I believe that the EU institutions will be able to respond more quickly to such challenges in the future.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Writing. — Although there are unproblematic positions in the improvements to the EU budget, the planned expenditure is clearly too high. While only EUR 121 billion is available, expenditure of EUR 145 billion is planned. The Commission cannot explain the fiscal miracles it is trying to make up for this deficit, nor can it support the signal sent by this budget. While more discipline is needed in the current crisis, the Commission is leading the EU Member States by example and presenting such an unbalanced budget. The picture that the Juncker Commission has provided so far fits in. Without orientation, it calls for higher public debt, without even being able to present a promising concept in the beginning. The role of the state is to be inflated more and more, measures to stimulate the economy exist only on paper. I do not support this draft budget, which repeats and deepens all the mistakes that cause the crisis.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — Negotiations on the 2014 and 2015 budgets concluded on December 8, 2014. And among these agreements, the Council has taken into account Parliament's concern about the amount of arrears. I therefore welcome such a measure to grant an extension of more than EUR 4 billion to the 2014 EU budget.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — having into account the joint declaration of Parliament, the Council and the Commission on payment appropriations, agreed in the joint conclusions of 12 November 2013 and Council Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 establishing the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) for the period 2014-2020; whereas draft amending budget (POR) No 3/2014 to the 2014 general budget proposed an increase of EUR 1568 million in revenue forecasts from fines and penalties and other revenues, and an increase of EUR 4738 million in payment appropriations in categories 1a, 1b, 2, 3a, 3b and 4 of the multiannual framework; as the implementation of the 2014-2020 MFF began with a huge accumulation of overdue payments, with unpaid invoices reaching around EUR 23.4 billion at the end of 2013, I voted in favour of the proposal to mobilise the margin for unforeseen events, which aims at implementing specific and maximum flexibility as a guarantee of compliance with Union obligations.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — After arduous negotiations, an agreement has been reached that will allow the payment of outstanding invoices, for which the amount of EUR 4.8 billion has been agreed for the period 2014-2015.  In addition, the Commission, the Council and Parliament have agreed on a payment plan aimed at reducing the level of unpaid invoices within the current multiannual framework. An unprecedented level of default has accumulated throughout this year.  The agreed EUR 4.8 billion will enable part of the accumulated invoices to be met, thus helping to alleviate the situation of many SMEs, universities, local authorities and NGOs. For 2015, it has been agreed to allocate EUR 145 321.5 million to commitment appropriations and EUR 141 214,040 563 million to payment appropriations. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - We can abstain from the amending budget No 3 on the ground that it gives a very insufficient solution to the problem of suspended payments and that it is part of an austericidal and insolidary agreement that includes the 2015 budget that We can reject.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - We can abstain from the amending budget No 3 on the ground that it gives a very insufficient solution to the problem of suspended payments and that it is part of an austericidal and insolidary agreement that includes the 2015 budget that We can reject.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I have not been able to vote in favour of the draft amending budget because it is not a sufficient answer for the hole in all the European Union budgets. These are defaults on the payrolls of EU officials, a problem that requires an urgent solution; however, these are defaults since the 2010 financial year and, again, these are about resolving patched crises that will aggravate the problem of non-payment by the European institutions in the medium term. We continue to play with the effective payment of millions of euros without proposing a new budgetary framework that will be able to solve the problem. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — I voted against draft amending budget No 3/2014 on the revenue from fines, interest payments, reimbursements and repayments.  We are against what has been dubbed ‘fresh money’ at the end of this year’s budget. We must put the principles of added value and efficiency at the heart of budgetary decision making in Europe.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — First of all, I would like to stress that the Parliament, the Council and the Commission committed by joint declaration of 12 November 2013 to ensure that the Union has the financial resources necessary to fulfil its legal obligations in 2014 by ensuring an orderly movement of payments and applying the different flexibility mechanisms covered by the Multiannual Financial Framework Regulation - MFF.  I support the Commission's proposal for a draft amendment to budget 3/2014, which calls for an increase in payments and proposes to use all available instruments to address the shortfall in payments in all items. In particular, I welcome the allocation of more than 70% of the amount requested, which, in general terms, is the main area in the EU budget affected by the shortfall in payments. I also call on the Commission to develop a long-term solution in this regard, and I encourage the Commission and the Council to apply all flexibility instruments under the Multiannual Financial Framework, the MFF, in order to further reduce the problem in the meantime.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — I support the proposal to amend the 2014 budget, which provides for increased revenues from penalties and interest, as we know how the debt has increased in recent years and reached €23.4 billion, exceeding the Commission's forecasts and expected to increase further. All flexibility instruments should be used to reduce debt. Parliament must report regularly on the expected development of payments. The aim of the changes will be met if we have a clear overview of past and present commitments that must be respected in order to avoid financial penalties.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — The use of specific-use reserves to support funds to repay wrong and frivolous decisions of previous policies distorts the credibility and solvency of the EU.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — The author of the proposal set out before us, MEPs, his reasons for endorsing the amendment in debate, in plenary session at the December session in Strasbourg. I therefore voted in favour of the text on the Council's position on the European Union's draft amending budget No. 3/2014 for the 2014 financial year, Section III - Commission.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. — I support all the measures taken in order to make a realistic budget and to apply all the flexibility instruments needed in order to come up with a long term solution in this respect. I welcome all transparency measures, such as a report back to the Parliament regularly on the expected evolution by the Commission.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — Since 2010 there has been an increase in the amount of outstanding invoices and projects with suspended payments. This budget aims to contribute to solving this problem, but falls far short of the amounts needed and channels funds into areas that are not the objective priority in a European Union urgently reducing economic and social inequalities.  An example of this is the letter from the Committee on Regional Development on the subject, which notes late payments in the cohesion category, amounts that already amount to EUR 23.4 billion at the end of 2013. However, the document also channels funds into instruments linked to security and defence policy, a policy with which we do not agree, either by its clear attack on the sovereignty of each country or by the unacceptable prospect of creating a Europe based on the force of arms.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — (DE) I voted against draft amending budget No 3, which legitimises the misuse of the member states' fines, rather than being kept in the middle of the European Union. It would be in the best interests of the Member States first to clear up the misconduct and not to use the money to finance the EU, as this would only result in a long-term credit existence.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. — (IT) I wanted to support this and the other amending budgets as a matter of responsibility. The situation in the European budget is indeed dramatic, with more than EUR 20 billion in debts still to be paid off. This agreement on 2014 certainly does not resolve the situation, but at least it allows the payment of some of the most urgent invoices that are still waiting. With the crisis situation and the general narrowness present in all the Member States, I believe it was impossible to achieve more than the result that was achieved after weeks of difficult negotiations. Unfortunately, my regret remains for 2015, as a wrong path has been chosen, which goes in the opposite direction to sound budgetary management: we will still increase debts, as there is a lack of resources to cover budgeted expenditure. A very dangerous and un serious choice has been made, which denoted a lack of responsibility on the part of several of my colleagues in this House: next year we will still be discussing the same issues, perhaps even aggravated, and I am sure that they will therefore all be forced to admit the failure of the strategy chosen in this first year of the new legislature, if they have the humility and reasonableness to do so.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — Since 2010 there has been an increase in the increasing and cumulative effect of unpaid invoices and projects with suspended payments. This amending budget is a test of solving this problem by falling far short of the necessary amounts and channelling funds into areas that are not the objective priority in a European Union urgently reducing economic and social inequalities. An example of this is the letter from the Committee on Regional Development on the subject that notes late payments in the Cohesion category, amounts that already amount to EUR 23.4 billion at the end of 2013. However, the document also channels funds into instruments related to security and defence policy, a policy with which we are in deep disagreement.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: Mr President, I will talk about the Mediterranean issue as many times as necessary, until we can have a satisfactory situation. The situation in the Mediterranean challenges us; 3,224 people drowned in the Mediterranean while trying to reach European soil, the International Organization for Migration recently reported. This drama is just one side of the complex phenomenon of immigration to our countries and to which, from this institution, we have to solve now: analyze its causes and effects from prudent and sensible positions, promote legal migration flows, development aid in countries of origin and an international policy that avoids humanitarian crises, a consequence of violence caused by totalitarianism , extreme greed, failed states and poverty. And, of course, we must relentlessly defend the management of immigration in the European Union and at borders with strict respect for human rights and the dignity of immigrants. Think global but act in local, ladies and gentlemen. It is inevitable to approach the local reality of immigration also in the border areas of the European Union. I consider a comprehensive approach to immigration fundamental.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr. President! I would like to point out once again that we have obtained the revised 2014 budget, that we have adopted a budget for 2015. The fact that we have not run into the feared liquidity bottlenecks is also due to the consistency and far-sighted conduct of the negotiations of our Parliament, which has found a way to ensure that the European Union as a whole is solvent by redeployment and by finding compromise. It would also have been a huge disgrace in public. On the one hand, we are talking about constantly re-launched investment programmes and, on the other hand, we have a liquidity bottleneck, so we would not have been able to pay bills that are in place quite simply. Just one example of how beautiful the world could be if the Member States paid their membership fees properly: we have had some whatsoever in revenue due to the falling gross domestic product. We have had some reductions in revenues due to reduced VAT sales. On the other hand, we have been able to take more punitive taxes. This balance would give rise to a plus. So the world would be beautiful. I appeal once again to the Member States to pay their membership fees properly.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this draft amending budget because it points to the problem of reducing Member States' contributions following the United Kingdom's decision to maintain its METHOD of calculating GDP. This report indicates the reduction, both in payments and credit, that certain European institutions will have to face because of this irresponsible decision. The proposal ensures that the necessary payments are made while criticising the consequences of reducing the European Union's own resources. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — Whilst a new Data Supervisor could not be appointed and this resulted in some saving, it also changes the expected contributions from Member States based upon macroeconomic data.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of all draft amending budgets for 2014 and for the agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council on the 2015 budget. I congratulate the Negotiators of the European Parliament on the eur 4.25 billion allocated to the emergency debts of this year's EU budget. The European Commission would be obliged to draw up a step-by-step plan for the reduction of outstanding bills and to establish a sustainable debt ceiling in the future. Thanks to Parliament, eur 0.5 billion will be allocated to commitments. than the COUNCIL of the EU proposed. More funding will be allocated to horizon 2020 and the Erasmus+ programme for student and youth exchange. It is to be welcomed that the increase in funding for European neighbourhood programmes, humanitarian aid and the common foreign security policy has been increased, which is very relevant in the light of today's situation in Europe. However, I do not support the reduction in funding for the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund, which will affect many EU farmers, who are in a particularly difficult situation because of the protracted Russian embargo and who need EU assistance.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour, because this draft amending budget will reduce the need for additional own resources for the Union budget by EUR 2 433 million which, together with amending budgets No 3, 8 and 6, will offset the payment needs requested in draft amending budget No 3, as set out in the conditions of 8 December 2014.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The European Parliament and the Council have reached agreement on a comprehensive draft including the new draft budget 2015 and the draft amending budgets (PBR) outstanding for 2014. It therefore includes the revision of the forecasts for traditional own resources (RPT, i.e. tariffs and contributions in the sugar sector) and VAT and GNI bases. It also includes the amount of British corrections and their funding, which have the effect of altering the remedy between Member States. Finally, it includes forecasts for other revenues, including fines. So I voted against this draft amending budget.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this measure, which deals with the revision of the forecasts for traditional own resources (TOR), i.e. contributions from the sugar and customs duties sectors, from the EU.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report which is part of the overall agreement to approve the 2014 amending budget and the 2015 budget. In particular, the purpose of this chapter is to review forecasts relating to traditional own resources (customs duties and contributions in the sugar sector), as well as to re-review forecasts of other revenues from a set of fines which have become final and can therefore be entered in the budget. It is therefore part of the comprehensive agreement that will allow the payment of outstanding invoices, for which the amount of EUR 4.7 billion has been agreed for the period 2014-2015. In addition, the Commission, the Council and Parliament have agreed on a payment plan aimed at reducing the level of unpaid invoices within the current multiannual framework. The agreed EUR 4.7 billion will enable part of the accumulated invoices to be met, thus helping to alleviate the situation of many SMEs, universities, local authorities and NGOs. For 2015, it has been agreed to allocate EUR 145 321.5 million to commitment appropriations and EUR 141 214,040 563 million to payment appropriations.  For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — The European Parliament and the Council have reached agreement on a comprehensive draft including the new draft budget 2015 and the draft amending budgets (PBR) outstanding for 2014. It therefore includes the revision of the forecasts for traditional own resources (RPT, i.e. tariffs and contributions in the sugar sector) and VAT and GNI bases. It also includes the amount of British corrections and their funding, which have the effect of altering the remedy between Member States. Finally, it includes forecasts for other revenues, including fines. So I voted against this draft amending budget.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the draft amending budget which aims to reduce budget appropriations for the European Data Protection Supervisor. I agree with the revision on traditional own resources, i.e. customs duties and levies for the sugar sector, but also the inclusion in the budget of the relevant corrections, as well as their financing as a result of the change in the allocation of these own resources between Member States and contributions from the EU budget. I am convinced that the overall impact on revenues will represent a substantial decrease in the conditions of own resources and will constitute important aid for all EU Member States.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. Revision of the forecasts for traditional own resources (TOR, i.e. customs duties and sugar levies) and VAT and GNI bases, as well as the accounting of the relevant UK corrections and their financing, which involve a change in the distribution between Member States of contributions to the EU budget from own resources. Realisation of EUR 248 460 from appropriations for the European Data Protection Supervisor (due to delay in appointment) to humanitarian aid. Revenue increase of EUR 3.85 billion, mainly due to the inclusion in the budget of fines and default interest which have become final, resulting in relief from contributions from Member States.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — (IT) We agree with this draft budget which reallocated some funds to the humanitarian aid lines.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) This draft amending budget has more technical than political value in that it confines itself to accounting for certain additional revenue, some lower expenditure and a redistribution of resources between the budget headings. My vote in favour is in fact a mere acknowledgeee.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of amending budget No 4/2014, which mainly concerns a surplus in the 2013 budget, i.e. an update of the revenue forecasts from both VAT and certain fines. During the negotiations with the Council, Parliament decided to set up a 'package' with the otherBR, to compensate for the increased unforeseen revenue, with the payment needs contained in the other amending budgets.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of this report so that the European Union can fulfil its obligations, and since this Draft Amending Budget (DAB) is crucial to avoid cash shortages that could lead to an implementation deficit in 2014.  Adoption of DAB No4/2014 will reduce the need for additional own resources for the Union Budget.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — Draft amending budget No 4/2014 provides for a reduction in resources for the European Data Protection Supervisor, a revision of the forecasts for traditional own resources, such as customs duties and sugar levies, and a revision of the forecasts for other revenue from fines. This implies a change in the size and distribution among the Member States of their contributions to the Union budget from own resources. I am voting in favour of this resolution as the adoption of PBR 4/2014 will reduce the need for additional own resources for the Union budget which, together with the reduction in member states' contributions based on gross national income to the Union budget, will fully compensate for the additional payment requirements required in PBR 3/2014, as agreed in the Joint Conclusions of 8 December 2014.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this draft amending budget because it points to the problem of reducing Member States' contributions following the United Kingdom's decision to maintain its METHOD of calculating GDP. This report indicates the reduction, both in payments and credit, that certain European institutions will have to face because of this irresponsible decision. The proposal ensures that the necessary payments are made while criticising the consequences of reducing the European Union's own resources. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — This Draft Amending Budget concerns a revision of the forecast of traditional own resources, i.e. customs duties and sugar sector levies, VAT and Gross National Income (GNI) bases, and the budgeting of the relevant UK corrections. It also reduces budgetary commitment and payment appropriations for the European Data Protection Supervisor and proposes some modifications to the nomenclature of the European Regional Development Fund to reflect the adopted legal basis. Keeping in mind that this DAB is crucial to avoid cash shortages that could lead to an implementation deficit in 2014 I voted in favour of it.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. This draft amending budget No. 4 reports on the decline in own resources but at the same time budgets for additional income from fines and late payments amounting to EUR 2.433 billion, thereby reducing the contribution of Member States. It should also be noted that this amending budget redirects appropriations into payments for humanitarian aid for 2014.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. — The European Parliament today adopted by a large majority the EU budget for 2015 and the amendments on surplus resources for 2014. The huge advantage of the agreement is that it will be able to pass the EU budget for 2015 later this year, i.e. next year it would not only be possible to pay 12th of this year's budget per month. By 2014, an additional €4 billion will be mobilised, of which EUR 3.5 billion will be the result of so-called 'fresh money', i.e. not transfers. The EP only agreed to the adoption of next year's EU budget on the condition that the European Commission draws up a plan to reduce unpaid bills to sustainable levels. In 2014, €23.4 billion will have to be paid from the previous year. To this end, today's vote provides an additional resource of nearly EUR 4 billion. Today's decision by the European Parliament also provided agricultural and cohesion resources for Hungary in this year's and next year's budgets. The Hungarian People's Party delegation, together with the European People's Party, acted responsibly on behalf of the national interests of Hungary and voted in favour of the 2015 EU budget and all the reports contained in the related agreement. The agreement also includes reports mobilising the Solidarity Fund to mitigate the damage caused by natural disasters affecting different regions of Europe.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted against the report because the revision of the traditional own resources forecasts is done to satisfy the policies of specific countries and not for the good of the citizens as a whole.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - Draft amending budget (POR) No 4/2014 covers a review of traditional own resources (RPT) forecasts, i.e. customs duties and levies in the sugar sector), the VAT and Gross National Income (GNI) bases, the budgeting of corrections for the United Kingdom, and a review of the forecasts for other revenue stemming from fines, giving rise to a change in the level and distribution between Member States of their contributions to the Union budget under own resources. This POR No 4/2014, as amended by amending letter 1, covers a review of traditional own resources forecasts (PTRs, i.e. customs duties and levies in the sugar sector), on the basis of the Commission's calculations and other elements, as well as a review of the forecasts for other revenue stemming from fines which have become final and may therefore be entered in the budget. The decrease in THERs, estimated at around EUR 646.1 million, and the VAT-based own resource estimated at EUR 192.4 million, is offset by the above-mentioned fines of eur 2 433 million and therefore automatically reduces the need for additional GNI-based contributions by EUR 1 594.5 million.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — This 4th Amending Budget aims to cover a review of traditional own resources (PR) forecasts, such as customs duties and sugar sector levies, VAT and GNI bases, the budgeting of corrections corresponding to the United Kingdom, the review of revenue stemming from fines. This results in a change in the level and distribution between Member States of contributions to the general EU budget under these resources. While traditional PCs by EUR 646.1 million and VAT-based PR are falling by EUR 192.4 million, on the other hand there is an increase in fines and interest on late payment of EUR 2.433 million. Since then, national GNI-based contributions are reduced by EUR 1,594.5 million. We disagree with this option. We disagree that national contributions should be aleded, a measure benefiting large countries and impoverishing the redistributive function of the budget. What was required was an extra strengthening of a very small budget to meet the objectives of cohesion – which are increasingly mere dead letter in the treaties. In this case, it is proposed to reduce the appropriations of the European Data Protection Supervisor by channelling them into humanitarian aid.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — The revision of the traditional own resources forecasts is done to satisfy the policies of specific countries and not for the good of the citizens as a whole. That is why I am voting against draft amending budget No 10. 4/2014

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. " Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa Alignment with the 2014 budget has been adopted and congratulations are due to every vote in favour.
