The negotiations between Parliament and the Council have been difficult, but the difficulties that have accompanied them go away in oblivion just as some of the outstanding bills will go away. An additional €4.25 billion to settle unpaid bills from 2014, including more than €4 billion in contingency margins, will certainly help stabilise EU debt. A permanent postponement of their payment would only drill holes in the next annual budgets. We must make every effort to make the promise of a full fiscal balance by 2016 a reality. The main purpose of the repayment plan is to gradually reduce their amount, and this is important to bear in mind. We are pleased that payments to companies working on projects paid for by EU funds in the Member States will finally be settled. It is also welcome that the European Parliament is already feeling very good at the table where it sits with the Commission and the Council.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - We can abstain from amending budget No 4 on the ground that it gives a very insufficient solution to the problem of suspended payments and that it is part of an austericidal and insolidary agreement that includes the 2015 budget that We can reject.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for the proposal for a Resolution on the Council's position on draft amendments to budget No 1000/2013. 4/2014 as these amendments will reduce the need for additional own resources for the European Union budget and will also reduce the resources earmarked for the European Data Protection Supervisor. The amendments, which are primarily based on a revision of the forecasts of traditional own resources and VAT and GNI bases, also take into account the final fines that can be entered into the budget.  In my view, the changes to budget No. 4/2014 balanced and will, at least in part, benefit the financial stability of the Union.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We can abstain from amending budget No 4 on the ground that it gives a very insufficient solution to the problem of suspended payments and that it is part of an austericidal and insolidary agreement that includes the 2015 budget that We can reject.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - Draft amending budget No 4/2014 mainly concerns a surplus in the 2013 budget, which consists of an update of the revenue forecasts both from VAT and from certain fines. During the negotiations, Parliament strategically decided to form a 'package' with the other PBR, in order to compensate for the increased unforeseen revenue, with the payment needs contained in the other amending budgets.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this draft amending budget because it points to the problem of reducing Member States' contributions following the United Kingdom's decision to maintain its METHOD of calculating GDP. This report indicates the reduction, both in payments and credit, that certain European institutions will have to face because of this irresponsible decision. The proposal ensures that the necessary payments are made while criticising the consequences of reducing the European Union's own resources. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. — The adoption of this motion for a Resolution on draft amending budget No 4/2014 will reduce the need for additional own resources for the Union budget by EUR 2 433 million and will therefore serve to, together with actions to reduce the contribution of GNI of the Member States to the Union budget resulting from PPRs No 3/2014, No 8/2014 and No 6/2014, fully offset the needs for additional payments requested in PPR No 3/2014, as agreed in the joint conclusions of 8 December 2014. That is why I voted in favour of this proposal

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — The European Commission has included in amending draft budget number 4 the amount of EUR 2.4 billion created by collecting penalties and interest on late payments. The €2.4 billion will cover a deficit of €838.5 million resulting from a smaller influx of the Union's own resources (a deficit of €646.1 million based on import duties and a VAT-based shortfall of €192.4 million).  I supported the Report amending draft budget number 4, as this is an inclusion of realised revenues, which will allow to reduce contributions based on gross national income by 1.59 billion, the same way to reduce the burden on Member States' budgets.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. - I voted in favour because this decision went with the amending budget in 2014.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. - Amending budget No 4/2014 concerns, in particular, the general state of revenue and expenditure. in line with the adjustment of the 2014 financial statements for other matters. Here, too, the Commission had to increase the estimated revenue figure to almost EUR 4 billion during the negotiations. The updating of the revenue figures depends mainly on the revenue received as a result of fines and the reduction in administrative expenditure.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the report 'Deprez Draft amending budget No 1/2004'. 4/2014 - traditional own resources (PIP), VAT bases and gross national income (GNI)', because it adequately addresss the issues under consideration.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — (IT) The document signed by Mr Deprez on the draft amending budget refers to an addition to the budget for 2013, which takes account of forecasts of revenue from VAT and the payment of fines.  The report seems rational and comprehensive, and that is why I thought it appropriate to support it with my vote in favour.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — Since some of the factors in the amending budget may well seem positive, such as amending budgets Nos 4, 6 and 8, it might be considered that the drafts should be approved as a whole. However, the fact that the overall budget is still far too high to be able to finance it sensibly and, above all, sustainably over the next few years, weighs more heavily and I reject it.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — As every year, the EU is increasing its amending budgets (9 in 2013) without succeeding in rectifying its delicate budgetary situation. Due to the historic contraction of the 2014 budget (down $10 billion, or less 6%), unpaid debts continue to accumulate without being able to finance any new priority. This amending budget allows for the recording of new exceptional revenues from fines levied by the EU. But far from subsidizing the budget to reduce unpaid debts, this resource is offset by a decrease in contributions normally having been added by states. This new austere manipulation is aberrant because the amount of fines is by definition unstable. Europe is sinking into short-sighted mismanagement. Having already voted against the 2014 budget in November 2013, I am voting against this amending budget, which is as artificial as it is derisory.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — This draft amending budget (POR) No 4/2014 covers a review of traditional own resources (PTR) forecasts, i.e. customs duties and levies in the sugar sector), the VAT and Gross National Income (GNI) bases, the budgeting of the corresponding Corrections of the United Kingdom and a revision of the forecasts for other revenue stemming from fines, resulting in a change in the level and distribution between Member States of their contributions to the Union budget under own resources. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it highlights the various measures agreed by the Commission, Council and Parliament to balance the additional funds required from Member States for DAB No 3/2014. I also support the adoption of DAB No 4/2014 as it will reduce the need for additional own resources for the Union budget.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I am in agreement with the draft amending budget No 4/2014 on traditional own resources (TOR), VAT and Gross National Income (GNI) bases.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The Council, the Commission and the European Parliament have finally reached agreement on the European Union's draft 2015 general budget and the last "package" of the 2014 amending budgets (PBR). Among the amending budgets, number 4 includes a revision of the forecasts for traditional own resources (TRP) (tariffs and contributions in the sugar sector), VAT bases and the gross national income of Member States (GNI). This amending budget also takes into account the amount of UK corrections and how they are financed, which will have a direct impact on the distribution of Member States' contributions. This PBR 4 also contains forecasts for other revenues and in particular fines. I have obviously voted against this draft amending budget No. 4 on the grounds that I oppose any transfer of national, budgetary and other sovereignty.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of draft amending budget No 4/2014, which provides for an update and revision of the forecasts relating to customs duties and contributions in the sugar sector, the basis of VAT and gross national income, and other revenue from fines, thus entailing a change in the distribution between Member States of their contributions to the Union budget from own resources.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. — I voted for this draft which provides for budgetary adjustments in relation to the recalculation of the tax base and the calculation of financial resources in the Budget of the European Union. This correction illustrates the difficulties faced by the European Union in the correct and coherent record of the gross national income of each Member State and the calculation of the rate of contributions to the common European budget.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I abstained on this draft amending budget because, although it allows the financing of a small part of the research programmes or the repayment of some beneficiaries of the European funds, I regret that the Member States have preferred to reduce their commitments to Europe just so as not to aggravate their national debt. This amending budget does nothing to resolve the critical general budgetary situation, nor does it put an end to the snowball effect of the accumulation of unpaid debts.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal because it will contribute significantly to increasing the efficiency of the European Union's spending.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Draft amending budget (PBR) No 4/2014 concerns a revision of the forecasts for traditional own resources and the basis of VAT and gross national income (GNI), the accounting of the relevant UK corrections and a revision of the forecasts for other revenue from fines, and therefore involves a change in the size and distribution among Member States of their contributions to the Union budget from own resources. PBR No 4/2014 is essential to avoid liquidity shortages that could lead to an implementation deficit in 2014. For these reasons, I would vote in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. — The draft amending budget No. 6 provides for the reduction of budgetary appropriations for the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and the reserve for sustainable fisheries partnership agreements, for a total of EUR 76.3 million in commitment appropriations and EUR 6.2 million in payment credits. At the same time, this PBR provides for an increase in budgetary appropriations to the European Ombudsman to the amount of EUR 93,500. This draft amending budget is once again poorly implemented and will result in a reduction in the appropriations reserved for fishing professionals, who are facing very serious difficulties. Moreover, there is no evidence to assess the amount of the decrease in the GNI share for France. Finally, how can a general reduction in member states' GNI contribution be seriously envisaged at a time when the European Union is facing a serious payments crisis? These cosmetic measures will absolutely not solve the budgetary crisis facing the Union. That is why I have decided to vote against PBR 6/2014.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — Amending budget number 4 is an integral part of the package of amendments that ensure the balancing of budget revenues and expenditures for 2014.  In recent weeks, a compromise has been sought through the trilogue over the final amount of payments. In my view, the proposed amendments are the minimum necessary to meet the obligations incurred by implementing a large number of programmes and projects that have already been approved by the Council and are already at various stages of implementation. It goes without saying that we must fulfil our commitments, adhering to the default MFF and at the same time taking advantage of other revenues incurred from fines.  In my view, the unquestionable revision of budget financing from traditional own resources to be paid into the budget in 2014, as well as the revision of value added tax bases and gross national income for 2014, is unquestionable. It is a well-established practice where up-to-date economic forecasts are the basis for more accurate revenue forecasts and accordingly more accurate payments from Member States to the budget. Similarly, in the case of the United Kingdom, a correction is being made to offset the net 'windfall gains' of traditional own resources, relating to the period 2011-2013. With these corrections, we follow the rules that have been in the case since 2007 defined by the Council Decision on the European Communities' own resources system (2007/436/EC, Euratom).

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — Through this text, it is up to the European Parliament to approve the revision of certain budget lines for 2014, including the inclusion of fines and the revision of Britain's contribution to the European budget. I am in favour of such a measure.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — Whereas draft amending budget (POR) No 4/2014 covers a review of traditional own resources forecasts (customs duties and levies in the sugar sector, providing for a reduction of EUR 2 433 million), the VAT and Gross National Income (GNI) bases - automatically reducing the need for additional GNI-based contributions by EUR 1594.5 million), the budgeting of the corresponding UK corrections and a review of the forecasts for other revenue stemming from fines, resulting in a change in the level and distribution between Member States of their contributions to the Union budget in respect of own resources. Since por no 4/2014 also reduces commitment and payment appropriations to the European Data Protection Supervisor by EUR 248 460 and is essential to avoid liquidity shortages likely to lead to an implementation shortfall in 2014, I voted in favour of this resolution approving the Council's position on draft amending budget No 4/2014.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — After arduous negotiations, an agreement has been reached that will allow the payment of outstanding invoices, for which the amount of EUR 4.8 billion has been agreed for the period 2014-2015. In addition, the Commission, the Council and Parliament have agreed on a payment plan aimed at reducing the level of unpaid invoices within the current multiannual framework. An unprecedented level of default has accumulated throughout this year.  The agreed EUR 4.8 billion will enable part of the accumulated invoices to be met, thus helping to alleviate the situation of many SMEs, universities, local authorities and NGOs. For 2015, it has been agreed to allocate EUR 145 321.5 million to commitment appropriations and EUR 141 214,040 563 million to payment appropriations. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - We can abstain from amending budget No 4 on the ground that it gives a very insufficient solution to the problem of suspended payments and that it is part of an austericidal and insolidary agreement that includes the 2015 budget that We can reject.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - We can abstain from amending budget No 4 on the ground that it gives a very insufficient solution to the problem of suspended payments and that it is part of an austericidal and insolidary agreement that includes the 2015 budget that We can reject.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this draft amending budget because it points to the problem of reducing Member States' contributions following the UNITED Kingdom's decision to maintain its METHOD of calculating GDP. This report indicates the reduction, both in payments and credit, that certain European institutions will have to face because of this irresponsible decision. The proposal ensures that the necessary payments are made while criticising the consequences of reducing the European Union's own resources. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — I voted with the majority to support draft amending budget No 4/2014 on traditional own resources (TOR), VAT and gross national income (GNI) bases.  Draft amending budget No 4/2014 calls for a revision of the forecast of TOR, VAT and Gross National Income (GNI) bases, the budgeting of the relevant UK corrections, and a revision of the forecast of other revenue arising from fines. This would result in a change in the level and distribution between Member States of their own resources contributions to the Union budget.  The adoption of DAB No 4/2014 will reduce the need for additional own resources for the Union budget by EUR 2 433 million and will therefore, together with the reduced shares of the GNI contribution from Member States to the Union budget, fully compensate for the additional payment needs requested in DAB No 3/2014, as agreed in the joint conclusions of 8 December 2014.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — I supported the Report amending draft budget number 4, as this is an inclusion of realised revenues, which will allow to reduce contributions based on gross national income by 1.59 billion and thus reduce the burden on Member States. In amending the draft budget number 4, the European Commission included €2.4 billion created by collecting penalties and interest on late payments. The €2.4 billion will cover a deficit of €838.5 million resulting from a smaller influx of the Union's own resources (a deficit of €646.1 million based on import duties and a VAT-based shortfall of €192.4 million).

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — I support the draft amendment to the 2014 budget (DAB) relating to the revision of own resources and VAT and GNI bases of the UK budget and the revision of the forecast of other revenues from fines, resulting in the distribution of contributions from own resources between Member States.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — The revision of the traditional own resources forecasts is done to satisfy the policies of specific countries and not for the good of the citizens as a whole.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — The author of the proposal set out before us, MEPs, his reasons for endorsing the amendment in debate, in plenary session at the December session in Strasbourg. I therefore voted in favour of the text on the Council's position on the European Union's draft amending budget No. 4/2014 for the 2014 financial year, Section III - Commission.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — This 4th Amending Budget for 2014 covers a review of traditional own resources (PR) forecasts such as customs duties and sugar sector levies, VAT and GNI bases, the budgeting of corrections corresponding to the United Kingdom, review of revenue stemming from fines, resulting in a change in the level and distribution between Member States and their contributions to the EU general budget , under these resources. While traditional PCs are falling by EUR 646.1 million and VAT-based PR by EUR 192.4 million, on the other hand there is an increase in fines and interest on late payment of EUR 2 433 million and therefore automatically reduces the need for additional GNI-based contributions by EUR 1 594.5 million. This should not serve to lighten national contributions, but as an extra boost to an already limited budget to meet the Union's cohesion objectives. This amending budget is proposed to reduce the appropriations for commitments and payments for the European Data Protection Supervisor, channelling it into the humanitarian aid heading.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — Since this proposal would, among other things, also mean a higher burden on Austria, I rejected it in principle. Partial payment options are a welcome idea, but the proposal itself makes it impossible for me to agree. In addition, this proposal forms the basis for amending budgets 3, 4, 6 and 8. In this respect, the amending budgets mentioned above were also to be rejected.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — This 4th Amending Budget for 2014 aims to cover a review of traditional own resources (PR) forecasts, such as customs duties and sugar sector levies, VAT and GNI bases, the budgeting of corrections corresponding to the United Kingdom, review of revenue stemming from fines, resulting in a change in the level and distribution between Member States and their contributions to the EU general budget , under these resources. While traditional PCs are falling by EUR 646.1 million and VAT-based PR by EUR 192.4 million, on the other hand there is an increase in fines and interest on late payment of EUR 2 433 million, automatically reducing the need for additional GNI-based contributions by EUR 1 594.5 million. This should not serve to lighten national contributions but as an extra boost to an already tight budget.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — The Commission proposes that the European Union Solidarity Fund be mobilmised in relation to flooding in Italy (Cerdeña) of November 2013, an earthquake in Greece (Kefalonia), ice storms in Slovenia, and the same ice storms followed by flooding in Croatia from late January - early February 2014, on the basis of paragraph 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013. I am in favour of this, so I voted in favour of this report.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of all draft amending budgets for 2014 and for the agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council on the 2015 budget. I congratulate the Negotiators of the European Parliament on the eur 4.25 billion allocated to the emergency debts of this year's EU budget. The European Commission would be obliged to draw up a step-by-step plan for the reduction of outstanding bills and to establish a sustainable debt ceiling in the future. Thanks to Parliament, eur 0.5 billion will be allocated to commitments. than the COUNCIL of the EU proposed. More funding will be allocated to horizon 2020 and the Erasmus+ programme for student and youth exchange. It is to be welcomed that the increase in funding for European neighbourhood programmes, humanitarian aid and the common foreign security policy has been increased, which is very relevant in the light of today's situation in Europe. However, I do not support the reduction in funding for the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund, which will affect many EU farmers, who are in a particularly difficult situation because of the protracted Russian embargo and who need EU assistance.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. — I approved the proposal to provide a total of almost 49 million euros through the European Union Solidarity Fund for Italy (floods in Sardinia in November 2013), Greece (earthquake in Cephalonia) and Slovenia and Croatia affected by ice storms and floods at the end of January-early February 2014.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. — The EU has a Solidarity Fund and a Regulation with provisions for the use of them. Italy, Greece, Slovenia and Croatia have requested these funds for floods, earthquakes, ice storms and flood-followed storms, respectively, and comply with the provisions of the Regulation. That is why I voted in favour so that with the funds they receive they can solve the problems they have suffered.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The mobilization of this EU Solidarity Fund for Italy (Sardinia), which faced floods in November 2013, Greece (Cefalonia), the scene of an earthquake, Slovenia, hit by ice storms, and Croatia, hit by the same ice storms, followed by floods, at the end of January-early February 2014 is vital. It will thus bring almost EUR 47 million to these regions and that is why I voted for this mobilization.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of allocating EUR 47 million to Sardinia, Greece and Slovenia affected by major natural disasters.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in relation to flooding in Italy (Cerdeña) in November 2013, an earthquake in Kefalonia (Greece) which caused numerous casualties and left 3,000 people homeless, ice storms in Slovenia, and the same ice storms followed by flooding in Croatia in late January - early February 2014. With this decision, the affected areas will be able to benefit from joint aid of around EUR 47 million to help alleviate the consequences of these disasters.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted on this report because it supported Parliament's decision on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund. The funds will be allocated to Italy (Sardinia) in november 2013. floods, Greece (Kefalona Island) due to the earthquake, Slovenia due to ice storms and Croatia due to ice storms and subsequent floods. In 2013, Heavy rains hit Sardinia, Italy, causing large swooping from the shores and causing massive floods. 2014 A violent earthquake (5.8 points on the Richter scale) occurred in the north-east of Kefalolian Island, followed by several strong underground strikes, leaving 3,000 people homeless and several dead. Slovenia has been hit by one of the worst winter storms in decades, devastating parts of Europe and causing damage in several countries. Slovenia was hit hardest in 2014, when almost half of the country's forests were devastated by ice, and a quarter of homes were left without electricity after heavy snowfall and exhausting. Croatia has suffered from the same meteorological phenomenon that Slovenia had to seek help from the EU Solidarity Fund. The north-western regions and parts of the northern Adriatic region have been particularly affected. In addition, the introduction of ice and snow was the result of flooding, which caused even more damage to important major public infrastructures and private and public property.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted for this because we need to have concrete help for the zones in the European Union which have suffered natural catastrophes.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. If we do not endorse the Union's cohesion policy and believe that it does not alleviate economic and social disparities between Member States, we believe that the principle of European solidarity can make sense when one of our European neighbours is seriously affected by a natural disaster. Moreover, the climatic events that have hit the south of France in recent months reinforce the idea that mutual financial assistance must enable us to better respond to the human, material and financial consequences of this type of tragic event. Common management of natural risks must be encouraged at European level in order to strengthen risk pooling. That is why I voted for the mobilization of this solidarity fund.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — Vote in favour of the measure (linked to draft amending budget No 5 for the financial year 2014). In this case, the EU Solidarity Fund is activated for an amount of EUR 46 998 528 in commitment and payment appropriations. The activation concerns: the floods that occurred in Italy (Sardinia) in November 2013; the earthquake in Greece (Kefalonia); snowstorms that hit Slovenia and the same storms, followed by floods, to which Croatia was the victim in late January-early February 2014.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. — The report proposes that the European Union Solidarity Fund be mobilized in relation to flooding in Italy (Cerdeña) in November 2013, an earthquake in Greece (Kefalonia), ice storms in Slovenia and ice storms followed by flooding in Croatia at the end of January - early February 2014, on the basis of paragraph 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013. In parallel with this proposal to mobilise the Solidarity Fund, the Commission has submitted a draft amending budget (PPR No 5/2014 of 8.9.2014), with a view to entering in the 2014 budget the corresponding commitment and payment appropriations — EUR 46 998 528 — as provided for in paragraph 26 of the IA.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — (IT) The tragedies in Italy and Greece and the great inconveniences in Slovenia deserve financial support. I am thinking in particular of the floods in northern Italy in recent months, caused by a careless consumption of land carried out without proper controls and without secureing the new infrastructure. Politicians in my country must learn that building speculation in those areas generates death and wipe out entire communities.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) I fully support the political elements of this document. The call for greater flexibility in the EU budget and, above all, the allocation of funds to help parts of European (and Italian) territory that have been affected by natural disasters are always a principle worth upholding, which I did with my vote in favour.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to respond to major natural disasters and express European solidarity with affected regions in Europe. The Fund may provide financial assistance to Member States and candidate countries negotiating their participation. Italy, Greece, Slovenia and Croatia have been affected by different types of natural disasters – floods, earthquakes and snowandstorms – which have caused considerable damage in those Member States. I support the mobilisation of EUR 46 998 528 in favour of the Member States concerned, which contributes to the EU demonstrating its solidarity and support for the affected countries by contributing to the financing of urgent measures, such as the immediate restoration of the operation of infrastructure and equipment in the fields of energy production, the supply of drinking water, the treatment of waste water , telecommunications, transport, health and education; the implementation of provisional housing measures and the provision of relief services to meet the immediate needs of the affected population; the immediate consolidation of preventive infrastructure and the protection of cultural heritage sites; immediate cleanliness of disaster areas, including natural areas.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - Considering that the European Union has set up the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF, ) to respond to major natural disasters and express its solidarity with the affected regions within the EU, I welcome the decision we have taken, which will enable the affected populations to have resources to support reconstruction and the return to normality as soon as possible. Another problem that remains open is, on the other hand, that of "special instruments" to be financed from resources above the annual ceilings set. I believe, in fact, that natural disasters cannot be foreseen or avoided, and therefore the Union cannot and must never make the necessary funds go away, without prejudicing the other objectives to be achieved. I hope that political agreement can be reached on this in 2015.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — The European Union has created a European Union Solidarity Fund to show solidarity with the population of regions struck by disasters. I have voted in favour of this report to enable the mobilisation of the European Solidarity Fund in favour of floods in Italy, an earthquake in Greece, ice storms in Slovenia and the same ice storms, followed by floods, in Croatia, which damaged private and public infrastructure, including households, and which had repercussions on the conditions and economic stability of the regions concerned.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — The Commission has proposed the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund following floods in Italy (Sardinia) in November 2013, an earthquake in Greece (Kefalonia), ice storms in Slovenia and the same ice storms, followed by floods in Croatia at the end of January/early February 2014. I could only vote in favour of this resolution because the EU Commission has provided eur 16 310 467 to deal with the situation in Sardinia, which has been hit by torrential rain, which has caused rivers to be flooded and severely flooded. Overall, including Greece, Slovenia and Croatia, appropriations of around EUR 47 million are available.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — The Commission proposes that the European Union Solidarity Fund be mobilmised in relation to flooding in Italy (Cerdeña) of November 2013, an earthquake in Greece (Kefalonia), ice storms in Slovenia, and the same ice storms followed by flooding in Croatia from late January - early February 2014, on the basis of paragraph 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013. I am in favour of this, so I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — While, Italy and Greece were affected by non-related, different types of disasters, one of the worst winter blizzards in Europe damaged several countries, with particularly damaging effects to Slovenia and Croatia. The Commission proposed to mobilise the EU solidarity Fund for a total amount of EUR 46 998 528. Solidarity is a main pillar of our Union; therefore, I voted in favour of granting this support.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. — I welcome the vote on the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund within the general budget of the European Union in the form of commitment and payment appropriations for advance payments, and I believe that this measure is a real measure of solidarity, which supports the european citizens affected.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. — Different types of natural disasters (floods, earthquakes and ice storms) caused considerable damage in Italy in November 2013, Greece, Slovenia and Croatia in late January/early February 2014. The Solidarity Fund enables the European Union to provide effective assistance to a Member State or a country in the process of accession when it has to deal with the damage caused by a major natural disaster. It is proposed to bring in this fund for Italy to the tune of EUR 16 310 467, for Greece to the tune of EUR 3,683,320, for Slovenia to the tune of EUR 18,388,478 and finally for Croatia to the tune of EUR 8,616,263. In the name of European solidarity with the Member States of the Union and the accession countries and their inhabitants who are experiencing a period of great difficulty, I voted in favour of this financial support.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. Italy, Greece, Slovenia and Croatia were hit by natural disasters in 2013 and 2014. Severe weather hit Croatia, Slovenia and Italy, while Greece suffered an earthquake. In the face of these dramatic situations, the support of the European Union is welcome. With more than 46 million euros mobilized through the Solidarity Fund, this aid will help meet the needs of affected populations and rehabilitate infrastructure affected by these disasters.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to deal with serious natural disasters and to express European solidarity with the regions of Europe affected by disasters. I supported the mobilisation of the Fund in favour of Italy, Greece, Slovenia and Croatia. In particular, with regard to Italy, the EUSF will financially support Sardinia, which was hit on 18 and 19 November 2013 by violent torrential rains that caused rivers to be flooded and severe floods.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. — The European Parliament today adopted by a large majority the EU budget for 2015 and the amendments on surplus resources for 2014. The huge advantage of the agreement is that it will be able to pass the EU budget for 2015 later this year, i.e. next year it would not only be possible to pay 12th of this year's budget per month. By 2014, an additional €4 billion will be mobilised, of which EUR 3.5 billion will be the result of so-called 'fresh money', i.e. not transfers.  The EP only agreed to the adoption of next year's EU budget on the condition that the European Commission draws up a plan to reduce unpaid bills to sustainable levels. In 2014, €23.4 billion will have to be paid from the previous year. To this end, today's vote provides an additional resource of nearly EUR 4 billion. Today's decision by the European Parliament also provided agricultural and cohesion resources for Hungary in this year's and next year's budgets. The Hungarian People's Party delegation, together with the European People's Party, acted responsibly on behalf of the national interests of Hungary and voted in favour of the 2015 EU budget and all the reports contained in the related agreement. The agreement also includes reports mobilising the Solidarity Fund to mitigate the damage caused by natural disasters affecting different regions of Europe.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. — The important contributions of the Member States must be given to Europeans and in particular to those affected by natural disasters. It is a healthy and sincere solidarity that I support, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the report because, although there are clearly fewer funds available to repair earthquake damage in Greece (Kefalonia), any assistance is desirable.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. — In January 2014 I had the pleasure of being the rapporteur of the European Parliament's report for the reform of Regulation (EC) No 2012/2002, which establishes and regulates the EU Solidarity Funds. The objective of mobilizing these funds is to minimize the immediate and direct impact of natural disasters. The help of these funds covers some of the costs of emergency services action and the reconstruction and reactivation of the most necessary infrastructures and services. Flooding in Italy or Croatia, the Earthquake of Greece and the frosts of Slovenia require effective action. In this sense, the Solidarity Funds not only have an effect on the recovery of these more basic infrastructures, such as roads or railways, but also have a considerable impact in recovering and stabilizing the economic and social activity of regions affected by natural disasters. The Solidarity Funds are a fundamental instrument for promoting and strengthening the bonds of cooperation and solidarity between Member States.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The draft amending budget in question covers the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF) amounting to almost EUR 47 million in commitment and payment appropriations following the floods in Italy (Sardinia) during November 2013, of an earthquake in Greece (Kefalonia), snow and ice storms in Slovenia and the same storms, followed by floods, in Croatia at the end of January/early February 2014. I recognise the urgency of providing financial assistance through the EUSF to the countries affected by these natural disasters by agreeing to the adoption of additional commitment appropriations amounting to EUR 47 million in the 2014 budget and the transfer of the corresponding payment needs to the 2015 budget.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing — The European Union Solidarity Fund is an important instrument whose very name tells of the nature of its mission. In the past, the Slovak Republic also received significant assistance in the event of a natural disaster in the High Tatras. These funds have greatly helped to repair the damage that has been caused in our mountains. I will therefore always support proposals that will lead to us using this fund to help the Member States of the European Union deal with the damage from natural disasters, as we are now doing in relation to Italy, Greece, Slovenia and Croatia. I believe that our joint funds will help the people of these countries in particular.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — This measure and the allocation of these resources will be very important for Sardinia and its inhabitants affected by the floods. I am voting in favour of the measure (linked to draft amending budget No 5 for the financial year 2014).

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — Although there are clearly fewer funds to repair earthquake damage in Greece (Kefalonia), all aid is in the right direction and I am voting in favour of it.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. — I voted against UK taxpayers’ money being sent to Italy, Greece, Slovenia and Croatia, especially when we have natural disasters to deal with in our own country, and we are already paying GBP 21 million A DAY in foreign aid. A further demand of EUR 46 million, a large percentage of which will come from the UK, is not something that British taxpayers want.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - Our vote is in favour of all redistributive transfers that are intended to aid to regions or countries affected by natural disasters. We particularly believe in the redistributive nature of the European budget.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the urgent need to release financial assistance to Italy, Greece, Slovenia and Croatia, which were affected by the natural disasters in 2013 and 2014. I see it as the duty of the European Union and the main purpose of the EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF).

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - Our vote is in favour of all redistributive transfers that are intended to aid to regions or countries affected by natural disasters. We particularly believe in the redistributive nature of the European budget.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a motion for a resolution on the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council to mobilise the Solidarity Fund for the benefit of disaster-hit Italy, Greece, Slovenia and Croatia: heavy rainfall, rain, earthquakes, ice storms and floods. Given that these disasters affected the majority of the populations affected, leaving serious and lasting consequences on living conditions and economic stability, I support the fact that the European Commission recognised the importance of qualifying also Greece and Italy, although the damage assessment was below the threshold for the category of major natural disaster, while on the other hand, estimates in Croatia and Slovenia were above the threshold. It strongly supports financial assistance directed to affected areas, notably those where the damage and consequences are devastating.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. — While I understand that this is for aid, which could be used to help victims, the British public are already more than generous with donating funds to charitable causes when natural disasters occur. I do not believe foreign aid to be in the remit of the EU, so I voted against this proposal.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I supported the mobilisation of the fund, as it is crucial we show solidarity with people from the affected areas by helping to rebuild basic infrastructure, funding emergency services, providing temporary accommodation, contributing to clean-up operations and countering immediate health risks.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour of the report by Mr Beazley on behalf of the Committee on The Patricija Šulin, as she supports the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund following floods that hit Sardinia (Italy) in 2013, an earthquake that struck Greece and the ice storms that caused extensive damage in Slovenia. As far as my own country is concerned, I would like to highlight the funding for Sardinia which, as we know, has suffered considerable damage and which will be able to benefit from a substantial allocation to repair the damage suffered.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this draft amending budget because it involves mobilizing the funds needed in the 2014 budget to be earmarked for these different natural disasters. The European Union must be able to act as quickly as possible to help victims of such natural disasters which have terrible consequences for the inhabitants of the affected regions. Mobilisation of funds to address the consequences on the local population is essential for a European Union project that tries to help people, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUIF) was created just to respond jointly and severally to disasters such as floods in Italy( Sardinia) in November 2013, the earthquake in Greece (Kefalonia), ice storms in Slovenia and the ice storms themselves, followed by flooding, in Croatia in late January - early February 2014.  It is a political and moral responsibility to vote in favour of the European Union intervening in solidarity to help reduce the suffering of all European citizens affected by these calamities.  As argued above, I vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. — Solidarity is the fundamental philosophy of the foundations of the European Union. The European Union has a duty to assist those Member States that have suffered natural disasters: Italy, Greece and Slovenia. I supported this decision.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of mobilising the EU Solidarity Fund: Floods in Italy - Earthquakes in Greece - Blizzard in Slovenia - Ice and floods in Croatia, because this report launches financial support for Italy, Greece Slovenia and Croatia for the damage caused by natural disasters. However, the funds for Greece could have been increased in order to strengthen more effectively those affected by the devastating earthquake in Kefalonia.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. — (IT) I supported the report on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund totalling EUR 46 988 528. Several types of natural disasters have caused considerable damage in EU Member States, such as Italy, Greece, Slovenia and Croatia, which have applied for the Fund to be activated as a result of particularly serious damage. It is essential to show solidarity with the people of disaster-affected regions.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — (IT) My support for the Šulin report, which calls for the mobilization of the European Union Solidarity Fund following floods in Italy (Sardinia), an earthquake in Greece and ice storms in Slovenia, was, in my view, a real act of conscience.  As an Italian, I can only welcome the fact that, thanks to funding from the Fund, Sardinia, the victim, in November 2013, of torrential rains that caused rivers to be cut off and severe floods, will finally be able to benefit from a substantial allocation, to be allocated to the reconstruction and economic recovery of the affected area.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — I fully support the request for support from the EU Solidarity Fund for the countries mentioned. The European Union has a duty to help its Member States after such serious natural disasters. This is precisely what the Solidarity Fund was set up for.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — The European Commission is proposing 47 million euros to help Italy, Greece, Slovenia and Croatia, which were severely affected by various natural disasters between November 2013 and February 2014. In the case of Slovenia and Croatia, it is the largest snowstorm in Europe, causing major flooding. In Slovenia, for example, nearly half of the country's forests have been damaged by ice, while one in four homes has been without electricity. This is an important aid to enable them to re-establish their infrastructure, but these "natural" disasters are becoming more and more recurrent. Our production methods are largely responsible for this. Yet Europe is reluctant to commit itself despite the danger to the planet and its climate. Millions of people are threatened by the loss of drinking water, floods or the very disappearance of their country. The last UN summit in Lima opened the idea of "voluntary" agreements, under the guise of wanting to succeed at any cost, the legally binding foundations of the agreement have jumped. I am voting for this necessary and urgent aid for these three countries.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — This proposal aims to mobilise the European Solidarity Fund for floods in Italy (Sardinia) in November 2013 of an earthquake in Greece (Kefalonia), ice storms in Slovenia and the same storms, followed by floods, in Croatia in late January and early February 2014, on the basis of paragraph 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013. Different types of natural disasters (floods, earthquakes and snowandstorms and ice) have caused considerable damage to EU requesting Member States, while Italy and Greece have been affected by unrelated disasters of different kinds, one of the worst winter snowfalls in Europe has affected several countries, with particularly negative effects for Slovenia and Croatia The EU has to be sympathetic to its members suffering from this type of natural disaster. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — The EU Solidarity Fund was specifically created to show support for citizens living in areas affected by natural disasters. I therefore voted in favour of this proposal because of our responsibility to aid and ensure that the funds reach the localities that were worst affected.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of this report, which proposes to mobilise the European Solidarity Fund in favour of floods in Italy (Sardinia) during November 2013, an earthquake in Greece (Kefalonia), ice storms in Slovenia, and the same ice storms, followed by floods, in Croatia, at the end of January/beginning of February 2014.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. In contrast to the European Union's cohesion policy, which does not reduce the economic and social gaps between the various Member States, we do not reject the very principle of solidarity with a European state that is the victim of natural disaster. The south of France has recently had to suffer the devastating effects of bad weather and in the face of this type of situation, the idea of mutual financial, material and human assistance must be imposed on all. Management at European level of natural hazards and urgent solutions must therefore be encouraged. I voted for the mobilization of the EU Solidarity Fund.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund in order to assist in helping rebuild infrastructure, fund emergency services, provide temporary accommodation as well as contribute to clean-up operations and counter immediate health risks.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the report by Mr Beazley on beazley. Sulin on the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund in favour of the November 2013 floods in Sardinia, the earthquake in Greece and the ice storms in Slovenia and Croatia this year.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. The EUSF was created following the floods that hit Central Europe in the summer of 2002. I voted in favour of the deployment of this fund in the specific case of floods in Italy, the earthquake in Greece and the ice in Slovenia and Croatia.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal to help Italy cope with floods, Greece earthquakes, Slovenia and Croatia in dealing with the effects of snowstorms and floods. The European Union Solidarity Fund is designed precisely to help and show solidarity with the people of the disaster-stricken regions.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — (IT) The European Union has set up the Solidarity Fund to show its solidarity with the populations of the regions affected by disasters. Italy, Greece, Slovenia and Croatia have applied to mobilise the Fund in connection with disasters in their territories. Within the framework of the general budget of the European Union set for the financial year 2014, a sum of EUR 46 998 528 of commitment and payment appropriations shall be mobilised under the Fund. For these reasons, I would vote in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. — I welcome the compromise reached on the EU Budget for 2014 and the compromise for the development of the general EU Budget for 2015. That's good news. The European Union must now dedicate itself to goals that must enable a better life for citizens, especially in those parts that have been affected by the economic crisis and are still slowly being pulled out of it or are still in recession like Croatia. In the discussion under this item on the agenda, I would especially like to welcome the adoption of two decisions to mobilise funds from the European Solidarity Fund, taking into account the ice storm in February 2014 followed by floods and the floods that hit Croatia again in May 2014. This year in Croatia and its neighbourhood, nature has twice shown its destructive strength. Direct estimated damage in Croatia is 370m euros higher. Unfortunately, despite all the efforts undertaken and the solidarity shown by the inhabitants of other parts of Croatia and Europe, a part of the inhabitants of Posavina County will not welcome the Christmas holidays in their homes. I hope that this eu Solidarity Fund assistance of around €17.6 million will help them return home more quickly and recover the parts of Croatia that have been hit by these severe disasters.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. If we do not endorse the Union's cohesion policy and believe that it does not alleviate economic and social disparities between Member States, we believe that the principle of European solidarity can make sense when one of our European neighbours is seriously affected by a natural disaster. Moreover, the climatic events that have hit the south of France in recent months reinforce the idea that mutual financial assistance must enable us to better respond to the human, material and financial consequences of this type of tragic event. Common management of natural risks must be encouraged at European level in order to strengthen risk pooling. That is why I voted for the mobilization of the Solidarity Fund.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. — (IT) The dramatic floods which struck Sardinia a year ago are still a wound which is struggling to heal, not only for the Sardinian populations affected, but for the whole of Italy, which is now tired of seeing its territory continually devastated. With today's vote, the European Parliament approved the allocation of more than EUR 16 million to deal with the huge amount of damage caused by the rainfall and water just over a year ago in and around the province of Olbia. I naturally voted in favour of this appropriation from the European Solidarity Fund, which is being used by the EU to help Member States cope with the exorbitant, material and moral costs that natural disasters leave behind. A sum, in this case, in high absolute terms, which certainly does not cover the entire estimate of the calculated damage. It is, however, an important contribution, which will certainly help the populations so badly affected by this tragedy.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — The European Union Solidarity Fund was set up to respond to large-scale natural disasters and to express solidarity within the European Union for those countries affected by disasters. Croatia has applied to mobilise the Fund due to ice storms followed by floods in January and February 2014. The direct damage suffered by Croatia amounted to EUR 291 904 630, while the proposed amount from the EU Solidarity Fund for Assistance to Croatia amounted to EUR 8 616 26. Heavy rainfall in Croatia has caused catastrophic floods that have led to the destruction of crops and the collapse of traffic routes, housing, evacuation of populations and livestock. In just three days, the amount of precipitation reached the quarterly average. The hardest hit cities and municipalities were: Slavonski Brod, Oriovac, Slavonski Šamac, Oprisavci, Okučani and the wider area of Županja. I support the adoption of proposals by the European Commission and the Council to provide financial assistance to Croatia, which would compensate for some of the damage caused by disasters. Requests for mobilisation were also submitted by Italy, Greece and Slovenia. Taking into account the maximum possible amount of the grant, the Commission approved the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund of EUR 46 998 528.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — (IT) I fully support the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund for those Member States (in this case the floods in Italy, the earthquake in Greece, the ice storms in Slovenia and the same ice storms and floods in Croatia, where these disasters have caused considerable damage which requires the activation of the Fund. Although Italy and Greece have been affected by disasters of a different nature and not related to the others, one of Europe's worst winter storms has affected many countries, causing particularly serious damage in Slovenia and Croatia. In the exceptional circumstances, it was useful to activate the Fund quickly. I hope that the regions affected by these extraordinary disasters, where there are profound and lasting repercussions on the living conditions of the citizens and on the economic stability of the regions themselves, will be able to recover as soon as possible.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Writing. — Given that I consider genuine solidarity between the European states to be a great achievement, I agree with the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund. If the EU were to show the same understanding of solidarity in all areas as it does in the area of disaster relief, it would not have to complain about a lack of acceptance among the citizens. Instead, tax money is invested in opaque projects and ailing banks are supposedly bailed out. Solidarity means helping people who come in need, not freeing their creditors from any risk of loss.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — The European Solidarity Funds were designed to provide financial support to regions where natural disasters with the greatest consequences are affected. I therefore vote in favour of the use of such a fund in order to best remedy the damage caused by calamities in Italy, Croatia, Greece and Slovenia.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — The Commission proposes mobilising the EU Solidarity Fund following the floods in Italy (Sardinia) in November 2013, an earthquake in Greece (Kefalonia), ice storms in Slovenia and ice storms followed by floods in Croatia in late January and early February 2014. Such disasters have caused considerable damage to the requesting Member States and the eligibility criteria set out in Council Regulation (EC) No 2012/2002 establishing the European Union Solidarity Fund are met. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution approving the decision to mobilise eur 46 998 528 for Italy, Greece, Slovenia and Croatia.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in relation to floods in Italy (Cerdeña) in November 2013, an earthquake in Kefalonia (Greece) which caused numerous casualties and left 3,000 people homeless, ice storms in Slovenia, and the same ice storms followed by flooding in Croatia in late January - early February 2014. With this decision, the affected areas will be able to benefit from joint aid of around EUR 47 million to help alleviate the consequences of these disasters.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - Our vote is in favour of all redistributive transfers that are intended to aid to regions or countries affected by natural disasters. We particularly believe in the redistributive nature of the European budget.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — I agree with the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund for a total amount of EUR 46 998 528 to minimise the effects of the serious natural disasters described in this report in Croatia, Slovenia, Greece and Italy this year and last year.  The activation of this fund was based on the criteria for extraordinary regional disasters, provided for in the last paragraph of Article 2 of Regulation (EC) No 2012/2002, which lays down the conditions for mobilising the Solidarity Fund in exceptional circumstances, as they result from situations which do not qualify as a major natural disaster, in the light of the Regulation on the European Union Solidarity Fund. I believe that the European Union has once again fulfilled one of its noblest principles: solidarity and mutual help between different nations that share the same values, the same continent and share part of its sovereignty in a voluntary and committed way.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. — (IT) I have chosen to vote in favour in order to help the citizens of areas affected by earthquakes or weather phenomena of extraordinary intensity, in Italy and In Europe.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - Our vote is in favour of all redistributive transfers that are intended to aid to regions or countries affected by natural disasters. We particularly believe in the redistributive nature of the European budget.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - The Commission proposes to mobilize the European Union Solidarity Fund in relation to flooding in Italy (Cerdeña) in November 2013, an earthquake in Greece (Kefalonia), ice storms in Slovenia, and the same ice storms followed by flooding in Croatia from late January - early February 2014, on the basis of paragraph 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013. I am in favour of this, so I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. — I understand that this is for aid which could be used to help victims. The British public are already more than generous in donating funds to charitable causes when natural disasters occur. I do not believe foreign aid to be in the remit of the EU, so I voted against this proposal.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — Today I voted to support the mobilisation of the European Solidarity Fund (EUSF) for Member States affected by disasters. The Commission's proposal concerned EUSF being granted in favour of floods in Italy during November 2013, an earthquake in Greece, ice storms in Slovenia, and the same ice storms, followed by floods in Croatia, at the end of January / beginning February 2014. The Commission proposed to mobilise the EU solidarity Fund for a total amount of EUR 46 998 528.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. — Croatia will generate €8.6 million from the European Solidarity Fund after meeting all the conditions due to the damage caused by ice storms and floods that hit some Croatian areas in early 2014. Unfortunately, this natural disaster has hit the economically underdeveloped areas of Primorje-Gorski Kotar, Karlovac and Sisak-Moslavina Counties, and additionally Zagreb and Varaždin Counties.  The recovery of demographically old and unoblowned areas requires the design of longer-term and comprehensive development strategies with instruments that are not necessarily focused only on economic and financial factors. Since Gorski Kotar was particularly badly damaged in the freezing rains, the greatest damage was caused in natural zones, namely in Croatian forests.  It is clear that the disbursement of funds through the fund will be in addition to the funds from the national budget necessary for the social, cultural and natural recovery of sensitive areas of Croatia, since forests are directly related to rural development, i.e. they are crucial for the natural and economic sustainability of this area.   I supported the mobilisation of funds due to their focus on remediating elements crucial to the successful recovery of affected areas.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. — At the end of January and early February 2014, slovenia was hit by the ice. Severe ice has caused enormous economic damage. About 250,000 people were left without electricity without power, and the stings caused many roads across the country to be closed. The greatest damage was caused to transport and energy infrastructure. In addition, almost half of the country's forests have been destroyed. Slovenia has submitted an application for the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund. Total damage per žledolom was estimated at EUR 428 733 722. This amount represents 1.23% of Slovenian BDN and exceeds the threshold for mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund of EUR 209.6 million applicable to Slovenia in 2014. As the estimated total damage exceeds the threshold, the accident is classified as a 'major natural disaster'. On the basis of the calculations, the European Commission has proposed an aid amount of EUR 18 388 478 to Slovenia. In addition to Slovenia, financial assistance from the Solidarity Fund was also granted to Italy due to flooding in Sardinia, Greece due to the earthquake in Kafeleria and Croatia due to slead and subsequent floods. As it is important to show solidarity and to help countries overcome the difficult situations caused by natural disasters, I supported the proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to the four countries mentioned.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — The mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund enables assistance to a Member State following the damage caused by one of the natural disasters. A maximum of €1 billion a year is available from a mobilisation fund not financed by the regular EU budget to complement Member States' public expenditure.  For 2014, the European Union approved an amount of 46 998 528. The first wave of floods occurred in February 2014 and caused €291,904,630 in damage. In certain places, the damage was so bad that the city's full infrastructure was destroyed, making the population unable to function normally. The total aid approved for the first wave of floods is 8 616 263 euros.  Croatia also applied within the foreseen deadlines to mobilise funds from the fund, taking into account the hailstorms of this flood. I myself visited flooded areas in Croatia and I would point out that this fund enables assistance in the reconstruction of hard-hit areas with the funds necessary for these cities, areas and families to function normally again. Therefore, I support the report.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — I supported this proposal since I am well aware of these natural disasters and their consequences, and I am particularly familiar with the consequences caused by ice and floods in Croatia. I also addressed to the European Commission a parliamentary question for the purpose of granting assistance to Croatia, since the Republic of Croatia also encountered ice that caused damage to power lines and centuries-old forests. The amount of 8.6m euros from the Solidarity Fund will not be enough to compensate for the damage caused, as the entire transmission infrastructure as well as many of the facilities have been destroyed, and many people have been left homeless, while the damage is estimated at 297m euros. However, money from the Solidarity Fund is necessary given the poor economic situation in Croatia, while eu assistance will be more than welcome.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — Although there are clearly fewer funds to repair earthquake damage in Greece (Kefalonia), all aid is in the right direction.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund for Italy (Sardinia), which was flooded in November 2013, Greece (Cefalonia), the scene of an earthquake, Slovenia, hit by ice storms, and Croatia, which was hit by the same ice storms. followed by floods in late January-early February 2014. Indeed, it is essential to play the solidarity card in such circumstances.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. —I supported this report because I believe that fiscal discipline, which I myself advocate, must not go at the expense of the most vulnerable. Natural disasters create special circumstances in which we must show maximum solidarity. One way is to raise awareness of the necessity of helping each other and humanitarian action in such crisis situations, as european conservatives and reformists in Croatia have done by restoring children's playgrounds in the flooded eastern part of the country. However, it should not be forgotten the importance of institutional assistance, which is nevertheless a guarantor of a certain security for a community that has lost and suffered greatly through a series of unfortunate circumstances. That is why it is important to perfect the Solidarity Fund mechanisms to better suit the needs of the affected areas. Amendments adopted at the end of the last term, which, among other things, introduce an advance measure that would ensure the timeliness of the reaction are certainly a step in the right direction.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. — My vote is in favour of mobilizing extra funds for the benefit of States affected by natural disasters.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund because I believe it is important to respond to major natural disasters and to express European solidarity with the affected regions within the EU. In this case, Among the beneficiary countries there is also Italy, which has submitted a request for mobilization due to the serious flood that occurred in Sardinia in 2013. By voting in favour of this report, therefore, the Commission was also asked to provide an appropriation in support of our country.  However, I would like to express the need to provide for greater speed in the approval and disbursement of the Fund in the future, which, for the umpteenth time, was used for negotiation purposes during the procedure for approving the budget for 2015. In fact, an instrument based on one of the basic principles of the European Union has once again become a symbol of the end of solidarity between the Member States.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — The support of EU citizens who have been hit hard by disasters and are thus put to the test by fate is, in principle, to be welcomed. That is why I voted in favour of mobilising the Solidarity Fund for Italy, Greece, Slovenia and Croatia, as the Fund is intended precisely for such causes and is intended to be used accordingly to help the people in the affected regions.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — The text approves the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund for Italy, Greece, Slovenia and Croatia. In the case of Italy, the mobilisation request follows heavy rains in November 2013, which caused many rivers to overflow and major floods. Greece was hit by a violent earthquake, followed by dozens of severe seismic aftershocks between January and February last year, leaving 3,000 people homeless and several injured.  As the total damage falls below the major disaster threshold for mobilising the Solidarity Fund, the request was examined on the basis of the extraordinary regional disaster criteria. On the other hand, Slovenia and Croatia were affected by winter snowstorms that hit several areas of Europe and several countries between January and February this year. In Croatia the melting of ice and snow resulted in floods that caused additional damage. As the total direct damage estimated in both countries exceeds the normal threshold for mobilising the Solidarity Fund, this disaster can be considered a major natural disaster. We voted for it.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the proposal to mobilise the EU Solidarity Fund on the basis of applications for mobilisation of the Fund submitted by Italy, Greece, Slovenia and Croatia, which refer to floods in Sardinia (Italy) in November 2013, an earthquake in Kefalonia (Greece) in January 2014 and ice storms in Slovenia and Croatia in January and February 2014 , followed, in Croatia, by further flooding. As regards the Situation in Italy in particular, the damage caused in Sardinia has been estimated at EUR 652 418 691 and the appropriation will be EUR 16 310 467, which is necessary to help the region. However, it remains a priority and fundamental to focus on the prevention of these phenomena, so that we do not have to resort to these instruments all the time, which should remain exceptional.

name: Alessandra MORETTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, although the agreement on the 2005 budget cannot be considered sufficient and satisfactory, as a Parliament we have nevertheless decided to vote for it out of a sense of responsibility. Despite the efforts made primarily by our Socialist rapporteur, Mr Gardiazabal, and especially by Prime Minister Renzi and the Italian Presidency, we do not believe that the money allocated is sufficient. Why? Because the Council has once again been prey, as is often the case, to national self-interest, particularly those of Germany, France and England, which have shown a strong will to close the agreement. Parliament has, however, managed to obtain a buffer against the payment crisis and is committed to supporting and protecting the most significant programmes, such as the Erasmus programme and the Horizon 2020 programme. However, it remains a priority that in the coming years an intelligent and comprehensive reform of the entire budgetary adoption procedure should be undertaken, which increasingly shows a number of limitations and contradictions.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Mr. President, I supported this amendment to the 2014 budget, which mobilises €46.9 million in funding from the European Solidarity Fund to help Croatia, Slovenia, Italy, Greece and Austria from damage to natural disasters. The damage amounted to 1.5 billion euros, and in Croatia alone ice and floods in January and February 2014 caused the displacement of a large number of people and damage of 291.9 million euros.  These amendments to the budget of the European Solidarity Fund mobilise €8.6 million. This is not enough to cover all damages in the Republic of Croatia, and therefore it is very important to activate other funds to help the damaged areas.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Mr. President, a number of natural disasters have struck from floods, earthquakes to ice storms Italy and Greece, Slovenia and Croatia, causing significant damage to the transport, energy and water networks and infrastructure on public buildings, private property and forests. The European Solidarity Fund was set up to respond to major natural disasters and in some way mitigate member states' costs in these situations.  Therefore, I believe that the adoption of this amendment to budget number 5 is essential in order to pay at least in a small part those damages that have occurred both in the Republic of Croatia and in a number of counties where the total amount of damage estimates is almost 292 million euros, and this 8.6 million euros approved by the Solidarity Fund will help Croatia in terms of the national budget to pay some of the damages to those most vulnerable counties in connection with these natural disasters.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: Mr President, I was about to say that the first instinct of the legislator in a crisis is to reach for his wallet, but of course it is really to reach for your wallet. Whenever we are faced with one of these catastrophic events the answer is always to spend somebody else’s money, which allows you a vicarious glow of virtue at no cost to yourself.  Can I suggest something to colleagues from across the Chamber: if you feel moved by bad news of this kind, reach into your own pocket rather than into your constituents’ pockets! And I do not say that only as a rhetorical device. One of the particular catastrophes that we are talking about in this report was the floods that devastated eastern Slovenia and other parts of the Balkans in May. I was very proud a few weeks ago to lead a group of politicians from the Alliance of European Conservatives and Reformists doing some physical work clearing up the damage caused by those floods with our  friend Ruža Tomašić, the patriotic anti-corruption MEP for Croatia. It is possible to go and do something with your own hands, rather than passing the bill to somebody else, and shall I tell you something? It makes you feel a lot better.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this draft amending budget because it involves mobilizing the funds needed in the 2014 budget to be earmarked for these different natural disasters. The European Union must be able to act as quickly as possible to help victims of such natural disasters which have terrible consequences for the inhabitants of the affected regions. Mobilisation of funds to address the consequences on the local population is critical to a European Union project that tries to help people. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — Aid through the Solidarity Fund is not an efficient means of assisting with floods.  It only represents a small portion of the money spent by Member States and is an administrative nightmare.  Far better to reduce Member States’ contributions and to allow them to deal with such matters directly themselves.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of all draft amending budgets for 2014 and for the agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council on the 2015 budget. I congratulate the Negotiators of the European Parliament on the eur 4.25 billion allocated to the emergency debts of this year's EU budget. The European Commission would be obliged to draw up a step-by-step plan for the reduction of outstanding bills and to establish a sustainable debt ceiling in the future. Thanks to Parliament, eur 0.5 billion will be allocated to commitments. than the COUNCIL of the EU proposed. More funding will be allocated to horizon 2020 and the Erasmus+ programme for student and youth exchange. It is to be welcomed that the increase in funding for European neighbourhood programmes, humanitarian aid and the common foreign security policy has been increased, which is very relevant in the light of today's situation in Europe. However, I do not support the reduction in funding for the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund, which will affect many EU farmers, who are in a particularly difficult situation because of the protracted Russian embargo and who need EU assistance.

name: Hugues BAYET
