text: In writing. — The aim here is to include in commitment appropriations on the 2014 budget and in payment appropriations for the 2015 financial year the amount of 49 million euros needed to cover the mobilization of the European Union Solidarity Fund following floods in November 2013 in Sardinia, an earthquake in Cefalonia in Greece, ice storms in Slovenia and the same ice storms followed by floods in Croatia in late January and early February 2014.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: in writing. — I have just voted in favour of European aid for the 2013 floods in Italy. In the meantime there have been more floods, and so in a year's time we will still be here, as happened last year and the year before. A few months ago Genoa, the city where I was born, ended up underwater for the second time in three years, as well as the whole of Liguria and the reason is always the same: bad land management made by corrupt politicians servants of collusive entrepreneurs who have more to gain from emergency and disaster than from safety.  I will always vote to help the territory rise, but I'm tired. Tired of 30 years of emergencies. Tired of thirty years of juntas of the same color that they have never done prevention and no, their color is not red, but the gray of the concrete with which they covered my region. So I am addressing you citizens, you too will shortly be voting. Do not vote for the emergency, vote for prevention.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the amending budget No 5/2014 because it was necessary to enable the Solidarity Fund and have the necessary resources to meet the commitment and payment appropriations for the floods in Sardinia (Italy) in November 2013, an earthquake in Greece, ice storms in Slovenia and ice storms followed by flooding in Croatia in late January and early February 2014.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. Opposed to the EU's cohesion policy, we nevertheless consider that solidarity between Member States, especially when they are affected by major natural disasters, as was the case in the South of France, is necessary. The mobilization of this EU Solidarity Fund for Italy (Sardinia), which faced floods in November 2013, Greece (Cefalonia), the scene of an earthquake, Slovenia, hit by ice storms, and Croatia, hit by the same ice storms, followed by floods at the end of January-early February 2014, is vital. It will thus bring almost EUR 47 million to these regions and I have therefore voted for this draft amending budget No. 5/2014.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this technical measure, which releases the EUR 47 million needed for Solidarity Fund assistance to Sardinia, Greece and Slovenia.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — I voted in favour since draft amending budget No 5/2014 is related to the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund for around EUR 47 million to deal with the consequences of flooding in Italy (Cerdeña) in November 2013, an earthquake in Kefalonia (Greece) that caused numerous casualties and left 3,000 people homeless, ice storms in Slovenia and the same ice storms followed by flooding in Croatia in late January - early February 2014.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. — The Solidarity Fund was set up with the intention of assisting Member States and candidates in the event of natural disasters. The year 2014 will be remembered in Croatia for the natural adversity caused by great human suffering and material damage.  Gorski Kotar was shackled by snow and ice at the beginning of the year, and hit by floods that caused extensive damage to both public infrastructure and private property. Croatian government estimates suggest damages of 292m euros, so the 8.6m euros the European Union plans to allocate to Croatia is more than welcome.  After Gorski Kotar, Croatia was again killed in May when floods hit Slavonia, causing even more devastation and damage of 297.6m euros. The consequences of the water wave will be felt for a long time, but the Government of the Republic of Croatia is making significant efforts to normalize the situation in order to enable the return of citizens to flooded homes. The amount of 8.9 million that the EU will allocate from its budget to remediate the effects of floods will significantly help in these efforts. I welcome these budget changes, as the appropriations show that in distress, the Member States of the European Union are not alone, but can count on assistance from both the Union and other Member States.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted for this because we need to have concrete help for the zones in the European Union which have suffered natural catastrophes.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — I voted for PBR 5, which aims to mobilise the funds needed for repair programmes after the terrible property damage caused by natural disasters (floods, ice, earthquakes) in several Member States. In these cases, the principle of European solidarity makes perfect sense.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the activation of the EU Solidarity Fund to the amount of EUR 46 998 528 in commitment and payment appropriations. The activation concerns the floods that occurred in Italy (Sardinia) in November 2013, the earthquake that occurred in Greece (Kefalonia), the snowstorms that hit Slovenia and the same storms, followed by floods, of which Croatia was the victim in late January-early February 2014.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the motion for a Resolution of the European Parliament on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund for floods in Italy, earthquakes in Greece and ice storms in Slovenia, all of which caused serious damage to the three Member States in question. I believe that, in the event of such events, a principle of superior solidarity between states should be applied, allowing timely and effective aid to the populations. In view of the fact that these events, thanks to the instruments at our disposal, are now predictable, I hope that the European Union will make a further effort by giving fresh impetus to those measures which will help to predict, and therefore to prevent, with a broader overall framework of action, the catastrophic consequences of these phenomena.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — The Union's resources must be used as much as possible for the sake of good. Support for people affected by earthquakes and floods will never be lacking on our part.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — Italy is a net contributor to the EU, which makes my nose twist a little, but I understand that. The problem is that your exposure is often higher than expected because you are unable to ask for funds. With this draft amending budget, funds are allocated to the areas of Sardinia affected by the flood, and therefore some of those resources return to our country. My vote was clearly in favour.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the report on amending budget No 5, which provides for the mobilisation of aid totalling EUR 47 million from the European Union Solidarity Fund. This is an essential instrument, which provides effective and real help to citizens affected by natural disasters. In particular, this vote provides funds for Greece, Slovenia and Croatia, but above all important support for Sardinia, which will receive about 16 million euros for the damage caused by the November 2013 flood.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of this report due to the urgent need to release financial assistance in relation to floods in Italy, earthquake in Greece, ice storms in Slovenia and ice storms and floods in Croatia through the EU Solidarity Fund.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — Draft amending budget No 5/2014 concerns the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF) amounting to EUR 46 998 528 in commitment and payment appropriations in relation to floods in Italy (Sardinia) in November 2013, earthquakes in Greece (Kefalonia), ice storms in Slovenia and the same ice storms, followed by floods, in Croatia between the end of January and the beginning of February 2014. This amendment is necessary in order to be able to pay the contributions relating to the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund, which directly affects us with the approximately EUR 16 million allocated to Sardinia. That is why I could only vote in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this draft amending budget because it involves mobilizing the funds needed in the 2014 budget to be earmarked for these different natural disasters. The European Union must be able to act as quickly as possible to help victims of such natural disasters which have terrible consequences for the inhabitants of the affected regions. Mobilisation of funds to address the consequences on the local population is critical to a European Union project that tries to help people. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because I support the mobilisation of funds through EUSF to countries affected by natural disasters.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. With the vote on amending budget 5, the European Union is rightly committing the Solidarity Fund to help countries hit by natural disasters in 2013 and 2014. Floods in Sardinia and Croatia and the earthquake in Greece, for example, have severely damaged public and private infrastructure and the homes of local people. The release of EUR 47 million for these countries will help to repair the damage caused.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) has been created to deal with serious natural disasters and to express solidarity with the regions of Europe affected by disasters. I supported the mobilisation of the Fund in favour of Italy, Greece, Slovenia and Croatia. In particular, with regard to Italy, the EUSF will financially support Sardinia, which was hit on 18 and 19 November 2013 by violent torrential rains that caused rivers to be flooded and severe floods.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. — The European Parliament today adopted by a large majority the EU budget for 2015 and the amendments on surplus resources for 2014. The huge advantage of the agreement is that it will be able to pass the EU budget for 2015 later this year, i.e. next year it would not only be possible to pay 12th of this year's budget per month. By 2014, an additional €4 billion will be mobilised, of which EUR 3.5 billion will be the result of so-called 'fresh money', i.e. not transfers.  The EP only agreed to the adoption of next year's EU budget on the condition that the European Commission draws up a plan to reduce unpaid bills to sustainable levels. In 2014, €23.4 billion will have to be paid from the previous year. To this end, today's vote provides an additional resource of nearly EUR 4 billion. Today's decision by the European Parliament also provided agricultural and cohesion resources for Hungary in this year's and next year's budgets. The Hungarian People's Party delegation, together with the European People's Party, acted responsibly on behalf of the national interests of Hungary and voted in favour of the 2015 EU budget and all the reports contained in the related agreement. The agreement also includes reports mobilising the Solidarity Fund to mitigate the damage caused by natural disasters affecting different regions of Europe.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the report because, although there are clearly fewer funds available to repair earthquake damage in Greece (Kefalonia), any assistance is desirable.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — The text approves the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund for Italy, Greece, Slovenia and Croatia.  In the case of Italy, the mobilisation request follows heavy rains in November 2013, which caused many rivers to overflow and major floods. Greece was hit by a violent earthquake, followed by dozens of severe seismic aftershocks, between January and February last year, leaving 3,000 people homeless and several injured.  As the total damage falls below the major disaster threshold for mobilising the Solidarity Fund, the request has been examined on the basis of the extraordinary regional disaster criteria – which we support. On the other hand, Slovenia and Croatia were affected by winter snowstorms that hit several areas of Europe and several countries between January and February this year. In Croatia, there was also the aggravation of melting ice and snow resulting in floods that caused additional damage. As the total direct damage estimated in both countries exceeds the normal threshold for mobilising the Solidarity Fund, this disaster can be considered a major natural disaster. We voted in favour.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing — The amending budget is important for the application of the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund under point 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement, so that the elimination of the consequences of natural disasters in Italy, Greece, Slovenia and Croatia can be effectively facilitated. It is essential to support this budgetary adjustment in order to release resources to the Member States concerned. Mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund under point 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management (Floods in Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria)

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — Although there are clearly fewer funds to repair earthquake damage in Greece (Kefalonia), all aid is in the right direction. That is why I am voting in favour of draft amending budget No 10. 5/2014

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - Our vote is in favour of all redistributive transfers that are intended to aid to regions or countries affected by natural disasters. We particularly believe in the redistributive nature of the European budget. However, we oppose the adoption of the 2015 budget and criticise the agreement on amending budgets negotiated in parallel.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - Our vote is in favour of all redistributive transfers that are intended to aid to regions or countries affected by natural disasters. We particularly believe in the redistributive nature of the European budget. However, we oppose the adoption of the 2015 budget and criticise the agreement on amending budgets negotiated in parallel.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a motion for a resolution on the Council's position on the draft amendment to budget No 1009/2013. 5/2014 concerning the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund following floods in Italy's Sardinia, earthquakes in Greece's Kefalonia, ice storms in Slovenia and icy storms accompanied by floods in Croatia. In my view, it is of utmost importance to help areas affected by natural disasters, which would stabilise the economic and social situation in these areas as soon as possible. The budgetary adjustment of EUR 46,998,528.00 in the 2014 budget will specifically help all those who bear the consequences of these events and who are still recovering from them. It is necessary to send a strong signal to people living in the affected areas: the European Union is present and ready to help. But I believe that help needs to be more dynamic, faster and more comprehensive to avoid consequences.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. — While I understand that this is for aid, which could be used to help victims, the British public are already more than generous with donating funds to charitable causes when natural disasters occur. I do not believe foreign aid to be in the remit of the EU, so I voted against this proposal.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. — I welcome the adoption of the report by my colleague Patricija Ooulin on the mobilization of the European Union Solidarity Fund for Italy, Greece, Slovenia and Croatia. The applications included floods in Sardinia in November 2013, an earthquake in Cephalonia (Greece) in January 2014, and ice storms that occurred in early 2014 in Slovenia and Croatia, followed by floods in Croatia. I believe that solidarity is an essential principle of the European Union. It was to apply to those territories facing disasters with serious human and economic consequences.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I supported the mobilisation of the fund, as it is crucial we show solidarity with people from the affected areas by helping to rebuild basic infrastructure, funding emergency services, providing temporary accommodation, contributing to clean-up operations and countering immediate health risks.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Gérard Deprez. The proposal provides for the mobilisation of aid totalling EUR 47 million from the European Union Solidarity Fund. This is a very important instrument, through which we are able to offer concrete help to citizens affected by natural disasters. We fought for the Fund to remain so and defended its resources during the negotiations. Specifically, amending budget No 5 provides funds for Greece, Slovenia and Croatia, but above all important support for Sardinia, to which approximately EUR 16 million will go, to support the population following the disasters caused by the november 2013 floods.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this draft amending budget because it involves mobilizing the funds needed to adapt the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund in the budgets for the 2014 financial year. The European Union must be able to act as quickly as possible to help victims of such natural disasters which have terrible consequences for the inhabitants of the affected regions. Mobilisation of funds to address the consequences on the local population is critical to a European Union project that tries to help people. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — In 2014, Croatia was hit by severe floods affecting both Italy, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia. The consequences are catastrophic, over 15,000 people have been evacuated, and most of them have lost everything they had. The total flood damage in Croatia alone was estimated at 291.9m euros, and the total walk in these areas amounted to 1.5 billion euros.  Although various humanitarian actions have been launched to help the affected areas, residents will not return to their homes, farmland and lives for a long time to come. Mobilising the Solidarity Fund would provide 46.9m euros from the European Solidarity Fund to help affected areas of Italy, Greece, Slovenia and Croatia. I support the Solidarity Fund mobilisation report due to the extensive flood damage to be sanctioned and people who have lost their homes should be provided with assistance, housing and conditions for a normal life. I also think it is important to use EU funds to ensure these areas preventively, as we are witnessing more frequent natural disasters.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. - It goes hand in hand with the Solidarity Fund, it is imperative to help our Member States, I support this decision.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the Deprez report 'Draft amending budget No 1/2004'. 5/2014: Floods in Italy (Sardinia) in 2013 - Earthquakes in Greece - Blizzard in Slovenia - Ice and floods in Croatia in 2014", because this report includes in the EU budget funds for the financial support of Italy, Greece, Slovenia and Croatia.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of amending budget No 5/2014 on expenditure on the mobilisation of the EGF, the EU Solidarity Fund to ensure full and timely aid to those countries that have been affected by natural disasters in the last year. Of all these, the floods in Sardinia, to which 16 of the total 47 million in aid were allocated to Italy, Greece, Croatia and Slovenia. This amending budget will be considered outside the ceiling of the 2014 Multiannual Financial Framework to ensure the timely arrival of funds to the affected areas.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — Draft amending budget No 5 provides for substantial funds for Greece, Slovenia, Croatia and Sardinia, which have recently been affected by terrible natural disasters. I could only support this budgetary change, which will involve, among other things, the handing out of approximately EUR 16 million in support of the Region of Sardinia, the victim, in November 2013, of an epochal flood

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — I fully support the request for support from the EU Solidarity Fund for the countries mentioned. The European Union has a duty to help its Member States after such serious natural disasters. This is precisely what the Solidarity Fund was set up for.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — The European Commission is proposing 47 million euros to help Italy, Greece, Slovenia and Croatia, which were severely affected by various natural disasters between November 2013 and February 2014. Some of it has already been allocated to these countries. In view of the budgetary difficulties, for this fund for "major natural disasters", the Commission and Parliament propose to include the commitment appropriations corresponding to the 2014 budget but to defer the payment needs corresponding to the 2015 budget. This amending budget therefore creates new unpaid debts by deciding not to pay, in 2014, the relief funds to which Member States are immediately entitled under the compensation of natural disasters. I am voting against this postponement, which is the result of poor budget management.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — This draft amending budget No 5 for the financial year 2014 covers the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF) amounting to EUR 46 998 528 in commitment and payment appropriations following floods in Italy (Sardinia) during November 2013, of an earthquake in Greece (Kefalonia), snow and ice storms in Slovenia and the same storms, followed by floods, in Croatia at the end of January/early February 2014.  With this approval it is possible to formally include this budgetary adjustment in the 2014 budget. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report. Draft amending budget No 5/2014 covers the sum allocated to Italy, Greece, Slovenia and Croatia as part of the EU Solidarity Fund. I voted in favour of allocating the funds to repair the damage caused by natural disasters in the aforementioned countries as it is essential that our citizens receive the support they need.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of the draft amending budget No 5/2014 on floods in Italy (Sardinia) in 2013 – Earthquakes in Greece – Ice in Slovenia – Ice followed by floods in Croatia in 2014.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. I voted for PBR 5, which aims to mobilise the funds needed for repair programmes after the terrible property damage caused by natural disasters (floods, ice, earthquakes) in several Member States. In these cases, the principle of European solidarity makes perfect sense.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of draft amending budget No 5/2014 for the release of commitment and payment appropriations in connection with last year's floods in Sardinia, an earthquake in Greece and ice storms in Slovenia and Croatia.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - As the formal criteria for the allocation of aid have been met and the aid should be provided quickly and unbureaucratically, I voted in favour of the motion.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. The EUSF was created following the floods that hit Central Europe in the summer of 2002. I voted in favour of the deployment of this fund in the specific case of floods in Italy, the earthquake in Greece and the ice in Slovenia and Croatia.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal because I believe that countries affected by natural disasters need to be provided with financial assistance through the European Union Solidarity Fund to help reduce the effects of the disaster.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Draft amending budget No 5/2014 concerns the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF) amounting to EUR 46 998 528 in commitment and payment appropriations in relation to floods in Italy (Sardinia) in November 2013, earthquakes in Greece (Kefalonia), ice storms in Slovenia and the same ice storms, followed by floods, in Croatia between the end of January and the beginning of February 2014. Given that draft amending budget No 5/2014 is intended to formally enter the adjustment in the 2014 budget, I would vote in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. — The draft amending budget No. 6 provides for the reduction of budgetary appropriations for the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and the reserve for sustainable fisheries partnership agreements, for a total of EUR 76.3 million in commitment appropriations and EUR 6.2 million in payment credits. At the same time, this PBR provides for an increase in budgetary appropriations to the European Ombudsman to the amount of EUR 93,500. This draft amending budget is once again poorly implemented and will result in a reduction in the appropriations reserved for fishing professionals, who are facing very serious difficulties. Moreover, there is no evidence to assess the amount of the decrease in the GNI share for France. Finally, how can a general reduction in member states' GNI contribution be seriously envisaged at a time when the European Union is facing a serious payments crisis? These cosmetic measures will absolutely not solve the budgetary crisis facing the Union. That's why I decided to vote against PBR No. 6/2014.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — In line with my favourable vote on the use of the European Solidarity Fund for Italy, Greece, Slovenia and Croatia, following natural disasters, I am also voting to redeploy the necessary funds in the EU budget.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — In parallel with the proposal to mobilise the EU Solidarity Fund, in the amount of EUR 46 998 528 for Italy, Greece, Slovenia and Croatia, the Commission submitted a draft amending budget (POR No 5/2014 of 8 September 2014) to include in the 2014 budget the corresponding commitment appropriations and to carry over the corresponding payment appropriations for the 2015 budget. Because I believe that financial assistance should be provided to these countries affected by natural disasters, I voted in favour.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — After arduous negotiations, an agreement has been reached that will allow the payment of outstanding invoices, for which the amount of EUR 4.8 billion has been agreed for the period 2014-2015.  In addition, the Commission, the Council and Parliament have agreed on a payment plan aimed at reducing the level of unpaid invoices within the current multiannual framework. An unprecedented level of default has accumulated throughout this year.  The agreed EUR 4.8 billion will enable part of the accumulated invoices to be met, thus helping to alleviate the situation of many SMEs, universities, local authorities and NGOs. For 2015, it has been agreed to allocate EUR 145 321.5 million to commitment appropriations and EUR 141 214,040 563 million to payment appropriations. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - Our vote is in favour of all redistributive transfers that are intended to aid to regions or countries affected by natural disasters. We particularly believe in the redistributive nature of the European budget. However, we oppose the adoption of the 2015 budget and criticise the agreement on amending budgets negotiated in parallel.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund was set up to deal with major natural disasters and to express the European Union's solidarity with the affected regions. In 2013 and 2014, Italy, Greece, Slovenia and Croatia were the victims of extraordinary regional disasters or major natural disasters. These disasters have, of course, not been inconsequential for some of the citizens of these countries. That is why I voted in favour of mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund to help these people in need. Solidarity must be at the heart of the European project!

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this budgetary amendment, resulting from the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund for a total amount of EUR 46 998 528 to minimise the effects of the serious natural disasters in Croatia, Slovenia, Greece and Italy in this and last year, for the reasons set out in the explanation for the vote of the A8-0073/2014 report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. —I voted for this text, which allows the Solidarity Fund to be mobilised for a sum of 47 million euros. These funds are allocated to aid programmes following natural disasters, including major floods in Sardinia and Croatia, the aftermath of the earthquake in Greece and the damage caused by ice in Slovenia. This fund is a concrete example of European solidarity.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour because it was a question of providing due help to areas belonging to the Member States affected by natural disasters such as earthquakes and floods.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - Our vote is in favour of all redistributive transfers that are intended to aid to regions or countries affected by natural disasters. We particularly believe in the redistributive nature of the European budget. However, we oppose the adoption of the 2015 budget and criticise the agreement on amending budgets negotiated in parallel.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this draft amending budget because it involves mobilizing the funds needed in the 2014 budget to be earmarked for these different natural disasters. The European Union must be able to act as quickly as possible to help victims of such natural disasters which have terrible consequences for the inhabitants of the affected regions. Mobilisation of funds to address the consequences on the local population is critical to a European Union project that tries to help people. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. — While I understand that this is for aid, which could be used to help victims, the British public are already more than generous with donating funds to charitable causes when natural disasters occur. I do not believe foreign aid to be in the remit of the EU, so I voted against this proposal.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — I voted with the majority in support of the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund for the countries affected by natural disasters.  Draft amending budget No 5/2014 relates to the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF) for an amount of EUR 46 998 528 in commitment and payment appropriations in relation to the floods in Italy during November 2013, an earthquake in Greece, ice storms in Slovenia, and the same ice storms, followed by floods in Croatia, at end January / beginning February 2014.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of mobilising the Solidarity Fund, because I believe that the principle of solidarity on which it is based is right and eminently "European". If we are part of a European Union, then countries and regions in difficulty must not be abandoned, above all, but not only, in cases where the cause depends on natural disasters. My vote in favour is not only for my region, Sardinia, which was hard hit by the 2013 floods, but also for all the other cases in which the forces of nature have seriously affected other European regions, slowing down their economic growth substantially. I believe that the contribution is insufficient to adequately support the regions affected, especially in view of the reduction in the amount of the fund itself, but also that its very existence demonstrates the will of the institutions to be close and useful to the citizens. I believe that solidarity is one of the most distinguished values of the European Union, my decision to vote in favour of the measure was based on this conviction.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — I supported MeP Deprez's report amending draft budget no. 5/2014: floods in Italy, Sardinia in 2013, earthquakes in Greece, ice and floods in Slovenia and ice and floods in Croatia in 2014, which underlines that the European Union Solidarity Fund must urgently provide financial assistance to countries affected by natural disasters. The draft amendment to budget No.5/2014 itself relates to the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund of €46 998 528 in commitment appropriations and payment appropriations due to natural disasters in the Member States.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — I support changes to draft budget No. 5/2014 relating to the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund of EUR 46 998 528 for floods in Italy (Sardinia) in 2013, earthquakes in Greece, ice in Slovenia and ice and floods in Croatia in 2014. I especially welcome the funds earmarked for Croatia since many areas were destroyed after floods and freezing rains in January and early February 2014. It is now important that the funds are used as soon as possible through line ministries to rebuild the damaged areas. Assistance from the Solidarity Fund is also important for Italy, Greece, Slovenia and Croatia, as along with the reconstruction of vulnerable areas, it will also be a generator of economic activity in the affected areas, primarily in the construction sector that has been hit deepest by the economic crisis.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — Although there are clearly fewer funds to repair earthquake damage in Greece (Kefalonia), all aid is in the right direction.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of Mr Deprez's proposal, which was presented in the plenary debate in December 2014. I therefore voted in favour of the text on the Council's position on the European Union's draft amending budget No. 5/2014 for the 2014 financial year, Section III - Commission.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. — Natural disasters are unpredictable and the EU must give a fast response to the affected regions in order to recover as soon as possible. That is why I support this report on a Draft Amending Budget and I stress the urgent need to release financial assistance through the EUSF to the countries affected by this natural disaster.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. — My vote is in favour of mobilging extra funds for States affected by natural disasters.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — Draft amending budget No 5 for the financial year 2014 covers the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF) amounting to EUR 46 998 528 in commitment and payment appropriations following floods in Italy (Sardinia) during November 2013, of an earthquake in Greece (Kefalonia), snow and ice storms in Slovenia and the same storms, followed by floods, in Croatia at the end of January/early February 2014. As stated in the report, the lack of payment appropriations in 2014 excludes from the outset the possibility of finding the resources for draft amending budget No 5/2014 through reallocation.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — Since this proposal would, among other things, also mean a higher burden on Austria, I rejected it in principle. Partial payment options are a welcome idea, but the proposal itself makes it impossible for me to agree. In addition, this proposal forms the basis for amending budgets 3, 4, 6 and 8. In this respect, the amending budgets mentioned above were also to be rejected.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — Draft amending budget No 5 for the financial year 2014 covers the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF) amounting to EUR 46 998 528 in appropriations for commitments and payments following floods in Italy (Sardinia) during November 2013, an earthquake in Greece (Cephalonia), snow and ice storms in Slovenia and the same storms , in Croatia, followed by floods, in late January and early February 2014. We're in agreement.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I have not been able to vote in favour of the draft amending budget because it is not a sufficient response to the hole in all the European Union budgets. This budget sanctions the United Kingdom's position on the calculation of its GDP, legitimizing the reduction of its payments and aggravating both the budgetary situation and the balance of contributions between Member States. However, this budget guarantees the payment of unpaid invoices by the European institutions; that is why I have not been able to vote against this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — This is the Draft Amending Budget which led to the extra payments required of the United Kingdom disproportionately.  In consequence, I cannot support it.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of all draft amending budgets for 2014 and for the agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council on the 2015 budget. I congratulate the Negotiators of the European Parliament on the eur 4.25 billion allocated to the emergency debts of this year's EU budget. The European Commission would be obliged to draw up a step-by-step plan for the reduction of outstanding bills and to establish a sustainable debt ceiling in the future. Thanks to Parliament, eur 0.5 billion will be allocated to commitments. than the COUNCIL of the EU proposed. More funding will be allocated to horizon 2020 and the Erasmus+ programme for student and youth exchange. It is to be welcomed that the increase in funding for European neighbourhood programmes, humanitarian aid and the common foreign security policy has been increased, which is very relevant in the light of today's situation in Europe. However, I do not support the reduction in funding for the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund, which will affect many EU farmers, who are in a particularly difficult situation because of the protracted Russian embargo and who need EU assistance.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This PBR, which deals with the revision of forecasts for traditional own resources, VAT and GNI contributions, the reduction of the budgetary appropriations of the European Fund for Maritime Affairs and Fisheries and the reserve for partnership agreements in the field of sustainable fisheries (EUR 76.3 million in the EC and EUR -6.2 million in CP), as well as the increase in the appropriations granted to the European Ombudsman (whose usefulness has yet to be demonstrated) only helps to mask the EU's difficulties, and still does not fill the real budgetary problems. I therefore voted against this draft amending budget No. 6/2014.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted against this amending measure, which is mainly linked to a change in the calculations and compensations of contributions due by Member States on the basis of VAT and GNI resources for the years 1995 to 2013. The new allocations lead some countries to have their contributions back (including France EUR 1 billion and Germany), while other countries, including Italy, have to pay new contributions.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report which is part of the overall agreement to approve the 2014 amending budget and the 2015 budget. After arduous negotiations, an agreement has been reached that will allow the payment of outstanding invoices, for which the amount of EUR 4.7 billion has been agreed for the period 2014-2015. In addition, the Commission, the Council and Parliament have agreed on a payment plan aimed at reducing the level of unpaid invoices within the current multiannual framework. An unprecedented level of default has accumulated throughout this year.  The agreed 4.7 billion will enable some of the accumulated invoices to be met, helping to alleviate the situation of many SMEs, universities, local authorities and NGOs. It is true that the figure is not sufficient, but the alternative, the non-agreement, would have dire consequences: not having a fully operational budget for 2015, losing the possibility of paying the arrears and putting at risk the investment programme that the Commission has just presented. For 2015, it has been agreed to allocate EUR 145 321.5 million to commitment appropriations and EUR 141 214,040 563 million to payment appropriations. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted for this report because is essentiel to have an updated budget.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — The draft amending budget No. 6 provides for the reduction of budgetary appropriations for the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and the reserve for sustainable fisheries partnership agreements, for a total of EUR 76.3 million in commitment appropriations and EUR 6.2 million in payment credits. At the same time, this PBR provides for an increase in budgetary appropriations to the European Ombudsman to the amount of EUR 93,500. This draft amending budget is once again poorly implemented and will result in a reduction in the appropriations reserved for fishing professionals, who are facing very serious difficulties. Moreover, there is no evidence to assess the amount of the decrease in the GNI share for France. Finally, how can a general reduction in member states' GNI contribution be seriously envisaged at a time when the European Union is facing a serious payments crisis? These cosmetic measures will absolutely not solve the budgetary crisis facing the Union. That is why I have decided to vote against PBR 6/2014.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — I voted against. This amending budget is mainly linked to a change in the calculations and compensations of contributions due by Member States on the basis of VAT and GNI resources for the years 1995 to 2013. The new allocations lead some countries to have back contributions already paid (including France EUR 1 billion and Germany), while others have to pay new contributions (in particular the United Kingdom EUR 2.1 billion, Belgium EUR 0.6 billion and Italy EUR 0.34 billion). In view of the abnormally high balances, Member States were allowed to delate repayments on a voluntary basis until September 2015 during the trialogue. As a result of this extension, the total repayment entered in this PBR No 6 is reduced from EUR 9.5 billion to EUR 4.1 billion. This case has highlighted the distortions of the "rebates" granted to several Member States (not just the United Kingdom) in various ways and the inclusion in GDP of illicit activities.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — (IT) This correction reduces the budgetary appropriations for the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, and we are opposed to these measures.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) This draft amending budget has the burden and the honour of trying to straighten out certain distortions which had been created over time. Compared to the initial draft, it also proposes a somewhat more gradual and equitable adjustment, which helps net debtor countries such as Italy, especially if they owe a further contribution. Congratulations to the Italian Presidency on completing these negotiations, despite the difficult position due to its own situation.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of draft amending budget No 6 on the impact of the annual compensation of contributions due to Member States on the basis of VAT and GNI resources. Reserves were left for the period 1995-2013, for a significant amount, amounting to approximately EUR 9.5 billion. These amounts will be allocated among the Member States by a corresponding reduction in their annual contribution. Given the exceptional nature of the amount, I agree with the decision to de-elate these adjustments.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of the report as its adoption will reduce the need for Member States’ GNI contributions and compensate for the additional payment needs. I welcome that the proposal uses EUR 6.2 million of the savings to help finance humanitarian aid crises.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — Given that this amending is linked to a change in the calculations and compensations of contributions due by Member States on the basis of VAT and GNI resources for the years 1995 to 2013, the new allocations would have led some countries to have their contributions already paid back, while others would have to pay new contributions (in particular the United Kingdom). For the reasons set out above and in order to try to solve the problem of payments in some way, I could only vote in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — I have not been able to vote in favour of the draft amending budget because it is not a sufficient response to the hole in all the European Union budgets. This budget sanctions the United Kingdom's position on the calculation of its GDP, legitimizing the reduction of its payments and aggravating both the budgetary situation and the balance of contributions between Member States. However, this budget guarantees the payment of unpaid invoices by the European institutions; that is why I have not been able to vote against this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Draft Amending Budget which relates to the revision of the forecast of traditional own resources, VAT and GNI contributions, a reduction in the budgetary appropriations for the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and the reserve for Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreements, as well as an increase in the budgetary appropriations for the European Ombudsman.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. This draft amending budget No. 6 shows that the European Union's own resource needs have decreased by a total of EUR 4,095.5 million. This decrease translates into a consequent adjustment for Member States in their contribution to the EU budget. For some, this situation is welcome as their budgetary situation is fragile. For others, whose contribution is adjusting upwards, it was necessary to make it possible to spread payments. With the amendment of Regulation 1150/2000, it is done. That is why I supported this text.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. — The European Parliament today adopted by a large majority the EU budget for 2015 and the amendments on surplus resources for 2014. The huge advantage of the agreement is that it will be able to pass the EU budget for 2015 later this year, i.e. next year it would not only be possible to pay 12th of this year's budget per month. By 2014, an additional €4 billion will be mobilised, of which EUR 3.5 billion will be the result of so-called 'fresh money', i.e. not transfers.  The EP only agreed to the adoption of next year's EU budget on the condition that the European Commission draws up a plan to reduce unpaid bills to sustainable levels. In 2014, €23.4 billion will have to be paid from the previous year. To this end, today's vote provides an additional resource of nearly EUR 4 billion. Today's decision by the European Parliament also provided agricultural and cohesion resources for Hungary in this year's and next year's budgets. The Hungarian People's Party delegation, together with the European People's Party, acted responsibly on behalf of the national interests of Hungary and voted in favour of the 2015 EU budget and all the reports contained in the related agreement. The agreement also includes reports mobilising the Solidarity Fund to mitigate the damage caused by natural disasters affecting different regions of Europe.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted against the report because it transfers the commitment appropriations of the 2014 SAP to 2015, while reducing the corresponding funds in the 2015 P/O.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — The Amending Budget No 6 proposed here concerns the revision of traditional own resources forecasts, VAT contributions and GNI, resulting in a reduction in funding in the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF) of almost EUR 77 million in commitments and EUR 6.2 million in payments. This reduction is mainly due to the late adoption of the fund's legal basis, which makes it impossible to use the money in a timely manner, a regrettable aspect given the sharp decline that the sector has suffered in recent decades.  The proposal moves forward with the use of the EUR 6.2 million of payments withdrawn from the EMFF to help finance possible humanitarian assistance crises by the end of the year. Given the circumstances explained in relation to the delay in the adoption of the EMFF, regrettable fact, as has been said, this amendment is nonetheless understandable and acceptable.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — Since draft amending budget No 1/2004 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 December 6/2014: Review of the forecast of traditional own resources, VAT and GNI-based contributions, pass on the commitment appropriations of the 2014 GPA to 2015, while reducing the corresponding funds in the 2015 P/O, I vote against it.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - We can abstain from amending budget No 6 on the ground that it gives a very insufficient solution to the problem of suspended payments and that it is part of an austericidal and insolidary agreement that includes the 2015 budget that We can reject.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We can abstain from amending budget No 6 on the ground that it gives a very insufficient solution to the problem of suspended payments and that it is part of an austericidal and insolidary agreement that includes the 2015 budget that We can reject.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a motion for a resolution on the Council's position on the draft amendment to budget No 1009/2013. 6/2014 on the grounds that funding made since the late adoption of the legal basis of the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and an updated assessment of the state of negotiations related to sustainable fisheries partnership agreements will be channelled in cases of humanitarian crises. Also, these amendments will contribute to reducing Member States' GNI contributions and increasing the forecasts for traditional own resources. Therefore, I consider that amendments to the No. 6/2014 well thought out.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I supported the draft amending budget as it reduces the amount Member States, such as the UK, need to pay due to the recent GNI adjustments.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - Draft amending budget No 6 concerns the impact of the annual compensation for contributions due to Member States on the basis of VAT and GNI resources. This update is mainly due to the fact that some reserves for the period 1995-2013 have been released, leading to a significant amount of around EUR 9,5 billion. These sums had to be redistributed among the Member States by a corresponding reduction in their annual contribution. In view of the exceptional nature of the amount, it was decided during the negotiations to de-ration these adjustments.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — I have not been able to vote in favour of the draft amending budget because it is not a sufficient response to the hole in all the European Union budgets. This budget sanctions the United Kingdom's position on the calculation of its GDP, legitimizing the reduction of its payments and aggravating both the budgetary situation and the balance of contributions between Member States. However, this budget guarantees the payment of unpaid invoices by the European institutions; that is why I have not been able to vote against this report.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — Additional amounts set out in statistical corrections will impose an additional budgetary burden on Member States, especially those in a difficult economic situation.  I supported the report on the draft amendment to budget number 6 for 2014, which will reduce Member States' contributions based on gross national income by €4.5 billion.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I abstained from the vote in the Deprez Report on draft amending budget No 1/2004. 6/2014: Review of the provision of traditional own resources, VAT and GNI-based contributions because it does not adequately address the serious issues under consideration.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — Draft amending budget No 6 refers to the impact of the annual compensation of contributions due to the Member States of the European Union on the basis of VAT and GNI.  In my opinion, the document is entirely acceptable, and I have therefore chosen to support it with a vote in favour.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — Since some of the factors in the amending budget may well seem positive, such as amending budgets Nos 4, 6 and 8, it might be considered that the drafts should be approved as a whole. However, the fact that the overall budget is still far too high to be able to finance it sensibly and, above all, sustainably over the next few years, weighs more heavily and I reject it.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — As every year, the EU is increasing its amending budgets (9 in 2013) without succeeding in rectifying its delicate budgetary situation. Due to the historic contraction of the 2014 budget (down $10 billion, or less 6%), unpaid debts continue to accumulate without being able to finance any new priority. This amending budget adds to the austerity. It allows states to temporarily reduce their contribution to the European budget in return for collecting a surplus of fines collected by the EU (rectification budget 4). By the way, this amending budget still eliminates appropriations, notably by cutting the European Fund for Maritime Affairs and Fisheries. Europe is sinking into short-sighted austerity. Having already voted against the 2014 budget in November 2013, I am voting against this stupid and irresponsible amending budget for the future of the continent.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — This draft amending budget (POR) No 6/2014 concerns the revision of traditional own resources forecasts, VAT and GNI contributions, a reduction in appropriations for the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and the reserve for sustainable fisheries partnership agreements, as well as an increase in appropriations for the European Ombudsman. Por No 6/2014's objective is to formally include these adjustments in the budget for the financial year 2014. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report as it is part of a series of amendments that will compensate for the additional payment needs requested from Member States in DAB No 3/2014 as agreed in the joint conclusions of 8 December 2014. It goes hand in hand with the other draft amending budgets which in part were to ensure that the EU Solidarity Fund can aid the areas affected by natural disasters.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of the draft amending budget No 6/2014 on revision of the forecast of traditional own resources, VAT and GNI contributions.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. I voted against PBR 6, which provides for the reduction of budgetary appropriations for the European Maritime And Fisheries Fund and the reserve for partnership agreements in the field of sustainable fisheries. A total of 76.3 million euros in commitment credits and 6.2 million payment credits were thus eliminated. In addition, in this PBR additional budgetary appropriations (to the tune of 93,500 euros) will be allocated to the missions of the European Ombudsman. This draft amending budget is therefore bad, as it provides for the reduction of funds for fishing professionals who are already victims of serious difficulties. Finally, in substance, PBR 6 does not solve the serious problems of clearing the debts of the EU and the LRAs (remains to be liquidated).

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of draft amending budget No 6/2014 for the revision of the forecasts of traditional own resources and the balances of VAT and GNI own resources. It also provides for a reduction in the budget appropriations for the European Maritime Affairs Fund and an increase in the appropriations allocated to the European Ombudsman.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - As the estimates put the planning for the current period on a more reliable basis for planning, I voted in favour of the application.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the revision of the forecasts for traditional own resources and VAT and GNI contributions and which frees up EUR 4.5 billion in the new EU budget. Although the sums may have been higher, this compromise is better than nothing at all.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the proposal because it will make it possible to save EUR 6.2 million to help finance humanitarian aid at the end of the year in the event of possible crises.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Draft amending budget (PBR) No 6/2014 concerns the revision of the forecasts of traditional own resources and vat and GNI own resources balances, a reduction in the budgetary appropriations relating to the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and the reserve for partnership agreements in the field of sustainable fisheries, and an increase in the budgetary appropriations allocated to the European Ombudsman. The overall impact of the PBR in terms of revenue, following the adoption of Letter of Amendment No 1/2014, is a decrease of EUR 4 095.5 million in own resources requirements, including a reduction in GNI-based Member States' contributions of EUR 4 515.5 million and an increase in traditional own resources of EUR 420 million. For these reasons, I would vote in favour.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. - Whereas draft amending budget (POR) No 6/2014 concerns the revision of traditional own resources forecasts, VAT and GNI contributions, a reduction in appropriations for the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and the reserve for sustainable fisheries partnership agreements, as well as an increase in appropriations for the European Ombudsman. The overall impact of this POR in terms of revenue is a reduction in the mobilisation of own resources by EUR 4 095.5 million and its objective is to formally include these adjustments in the budget for the financial year 2014. Noting that the adoption of this POR No 6/2014 reduces the needs for GNI contributions of the Member States by EUR 4515.5 million and increases the forecasts for traditional own resources by EUR 420 million, I declare that I would vote in favour of this resolution approving the Council's position on draft amending budget No 6/2014.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — After arduous negotiations, an agreement has been reached that will allow the payment of outstanding invoices, for which the amount of EUR 4.8 billion has been agreed for the period 2014-2015. In addition, the Commission, the Council and Parliament have agreed on a payment plan aimed at reducing the level of unpaid invoices within the current multiannual framework. An unprecedented level of default has accumulated throughout this year.  The agreed EUR 4.8 billion will enable part of the accumulated invoices to be met, thus helping to alleviate the situation of many SMEs, universities, local authorities and NGOs. For 2015, it has been agreed to allocate EUR 145 321.5 million to commitment appropriations and EUR 141 214,040 563 million to payment appropriations. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - We can abstain from amending budget No 6 on the ground that it gives a very insufficient solution to the problem of suspended payments and that it is part of an austericidal and insolidary agreement that includes the 2015 budget that We can reject.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I supported this amending budget because it updates the contribution each Member State must make to the general budget of the European Union as a result of the change in calculation methods. In general, Member States' contribution to the budget is reduced compared to the previous year.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. — Traditional own resources are assessed on the basis of what appear to be objective measurements of tax resources and general economic outputs. The underlying assumption is that the methodologies deployed to gather data are fit for purpose across all Member States of the EU in a comparable manner. It is necessary to continually review this assumption.  For example, are estimations of services inputs across economies really comparable when ranging from larger countries to the smallest like Malta? And from countries with the largest reliance on services to those with the smallest? Similarly, estimates and time phasing of re-exports in national accounts have little importance for larger countries, but could distort the picture enormously for the smallest ones. Meanwhile, despite the pretence, current data about public revenues and expenditures are still far from being measured on an accruals basis. What’s more, the criteria used make no allowance for the fact that some tax structures, like VAT, carry a higher fixed cost per capita for smaller states than for larger ones. The use of so-called objective criteria and data give the impression that the allocation of contributions is a fair distribution of burdens among Member States. It may be a mistaken impression.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - We can abstain from amending budget No 6 on the ground that it gives a very insufficient solution to the problem of suspended payments and that it is part of an austericidal and insolidary agreement that includes the 2015 budget that We can reject.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I have not been able to vote in favour of the draft amending budget because it is not a sufficient answer for the hole in all the European Union budgets. This budget sanctions the United Kingdom's position on the calculation of its GDP, legitimizing the reduction of its payments and aggravating both the budgetary situation and the balance of contributions between Member States. However, this budget guarantees the payment of unpaid invoices by the European institutions; that is why I have not been able to vote against this report.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — Today I voted in favour of draft amending budget No 6/2014 on the revision of the forecast of traditional own resources, VAT and GNI contributions. It also involves a reduction in the budgetary appropriations for the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and the reserve for Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreements, as well as an increase in the budgetary appropriations for the European Ombudsman. I welcome the proposal to use EUR 6.2 million of the savings in payment appropriations to help finance possible humanitarian aid crises by the end of the year.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — I supported Deprez's report amending draft budget no. 6\2014: reviewing estimates of traditional own resources, VAT and GNI contributions, as the impact of draft budget amendment No 1000/2015 is 6\2014 on member contributions under the GNI reduction of EUR 4 515.5 million and an increase of EUR 420 million in forecasts for traditional own resources. I also welcome the proposal to use the €6.2 million spent under the payment appropriations referred to in paragraph 2 to contribute to aid funding in the event of possible humanitarian crises by the end of the year. Also, by adopting draft budget amendment No. 6\2014 will reduce the need for GNI contributions from Member States by €4 515.5 million.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — I support this draft budget relating to the revision of traditional own resources forecasts and VAT and GNI contributions, the reduction of budget appropriations earmarked for the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and the reserve for sustainable fisheries partnership agreements. The reason for the reduction of the budget appropriations related to the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund is too late to adopt the legal basis of the Fund. The main effect of the draft GNI-based budget change through all members is a reduction of 4 515.5m euros.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — Transfers commitment appropriations for 2014 to 2015, while reducing the corresponding funds in the 2015 P/O.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of Mr Deprez's proposal, which was presented in the plenary debate in December 2014. I therefore voted in favour of the text on the Council's position on the European Union's draft amending budget No. 6/2014 for the 2014 financial year, Section III - Commission.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — Amending Budget No 6 concerns the revision of traditional own resources forecasts, VAT contributions and GNI. In practice it represents a reduction in funding in the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund of almost EUR 77 million in commitments and EUR 6.2 million in payments.  This reduction is mainly due to the late adoption of the fund's legal basis, which makes it impossible to use the money in a timely manner, a regrettable aspect given the increase in the decline that the sector has been suffering in recent decades, adding more difficulties with this reduction.  The proposal moves forward with the use of the EUR 6.2 million of payments withdrawn from the EMFF to help finance possible humanitarian assistance crises by the end of the year.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — Since this proposal would, among other things, also mean a higher burden on Austria, I rejected it in principle. Partial payment options are a welcome idea, but the proposal itself makes it impossible for me to agree. In addition, this proposal forms the basis for amending budgets 3, 4, 6 and 8. In this respect, the amending budgets mentioned above were also to be rejected.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — Amending Budget No 6 proposed here concerns the revision of traditional own resources forecasts, VAT contributions and GNI, resulting in a reduction in funding in the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund by almost EUR 77 million in commitments and EUR 6.2 million in payments. This reduction is mainly due to the late adoption of the EMFF legal basis, which makes it impossible to use the money in a timely manner, a regrettable aspect given the increase in the decline that the sector has been suffering in recent decades, adding more difficulties with this reduction.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it involves mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund to deal with the emergency situation arising from the recent floods in the Balkan area. The European Union must be able to act as quickly as possible to help victims of such natural disasters which have terrible consequences for the inhabitants of the affected regions, both in EU countries and others. Mobilisation of the Fund to address the consequences on the local population is essential for a European Union project that tries to help people, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund was set up to provide solidarity in the event of major natural disasters. The cause was the severe flooding in Central Europe in the summer of 2002. Since then, the Fund has been used in many disasters and is therefore one of the EU's most important aid to the affected population. The EU's Multiannual Financial Framework for 2014-2020 provides a mobilisation of the Fund within an annual expenditure ceiling of €500 million.  Due to floods in May and June 2014, Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria have applied for such a contribution from the Fund.  I therefore welcome the fact that, with the adoption of the decision by the European Parliament, almost EUR 80 million will be made available to these countries from the European Union Solidarity Fund to deal with the consequences of the floods.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of all draft amending budgets for 2014 and for the agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council on the 2015 budget. I congratulate the Negotiators of the European Parliament on the eur 4.25 billion allocated to the emergency debts of this year's EU budget. The European Commission would be obliged to draw up a step-by-step plan for the reduction of outstanding bills and to establish a sustainable debt ceiling in the future. Thanks to Parliament, eur 0.5 billion will be allocated to commitments. than the COUNCIL of the EU proposed. More funding will be allocated to horizon 2020 and the Erasmus+ programme for student and youth exchange. It is to be welcomed that the increase in funding for European neighbourhood programmes, humanitarian aid and the common foreign security policy has been increased, which is very relevant in the light of today's situation in Europe. However, I do not support the reduction in funding for the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund, which will affect many EU farmers, who are in a particularly difficult situation because of the protracted Russian embargo and who need EU assistance.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. — The proposal, which I supported, seeks to approve the european Union Solidarity Fund's intervention on Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria following very heavy floods in May and June 2014 which caused extensive damage to public infrastructure and caused damage to thousands of families. Nearly 80 million euros have been mobilised.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. Following PBR 7/2014, providing EUR 79,726,440 in commitment credits for 2014 and as much in 2015 in payment credits, it is proposed that we support three countries following severe floods by the EU Solidarity Fund (Serbia and Croatia in May 2014 and Bulgaria in the affected by floods in June 2014). The Fund aims to express the EU's solidarity with the people of the regions affected by these disasters, so I voted in favour.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the request to mobilise the Solidarity Fund to the sum of EUR 80 million for croatian, Serbian and Bulgarian citizens affected by last spring's floods.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in relation to the floods in Serbia and Croatia in May 2014 and in Bulgaria in June 2014. During May 2014, vast regions of the Republic of Serbia and, to a lesser extent, Croatia were affected by inclement weather conditions that caused some of the worst floods to be remembered, causing enormous destruction in public and private infrastructure and damage to hundreds of thousands of households. A month later, heavy rains four times more abundant than the monthly weather standard affected parts of the Republic of Bulgaria causing severe flooding and disruption. In this way, EUR 79.7 million will be mobilized to help alleviate the consequences of the disasters in these territories.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted on this report because it supported Parliament's decision on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund. The funds will be allocated to Bulgaria as a result of the heavy and heavy rainfall that fell in June 2014, which almost quadrupled the monthly rate and caused severe flooding. Damage to public infrastructure and installations in the fields of energy, water and water resources, telecommunications, transport, health, education, emergency services, cultural heritage and protected natural areas has been damaged. Large quantities of leached soil and waste, flooded sewage systems and spilled wastewater in affected regions have led to a deterioration in living conditions.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted for this because we need to have concrete help for the zones in the European Union which have suffered natural catastrophes.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. Considering that the principle of European solidarity must, of course, be applied to remedy the damage caused by natural disasters, I have of course voted in favour of mobilising the EU Solidarity Fund.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — Vote in favour of mobilising the EU Solidarity Fund (linked to amending budget No 7 for the financial year 2014). The amount of the funds is EUR 79 726 942 in commitment and payment appropriations. The intervention relates to the damage caused by the floods in Serbia and Croatia in May 2014 and the floods in Bulgaria in June 2014.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. — The report proposes to mobilisation the European Union Solidarity Fund in relation to flooding in Serbia and Croatia in May 2014 and Bulgaria in June 2014 on the basis of paragraph 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013. The mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund for each of these cases and the allocation of the corresponding appropriations amounts to EUR 19 501 835 for Croatia and Bulgaria under line 13 06 01 of the 2014 budget, and the corresponding appropriations of EUR 60 224 605 for Serbia on line 13 06 02 (dedicated to the countries in the process of accession), both in commitment appropriations and in payment appropriations. In parallel with this proposal to mobilize the Solidarity Fund, the Commission has submitted a draft amending budget (PPR No 7/2014 of 17.10.2014), with a view to entering in the 2014 budget the corresponding commitment and payment appropriations — EUR 79 726 440 — as provided for in paragraph 26 of the Interinstitutional Agreement.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. MEPs voted to mobilise the Solidarity Fund for Bulgaria, Croatia and Serbia. Indeed, the floods that took place in the region this summer have caused considerable damage. The European Union had to help these countries cope with the disastrous consequences of bad weather. The Solidarity Fund will provide financial assistance of nearly 80 million euros to these three countries. This fund is a proof of European solidarity with the population of Member States affected by a major natural disaster.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the motion for a Resolution of the European Parliament on the Council's position on draft amending budget No. EU Regulation (EC) No 7/2014 mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) amounting to EUR 79 726 440 in commitment and payment appropriations, in relation to the floods in Serbia and Croatia in May 2014 and Bulgaria in June 2014, in accordance with the principle of solidarity that Europe must give to Member States at certain particular times. In these cases, it is essential to invest resources in the prevention of hydrogeological failure, in order to protect citizens and protect them from the sometimes devastating risks of such events. The same applies to the territories themselves for which, over and above the unpredictability of such events, damage can always be limited.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — Support for families and businesses in difficulty is one of the Union's duties. The vote is in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) Solidarity between the EU States (and with the candidate countries) should go beyond purely accountants' logic, and in line with this principle I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to respond to major natural disasters and express European solidarity with affected regions in Europe. The Fund may provide financial assistance to Member States and candidate countries negotiating their participation. In May 2014, Serbia and Croatia were affected by the worst floods in memory. In June 2014, bulgaria was affected by severe flooding. I support the mobilisation of EUR 79 726 440 in favour of the Member States concerned, which contributes to the EU demonstrating its solidarity and support for the affected countries by contributing to the financing of urgent measures, such as the immediate restoration of the operation of infrastructure and equipment in the fields of energy production, the supply of drinking water, the treatment of waste water , telecommunications, transport, health and education; the implementation of provisional housing measures and the provision of relief services to meet the immediate needs of the affected population; the immediate consolidation of preventive infrastructure and the protection of cultural heritage sites; immediate cleanliness of disaster areas, including natural areas.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — The European Union has created a European Union Solidarity Fund to show solidarity with the population of regions struck by disasters. I have voted in favour of this report to enable the mobilisation of the European Solidarity Fund in favour of floods in Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria which led to the destruction of public and private infrastructure and worsened the living conditions in the affected areas.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — The Commission proposes the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund following very serious floods in Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria, totalling some EUR 79 million. In order to facilitate the mobilisation of this fund and to show Europe's proximity to the territories affected by natural disasters, I can only vote in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it involves mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund to deal with the emergency situation arising from the recent floods in the Balkan area. The European Union must be able to act as quickly as possible to help victims of such natural disasters which have terrible consequences for the inhabitants of the affected regions, both in EU countries and others. Mobilisation of the Fund to address the impact on the local population is critical to a European Union project that tries to help people. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — I agree with the Commission's proposal to mobilise the European Solidarity Fund with regard to the floods in Serbia and Croatia in May 2014 and floods in Bulgaria in June 2014. In the light of the examination of the applications, and considering the maximum possible grant from the Fund, as well as the scope for reallocating appropriations, the Commission proposes to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund. Solidarity is a main pillar of our Union. Therefore, I voted in favour of granting this support.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. — I welcome the vote to mobilise the Solidarity Fund in support of European citizens affected by floods in Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria.
