These serious floods have caused massive damage to public and private infrastructure, damaged hundreds of thousands of households, with the most affected economic sectors being mining, agriculture and transport infrastructure.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. — During last May, bad weather hit much of the Republic of Serbia and, to a lesser extent, Croatia, causing severe flooding causing massive destruction of public and private infrastructure and causing damage to hundreds of thousands of homes. A month later, heavy and severe rains exceeding four times the monthly climate averages hit parts of the Republic of Bulgaria, causing severe flooding and disruption. The Solidarity Fund enables the European Union to provide effective assistance to a Member State or a country in the process of accession when it has to deal with the damage caused by a major natural disaster. It is proposed to bring in eur 19,501,835 for Croatia and Bulgaria, and for Serbia eur 60,224,605. In the name of European solidarity with the Member States of the Union and the accession countries and their inhabitants who are experiencing a period of great difficulty, I voted in favour of this financial support.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. Through this text, the Commission rightly proposes to activate the European Union Solidarity Fund for Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria, which were hit by severe floods during the months of May and June 2014. In these countries, the damage caused by these bad weather has been considerable. In these circumstances, it is important that the European Union supports the rehabilitation of destroyed infrastructure and is on the side of the populations affected by these exceptional climatic conditions.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. — In May 2014, bad weather severely affected large areas of the Republic of Serbia and Croatia, causing severe flooding. A month later, heavy and sustained rainfall hit some provinces of the Republic of Bulgaria, causing extensive damage. I voted in favour of the proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund in favour of these seriously affected regions.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. — The European Parliament today adopted by a large majority the EU budget for 2015 and the amendments on surplus resources for 2014. The huge advantage of the agreement is that it will be able to pass the EU budget for 2015 later this year, i.e. next year it would not only be possible to pay 12th of this year's budget per month. By 2014, an additional €4 billion will be mobilised, of which EUR 3.5 billion will be the result of so-called 'fresh money', i.e. not transfers.  The EP only agreed to the adoption of next year's EU budget on the condition that the European Commission draws up a plan to reduce unpaid bills to sustainable levels. In 2014, €23.4 billion will have to be paid from the previous year. To this end, today's vote provides an additional resource of nearly EUR 4 billion. Today's decision by the European Parliament also provided agricultural and cohesion resources for Hungary in this year's and next year's budgets. The Hungarian People's Party delegation, together with the European People's Party, acted responsibly on behalf of the national interests of Hungary and voted in favour of the 2015 EU budget and all the reports contained in the related agreement. The agreement also includes reports mobilising the Solidarity Fund to mitigate the damage caused by natural disasters affecting different regions of Europe.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. — The important contributions of the Member States must be given to Europeans and in particular to those affected by natural disasters. It is a healthy and sincere solidarity that I support, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. — While I supported the report on the granting of assistance from the Solidarity Fund to address the damage caused by floods in Bulgaria, I believe that once again an injustice is being committed against Bulgaria. This injustice, of course, also applies to other small and poorer countries in the Union. The whole solidarity fund mechanism is wrong. It serves the interests of the rich and is ingesting poor Member States. The formula by which aid is calculated to overcome the consequences is wrong. It may be very appropriate, but it's unfair. Bulgaria is allocated 10.6 million euro. eur 311 million in damages. European. And the damage is great in underdeveloped regions. It'il be decades before they get over it. I use this case to call on both the Commission and Parliament to amend the legal basis on which the Solidarity Fund is working to remedy these injustices in the future. Citizens of Member States need to see genuine solidarity in such cases. This is now no solidarity. I dare say that on this issue I express the opinion of the majority of Bulgarian citizens. We're not second-hand people.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the report, even though the funds provided are scarce and do not meet the needs of the countries, because any aid is desirable.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. — Last May and June 2014 Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria suffered a period of heavy rains causing heavy flooding that caused extensive property damage. In this regard, the mobilization of the Solidarity Funds is essential to help cover emergency costs and assist in the reconstruction and implementation of the most necessary services and infrastructures. The objective of mobilizing these funds is to reduce the immediate and direct impact of natural disasters, which is why rapid and effective mobilization of these funds is needed. In this regard, in January 2014 I had the pleasure of being the rapporteur of the report for the reform of Regulation (EC) No 2012/2002, which establishes and regulates the EU Solidarity Funds, considering that rapid mobilisation of these funds is essential for the minimisation of disaster damage. These funds are also a key instrument for strengthening the EU accession process, as candidate countries are entitled to such funds, as is the case in Serbia in the process of accession negotiations.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - The report approves the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund following the floods in Serbia and Croatia in May 2014 and the floods in Bulgaria in June 2014. Serbia and Croatia were affected by the severe flooding. Causing serious damage to public and private infrastructure and damage to hundreds of thousands of families. As the total direct damage estimated in both countries exceeds the normal threshold for mobilising the Solidarity Fund, this disaster can be considered a major natural disaster.  In Bulgaria, some of its regions have been affected by heavy and abundant rainfall causing severe flooding. Public infrastructure and equipment have been damaged in the fields of energy, water and water resources, telecommunications, transport, health, education, emergency services, cultural heritage and protected natural areas. As the estimated total direct damage exceeds the threshold, this disaster can be considered a 'major natural disaster'. In both cases, the mobilisation of the Fund, which we supported, is justified. However, we call for the importance of the adoption (and due funding) of disaster prevention measures, also of the kind that are now in these two countries.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing — The European Union Solidarity Fund is an important instrument whose very name tells of the nature of its mission. In the past, the Slovak Republic also received significant assistance in the event of a natural disaster in the High Tatras. These funds have greatly helped to repair the damage that has been caused in our mountains. I will therefore always support proposals that will lead us to use this fund to help the Member States of the European Union and Serbia to repair damage from natural disasters, as we are doing now in relation to Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria. I believe that our joint funds will help the people of these countries in particular.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — Each country must be examined differently and in accordance with the specific circumstances of the prevailing treaties. In this report, the funds provided for are minimal and do not meet the needs of the countries, but all aid is in the right direction. That is why I am voting in favour of mobilising the EU Solidarity Fund for floods in Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - Our vote is in favour of all redistributive transfers that are intended to aid to regions or countries affected by natural disasters. We particularly believe in the redistributive nature of the European budget.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the urgent need to release financial assistance to Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria, which were affected by the natural disasters in 2014. I see it as the duty of the European Union and the main purpose of the EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF).

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - Our vote is in favour of all redistributive transfers that are intended to aid to regions or countries affected by natural disasters. We particularly believe in the redistributive nature of the European budget.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a motion for a resolution on the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund for Croatia, Serbia and Bulgaria, which applied for floods affecting them in May and June 2014. Weather conditions have caused extremely severe damage to public and private infrastructure, destroyed hundreds of thousands of homes and left memories of one of the worst floods in those areas ever. All three countries requested a higher amount than the fund's intended threshold for those countries. Therefore, as huge damages have been caused and these areas need urgent financial assistance, I strongly support the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund for the benefit of these countries.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. — While I understand that this is for aid, which could be used to help victims the British public are already more than generous with donating funds to charitable causes when natural disasters occur. I do not believe foreign aid to be in the remit of the EU, so I voted against this proposal.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I supported the mobilisation of the fund, as it is crucial we show solidarity with people from the affected areas by helping to rebuild basic infrastructure, funding emergency services, providing temporary accommodation, contributing to clean-up operations and countering immediate health risks.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour of the report by Mr Beazley on behalf of the Committee on The José Manuel Fernandes, as he supports areas of the Reed and Croatia that, in May 2014, were seriously affected by natural disasters. In addition, heavy rainfall fell in parts of Bulgaria in June 2014, causing extensive structural and economic damage. The European Union, once again, thanks to the Solidarity Fund, is showing sensitivity towards all countries affected by natural disasters, in line with the principle of solidarity.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this draft amending budget because it involves mobilizing the funds needed to adapt the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund in the budgets for the 2014 financial year. The European Union must be able to act as quickly as possible to help victims of such natural disasters which have terrible consequences for the inhabitants of the affected regions. Mobilisation of funds to address the consequences on the local population is critical to a European Union project that tries to help people. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. — Severe naturally sourced floods affected Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria in 2014 causing extensive damage, especially in homes. That is why, after an assessment of damage by States and the Commission, I believe that it is necessary to help these countries financially through the EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF). The funding package stipulated for this aid entails overcoming the 500 million annual funding barrier stipulated for the EUSF (2014), but this problem can be satisfactorily addressed by moving to the 2015 budget part of the stipulated funding. I believe that this solution is appropriate so as not to transgress the budgetary barriers established and, more importantly, allows such much-needed funding to be provided to help citizens of countries hit by these recent floods. For these reasons, I vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — I supported the €79.7 million Mobilisation Report from the European Union Solidarity Fund for Croatia, Serbia and Bulgaria to try to address the effects of the catastrophic floods in May this year.  Total damage to flooded areas in Croatia is estimated at 297.6m euros. Thousands of crazy people have been displaced, transport and energy infrastructure have been damaged, crops and livestock have been damaged, housing has been flooded. 8.9m euros will be allocated to Croatia through the European Union solidarity fund to repair the damage.  In my view, in addition to the available funds from the EU Solidarity Fund, eu funds, the European Investment Bank and other sources of funding should be mobilised to avoid disasters of this magnitude in the future.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. — Solidarity is the fundamental philosophy of the foundations of the European Union. The European Union has a duty to assist those EU Member States and potential candidate countries that have suffered natural disasters: Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria. I supported this decision.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the Fernandes report on the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund: floods in Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria, because this report launches financial support for Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria for the damage caused by natural disasters.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. — In May 2014, bad weather severely affected large areas of the Republic of Serbia and Croatia, causing some of the most serious floods that caused the destruction of public and private infrastructure and damage to hundreds of thousands of families. It is necessary to help the victims of natural disasters in regions that need financial support to recover the extensive damage caused to infrastructure and people. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — During May 2014 large areas of the Republic of Serbia and, to a lesser extent, Croatia, were hit by a terrible wave of bad weather.  A month later, heavy rainfall hit some provinces of the Republic of Bulgaria, causing severe flooding, resulting in infrastructural and economic damage.  My vote in favour of the Fernandes report stems from the conviction that the European Union must always be ready to intervene to help the Community populations affected by natural disasters, on the basis of the principle of solidarity between the Member States, which is the very foundation of the Treaties.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — I fully support this motion too. The seriousness of this disaster cannot be borne by the individual Member States alone. Serbia in particular needs urgent support, since the amount of damage caused there amounts to more than EUR 1 billion.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Writing. — (DE) As permanent rapporteur for Serbia, I would like to stress how devastating the scale of the floods in mid-May was for that country. More than 1.6 million people were affected by the floods, resulting in damage of more than one billion euros. The European Union has provided rapid and unbureaucratic assistance in the largest crisis management measure in the history of the Union. In total, the European Union will have provided Serbia with more than EUR 172 million by the end of 2014 as a result of the floods. A few weeks ago, I was in Belgrade and I learned that the people there are aware that it was the European Union in particular that helped them in these difficult times. Solidarity with the Member States is just as important as solidarity with the candidate countries. I would ask the Commission to continue along this path of solidarity as it has done so far.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — The Solidarity Fund is being asked here to provide financial assistance to Croatia, Bulgaria and Serbia to repair the damage caused by the large-scale floods they experienced in the summer of 2014. This is an important aid to enable them to rebuild their infrastructure, especially energy, and continue to secure them. I am voting for this urgently needed aid for these three countries. By lamenting that Europe is not more strongly committed to the danger that our production methods pose to the planet and climate change.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — This proposal aims at mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund following the floods in Serbia and Croatia in May 2014 and the floods in Bulgaria in June 2014, on the basis of paragraph 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013. The EU must be in solidarity with its members who suffer this type of natural disaster. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal as large parts of Serbia, Bulgaria and Croatia were hit by heavy rains and flooding. Other budgetary measures have been arranged that ensure that Member States will not be required to contribute extra funds to alleviate the situation in the areas affected by natural disasters.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of this report, which proposes to mobilise the European Solidarity Fund in favour of floods in Serbia and Croatia in May 2014 and to floods in Bulgaria in June 2014.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Considering that the principle of European solidarity must obviously apply to remedy the damage caused by natural disasters, I have of course voted in favour of mobilising the EU Solidarity Fund.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund in order to better equip Member States to rebuild basic infrastructure, fund emergency services, provide temporary accommodation, contribute to clean-up operations and counter immediate health risks.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund following the floods in Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria last spring.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. The EUSF was created following the floods that hit Central Europe in the summer of 2002. I voted in favour of the deployment of this fund in the specific case of floods in Serbia, Bulgaria and Croatia.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal to help Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria with a total of EUR 79 726 440 in order to eradicate damage caused by floods. The European Union Solidarity Fund is designed precisely to help and show solidarity with the people of the disaster-stricken regions.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — (IT) The European Union has set up the Solidarity Fund to show its solidarity with the populations of the regions affected by disasters. Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria have applied to mobilise the Fund in connection with floods in their territories. Within the framework of the general budget of the European Union set for the financial year 2014, a sum of EUR 79 726 440 of commitment and payment appropriations shall be mobilised under the Fund. For these reasons, I would vote in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. If we do not endorse the Union's cohesion policy and believe that it does not alleviate economic and social disparities between Member States, we believe that the principle of European solidarity can make sense when one of our European neighbours is seriously affected by a natural disaster. Moreover, the climatic events that have hit the south of France in recent months reinforce the idea that mutual financial assistance must enable us to better respond to the human, material and financial consequences of this type of tragic event. Common management of natural risks must be encouraged at European level in order to strengthen risk pooling. That is why I voted for the mobilization of the Solidarity Fund.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — Heavy rainfall in eastern Croatia from 13 to 15 May caused catastrophic flooding that led to the collapse of traffic routes and the evacuation of the population. Rainfall in just three days reached the quarterly average. Unstable conditions on the ground, the spaciousness of the flooded area, damage to houses and other buildings, crops and livestock, the risk of mines mined and a large number of long-term dislocated persons from Croatia, as well as from BiH, are the reasons why Croatia has requested international assistance. The direct damage suffered by Croatia amounted to EUR 297 629 million, while the proposed amount from the EU Solidarity Fund for Assistance to Croatia amounted to EUR 8 959 725. Based on the overall damage assessment and claims from Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria, the Commission proposed the activation of the Solidarity Fund in the amount of EUR 79 726 440. I believe that Croatia needs to invest in a better flood defence system to reduce future damage.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Writing. — (DE) I believe it is necessary to take more preventive measures. Of course, it is primarily the states concerned that are called upon to do this. At the same time, the EU has the opportunity to refocus on one of its very own tasks. As Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria are sometimes affected by the same natural events, it must support and promote cross-border cooperation for the benefit of all EU citizens.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — European Solidarity Funds have been designed to provide financial support to regions where natural disasters with the greatest consequences are falling. I therefore vote in favour of the use of such a fund in order to best remedy the damage caused by severe weather in Croatia and Bulgaria.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — The Commission proposes mobilising the EU Solidarity Fund following the floods in Serbia and Croatia in May 2014 and floods in Bulgaria in June 2014. Such disasters have caused considerable damage to the requesting Member States and the eligibility criteria set out in Council Regulation (EC) No 2012/2002 establishing the European Union Solidarity Fund, are met, as set out in Regulation (EU) No 661/2014 of the European Parliament and the Council. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution approving the decision to mobilise eur 79 726 440 for Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of mobilizing the European Union Solidarity Fund in relation to flooding in Serbia and Croatia in May 2014, and in Bulgaria in June 2014. During May 2014, vast regions of the Republic of Serbia and, to a lesser extent, Croatia were affected by inclement weather conditions that caused some of the worst floods to be remembered, causing enormous destruction in public and private infrastructure and damage to hundreds of thousands of households. A month later, heavy rains four times more abundant than the monthly weather standard affected parts of the Republic of Bulgaria causing severe flooding and disruption. In this way, EUR 79.7 million will be mobilized to help alleviate the consequences of the disasters in these territories.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - Our vote is in favour of all redistributive transfers that are intended to aid to regions or countries affected by natural disasters. We particularly believe in the redistributive nature of the European budget.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund following requests from Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria for flooding in 2014. The damage caused by these floods has been numerous and terrible: massive destruction of public and private infrastructure, damage to hundreds of thousands of households, destruction of agricultural crops, etc. Both the economic sector and the citizens of these countries have been hard hit by these floods! That is why it was crucial to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund to help these countries and their citizens.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund of EUR 79 726 440 in favour of minimising the damage caused by the severe floods in Serbia and Croatia in May 2014 and for floods in Bulgaria in June 2014 , on the basis of paragraph 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013. We are facing natural disasters, which have negatively and in a very incisive way, various economic sectors, including energy, mining and agriculture, as well as road infrastructure, public telecommunications equipment, health, education and coastal protection facilities, which can and should be covered within the scope of the Solidarity Fund.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour because the intervention we are voting on aims to repair the damage caused by floods which have had a terrible impact on the affected areas.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - Our vote is in favour of all redistributive transfers that are intended to aid to regions or countries affected by natural disasters. We particularly believe in the redistributive nature of the European budget.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because it involves mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund to deal with the emergency situation arising from the recent floods in the Balkan area. The European Union must be able to act as quickly as possible to help victims of such natural disasters which have terrible consequences for the inhabitants of the affected regions, both in EU countries and others. Mobilisation of the Fund to address the impact on the local population is critical to a European Union project that tries to help people. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. — While I understand that this is for aid, which could be used to help victims, the British public are already more than generous with donating funds to charitable causes when natural disasters occur. I do not believe foreign aid to be in the remit of the EU, so I voted against this proposal.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — I voted for the Commission's proposal to mobilise the EU Solidarity Fund in favour of floods in Serbia and Croatia in May 2014 and floods in Bulgaria in June 2014. The flooding is of natural origin and therefore falls within the field of application of the Solidarity Fund. The total amount of aid proposed for Croatia and Bulgaria comes to EUR 19 501 835 and Serbia will receive the appropriation of EUR 60 224 605.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. — I supported the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund because I think it will make it easier for Croatia, Serbia and Bulgaria to recover from the damage caused by the severe floods.  As a Croatian representative, I am personally familiar with the unfortunate events that took place in Croatia and other countries. The resulting damages will leave long-lasting consequences on the lives of citizens who have been directly affected by the floods, and the resulting damage will have an adverse impact on the overall economic development of the countries. In the Republic of Croatia, floods caused damage of a total of 197m euros, accounting for almost 0.7% of gross national income. More than 4000 outbuildings and more than 2700 residential buildings were flooded and most of the structures have permanent structural damage. Also of particular concern is the fact that more than 26,000 people were evacuated from their homes during the floods.  The overall situation is hampered by damage to infrastructure in affected areas, the reconstruction of which is crucial for normalising citizens' lives.  The Solidarity Fund will greatly facilitate this process, funds from the Fund will help to more efficiently repair damages, but will also directly lead to increased stability and facilitate the economic recovery of countries. For all the above reasons, I voted to mobilize this Solidarity Fund.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — The Solidarity Fund is a tool to enable the European Union to swiftly and effectively support a Member State in its efforts to deal with damage caused by a major natural disaster. It is a fund financed by the regular EU budget and can be made available for up to €1 billion a year.  Based on the estimate, the damages are as follows: Serbia 1 105 622m euros, Croatia 297 629m euros, Bulgaria 311 328m euros. The Commission proposed to mobilise eu solidarity funds totalling €79 726 440. This support will certainly help member states and their residents in repairing damages and restoring the damaged parts.  I personally visited flooded areas in Croatia and for this reason I understand the importance of these funds to return the economy to a positive direction. The funds will help restore infrastructure in affected areas, especially rural areas. It is also important to provide a dignified life for the affected population. Therefore, I support the report.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — The Solidarity Fund is one of the instruments enabling the European Union to swiftly and effectively support a Member State in its efforts to deal with damage caused by a major natural disaster. The Fund is financed by a regular EU budget with €1 billion a year at its disposal. Although the estimated damages amounted to: in Serbia 1 105 622m euros, Croatia 297 629m euros, Bulgaria 311 328m euros, I am aware that funds from the Union budget will not be sufficient to cover the total damage. I therefore supported the Commission's proposal to mobilise Union solidarity funds totalling €79 726 440, of which €8.9 million will go to Croatia, €60.2 million to Serbia and €10.5 million to Bulgaria, and I also call on Member States to take serious approaches to developing flood defence strategies and infrastructure construction so that this scenario does not happen again in the future.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — Each country must be examined differently and in accordance with the specific circumstances of the prevailing treaties. In this report, the funds provided for are minimal and do not meet the needs of the countries, but all aid is in the right direction.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — The Commission proposes to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund for Serbia and Croatia, which was flooded in May 2014, and Bulgaria, which was flooded in June 2014, on the basis of point 11 of the inter-institutional agreement of 2 December 2013. The Solidarity Fund aims to help European citizens who are victims of extraordinary negative circumstances. During The month of May 2014, bad weather hit much of the Republic of Serbia and, to a lesser extent, Croatia, causing the most severe human-memory floods, causing massive destruction of public and private infrastructure and causing damage to hundreds of thousands of households. A month later, heavy and severe rains exceeding four times the monthly climate averages hit parts of the Republic of Bulgaria, causing severe flooding and disruption.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. — I voted positively on this report, although I share the concerns of the majority in my group regarding the Draft Amendments to the 2014 Budget and the Draft Budget for 2015. While they rightly seek fiscal discipline from Member States that are used to spending money they do not have, the Institutions of the European Union often behave equally irresponsibly. The Union's credibility towards Member States and citizens cannot be built in this way and order will finally have to be brought into European finances. However, as an MP from Croatia, I know very well the situation on the ground that was directly affected by the May floods. To people who lost their roof over their heads and now live in dumpsters, our political outsmarting of them means little to abstract things. They see Europe through a dignified life they do not have at the moment, and the payment of these grants can nevertheless help us restore their lost dignity. That's why I supported this report.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. — My vote is in favour of mobilizing extra funds for the benefit of States affected by natural disasters.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — The European Union has set up the European Union Solidarity Fund (Fund) to express its solidarity with the people of the regions affected by disasters. Article 10 of Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 allows the Fund to be mobilised within an annual ceiling of EUR 500 million (in 2011 prices). Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria have submitted a request to mobilise the Fund following floods. The Serbian authorities estimate the total amount of direct damage caused by the disaster at EUR 1.1 billion. This estimate is based on the results of the recovery needs assessment carried out with the participation of the EU and international organisations in the period immediately following the disaster.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: As a result of the floods that occurred in Bulgaria in 2014, many towns and villages experienced devastating disasters, dozens of casualties were given. In many settlements, all infrastructure and communication links have been cut off, and tens of thousands of citizens have yet to rebuild their homes. Guided by the understanding that we, as representatives of the institutions, stand a number of tasks until the full return to normal life of the injured areas, from the very first days I contacted the local authorities about the real dimensions of the damage suffered. I received official information from more than a 100 municipalities in the affected 13 districts of Bulgaria, which I passed on to the central authorities. Two Bulgarian governments have worked on the requests for compensation from the Solidarity Fund, and the funds received will help restore the public infrastructure of the affected regions, where over three million and three hundred thousand of my compatriots live.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: I supported the report on budget adjustments in relation to the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund, but I believe that the financial assistance granted to Bulgaria is extremely insufficient. It is completely unfair that a Member State with proven damages above EUR 311 million receives only EUR 10.6 million. I demand that the current solidarity fund mechanism be reconsidered and modified to be more useful and to do what it was set up for. Is it worth it to someone in the Chamber fairly one of the most affected countries in the European Union, namely Bulgaria, to receive six times less financial assistance than the neighboring Republic of Serbia, which is not even a member of the European Union but will receive EUR 60 million in compensation? On 9 December, I also referred this question to the European Commission. I would like to point out that this mechanism, instead of helping, clearly discriminates against the more affected and poorer countries, as Bulgaria is unfortunately at the moment. Does anyone really think that eur 10.6 million will repair damage of more than EUR 300 million? And this, I repeat, we are talking about one of the most damaged regions, the northwest, which at the same time is also the poorest in Europe. Again, the mechanism needs to change because it is ingesting poorer countries, depriving them of adequate aid and leaving them virtually alone to save themselves. This is not solidarity.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Mr. President, this budget change is also very important for mobilising 80m euros in funds to help Croatia, Bulgaria, Serbia after the severe floods of May this year. These are funds that are significant for remediation of damages, but it remains very important to bear in mind that funds need to be allocated to preventive infrastructure and in general to prevent from these severe floods that are increasingly common at EUROPEAN Union level.  Therefore, it is necessary to think about how to invest as much european funds, european investment bank funds and other sources of financing as possible in preventing such accidents and disasters from happening in the future.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Mr. President, draft budget change No. 7 for 2014 is extremely important because it allows the disbursement of funds from the European Solidarity Fund for the Republic of Croatia, due to the extensive damage caused by the floods, which destroyed public and private infrastructure and damaged hundreds of thousands of homes in May this year, both in Croatia, but also in Serbia, our neighbouring country, as well as in Bosnia and Herzegovina. These are in any case major difficulties that had to be answered by a quality signing, primarily damages estimated at nearly 300m euros, the funds foreseen in this budget for the Republic of Croatia of nearly 9m euros together with those for floods and for ice that were a few months before, account for a total assistance to Croatia of about 16.5m euros. I believe that these funds will facilitate the Croatian budget in order to help a number of counties that have been badly affected by this disaster.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Mr. President, it was the great floods of 2002 that were the reason for the creation of the European Union Solidarity Fund, and I want to thank all the citizens and institutions who helped.  Of course, the amount approved is not nearly enough to cover the costs, but it is a strong confirmation of one of the fundamental principles of the European Union, the principle of solidarity. But I warn about the problem of better prevention of flood damage, which is necessary given the outdated ways of managing rivers in Europe, including Croatia. But it costs a lot of money together with repairing the damage. Under the current directives, Croatia should invest HRK 45 billion in network installation and renovation of facilities by 2023, which is almost half of the annual budget. Given that direct flood damage in Croatia alone amounts to almost 300m euros, the question arises as to how much expected investments are achievable. Better prevention also reduces the possible costs of remediation in the future.  I hope that the European Union will, through the Funds, significantly help the members to make the expected investments.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Mr. President, I voted positively on this report, although I share the concerns of the majority in my group regarding the draft amendments to the 2014 budget and the draft budget for 2015.   Although they rightly seek fiscal discipline from Member States that are used to spending money they do not have, european Union insitutions often behave equally irresponsibly. The Union's credibility towards Member States and citizens cannot be built in this way and order will finally have to be brought into European finances. But as an MP from Wrestling, I know very well the situation on the ground that was directly affected by the May floods. To people who lost their roof over their heads and now live in dumpsters, our political outsmarting of them means little to abstract things. They see Europe through a dignified life that they do not have at the moment, and the payment of these grants can nevertheless help us restore their lost dignity, and that is why I supported this project.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this draft amending budget because it involves mobilizing the funds needed to adapt the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund in the budgets for the 2014 financial year. The European Union must be able to act as quickly as possible to help victims of such natural disasters which have terrible consequences for the inhabitants of the affected regions. Mobilisation of funds to address the consequences on the local population is critical to a European Union project that tries to help people. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — Aid through the Solidarity Fund is not an efficient means of assisting with floods.  It only represents a small portion of the money spent by Member States and is an administrative nightmare.  Far better to reduce Member States’ contributions and to allow them to deal with such matters directly themselves.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of all draft amending budgets for 2014 and for the agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council on the 2015 budget. I congratulate the Negotiators of the European Parliament on the eur 4.25 billion allocated to the emergency debts of this year's EU budget. The European Commission would be obliged to draw up a step-by-step plan for the reduction of outstanding bills and to establish a sustainable debt ceiling in the future. Thanks to Parliament, eur 0.5 billion will be allocated to commitments. than the COUNCIL of the EU proposed. More funding will be allocated to horizon 2020 and the Erasmus+ programme for student and youth exchange. It is to be welcomed that the increase in funding for European neighbourhood programmes, humanitarian aid and the common foreign security policy has been increased, which is very relevant in the light of today's situation in Europe. However, I do not support the reduction in funding for the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund, which will affect many EU farmers, who are in a particularly difficult situation because of the protracted Russian embargo and who need EU assistance.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. — The aim is to include in commitment appropriations in the 2014 budget and in payment appropriations in the 2015 budget the 80 million euros needed for the mobilization of the European Union Solidarity Fund following floods in May 2014 in Serbia and Croatia and in June 2014 in Bulgaria.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This draft amending budget 7/2014 concerns the mobilization of the EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF) for a total of EUR 79,726,440 in commitment and payment credits following floods in Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria. Unfortunately, as noted by the Members of the Committee on Budgets, the shortage of CP for 2014 (PBR 3/2014) makes it very difficult to redeploy the resources necessary for this PBT. To deal with these floods and to support the people, I voted for this draft amending budget.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the technical measure making the resources of the Solidarity Fund available to Croatian, Serbian and Bulgarian citizens affected by last spring's floods.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — I voted in favour, given that draft amending budget No 7/2014 concerns the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) of EUR 79.7 million to help alleviate the consequences of flooding in Serbia and Croatia in May 2014 and Bulgaria in June 2014. During May 2014, vast regions of the Republic of Serbia and, to a lesser extent, Croatia were affected by inclement weather conditions that caused some of the worst floods to be remembered, causing enormous destruction in public and private infrastructure and damage to hundreds of thousands of households. A month later, heavy rains four times more abundant than the monthly weather standard affected parts of the Republic of Bulgaria causing severe flooding and disruption. In this way, EUR 79.7 million will be mobilized to help alleviate the consequences of the disasters in these territories.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. — The Solidarity Fund was set up with the intention of assisting Member States and candidates in the event of natural disasters. The year 2014 will be remembered in Croatia for the natural adversity caused by great human suffering and material damage.  Gorski Kotar was shackled by snow and ice at the beginning of the year, and hit by floods that caused extensive damage to both public infrastructure and private property. Croatian government estimates suggest damages of 292m euros, so the 8.6m euros the European Union plans to allocate to Croatia is more than welcome.  After Gorski Kotar, Croatia was again killed in May when floods hit Slavonia, causing even more devastation and damage of 297.6m euros. The consequences of the water wave will be felt for a long time, but the Government of the Republic of Croatia is making significant efforts to normalize the situation in order to enable the return of citizens to flooded homes. The amount of 8.9 million that the EU will allocate from its budget to remediate the effects of floods will significantly help in these efforts. I welcome these budget changes, as the appropriations show that in distress, the Member States of the European Union are not alone, but can count on assistance from both the Union and other Member States.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted for this because we need to have a concrete help for the zones in the European Union which have suffered natural catastrophes.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the draft amending budget to mobilise the EU Solidarity Fund to support Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria, which hit the floods this year. These floods are considered to be the worst in history, causing massive destruction of public and private infrastructure, as well as damage to hundreds of thousands of households, affecting thousands of people who needed medical attention or needed to be placed in temporary areas of accommodation. Solidarity is one of the fundamental principles of the European Union, and with this decision the European Parliament demonstrates once again that it respects the fundamental principles of the EU and puts concern of the citizen before any other interest.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of activating the EU Solidarity Fund to the amount of EUR 79 726 942 in commitment and payment appropriations to repair the damage caused by the floods in Serbia and Croatia in May 2014 and the floods in Bulgaria in June 2014.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — (IT) We strongly support the allocation of resources in addition to provide relief to the Serbian, Croatian and Bulgarian populations affected by the numerous floods.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this draft amending budget, but I have two open political questions: on the one hand, the speed of the Serbian, Croatian and Bulgarian administrations in asking for these funds ( I would like to see so much efficiency in my country too) and, on the other hand, the rigidity of some European countries in putting their hands on their wallets. Both of these aspects give cause for much deeper political reflection, which I will take with me to the rest of my term of office.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - I have voted in favour of amending budget No 7 on the activation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to the amount of EUR 79 726 942: they will serve to provide a refreshment from the damage caused by the floods in Serbia and Croatia in May 2014 and the floods in Bulgaria in June 2014. During the negotiations, the solidarity fund budget line was increased by EUR 127 million, a strong signal of aid for the affected populations.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of this report due to the urgent need to release financial assistance in relation to floods in Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria through the EU Solidarity Fund.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — Draft amending budget No 7/2014 refers to the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to the amount of EUR 79,726,440 in commitment and payment appropriations in connection with the floods in Serbia and Croatia in May 2014 and Bulgaria in June 2014. In order to allow EUSF financial assistance for the countries affected by this natural disaster, I could only vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this draft amending budget because it involves mobilizing the funds needed to adapt the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund in the budgets for the 2014 financial year. The European Union must be able to act as quickly as possible to help victims of such natural disasters which have terrible consequences for the inhabitants of the affected regions. Mobilisation of funds to address the consequences on the local population is critical to a European Union project that tries to help people. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this initiative because I support the release of financial assistance through EUSF to countries affected by natural disasters.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. In May and June 2014, very severe floods hit Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria causing very significant damage to both private individuals, individuals and businesses, and the infrastructure necessary for a country to function properly. The vote on this amending budget No. 7 for the 2014 financial year embodies the European Union's support for these countries and their people. With a budget of around 79 million euros, the Solidarity Fund will play a welcome role in the reconstruction and renovation of the damaged areas.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. — The European Parliament today adopted by a large majority the EU budget for 2015 and the amendments on surplus resources for 2014. The huge advantage of the agreement is that it will be able to pass the EU budget for 2015 later this year, i.e. next year it would not only be possible to pay 12th of this year's budget per month. By 2014, an additional €4 billion will be mobilised, of which EUR 3.5 billion will be the result of so-called 'fresh money', i.e. not transfers.  The EP only agreed to the adoption of next year's EU budget on the condition that the European Commission draws up a plan to reduce unpaid bills to sustainable levels. In 2014, €23.4 billion will have to be paid from the previous year. To this end, today's vote provides an additional resource of nearly EUR 4 billion. Today's decision by the European Parliament also provided agricultural and cohesion resources for Hungary in this year's and next year's budgets. The Hungarian People's Party delegation, together with the European People's Party, acted responsibly on behalf of the national interests of Hungary and voted in favour of the 2015 EU budget and all the reports contained in the related agreement. The agreement also includes reports mobilising the Solidarity Fund to mitigate the damage caused by natural disasters affecting different regions of Europe.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the report because, although in this SAP 7 the funds provided for are minimal and do not meet the needs of the countries, any assistance is desirable.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - I was the rapporteur for the mobilisation of €79,726,440 from the EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to help flood-affected populations in Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria in May and June this year. The EUSF allows the Union to financially support a Member State, a candidate country or a region in the event of major natural disasters. This report was adopted by 665 votes to 30 and 8 abstentions. During May 2014, bad weather affected large areas of the Republic of Serbia and, to a lesser extent, Croatia, causing some of the worst floods in memory and massive destruction of public and private infrastructure, and has also caused damage to hundreds of thousands of families. A month later, intense and abundant rainfall, four times higher than monthly weather patterns, affected parts of the Republic of Bulgaria, causing severe flooding and disruption.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — Following the events of 2014, when during May bad weather has plagued most of the Republic of Serbia and to a lesser extent Croatia, leading to the largest floods felt in these countries of memory, causing massive destruction of public and private infrastructure, thousands of family homes, followed in August by heavy rains in Bulgaria, causing many floods that have led to serious disruption, the Commission has received and analysed three requests for mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund. This draft amending budget No 7/2014 relates precisely to the mobilisation of this Fund in the amount of EUR 79,726,440 in commitment and payment appropriations and intends to formally include this budgetary adjustment in the 2014 budget. Of course we voted in favour. However, we stress that a preventive approach to disasters should be developed, which will allow them to be avoided as far as possible or at least minimise their magnitude and impacts. The Solidarity Fund is a necessary instrument. But other upstream instruments are also needed.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing — The amending budget is important for the application of the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund under point 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement in order to effectively assist in the elimination of the consequences of natural disasters in Bulgaria, Serbia and Croatia. It is essential to support this budgetary adjustment in order to release resources to the Member States concerned. Amendment of Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1150/2000 implementing Decision 2007/436/EC, Euratom on the system of the European Communities' own resources

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — Each country must be examined differently and in accordance with the specific circumstances of the prevailing treaties. In this SAP 7, the funds provided for are minimal and do not meet the needs of the countries, but all aid is in the right direction. That is why I am voting in favour of draft amending budget No 10. 7/2014 on floods in Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - Our vote is in favour of all redistributive transfers that are intended to aid to regions or countries affected by natural disasters. We particularly believe in the redistributive nature of the European budget. However, we oppose the adoption of the 2015 budget and criticise the agreement on amending budgets negotiated in parallel.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. - This debate does not catch us by surprise: it is a direct consequence of the pressure on the humanitarian aid budget at the global level, with a record number of simultaneous humanitarian crises threatening to become chronicles. We're talking about Syria, South Sudan or the Central African Republic. In the specific case of Syria, the World Food Programme has patched up, but we do not know how many more lives it will cost not to secure humanitarian aid in the area. The response of the international community is being insufficient when it is estimated that around four million people in Syria face food insecurity.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - Our vote is in favour of all redistributive transfers that are intended to aid to regions or countries affected by natural disasters. We particularly believe in the redistributive nature of the European budget. However, we oppose the adoption of the 2015 budget and criticise the agreement on amending budgets negotiated in parallel.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for the proposal for a Resolution on the Council's position on draft amendments to budget No 1000/2013. 7/2014 relating to the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund for the repair of flood damages that hit Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria in 2014, as the projected €79 726 440.00 will significantly help these areas that have not yet recovered from the effects of the floods. A large part of the people have lost their homes, or they are significantly damaged and live in "container settlements". The economic development of these areas suffers and lags behind because of these predicates.  It is necessary to help people living there as quickly as possible in order to recover from significant losses and start a normal life again. The Assistance of the Solidarity Fund will contribute to the process of reconstruction and resolution, which, with joint assistance and synergies, should be completed as soon as possible.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. — While I understand that this is for aid, which could be used to help victims, the British public are already more than generous with donating funds to charitable causes when natural disasters occur. I do not believe foreign aid to be in the remit of the EU, so I voted against this proposal.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I supported the mobilisation of the fund, as it is crucial we show solidarity with people from the affected areas by helping to rebuild basic infrastructure, funding emergency services, providing temporary accommodation, contributing to clean-up operations and countering immediate health risks.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of draft amending budget No 7, which concerns the activation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to the amount of EUR 79 726 942. They are necessary to repair the damage caused by the floods in Serbia and Croatia in May 2014 and the floods in Bulgaria in June 2014. In the compromise reached in the trialogue of 8 December, the solidarity fund budget line was increased by EUR 127 million. This is an important sign of solidarity and aid, enabled by the activation of the Fund, a fundamental instrument for support in the event of natural disasters.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this draft amending budget because it involves mobilizing the funds needed to adapt the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund in the budgets for the 2014 financial year. The European Union must be able to act as quickly as possible to help victims of such natural disasters which have terrible consequences for the inhabitants of the affected regions. Mobilisation of funds to address the consequences on the local population is critical to a European Union project that tries to help people. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the Deprez report on draft amending budget No 1/2004. 7/2014: floods in Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria, because this report allocates funds to the EU budget for the financial support of Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the correction of budget 2014 No 7 on expenditure on the mobilisation of the EGF, the EU Solidarity Fund, to ensure full and timely EU aid to Serbia Croatia and Bulgaria, which have been hit this year by disastrous floods. Almost EUR 80 million in total aid has been allocated, with a change to the budget that will be considered outside the ceiling of the 2014 Multiannual Financial Framework, to ensure the timely arrival of funds to the affected areas. We need to deal with times of need linked to natural disasters with the greatest possible flexibility, including from a technical point of view, such as the EU budget.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — Draft amending budget No 7 allows a substantial additional sum to be allocated to the European Union Solidarity Fund. This budget change will make it possible to adequately support Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria, which were affected by major natural disasters between May and June 2014.  My vote in favour of this document stems from the conviction that the European Union must not miss an opportunity to show closeness and support to all its Member States.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — I fully support this motion too. The seriousness of this disaster cannot be borne by the individual Member States alone. Serbia in particular needs urgent support, since the amount of damage caused there amounts to more than EUR 1 billion.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — This draft amending budget No 7/2014 concerns the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF) amounting to EUR 79 726 440 in commitment and payment appropriations following floods in Serbia and Croatia and floods in Bulgaria. The purpose of draft amending budget No 7/2014 is to formally include this budgetary adjustment in the 2014 budget. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — This budget amendment specifically stresses the urgency to make financial assistance available for natural disaster relief through the EU Solidarity Fund. I therefore voted in favour of making the funds available and making the necessary alterations to the 2014 budget to allow for aid to be sent to the countries and communities in need of assistance.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I am in agreement with the draft amending budget No 7/2014 on floods in Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. I voted for this amending budget 7, which concerns the mobilization of the funds needed to help Member States and their populations, victims of serious natural disasters.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of draft amending budget No 7/2014 for the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in commitment and payment appropriations relating to the floods in Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria this year.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - As the formal criteria for the allocation of aid have been met and the aid should be provided quickly and unbureaucratically, I voted in favour of the motion.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. The EUSF was created following the floods that hit Central Europe in the summer of 2002. I voted in favour of the deployment of this fund in the specific case of floods in Serbia, Bulgaria and Croatia.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal because I consider that countries affected by natural disasters should be granted financial assistance through the European Union Solidarity Fund.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Draft amending budget No 7/2014 refers to the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) amounting to EUR 79 726 440 in commitment and payment appropriations in connection with the floods in Serbia and Croatia in May 2014 and Bulgaria in June 2014. Draft amending budget No 7/2014 is intended to formally enter the adjustment in the 2014 budget. For these reasons, I would vote in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. If we do not endorse the Union's cohesion policy and believe that it does not alleviate economic and social disparities between Member States, we believe that the principle of European solidarity can make sense when one of our European neighbours is seriously affected by a natural disaster. Moreover, the climatic events that have hit the south of France in recent months reinforce the idea that mutual financial assistance must enable us to better respond to the human, material and financial consequences of this type of tragic event. Common management of natural risks must be encouraged at European level in order to strengthen risk pooling. That is why I voted for the mobilization of the Solidarity Fund.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — In line with the positive vote I have given to the european Solidarity Fund for Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria, following natural disasters, I also vote to redeploy the necessary funds in the EU budget.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — In parallel with the proposal to mobilise the EU Solidarity Fund, eur 79 726 440 for Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria, the Commission submitted a draft amending budget (POR No 7/2014 of 17 October 2014) to include in the 2014 budget the corresponding commitment appropriations and to carry over the corresponding payment appropriations to the 2015 budget. Because I believe that financial assistance should be provided to these countries affected by natural disasters, I voted in favour.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — After arduous negotiations, an agreement has been reached that will allow the payment of outstanding invoices, for which the amount of EUR 4.8 billion has been agreed for the period 2014-2015.  In addition, the Commission, the Council and Parliament have agreed on a payment plan aimed at reducing the level of unpaid invoices within the current multiannual framework. An unprecedented level of default has accumulated throughout this year.  The agreed EUR 4.8 billion will enable part of the accumulated invoices to be met, thus helping to alleviate the situation of many SMEs, universities, local authorities and NGOs. For 2015, it has been agreed to allocate EUR 145 321.5 million to commitment appropriations and EUR 141 214,040 563 million to payment appropriations. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - Our vote is in favour of all redistributive transfers that are intended to aid to regions or countries affected by natural disasters. We particularly believe in the redistributive nature of the European budget. However, we oppose the adoption of the 2015 budget and criticise the agreement on amending budgets negotiated in parallel.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — In order to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund following requests from Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria to intervene on the floods suffered by these countries in 2014, it was important to vote on this draft amending budget. Remember! The damage caused by these floods has been numerous and terrible: massive destruction of public and private infrastructure, damage to hundreds of thousands of households, destruction of agricultural crops, etc. Both the economic sector and the citizens of these countries have been hard hit by these floods! That is why it was crucial to allocate part of the European budget through the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to help them.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — In order to implement as a matter of urgency the European Union Solidarity Fund of EUR 79 726 440, in favour of minimising the damage caused by the severe floods in Serbia and Croatia in May 2014 and for the floods in Bulgaria in June 2014, described in the European Parliament report A8-0075/2014, this budgetary adjustment was necessary which I obviously voted in favour of.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this text because it allows the mobilization of the Solidarity Fund to help people affected by major floods in Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria. 80 million euros in commitment and payment credits will be mobilised to deal with the damage.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour because it is a question of allocating aid to European populations affected by major natural disasters.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - Our vote is in favour of all redistributive transfers that are intended to aid to regions or countries affected by natural disasters. We particularly believe in the redistributive nature of the European budget. However, we oppose the adoption of the 2015 budget and criticise the agreement on amending budgets negotiated in parallel.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this draft amending budget because it involves mobilizing the funds needed to adapt the mobilization of the Solidarity Fund in the budgets for the 2014 financial year. The European Union must be able to act as quickly as possible to help victims of such natural disasters which have terrible consequences for the inhabitants of the affected regions. Mobilisation of funds to address the consequences on the local population is critical to a European Union project that tries to help people. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. — While I understand that this is for aid, which could be used to help victims, the British public are already more than generous with donating funds to charitable causes when natural disasters occur. I do not believe foreign aid to be in the remit of the EU, so I voted against this proposal.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — I voted with the majority to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) for Member States affected by natural disasters.  Draft amending budget No 7/2014 calls for the mobilisation of the EUSF for an amount of EUR 79 726 440 in commitment and payment appropriations in relation to the floods in Serbia and Croatia in May 2014 and the floods in Bulgaria in June 2014. Financial assistance should be released to these countries as a matter of urgency.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — I supported Deprez's report amending draft budget no. 7\2014 due to floods in Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria relating to the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund of EUR 79 726 440 in commitment appropriations and payment appropriations due to damage caused by natural disasters.  It should be noted that the European Union Solidarity Fund urgently needs to provide assistance to countries affected by this natural disaster.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — I support this amendment to the flood budget in Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria as I am aware of the extent of the damage caused by the May and June floods in those countries. The amount of 79 726 440 will certainly not be sufficient to compensate for all damages, but it will ease the financial situation for national governments still facing the consequences of damages today. I believe that these funds will accelerate the reconstruction of villages, residential and commercial buildings that, according to the population that are damaged, should flow faster and will be a positive input towards the recovery of the economies of these countries.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — Each country must be examined differently and in accordance with the specific circumstances of the prevailing treaties. In this SAP 7/2014 the funds provided are minimal and do not meet the needs of the countries, but all aid is in the right direction.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — The Commission proposes to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund for Serbia and Croatia, which was flooded in May 2014, and Bulgaria, which was flooded in June 2014, on the basis of point 11 of the inter-institutional agreement of 2 December 2013. During The month of May 2014, bad weather hit much of the Republic of Serbia and, to a lesser extent, Croatia, causing the most severe human-memory floods, causing massive destruction of public and private infrastructure and causing damage to hundreds of thousands of households. A month later, heavy and severe rains exceeding four times the monthly climate averages hit parts of the Republic of Bulgaria, causing severe flooding and disruption.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. — Natural disasters are unpredictable and the EU must give a fast response to the affected regions in order to recover as soon as possible. The flooding is of natural origin and therefore falls within the field of application of the Solidarity Fund. I agree with the Commission proposal to mobilise the European Solidarity Fund in favour of the floods in Serbia and Croatia in May 2014 and the floods in Bulgaria in June 2014.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. — My vote is in favour of mobilizing extra funds for the benefit of States affected by natural disasters.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — Following the events of 2014, when, during May, bad weather hit most of the Republic of Serbia and croatia to a lesser extent, leading to the largest floods felt in these countries of memory, causing massive destruction of public and private infrastructure and in thousands of family homes, followed in August by heavy rains in Bulgaria, causing many floods that led to serious disruption, the Commission received and analysed three requests for mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund.  This draft amending budget No 7/2014 relates precisely to the mobilisation of this Fund in the amount of EUR 79 726 440 in commitment and payment appropriations and intends to formally include this budgetary adjustment in the 2014 budget. We voted for it.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — Following the events of 2014 when, during May, bad weather plagued most of the Republic of Servia and to a lesser extent Croatia, leading to the largest floods felt in these countries of memory, causing massive destruction of thousands of homes and public and private infrastructure, followed in August by heavy rains in Bulgaria, causing many floods that led to serious disruption, the European Commission received and analysed three requests for mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund. This draft amending budget No 7/2014 relates precisely to the mobilisation of this Fund in the amount of EUR 79726440 in commitment and payment appropriations and intends to formally include this budgetary adjustment in the 2014 budget. We voted for it.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this draft amending budget because it proposes the use of resources accumulated in previous years to meet the possible resource needs in the other amending budgets. This amending budget proposes the relocation of resources in a way that allows efficient use, while pointing to the important fact of the reduction of own resources income and the increase in revenue through fines and interest from them. This report will help to make necessary payments and that is why I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — This is a technical matter; I therefore abstained.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of all draft amending budgets for 2014 and for the agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council on the 2015 budget. I congratulate the Negotiators of the European Parliament on the eur 4.25 billion allocated to the emergency debts of this year's EU budget. The European Commission would be obliged to draw up a step-by-step plan for the reduction of outstanding bills and to establish a sustainable debt ceiling in the future. Thanks to Parliament, eur 0.5 billion will be allocated to commitments. than the COUNCIL of the EU proposed. More funding will be allocated to horizon 2020 and the Erasmus+ programme for student and youth exchange. It is to be welcomed that the increase in funding for European neighbourhood programmes, humanitarian aid and the common foreign security policy has been increased, which is very relevant in the light of today's situation in Europe. However, I do not support the reduction in funding for the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund, which will affect many EU farmers, who are in a particularly difficult situation because of the protracted Russian embargo and who need EU assistance.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. — This draft amending budget (PBR) 8/2014 aims to include in the 2014 budget the surplus for the 2013 financial year, amounting to just over EUR 1 billion, the majority of which comes from fines and late interest. This PBR 8 will partially compensate member states for the funding of PBR 3/201, 5/2014 and 7/2014.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This draft amending budget No. 8/2014 is to allow the return of the surplus resulting from the 2013 financial year to cover the remaining expenses of the 2014 budget. This report is a good example of the EU's logic, spending taxpayers' money, remonstrating with Member States on the one hand but failing to deliver on the financial commitments it has made on the other. The EU thus finds itself in the situation of the bad payer, unable to meet its commitments and trying by all means to fill its risky budgetary management. So I voted against this report.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this measure, which accounts for a surplus of EUR 1 005 406 925.37 for the financial year 2013 (excluding EFTA and EEA contributions) entered as revenue in the 2014 budget. The accounting of the surplus will result in a corresponding decrease in the overall contribution of Member States to the financing of the EU budget.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report which is part of the overall agreement to approve the 2014 amending budget and the 2015 budget. In particular, draft amending budget No 8/2014 aims to record for the 2014 financial year the surplus for the 2013 financial year, amounting to EUR 1 005 million. The agreement reached will allow the payment of outstanding invoices, for which the amount of EUR 4.7 billion has been agreed for the period 2014-2015. In addition, the Commission, the Council and Parliament have agreed on a payment plan aimed at reducing the level of unpaid invoices within the current multiannual framework. An unprecedented level of default has accumulated throughout this year.  The agreed 4.7 billion will enable some of the accumulated invoices to be met, helping to alleviate the situation of many SMEs, universities, local authorities and NGOs. For 2015, it has been agreed to allocate EUR 145 321 500 000 to commitment appropriations and EUR 141 214 040 563 to payment appropriations. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted for this because we need to have concrete help for the zones in the European Union which have suffered natural catastrophes.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — I voted against this draft amending budget 8/2014, which aims to re-enter the 2013 surplus to cover the expenditure of the 2014 budget. The European Union is struggling and proves again that it is reduced to making the funds of drawers to try to find a solution to the serious problems of unpaid debts. For years now, the EU has made commitments without worrying for a moment about how it should pay. It is now facing a very serious financial and fiscal crisis.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of accounting for the financial year 2013. Already presented as PBR No 2, following the failure of the first conciliation on the 2015 budget it is now resubmitted identically as PBR No 8. The implementation of the 2013 financial year reveals a surplus of EUR 1 005 406 925.37 (excluding EFTA and EEA contributions), which is then entered as revenue in the 2014 budget. The accounting of the surplus will result in a corresponding decrease in the overall contribution of Member States to the financing of the EU budget.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — I have today voted in favour of draft amending budget No 8/2014 concerning the surplus resulting from the implementation of the 2013 budget. At the end of 2013, there was a surplus of around EUR 1 005 million, due to higher revenues of EUR 771 million, lower expenditure of EUR 276 million and a negative exchange rate difference of EUR 42 million. A refund has therefore been determined to the Member States, which is made by offsetting the contributions paid monthly by member states to the EU.
