For Italy, the amount of the refund will be around EUR 110 million.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — The adoption of this draft budget will reduce the share of the Member States' contribution to the Union budget by about one billion euros and, consequently, will partly compensate for their contribution to the financing of other amending projects.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) This draft amending budget is only an application of the rules and there is very little political. It is certainly good to see that the EU saves money and returns the money to its main taxpayers (who are the Member States).

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I supported, with my vote in favour, amending budget No 8, concerning the surplus of the 2013 budget, of approximately EUR 1 005 million, due to increased revenues of EUR 771 million, lower expenditure of EUR 276 million and a negative component on exchange rates (-EUR 46 million). During the negotiations, Parliament supported the formation of a 'package' with the otherBRps, in order to offset the higher revenues due to the surplus of the 2013 budget, with the payment needs contained in the other amending budgets.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of this report to enable entry of the surplus from the 2013 financial year in the 2014 budget.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — Draft amending budget No 8/2014 is intended solely to enter in the budget the surplus resulting from the implementation of the 2013 financial year, amounting to approximately ONE billion euros, mainly the result of unforeseen revenue from fines and penalties. This is a technical amending and necessary to replace the previous one. For these reasons, I am voting in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this draft amending budget because it proposes the use of resources accumulated in previous years to meet the possible resource needs in the other amending budgets. This amending budget proposes the relocation of resources in a way that allows efficient use, while pointing to the important fact of the reduction of own resources income and the increase in revenue through fines and interest from them. This report will help to make necessary payments and that is why I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report since it dealt with the issue of surplus from the implementation of the budget year 2013. The adoption of this DAB No 8/2014 will reduce the share of the GNI contribution from Member States to the Union budget by EUR 1 005 million and will therefore partly compensate for their contribution to the financing of DABs No 3, 5 and 7/2014.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. During the 2013 financial year, the European Union budget generated a surplus of EUR 1.005 million. By voting in favour of this amending budget No. 8, the European Parliament has allowed this budget surplus to be re-injected into the 2014 budget, which I am satisfied with.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. — The European Parliament today adopted by a large majority the EU budget for 2015 and the amendments on surplus resources for 2014. The huge advantage of the agreement is that it will be able to pass the EU budget for 2015 later this year, i.e. next year it would not only be possible to pay 12th of this year's budget per month. By 2014, an additional €4 billion will be mobilised, of which EUR 3.5 billion will be the result of so-called 'fresh money', i.e. not transfers.  The EP only agreed to the adoption of next year's EU budget on the condition that the European Commission draws up a plan to reduce unpaid bills to sustainable levels. In 2014, €23.4 billion will have to be paid from the previous year.  To this end, today's vote provides an additional resource of nearly EUR 4 billion. Today's decision by the European Parliament also provided agricultural and cohesion resources for Hungary in this year's and next year's budgets. The Hungarian People's Party delegation, together with the European People's Party, acted responsibly on behalf of the national interests of Hungary and voted in favour of the 2015 EU budget and all the reports contained in the related agreement. The agreement also includes reports mobilising the Solidarity Fund to mitigate the damage caused by natural disasters affecting different regions of Europe.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted against the report because the transfer of the 2013 surplus to the 2014 PC is not carried out in targeted areas where there are real needs but as a reserve for additional payments.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The conciliation committee did not agree on draft amending budget No 2/2014 and therefore this draft amending budget aims to include in the 2014 budget the surplus for the financial year 2013, amounting to EUR 1 005 million. The main components of this surplus consist of a positive result of EUR 771 million in revenue, under-implementation of expenditure of EUR 276 million and a negative exchange rate variation of EUR 42 million. On the revenue side, the increase is mainly due to late payment interest and fines, while the amount of own resources actually collected is decreasing and revenues from surpluses, balances and adjustments also decrease. On the expenditure side, the under-implementation of the 2013 and 2012 appropriations did not result from a decrease in absorption capacity, but pointed out all the indicators available for the fact that there is a shortfall in payment appropriations in both the 2012 and 2013 budgets.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — Draft amending budget No 8/2014 aims to include in the 2014 budget the surplus for the financial year 2013, amounting to EUR 1005 million. The main components of this surplus consist of a positive result of EUR 771 million in revenue, under-implementation of expenditure of EUR 276 million and a negative exchange rate variation of EUR 42 million. On the revenue side, the increase is mainly due to interest on late payment and fines (EUR 1331 million), while the amount of own resources actually collected is decreasing compared to those already budgeted (EUR 226 million), and revenues from surpluses, balances and adjustments also decrease (-360 million euros). Regrettably, the adoption of this draft amending budget will reduce the share of the GNI-based contribution of the Member States to the EU budget by EUR 1005 million and therefore partially offset its contribution to the financing of POR 3, 5 and 7/2014. It is above all the great countries that win with this.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — The transfer of the 2013 surplus to the 2014 PC is not carried out in targeted areas where there are real needs, but as a reserve for additional payments, which means that they will be given to the benefit of those in power. That is why I am voting against draft amending budget No 10. 8/2014 for the surplus resulting from implementation in the financial year 2013.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - We can abstain from amending budget No 8 on the ground that it gives a very insufficient solution to the problem of suspended payments and that it is part of an austericidal and insolidary agreement that includes the 2015 budget.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We can abstain from amending budget No 8 on the ground that it gives a very insufficient solution to the problem of suspended payments and that it is part of an austericidal and insolidary agreement that includes the 2015 budget.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a motion for a resolution on the Council's position on the draft amendment to budget No 1009/2013. 8/2014 as it brings €1.005 million into the 2014 budget as a surplus from the 2013 budget. This way, the share of Member States' contributions under the GNI of the European Union budget will be reduced, the thus reducing their contribution to other budget changes. It is important that the amendments adopted are in line with the principles of fair financial management and consistent union priorities.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I supported the draft amending budget, as the budgeting of this surplus will diminish accordingly the global contribution of Member States to the financing of the EU budget.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - Draft amending budget No 8 concerns the surplus of the 2013 budget of around EUR 1 005 million, due to increased revenue of EUR 771 million, lower expenditure of EUR 276 million and a negative component on exchange rates (-EUR 46 million). During the negotiations, Parliament strategically decided to form a 'package' with the otherBR, in order to offset the higher revenues due to the surplus of the 2013 budget with the payment needs contained in the other amending budgets.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this draft amending budget because it proposes the use of resources accumulated in previous years to meet the possible resource needs in the other amending budgets. This amending budget proposes the relocation of resources in a way that allows efficient use, while pointing to the important fact of the reduction of own resources income and the increase in revenue through fines and interest from them. This report will help to make necessary payments and that is why I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — I supported the report amending draft budget number 8, which included a budget surplus of around €1 billion from the 2013 financial year.  Implementing the amendment to draft budget number 8 will reduce Member States' contributions to the European Union budget on the basis of gross national income by €1 billion, while replacing member states' contributions generated by the implementation of draft budgets number 3, 5 and 7, which mobilise funds to pay old bills and European Solidarity Fund funds earmarked for Member States affected by natural disasters.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the Deprez report on draft amending budget No 1/2004. 8/2014 - Surplus resulting from implementation in the financial year 2013 because the issues under consideration are adequately addressed.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. - The surplus resulting from the implementation of the 2013 budget was calculated in draft amending budget No 8/2014 for approximately one billion euros. This surplus was calculated by the Commission, taking into account the balance for the end of the 2013 financial year. This figure will be allocated on proportional and competent criteria between the Member States and will be deducted directly from the contributions that each country pays to the European Union. I voted in favour of the text at the end of the approval of the amending procedures for the 2014 budget.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — Since some of the factors in the amending budget may well seem positive, such as amending budgets Nos 4, 6 and 8, it might be considered that the drafts should be approved as a whole. However, the fact that the overall budget is still far too high to be able to finance it sensibly and, above all, sustainably over the next few years, weighs more heavily and I reject it.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — This amending budget is a new symptom of European budget mismanagement. Parliament is here invited to vote on exactly the same amendment it has already voted on under the name of amending budget No. 2 in October. At the time, as the Council had never been able to reach an agreement with the Commission, this amendment was never implemented. The Commission is once again submitting it to the vote of a Parliament which is more than ever making budgetary representation. In essence, the amendment consists of deferring to the 2014 budget one billion euros of surpluses recorded in the 2013 budget, even though there are more than 20 billion unpaid. The management of the European budget is thus organised to make it impossible to achieve an increasing share of planned expenditure, in particular because of the complexity of the rules for the management of European funds. Worse, this amending budget still plans to exceptionally reduce the contribution of states to the European budget in line with the surplus recorded. In the face of such short-sighted mismanagement, I vote against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — This draft amending budget No 8/2014 was submitted by the Commission because the conciliation committee did not reach agreement on draft amending budget No 2/2014, which had exactly the same objective and content as POR No 8/2014.  This draft amending budget No 8/2014 aims to include in the 2014 budget the surplus for the financial year 2013, amounting to EUR 1 005 million. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the adoption of this draft amending budget No 8/2014 that will reduce the share of the GNI contribution from Member States to the Union budget and will therefore partly reduce the amount needed for the financing of DABs No 3/2014, 5/2014 and 7/2014.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of the draft amending budget No 8/2014 on surplus resulting from the implementation of the budget year 2013.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. I voted against this draft amending budget No. 8/2014, which aims to re-enter the 2013 surplus to cover the expenditure of the 2014 budget. The European Union is struggling and proves again that it is reduced to making the funds of drawers to try to find a solution to the serious problems of unpaid debts. For years now, the EU has made commitments without worrying for a moment about how it should pay. It is now facing a very serious financial and fiscal crisis.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - The application was intended to allow the transfer of budget surpluses from 2013 to the financial year 2014. I think this is laudable in principle, but here too I criticise the lack of transparency towards the citizen. That is why I abstained.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because I support the mobilization of additional resources from surpluses in the past years, so that this EU money remains available for 2015, and thus make the best use of the instruments of the European budget.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Draft amending budget No 8/2014 aims to include in the 2014 budget the surplus resulting from the implementation of the 2013 financial year, which amounts to EUR 1 005 million. Article 18 of the Financial Regulation provides that the difference between the provisional accounts and the estimates to be entered in the Union budget is the only item in the amending budget in question. For these reasons, I would vote in favour.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — Amending budget number 8 is an integral part of the package of amendments that ensure the balancing of budget revenues and expenditures for 2014. The current draft amendment to the budget is being amended by NIP 2/2014 as of April this year, which has not been accepted until now due to the rejection of NIP 3/2014. Therefore, the Commission reintroduced the Draft, which is an important component of the amendments to the 2014 budget. When we look at the full package of budget changes, this is precisely the increase in revenues of approximately €1 billion generated by the 2013 budget surplus, an indispensable part of the equation in which the final budget in 2014 is such that it can ensure financial stability. I believe that the whole package of budget changes we have ahead of us is an acceptable compromise that will allow for the implementation of the plan that ensures the necessary growth for EU members while remaining within the Multiannual Financial Framework.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — Through this text, it is up to the European Parliament to approve the revision of certain budget lines for 2014, including the inclusion of the surplus budget lines for 2013. I am in favour of such a measure.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. - Whereas draft amending budget (POR) No 8/2014 aims to include in the 2014 budget the surplus for the financial year 2013, eur 1 005 million, of which EUR 771 million comes from revenues (the increase is mainly due to late payment interest and fines), EUR 276 million from under-implementation of expenditure (mainly the result of a shortfall in payment appropriations in the 2012 and 2013 budgets) and EUR 42 million from a exchange variation. It should be noted that this POR was presented only because POR No 2/2014, whose objective was the same, did not have an agreement in the conciliation committee because of differences in positions between Parliament and the Council and not because of the content. The adoption of POR No 8/2014 will reduce the share of the GNI-based contribution of the Member States to the Union budget by EUR 1005 million, thus partially offsetting its contribution to the financing of POR 3, 5 and 7/2014. I voted in favour.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — After arduous negotiations, an agreement has been reached that will allow the payment of outstanding invoices, for which the amount of EUR 4.8 billion has been agreed for the period 2014-2015.  In addition, the Commission, the Council and Parliament have agreed on a payment plan aimed at reducing the level of unpaid invoices within the current multiannual framework. An unprecedented level of default has accumulated throughout this year.  The agreed EUR 4.8 billion will enable part of the accumulated invoices to be met, thus helping to alleviate the situation of many SMEs, universities, local authorities and NGOs. For 2015, it has been agreed to allocate EUR 145 321 500 000 to commitment appropriations and EUR 141 214 040 563 to payment appropriations. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - We can abstain from amending budget No 8 on the ground that it gives a very insufficient solution to the problem of suspended payments and that it is part of an austericidal and insolidary agreement that includes the 2015 budget.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. — (IT) I have chosen to vote in favour because the accounting of the surplus will result in a corresponding decrease in the overall contribution of the Member States to the financing of the EU budget.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - We can abstain from amending budget No 8 on the ground that it gives a very insufficient solution to the problem of suspended payments and that it is part of an austericidal and insolidary agreement that includes the 2015 budget.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this draft amending budget because it proposes the use of resources accumulated in previous years to meet the possible resource needs in the other amending budgets. This amending budget proposes the relocation of resources in a way that allows efficient use, while pointing to the important fact of the reduction of own resources income and the increase in revenue through fines and interest from them. This report will help to make necessary payments and that is why I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — Today I voted with the majority on draft amending budget No 8/2014.  This draft amending budget is devoted solely to the budgeting of the 2013 surplus, for an amount of EUR 1 005 million, in accordance with Article 18 of the Financial Regulation. DAB No 8/2014. It was presented by the Commission because the Conciliation Committee could not reach an agreement on DAB No 2/2014, which had the exact same purpose and contents.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — I supported colleague Deprez's report amending draft budget number 8\2014 aimed at bringing in €1 005 million as a surplus from the 2013 financial year. the 2014 budget and the adoption of draft budget changes 8\2014 by EUR 1 005 million will reduce the proportion of Member States' contributions under GNI to the budget, partially replacing their contribution to the financing of draft amendments to budget No 1005 million. 3.5 and 7\2014.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — I support this amendment to budget No. 8/2014 targeting a surplus resulting from the 2013 budget. In the 2013 financial year, a budget surplus of over €1 billion was achieved, which, under the new amendment, is to be transferred to the 2014 budget, while the main parts of this surplus stem from fines and default interest and this amount can be transferred in 2014 and directed to the needs of the budget.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — The transfer of the 2013 surplus to the 2014 PC is not carried out in targeted areas where there are real needs, but as a reserve for additional payments, which means that they will be given as they see fit and for the benefit of those in power.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the text on the Council's position on the European Union's draft amending budget No. 8/2014 for the 2014 financial year, Section III - Commission. The aim is to include in the 2013 budget the surplus of EUR 1,005 million, in accordance with Article 18 of the Financial Regulation, as it has been presented by the Commission, and the Council's position on it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — Draft amending budget No 8/2014 aims to include in the 2014 budget the surplus for the financial year 2013, amounting to EUR 1 005 million. The main components of this surplus consist of a positive result of EUR 771 million in revenue, under-implementation of expenditure of EUR 276 million and a negative exchange rate variation of EUR 42 million. On the revenue side, the increase is mainly due to late payment interest and fines (EUR 1 331 million), while the amount of own resources actually collected is decreasing compared to those already budgeted (EUR 226 million), and revenues from surpluses, balances and adjustments also decrease (-360 million euros). Regrettably, the adoption of POR No 8/2014 will reduce the share of the GNI-based contribution of the Member States to the Union budget by EUR 1005 million and therefore partially offset its contribution to the financing of POR 3, 5 and 7/2014.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — Since this proposal would, among other things, also mean a higher burden on Austria, I rejected it in principle. Partial payment options are a welcome idea, but the proposal itself makes it impossible for me to agree. In addition, this proposal forms the basis for amending budgets 3, 4, 6 and 8. In this respect, the amending budgets mentioned above were also to be rejected.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — Draft amending budget No 8/2014 aims to include in the 2014 budget the surplus for the financial year 2013, amounting to EUR 1 005 million. The increase is mainly due to late payment interest and fines (EUR 1 331 million), while the amount of own resources actually collected is decreasing compared to those already budgeted (EUR 226 million), and revenues from surpluses, balances and adjustments also decrease (-EUR 360 million); Regrettably, the adoption of POR No 8/2014 will reduce the share of the GNI-based contribution of the Member States to the Union budget by EUR 1005 million and therefore partially offset its contribution to the financing of POR 3, 5 and 7/2014.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — In the light of the latest statistical reviews approved by the Member States, it appears that some States did not pay all their contributions to the Union budget for several years, while others overpaid, and that these deviations have been determined by the significant statistical changes reported by the Member States. Certain Member States which in the past benefited from the underestimation of their GNI have expressed their reluctance to pay the supplementary amounts they owe before the legal deadline expires. In view of this situation, the Council requested the Commission to submit a proposal taking account of this situation, changing the relevant rules and allowing the deferment and disbursement in tranches of the amounts due. The new proposal introduces greater discretion for Member States with regard to the timetable for their supplementary contributions, derived from GNI adjustments, to the Union budget. It is easy to foresee that this will create new difficulties for future EU budgets, so I have not been able to vote in favour and abstained.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — Whilst on the one hand this proposal gives the UK some interest-free credit as has already been agreed with the Commission, the nature of the text is somewhat confrontational.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of all draft amending budgets for 2014 and for the agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council on the 2015 budget. I congratulate the Negotiators of the European Parliament on the eur 4.25 billion allocated to the emergency debts of this year's EU budget. The European Commission would be obliged to draw up a step-by-step plan for the reduction of outstanding bills and to establish a sustainable debt ceiling in the future. Thanks to Parliament, eur 0.5 billion will be allocated to commitments. than the COUNCIL of the EU proposed. More funding will be allocated to horizon 2020 and the Erasmus+ programme for student and youth exchange. It is to be welcomed that the increase in funding for European neighbourhood programmes, humanitarian aid and the common foreign security policy has been increased, which is very relevant in the light of today's situation in Europe. However, I do not support the reduction in funding for the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund, which will affect many EU farmers, who are in a particularly difficult situation because of the protracted Russian embargo and who need EU assistance.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report on the EU's own resources tells us that for several years a series of Member States have made an insufficient contribution to the EU budget compared to what they should have paid while other Member States have made too large a contribution. Some States (7 in total) whose contribution has been underestimated have expressed their refusal to pay the supplements they owe within the time frames provided by the Brussels injunctions. France, on the other hand, contributes EUR 21 billion a year to the European Budget, while it recovers only 13 billion euros, even though many of my compatriots are suffering the full brunt of the economic and social crisis. The United Kingdom, in the wake of the thatcher rebate, has once again succeeded in preserving these interests. It's time to say "I want my money back." So I voted against this report.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted against the amendment of the own resources regulation linked to the highly contested recalculations of contributions from the Member States referred to in draft amending budget No 6 of 2014.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — After arduous negotiations, an agreement has been reached to allow the payment of outstanding invoices, for which the amount of EUR 4.7 billion has been agreed for the period 2014-2015. In addition, the Commission, the Council and Parliament have agreed on a payment plan aimed at reducing the level of unpaid invoices within the current multiannual framework. An unprecedented level of default has accumulated throughout this year. The agreed EUR 4.7 billion will enable part of the accumulated invoices to be met, thus helping to alleviate the situation of many SMEs, universities, local authorities and NGOs. It is true that the figure is not sufficient, but the alternative, the non-agreement, would have dire consequences: not having a fully operational budget for 2015, losing the possibility of paying the arrears and putting at risk the investment programme that the Commission has just presented. For 2015, it has been agreed to allocate EUR 145 321 500 000 to commitment appropriations and EUR 141 214 040 563 to payment appropriations. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I supported these amendments because I think that the European Parliament must be more involved in the dialogue with the Member States concerning their contributions.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the Union's own resources system and the adjustment of Member States' national contributions. The proposal aims to amend Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1150/2000 in order to enable Member States to make available the amount resulting from these adjustments (VAT and VAT balances) at any time between the first working day in December and the first working day of September of the following year, when the individual threshold or excess of the general threshold is exceeded. I support this measure for the fact that Member States will be able to benefit from the flexibility of payments, which would reduce the financial burden, especially during the end-of-year period.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — Amendment of the Own Resources Regulation linked to the highly contested recalculated contributions from the Member States referred to in PBR No 6 (voted on earlier). I voted against.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — I have today voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council regulation amending Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1150/2000 implementing Decision 2007/436/EC, Euratom, on the system of the Community's own resources. In view of the fact that, in the light of the recent statistical reviews carried out by the Member States, it has been found that some Member States have paid lower contributions than those due to the Union budget, while others would have paid more contributions, I voted in favour of this report, which goes in the direction of adjusting Member States' contributions, recognising that the amounts of the 2014 VAT and GNI-based own resources adjustments are high and can represent a considerable financial burden for some Member States.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — This amendment to Regulation No 1150/2000 gives Member States the flexibility they need as to how they should make available the amounts resulting from the adjustments to their national contributions.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) My vote in favour of this report is almost self-evident: it is a question of ratifying the application of normal procedures and of doing so with the flexibility allowed by the rules.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — This proposal aims to budget the surplus resulting from the implementation of the budget year 2013 by applying the correctional mechanism resulting in a change in the distribution between Member States of their own-resources contributions to the EU budget. I voted in favour, as although the contributions of Malta increased, it can provide sufficient resources to cover important programmes administered from this part of the budget such as the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership and the Emergency Aid Reserve, to help address possible humanitarian crises.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — Thanks to amending budget No 6/2014, it has been possible to modify the system for calculating compensation for contributions due by Member States on the basis of VAT and GNI resources. With the new allocations, the previous system, in force from 1995 to 2013, would have led some countries to be repaid contributions already paid while others would have to pay others. I am voting in favour of this new system which solves the problem of Member States' contributions.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — In the light of the latest statistical reviews approved by the Member States, it appears that some States did not pay all their contributions to the Union budget for several years, while others overpaid, and that these deviations have been determined by the significant statistical changes reported by the Member States. Certain Member States which in the past benefited from the underestimation of their GNI have expressed their reluctance to pay the supplementary amounts they owe before the legal deadline expires. In view of this situation, the Council requested the Commission to submit a proposal taking account of this situation, changing the relevant rules and allowing the deferment and disbursement in tranches of the amounts due. The new proposal introduces greater discretion for Member States with regard to the timetable for their supplementary contributions, derived from GNI adjustments, to the Union budget. It is easy to foresee that this will create new difficulties for future EU budgets, so I have not been able to vote in favour and abstained.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — This dossier is connected to Draft Amending Budget No 6 of 2014 on which I voted in favour, since it speaks about the revision of the forecast of traditional own resources as well as an increase in the budgetary appropriations for the European Ombudsman.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The European Union budget plays a key role in expressing solidarity between states and in the economic development of our continent. Covering a long period - ranging from 5 to 7 years - the Community budget can also see sometimes brutal adjustments for states that need to make it more abundant. Therefore, this text, which provides for the possibility for Member States to defer the availability of the amounts resulting from these adjustments, is welcome. However, it risks further complicating the system of own resources and underlines the need to reform the current framework.

name: Diane DODDS
text: in writing. — I welcome the fact that changes are to be made to ensure that the ludicrous situation where Member States are handed EU bills simply out of the blue cannot happen unchecked again. The reality is that the United Kingdom pays far more into Europe than it gets out – both in financial and social terms. The reality is that no calculation of GNI, and no calculation of VAT, over any length of time, should mean that the UK taxpayer should give more money to Europe simply because the economy they are a part of is growing. This, however, is not something the bearers of this report realise – they want more, more, more. Such a wanton disregard for the pressures facing household budgets strikes to the very heart of the increasing argument that fairness must be re-enacted within our relationship with the EU.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted against the report because this proposal makes the own resources system even more complex and aims to amend the legislation, which will soon be replaced, retroactively, by acts already agreed.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - Several Member States paid less than that stipulated for their contributions to the Union budget over several years, while others paid a higher amount and these deviations were motivated by the major statistical changes reported by the Member States. It is also true that Member States have paid in the past, without significant delays, the total amount of their contributions to the Union budget and certain Member States have benefited from the previous underestimation of their GNI have shown reluctance to pay the additional amounts due within the legal deadline. Having said this and for the sake of transparency, I believe that a report on the calculations and underlying data on the adjustments to the VAT and GNI balance sheet should be submitted annually to Parliament in the context of the budgetary procedure, providing sufficient time for its assessment, and that Parliament should be notified to the Decision of the Member States on the dates and amounts of the benefits.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — In recent years, several Member States have paid less than that stipulated for their contributions to the Union budget, while others have paid a higher amount. These deviations were motivated by significant statistical changes reported by member states. As a general rule, Member States have paid in the past, without significant delay, the total amount of their contributions to the EU budget, based on their GNI and VAT, even in times of crisis and severe budgetary pressure. While we recognise that the amounts of vat and GNI-based own resources adjustments for 2014 are exceptionally high, we cannot but question the reasons for this discrepancy, given the sophisticated mechanisms at the service of national accounts, particularly at the level of the countries where this issue arises. In this sense, we have doubts about this change motivated by a statistical discrepancy which should have, yes, a proper treatment to prevent such situations from happening again. The most important thing is that the Member States concerned pay what they owe, but we cannot fail to point out the particularly favourable conditions that are being afforded, especially to a country such as the United Kingdom, which has long benefited from unjustifiable and unfair prerogatives, such as the famous British cheque.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: writing — On the one hand, there is criticism that, within the framework of the multiannual financial framework 2014-2020, the European Union is unable to meet its obligations. On the other hand, it is essential that the rules are also set correctly in relation to member states' contributions to the European Union budget. Although the Conciliation Committee has not reached an agreement, and although the high amounts of adjustments to own resources based on VAT and GNI in 2014 may represent a high financial burden for individual Member States, it is important that we are able to set this system effectively and operational in the future.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — This proposal makes the own resources system even more complex and aims to amend the legislation, which will soon be replaced, retroactively, by acts already agreed. That is why I am voting against the Union's own resources system - adjustments to the national contributions of the Member States.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - We can abstain because this report criticises the Council very warmly. For Podemos, the precedent set by the Council during the negotiation of the 2015 budget should have been the subject of exemplary condemnation by the European Parliament.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We can abstain because this report criticises the Council very warmly. For Podemos, the precedent set by the Council during the negotiation of the 2015 budget should have been the subject of exemplary condemnation by the European Parliament.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council Regulation amending Regulation No 1999/2013. 1150/2000, as I consider it necessary to better harmonise member states' national contributions and because that Regulation has caused one-off consequences for some Member States.  It is necessary to establish a system of national contributions that is clear, transparent and balanced in order to avoid situations of overpaid or underpaid payments. A well-balanced and thoughtful budget constitutes a fair implementation of the union's political priorities. It is important that Member States' contribution is better aligned in order to contribute to qualitative budget implementation and to addressing the shortcomings of the current system.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. — (IT) In today's report Parliament has given its opinion to the Council on the calculation of the adjustment of the Member States' national contributions to the European Union budget. This is an annual calculation carried out by the Commission, which is based on a technical exercise, on the basis of data provided by the Member States themselves. However, we wanted to emphasise, through two amendments, that Parliament needs to improve the flow of information on changes in the revenue of the EU budget.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — In the light of the latest statistical reviews approved by the Member States, it appears that some States did not pay all their contributions to the Union budget for several years, while others overpaid, and that these deviations have been determined by the significant statistical changes reported by the Member States. Certain Member States which in the past benefited from the underestimation of their GNI have expressed their reluctance to pay the supplementary amounts they owe before the legal deadline expires. In view of this situation, the Council requested the Commission to submit a proposal taking account of this situation, changing the relevant rules and allowing the deferment and disbursement in tranches of the amounts due. The new proposal introduces greater discretion for Member States with regard to the timetable for their supplementary contributions, derived from GNI adjustments, to the Union budget. It is easy to foresee that this will create new difficulties for future EU budgets, so I have not been able to vote in favour and abstained.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. — In the light of the latest statistical reviews approved by the Member States, it appears that some States did not pay all their contributions to the Union budget for several years, while others overpaid. These deviations have been determined by the significant statistical changes reported by Member States. The Commission therefore initiated a broader negotiation process with different States, which aims to ensure that equal treatment between Member States concerned is maintained in terms of contribution to the European budget.  I support the Commission's proposal as amended as it makes the European Parliament aware of the process at all times, a factor which I consider fundamental to the transparency and proper functioning of the institutions. For these reasons I vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — I supported the Report on harmonisation of Member States' national contributions.  Member States' contributions to the EU budget under GNI and VAT account for the bulk of the EU's budget revenues. Every year in October, member states' latest GNI statistics correct payments to the EU budget. This year's audit found that for years some Member States have paid less and some more into the EU budget.  Croatia paid more because the account was based on a larger GNI. As the economy is in continuous decline, it will receive a return of 32.5m euros. France (€1 billion) and Germany (€779.2 million) will receive the largest returns, with additional amounts to be paid by the United Kingdom (€2.1 billion), the Netherlands (€642.7 billion) and Italy (€340.1 million). This correction will return €3.69 billion to Member States that paid more into the EU budget, and member states that paid less will have to pay an additional €3.2 billion. Overall, member states' GNI contributions in the EU budget will be reduced by a total of €420 million.  Member States that have to pay additional funds had until the first working day in December, they were given an instrument of flexibility to postpone payments until September next year.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — I rejected this proposal on the basis of the fundamental consideration that the new calculation of the contribution levels will place a higher burden on Austria. While the partial payment option is a welcome idea in itself, the proposal as a whole must be rejected.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — This text illustrates the growing confusion of European budgetary procedures. Each year, Member States review in principle in December their contribution to the EU based on adjustments to their tax and economic statistics. But for several years now, the Commission's strengthened controls on states have made it impossible to make these adjustments on time, as the Court of Auditors has denounced. As a result, some states have accumulated significant delays in their revised contributions under previous years. As these delays are linked to the Commission's controls, they refuse to pay them in bulk. The Commission has therefore proposed an interim mechanism for deferring these revised payments. While denouncing its complexity, Parliament's report validates this mechanism without in any way resolving the bureaucratic paralysis created by the European Commission. I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — It has been found that several Member States have paid less than that stipulated for their contributions to the Union budget. The existing rules should result in the rapid correction of underpayments and overpayments.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. I voted against this report considering that my country, France, is paying 21 billion euros to the European Union budget and that it receives in return only 13 billion (mainly under the CAP), or 8 billion that go to support other Member States mainly from Eastern Europe. The United Kingdom will once again be able to preserve its interests, which will of course not be the case for President Hollande and his government, who will again be unable to act for France and the French. Defending national sovereignty, and in the economic and social context as we know it, I believe that this EUR 21 billion should therefore remain at the disposal of our national budget and thus contribute to the improvement of the daily lives of our compatriots.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I supported this report.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - The application is intended to allow the repayment or repayment of EU contributions required by the contract to be deferred. This was incomprehensible to me for several reasons. On the one hand, Member States can easily make up for the comparatively small contributions. On the other hand, I do not understand the criticism of the practice to date, since the existing regulations themselves have been adopted by the Member States in this way. Furthermore, this change in previous practice is not a good one for me, since the Member States can always push for a reduction in the EU budget and thus for a reduction in their respective contributions. I have therefore voted against the motion.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it deals with the adaptation of national contributions to the Union's own resources. Only a complete reform of the EU's own resource system would make up for the liquidity gap that the EU is currently facing.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the proposal because it allows Member States to choose more flexibly how to make available the amounts required by the adjustment of their own resources based on VAT and GNI, if the total amount is very high.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — In the light of recent statistical revisions carried out by the Member States, it seems that for several years some Member States have paid lower contributions than those due to the Union budget, while others have paid too high a contribution. For the sake of transparency, a report on the calculations and data underlying the adjustments to the VAT and GNI balances should be submitted annually to Parliament in the context of the budgetary procedure, ensuring that there is sufficient time for it to be examined. The decision of the Member States on the dates and amounts of instalments should be notified to Parliament. For these reasons, I would vote in favour.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — (IT) My vote in favour of the motion for a resolution is due to the fact that the Commission's proposal is part of a broader negotiating package, which includes the amending budgets of the last two years, and, following the amendments included in the text of the proposal by Parliament, I believe that it should be adopted.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — Recent measures to revise Member States' contributions based on their VAT and gross national income have revealed that some Member States have contributed too little or too little to the EU budget in recent years. In other words, the statistical calculations were not sufficiently precise and homogeneous between the Member States. However, such statistical adjustments can subsequently have a considerable impact on the contribution of certain Member States to the European Union budget, which is why the Council wishes to allow the deferred payment of such contributions in exceptional circumstances. This, unfortunately, weighs on the complexity of setting the European budget. Nevertheless, I resolve to vote in favour of such a measure because the priority is the adoption of the budgets of 2014 and 2015 so that the European Union can deal as quickly as possible with key economic issues.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — Under the Community's own resources system and in the light of the latest statistical analyses agreed by the Member States, it appears that several Member States have paid less than that stipulated for their GNI and VAT-based contributions to the Union budget, and that others have paid a higher amount. Certain Member States which have benefited from underestimation of their GNI have shown reluctance to pay the additional amounts due within the legal deadline. For this reason, the Council requested the Commission to authorise the deferral and payment in instalments of the amounts due. Whereas, for the sake of transparency, a report on the calculations and underlying data relating to adjustments to the VAT and GNI balance sheet should be submitted annually to Parliament in the context of the budgetary procedure. Recognising that the amounts of adjustments are exceptionally high, which may be an important burden and, given that this proposal is part of a more comprehensive negotiating package including the 2014 amending budgets and the 2015 budget, I voted in favour of this resolution which calls for transparency of the deferral and payment process in instalments to the Union budget.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — After arduous negotiations, an agreement has been reached that will allow the payment of outstanding invoices, for which the amount of EUR 4.8 billion has been agreed for the period 2014-2015. In addition, the Commission, the Council and Parliament have agreed on a payment plan aimed at reducing the level of unpaid invoices within the current multiannual framework. An unprecedented level of default has accumulated throughout this year. The agreed EUR 4.8 billion will enable part of the accumulated invoices to be met, thus helping to alleviate the situation of many SMEs, universities, local authorities and NGOs. For 2015, it has been agreed to allocate EUR 145 321 500 000 to commitment appropriations and EUR 141 214 040 563 to payment appropriations. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - We can abstain because this report criticises the Council very warmly. For Podemos, the precedent set by the Council during the negotiation of the 2015 budget should have been the subject of exemplary condemnation by the European Parliament.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - We can abstain because this report criticises the Council very warmly. For Podemos, the precedent set by the Council during the negotiation of the 2015 budget should have been the subject of exemplary condemnation by the European Parliament.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - In the light of the latest statistical reviews approved by the Member States, it appears that some States did not pay all their contributions to the Union budget for several years, while others overpaid, and that these deviations have been determined by the significant statistical changes reported by the Member States. Certain Member States which in the past benefited from the underestimation of their GNI have expressed their reluctance to pay the supplementary amounts they owe before the legal deadline expires. In view of this situation, the Council requested the Commission to submit a proposal taking account of this situation, changing the relevant rules and allowing the deferment and disbursement in tranches of the amounts due. The new proposal introduces greater discretion for Member States with regard to the timetable for their supplementary contributions, derived from GNI adjustments, to the Union budget. It is easy to foresee that this will create new difficulties for future EU budgets, so I have not been able to vote in favour and abstained.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the proposal for a Council regulation amending Euratom.  In light of the latest statistical revisions agreed by the Member States, it appeared that a number of Member States underpaid their due contributions to the Union budget over a number of years, while others overpaid theirs. The United Kingdom was one of the Member States to underpay. The rules currently in force would have resulted in the prompt correction of those under- and over-payments. The Council called on the Commission to present a proposal to accommodate the situation, by changing the concerned rules and allowing the deferral and payment by instalments of amounts. Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1150/2000 should therefore be amended accordingly.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — Due to the exceptionally high level of additional funds to be paid by certain Member States as a result of the adjustment of GNI-based contributions to their own resources in 2014, the Commission submitted to the Council a proposal for a Council Regulation amending the Regulation on the European Communities' own resources system.  I welcome this Commission proposal, as it gives Member States the necessary flexibility because they have to pay the amount resulting from the harmonisation of national contributions (own resources) on the basis of value added tax and gross national income, if the total is extremely high. I would also point out the importance of communicating and taking into account the views of the ECA. It is also important that Eurostat adheres to the ECA's recommendations regarding its verification methodology in order to fully respect the principle of equal treatment of Member States in practice. Therefore, I support the report.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — I support the proposal to amend Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1150/2000, as making high sums of money available can certainly represent (and represents) fiscal and other pressure for economically weaker Member States. If this proposal leads to real and not only prescribed assistance, it will be a great relief to some Member States in today's economic crisis. We can and must facilitate the situation by all possible means, but also, we must not use these funds when it is not necessary. Efficiency and solidarity are fundamental principles of the European Union.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — This proposal makes the own resources system even more complex and aims to amend the legislation, which will soon be replaced retroactively by acts already agreed.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of my colleague's text. Nevertheless, I would like to stress that I regret that the issue of the postponement of the adjustment of national contributions has taken a step in the Council over the desire to find a negotiating position for the budgets for the 2014 and 2015 financial years, which was only defined on the last day of the 21-day conciliation period provided for by Article 314 of the FUE Treaty. , which made the conciliation committee unable to reach an agreement.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — In recent years, several Member States have paid less than that stipulated for their contributions to the Union budget, while others have paid a higher amount. These deviations were motivated by the important statistical changes reported by the Member States. As a general rule, Member States have paid in the past, without significant delay, the total amount of their contributions to the Union budget based on GNI and VAT, even in times of crisis and severe budgetary pressure. While we recognise that the amounts of vat and GNI-based own resources adjustments for 2014 are exceptionally high, we cannot but question the reasons for this discrepancy, given the sophisticated mechanisms at the service of national accounts, particularly at the level of the countries where this issue arises. In this sense, we have doubts about this amendment to the Treaties, motivated by a statistical discrepancy which should, yes, have its own treatment to prevent these situations from happening again.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — Since this proposal would, among other things, also mean a higher burden on Austria, I rejected it in principle. Partial payment options are a welcome idea, but the proposal itself makes it impossible for me to agree. In addition, this proposal forms the basis for amending budgets 3, 4, 6 and 8. In this respect, the amending budgets mentioned above were also to be rejected.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — In recent years, several Member States have paid less than that stipulated for their contributions to the Union budget, while others have paid a higher amount.  As a general rule, Member States have paid in the past, without significant delay, the total amount of their contributions to the Union budget based on GNI and VAT, even in times of crisis and severe budgetary pressure. While we recognise that the amounts of vat and GNI-based own resources adjustments for 2014 are exceptionally high, we cannot but question the reasons for this discrepancy, given the sophisticated mechanisms at the service of national accounts, particularly at the level of the countries where this issue arises.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to intervene in the event of serious natural disasters and bring European solidarity to Europe's sinister regions. The Fund may provide financial assistance to Member States and accession countries in the event of a serious natural disaster provided that direct total damage exceeds EUR 3 billion at 2011 prices or 0.6% of the country's gross national income, if lower.  The MFF Regulation for the period 2014-2020 allows the Mobilisation of the Fund within the annual limit of EUR 500 000 000 in Article 10. This Decision of the European Parliament and of the Council is not linked to any specific case of natural disaster. Instead, its objective is to record EUR 50 000 000 in commitment and payment appropriations in the 2015 budget, which corresponds to the advances to be paid more quickly and effectively in the event of a natural disaster next year. That's why I voted for it.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to provide solidarity assistance in the event of major natural disasters. The cause was the severe flooding in Central Europe in the summer of 2002. Since then, the Fund has been used in many disasters and is therefore one of the EU's most important aid to the affected population. The EU's Multiannual Financial Framework for 2014-2020 provides a mobilisation of the Fund within an annual expenditure ceiling of €500 million. However, in the event of a disaster, Member States may need financial support more quickly than is possible under the normal procedure, which is why it has been possible to make an advance payment at the request of the Member State concerned shortly after the Commission has applied for a contribution from the Fund. I therefore welcome the fact that, with the adoption of the decision by the European Parliament, EUR 50 million in advance payments and corresponding appropriations will be made available for the 2015 financial year.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — Aid through the Solidarity Fund is not an efficient means of assisting with floods.  It only represents a small portion of the money spent by Member States and is an administrative nightmare.  Far better to reduce Member States’ contributions and to allow them to deal with such matters directly themselves.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of all draft amending budgets for 2014 and for the agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council on the 2015 budget. I congratulate the Negotiators of the European Parliament on the eur 4.25 billion allocated to the emergency debts of this year's EU budget. The European Commission would be obliged to draw up a step-by-step plan for the reduction of outstanding bills and to establish a sustainable debt ceiling in the future. Thanks to Parliament, eur 0.5 billion will be allocated to commitments. than the COUNCIL of the EU proposed. More funding will be allocated to horizon 2020 and the Erasmus+ programme for student and youth exchange. It is to be welcomed that the increase in funding for European neighbourhood programmes, humanitarian aid and the common foreign security policy has been increased, which is very relevant in the light of today's situation in Europe. However, I do not support the reduction in funding for the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund, which will affect many EU farmers, who are in a particularly difficult situation because of the protracted Russian embargo and who need EU assistance.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund aims to combat large-scale natural disasters and to express the community's solidarity with the affected European regions. It has an annual ceiling of 500 million euros. This proposal for a decision, which I supported, aims to mobilise a sum of 50 million euros in commitments and payments for the payment of advances under the Fund in emergency cases for the 2015 financial year. The advance may not be more than 10% of the expected financial contribution (and is by no means more than 30 million euros).

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution on the mobilization of the EU Solidarity Fund on disaster-affected regions is not linked to a particular case of natural disaster, as was the case with other requests for votes on aid following events in countries. The report aims to register EUR 50 million in commitment and payment credits in order to plan for advances to be made as soon as possible in the event of natural disasters in 2015. This should allow us to react more quickly than the normal procedure, but I would like to deplore the low level of funding in this regard when the EU does not hesitate to spend money all over the world. In order to guarantee the principle of solidarity at European level, to which I cannot remain insensitive in the event of natural disasters, I have obviously voted in favour.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the early mobilisation of EUR 50 million from the Solidarity Fund for the financial year 2015. This appropriation will not affect its future interventions, but should speed up its use operations.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Decision of the Parliament and of the Council which will allow a total of EUR 50 million to be recorded in the 2015 budget in commitment and payment appropriations for the European Union Solidarity Fund.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted for this because we need to have concrete help for the zones in the European Union which have suffered natural catastrophes.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund for EUR 50 000 000 in commitment and payment appropriations, which will be included in the 2015 budget for the payment of advances in order to meet the most urgent needs. With this decision, the Union is in solidarity with the population of the regions affected by natural disasters. This year, several EU and non-EU countries have been severely affected by flooding caused by torrential rains as well as other natural disasters such as earthquakes. Hundreds of thousands of European citizens have suffered colossal material and financial damage. Citizens lost in a split second homes, agricultural crops, and even domestic animals. Solidarity is one of the fundamental principles of the European Union and with this decision, the European Parliament demonstrates once again that it respects the fundamental principles of the EU and puts concern of the citizen before any other interest.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — Vote in favour. The 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework set the maximum annual allocation threshold (at 2011 prices) for the EU Solidarity Fund (which intervenes in the event of natural disasters) at EUR 500 million. For the payment of advances, the maximum annual amount that can be allocated is EUR 50 million. This vote mobilises the Solidarity Fund for commitment and advance payment appropriations of EUR 50 million for the financial year 2015. This appropriation clearly does not prejudge further future interventions and should, in any case, make it possible to speed up future operations which will undoubtedly see the use of the fund (since many disasters are affecting Italy, France and other Member States). In the Committee on Budgets, this measure passed almost unanimously by 36 votes in favour and only one against.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund for disaster-affected regions. The European Union Solidarity Fund was set up to respond to major natural disasters and is one of the most visible and effective examples of solidarity in the EU. The current decision of the European Parliament and the Council aims to include in the 2015 budget the amount of EUR 50 million, which corresponds to advances, which will be used to respond more quickly and effectively should exceptional events occur in the course of next year. A prompt response to disasters by the European institutions, through the anticipation of resources, can make a decisive contribution to providing concrete assistance to the European citizens affected, and that is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — Once again, the lack of flexibility in the financial instruments of the institutions, which require additions and corrections every year, is demonstrated. These changes necessarily lead to increases in expenditure and help to increase the mass of back payments.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this proposal in the hope that the money set aside in this Fund will never be used and that it will be proposed every year as an EU saving. It is a pity to know that this prospect is unlikely, and I welcome the allocation of sums to be used in emergency cases.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to respond to major natural disasters and express European solidarity with affected regions in Europe. The Fund may provide financial assistance to Member States and candidate countries negotiating their participation. The fund can also be mobilised in the event of regional disasters. The purpose of this Decision of Parliament and the Council is to include in the 2015 budget the amount of EUR 50 million in appropriations for authorisation and payment, which corresponds to advances which will have to be paid more quickly and efficiently in the event of a natural disaster next year. With this decision we send a clear political message of solidarity, while providing real assistance to affected citizens more quickly.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the amendment to the legislation concerning the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF). It is important to ensure that Member States receive financial support to respond to a natural disaster as quickly as possible. However, the question of the financing of special instruments remains open and I hope that a solution can be found as soon as possible.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — The European Union has created a European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to show solidarity with the population of regions struck by disasters. I have voted in favour of this report to enable a prompt reaction in the event of a natural disaster next year. A prompt reaction, including through the payment of an advance payment, will assure that the objectives of the EUSF (solidarity and genuine assistance to affected citizens) are achieved.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund was set up to deal with serious natural disasters and to express European solidarity with the regions of Europe affected by disasters. The Fund may provide financial support to Member States and countries engaged in accession negotiations affected by major natural disasters if the total direct damage caused by the disaster exceeds EUR 3 billion, at 2011 prices, or 0.6% of the gross national income of the country concerned, whatever the lower amount. It can also be mobilised in the event of a regional disaster. I am voting in favour of this resolution because the EU Solidarity Fund is not only another form of financial support from the Eu ropean Union, but also helps to send a clear political message of solidarity, while providing real assistance to the affected areas. These objectives can be achieved by means of a timely reaction, which may also take the form of an advance.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to intervene in the event of serious natural disasters and bring European solidarity to Europe's sinister regions. The Fund may provide financial assistance to Member States and accession countries in the event of a serious natural disaster provided that direct total damage exceeds EUR 3 billion at 2011 prices or 0.6% of the country's gross national income, if lower.  The MFF Regulation for the period 2014-2020 allows the Mobilisation of the Fund within the annual limit of EUR 500 000 000 in Article 10. This Decision of the European Parliament and of the Council is not linked to any specific case of natural disaster. Instead, its objective is to record EUR 50 000 000 in commitment and payment appropriations in the 2015 budget, which corresponds to the advances to be paid more quickly and effectively in the event of a natural disaster next year. That's why I voted for it.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. — The EU Solidarity Fund is a non-refundable financial instrument for emergencies, while also representing the expression of Union solidarity by providing concrete support to affected citizens. The purpose of this fund is to cover part of the public expenditure incurred by the beneficiary State to overcome the effects of major natural disasters. Romania has received support through this Fund, being allocated by the Commission the amount of EUR 2 475 689, in order to remove the damage caused by the drought, as well as the forest and vegetation fires that affected our country in 2012. The objective of this Decision is to include in the 2015 budget the amount of EUR 50 million in the form of commitment and payment appropriations, this amount being necessary to pay quickly and efficiently the advances in the event of a natural disaster occurring in the following financial year. I voted in support of this very important measure to make financial assistance available to the Member States in a faster manner.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to respond to major natural disasters and express European solidarity with disaster-stricken regions within Europe. The Fund can provide financial aid to Member States and countries engaged in accession negotiations in the event of a major natural disaster. The current Decision of the European Parliament and of the Council is not linked to a specific case of a natural disaster. It aims at entering in the 2015 budget the amount of EUR 50 million in commitments and payments, which corresponds to advances that will need to be paid out in a speedier and more efficient way in the event of a natural disaster next year. I agree with the need to have such a change in process to provide support in a quicker way.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. Under the current rules, it is possible to budget, under the Solidarity Fund, an amount of 50 million euros to respond to natural disasters more quickly than the normal procedure would allow. It is crucial, in fact, that Member States affected by exceptional natural phenomena can quickly count on European aid in addition to the budgetary measures they are already taking.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) provides financial support to Member States and countries engaged in accession negotiations affected by major natural disasters, if the total direct damage caused by the disaster exceeds EUR 3 billion. It can also be mobilised in the event of a regional disaster. With this vote, I supported the decision of the European Parliament and the Council to include in the 2015 budget an amount of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations, which correspond to the advances to be paid in the event of a natural disaster next year. This decision is designed to provide Member States with financial support to respond to natural disasters as quickly as possible.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. — The European Parliament today adopted by a large majority the EU budget for 2015 and the amendments on surplus resources for 2014. The huge advantage of the agreement is that it will be able to pass the EU budget for 2015 later this year, i.e. next year it would not only be possible to pay 12th of this year's budget per month. By 2014, an additional €4 billion will be mobilised, of which EUR 3.5 billion will be the result of so-called 'fresh money', i.e. not transfers.  The EP only agreed to the adoption of next year's EU budget on the condition that the European Commission draws up a plan to reduce unpaid bills to sustainable levels. In 2014, €23.4 billion will have to be paid from the previous year. To this end, today's vote provides an additional resource of nearly EUR 4 billion. Today's decision by the European Parliament also provided agricultural and cohesion resources for Hungary in this year's and next year's budgets. The Hungarian People's Party delegation, together with the European People's Party, acted responsibly on behalf of the national interests of Hungary and voted in favour of the 2015 EU budget and all the reports contained in the related agreement. The agreement also includes reports mobilising the Solidarity Fund to mitigate the damage caused by natural disasters affecting different regions of Europe.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. — The important contributions of the Member States must be given to Europeans and in particular to those affected by natural disasters. It is a healthy and sincere solidarity which I support, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the report because I am convinced that the EU must be flexible when there are reasons for compensating countries affected by natural disasters.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to respond to major natural disasters and express European solidarity with affected regions in Europe. Countries negotiating their support may have financial aid if the total direct damage caused by the disaster exceeds EUR 3 billion or 0.6 % of the country's gross national income, whichever is lower. The European Parliament strongly defended in the relevant negotiations with the Council the need to provide financial assistance to Member States to respond to a disaster more rapidly than provided for by the normal procedure. This position prevailed in the negotiations, so a maximum amount of EUR 50 million should be entered in the budget each year for this purpose. I agree that the amounts will be entered in the 2015 budget.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. — In 2002, as a result of severe flooding in Central Europe, the EU decided to set up the Solidarity Funds to intervene in cases of serious natural disasters, the basis of which was laid down in Regulation (EC) No 2012/2002. The priority of mobilizing the Solidarity Funds is to minimize the immediate and direct impact of natural disasters. In this regard, in January 2014 I had the pleasure of being the rapporteur of the European Parliament's report for the reform of the Regulation establishing these funds with the aim of ensuring rapid and effective mobilisation. This reform entered into force on 28 June 2014, ensuring greater effectiveness and speed in the mobilization of funds, as well as a simplification of the criteria in the aid request. Achieving rapid and effective goals is crucial to minimizing the impact of natural disasters. The speed with which such funds can be available to cover some of the rescue efforts, as well as to initiate the reconstruction and recovery of strategic infrastructure and services, will depend to a large extent on the economic and social recovery of regions affected by natural disasters.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing — In the past, the European Parliament has always vigorously defended the provisions of the new Solidarity Fund Regulation in its respective negotiations with the Council, recognising the need for Member States to receive financial support in order to respond to natural disasters more quickly than would be possible under the normal procedure. I therefore support the introduction in the budget of up to EUR 50 million to this end, which will make it possible to provide the Member State with an advance of up to 10% of the envisaged financial contribution. In fact, the European Union Solidarity Fund contributes to sending a clear political signal of solidarity and provides real assistance to affected citizens and regions.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — The EU must be flexible when there are reasons for compensating countries affected by natural disasters. I am voting in favour of mobilising the EU Solidarity Fund for disaster-affected areas.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. — (IT) In recent months, an extraordinary wave of bad weather has hit Italy, causing enormous damage in many regions. My region, Sicily, has been hit by violent tornadoes and whirlwinds which have caused considerable economic damage and sowed terror among the population. Although of a different nature, many Member States of the Union have found themselves in a position where it is necessary to request the intervention of this fund. The Solidarity Fund is not just economic aid, it is a financial instrument. It also, and above all, represents a political message: the European Union is there; it not only imposes constraints but offers help and support.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
