text: in writing. - Our vote is in favour of all redistributive transfers that are intended to aid to regions or countries affected by natural disasters. We particularly believe in the redistributive nature of the European budget.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the motion on the EU Solidarity Fund. This fund is created to respond to major natural disasters. This expresses the solidarity of all the Member States, which I think is absolutely necessary for the Union. It is important to ensure that money reaches the affected Member State rapidly, in order for the citizens of the region to feel the support.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - Our vote is in favour of all redistributive transfers that are intended to aid to regions or countries affected by natural disasters. We particularly believe in the redistributive nature of the European budget.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a motion for a Resolution on the proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in order to bring €50 million into the 2015 budget, which would allow for faster and more effective action in the event of assisting in major natural disasters over the next year. The Fund was set up to deal with major natural disasters as successfully as possible and to provide financial assistance to affected countries and regions, i.e. EU Member States and accession countries as quickly and efficiently as possible.  In my view, it is of utmost importance that Member States and accession countries receive financial assistance more quickly at the time of the disaster than is made possible by normal procedure. This kind of support from the EU carries a clear political message of solidarity while helping those in need.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. — While I understand that this is for aid, which could be used to help victims, the British public are already more than generous with donating funds to charitable causes when natural disasters occur. I do not believe foreign aid to be in the remit of the EU, so I voted against this proposal.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I supported the mobilisation of the fund, as it is crucial that we show solidarity with people from the affected areas by helping to rebuild basic infrastructure, funding emergency services, providing temporary accommodation, contributing to clean-up operations and countering immediate health risks.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. — (IT) The report that has just been adopted is not linked to a specific case of mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund, but aims to introduce into the 2015 budget an amount of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations, which correspond to an advance that will be necessary to ensure efficient responses in the event of natural disasters at the beginning of next year. This is a fundamental instrument for us, which we must improve in order to obtain answers more quickly than we have had to date, given also the particular solidarity and emergency nature of the same.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to intervene in the event of serious natural disasters and bring European solidarity to Europe's sinister regions. The Fund may provide financial assistance to Member States and accession countries in the event of a serious natural disaster provided that direct total damage exceeds EUR 3 billion at 2011 prices or 0.6% of the country's gross national income, if lower.  The MFF Regulation for the period 2014-2020 allows the Mobilisation of the Fund within the annual limit of EUR 500 000 000 in Article 10. This Decision of the European Parliament and of the Council is not linked to any specific case of natural disaster. Instead, its objective is to record EUR 50 000 000 in commitment and payment appropriations in the 2015 budget, which corresponds to the advances to be paid more quickly and effectively in the event of a natural disaster next year. That's why I voted for it.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to respond to major natural disasters and express European solidarity through financial assistance to the regions affected by these disasters in Europe. The EUSF currently has a maximum budget of EUR 500 million per year, but it has been noted that in many cases it would be desirable to create a mechanism to deal with extreme emergencies. To this end, 10% of the total FUNDS of the EUSF – a fund of EUR 50 million – which will serve for the early financing of disaster-affected areas is reserved, allowing for faster and more efficient reaction without having to wait for the full completion of the red tape.  This measure is not simply another form of EU financial support, but is a clear political message of solidarity, while providing real assistance to the citizens concerned.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — Over the past three years, more than 40,000 human lives have been lost in natural disasters in the world and economic losses worth around $350 billion have been caused. In 2012, the biggest economic losses, out of a total of $18 billion, were caused by floods that hit Germany, the Czech Republic and neighbouring countries. This year, a hailstorm called Andreas hit Germany and France in July, causing total economic losses estimated at $3.8 billion.  The biggest natural disaster of the year, Cyclone Donat, hit Croatia, Italy, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia in the spring, resulting in catastrophic consequences. The consequences in Croatia were unsightly, with more than 15,000 people evacuated and total damage estimated at more than 220m euros. These are just some of the natural disasters that have hit Europe and left behind damages that have not been remedied to this day.  I therefore support this proposal to mobilise €50 million from the European Union Solidarity Fund. This money is needed to recover the damaged areas and prevent more damage. The consequences of natural disasters, which are becoming more frequent, are enormous, not only because of the lives lost but also the loss of homes, jobs, the disappearance of industries and economies that were developed in this area.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. — Over the past year, a number of countries in Europe, including Bulgaria, have fallen victim to natural disasters that have caused billions of euros in damage and claimed dozens of lives. According to the calculation of the authorities in Bulgaria, the floods that flooded Varna, Dobrich, Veliko Tarnovo Gabrovo, Burgas, Montana and many other settlements caused damage to more than EUR 300 million or over 0.8% of the country's GDP. As a representative of one of the countries concerned, I am satisfied that with its decision to mobilise the European Solidarity Fund for financial assistance to the countries concerned, the European Union has proven that solidarity, as one of the founding and fundamental European values, is not just a good wish enshrined in the Treaties. In the coming months, Bulgaria will receive EUR 10 542 100 from the EU Solidarity Fund. Although a small percentage of the total damage, the funds will be used for emergency recovery activities. With its vote today, the European Parliament has shown that in times of difficulties and crises, Member States reach out to each other and can show support in times of need. I am convinced that it is solidarity and combined efforts that are the driving force of our continent!

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the Mureşan report on the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund: disaster-affected areas, because this report launches financial support for these regions for the damage they have suffered.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund. The report is aimed at entering in the 2015 budget an amount of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations corresponding to the advances to be disbursed more effectively and promptly in the event of a natural disaster. It is therefore of the utmost importance to express solidarity and support for all citizens of countries affected by disasters.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — (IT) The decision to vote in favour of the Mureșan report stems from the awareness that the inclusion of a further EUR 50 million in the 2015 budget to be allocated, in the form of advances, to the European Union Solidarity Fund, will allow for more timely action by the European Union in the event of a natural disaster occurring within the Community's borders next year.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — Only support should be provided for the re-establishment of the Solidarity Fund for disaster-affected regions. We must continue to support those citizens of the European Union who have been badly affected by fate and help them rebuild their homeland.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — This report aims to improve the European Union Solidarity Fund, which helps countries affected by "major natural disasters" to help them rebuild. It includes in the 2015 budget the amount of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment credits to enable the funds to be poured more quickly to the country in distress. The demands of this fund will increase as the unbridled capitalism that disrupts the climate and the austere policies of governments do not allow to cope. I am voting for this crucial allocation to help countries affected by ever-increasing environmental disasters.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to respond to major natural disasters and express European solidarity with affected regions in Europe. The Fund may provide financial assistance to Member States and countries negotiating their participation in the event of major natural disasters if the total direct damage caused by the disaster exceeds EUR 3 billion at 2011 prices or 0.6 % of the country's gross national income, whichever is lower. It can also be mobilised in the event of a regional disaster. With the changes introduced, I hope that this instrument will become faster and more effective. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — In light of the ongoing climatic challenges and natural disasters, the EU Solidarity Fund offers some relief for the European region. This is why I voted in favour of this proposal that will set aside funds for payment of advances and the corresponding appropriations entered into the general budget of the Union. We experienced multiple natural disasters in 2014 and it is crucial that the EU Solidarity Fund is ready to offer support and relief for those most affected.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The severity and complexity of natural disasters in Europe has been increasing rapidly and inevitably in recent years, creating considerable human and material damage for some regions. The economic, social and environmental damage these disasters cause cannot go unanswered. By approving the mobilization of the Solidarity Fund to the tune of EUR 50 million to ensure the most urgent needs, we are respecting our commitments and expressing our solidarity with the people of the affected regions of the EU but also with the member countries affected by these disasters. There is a real challenge for the EU to coordinate and strengthen its instruments so that it can have viable means to respond effectively to these cross-border disasters.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing — The European Union Solidarity Fund is an important instrument of the European Union for dealing with the consequences of major natural disasters. Financial assistance is a concrete expression of solidarity between the Union and its citizens with affected regions, where the damage caused by the disaster exceeds EUR 3 billion or 0.6% of the country's gross national income.  In view of the unfortunate experience of previous years with delays in disbursement of aid, I voted in favour of adopting a decision to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund for the next financial year 2015 in order to be able to provide eur 50 000 000 in commitment and payment appropriations for advance payments.  Thanks to this measure, it will be possible to pay financial support to the disaster-affected region more swiftly and flexibly next year.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of this report, which proposes to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) in favour of major natural disasters and express European solidarity to disaster-stricken regions within Europe.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Considering that the principle of European solidarity must obviously apply to remedy the damage caused by disasters, I have of course voted in favour of mobilising the EU Solidarity Fund.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund in order to better equip Member States to rebuild basic infrastructure, fund emergency services, provide temporary accommodation, contribute to clean-up operations and counter immediate health risks.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of the report by Mr De Clercq on behalf of the Committee on The Protection of human Rights, Research and Energy. Muresan on the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund so that EUR 50 million is already being mobiliseed to cover a possible natural disaster in a more timely manner next year.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. — I voted for this project because the report institutionalises mechanisms to support disaster-affected regions. However, the report has some shortcomings in the clarity and means used to support disaster-affected regions and does not make major additions to the existing legal basis.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - As the formal criteria for the allocation of aid have been met and the aid should be provided quickly and unbureaucratically, I voted in favour of the motion.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. The EUSF was created following the floods that hit Central Europe in the summer of 2002. I voted in favour of the deployment of this fund, which allows for the rapid mobilization of resources in the event of a disaster.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal to include EUR 50 million in the 2015 budget, as it will be able to help people living in disaster areas more quickly and efficiently. It is very important that natural disasters have all the conditions in place to ensure that aid arrive arrive as soon as possible.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Ladies and gentlemen, the European Union has set up a European Union Solidarity Fund to show solidarity with the people of disaster-stricken regions. Council Regulation No 1311/2013 authorises the use of the European Union Solidarity Fund up to a maximum annual amount of EUR 500 million and provides for an amount of EUR 50 000 000 to be made available for the payment of advances from appropriations entered in the general budget of the Union. For these reasons, I would vote in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. If we do not endorse the Union's cohesion policy and believe that it does not alleviate economic and social disparities between Member States, we believe that the principle of European solidarity can make sense when one of our European neighbours is seriously affected by a natural disaster. Moreover, the climatic events that have hit the south of France in recent months reinforce the idea that mutual financial assistance must enable us to better respond to the human, material and financial consequences of this type of tragic event. Common management of natural risks must be encouraged at European level in order to strengthen risk pooling. That is why I voted for the mobilization of the Solidarity Fund.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — I am in favour of expressing the solidarity of the peoples through a dedicated fund amounting to 50 million euros for 2015.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to respond to major natural disasters and to express European solidarity with the people of the affected regions. The conditions for mobilising the EUSF are defined in Council Regulation (EC) No 2012/2002, which, in its current wording, provides for the possibility of mobilising the Fund by a maximum amount of EUR 50 000,000 for the payment of advances, including the inclusion of its appropriations in the general budget of the Union (see Article 4a(4). This is a new provision which seeks to ensure that, following a preliminary assessment by the Commission, financial aid (in the form of advances) can be provided quickly and efficiently to Member States in response to disasters that may occur. The purpose of this Decision is precisely to include in the 2015 budget the amount of EUR 50 million in authorising and payment appropriations, which corresponds to advances payable in the event of a natural disaster next year. Because I believe that it is essential to create conditions for rapid responses to possible natural disasters, I voted in favour.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Decision of the Parliament and of the Council which will allow a total of EUR 50 million to be recorded in the 2015 budget in commitment and payment appropriations for the European Union Solidarity Fund.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - Our vote is in favour of all redistributive transfers that are intended to aid to regions or countries affected by natural disasters. We particularly believe in the redistributive nature of the European budget.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — As part of the European Union Solidarity Fund, I voted in favour of the inclusion in the 2015 budget of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations. This decision should allow for advances to be made faster and more efficient in the event of a natural disaster next year. As a reminder, the European Union Solidarity Fund aims to combat large-scale natural disasters and to express solidarity with the affected regions. It was therefore important to me to enable this Fund to provide faster assistance to citizens affected by such a tragedy.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — The European Union has set up the Solidarity Fund (EUSF) as a way of responding, in solidarity and addressing regions affected by major natural disasters. The conditions for mobilising this Fund are set out in Council Regulation (EC) No 2012/2002, with an annual ceiling of around EUR 500 000 000, and EUR 50 000 000 may be mobilised for payment of advances. I therefore agree with the proposal to include in the 2015 budget the amount of EUR 50 million in authorising and payment appropriations (which corresponds to the advances that may have to be paid) in order, more quickly and more effectively, to respond to the minimisation of the effects of an unforeseen natural disaster. It is therefore a preventive measure, which aims to ensure a priori mobilisation of the EUSF in a timely manner to deal with Member States which need to respond swiftly to the harmful effects caused by a natural disaster, as well as the possibility of being granted an advance at the request of a Member State on the basis of a preliminary assessment of the damage caused.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - Our vote is in favour of all redistributive transfers that are intended to aid to regions or countries affected by natural disasters. We particularly believe in the redistributive nature of the European budget.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to intervene in the event of serious natural disasters and bring European solidarity to Europe's sinister regions. The Fund may provide financial assistance to Member States and accession countries in the event of a serious natural disaster provided that direct total damage exceeds EUR 3 billion at 2011 prices or 0.6% of the country's gross national income, if lower. The MFF Regulation for the period 2014-2020 allows the Mobilisation of the Fund within the annual limit of EUR 500 000 000 in Article 10. This Decision of the European Parliament and of the Council is not linked to any specific case of natural disaster. Instead, its objective is to record EUR 50 000 000 in commitment and payment appropriations in the 2015 budget, which corresponds to the advances to be paid more quickly and effectively in the event of a natural disaster next year. That's why I voted for it.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. — While I understand that this is for aid, which could be used to help victims, the British public are already more than generous with donating funds to charitable causes when natural disasters occur. I do not believe foreign aid to be in the remit of the EU, so I voted against this proposal.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — Today I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the EUSF for regions affected by disasters.  The current decision of the European Parliament and the Council aims at including EUR 50 million in commitments and payments in the 2015 budget. This amount corresponds to advances that will need to be paid out in a speedier and more efficient way in the event of a natural disaster next year.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. — I support the decision to mobilise up to €50 million from the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2013 to pay advances and other appropriations. Since it was established in 2002, more than €3.5 billion has been disbursed from the Fund to help remediate 56 disasters, which clearly supports the justification for the existence of the fund and its importance for the European Union.  While the very existence of the Fund testifies to the unity and solidarity of the European Union, I believe that the disbursement of funds should be more effective in order to remediate the consequences of natural disasters as early as possible. The increasing and costly consequences of climate change show that the Solidarity Fund will become an increasingly important EU financial instrument. The European Union must change its approach to climate change as soon as possible. As a Community, we need to focus our public policies on climate change prevention. Our shared resources in this approach can have a much greater impact while focusing only on repairing damages is unsustainable in the long run.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — The European Union Solidarity Fund plays the role of protecting and remediing damage in places affected by various disasters. This fund is provided with a sum of €50 000 000, which should be included in the 2015 budget for payment in order to address the greatest needs.  I support the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund, as it provides solutions to natural disasters that people are unable to influence, anticipate, that leave behind human life losses and material consequences. The purpose of this tool is to show solidarity with the inhabitants of the region who have been killed by the disaster. It enables faster and more efficient recovery of affected areas and therefore I support the report.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — Solidarity is one of the founding principles of the European Union. It is in these moments when we face the grave consequences of natural disasters that we have the opportunity to put this principle into practice as well. This is one of the reasons why I supported this initiative, as it provides assistance through the Solidarity Fund to Member States, which, in addition to suffering the severe consequences of natural disasters, are in a bad economic situation. These Member States need assistance as financial benefits from member states' budgets are insufficient to finance the damages caused. Natural disasters have been occurring more frequently over the past few years, and with the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund, I call on all Member States to make use of the available EU funds to better prevent natural disasters.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — The EU must be flexible when there are reasons for compensating countries affected by natural disasters.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. " One of the central values of the Union must be solidarity! Without solidarity, no Europe. The European Union Solidarity Fund is one of its important instruments. Its aim is to combat large-scale natural disasters and to express the community's solidarity with the affected European regions. The Fund is able to provide financial assistance to Member States and accession countries in the event of a major natural disaster if the direct damage caused by the disaster exceeds EUR 3,000,000,000 in 2011 prices or 0.6% of gross national income (GNI), with the lowest figure being retained.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. — Natural disasters are unpredictable and EU must give a fast response to the affected regions by the European Union Solidarity Fund. That is why I support this report, so that the general budget of the European Union is ready for the financial year 2015.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. — My vote is in favour of mobilizing extra funds for the benefit of States affected by natural disasters.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — having regard to the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, budgetary cooperation and good financial management, in particular paragraph 11, the framework of the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015, the European Union Solidarity Fund is mobilised , in order to allocate the amount of EUR 50 000 000 in payment and authorisation appropriations for the payment of advances. We have nothing to owe.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — The support of EU citizens who have been hit hard by disasters and are thus put to the test by fate is, in principle, to be welcomed. I therefore voted in favour of re-establishing the Solidarity Fund for disaster-affected regions.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — The Commission has proposed mobilizing the Flexibility Instrument above the MFF deadlines to supplement the financing of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 at EUR 79.8 million in commitment appropriations in relation to the additional allocation of the Structural Funds to Cyprus, totaling EUR 100 million for the 2015 financial year. I voted in favour of this report to mobilisation the Flexibility Instrument and amend the Commission's proposal to finance the additional allocation to cypriot Structural Fund programmes under subheading 1b up to EUR 83.26 million.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — This appears to grant an additional allocation from Structural Funds to Cyprus, in the amount of 100 million euros.  I oppose the use of the flexibility mechanism here.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of all draft amending budgets for 2014 and for the agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council on the 2015 budget. I congratulate the Negotiators of the European Parliament on the eur 4.25 billion allocated to the emergency debts of this year's EU budget. The European Commission would be obliged to draw up a step-by-step plan for the reduction of outstanding bills and to establish a sustainable debt ceiling in the future. Thanks to Parliament, eur 0.5 billion will be allocated to commitments. than the COUNCIL of the EU proposed. More funding will be allocated to horizon 2020 and the Erasmus+ programme for student and youth exchange. It is to be welcomed that the increase in funding for European neighbourhood programmes, humanitarian aid and the common foreign security policy has been increased, which is very relevant in the light of today's situation in Europe. However, I do not support the reduction in funding for the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund, which will affect many EU farmers, who are in a particularly difficult situation because of the protracted Russian embargo and who need EU assistance.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The EU is facing a serious economic and fiscal crisis. Many states are bearing the brunt of the austerity policy decided by Brussels.  The mobilization of the flexibility instrument here in favour of Cyprus is a good indication of the budgetary situation in which the EU finds itself. This flexibility instrument, capped at EUR 200 million, will have to provide 80 million (or 40%!) to Cyprus in order to finance the Structural Funds programmes. In view of the economic and social situation in the Union but also the EU's failing management of its budgets, I therefore voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of activating the flexibility instrument to supplement, with an amount of EUR 79 785 595, above the ceiling, the funding provided for in the GENERAL BUDGET of the EU for the financial year 2015 for structural fund programmes for Cyprus, which would benefit, for the year 2015, from a budget of up to EUR 100 000 000.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — I voted in favour, since the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument will complement the financing of the general budget of the European Union for the 2015 financial year by EUR 79.8 million in commitment appropriations in relation to the additional allocation of the Structural Funds for Cyprus, for a total amount of EUR 100 million for the 2015 financial year.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted for this because we need to have concrete help for the zones in the European Union which are less rich.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — Faced with an unprecedented payments crisis, the European Union must absolutely control its multi-year financial framework and avoid at all costs from mobilising the flexibility instrument for such large amounts. Indeed, the mobilization of the flexibility instrument reflects a shortage of European credits. However, the ceiling of this instrument is limited to 200 million euros. It therefore seems totally disproportionate to mobilise eur 80 million for Cyprus, or almost 40% of the total amount. That is why I voted against the decision of the European Parliament and the Council.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour. The 2014-2020 MFF authorises the use of the flexibility instrument to allow the financing of clearly identified expenditure that could not be financed within the available ceilings of one or more headings of the Multiannual Financial Framework. The Commission proposes to activate the flexibility instrument to supplement, with an amount of EUR 79 785 595, above the ceiling, the funding provided for in the EU general budget for the financial year 2015 for structural fund programmes for Cyprus, which would benefit, for 2015, from a budget of up to a total amount of EUR 100 000 000.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the proposal to mobilise the financial flexibility instrument in favour of supplementing the financing provided for in the EU general budget for the Structural Funds of Cyprus. In 2013, the island of Cyprus faced a serious financial crisis in the local banking system, caused primarily by a lack of control of the sector, which almost led to its default. The appropriations provided for in the flexibility instrument are intended to support the start of a favourable economic situation for Cyprus, which seems essential in order to guarantee stability on the island, given also the sensitivity of the present historic moment, since the process of reunification between the Turkish Cypriot and Greek Cypriot parties has just resumed.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) The Cypriot economy, however small, is experiencing its difficulties. It is our duty, within an economic and monetary union, also to support it financially so that it can once again become a stable and reliable partner on which we can count both politically and economically. I therefore voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. — Council Regulation No 1311/2013 of 2 December 2013 establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 provides for the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to enable the financing of specifically identified expenditure that cannot be financed within the available ceilings of one or more headings of the multiannual financial framework. After analysing all the possibilities for reallocation of appropriations, it is necessary to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument to complement the financing of the General Budget of the Union for the financial year 2015 amounting to EUR 83 285 595, in addition to the ceiling of sub-heading 1b, in favour of the Structural Funds programmes for Cyprus. These amounts will be used to complement the financing of the Structural Fund programmes for Cyprus for the financial year 2015 with an amount of EUR 100 000 000.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - After examining all the possibilities for commitment appropriations under heading 1b, after the European Parliament and the Council of the EU had already activated the flexibility instrument for the financial year 2014 on 20 November 2013, to finance structural fund programmes for Cyprus with an amount of EUR 89 million in commitment appropriations and, finally, after learning that the ceilings of subheading 1b do not allow adequate funding of the important and urgent political priorities of the the EU general budget for the financial year 2015, I have decided to vote in favour of mobilising the flexibility instrument. In this way, we will be able to supplement the planned funding of EUR 80 000 000 for structural fund programmes for Cyprus under heading 1b.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — The multiannual financial framework for the years 2014-2020 allows for the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to allow the financing of clearly identified expenditure which could not be financed within the limits of the ceilings available for one or more headings of the multiannual financial framework. This mobilisation seems to be necessary to finance the Cypriot Structural Funds programmes. The mobilisation of this instrument highlights the crucial need for the Union budget to be increasingly flexible.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — In view of the very serious economic and social situation, despite the modest increase in commitment appropriations for certain budget lines, the ceilings of subheading 1b for the financial year 2015 do not allow sufficient financing of important and urgent political priorities of the Union. I voted in favour of approving the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument and amending the Commission's proposal, in order to allow for the additional allocation of Structural Fund programmes for Cyprus under subheading 1b to an amount of EUR 83.26 million.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — The Commission has proposed mobilizing the Flexibility Instrument above the MFF deadlines to supplement the financing of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 at EUR 79.8 million in commitment appropriations in relation to the additional allocation of the Structural Funds to Cyprus, totaling EUR 100 million for the 2015 financial year. I voted in favour of this report to mobilisation the Flexibility Instrument and amend the Commission's proposal to finance the additional allocation to cypriot Structural Fund programmes under subheading 1b up to EUR 83.26 million.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — This report supports the Commission proposal for amends to finance the additional allocation for the Cypriot Structural Funds programmes – this after having examined all possibilities for re-allocating commitment appropriations. The report also reiterates that the mobilisation of this instrument, as foreseen in Article 11 of the MFF Regulation, proves once more the crucial need for the Union budget to be flexible. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. — The European Parliament today adopted by a large majority the EU budget for 2015 and the amendments on surplus resources for 2014. The huge advantage of the agreement is that it will be able to pass the EU budget for 2015 later this year, i.e. next year it would not only be possible to pay 12th of this year's budget per month. By 2014, an additional €4 billion will be mobilised, of which EUR 3.5 billion will be the result of so-called 'fresh money', i.e. not transfers.  The EP only agreed to the adoption of next year's EU budget on the condition that the European Commission draws up a plan to reduce unpaid bills to sustainable levels. In 2014, €23.4 billion will have to be paid from the previous year. To this end, today's vote provides an additional resource of nearly EUR 4 billion. Today's decision by the European Parliament also provided agricultural and cohesion resources for Hungary in this year's and next year's budgets. The Hungarian People's Party delegation, together with the European People's Party, acted responsibly on behalf of the national interests of Hungary and voted in favour of the 2015 EU budget and all the reports contained in the related agreement. The agreement also includes reports mobilising the Solidarity Fund to mitigate the damage caused by natural disasters affecting different regions of Europe.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the report because it concerns the full financing of the additional funds for the CYPRUS Structural Funds programmes.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — The document proposes mobilising the Flexibility Instrument by an amount above the ceilings of the Multiannual Financial Framework (2014-2020) in order to complement the financing of the EU general budget for the financial year 2015 with more than EUR 79.8 million in commitment appropriations, for a total amount of EUR 100 million for the financial year 2015 , to be used to complement the financing of the Structural Fund programmes for Cyprus in cohesion in 2014 and 2015 for the period 2015-2018. Following this proposal, this report agrees with the mobilisation of this Instrument with a view to financing the additional allocation of structural fund programmes for a maximum amount of EUR 83.26 million. In view of the complementary nature of the Flexibility Instrument, these additional payment appropriations serve to ensure coverage of additional authorisation appropriations for Cyprus on the basis of the expected payment profile. We voted in favour.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of mobilising the flexibility instrument in favour of the Structural Funds programmes for Cyprus, because it concerns the full financing of the additional funds for the Cyprus Structural Funds programmes.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. — This is to allow an additional amount from the Structural Funds to Cyprus for 2015 – giving a total of EUR 100 000 000.00 It is very easy for MEPs to vote away other people’s money, with limited information, and very little success from such schemes. Is it not time that we stopped taxing people to give this money out on whims, to prop up big businesses and NGOs? I voted against UK taxpayers’ money being used in this way.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - We voted in favour as Cyprus needed an extension of its Structural Funds as it was granted to other countries at severe economic juncture and under Troika surveillance programmes. Our favourable vote should not be understood as an implicit or explicit support for the Troika's monitoring programmes. However, this mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument corresponds to a much-needed enlargement of Structural Funds at the current Cypriot economic situation.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We voted in favour as Cyprus needed an extension of its Structural Funds as it was granted to other countries at severe economic juncture and under Troika surveillance programmes. Our favourable vote should not be understood as an implicit or explicit support for the Troika's monitoring programmes. However, this mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument corresponds to a much-needed enlargement of Structural Funds at the current Cypriot economic situation.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a motion for a resolution on the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of a flexibility instrument related to the financing of structural fund programmes for Cyprus, as this will ensure adequate implementation of the economic and social growth of that State. In my view, flexibility in the European Union budget is of great importance, which could help and react promptly in various situations that cannot be financed within the ceilings of available headings. I also support that the funds mobilised through the fund are used precisely to finance structural fund programmes due to the obvious importance that these funds have for Cyprus.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument, which mobilises EUR 11.3 million in payment credits for 2015 for Cyprus. The text was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. — (IT) Mrs Eider Gardiazabal's report provides for the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument to the sum of EUR 89.28 million in commitments in order to finance the programmes of the Structural Funds in Cyprus. This decision takes account of the particular difficult situation in Cyprus and I have therefore given my positive opinion.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — The Commission has proposed mobilizing the Flexibility Instrument above the MFF deadlines to supplement the financing of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 at EUR 79.8 million in commitment appropriations in relation to the additional allocation of the Structural Funds to Cyprus, totaling EUR 100 million for the 2015 financial year. I voted in favour of this report to mobilisation the Flexibility Instrument and amend the Commission's proposal to finance the additional allocation to cypriot Structural Fund programmes under subheading 1b up to EUR 83.26 million.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. — The Commission proposes to mobilisation the Flexibility Instrument, above the MFF deadlines, to supplement funding in the overall EU budget for the 2015 financial year. EUR 79.8 million in commitment appropriations is expected as a supplementary allocation to the Structural Funds to Cyprus, totaling EUR 100 million for 2015. The EP, having considered all the possibilities for reallocation of the commitment appropriations under subheading 1b, concludes that it seems necessary to mobilize the Flexibility Instrument. Despite the reinforcements contained in commitment appropriations in a limited number of budget items, the 2015 deadline does not allow adequate funding of EU policy priorities. It is therefore necessary to mobilisation the Flexibility Instrument and to amend the Commission's proposal to finance the additional allocation for Cypriot Structural Fund programmes up to EUR 83.26 million. Finally, the EP considers that the mobilisation of this instrument, as provided for in Article 11 of the MFF Regulation, demonstrates the need for more flexibility in the Union budget. I therefore vote in favour of this Resolution.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — The European Union assists all Member States, especially those in development, on the principle of solidarity. Cyprus has a specific situation of constant conflict with the Turkish side of the island and needs special support and assistance. Cyprus' development has slowed. In the last two years, the number of unemployed has been increasing and data from October 2014 show that the unemployment rate is 15.3%. Also, in 2014 the gdp decline continued. I support the European Union's efforts to help with these situations. Mobilising the flexibility instrument will ensure the financing of structural fund programmes for Cyprus, help drivers of economic growth and reduce unemployment.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the Rubial report on the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument in favour of the Structural Funds programmes for Cyprus, because the financial support for Cyprus, which has been impoverished as a result of the memoranda imposed on it by the Troika, is under way.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument on budgetary cooperation and sound financial management. It is necessary to activate the flexibility instrument for commitment appropriations in order to increase the allocation of structural funds for Cyprus.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the report signed by My colleague Gardiazabal Rubial, because I agree with the need to increase the commitment appropriations for certain budget lines, since the ceilings of subheading 1b for the financial year 2015 do not allow sufficient funding for priority political commitments for the Union.  At the same time, I support the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument to allow the additional allocation of Structural Fund programmes for Cyprus, under subheading 1b, to be allowed to amount to EUR 83.26 million.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — I can only refuse to increase the amount of money that is not available and thus further promotes the EU's debt.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — The flexibility instrument allows, for a given fiscal year, the financing of additional expenditure clearly identified outside the multi-year financial framework, the European Union budget for 7 years. In concrete terms, the aim here is to mobilise EUR 83 million on this instrument in order to finance the additional Structural Funds to which Cyprus is entitled. Structural funds are now directly conditioned on respect for "macro-conditionality" or respect for neoliberal doxa. I am voting to prevent Cypriot citizens from benefiting from cohesion policy funds. It is indeed this latest financial windfall that keeps the employment agencies afloat or more broadly the social in Europe.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — I agree with the mobilisation of this instrument to finance the Structural Fund programmes for Cyprus. The crisis that has affected this Member State justifies this exceptional situation in order to finance the additional allocation of the Structural Funds programmes for Cyprus under subcategory 1b for a maximum amount of EUR 83.26 million.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal. It is essential that the EU honours its commitments to its Members and utilises any available tools to make funds available for the projects dependent on the Structural Funds.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I supported the report on mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to finance the additional allocation for the Cypriot Structural Funds programmes

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The European Union is now facing an unprecedented unpaid crisis. Thus, at the end of 2014, the amount of unpaid bills amounts to about 30 billion euros while that of the remaining commitments to be realized (RAL - remains to be liquidated) exceeds 220 billion euros. The mobilization of the flexibility instrument therefore betrays the disastrous fiscal and financial situation in which the European Union is plunged, which no longer has the current funds necessary for its policies and commitments. It should also be noted that this flexibility instrument is capped at EUR 200 million and that we are proposed here to release 80 million, or 40%, to finance the Structural Funds programmes for Cyprus. In view of the economic and social situation in Europe and in particular in France, I voted against it.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. — The mobilisation of the flexibility instrument will clearly identify expenses which cannot be covered by the EU budget without exceeding the maximum expenditure set out in the MFF.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - Since the specific impact assessment seems to me to be inadequate, and I do not see any meaningful and plausible calculations in particular about the economic development of the region as a result of financial aid, I voted against the granting of aid in this case.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the flexibility instrument, which allows the financing of clearly identified expenditure that could not be funded within the ceilings available under one or more sections of the MFF. Here, it is a question of mobilising EUR 83,260,000 for the Structural Funds for Cyprus programmes.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the draft because it will allow for faster funding for the european Union's important and urgent priorities. In this case, it is important for the smooth development of Cyprus.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Ladies and gentlemen, Article 11 of Council Regulation No 1311/2013 establishing a flexibility instrument provides for an annual ceiling of EUR 471 million. It is necessary to activate the flexibility instrument in order to supplement the funding provided for in the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 for the Structural Funds programmes for Cyprus. By decision of 20 November 2013, the European Parliament and the Council have already activated the flexibility instrument for the 2014 financial year to finance structural fund programmes for Cyprus. After considering all the possibilities for reassigning appropriations, additional payment appropriations must be provided for the financial years 2014-2015 to cover the additional commitment appropriations for Cyprus on the basis of the expected payment profile. For these reasons, I would vote in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. — Faced with an unprecedented payments crisis, the European Union must absolutely control its multi-year financial framework and avoid at all costs from mobilising the flexibility instrument for such large amounts. Indeed, the mobilization of the flexibility instrument reflects a shortage of European credits. However, the ceiling of this instrument is limited to 200 million euros. It therefore seems totally disproportionate to mobilise eur 80 million for Cyprus, or almost 40% of the total amount. That is why I voted against the decision of the European Parliament and the Council.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — Given previous cases of mobilisation of the flexibility instrument under the Multiannual Financial Framework, I consider its use to be an important corrective measure for financing and implementing essential structural programmes in the Member States.  This mobilisation for Cyprus will this time include commitments under Heading 1b of EUR 79 785 595, as well as the provision of an additional EUR 11 315 595 for loans to be used to finance the Cyprus Structural Funds programme item with the European Union budget for the 2015 financial year. In my view, it is indicative of the Commission's proposal to grant the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument for Cyprus in 2014, but only in the part of the commitments defined under the MFF items without granting additional funds for credit payments.  In conclusion, it is also important to highlight last year's mobilisation of the flexibility instrument proposed before the European Parliament by the EPP Group Group, and this time we also supported the mobilisation of a flexibility instrument to finance the cyprus programme.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Writing. — The reasoning put forward is an insult to reason. This is not about helping a European partner country to invest in infrastructure and the economy. Instead, under an easy-to-see camouflage, the Cypriot state budget is being improved with european support programmes. After additional financial resources were already made available last year, the miraculous recalculation underlying this draft decision resulted in a further considerable additional need. I refuse to vote in favour of this, partly because I am convinced that the third, equally outrageous, adjustment will be presented to the European Parliament as early as next year. Instead of transferring more and more taxpayers' money, the realisation that Cyprus will be permanently drip-drip under this euro should finally prevail. It is absolutely unsolidarity to deny an economic recovery to a European partner!

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — The challenge facing Cyprus is unprecedented and the impact of the crisis unfortunately continues to overwhelm this Member State. As such, the Structural Funds are used to finance the real economy. With this resolution, the European Parliament agrees to the use of such a mechanism and to the redeployment of certain budget lines towards it.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — Article 11 of Council Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 allows the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument within the annual ceiling of EUR 471 million (at 2011 prices) in order to allow the financing of clearly identified expenditure which cannot be financed within the limits of one or more headings. After an analysis of all the possibilities for reallocation of appropriations under subcategory 1b, it is necessary to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument to complement funding in the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 amounting to EUR 83 285 595, in addition to the subcategory 1b ceiling for the Structural Funds programmes for Cyprus, in order to grant cyprus an additional allocation under the Structural Funds for the financial year 2015 with a total amount of EUR 100 000 000. I therefore voted in favour of this decision to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour as the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument will complement the financing of the general budget of the European Union for the 2015 financial year by EUR 79.8 million in commitment appropriations in relation to the additional allocation of the Structural Funds to Cyprus, for a total amount of EUR 100 million for the 2015 financial year.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - We voted in favour as Cyprus needed an extension of its Structural Funds as it was granted to other countries at severe economic juncture and under Troika surveillance programmes. Our favourable vote should not be understood as an implicit or explicit support for the Troika's monitoring programmes. However, this mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument corresponds to a much-needed enlargement of Structural Funds at the current Cypriot economic situation.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of mobilising the flexibility instrument to finance, up to EUR 83,260,000, the additional endowment for the Structural Funds programmes for Cyprus. This mobilization of the flexibility instrument will allow the country to be granted an additional endowment totalling EUR 100,000,000.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - We voted in favour as Cyprus needed an extension of its Structural Funds as it was granted to other countries at severe economic juncture and under Troika surveillance programmes. Our favourable vote should not be understood as an implicit or explicit support for the Troika's monitoring programmes. However, this mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument corresponds to a much-needed enlargement of Structural Funds at the current Cypriot economic situation.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - The Commission has proposed mobilizing the Flexibility Instrument above the MFF deadlines to supplement the financing of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 at EUR 79.8 million in commitment appropriations in relation to the additional allocation of the Structural Funds to Cyprus, totaling EUR 100 million for the 2015 financial year. I voted in favour of this report to mobilisation the Flexibility Instrument and amend the Commission's proposal to finance the additional allocation to cypriot Structural Fund programmes under subheading 1b up to EUR 83.26 million.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — I voted with the majority in supporting the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to finance the Cypriot Structural Funds programmes.  After having examined all possibilities for re-allocating appropriations it appears necessary to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument for commitment appropriations. The Commission has proposed to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument to complement financing in the 2015 general budget of the European Union. A sum of EUR 79.8 million in commitment appropriations will go towards the financing of the Cypriot Structural Funds programmes.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — I support this report, as well as the decision to finance the Cyprus Structural Funds for Development and Employment for which eur 100 000 will be allocated. These are funds that should lead to increased employment, modernisation of social protection systems, flexibility of the labour market, increasing investment in human capital through better education and skills acquisition and strengthening administrative capacity, and ultimately the growth of the gross social product of the state.  Investing in employment and personnel development is one of the primary policy objectives of the European Union, especially in times of high unemployment. People are a significant resource, the development of societies and economies depends largely on the development of the population and therefore I support this report.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — I fully support this decision to finance the Cyprus Structural Development and Employment Funds for which €100 000 million will be allocated. This is an expenditure that will lead to increased employment, modernisation of social protection systems, flexibility of the labour market, increasing investments in human capital through better education and skills acquisition, and strengthening administrative capacity. Investment in employment is one of the primary policy objectives of the European Union, especially in times of high unemployment. People are our most important resource, our future depends on the success of young people and every money redirected to help employment and development is well invested money that I will support in the future.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing — I do not agree with the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument because it leads to higher EU spending. Structural Funds programmes are already receiving excessive amounts of money and, as the European Court of Auditors noted in its report, the main criterion in their use is the mere spending of funds. In view of this fact, as well as the chronic inefficiencies of the Structural Funds, I consider their further increase to be unjustified.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — The full financing of the additional funds for the Cyprus Structural Funds programmes is in the positive direction.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the text on the european Parliament and Council's proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument, in accordance with point 12 of the 2 December 2013 inter-institutional agreement between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, budgetary cooperation and good financial management. In passing, my colleague Eider Gardiazabal Rubial has done an excellent job on this issue.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. — Flexibility allows adapting European tools and budgets to the real needs of institutions, regions and countries. After examination of all possibilities for reallocating commitment appropriations it appears necessary to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument for commitment appropriations; I therefore agree with the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument and amendment of the Commission proposal to finance the additional allocation for the Cypriot Structural Funds programmes.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. — Although I consider cyprus' bailout conditions totally unfair, my favourable vote on this point is based on the need for the mobilization of necessary financial resources for Cyprus.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — The Commission's proposal for the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument, for an amount exceeding the MFF ceilings, in order to complement the financing of the eu general budget for the financial year 2015 with more than EUR 79.8 million in authorising appropriations, for a total amount of EUR 100 million for the financial year 2015 , to be used to complement the financing of the Structural Fund programmes for Cyprus under subheading 1b in 2014 and 2015 for the period 2015-2018. In view of the complementary nature of the Flexibility Instrument, these additional payment appropriations serve to ensure coverage of additional authorisation appropriations for Cyprus on the basis of the expected payment profile. We voted for it.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — The document proposes mobilising the Flexibility Instrument by an amount higher than the MFF ceilings in order to complement the financing of the EU general budget for the financial year 2015 with an additional EUR 79.8 million in authorisation appropriations to be used to complement the financing of structural fund programmes for Cyprus under cohesion. Following this proposal, this report agrees with the mobilisation of this Instrument, amending it to finance the additional allocation of structural fund programmes by a maximum amount of EUR 83.26 million. In view of the complementary nature of the Flexibility Instrument, these additional payment appropriations serve to ensure coverage of additional authorisation appropriations for Cyprus on the basis of the expected payment profile. We voted for it.

name: Clare MOODY
text: Mr President, in October my Labour colleagues and I voted for the EU to do more of what it is good at. Since then, we saw an inspirational example of this when Philae landed on a comet. It has been compared to landing a washing machine on Burnham-on-Sea from 500 million miles away. We have seen significant and welcome progress this year with a reversal of many of the Council’s most destructive cuts – cuts that would have hurt communities, small businesses and centres of research in my region. Unfortunately we have not seen a sufficient reallocation of funding from the CAP or from our monthly visits here to Strasbourg, a beautiful city to visit but not what you would call a good use of time and money. We want to see EU money spent on areas with real added value for our citizens and on projects that fulfil our international responsibilities. I look forward to this budget being put to that good work in 2015.

name: Alessandra MORETTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, despite the adoption of this budget, I believe that we can and must do much more. We refer to the efforts made by the Socialists and Democrats, but the Council has once again remained the object of strength and arrogance only by certain European countries, such as Germany, France and England. However, we have managed to achieve something compared to the commitments that keep alive and significant programmes such as Erasmus and Horizon 2020. However, our commitment to an intelligent and comprehensive reform of the entire budgetary adoption procedure remains a priority.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I voted against the new EU budget for 2015 because it is a budget in the same line as the previous ones. It continues to promote the neoliberal economic policies that have led us to the crisis, insists on memorandums and reform programmes for Member States, instigating privatizations and liberalizations of public services, austerity, cuts and deregulation of industrial relations. Moreover, the amount of this budget has been cut, at a time when public investment would be most necessary to generate jobs and to ensure public services for all European citizens.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — Taxpayers in the United Kingdom will not support yet another increase in membership fees to the European Union. Whilst the compromise may be elegant in terms of avoiding provisional twelfths, the interests of the people are not fully considered.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. — I am satisfied with the general budget deal. Taking into account the really complicated negotiation process and often colliding Council and EP positions, it is extremely important that the budget was finally adopted in a comparably timely manner. Moreover, the increase of EUR 244.2 million in the overall level of commitment appropriations compared to the initial proposition of the Council is a significant achievement which will help to stabilise the current fiscal debt levels. In addition, the bigger part of funds allocated to competitiveness and innovation is a promising sign for steady growth and job creation. I believe this will contribute to the overall Europe 2020 strategy and induce the overall economic performance of the EU.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council on the 2015 budget. I congratulate the Negotiators of the European Parliament on the eur 4.25 billion allocated to the emergency debts of this year's EU budget. The European Commission would be obliged to draw up a step-by-step plan for the reduction of outstanding bills and to establish a sustainable debt ceiling in the future. Thanks to Parliament, eur 0.5 billion will be allocated to commitments. than the COUNCIL of the EU proposed. More funding will be allocated to horizon 2020 and the Erasmus+ programme for student and youth exchange. It is to be welcomed that the increase in funding for European neighbourhood programmes, humanitarian aid and the common foreign security policy has been increased, which is very relevant in the light of today's situation in Europe. However, I do not support the reduction in funding for the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund, which will affect many EU farmers who are in a particularly difficult situation because of the protracted Russian embargo and who need EU assistance.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. As the European Union's unpaid bills pile up, huge budgets continue to be announced. The European Union will not be able to solve the problems faced by its Member States with billions of euros that it takes from them. It is the european Union's guidelines that urgently need to be reviewed rather than new budgets for policies that are doomed to fail.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. — (SV) I voted against the budget. I believe that the EU budget must be significantly cut. In addition, there are major problems in the costly agricultural policy and the regional and structural funds. Resources also go to the militarisation of the EU and fortress Europe, which I cannot support. I would also like to underline fundamental criticism of the entire budgetary process, which is characterised by finality. Summits and all negotiations are conducted without transparency, which confirms the undemocratic nature of the EU.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — After arduous negotiations, and while it is clear that the agreement could be more ambitious, Parliament has succeeded in reversing the Council's cuts as well as increasing the budget in certain areas of particular relevance. As an example, an increase of EUR 45 million has been achieved for heading 1a, in particular for the COSME programme and for Horizon 2020, and EUR 16 million for Erasmus+, as well as an additional 32 million for heading 4 (UNWRA and humanitarian aid). In total, commitment appropriations of EUR 145 321 500 000 and payment appropriations of EUR 141 214 040 563 have been agreed for 2015. In addition, agreement has been reached to reduce the level of unpaid invoices within the current multiannual framework. For all this, I have given my vote in favour.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted against this proposal for amendments because I do not think they are in the interests of the European Parliament.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — (IT) I am voting against, in line with my critical attitude towards this European Union. It's all to be done again!

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — (IT) Every year there is a timely tug-of-war between the positions of the Council and Parliament, but it has nevertheless adopted this year's budget. Forecasts for next year show a short gap of more than $4 billion in addition to the many unpaid bills from last year.

name: Ole CHRISTENSEN
text: Written. — We are categorically opposed to EU funds being used for the relocation of jobs and stress that this is already illegal. We are opposed to subsidies for tobacco production and we are opposed to aid being granted in any way to long journeys of live animals causing animal suffering. We're in favor of greater control if you don't have to. The Union's expenditure and the European Parliament's use of money, as well as an increased level of investment in Europe that benefits growth and jobs in all Member States. That is why we are actively fighting for these matters in our respective committees and for this to be included in relevant legislative texts. The Danish Social Democrats in the European Parliament have been actively working for years to strengthen control and fairness in covering members' general expenses, etc.m. We also actively support renewed and strengthened EU action in relation to the Middle East peace process and see the work of UNRWA as an important part of this process. We therefore choose to support the budgetary compromise which, after great effort, has been achieved between the European Parliament and the Council, and are therefore obliged to settle all the amendments to the budget itself, in that we nevertheless acknowledge that there are still major unresolved problems, not least in terms of the volume of unpaid bills.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) This draft budget avoids the provisional exercise and, above all, gives credit and satisfaction to the Italian Presidency for the difficult balance sought and found. In fact, the difficulty of the negotiations, combined at a time of serious crisis, especially for some States, makes the result achieved extraordinary, in particular with regard to those chapters of expenditure that have had substantial increases (I am referring in particular to COSME).

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — This new Draft Budget 2015 entails a EUR 800 million overall reduction of payment appropriations compared to the Commission’s original Draft Budget. The proposed distribution of payment appropriations in the new Draft Budget 2015 will continue to reduce the backlog of unpaid bills from the past programming period for Cohesion, to address and to successfully launch the new important spending programmes in 2015. It is particularly important that the EUR 20 million increase in the operational expenditure of FRONTEX is offset by a corresponding reduction of the budget item on support of border management. I voted in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — I voted against the new EU budget for 2015 because it is a budget in the same line as the previous ones. It continues to promote the neoliberal economic policies that have led us to the crisis, insists on memorandums and reform programmes for Member States, instigating privatizations and liberalizations of public services, austerity, cuts and deregulation of industrial relations. Moreover, the amount of this budget has been cut, at a time when public investment would be most necessary to generate jobs and to ensure public services for all European citizens.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, since the European Parliament wanted to stabilise the payment crisis and get a concrete payment plan. The European Parliament managed to tackle the payment crisis by pushing for extra money in 2014 for draft amending budgets of 2014 (EUR 3.53 billion), including increases in 2015 and a joint statement on a payment plan.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. — I had been highly critical of the initial draft of the 2015 budget presented by the European Commission because the measures to help farmers following the Russian embargo were then financed by the crisis reserve, made available by the new CAP in the event of an agricultural crisis. However, the difficulties that farmers face today because of the embargo are not the consequences of an agricultural crisis but indeed diplomatic. To use the crisis reserve was to double penalize them, which was unjustified and not acceptable. This proposal was withdrawn in the new draft general budget, which is why I finally supported it.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. — The European Parliament today adopted by a large majority the EU budget for 2015 and the amendments on surplus resources for 2014. The huge advantage of the agreement is that it will be able to pass the EU budget for 2015 later this year, i.e. next year it would not only be possible to pay 12th of this year's budget per month. By 2014, an additional €4 billion will be mobilised, of which EUR 3.5 billion will be the result of so-called 'fresh money', i.e. not transfers. The EP only agreed to the adoption of next year's EU budget on the condition that the European Commission draws up a plan to reduce unpaid bills to sustainable levels. In 2014, €23.4 billion will have to be paid from the previous year. To this end, today's vote provides an additional resource of nearly EUR 4 billion. Today's decision by the European Parliament also provided agricultural and cohesion resources for Hungary in this year's and next year's budgets. The Hungarian People's Party delegation, together with the European People's Party, acted responsibly on behalf of the national interests of Hungary and voted in favour of the 2015 EU budget and all the reports contained in the related agreement. The agreement also includes reports mobilising the Solidarity Fund to mitigate the damage caused by natural disasters affecting different regions of Europe.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted against the draft general budget because it shifts the EU's centre of gravity more towards numbers and economic power than towards its own citizens and meeting their needs.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The EU budget for 2015 will be €145.32 billion in authoritated appropriations and €141.21 billion in payment appropriations. I participated in the hundreds of hours of negotiation that allowed a good agreement with regard to the 2014 budgets, amending budgets and the 2015 budget. This budget allows for the realisation of our growth and employment priorities. This agreement also stabilises the European Union's debt and avoids the collapse of the budget. We have managed to minimise the cuts that the Council has proposed. In addition, we have strengthened our commitments on employment and growth programmes, including research (Horizon 2020), Support for SMEs (COSME) and youth programmes (ERASMUS+). The European Union's external solidarity has also been strengthened with regard to humanitarian aid. In 2015, as we agreed with the Commission and the Council, we must have a plan to deal with invoices that have already been overdue and unpaid. The European Union must apply to itself the same rigour as it asks the Member States and, in addition, must fulfil its commitments, in particular what it has adopted in the multiannual financial framework.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — We have tabled an important set of amendments to the budget. Unfortunately they were sinking (with the votes against the members of the PS, PSD and CDS). Of these proposals we highlight: - Improving the access of MSMEs to finance; - Increased appropriations for the Youth Employment Initiative – advocating the creation of jobs with permanent rights and contracts. - Substantial increase in appropriations for the promotion of social cohesion and mitigation of the most serious forms of poverty in the Union - Member States, with unemployment rates above 10 % and a risk rate of poverty and/or social exclusion above 20 %, would have a funding rate of the operational programme of 100 % of total eligible expenditure. - Increase of EUR 77 million for the milk rubric for schools giving preference to local and/or national products - Pilot project - Creation of shelters for women victims of domestic violence and sexual exploitation. It is regrettable that this budget package once again does not serve the development interests of each Member State, revealing the enormous hypocrisy of those who, announcing a new cycle, insist on the same old guidelines, refusing any kind of solidarity between Member States.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — Shifts the EU's centre of gravity more towards numbers and economic power than towards its own citizens to meet their needs. That is why I am voting against the new general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of the draft budget for 2015 following the intense negotiations of our institution with the Council. This draft budget provides for 145,321.5 million commitment appropriations for 2015 and 141,214.0 million payment appropriations. In particular, I welcome the support for Research programmes and the maintenance of Erasmus for students, as well as the EUR 273.6 million that will be allocated to farmers without touching the agricultural crisis reserve to compensate for the losses incurred as a result of the Russian embargo. It is a great victory to extend solidarity with farmers to all and not just to use the reserve devoted to the agricultural crisis foreseen by the CAP. I insist, however, that a plan to clear payments be found in response to the current crisis, before the Commission proposes a draft budget for 2016. It is now essential to find a new system of own resources to break this impasse.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. — I supported the agreement reached as it will allow the Council's un funded cheque policy to be temporarily alleviated at least for the time being since 2012. We will be able to pay outstanding bills on issues as important as humanitarian aid, which had a hole of 160 million euros.
