But with our vote we have also ensured that the level of payments and commitments for 2015 is equalised, which will stop the spiral of unpaid invoices, which has also been reinforced by an agreement on a payment plan that allows the EU to get out of the situation it is currently in, with more than 23 billion in unpaid invoices. This is the first step, Parliament will remain vigilant in the coming months to ensure that Member States meet their budgetary commitments.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. — The agreement reached will allow the payment of outstanding invoices, for which the amount of EUR 4.8 billion has been agreed for the period 2014-2015. Although it is far from the initial figures, this amount will allow to meet some of the accumulated invoices and thereby alleviate the situation of many SMEs, universities, local communities and NGOs that are currently waiting to be paid.  As important as the 2014 payments figures and the 2015 budget has been to reach agreement between Parliament, Council and Commission on a payment plan that will allow the EU to get out of the situation it is currently in with more than EUR 23 billion in unpaid invoices. With regard to the 2015 budget, we have managed to reverse all Council cuts as well as category 1a increases, which reflect the priority of contributing to improved access to finance through the EU budget, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, in particular for the COSME programme, as well as for the Horizon 2020 and Erasmus+ programmes , and the amount earmarked for humanitarian aid in category 4.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for the new draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015, as I consider it to be balanced and in line with the EU guidelines for the coming year.  At a time of severe financial crisis that Europe is going through, it is important to focus budgetary expenditure on sustainable growth and creating a competitive economy that will be able to stimulate progress and positive growth. It is important to ensure that the budget is able to suffer and successfully deal with any crisis situations. I also support the importance of cohesion policy within the European budget, which certainly plays a major role, and the principle of flexibility when it comes to the structure itself.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. — It is good to have a final agreement on next year’s budget. I am pleased to see further resources allocated to the European Asylum Support Office, which has an ever increasing number of tasks. Although it is concerning that the funds available for humanitarian aid to areas such as South Sudan are not sufficiently reinforced to address what is a potentially devastating malnutrition situation, I am encouraged to see that we have allocated further funds in this year’s budget to help those most in need.  The European Union’s budget can be a useful tool for Member States to boost economic growth and this is a sensible budget for 2015. For this reason I voted in favour.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I voted against an increase in next year’s EU budget. We need to put the principles of added value and efficiency at the heart of budgetary decision-making in Europe. I want to see a real budget reform in the EU with a greater focus on generating growth and jobs, and areas that do not bring any real benefits to our constituents cut.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: Written. — We are categorically opposed to EU funds being used for the relocation of jobs and stress that this is already illegal. We're in favor of greater control if you don't have to. The Union's expenditure and the European Parliament's use of money, as well as an increased level of investment in Europe that benefits growth and jobs in all Member States. That is why we are actively fighting for these matters in our respective committees and for this to be included in relevant legislative texts.  The Danish Social Democrats in the European Parliament have been actively working for years to strengthen control and fairness in covering members' general expenses, etc.m. We also actively support renewed and strengthened EU action in relation to the Middle East peace process and see the work of UNRWA as an important part of this process. We therefore choose to support the budgetary compromise which, after great effort, has been achieved between the European Parliament and the Council, and are therefore obliged to settle all the amendments to the budget itself, in that we nevertheless acknowledge that there are still major unresolved problems, not least in terms of the volume of unpaid bills.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. " I voted in favour of the draft budget for 2015, the result of long negotiations with the Member States. $145.3 billion in commitment appropriations, $141.2 billion in payment appropriations was validated, $2.2 billion more than the final payments in the 2014 budget. Also, an additional EUR 4.25 billion was granted by Member States to pay unpaid bills in 2014. I also approved the arrows that were decided. For example, an additional EUR 45 million will be allocated for the Horizon 2020 research and development programme and an additional EUR 16 million for the Erasmus student programme, which, I recall, must benefit new profiles, such as apprentices or young entrepreneurs.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — I voted against the new EU budget for 2015 because it is a budget in the same line as the previous ones. It continues to promote the neoliberal economic policies that have led us to the crisis, insists on memorandums and reform programmes for Member States, instigating privatizations and liberalizations of public services, austerity, cuts and deregulation of industrial relations. Moreover, the amount of this budget has been cut, at a time when public investment would be most necessary to generate jobs and to ensure public services for all European citizens.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - I voted in favour of the 2015 budget. In the context of this vote, I wanted to stress the need to maintain and even increase spending on key EU programmes such as Erasmus+ and Horizon 2020. It is also necessary to comply with the political declarations concerning support for these programmes and to secure funds for their implementation. In particular, I am concerned that, despite the difficulties in guaranteeing payments for Horizon 2020, eur 2.7 billion is planned to be transferred from this programme to the implementation of the new investment plan. I believe that these two initiatives are extremely important for improving the Union's competitiveness and should be complementary to each other. However, given the different way in which they are implemented, they should be provided with independent sources of funding.  Finally, I would point out that the budget must reflect the real need to cover certain actions and programmes, otherwise we will never deal with unpaid commitments and we will have to constantly adopt amending budgets.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. - It's good that we're finishing the year with the new 2015 budget. I supported this decision. Economic growth is planned for next year. I voted in favour.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I voted against the 'New draft general budget of the European Union - financial year 2015', because it is a budget that supports the Brussels bureaucracy.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — Since some of the factors in the amending budget may well seem positive, such as amending budgets Nos 4, 6 and 8, it might be considered that the drafts should be approved as a whole. However, the fact that the overall budget is still far too high to be able to finance it sensibly and, above all, sustainably over the next few years, weighs more heavily and I reject it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the European Union budget for 2015, which includes more funding for the Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme, the Erasmus+ student exchange programme and foreign policy, among other areas. This budget will have EUR 145.3 million in authoritato appropriations and EUR 141.2 billion in payment appropriations. The European Parliament's priority during negotiations with the Council was to ensure that unpaid invoices are paid to companies, local authorities and other beneficiaries of European funds. An additional €4 billion has been achieved to pay outstanding invoices in 2014 through an amending budget. The European institutions have also been able to commit to drawing up a plan to bring the value of outstanding invoices down to sustainable levels by 2016, as by the end of this year it is estimated that the amount will be around EUR 23 billion. It turns out to be a good deal after difficult negotiations.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of the adoption of the 2015 budget and would like to thank the rapporteurs for all their work in securing an agreement that improves significantly the Council’s initial position and prevents the collapse of the EU budget 2015. This is an instrument to promote growth and jobs and is one that I support.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I am in agreement with the new general budget report of the European Union for the financial year 2015. I have voted in favour of Amendment 21, which insists on increasing the level of commitment appropriations to EUR 300 million in order to provide sufficient resources to ease the dramatic humanitarian situation and to support the efforts of reconstruction in the Gaza strip.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. On the agenda of this budget are 10 priorities, including boosting jobs, growth and investment, connecting the digital single market, combating global warming, securing Europe's borders,... The EU, which claims to boost investment through its 2015 budget, should instead start by withdrawing its directive on seconded workers, which has led to unfair competition in the labour market, particularly in France! And what about unpaid bills, which accumulate and account for almost 20% of revenue! The EU today announced that it had provided some room for manoeuvre? But who's going to clear this debt that doesn't say his name? The lessons of fiscal morality, which are assailed by Brussels to the Member States, are completely indecent.... To this must be added the 220 billion RAL (commitments that have yet to be liquidated) which far exceed the payment appropriations mobilized. How will the EU deal with this situation? Mr LAMASSOURE said at the last Committee on Budgets that he chaired that the situation at the end of June 2014 was much worse than the one he had inherited five years earlier. It is likely that Mr. ARTHUIS will say the same thing in 2019. I voted against it.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — The amount of missing payments is increasing year on year and about thirty million unpaid invoices are being carried forward to 2015. I therefore welcome the 2015 budget proposal adopted following the trilogue because the European Union has been given an extension to answer this question. I am also in favour of increasing the EU budget for 2015, although it does not allow the Union's institutions and agencies to function optimally. As such, the European Parliament should remain vigilant and urge the Council to respect the multi-year budget framework.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. — All 16 of these amendments were to raise the budget of the European Union, and consequently increase the contributions required by Member States.  I therefore voted against these amendments, as well as the budget overall.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — After arduous negotiations, Parliament has succeeded in reversing the Council's cuts, as well as increasing the budget in certain areas of particular relevance. As an example, an increase of EUR 45 million has been achieved for heading 1a, in particular for the COSME programme and for Horizon 2020, and EUR 16 million for Erasmus+, as well as an additional 32 million for heading 4 (UNWRA and humanitarian aid). In total, commitment appropriations of EUR 145 321 500 000 and payment appropriations of EUR 141 214 040 563 have been agreed for 2015. In addition, agreement has been reached to reduce the level of unpaid invoices within the current multiannual framework. For all this, I have given my vote in favour.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — The European Parliament approved by a very large majority the European Union budget for 2015 and the bailout of the 2014 budget. The 2015 budget will now amount to EUR 145.3 billion in commitment appropriations and EUR 141.2 billion in payment appropriations (it should be noted that the overall level of commitment appropriations is 1.6% higher than the 2014 budget and 1.2 billion above the Council's original position). I am also particularly pleased with the addition of $95 million for Horizon 2020, COSME, ERASMUS and humanitarian aid, and I also welcome the fact that, thanks to the new revenue allocated in the Common Agricultural Policy, a solution has been found to finance emergency measures of up to EUR 273.6 million in response to the Russian embargo on food imports, without immediately mobilising the reserve for crises in the agricultural sector. However, it should be noted that if the Commission is thus allowed to meet the most urgent payment needs in 2014, the level of additional payment credits in the 2014 budget will not be enough to stop the recurring snowball effect of unpaid bills in 2015.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. — We are categorically opposed to EU funds being used for the relocation of jobs and stress that this is already illegal. We are opposed to subsidies for tobacco production and we are opposed to aid being granted in any way to long journeys of live animals causing animal suffering. We're in favor of greater control if you don't have to. The Union's expenditure and the European Parliament's use of money, as well as an increased level of investment in Europe that benefits growth and jobs in all Member States. That is why we are actively fighting for these matters in our respective committees and for this to be included in relevant legislative texts. The Danish Social Democrats in the European Parliament have been actively working for years to strengthen control and fairness in covering members' general expenses, etc.m. We also actively support renewed and strengthened EU action in relation to the Middle East peace process and see the work of UNRWA as an important part of this process. We therefore choose to support the budgetary compromise which, after great effort, has been achieved between the European Parliament and the Council, and are therefore obliged to settle all the amendments to the budget itself, in that we nevertheless acknowledge that there are still major unresolved problems, not least in terms of the volume of unpaid bills.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted against the new EU budget for 2015 because it is a budget in the same line as the previous ones. It continues to promote the neoliberal economic policies that have led us to the crisis, insists on memorandums and reform programmes for Member States, instigating privatizations and liberalizations of public services, austerity, cuts and deregulation of industrial relations. Moreover, the amount of this budget has been cut, at a time when public investment would be most necessary to generate jobs and to ensure public services for all European citizens.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — Today I voted against the general budget for the European Union for the 2015 financial year. We will always argue for maximum restraint on the EU budget. I could not support the final general budget for 2015, as it is a real-terms rise on the 2014 budget and it is still too high. According to the draft package, the overall level of commitment appropriations in the 2015 budget is set at EUR 145 321.5 million while the payment appropriations total comes to an additional EUR 3 529.6 million.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — The European Union budget for 2015 was unable to conclude by 17 November. A new draft needed to be issued, as negotiations between the European Parliament and the Council were not easy. I support a new budget proposal that tries to resolve unpaid bills and, as soon as possible, eradicate any problems that have arisen. This budget concerns not only companies, students or NGOs, it concerns all citizens of the European Union. The new budget contributes to the growth and creation of new jobs that are of utmost importance for all Member States, including Croatia.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — Shifts the EU's centre of gravity more towards numbers and economic power than towards its own citizens to meet their needs.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — According to the provisions of the treaties, draft amendments must, in order to be adopted, receive the votes of the majority of MEPs who make up the European Parliament. On the advice of my colleagues in the BUDG Commission, I voted in favour of: - the draft amendments to the appropriations of Section III of the draft general budget 2015 with regard to the Commission; - the draft amendments to Sections I, II, IV, V, VI, VII, VIII, IX and X of the draft General Budget 2015 with regard to the European Parliament, the Council, the Court of Justice, the Court of Auditors, the Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions, the European Ombudsman, the European Data Protection Supervisor and the European External Action Service.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — What is at stake here is the adoption of draft amending budgets 2014, the Union budget for the financial year 2015, set at a level of EUR 145 321.5 million and EUR 141 214.0 million respectively in commitment and payment appropriations, as well as six joint declarations and three unilateral declarations. Once again, we have not provided the budget with sufficient budgetary resources to be able to meet the need to relaunch the economy, as well as the objectives of social and territorial cohesion. It should be stressed that this budget falls short of the MFF ceiling on most headings. We find it regrettable that this budget does not use the full amount of additional revenue stemming from fines to cover outstanding payment needs, in the framework where debt is already close to EUR 25 billion and at a time when we already know that in 2015 this debt will increase, given the misadjustment between commitment and payment appropriations. In short, this budget package does not serve the interests of the EU and shows a great hypocrisy of those who defend Europe more, while refusing any kind of solidarity between Member States.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — (DE) I have rejected the new general budget of the European Union because it is nothing more than a mixture of further debt and its commitment of funds which, in principle, do not contribute to the preservation of the Union or are not sustainable. It would be desirable to finally get a sustainable and, above all, more efficient strategy on the table with regard to the general budget. However, this is again not the case.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the EU budget for 2015 because it fundamentally prevents the Union from having to function for twelfths, even though the Council continues to resist the will of the Commission and Parliament to boost economic and social recovery in Europe. The Budget provides for payments of €141.2 billion and commitments of €145.3 billion. The expected payments include additional amounts compared to what originally planned for Horizon 2020 and erasmus. The agreement reached, which allowed the budget to be approved, also includes the immediate allocation of EUR 3.5 billion for late payments, in particular to SMEs, local authorities and universities, and the Council's commitment to present a solution to the accumulated payment deficit not covered by this additional tranche.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — What is at stake here is the adoption of draft amending budgets 2014, the Union budget for the financial year 2015, set at a level of EUR 145 321.5 million and EUR 141 214.0 million respectively in commitment and payment appropriations, as well as six joint declarations and three unilateral declarations. Once again, we see that the budget has not been endowed with sufficient budgetary resources to be able to meet the need for a recovery of the economy as well as the objectives of social and territorial cohesion. It should be stressed that this budget falls short of the MFF ceiling in most rubrics. We find it regrettable that this budget does not use the full amount of additional revenue stemming from fines to cover outstanding payment needs, in the framework where the debt is already close to EUR 25 billion and at a time when we already know that in 2015 this debt will increase given the misadjustment between commitment and payment appropriations.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, although I believe that Europe must do more, I nevertheless voted in favour of this report because the increase in the commitments to allocate appropriations compared with the previous budget certainly allows more resources to be allocated. although lower than would be appropriate, to some of the priority areas of the Europe 2020 strategy, which has as its ultimate goal growth and employment. Increasing the funds for projects such as Horizon 2020 and Erasmus+, as well as intervening in favour of the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises, means investing for the future of the Union and its citizens, in particular by stepping up the fight against unemployment, the rate of which is still very high, as shown above all by the data on youth unemployment, especially in some regions. Finally, I also welcome Parliament's efforts with regard to the 2014 amending budgets, in order to ensure greater continuity in the Union's action and to meet extraordinary needs, such as those arising from the flood in Sardinia, in respect of which the EUR 16 million has been allocated.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: On behalf of the representatives of the Jobbik Movement for Hungary, we had no choice but to vote 'no' to the European Union budget for 2015. This budget reflects the same neoliberal economic principles as it has done so far. You, the majority, have repeatedly rejected the amendments that sought to change this perception, but at the same time the seven-year framework itself is decisive. For the first time in real terms, the seven-year budget has been reduced by 4.5%, with 8.4% of cohesion funds in particular. This means that the gap between the so-called centre countries and the periphery will widen even further. You are saying very nice words about a united Europe catching up in terms of living standards and economy, but the figures show otherwise.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Mr. President, the agreement on the 2015 budget was reached in the mediation process and I supported it because it was important to ensure the implementation of the programme and payments since the beginning of the year.  The 2015 budget still does not solve the problem of unpaid bills, and I expect all institutions to engage more concretely in resolving this pressing issue. The payments were approved at €141.2 billion, a significant reduction on Parliament's proposal, which was €146.4 billion. Some of the difference was offset by an increase in payments in the 2014 budget, however we must be aware that this is not enough. Unpaid commitments have been growing since 2010 and it is time to revise the EU budget governance process.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: Mr President, year after year some Member States seem to pay far more attention – indeed exclusive attention – to the level of spending in the European Union budget, and ignore the content. I believe the two are intricately linked and we should do better to look more at the content. If we can use the European budget for those items of spending where, by spending at European level, you save money at national level by avoiding duplication or by economies of scale, then there would be far more consensus about the usefulness of the Union’s budget. In that respect, I think the growth in recent years of the research and development part of the budget, which is a manifest case of pooling resources to get a better result, to get a ‘bigger bang for your buck’ as the Americans say, is a good example and needs to be quoted much more often in domestic debates, not least in my own country.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: Mr President, I voted in favour of the 2015 budget and, like many in this Parliament, of course I would prefer a bigger budget but we have to remember it is taxpayers’ money. I voted against Amendment 4, which asked to at least double the current amounts. This is to be achieved by raising the contributions of those Member States with the highest GNI or GDP. But Ireland, a country which is burdened by debt, has the sixth highest in the EU of 28. We simply could not afford to increase our contributions to the budget so we have to be careful what we are asking for here. I also voted against Amendment 5 because, while we do need to do more to support Member States, we already do so through cohesion and CAP funds, the Social Fund and Horizon 2020. That is all we can do on the budget, unless of course we decrease the amount in some of those funds. I think, as many speakers have said, we need to look at how well we spend our money, how efficiently we spend our money, instead of constantly asking citizens for more. Very often, and indeed in nearly all cases, citizens cannot afford it.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. — The agreement reached will allow the payment of outstanding invoices, for which the amount of EUR 4.8 billion has been agreed for the period 2014-2015. Although it is far from the initial figures, this amount will allow to meet some of the accumulated invoices and thereby alleviate the situation of many SMEs, universities, local communities and NGOs that are currently waiting to be paid.  As important as the 2014 payments figures and the 2015 budget has been to reach agreement between Parliament, Council and Commission on a payment plan that will allow the EU to get out of the situation it is currently in with more than EUR 23 billion in unpaid invoices. With regard to the 2015 budget, we have managed to reverse all Council cuts as well as category 1a increases, which reflect the priority of contributing to improved access to finance through the EU budget, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, in particular for the COSME programme, as well as for the Horizon 2020 and Erasmus+ programmes , and the amount earmarked for humanitarian aid in category 4.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I voted against the new EU budget for 2015 because it is a budget in the same line as the previous ones. It continues to promote the neoliberal economic policies that have led us to the crisis, insists on memorandums and reform programmes for Member States, instigating privatizations and liberalizations of public services, austerity, cuts and deregulation of industrial relations. Moreover, the amount of this budget has been cut, at a time when public investment would be most necessary to generate jobs and to ensure public services for all European citizens.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. — The European Union's budget determines its revenue and expenditure and is decided each year by Parliament and the Council on a proposal from the Commission. Around 90% of the money goes back to the Member States, mainly in the form of regional support and payments to farmers.  For 2015, the compromise previously negotiated with the Council includes expenditure of EUR 141.21 billion and supplementary budgets of EUR 4.25 billion to further finance the projects already decided in 2014. I particularly welcome the fact that this budget, which was adopted with prudence and responsibility in times of tight coffers, provides, among other things, additional funds for small and medium-sized enterprises, as well as for education programmes and humanitarian aid. Fortunately, the fact that the 2015 EU budget is now in place also means that the new year does not have to be started with an emergency budget and that the new programmes can therefore start as planned.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — I do not support this budget, for the reasons outlined in my previous explanation of vote. I opposed all of the amendments for increasing funding, which appear to have been more political posturing than anything else.  The textual amendments were varied, but I deplore in particular the rejection of the amendments which would have required greater transparency from MEPs. Finally, I note that Amendment 30 was ruled inadmissible. I disagree; it was a textual matter.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. — The agreement reached will allow the payment of outstanding invoices, for which the amount of EUR 4.8 billion has been agreed for the period 2014-2015. Although it is far from the initial figures, this amount will allow to meet some of the accumulated invoices and thereby alleviate the situation of many SMEs, universities, local communities and NGOs that are currently waiting to be paid.  As important as the 2014 payments figures and the 2015 budget has been to reach agreement between Parliament, Council and Commission on a payment plan that will allow the EU to get out of the situation it is currently in with more than EUR 23 billion in unpaid invoices. With regard to the 2015 budget, we have managed to reverse all Council cuts as well as category 1a increases, which reflect the priority of contributing to improved access to finance through the EU budget, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, in particular for the COSME programme, as well as for the Horizon 2020 and Erasmus+ programmes , and the amount earmarked for humanitarian aid in category 4.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council on the 2015 budget. I congratulate the Negotiators of the European Parliament on the eur 4.25 billion allocated to the emergency debts of this year's EU budget. The European Commission would be obliged to draw up a step-by-step plan for the reduction of outstanding bills and to establish a sustainable debt ceiling in the future. Thanks to Parliament, eur 0.5 billion will be allocated to commitments. than the COUNCIL of the EU proposed. More funding will be allocated to horizon 2020 and the Erasmus+ programme for student and youth exchange. It is to be welcomed that the increase in funding for European neighbourhood programmes, humanitarian aid and the common foreign security policy has been increased, which is very relevant in the light of today's situation in Europe. However, I do not support the reduction in funding for the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund, which will affect many EU farmers who are in a particularly difficult situation because of the protracted Russian embargo and who need EU assistance.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. — I approved the 2015 draft budget. It includes, it should be noted, increases in funding for European youth exchange programmes (Erasmus), research and innovation (Horizon 2020), humanitarian aid and aid to refugees. Similarly, an additional $4.7 billion in means of payment was released to somewhat address the backlog of payments. Unfortunately, this will not be enough to solve the EU's payments crisis. In this regard, the Commission and the Member States have committed to presenting a plan in the spring to clean up unpaid bills. We will have to be very careful about that.

name: Bas BELDER
text: Written. — Member States have moderated the increase in the EU budget for 2015. Quite rightly, but the agreement still includes an increase of over 1.8% compared to the 2014 budget, far above low inflation. I cannot therefore support the budget. The negotiations were dominated by arrears. This is necessary to deal with this. Companies, research institutes and other beneficiaries must not fall victim to the EU's poor budgeting. Europe promises more than it can deliver. It plans too many financial obligations each year, which means that payments, with more realism, have to be left behind, resulting in a shortage of money when it comes to cashing out. Only a reduction in financial obligations would really solve the problem of arrears. However, the European Parliament wants to set and pay more every year. So it has a great responsibility in this. The European Parliament itself is responsible for making unrealistic financial commitments that are not paid out. If you want the bottom of the can, you get the lid on the nose. Parliament has not learned from this this year, which means that the budget will increase again next year!

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This new draft EU general budget for 2015 sets EUR 145.3215 billion in commitment appropriations and EUR 141.214 billion in payment credits. This will help to meet the most urgent payment needs in 2014 but the level of additional payment credits in the 2014 budget will not be enough to stop the recurring "snowball" effect of unpaid bills in 2015 which remain a very important problem. European technocratic policies are therefore good at criticising the Member States and demanding ever more austerity when the EU itself is unable to pay its own bills and has a considerable debt (more than EUR 220 billion of commitments remaining to be liquidated). So I voted against this budget.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) In line with my critical attitude towards this European Union, my final vote on the measure is clearly against it.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. — (SV) I voted against the budget. I believe that the EU budget must be significantly cut. In addition, there are major problems in the costly agricultural policy and the regional and structural funds. Resources also go to the militarisation of the EU and fortress Europe, which I cannot support. I would also like to underline fundamental criticism of the entire budgetary process, which is characterised by finality. Summits and all negotiations are conducted without transparency, which confirms the undemocratic nature of the EU.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — After arduous negotiations, and while it is clear that the agreement could be more ambitious, Parliament has succeeded in reversing the Council's cuts as well as increasing the budget in certain areas of particular relevance. As an example, an increase of EUR 45 million has been achieved for heading 1a, in particular for the COSME programme and for Horizon 2020, and EUR 16 million for Erasmus+, as well as an additional 32 million for heading 4 (UNWRA and humanitarian aid). In total, commitment appropriations of EUR 145 321 500 000 and payment appropriations of EUR 141 214 040 563 have been agreed for 2015. In addition, agreement has been reached to reduce the level of unpaid invoices within the current multiannual framework. For all this, I have given my vote in favour.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. — At the October part-session, Parliament expressed its priorities on the draft EU general budget for 2015. Conciliation with the Council in recent months has not been easy, as my colleagues in the Committee on Budgets have told us. Finally, agreement was reached on the 2014 amending budgets and the 2015 budget before the end of the year, so as to avoid going into provisional operation. I am voting in favour and I welcome the fact that the appropriations for research (Horizon 2020), the programmes for the competitiveness of SMEs (Cosme), education (Erasmus), cohesion and Frontex have been safeguarded and increased. Also welcome is the agreement for 2014, which accepted the proposal to increase appropriations by 3.529 billion and to adopt amending budgets to provide aid to countries affected by major natural disasters. In this chapter I express my appreciation for the 16 million that will be allocated to Italy for the flood in Sardinia in November 2013. Finally, the statement in which the three institutions undertake to implement a plan to reduce the level of unpaid invoices is encouraging: a plan to be agreed in good time and in any case before the presentation of the draft budget for 2016.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted against because I do not think this proposal from the Council is in the interest of the Union.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — The European Union is facing unpaid debts amounting to almost 30 billion euros. However, Parliament is using debt relief to demand an increase in the general budget, which the Council is right to oppose. In times of payment crisis, the copying should be completely reviewed and the financing of budget lines that replace the international sovereignty of Member States should be stopped. For example, the following budget lines should be called into question: - EUR 286 million to the Peace Process in Palestine; - EUR 882 million for humanitarian aid; - EUR 2,784,852 for the promotion of companies that integrate all, innovative and capable of reflection. The European Union budget is a real gas plant, which is why I voted against this report.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. — The agreement reached will allow the payment of outstanding invoices, for which the amount of EUR 4.8 billion has been agreed for the period 2014-2015.  With regard to the 2015 budget, the Council and Parliament agreed a total of EUR 145 321 500 000 in commitments and EUR 141 214 040 563 in payments.  In addition, the three institutions have agreed on a payment plan aimed at reducing the level of unpaid invoices within the current multiannual framework.  Following the failure of conciliation, the Commission presented a new draft budget for 2015 on 28 November.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. — The European budget for 2015 has finally been voted on. The European Parliament has succeeded in making its voice heard in the face of a Council that is reluctant to make any concessions. MEPs have released an additional EUR 4 billion to settle unpaid debts in previous years. However, let us remember that there are still 23 billion unpaid. This is a considerable amount of money that we need to put in place the Union's policies. I voted in favour of this budget. I particularly welcome the involvement of my fellow EPP MEPs who have succeeded in implementing the group's priorities.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — The 2015 budget provides for EUR 145.32 billion in commitments and EUR 141.21 billion in payments, as well as an extra €4.25 billion earmarked for the balance of unpaid invoices in 2014. The European Parliament has taken seriousness with a 2015 budget that allows the EU to pay off all its debts and that respects Europe's commitments to growth and employment policies. The funds that the Council has cut for research and development programmes, such as Horizon 2020, for aid to small and medium-sized enterprises through the Cosme programme, for education, including the Erasmus+ student mobility programme, and for aid to the most disadvantaged, have been restored. I regret, however, that, once again, the Council has not been prepared to support its political statements with sufficient budgetary resources as regards support for growth and employment. The Council no longer seems to have any priorities and seems to be solely interested in limiting member states' commitments as much as possible.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — The EU budget is not managed responsibly: payment commitments are increased each year. It should be remembered that the European Union already has 20 billion backlog still to be adjusted. No wonder citizens have little faith in the European institutions when their functioning is handled so irresponsibly.

name: Ole CHRISTENSEN
text: Written. — (DA) We support the budget that has been concluded, recognising the urgent need to have the EU budget adopted before the end of the year, otherwise a rigid and bureaucratic emergency budget would be activated. However, it remains our position that the European Union must show financial responsibility at this time and, as far as possible, prioritise these efforts within the existing framework. The Danish Social Democrats in the European Parliament have been actively working for years to strengthen control and fairness in relation to the general expenditure of Members, etc.m. We do not agree with the specific wording, but we want to send a clear signal that current practice can and must be improved. We also actively support renewed and strengthened EU action in relation to the Middle East peace process and see the work of UNRWA as an important part of this process, but we will not, in a non-legislative text, set ourselves a lump sum.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) This general budget, for which I voted in favour, gives us an important political fact: parliament's role is essential if it is not only the interest of the Member States to guide decisions. It was this House that fulfilled the meritorio task of representing the citizens, demanding that beyond the numbers there should be services and policies geared to those who, day by day, create the wealth that the European institutions help to redistribute. Congratulations to the negotiators, especially those of the European Parliament.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - The agreement reached on the 2015 general budget is certainly positive for having prevented the twelfths regime, which would have led to a scenario that would have been harmful to say the least. But the great difficulties in achieving this result are once again spurring us to move towards a reform of the EU's own resources system. This would guarantee the Financial Autonomy of the Union and allow us to make the whole system more efficient and focused on the objectives to be achieved, without suffering national reserves, which are currently too dependent on limited public resources. I voted in favour of the budget, not least because it safeguarded resources for research (Horizon 2020), programmes for the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises (Cosme), education (Erasmus), cohesion and Frontex.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — A compromise on the EU budget for 2015 was agreed by the Council on 9 December this year. I think that this agreement safeguards the EU’s credibility and allows us to stabilise the EU debt. The consequences of non-agreement on the budget would result in detrimental effects on the implementation of key policies and programmes and would send a damaging message to the citizens of Europe at a time of economic uncertainty, so I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — In the "draft package" agreed, following difficult negotiations, by the representatives of Parliament and the Council in the trialogue of 8 December 2014, it is noted that more attention has been paid to the gap observed over the other years between the resources committed and the resources allocated to payments, causing a backlog of payments and a proliferation of unpaid invoices. I voted against because I believe it is necessary to resolve previous debts and then plan the future seriously. I am not opposed to the Community budget a priori, but the approach adopted is certainly not sustainable.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — I voted against the new EU budget for 2015 because it is a budget in the same line as the previous ones. It continues to promote the neoliberal economic policies that have led us to the crisis, insists on memorandums and reform programmes for Member States, instigating privatizations and liberalizations of public services, austerity, cuts and deregulation of industrial relations. Moreover, the amount of this budget has been cut, at a time when public investment would be most necessary to generate jobs and to ensure public services for all European citizens.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, since the European Parliament wanted to stabilise the payment crisis and get a concrete payment plan. The European Parliament managed to tackle this payment crisis by pushing for extra money in 2014 for draft amending budgets of 2014 (EUR 3.53 billion), including increases in 2015 and a joint statement on a payment plan.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. While it is to be welcomed that the budget for 2015 could have been voted on on time, I would also like to stress, like my fellow MEPs, that a plan to clear payments must be found in response to the current crisis. Faced with the accumulation of unpaid bills since 2010, it seems crucial to find a new system of own resources. Finally, it is regrettable that all the revenues related to fines have not been donated to the EU budget.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: in writing. - I have voted in favour of the new general budget for the financial year 2015 because I believe a good balance has been achieved. From the outset of these negotiations, I was convinced we should not be making savings in the strategic sectors of heading 1A that are need to create jobs and growth. These issues deal with R&D, competitiveness, the Connecting Europe Facility and supporting measure for SMEs. The agreement reached is a significant improvement to the start of the negotiations, and since the sectors outlined above are largely being safeguarded I can give my consent to this text.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. — The European Parliament today adopted by a large majority the EU budget for 2015 and the amendments on surplus resources for 2014. The huge advantage of the agreement is that it will be able to pass the EU budget for 2015 later this year, i.e. next year it would not only be possible to pay 12th of this year's budget per month. By 2014, an additional €4 billion will be mobilised, of which EUR 3.5 billion will be the result of so-called 'fresh money', i.e. not transfers.  The EP only agreed to the adoption of next year's EU budget on the condition that the European Commission draws up a plan to reduce unpaid bills to sustainable levels. In 2014, €23.4 billion will have to be paid from the previous year.  To this end, today's vote provides an additional resource of nearly EUR 4 billion. Today's decision by the European Parliament also provided agricultural and cohesion resources for Hungary in this year's and next year's budgets. The Hungarian People's Party delegation, together with the European People's Party, acted responsibly on behalf of the national interests of Hungary and voted in favour of the 2015 EU budget and all the reports contained in the related agreement. The agreement also includes reports mobilising the Solidarity Fund to mitigate the damage caused by natural disasters affecting different regions of Europe.

name: Anneliese DODDS
text: in writing. — I voted today against an overall EU budget which failed to include sufficient reallocation of funds away from unreformed areas like the CAP and Strasbourg sessions. When working people, pensioners and the unemployed are under more financial pressure than ever, the EU budget must be prudent and reduce spending which is not targeted at producing sustainable growth and jobs.  Equally, we must use European funds to develop the technologies of the future. So today I also voted to protect EU research funding. The EU research budget has been particularly productive in the UK. The UK has received EUR 4.8 billion over the last 7 years from the EU research budget – more per capita than any country except the Netherlands. In the South-East of England, EU research funds and European partnerships have produced ground-breaking research, such as the Culham Centre for Fusion Energy which is exploring how to deliver carbon-free energy, and the University of Kent’s INTERLINK project to improve long-term care for older people.  It is disappointing that the UK Government failed to support proposed rises in EU research funding in the Council, whilst equally failing to secure a more prudent approach in relation to areas like the CAP.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted against the report, as it shifts the EU's centre of gravity more towards numbers and economic power than towards its own citizens and meeting their needs.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the adoption of the EU budget for 2015. Today's decision by the European Parliament fully secured the agricultural and cohesion resources due to Hungary from this year's and next year's EU budgets. If this had not been achieved, only one twelfth of this year's budget could have been paid monthly next year. This would not have made it possible to pay 100% of the aid, which would have damaged the Hungarian national interest. This budget is also important for Hungarian farmers. On the one hand, we have managed to protect agricultural resources for next year. We have succeeded in preventing the cuts proposed by the Council (e.g. beekeeping and oenological aid and the financing of the operational funds of producer organisations). On the other hand, we have been able to prevent the withdrawal of funds from funds for agricultural crises. Therefore, area payments will not be reduced next year. It is therefore a success that we have teamed up with Tamás Deutsch and Sándor Fazekas, Minister of Agriculture, to protect the direct payments that are important to Hungarian farmers.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. - (C) Supported the agreement reached between the Council of Ministers and the European Parliament on a package solution for the 2015 budget and the 2014 supplementary budgets. This is because the agreed budget is sufficient to resolve the emergency situation with regard to the unpaid bills resulting from the reluctance of the Member States to live up to their own promises. In addition, the agreement increases efforts in what we believe Europe and the world need, such as investment in growth and job creation and humanitarian aid. However, we have voted against the further increases in the budget not covered by the agreement.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The iron arm between the EP and the Council in relation to the 2015 budget resulted from the approach to be taken in relation to invoices already overdue and unpaid. In 2013, more than 23 billion invoices were left unpaid and the amount of 2014 will be higher. These unpaid people harm SMEs, students, researchers, national and local authorities. Parliament wants to pay what is due and at least stabilise this debt so that the budget does not collapse. At the same time, it is intended that funds and programmes for the period 2014-2020 will start without further delay. In 2014, around 5 billion extraordinary revenues from the EU budget were on the table, mainly resulting from fines. What would be normal is that this extraordinary revenue was to repay the debt. The Council wanted to take this EUR 5 billion and put them in national budgets. Furthermore, the Council, in relation to the 2015 budget, wanted to reduce commitments and cut payments by around EUR 2100 million. In the end, we were able to mobilise €3.6 billion of the estimated €5 billion in extraordinary revenues in 2014, which allows debt to be stabilised and the budget to collapse. In addition, we have strengthened the funding allocated for commitments to programmes for growth and jobs, including research (Horizon 2020), Support for SMEs (COSME) and youth programmes (ERASMUS+). The EU budget for 2015 will thus be EUR 145.32 billion in authoritato appropriations and EUR 141.21 billion in payment appropriations.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. — I would like to stress that, despite the difficulties that Member States have shown throughout the budget negotiation and their lack of commitment to the Community budget, thanks to the excellent work of rapporteur Eider Gardiazabal, certain achievements have been achieved. In particular, all Council cuts have been reversed and increases have been achieved in subheading 1a, to reflect the priority of contributing to improving access to finance through the EU budget, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), and heading 4. In addition, an increase of 45 million has also been agreed for subheading 1a, in particular for the COSME programme and for Horizon 2020 (CIS and Marie Curie), of EUR 16 million for Erasmus+, as well as an additional 32 million for heading 4 (UNRWA and Humanitarian Aid).

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — A budget mirrors a set of policy options. In this case, the EU budget is the main instrument for carrying forward EU policies and guidelines. We strongly disagree with each other. We also disagree with the budget that is used to implement them. Unsurprisingly, we voted against it. Among the most serious aspects, we highlight the strengthening of Frontex, Europol, the External Action Service, withdrawing funding from the Youth Employment Initiative, progress (employment), direct payments from the Common Agricultural Policy and international agreements, the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund. Once again, the budget with sufficient budgetary resources has not been endowed to be able to respond to the consequences of the economic and social crisis, as well as to the objectives of economic, social and territorial cohesion. It should be stressed that this budget still falls short of the ceiling foreseen in the Multiannual Financial Framework (2014-2020) for this year. It is regrettable that the budget does not use the full amount of additional revenue stemming from fines to cover outstanding payment needs, in a framework where the debt already amounts to close to EUR 25 billion. Debt that will increase given the misadjustment between commitment and payment appropriations.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing — The difficult negotiations of the European Parliament and of the Council of 8 December 2014, which preceded the draft package, created scope for a very fragile compromise. Therefore, the adoption of a joint declaration on the payment plan is necessary, as there are reasonable concerns that the level of payment appropriations will not be sufficient, thus creating a recurring effect of the increase in outstanding accounts. In this context, however, I support the joint commitment of the European Parliament, the Council and the European Commission, which is set out in the joint declaration on the payment plan and is a commitment to reduce the level of the accounts in question. It is regrettable that once again the Council has not been willing to supplement its political declarations with sufficient budgetary resources in terms of promoting jobs and growth, and is only interested in horizontal expenditure restraint in this context. It is essential to create resources for the European Union's pro-growth policies, which will lead to an improvement in the social situation of the populations of the Member States.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — Shifts the EU's centre of gravity more towards numbers and economic power than towards its own citizens to meet their needs, which is why I am voting against the report on the Council's position on the New Draft General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. — The agreement reached will allow the payment of outstanding invoices, for which the amount of EUR 4.8 billion has been agreed for the period 2014-2015. Although it is far from the initial figures, this amount will allow to meet some of the accumulated invoices and thereby alleviate the situation of many SMEs, universities, local communities and NGOs that are currently waiting to be paid.  As important as the 2014 payments figures and the 2015 budget has been to reach agreement between Parliament, Council and Commission on a payment plan that will allow the EU to get out of the situation it is currently in with more than EUR 23 billion in unpaid invoices. With regard to the 2015 budget, we have managed to reverse all Council cuts as well as category 1a increases, which reflect the priority of contributing to improved access to finance through the EU budget, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, in particular for the COSME programme, as well as for the Horizon 2020 and Erasmus+ programmes , and the amount earmarked for humanitarian aid in category 4.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — I welcome the final negotiations and parliament's vote on the draft EU budget for 2015. Its €145.32 billion in commitments and €141.21 billion in payments open up a wide range of opportunities and opportunities for Europe's further development. The 2015 budget allocated 2% more funding to projects compared to the 2014 budget, which means 1% more for payments.  88% of the general budget will "return" to the Member States in the form of funding for specific actions, 6% is for EU external policy and a further 6% for administration.  Parliament succeeded in restoring the €0.5 billion that the Council proposed to cut from its m.in humanitarian aid commitments. There is €45 million more for Research and Development programmes under Horizon 2020, €16 million more for the Erasmus+ student exchange programme and €32 million for foreign policy. Higher funds were also allocated to bank control agencies and Frontex.  I congratulate my colleagues who have been directly involved in the negotiations and i am pleased with the success of the whole European Parliament.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. - I am deeply disappointed that we still have not reformed the common agricultural policy. It is high time we shift to structural projects that bring jobs and growth. For example, the EU is helping to roll out broadband in my region of West Midlands to bridge the digital gap between urban and rural areas. Such projects offer more perspectives to people than direct payments ever could. Responsible budgeting is key. I do welcome increased funds for research and development, but if we cannot put our money where our mouth is, this undermines our credibility. The strength of the EU resides in its ability to improve people’s lives through strategic and coordination action – so why is this not reflected in our budget plans?

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - We voted against the Union budget for 2015 because it is a terrible agreement that continues with the contraction of the budget and still does not solve the problem of suspended payments. This bad deal is a missed opportunity for minimal redistribution within the European Union. The absence of negotiation and the imposition of the Council's position make the 2015 budget an anemic, anti-social and anti-European budget. A budget that will continue to destroy the European economy and widen the gap between the peoples of the North and the Peoples of the South.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. — Today, alongside my Labour Party colleagues in Europe, I voted against the 2015 EU budget in light of a lack of reform.  Although Labour MEPs have worked hard with our European colleagues to see increases in the research and development provision (an area that Britain is the biggest beneficiary of and which has gone towards projects such as the development of graphene in my region) and I welcome the fact that the EU will do more to meet its international responsibilities for humanitarian aid and development, I cannot support and vote for a budget that sees so much waste of taxpayers’ money on unreformed areas like the Common Agricultural Policy and Strasbourg sessions. We must see a move towards a budget that brings added value for taxpayers and sees investment in sustainable growth that creates jobs and secures the UK’s future as a major global player.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. Despite what can be described as contemptuous on the Council's side in this annual exercise, I welcome the result achieved for this 2015 budget. After bitter negotiations, the European Parliament has secured an increase in commitment appropriations from the position initially defended by the Member States, while the overall level of payment appropriations is now set at EUR 141.214 million. In particular, I will note increases in key areas such as HORIZON 2020 (up 49.4 million), Erasmus (up 16 million), COSME (up 14 million) and employment and social innovation (up 1.5 million). Despite this, it is clear that this budget does not respond sustainably to the problem of increasing the number of unpaid invoices from the European Union budget. Therefore, in a context marked by a particularly serious payments crisis and which has the effect of eating away, year after year, at the successive budgets set out to carry out European policies, we must go further in thinking about the establishment of the EU's own resources.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — At the outset, I would like to congratulate Parliament's negotiators on the compromise reached on the 2015 budget. I think that, as a result, we have achieved a balanced, good budget, which will be an effective investment tool for creating new jobs and boosting economic growth in the European Union, which is why I voted in favour of it.  It is important that eur 4.8 billion has been provided to settle the 2014 arrears. However, I am even more pleased with the declaration of a solution that will avoid the accumulation of unpaid invoices in the past. As recently as 2010, the outstanding invoice amounted to EUR 5 billion, while in 2014 it increased to EUR 23 billion. This means that there is a growing structural problem. If we want the European Union to be seen as a reliable and credible partner, we must avoid accumulating a backlog of payments, which is why I look forward to making a swift presentation of the Commission's proposals on this matter.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. — The European Parliament adopted the European Union budget for 2015 by a large majority today. Parliament's decision today fully secured the agricultural and cohesion resources due to Hungary from this year's and next year's EU budgets.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. — Across Europe our vital public services are under threat from austerity measures, many of which are ideologically driven.  Nevertheless, there remain areas of the EU’s budget where a touch of austerity would be a good thing.  Expenses such as the European House of History are unjustified at any time and ludicrous in the current political climate.  My votes reflect the need for the EU to invest in jobs, the economy and social justice.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We voted against the Union budget for 2015 because it is a terrible agreement that continues with the contraction of the budget and still does not solve the problem of suspended payments. This bad deal is a missed opportunity for minimal redistribution within the European Union. The absence of negotiation and the imposition of the Council's position make the 2015 budget an anemic, anti-social and anti-European budget. A budget that will continue to destroy the European economy and widen the gap between the peoples of the North and the Peoples of the South.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a motion for a resolution on the Council's position on the new draft general budget of the European Union for the 2015 financial year, as I believe that the level of unpaid bills needs to be reduced in the coming years, which is currently one of the problems of the European Union, and to ensure that all revenues and expenditures are balanced. I consider it a good increase in commitment and payment appropriations for 2015 and the mobilisation of contingency reserves. The Budget of the European Union should be in line with political priorities and particular attention to budgetary commitments should be paid to cohesion policy. The financial crisis in which the European Union currently finds itself requires a balanced but strong budget that will be able to cope with the challenges ahead.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. After difficult negotiations, Parliament has validated the agreement reached on the EU budget for 2015. This budget amounts to 145.3 billion euros for commitment appropriations and 141.2 billion euros for payment appropriations. This will enable it to continue to fund essential programmes such as Horizon 2020, COSME and ERASMUS. Also, in response to the Russian embargo on food imports, European farmers will receive nearly 274 million in compensation. With this agreement, the EU also says it wants to commit to clearing its debt, which currently amounts to more than 25 billion euros. Parliamentarians also reiterate the urgent need to reform the european budget funding system. As such, the conclusions of the work of the high-level group on the Union's own resources chaired by Mario Monti are highly anticipated.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I voted against an increase in next year’s EU budget. We need to put the principles of added value and efficiency at the heart of budgetary decision-making in Europe. I want to see a real budget reform in the EU with a greater focus on generating growth and jobs, and areas that do not bring any real benefits to our constituents cut.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. - Why did I decide to abstain in the vote on the resolution on the EU budget for 2015? The 2015 budget will be slightly higher than the current budget. In contrast to the council's original proposal, there has been at least an increase in appropriations related to science and research, increased financial support for UNRWA and rapid humanitarian aid. Above all, the proposal must be read at the still wholly insufficient level of money spent to combat poverty and the mere incomprehensible play with the figures in the budget line intended to support youth employment, which is merely intended to counter the EU's inability to spend sufficient resources to combat this problem. While I have considerable reservations about the 2015 budget, I have decided to abstain, however, on the grounds that, in my opinion, the proper conclusion of the budgetary procedure will lead to a timely transfer of the necessary funds to areas that I consider to be my priorities, such as SMEs, cohesion, science, research, education, youth support, humanitarian aid, etc. The budget provisional would not benefit anyone and would result in a serious complicating of the financing of major European projects. Moreover, it should be stressed that, in the absence of any other alternative draft budget in all this time, the EP has found itself in an almost impasse.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: Written. — (DA) We support the budget that has been concluded, recognising the urgent need to have the EU budget adopted before the end of the year, otherwise a rigid and bureaucratic emergency budget would be activated. However, it remains our position that the European Union must show financial responsibility at this time and, as far as possible, prioritise these efforts within the existing framework. The Danish Social Democrats in the European Parliament have been actively working for years to strengthen control and fairness in relation to the general expenditure of Members, etc.m. We do not agree with the specific wording, but we want to send a clear signal that current practice can and must be improved.  We also actively support renewed and strengthened EU action in relation to the Middle East peace process and see the work of UNRWA as an important part of this process, but we will not, in a non-legislative text, set ourselves a lump sum.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) I would like to thank my colleagues Eider Gardiazabal Rubial and Monika Hohlmeier for the not easy work they did during 2014 to ensure that Europe has a proper budget. At the end of a long negotiation, which was marked by the failure of the conciliation procedure, an agreement was reached thanks to Parliament's sense of responsibility and the work of the Italian Presidency. The proposal provides for 145.3 billion in commitment appropriations and 141.2 billion in payment appropriations. The agreement is not what we expected but, given the economic conditions of the Member States, it was the best compromise we could reach. Resources for research (Horizon 2020), programmes for the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises (COSME), education (Erasmus), cohesion and Frontex have been safeguarded and increased.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. " I voted in favour of the draft budget for 2015, the result of long negotiations with the Member States. $145.3 billion in commitment appropriations, $141.2 billion in payment appropriations was validated, $2.2 billion more than the final payments in the 2014 budget. Also, an additional EUR 4.25 billion was granted by Member States to pay unpaid bills in 2014. I also approved the arrows that were decided. For example, an additional EUR 45 million will be allocated for the Horizon 2020 research and development programme and an additional EUR 16 million for the Erasmus student programme, which, I recall, must benefit new profiles, such as apprentices or young entrepreneurs.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. — I voted against the 2015 EU budget because I am against the EU on principle, and also because European money - which is actually our tax money! - is misused and sometimes even used to finance lavish costs, or even pharaonic bonuses (such as the "transitional allowance", i.e. the severance pay, paid to Mr Van Rompuy, totalling 349,200 euros net!). Finally, I denounce the hypocrisy of this budget, which everyone knows will not be respected by the EU, which already has a cumulative debt of 30 billion euros, in violation of the treaties that prohibit it from taking on debt.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — The 2015 budget is too low– at least €5 billion is missing to achieve important cohesion objectives (first). We have encountered resistance from the Council, which, moreover, has devoted little time to deeper debates on budget matters. However, we have achieved some important increases in the budget amounts under the payment heading. These are not high amounts of value, but they concern sensitive areas, such as Erasmus, which is so important for students, as well as humanitarian, humanitarian support for the millions of refugees who have arrived in Turkey and Lebanon.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — I voted against the new EU budget for 2015 because it is a budget in the same line as the previous ones. It continues to promote the neoliberal economic policies that have led us to the crisis, insists on memorandums and reform programmes for Member States, instigating privatizations and liberalizations of public services, austerity, cuts and deregulation of industrial relations. Moreover, the amount of this budget has been cut, at a time when public investment would be most necessary to generate jobs and to ensure public services for all European citizens.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. — After difficult negotiations, following the three-way dialogue of 8 December 2014, the Council's position on the new Draft General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 is adopted. We welcome the fact that the increases achieved in the negotiations correspond to Parliament's political priorities and reaffirm the utmost importance of the work of the High-Level Group on Own Resources, chaired by Mario Monti. I welcome the increase of EUR 244.2 million in the overall level of commitment appropriations compared to the Council's original position of 2 September 2014; as well as the overall level of payment appropriations agreed for 2015 to increase by 1.6% from the 2014 budget. In addition, I believe that the implementation of the first phase of the cooperation agreement between Parliament and the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions is very satisfactory, as it is a good example of the search for synergies between the institutions. I therefore vote in favour of the proposal.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. - It's good that we're finishing the year with the new 2015 budget. I supported this decision. Economic growth is planned for next year. I voted in favour.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I voted against the Rubial and Hohlmeier report on the new general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015, because it is on the one hand an austerity budget at the service of Europe's banks and bureaucracy and, on the other hand, this budget does not strengthen solidarity and cohesion within the EU, as it does not provide sufficient funds to support the Mediterranean countries that have been impoverished by merch austerity.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. - I welcome the agreement between the Commission, the Council and Parliament on the EU budget for 2015. The tough negotiations that lasted until the last moment led to a more than satisfactory conclusion for Parliament, which managed to pass the payments plan as one of the main lines of the 2015 budget. This is a success that goes to combat the debt crisis of the Member States, which will therefore have a cornerstone from the EU budget to deal with late payments. In addition, the cuts proposed by the Council have been halved, which, given the delicate economic and financial situation, would have reduced the margins for investment.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — On 8 December, following difficult negotiations, Parliament, the Commission and the Council finally reached agreement on the 2015 Community budget. The report, signed by Mrs Gardiazabal Rubial and Mrs Hohlmeier, clearly sets out the strengths and weaknesses of the new spending package for 2015.  I particularly agree with the reference to the need to reform the European Union's own resources system, with the aim of finally overcoming the current impasse in the budgetary negotiations, and the need to reform, in the coming years, efforts to reduce unpaid invoices to a sustainable level. On the basis of these considerations, I felt it necessary to express my agreement with the document.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — Since some of the factors in the amending budget may well seem positive, such as amending budgets Nos 4, 6 and 8, it might be considered that the drafts should be approved as a whole. However, the fact that the overall budget is still far too high is, in order to be able to finance it sensibly and, above all, sustainably over the next few years, weighs more heavily and I reject it.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. " It is now ritual in every review of the European budget: Parliament expresses its categorical refusal at the first reading in October, before voting on an almost identical budget at second reading in December. A new illustration with the 2015 budget: after calling it "catastrophic" in October, the same rapporteurs are now proposing to adopt it without amendment. The final amount is still less than the Commission's proposal to leave, which is largely insufficient. Yet all the initial criticisms of Parliament remain intact. It continues to deplore the lack of budgetary translation of the stated priorities for employment and growth. It even notes that "the Council no longer seems to have political priorities and only seeks to limit spending as much as possible in all areas". He points out that the adjusted budget "will not be enough to stop the recurring "snowball" effect of unpaid bills in 2015." It protests the recurrent non-compliance with the Council's previous commitments. But he's voting for it, eyes closed. With such reports, the European Parliament abdicates the little power it has. I'm voting against this mock democracy.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — After tough negotiations it was possible to adopt a good budget for the EU. This new budget includes more funding for the Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme, the Erasmus+ student exchange programme and foreign policy, among other areas. This budget will have EUR 145.3 million in authoritato appropriations and EUR 141.2 billion in payment appropriations. A further €4 billion has also been made for the payment of overdue invoices and a plan to minimise this serious problem is planned, as the value of overdue invoices is expected to be EUR 23 billion by the end of 2015. Let us hope that this will be the budget for recovery and economic growth, with the consequent increase in jobs and the good way out of the crisis. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of the adoption of the 2015 budget and would like to thank the rapporteurs for all their work in securing an agreement that improves significantly the Council’s initial position and prevents the collapse of the EU budget 2015. This is an instrument to promote growth and jobs and is one that I support.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. After a tug-of-war between the European Parliament and the Member States, an agreement was reached on the EU budget for 2015 and the 2014 budget bailout. We have obtained an increase in the budget allocated for the period 2015 and a partial reimbursement of unpaid bills. The latter was a major element of discordance. We defended the total allocation of additional revenue from fines imposed on companies that do not respect the European Union's right to competition. In the face of the reluctance of the Member States, an agreement has been reached to grant only part of this envelope. I deeply regret this given that these unpaid bills are currently affecting businesses and local governments awaiting payment. This agreement still helps stabilize the number of unpaid bills. It is imperative to open up the European Union's own resources. Only these will ensure the long-term stability of European finances.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing — This year's negotiations on the EU budget have been difficult, given the fact that the Council has been reluctant to add funds to the political priorities it has proclaimed itself in the past. Addressing the lack of resources in the form of an agreement on a detailed repayment plan can only be considered as a temporarily satisfactory solution, given the overall circumstances and the urgent need to adopt a budget at the end of 2014.  I personally consider it paramount to provide sufficient budgetary resources to cover the most urgent invoices for suppliers who are directly working on EU-funded projects in the regions of the Member States. The effective functioning and credibility of cohesion policy must not be jeopardiseed by delays or even non-payment of accounts by the EU.  Consequently, it is necessary to ensure that investments are channeled into the areas that have been set as priority in the Europe 2020 strategy.
