Finally, I would like to express my delight that sufficient resources have been allocated to the Erasmus training programme and also to science, research and innovation.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I am in agreement with the new general budget report of the European Union for the financial year 2015. Nevertheless, I have voted in favour of the amendment 21, which insists on increasing the level of commitment appropriations to EUR 300 million in order to provide sufficient resources to ease the dramatic humanitarian situation and to support reconstruction efforts in the Gaza Strip.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The EU's general budget for 2015, which came out to forceps, will have exposed the flaws of the European "machin". The prospect of the use of the provisional twelfths in 2015, a veritable sword of Damocles swaying over the heads of the EU's budgetary and political bodies, has forced the members of the conciliation committee to reach an agreement to avoid sending "a disastrous signal to European citizens in these times of economic uncertainty"...  A wobbly agreement, which will not solve the fundamental problems that are well structural and not just cyclical. The European Union is pleased to have found a solution, which it seems will optimise economic growth. A budget focused "on supporting policies that promote competitiveness and economic convergence" and thus contributing "to growth and employment". This 2015 budget is in fact a list of wishful thinking and empty and agreed formulas, already formulated and repeated in previous budgets and for what results? A growth rate in the euro area at its lowest, Member States, including France, caught at the throat by an exponential public debt and European peoples suffocated by the austerity measures imposed by the European Union. I voted against it.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. — I believe that before voting for an increase to the EU budget it is essential that we reform key areas such as the CAP. There are some positive aspects of the budget such as an increase in funding for research and innovation.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. "I voted for the 2015 budget. Of course it is not perfect, of course it does not solve all the issues but we must move forward: a new Commission is in place, it shows a strong will to legislate better and well it had to be given the means to get started. It's done and we look forward to 2015. Nevertheless, we remain extremely vigilant about the deficit in the European budget; there is a problem here which can have disastrous consequences for the proper functioning of the European Union.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour of the text of Mr Beazley's resolution. Gardiazabal Rubial and Hohlmeier. Agreement was reached on the EU budget for 2015 after lengthy negotiations, halving the initially proposed cut of EUR 2.1 billion and setting the level of payment appropriations at EUR 141.2 billion, saving funds for farmers and increasing funds for research, small and medium-sized enterprises, young people and immigration.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. — After the failure of November, the main parties in Parliament reached a shaky agreement on the EU's 2015 budget, thus avoiding the use of the provisional twelfths. In the end, no radical solution was proposed to solve the growing problem of unpaid debts (30 billion euros in default). The Union does not know how to give lessons in budgetary orthodoxy to the States, even though it does not itself know how to organise the treasury. Apart from spending on natural disasters and solidarity, the EU budget cannot therefore receive the support of the ELECTed representatives of the FN/RBM.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. — I voted for the new European budget for the financial year 2015 as it is the result of a political consensus between the Council, the European Parliament and the Commission. The negotiations have been difficult, but I believe that this budget will enable important job creation and development objectives to be achieved. The 2015 budget also includes the pilot project we have started, aimed at increasing access to healthcare services in rural areas.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the adoption of the European Union's 2015 budget because, in the current unstable environment, the EU needs a stable budget that pays attention to strengthening a coherent foreign policy.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. — The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece is voting against the EU budget because it is deeply unpopular. It is the economic basis for so-called structural reforms, which are directed against the working people, serving the needs of the competitiveness of capital. Expressions of satisfaction among the political staff of monopolies in the European Parliament over the agreement with the Council on the 2015 budget attempt to hide its unpopular content. The increase in funds compared to those proposed by the Council concerns only the financing of business groups for investments in profitable sectors, such as energy, "green technologies", the digital market, research programmes in the service of capital, support for Europol, FRONTEX, the EU External Action Service, all EU repressive mechanisms and political, military instruments for its imperialist interventions. The EU budget is another tool, alongside those of urban governments, to blood the people's incomes, which are directed in a whole host of forms and mechanisms to monopolies and institutions to shield their power.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Considering that the overall level of commitment appropriations in the 2015 budget is set at EUR 145,321.5 million; that the overall level of payment appropriations in the 2015 budget is set at EUR 141,214,0 million; that the flexibility instrument for 2015 is mobilised to the amount of EUR 83,3 million in commitment appropriations, I would vote in favour.

name: Marit PAULSEN
text: Written. — (SV) We have supported the agreement reached between the Council of Ministers and the European Parliament on a package solution for the 2015 budget and the 2014 supplementary budgets. This is because the agreed budget is sufficient to resolve the emergency situation with regard to the unpaid bills resulting from the reluctance of the Member States to live up to their own promises. In addition, the agreement increases efforts in what we believe Europe and the world need, such as investment in growth and job creation and humanitarian aid. However, we have voted against the further increases in the budget not covered by the agreement. Marit Paulsen, Cecilia Wikström, Fredrick Federley (ALDE)

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: in writing. — Despite the lack of consensus in the Conciliation Committee, I am voting in support of the new draft budget because, despite some reservations, I consider this budget to be a better solution from the Point of view of the European Union than a possible provisional. Not only would the budgetary provisional as evidence of the inability to find a common solution be negatively perceived by the citizens of the European Union, but it would also have dire consequences in the implementation of key policies and programmes within the Union and would entail uncertainty. Within the budget, I consider it appropriate to implement some of the shifts made in the conciliation committee negotiations, in particular support for competitiveness and economic convergence. As former Dean of the Faculty of Law, I am pleased with the European Union's interest in investing in youth education and training, e.g. erasmus+, and the promotion of a new 'European' generation of young people, particularly in view of the long-term underfunding of this area, even if this support falls short of what I would consider ideal.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. - Following the shretry negotiations between Parliament and the Council, an agreement could be reached on the 2014 budgets, amending budgets and the 2015 budget, which, despite some shortcomings, represents a significant step forward from the Council's initial position. In fact, it should be taken into account that the overall level of payment appropriations agreed for 2015 represents an increase of EUR 1 217.1 million compared to the Council's initial reading. On the other hand, the increases in the negotiations will enable parliament's political priorities on growth and jobs to be addressed, with the increase in horizon 2020, COSME and ERASMUS+ programmes. Similarly, the European Union's external solidarity with humanitarian aid has been strengthened. Finally, while it is essential that efforts to reduce unpaid bills to a sustainable level are intensified in the coming years, the agreement reached will enable the most urgent payment needs to be addressed in 2014. It is therefore important to leave a word of gratitude here for the excellent work done by the representatives of Parliament, among whom I would like to highlight THE MEP José Manuel Fernandes.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. — It should be clear that I, as a UKIP MEP, opposed the Budget for 2015.  However, I would like to confirm that I voted in favour of those amendments put forward which would have resulted in greater scrutiny of Members’ pay and allowances. I do not believe that Amendment 30 should have been ruled inadmissible, because it related solely to the text of the report and was not binding upon the pay of Members or staff.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — After arduous negotiations, Parliament has succeeded in reversing the Council's cuts, as well as increasing the budget in certain areas of particular relevance. As an example, an increase of EUR 45 million has been achieved for heading 1a, in particular for the COSME programme and for Horizon 2020, and EUR 16 million for Erasmus+, as well as an additional 32 million for heading 4 (UNWRA and humanitarian aid). In total, commitment appropriations of EUR 145 321 500 000 and payment appropriations of EUR 141 214 040 563 have been agreed for 2015. In addition, agreement has been reached to reduce the level of unpaid invoices within the current multiannual framework. For all this, I have given my vote in favour.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - We voted against the Union budget for 2015 because it is a terrible agreement that continues with the contraction of the budget and still does not solve the problem of suspended payments. This bad deal is a missed opportunity for minimal redistribution within the European Union. The absence of negotiation and the imposition of the Council's position make the 2015 budget an anemic, anti-social and anti-European budget. A budget that will continue to destroy the European economy and widen the gap between the peoples of the North and the Peoples of the South.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — The European Parliament approved by a very large majority the European Union budget for 2015 and the bailout of the 2014 budget. The 2015 budget will now amount to EUR 145.3 billion in commitment appropriations and EUR 141.2 billion in payment appropriations (it should be noted that the overall level of commitment appropriations is 1.6% higher than the 2014 budget and 1.2 billion above the Council's original position). I am also particularly pleased with the addition of $95 million for Horizon 2020, COSME, ERASMUS and humanitarian aid, and I also welcome the fact that, thanks to the new revenue allocated in the Common Agricultural Policy, a solution has been found to finance emergency measures of up to EUR 273.6 million in response to the Russian embargo on food imports, without mobilising the reserve for crises in the agricultural sector from the outset. However, it should be noted that if the Commission is thus allowed to meet the most urgent payment needs in 2014, the level of additional payment credits in the 2014 budget will not be enough to stop the recurring snowball effect of unpaid bills in 2015.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. — I supported the european Union's new general budget for 2015. Negotiators have reached a compromise that provides for 145.32 billion euros in commitment credits and 141.21 billion euros in payment credits for 2015. Our French priorities have been taken into account with the increase in funding for major European programmes such as research programmes or Erasmus - (an additional EUR 16 million) and an increase in the foreign policy payments budget with an additional EUR 32 million. In addition, in the face of the current situation, we have secured the financing of EUR 274 million in compensation from farmers for the Russian embargo, without affecting the agricultural crisis reserve. Finally, we remain attentive to the changing budgetary situation and the establishment of a new system of own resources of the European Union which is proving to be fundamental; we encourage the group's work on own resources to continue.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - We voted against the Union budget for 2015 because it is a terrible agreement that continues with the contraction of the budget and still does not solve the problem of suspended payments. This bad deal is a missed opportunity for minimal redistribution within the European Union. The absence of negotiation and the imposition of the Council's position make the 2015 budget an anemic, anti-social and anti-European budget. A budget that will continue to destroy the European economy and widen the gap between the peoples of the North and the Peoples of the South.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. — (DA) We support the budget that has been concluded in that we recognise the urgent need to have the EU budget adopted before the end of the year, otherwise a rigid and bureaucratic emergency budget would be activated. However, it remains our position that the European Union must show financial responsibility at this time and, as far as possible, prioritise these efforts within an existing framework. The Danish Social Democrats in the European Parliament have been actively working for years to strengthen control and fairness in relation to the general expenditure of Members, etc.m. We do not agree with the specific wording, but we want to send a clear signal that current practice can and must be improved.  We also actively support renewed and strengthened EU action in relation to the Middle East peace process and see the work of UNRWA as an important part of this process, but we will not, in a non-legislative text, set ourselves a lump sum.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: in writing. — I supported the resulting compromise form of the EU budget for 2015, because the financing of the existing commitments of 2014 must be resolved in the first place, as the agreement allows. The new budget also ensures funding for priority areas, in particular strengthening competitiveness, citizenship, but also strengthening EU security. Compared to the council's original position, the European Parliament's negotiators managed, among other things, to increase the funding for Horizon 2020 research and development and the Erasmus+ student exchange programme, which are the long-term priorities of the Social Democrats.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted against the new EU budget for 2015 because it is a budget in the same line as the previous ones. It continues to promote the neoliberal economic policies that have led us to the crisis, insists on memorandums and reform programmes for Member States, instigating privatizations and liberalizations of public services, austerity, cuts and deregulation of industrial relations. Moreover, the amount of this budget has been cut, at a time when public investment would be most necessary to generate jobs and to ensure public services for all European citizens.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — We have adopted the EU budget for 2015 and a number of adjustments to the current 2014 budget. This is certainly very good news for the beneficiaries of EU funds.  It is worrying, however, that this was another year in which the budget negotiations took the form of an open war between the EU institutions. The main reason for this push between Parliament and the Commission and the Council of the EU was the issue of unpaid bills, which have been rolling over from year to year for several years. Of course, Parliament understands the budgetary problems of the Member States, but a situation in which countries do not want to give payment appropriations resulting from commitments they have made themselves undermines the credibility of the EU among its citizens and internationally. All the more important to appreciate Parliament's success in winning an additional more than €4 billion in unpaid bills in 2014. However, this does not mean that the problem has disappeared and will certainly arise again in the course of subsequent negotiations.  From an agricultural point of view, the decision to finance support for farmers who have suffered as a result of the Russian embargo, from the margin of the general budget and not from the so-called crisis reserve, is a favourable solution. This means that, if necessary, an additional reserve pool, i.e. around €450 million, remains available in 2015.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. — Negotiations on the European Union budget included negotiations on the general budget for the financial year 2015 and negotiations on draft amendments to the general budget for the financial year 2014. Following the failure to negotiate the commission's first proposal, on 28 November, it prepared a new draft budget for 2015, which provided for much lower amounts for both payments and commitments (EUR 373 million less in the area of commitments and as much as EUR 800 million less in the area of payments).  The negotiations were a sign of the increasing number of payments due, as the Commission had to delay increasing reimbursements to beneficiaries in 2014, and we were also able to detect rather restrictive administrative rules that contributed to an even greater backlog of payments. I am convinced that, under this agreement on the 2015 budget, the backlog of payments will continue to increase, which will have a markedly negative impact on the implementation of European Union policies and reduce its credibility. The agreement on the 2015 budget will hit the R&D, education and regional development programmes, which are key to the recovery of the European economy, the most affected.  For all the above reasons, I voted against the draft new general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — I supported the report of my colleagues, Gardiazabal Rubial and Hohlmeier, and stressed that following difficult negotiations under the trilogue, a draft package consisting of three elements, draft amendments to budget No.3/8\2014 for a total amount of EUR 49.8 million in payment appropriations, the Union budget for 2015, a set amount of EUR 145 321.5 million and EUR 141 214 million in commitment appropriations, namely payments, and six joint declarations and three unilateral declarations. Efforts should be stepped up to reduce the level of unpaid bills to a sustainable level, paying particular attention to cohesion policy. The European Union budget must be developmental and inclusive, including a full package of pilot projects and preparatory measures and €95 million for Horizon 2020, Cosme, ERASMUS and humanitarian aid.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — I supported the proposal, given that one of the most important points of the draft general budget for 2015 is precisely the promotion of competitiveness that is essential for economic growth and job preservation, the greater role of SMEs, as they guarantee sustainable growth, but are also ready to react swiftly and effectively to situations such as the Russian ban on food imports and adapt to market needs. Some of the important issues covered are security, citizenship and business policy, which would facilitate travel as well as the commitment to allocate (Global Europe) and the reduction of administration jobs, as well as the correction (reduction/increase) of funds for various institutions.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing — I did not support next year's EU budget because I have fundamental comments on its current form. The European Union's budget for next year will increase, despite the fact that this year's budget already contains a number of expenditures that would be desirable to be significantly reduced or eliminated altogether. It is extremely irresponsible to increase the budget in such a situation and in a situation where the European Union's economy is severely weakened.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing. — I supported the proposed general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 in today's vote, but I would like to say that the European Union budget for 2016 should already reflect the level of respect for human rights in the countries receiving this development aid in the development aid chapter.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — Shifts the EU's centre of gravity more towards numbers and economic power than towards its own citizens to meet their needs.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. "I voted, on the advice of the budget experts in my political group, in favour of the text. The European Parliament stresses that, while allowing the Commission to meet the most urgent payment needs in 2014, the level of additional payment appropriations in the 2014 budget will not be enough to stop the recurring "snowball" effect of unpaid bills in 2015. It therefore draws attention to the joint declaration on a payment timetable that accompanies the agreement on the 2014 budget and the 2015 budget.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. — This year's EU budget does not meet the EU's social and economic needs, so my vote is contrary.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted against the new Eu ropean Union budget, because I strongly believe that the accumulated debts must first be resolved and then that future developments and investments must be seriously planned. The agreement reached and leaks from the conciliation between Parliament and the Council is to be considered a failure, as many of the priorities expressed, such as employment and productive investment, have not been maintained. The Council's often intransigent and unrealistic vision has set in motion a vicious circle, which continues to foresee major cuts in the Union's budget which, subsequently, have to be remedied with numerous amending budgets due to the real needs of the Member States.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. — The new EU general budget for 2015 was adopted by a large majority of the European Parliament thanks to the votes of the EPP, Socialist and Liberal groups. This majority was achieved despite an uncompromising position of the Council which led the Commission to present a new proposal revised downwards compared to its proposal of June 2014. The 2015 budget thus adopted amounts to 145.2 billion (commitments) and 141.2 billion (payments), far from the 146.3 billion (commitments and payments) that the EP adopted last September. In fact, the EP once again bowed to the Council by relinquleaving its budgetary powers. The only compensation obtained does not increase the amount of unpaid projects in Community projects, particularly for local authorities, SMEs and associations. This budget is therefore totally unacceptable and does not, in particular, address the EU's social challenges both in terms of jobs and in the fight against inequality, which is against the EU's austerity measures.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — What is at stake here is the adoption of draft amending budgets 2014, the Union budget for the financial year 2015, set at a level of EUR 145 321.5 million and EUR 141 214.0 million respectively in commitment and payment appropriations, as well as six joint declarations and three unilateral declarations. Once again, we have not provided the budget with sufficient budgetary resources to be able to meet the need to relaunch the economy, as well as the objectives of social and territorial cohesion. It should be stressed that this budget falls short of the MFF ceiling on most headings. The EU needs not a restrictive, and even tricky, budget that kicks in payment appropriations, when in reality they were now more necessary than ever to revive the economy. In short, this budget package does not serve the interests of the EU and shows a great hypocrisy of those who defend Europe more, while refusing any kind of solidarity between Member States.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. — The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece is voting against the EU budget because it is deeply unpopular. It is the economic basis for so-called structural reforms, which are directed against the working people, serving the needs of the competitiveness of capital. Expressions of satisfaction among the political staff of monopolies in the European Parliament over the agreement with the Council on the 2015 budget attempt to hide its unpopular content. The increase in funds compared to those proposed by the Council concerns only the financing of business groups for investments in profitable sectors, such as energy, "green technologies", the digital market, research programmes in the service of capital, support for Europol, FRONTEX, the EU External Action Service, all EU repressive mechanisms and political, military instruments for its imperialist interventions. The EU budget is another tool, alongside those of urban governments, to blood the people's incomes, which are directed in a whole host of forms and mechanisms to monopolies and institutions to shield their power.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — Regulation (EC) No 1071/2009 concerns the completion of an internal road transport market with fair conditions of competition, which requires the uniform application of common rules for access to the profession of haulier of goods or road passengers. The measure to be taken by the Commission should have included an exhaustive list which included both the harmonised infringements and the harmonised level of gravity which may result in the loss of honourability of the carrier. This is not the case, so this report precludes the adoption of the Commission's Rules of Procedure, and that is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — Various amendments put forward by the EFDD MEPs were voted down; consequently I was unable to support this document.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. — This draft Regulation which Parliament has decided to reject was intended to harmonise infringements which endanger road safety and which may lead to the loss of the honourability of road hauliers in the EU. I abstained in the vote on this motion for a resolution because, while the draft Regulation could have been improved in certain social aspects, it is a first step in harmonising sanctions and gives international carriers greater legal certainty. It would have put an end to the abuses of certain traffic authorities with foreign drivers, imposing the same criterion when sanctioning such important road safety and social legislation offences as respect for driver's working and rest times, the validity of the authorisation and driver's license, as well as the fight against fraud in relation to driving licences or control mechanisms such as tachograph or the speed limiter. We hope that the Commission will be able to introduce a new draft Regulation to give greater legal certainty and to put an end to the excessive zeal of certain States against carriers from the periphery.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted against this proposal calling on the Commission to withdraw the draft implementing regulation on the list of serious breaches of EU rules. This Regulation establishes which specific breaches of EU rules deprives carriers of their reputation. These rules contribute to raising the level of professional competence of road transport operators, to rationalise the market and to improve the quality of the services provided for the benefit of road transport carriers, their customers and the economy in general, while at the same time improving road safety. The proposal is intended to reject this implementing regulation because the Commission did not include 'illegal cabotage' in the infringements. However, the Commission has indicated that such 'illegal cabotage' is not included because the Regulation on the basis of which this act is drawn up establishes a clear list of categories and does not contain a category of illegal cabotage, i.e. the implementing Regulation cannot extend the scope of the basic Regulation. For this reason, I am voting against the proposal to reject this regulation.

name: Ivo BELET
text: Written. — The list of serious infringements proposed by the Commission which could lead to the loss of a licence for transporters does not address the problem of social dumping. However, within the EU we are still faced with rogue transport companies, often post office companies, who flout social legislation. As it is very important to really tackle this problem, we are today asking the Commission to come up with a new and adapted proposal which does include the fight against social dumping. It is important that the Commission comes forward with a new proposal quickly so that we can get into the fight against social malpractice as quickly as possible.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This proposal asks us to oppose the Commission's draft regulation on the classification of serious breaches of EU rules that could damage the honourability of carriers by road.  Regulation (EC) 1071/2009 must allow for harmonization of the rules for fair competition. This objective should avoid, among other things, unfair competition between European countries which do not have the same working time rules or the same burdens and wages on companies. In addition, the text strengthens sanctions, particularly in the area of illegal work. So I voted for this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this own-initiative report by the European Parliament's Committee on Transport and Tourism, which denounces the inadequacy of the Commission's proposal for a regulation on the classification of serious infringements of Union rules on road transport. There are too many cases of social dumping that our transport companies ( both goods and people) suffer from companies formally located in eastern Europe but operating without limits and with few controls even in our country.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — In order to pursue the profession of road haulier in the EU, it is necessary to demonstrate that a fixed establishment is available in a Member State, to have the financial and professional capacity to pursue the profession and to be able to demonstrate that the carrier enjoys honourability.  This draft Implementing Regulation harmonises infringements which may lead to the loss of honourability of road hauliers in the EU, in particular those which endanger road safety.  Until now, States were responsible for assessing the seriousness of the infringements committed by carriers, resulting in a large disparity in penalties between them for the same infringement, which created legal uncertainty for international carriers.  I believe that this draft Regulation should have gone ahead in order to advance the harmonisation of sanctions and, therefore, in the legal certainty of carriers, which is why I abstained in the vote on this resolution, which prevents progress on both lines.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. — The list proposed by the European Commission on the classification for serious infringements of European road transport rules does not take adequate account of infringements linked to illegal cabotage and other aspects of road safety related to compliance with social legislation in the road sector, in particular as regards social dumping. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the transport committee's objection to the list. I also think it is of the utmost importance that the Commission should re-propose a new list as soon as possible in order to provide a complete list allowing Member States to penalise the same type of infringement in a uniform manner. The Commission will have to show that it really wants to build a social Europe, capable of combating illegal practices that lead to 'unfair' competition between the different Member States. Greater compliance with all EU rules for the road sector will have immediate effects in reducing fatal accidents on our roads and ensure fair competition between European logistics companies.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted against this proposal because it was not ambitious enough.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — The European Parliament wants to vote on the Commission's draft regulation on the classification of serious breaches of EU rules that could damage the honourability of carriers by road. Regulation (EC) 1071/2009 thus provides for harmonization of the rules for fair competition in order to reduce disparities between European countries that do not have the same rules in terms of working time, payroll taxes on companies, or wages. Above all, it provides for tougher penalties for illegal work, which will have a deterrent effect on illegal immigration. For all these reasons, I voted for it.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour of an own-initiative report by the European Parliament's Committee on Transport and Tourism denouncing the inadequacy of the European Commission's proposal for a regulation supplementing the rules already in force on the classification of serious infringements of Union rules on road transport. The TRAN Commission's complaint is well founded. There are too many cases, also reported by our workers and entrepreneurs, of social dumping that our transport companies ( both goods and people) suffer from companies formally located in eastern Europe but operating without limits and with little control even in our country.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. — In order to pursue the profession of road haulier in the EU, it is necessary to demonstrate four essential elements: having a fixed establishment in the Union, having the financial and professional capacity to practice the profession and being able to demonstrate that the carrier enjoys honourability.  This Implementing Regulation harmonises infringements which may lead to loss of honourability. To date, States were responsible for assessing the seriousness of the infringements, with a disparity of sanctions between States for the same infringement. This has created legal uncertainty in international carriers and also abuses by traffic authorities with certain foreign carriers, with France even contemplating prison sentences for performing the driver's weekly rest in the cabin. This Regulation harmonises only sanctions which pose a high risk to road safety, typically excessive working time, driving without a valid permit, excess weight, fraud in control elements such as tachograph etc. But it does not go into detail as regards other types of infringements, such as international cabotage legislation.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft regulation and to present a new list of serious infringements of Union rules which may lead to the loss of the good repute of the road transporter. The path taken by the Commission is dangerous: it has been decided to indicate strictly in delegated acts the cases in which the carrier loses his good repute and therefore the possibility of carrying out his work. If the indication is exhaustive, everything that is not included is granted, i.e. what is not indicated as serious will not be such as to allow the suspension of the service authorization. The sanctions framework must be common and comprehensive, otherwise there is a risk that each Member State will take individual initiatives that end up creating differences in treatment between countries. For example, other rules relating, for example, to illegal cabotage, which is a problem in the European Union, should also be included on the list as serious infringements. If this is not regarded as 'serious', this will have social consequences for business and social dumping.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution which rejects the Commission’s weak draft regulation relating to fair conditions of competition for the road transport internal market. Ireland is a small island nation, in which companies are forced to operate within two economic jurisdictions due to an enforced border.  The Westminster government has imposed an HGV levy which seeks to implement a charge on all heavy goods vehicles that cross the Irish border in what is an unfair and unworkable barrier for businesses that operate on a cross-border basis. Sinn Féin has resisted the introduction of this levy since its inception. We have raised serious concerns about the deeply negative impact that it will have on cross-border and island-wide trade, which currently accounts for GBP 2.3 billion in economic activity per annum. The levy hurts businesses north and south.  Any legislation emanating from the commission should prevent member governments from implementing such measures.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — (IT) The list of serious infringements leading to the loss of the good repute of the road hare, contained in the amendment proposed by the Commission, is not exhaustive enough, which is why the proposal is rejected.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this objection. I believe that road safety is an issue on which we cannot be approximate and indeed this implementing regulation lacked precision. It will be important, in rewriting it, to shift the bar towards more workable and concrete measures, so as not to place an excessive burden on transport companies.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. — I voted for this motion for resolution as I did not think the Commission’s list of serious infringements was comprehensive enough. The onus will now be on the Commission to revisit the list of infringements with a view to creating a more realistic, comprehensive list that is less open to interpretation and reduces red tape.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. — Regulation 1071/2009 lays down common rules for the exercise of the activity of road haulier and passengers, which contribute, inter among other factors, to increasing road safety and the level of professional qualification of carriers. It is for the European Commission, through delegated acts, to draw up a list of the categories, types and degrees of seriousness of serious infringements of Community rules.  I consider that the list drawn up does not meet the requirements of Parliament and in some cases goes beyond the power delegated to it, so this draft regulation is not compatible with the objective and content of basic Regulation 1071/2009, and the Commission should withdraw this draft regulation and present a new one to the European Parliament.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I support the text of the resolution tabled by Mr Cramer. In October 2009, a road package consisting of three EC regulations (No 1071/2009 – No 1072/2009 – No 1073/2009) was adopted, providing for new rules, such as the simplified and standardised presentation of the Community licence or the strengthening of procedures for the exchange of information between Member States on infringements committed by carriers.  With regard to this last point, It seems to me necessary for the Commission to withse the draft regulation in order to supplement Article 6(2), with an exhaustive list of categories, types and levels of seriousness of infringements of Union rules that may result in the loss of the good repute of the road hare. I would like to point out that there are contained objectives of the 'EU Guidelines 2011-2020 for road safety', which should be achieved as soon as possible, including a reduction in the number of deaths and injuries on European roads.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — The classification and harmonised categorisation of infringements is an important step forward ensuring fairer competition between undertakings, more harmonised enforcement, and an effective functioning of the European Register of Road Transport Undertaking’s information exchange system. It is in the interest of transparency and fair competition to lay down the common method of calculation of a frequency of occurrence beyond which repeated infringements shall be regarded as more serious by the competent authority of the Member State of establishment. Such repeated infringements may lead to the launching of a national administrative procedure, which, subject to the discretion of the competent authority, may lead to the loss of good repute by a transport operator. For this reason I voted in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — Regulation (EC) No 1071/2009 concerns the completion of an internal road transport market with fair conditions of competition, which requires the uniform application of common rules for access to the profession of haulier of goods or road passengers. The measure to be taken by the Commission should have included an exhaustive list which included both the harmonised infringements and the harmonised level of gravity which may result in the loss of honourability of the carrier. This is not the case, so this report precludes the adoption of the Commission's Rules of Procedure, and that is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. - Classification of serious road transport offences I voted against the EP report on the draft Commission regulation. I voted in favour of the opinion of the new Member States that the EP's official resolution against the Draft Regulation of the European Commission would adversely affect the carriers of the new Member States. The so-called 'old Member States' refer to 'social dumping', claiming that the 'new Member States' enjoy an unfair advantage from lower wage levels, thereby making it impossible for carriers of the old Member States to take over the market. This issue is a classic example of the tension between old and new Member States, of which, unfortunately, the old Member States have always been the winners, without exception, mainly because the new Member States have not been able to act together. However, today's close result suggests that these Member States are starting to wake up and find common denominator. It is starting to become clear that the interests of the old Member States are not always the same as those of the new ones, and that these common interests, other than those of others, can only be achieved by joining forces and joining forces. I hope that during this election period we will be able to set a positive example for our constituents and defend the interests of the new Member States while protecting European integrity.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, since it opposes the adoption of the draft Commission regulation with regard to the classification of serious infringements of the Union rules, which may lead to the loss of good repute by a road transport operator. The road transport sector is faced today with major problems, such as social dumping and unfair competition practices in the sector. The draft measure submitted by the Commission is not compatible with the aim or content of the basic legislative act Regulation 1070/2009, which is the completion of fair competition on the internal market, in my opinion. It also calls on the Commission to withdraw the draft regulation and submit to the committee a new list of serious infringements of the Union rules which may lead to the loss of good repute by a road transport operator.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. — This resolution proposes to the European Parliament to oppose the publication of the European Commission's delegated regulation to supplement Regulation (EC) 1071/2009 of Parliament and the Council with regard to the classification of serious breaches of EU rules that could prejudice the honourability of carriers by road. According to the mandate granted to the European Commission, the act was to establish common rules on the conditions to be met in order to practise as a carrier by road. However, a close examination of this act shows that its content as well as its form do not meet the issue. Indeed, the procedures in force in the 28 Member States are still too diverse and the assessment of the level of seriousness and the enforcement of offences are still subject to the national supervisory authorities or the relevant competent authorities. The act in question does not propose any harmonisation of existing rules, lacks clarity and does not bring real European added value. In addition, there is no mention of the cabotage problems that must be addressed. For these reasons, I opposed the adoption of this delegated act and voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The incompleteness of the list of breaches of EU rules that could damage the honour of carriers by road led me to vote in favour of objection to the European Commission's delegated act. Indeed, the Commission's proposed regulation did not include illegal coasting transport in its list of infringements, nor other rules concerning illegal coasting, in particular those relating to the execution of coasting operations under conditions contrary to national social legislation applicable to the contract.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. — I voted against the European Parliament's proposal on 'Assessing the good repute of carriers' for a complex of reasons. First of all, I believe that there are issues that precede the resolution of the reputational problem. I point out that there is still unequal treatment of carriers and distortions of competition rules and good practices. There are still Member States that artificially create severe barriers to the activities of small carriers, while others restrict carriers from other Member States. The issue of dumping by carriers from countries outside the Union has also not been resolved. These are priorities for me and we can't work backwards. I can't agree with some colleagues' thesis on the so-called "no-fly zone". "social dumping" by carriers from Member States such as Bulgaria. She's just not true. Statistics prove it. In Bulgaria, the average wage in the transport sector is about and above the national average. So there is no "social dumping". On the issue of cabotage – it is necessary and I do not see why we need to interfere with the regime and change something that works and is useful. Useful for workers, for companies, for nature, for the idea of free movement.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of proposal B8-0325/2014, since it opposes the adoption of the Commission's draft regulation, considering that it is incompatible with the purpose and content of the Regulation and furthermore calls on the Commission to withdraw it by submitting a new list of serious infringements of EU rules, which lead to the loss of the required guarantees of reliability of the road transport operator.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. - Transport policy is of great importance to the EU's internal market. In order to achieve fair competition, rules on driving and working hours, tachographs, maximum weights, training requirements, etc.m. We have therefore welcomed the European Commission's proposal for a list of such serious infringements that will cause a carrier to lose its reputation. However, the requirement to take social legislation into account, where the driver's origin sits first, is nothing more than covert discrimination and nationalism. For this reason, we chose to vote against the resolution and the amendments that have been put to it.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — This resolution opposes the adoption of the commission's draft regulation which complements an existing one (EC/1071/2009) concerning the classification of serious infringements of Union rules, which may result in the loss of suitability of road hauliers. The resolution considers that the list of infringements and the degree of seriousness of the offences submitted by the Commission is incomplete and, as such, should be rejected. We support this position. The list has gaps in illegal cabotage and its impact on road workers and is not balanced with national regulations, in particular on social issues. The minimalist nature of the commission's proposal is very symptomatic of the interests that the Commission serves and the objectives it pursues. The existing legislative framework at EU level has always given prevalence to the objectives of promoting free competition sacrosanct (and the inevitable monopolistic concentration that always comes to it), with a view to achieving the so-called internal market, in favour of the objectives of defending and strengthening the promotion of the health and safety of the work of the sector.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing — Regulation (EC) No 1071/2009) was aimed at completing the internal market in road transport, characterised by fair conditions of competition. This requires the uniform application of common rules for the authorisation of road haulage or passenger transport operators. These common rules are intended to contribute to achieving a higher level of professional qualifications for road transport operators, rationalising the market and improving the quality of services in the interests of road transport operators, their customers as well as greater road safety. However, the european Commission regulation submitted is incompatible with the objective or content of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council of 21 October 2009.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — (IT) I am voting in favour of the own-initiative report by the Committee on Transport and Tourism, which denounces the inadequacy of the European Commission's proposal for a regulation supplementing the rules already in force on the classification of serious infringements of Union rules on road transport.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — I am in favour of proposal B8-0325/2014, since it opposes the adoption of the Commission's draft regulation, considers that the draft is incompatible with the purpose and content of the regulation and also calls on the Commission to withdraw it by submitting to the Committee a new list of serious infringements of Union rules, which lead to the loss of the required guarantees of reliability of the road transport operator.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. — (IT) I wish to vote against the European Commission's proposal on 'serious infringements of road hauliers'. I would like to point out a crucial point in order to guarantee a truly effective control system: we are clearly sanctioning the phenomenon of illegal cabotage in the list of infringements. This is a practice that is increasingly infringing the rights of workers in the road transport sector by introducing mechanisms of dumping and unfair competition that Europe cannot afford to tolerate, with a view to developing a balanced and efficient internal market.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. — The list of serious road traffic offences presented by the Commission appears to be partial and not exhaustive. The exclusion of cabotage and the inability to ensure the application of social legislation are the greatest weaknesses. The legislation on driving hours is European and the free market – and therefore the possibility of cabotage – is European. It follows that any solutions must also be dealt with at European level. Both illegal cabotage and non-compliance with social and labour standards create potential risks to life, as they are closely linked to poor and degraded living and working standards. Adapting to European regulations, opening up borders to often unfair competition from foreign carriers, soaring operating costs and unsustainable taxation are just some of the problems facing the sector. Europe's objective must be to support road transport, to facilitate the activity of companies in the sector and to simplify bureaucratic procedures at a time when the world of road transport is experiencing a widespread and profound crisis.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of this motion for a Resolution which opposes the adoption of the draft Commission Regulation on the classification of serious Union infringements which may result in the loss of honourability of the carrier. This proposal urges the Commission to withdraw the project and submit a new list of infringements, as it does not fulfil the objective of creating fair conditions of competition, does not improve service and harms the already deteriorated working conditions of carriers, by not explicitly referencing illegal cabotage, an abusive practice which significantly affects the carrier's living and working conditions and entails , consequently, a great potential to create a risk of death or serious injury.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. — The European Parliament has today rejected a Commission regulation on the classification of serious infringements resulting in the loss of the reputation of road hauliers. The EP is therefore asking the Commission to draw up a new proposal and to treat as a serious infringement possible infringement of the so-called cabotage rules carried out primarily by transport companies in central and eastern European Member States. As a representative of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I did not support the motion, as I see a serious risk that the expansion of the scope of infringements could adversely affect Hungarian hauliers.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of this motion for a Resolution which opposes the adoption of the draft Commission Regulation on the classification of serious Union infringements which may result in the loss of honourability of the carrier. This proposal urges the Commission to withdraw the project and submit a new list of infringements, as it does not fulfil the objective of creating fair conditions of competition, does not improve service and harms the already deteriorated working conditions of carriers, by not explicitly referencing illegal cabotage, an abusive practice which significantly affects the carrier's living and working conditions and entails , consequently, a great potential to create a risk of death or serious injury.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted AGAINST The Resolution on the Draft Commission Regulation amending the Regulation with regard to the classification of serious breaches of EU rules and on the amendment of Annex III. Directive 2006/22/ because the Commission's proposal is not sufficiently clear or sufficiently elaborated.  Roads are the lifeblood of the European economy, and road transport is the lifeblood of the European economy. We are witnessing numerous problems of disloyal competition and so-called "social dumping" in truck transport. There are numerous examples of major differences in regulations between Member States and how I support the idea of levelling the rules, as the undermining of these rules abuts the freedom of movement of people and goods, I did not support this proposal for a Regulation. With the ANTI stance, I wanted to make clear my support for all those who are demanding that the European Commission come out with far clearer rules to increase road safety.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of my colleague Markus Ferber's resolution on the Commission's delegated act on serious breaches of EU rules that could damage the honour of carriers by road. The resolution aims to reject this delegated act, which brings no clarity or added value to the classification of offences, and has shortcomings in the transport of hazardous materials. The resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. — I wished to vote against this delegated act relating to the classification of offences detrimental to the honour of road hauliers in order to protest against the abuses linked to road coasting of goods. It is important to combat social dumping and unfair competition in this area, by limiting deliveries by European carriers in Member States in which they are not established and by insisting on penalties for breaches of regulations.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I supported the resolution opposing the Commission’s classification. I believe that illegal cabotage should be included on the list of serious road infringements, as it has an impact on working and living conditions that could lead to risk of road fatalities.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. — (IT) I support my colleague Michael Cramer's proposal because the current regulations, in addition to defining road traffic offences, also include comprehensive provisions on the liability of hauliers, drivers and companies operating in the freight transport sector. The Commission's draft regulation is compatible with the provisions of Regulation (EC) No 1071/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down common rules on the conditions to be fulfilled in order to carry out the activity of road transporter.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. "I wanted to defend the road coasting. The purpose of the regulation is to avoid unfair competition from foreign road hauliers, in large numbers, between road freight carriers, which would be favoured by lower cost prices (labour, fuel, vehicles) than those borne by our road hauliers. A majority of MEPs rejected an act by the European Commission on the classification of offences that harm road hauliers. This vote is a clear warning to the European Commission that cabotage is a sensitive subject with serious economic consequences. MEPs will pay particular attention to the Commission's proposals and will not accept the introduction of greater social dumping in the sector.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — The resolution is an important document, as it concerns the reputation of carriers, the prevention of various offences against Community rules. At the same time, it is an opportunity to take into account the interests of entrepreneurs and drivers in a sustainable way. I stress, this is about the rules of the European Union. At the same time, this should serve to eliminate the voluntary behaviour and regulation of certain governments, such as the Federal Government imposing on everyone the german minimum wage of EUR 8.50 per hour. Doubts – how will this be implemented?

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — Regulation (EC) No 1071/2009 concerns the completion of an internal road transport market with fair conditions of competition, which requires the uniform application of common rules for access to the profession of haulier of goods or road passengers. The measure to be taken by the Commission should have included an exhaustive list which included both the harmonised infringements and the harmonised level of gravity which may result in the loss of honourability of the carrier. This is not the case, so this report precludes the adoption of the Commission's Rules of Procedure, and that is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the Commission's draft regulation supplementing Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. in order to classify serious infringements of Union rules, which may lead to the loss of the required reliability guarantees for the road transport operator, and amending Annex III to Directive 2006/22/EC of the European Parliament, despite the reservations I expressed during the debate, as a first approach to this issue is under way to reduce unfair competition, social dumping in the crucial transport sector, road safety and respect for the labour rights of carriers.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. — I have chosen to vote against the motion for a resolution initiated by the European Parliament, because I consider the European Commission's proposal reasonable. The procedure did not allow members to table amendments. That is why Parliament has exercised its veto and called for an improved proposal. I believe that, with this proposal, the European Commission has already imposed several difficult conditions that should be respected by carriers, and they will have to adapt quite quickly. It still takes time. Changing the rules is never easy. I fear that if this classification of infringements is made even more stringent by the European Commission, the transport industry will be affected and the rules cannot be fully complied with. Also, the reason put forward in the resolution, the lack of illegal cabotage, is not correct. I believe that he has nothing to look for in this delegated act.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. - The aim of Regulation (EC) No 1071/2009 is to establish an internal market in road transport, based on fair conditions of competition. It also recognises the need to apply common rules for the authorization of goods or persons by road. These regulatory requirements will help to achieve a number of objectives: the achievement of a higher level of professional qualification for road hauliers, a rationalisation of the market, an improvement in the transport service and, more importantly, a strengthening of road safety conditions. I have given my assent to this document, because I agree with its meaning and purpose.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — (DE) I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because it aims to broaden the content of the Commission's proposal for a regulation. This increases the safety of road users as well as those of the motor vehicle drivers concerned. A general increase in road safety is to be welcomed, but above all, of course, not only in freight transport. The extension of the list of recognised infringements will play a major part in this.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — Regulation (EC) 1071/2009 of the European Parliament and the Council of 21 October 2009 sets out common rules on the conditions to be met in order to practise the profession of carrier by road. The commission's proposed addition was intended to classify cases of serious breaches of EU rules that could damage the honourability of carriers by road. The Commission's proposal remains very vague in this classification. This makes it even more difficult for the authorities to properly interpret the types and levels of serious offences. It also failed to provide a complete list of serious offences. The report calls on us to reject the Commission's proposal, so I vote for this report.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — I agree with the fact that the Commission's draft regulation is not compatible with the objective and content of Regulation (EC) No 1071/2009 of the European Parliament and the Council of 21 October 2009, which lays down common rules on the requirements for the exercise of road haulage and repeals Council Directive 96/26/EC.  It will be appropriate for the Commission to submit a new list of serious infringements of Union rules, which may result in the loss of suitability of the road haulier.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — I support this resolution in its opposition of the draft Commission regulation, considering that: the list of infringements is incomplete; the words used to describe the degrees of seriousness   of the serious infringements create complications for the relevant authorities to interpret; and that the existing legislation on the matter already outlines the clear provisions with regards to the responsibility carried by road transport operators.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I supported the report on classification of serious infringements of the Union rules, which may lead to the loss of good repute by the road transport operator. However, I have voted in favour of Amendment 6, which is asking for the highest level of seriousness to be accorded to infringements concerning animal transportation.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. We are asked to comment on the Commission's draft regulation on the classification of serious breaches of EU rules that could damage the honourability of carriers by road. Regulation (EC) 1071/2009 thus provides for harmonization of the rules for fair competition in order to reduce disparities between European countries that do not have the same rules in terms of working time, payroll taxes on companies, or wages. It also provides for tougher penalties for illegal work. For these reasons, I voted for it.

name: Alessandra MORETTI
text: in writing. — (IT) I regret the result of today's vote on the classification of serious infringements of Union rules which may lead to the loss of the road hare's reputation – a reputation which is necessary for the holder by the carrier of the requirements necessary to hold a licence. Indeed, I believe – while supporting the Commission's efforts to introduce a list establishing a common list of serious infringements – that the Commission has avoided addressing the great problem of the deterioration of social rights, also known as social dumping and, consequently, of so-called illegal cabotage. These are issues of fundamental importance to my group that the Commission, despite the limitations of its mandate – since it has only allowed it to include on the list infringements that lead to death or serious harm to people – cannot afford not to address. Having said that, However, I am convinced that for my country a list, albeit with a limited scope, would still have been a good starting point.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. "I voted against the act proposed by the Commission for two reasons. The first is technical: the act was drafted and did not bring European added value. The second is political: it was to tell the Commission that road congestion is an important issue and that we remain strongly mobilised on this subject in order to avoid any social dumping between carriers.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: in writing. — Although the commission proposal does not appear to be a complete and perfect solution to the problem of infringements, it would allow progress to be made towards fair conditions in the field of truck transport. The rejection of this proposal, which Parliament approved and which I voted against, may lead to a substantial delay and a slowdown in this process. I find that undesirable. I find it even more contentious that the requirements for the inclusion of the area of so-called social dumping are not covered by this regulation. Not only do I find this term highly contentious, but, in particular, in my opinion, it does not fall within the material scope of this regulation.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. — In its decision, the Commission consciously welcomes the absence of basic transport safety rules, which are a key policy link for strengthening business groups.  Inhuman employer exploitation with miserable working conditions for road transport workers endangers the lives and health of themselves and others who move and is responsible for hundreds of deaths and injuries. Working hours beyond human endurance, poor maintenance, overloading of vehicles even with dangerous loads, illegal cabotage operations that exploit poor work and rely on the so-called freedom of movement of EU services and workers are incentives for profitability, competitiveness criteria of transport companies.  The individual objections of the political groups of the European Parliament to the Commission's decision, on the basis of existing problems, are raised in the light of business competition. Not only do they not solve the problem but they move within the framework of the EU single market and the policy of low labour costs and business profitability. Transport workers must claim human working conditions. Employers are responsible for all infringements due to labour exploitation and intensification conditions and they must be punished.   The EU can only be built on the over-exploitation of workers. There is no solution within it but to release it, in conflict with monopolies and their power.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: In writing. "I voted against it. This list of violations of EUROPEAN rules for transport operators did not prohibit social dumping, in particular illegal cabotage, which is the act of a carrier operating in a neighbouring country without adequate authorisation, and therefore without any guarantee that it will comply with social and environmental standards. For the Socialists, social dumping and its corollary, unfair competition, are major societal problems in Europe, which have only worsened with the crisis. I am fully satisfied with this vote: the European Parliament has made maximum use of the powers conferred by the Lisbon Treaty to advance social progress. Social dumping is not a subject with which one can compromise. It is in the general interest of our fellow citizens.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Ladies and gentlemen, the aim of Regulation (EC) No 1071/2009 is to establish an internal market in road transport with fair conditions of competition, for which uniform application of common rules is necessary in order to authorise access to the occupation of road haulabuler for goods or persons. These common rules will help to achieve a higher level of professional qualifications for road hauliers, to rationalise the market, to improve the quality of service, in the interests of road hauliers, their customers and the economy in general, and to improve road safety. For these reasons, I would vote in favour.

name: Marit PAULSEN
text: Written. — Transport policy is of great importance for the EU's internal market. In order to achieve fair competition, rules on driving and working hours, tachographs, maximum weights, training requirements, etc.m. We have therefore welcomed the European Commission's proposal for a list of such serious infringements that will cause a carrier to lose its reputation. However, the requirement to take social legislation into account, where the driver's origin sits first, is nothing more than covert discrimination and nationalism. For this reason, we chose to vote against the resolution and the amendments that have been put to it. Marit Paulsen, Cecilia Wikström and Fredrick Federley (ALDE)

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — I support the proposal for a resolution rejecting the Commission's proposal to classify serious breaches of Union rules. The 2009 Regulation defines four criteria that road freight service providers must meet to obtain a licence to provide those services. The criterion of "good repute" was established with the aim of ensuring the ethical behaviour of the entrepreneur. In order to ensure consistent application of the rules in all Member States, it is necessary that the list defining the categories of infringements is complete and clear. In my view, this is not the case with the proposal submitted to us from the Commission. At the moment, the practical implementation of the regulation is highly uneven within the European Union, as the definition of infringements of the rules is left to the national authorities in charge of the area. Unfortunately, this amendment does not ensure the necessary harmonisation of implementation. Given that the proposed list is limited to actions resulting in death or serious injury, I consider the list to be incomplete. Given that the regulation stipulates that data on serious infringements will be available for electronic exchange between Member States no later than 1 January 2016 and that the lack of harmonised rules for the application of the rules in practice is already creating obstacles for undertakings in business, I think it is necessary to accelerate the drafting of the full text and its application.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — (IT) As a member of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, I am in favour of adopting the Commission's draft regulation because there is an unsatisfactory level of assessment of the weight of road traffic offences and infringements, which lead to serious safety risks. I agree with the content of the motion and hope that a new, more comprehensive assessment will be made of violations of road cabotage, with the term 'most serious infringements' (MSI), rather than 'very serious infringements' (VSI).

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - The motion for a resolution of the Committee on Transport and Tourism put to the vote on the draft regulation on the classification of serious infringements of EU rules which may lead to a loss of good repute by the road transport operator not only does not safeguard the interests of both parties concerned, i.e. hauliers and drivers, but also goes beyond the competence of the EU, calling for eu-level regulation of issues within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Member States. The lack of a balanced approach to cabotage services within the EU and the incomplete interpretation of the social and economic conditions in the development of individual Member States have convinced me to abstain in the vote on this resolution.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. "I am pleased that a large majority of my colleagues have rejected this text from the European Commission. Road coasting must be limited, the position of the European Commission must be clear. We must protect French companies from social dumping. To do this, we must limit the deliveries of a European carrier to a country that is not its own. The survival of our own carriers is at stake.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — Achieving an internal market for road transport with a level playing field would certainly improve the quality of service and increase road safety. However, the Commission's draft regulation does not sufficiently explain the list of serious infringements of Union rules which could result in the loss of suitability of the road haulier, in the same way as it does not present rules on illegal cabotage, despite its potential to create a risk of death or serious injury. Since the draft regulation is not compatible with the objective proposed, nor with the content of the Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council of 21 October 2009, I voted in favour of this resolution calling on the Commission to withdraw the draft regulation with regard to the classification of serious infringements of Union rules , which may result in the loss of suitability of the road haulier.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. "The list that has been submitted to us by the Commission is moving in the right direction. Clarifying serious traffic offences means strengthening road safety and fair competition between companies. Unfortunately, this list is far too restrictive from my point of view and that is why I did not support it. It does not sanction illegal cabotage, which can have a significant impact on road safety. Today, some companies do not comply with applicable national social legislation and employ drivers in inappropriate conditions which, in addition to undermining human dignity, can seriously affect attention and responsiveness while driving (e.g. weekly rest taken in the cab). Of course, this problem will have to be solved through a larger reform, but we must seize every opportunity to tackle the problem. Without this, we will not be able to establish healthy competition between companies in the sector on the one hand, and between road transport and other greener modes on the other. I now call on the Commission to come back as soon as possible with a new proposal.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — In order to pursue the profession of road haulier in the EU, it is necessary to demonstrate that a fixed establishment is available in a Member State, to have the financial and professional capacity to pursue the profession and to be able to demonstrate that the carrier enjoys honourability.  This draft Implementing Regulation harmonises infringements which may lead to the loss of honourability of road hauliers in the EU, in particular those which endanger road safety.  Until now, States were responsible for assessing the seriousness of the infringements committed by carriers, resulting in a large disparity in penalties between them for the same infringement, which created legal uncertainty for international carriers.  I believe that this draft Regulation should have gone ahead in order to advance the harmonisation of sanctions and, therefore, in the legal certainty of carriers, which is why I abstained in the vote on this resolution, which prevents progress on both lines.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of this motion for a Resolution which opposes the adoption of the draft Commission Regulation on the classification of serious Union infringements which may result in the loss of honourability of the carrier. This proposal urges the Commission to withdraw the project and submit a new list of infringements, as it does not fulfil the objective of creating fair conditions of competition, does not improve service and harms the already deteriorated working conditions of carriers, by not explicitly referencing illegal cabotage, an abusive practice which significantly affects the carrier's living and working conditions and entails , consequently, a great potential to create a risk of death or serious injury.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. — This document is essential for members of the Union in close proximity to the external borders or with a well-developed road transport sector. The Regulation determines which specific infringements deprives carriers of their good repute. The TRAN Committee rejected this proposal because the Commission did not include 'illegal cabotage' among the infringements. The Commission, for its part, clearly stated that such 'illegal cabotage' was excluded because the original Regulation establishes a clear list of categories. It does not contain the category of 'illegal cabotage' and therefore the implementing legislation of the original Regulation cannot extend the scope of the basic Regulation.  If the EP wishes to include an additional provision on 'illegal cabotage' in the implementing regulation, the basic regulation should be added first. I would suggest that we do not politicise the issue of cabotage and support the Commission's proposal. Studies carried out by the Commission (e.g. COM(2014) 222 final) show that illegal cabotage accounts for no more than 2% of international transport activities, while other infringements (such as non-compliance with the driving time regime) have a significantly greater negative impact on both competition between carriers and road safety.
