It is these other infringements that are laid down in the Commission Regulation, which will allow the elimination of malignant carriers from the transport business on their basis.  For its part, the definition and fight against illegal cabotage can lead to a separate debate and ask the Commission to draw up a separate document on the matter.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. — I supported this resolution on serious breaches of EU rules that could damage the honourability of road hauliers. In voting on this resolution, Parliament rejected the delegated act proposed by the Commission and which the Members of the French EPP delegation were challenging.  Indeed, this text directly concerned road coasting and was initially to be refused for technical reasons: the text did not add any added value in the classification of proposed offences and also had worrying shortcomings in terms of the transport of hazardous materials.  On the other hand, it was important for us to reaffirm our vigilance regarding any possible reform of the road sector to come. Cabotage remains a sensitive and economically important subject, and it must be given particular attention and mobilized to prevent social dumping.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of this motion for a Resolution which opposes the adoption of the draft Commission Regulation on the classification of serious Union infringements which may result in the loss of honourability of the carrier. This proposal urges the Commission to withdraw the project and submit a new list of infringements, as it does not fulfil the objective of creating fair conditions of competition, does not improve service and harms the already deteriorated working conditions of carriers, by not explicitly referencing illegal cabotage, an abusive practice which significantly affects the carrier's living and working conditions and entails , consequently, a great potential to create a risk of death or serious injury.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - Regulation (EC) No 1071/2009 aims at the completion of an internal road transport market with fair conditions of competition, which requires the uniform application of common rules for access to the profession of carrier of goods or road passengers. The measure to be taken by the Commission should have included an exhaustive list which included both the harmonised infringements and the harmonised level of gravity which may result in the loss of honourability of the carrier. This is not the case, so this report precludes the adoption of the Commission's Rules of Procedure, and that is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — I absolutely support this proposal on the grounds that I consider that the draft Regulation of the European Commission does not comply with the content and objective of the existing Regulation establishing common rules concerning the conditions for carrying out the activities of a road haulier. This draft is incomplete and makes it completely difficult to interpret the types of serious infringements.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — Road transport has a large representation in all Member States, including Croatia. I therefore welcome the adoption of a regulation formalising minimum conditions on social regulations relating to road transport activities, proposing a new set of rules with far stricter penalties and checks. The common objective is to improve the quality of road transport and checks must be carried out in stages to give a complete picture of the situation. Police officers need to be provided with all equipment to make the result more efficient and faster. It is important that Member States also adapt to the Common Training Programme Regulation, and only when there are resources to solve a potential problem can we expect results in this regard as well.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing. — I voted against the motion for a resolution on the Commission's abovementioned proposal mainly for the following two reasons. I believe that it is important that the list of offences be approved and entered into force on the first day of 2016, so that member states' supervisory authorities have a regulation that allows them to assess individual serious infringements in a uniform way. At the same time, I believe that the proposal to include illegal cabotage as an offence is not in line with Czech interests, since it actually concerns the issue of so-called social dumping in road transport, notwithstanding the fact that, in my opinion, its classification as a road traffic offence is, in principle, problematic.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — The Commission must draw up and submit a new regulation containing an updated list of serious infringements of EU rules leading to the loss of the road transport operator's required reliability guarantees.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — I supported this resolution, which was intended to amend or supplement Regulation (EC) 1071/2009 of the European Parliament and the Council with regard to the classification of serious breaches of EU rules that could harm the honourability of road carriers, and amending Schedule III of the European Parliament and Council Directive 2006/22/EC.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. — I pledge to support any proposal to severely punish unfair competition.  FN MPs voted in 2009 in favour of the basic text from which the new regulation flows.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — This resolution opposes the proposal from the delegation of powers to the Commission to establish a list of the categories, types and degrees of severity of the infringements causing the loss of suitability of the road haulier in order to adapt Annexes I, II and III to the Regulation concerned.  The resolution considers that the proposed document is incompatible with the objective of the existing Regulation, as the list has shortcomings in illegal cabotage and its impact on road workers, and is not balanced with national regulations, in particular as regards social issues.  This is an instrument that, by helping to enforce the labour law of each Member State, protects workers for maximum driving time and minimum rest, improving working conditions and road safety. However, it also presents its negative aspects, as it is part of the objective of ensuring the completion of an internal market for EU road transport which requires the uniform application of common rules for access to the activity of road haulier or passenger, an objective which in the neoliberal presuppositions where the Union market is dipped has harmful consequences , including the survival of micro and SMEs.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — (DE) I voted in favour of this regulation because it not only increases the safety of road users, but also those of drivers of motor vehicles. The extension of the list of recognised infringements will make a significant contribution to road safety in general.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing — The motion for a resolution tabled requested the withdrawal of the Commission's proposal. I voted against its adoption because, if it were approved, the Commission would have to develop a new alternative, thus blocking the whole process for a longer period of time, on the other hand, on the other hand, carriers would probably also be brought into European legislation, which would reduce the competitiveness of businesses not only from Slovakia, but from all over Central and Eastern Europe. For Slovak carriers, such measures would mean an increase in costs and would lead to redundancies, perhaps even redundancies.  In the long term, it is necessary to work to ensure that Slovakia is able to assert itself in the Single European Market, above all, by the high quality of products and services. However, until this happens, we must not allow administrative obstacles to take away from us often a single advantage – the lower cost of work, which is based on lower living costs.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. — In its decision, the Commission consciously welcomes the absence of basic transport safety rules, which are a key policy link for strengthening business groups.  Inhuman employer exploitation with miserable working conditions for road transport workers endangers the lives and health of themselves and others on the move and is responsible for hundreds of deaths and injuries. Working hours beyond human endurance, poor maintenance, overloading of vehicles even with dangerous loads, illegal cabotage operations that exploit poor work and rely on the so-called freedom of movement of EU services and workers are incentives for profitability, competitiveness criteria of transport companies.  The individual objections of the political groups of the European Parliament to the Commission's decision, on the basis of existing problems, are raised in the light of business competition. Not only do they not solve the problem but they move within the framework of the EU single market and the policy of low labour costs and business profitability. Transport workers must claim human working conditions. Employers are responsible for all infringements due to labour exploitation and intensification conditions and they must be punished.   The EU can only be built on the over-exploitation of workers. There is no solution within it but to release it, in conflict with monopolies and their power.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because it precludes the adoption of the draft Council Directive, since I consider that this draft Directive is not compatible with the objective and content of Directive 98/70/EU. I believe that the Commission should withdraw its draft Council Directive and submit a new one to the Committee based on the obligation to declare the default average values for the intensity of greenhouse gas emissions broken down by types of raw materials in relation to petrol and diesel, while allowing suppliers to declare the actual values. Since the motion for a resolution calls for exactly this, I voted for it in favour.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this motion to reject the new fuel-quality standards proposed this year by the European Commission. These watered-down proposals from the Commission have given into the heavy lobbying efforts of the Canadian Government and will risk a significant increase of oil derived from tar sands into the European Union. Tar sands are highly polluting and it is very disappointing to see the European Commission bow to oil industry pressure instead of prioritising the climate.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted against this text, which aims to impose even stricter conditions on our industries, which are already heavily penalised in relation to non-EU competition.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. — I voted against the Resolution and in favour of the Commission's proposal because the objective of the Commission's proposal was to establish a methodology that is clear and effective in measuring the reduction of 6% of emissions from fuels intended for transport, as set out in Article 7 of Directive 98/70 and always on the basis of the types of crude oil used in 2010. Parliament's resolution went further, wanting to restrict a type of crude oil that can be used in the EU and this would have very negative consequences for European industry which has made large investments to achieve the target of a 6% REDUCTION in CO2 and which agree to implement the methodology proposed.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The European Union introduces environmental specifications for fuels to reduce polluting emissions from cars. Directive 98/70/EC aims to meet the commitment of Directive 94/12/EC, which provided for the subsequent adoption of target values with a substantial reduction in polluting emissions from motor vehicles. We are being asked here by this motion for a resolution to oppose the adoption of the Council's draft directive, considering that it does not set strict enough requirements, particularly on emissions based on average values by default of the intensity of greenhouse gas emissions during production itself (which is undeniably impossible to assess). This proposal therefore introduces far too restrictive additional fuel standards and, in view of these explanations, I have spoken out against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted against this resolution, which would impose on each fuel supplier the burden of calculating individually the GHG intensity of its products according to the original raw material used to produce them. This is with the stated aim of discouraging the use of Canadian tar sands. As a result, every fuel supplier (be it an SME – the owner of a petrol station, the supermarket – or an oil company) should have a reporting system that associates the original raw material with each volume of petrol and diesel sold. This is unrealistic and would give rise to an enormous administrative burden both for fuel suppliers and for the Member States, which are required to monitor it. In addition, the most "unscrupulous" operators could benefit from the practical impossibility of verifying the declared data, to the detriment of the most rigorous operators. Finally, EU refineries would see the cost of raw materials increase compared to competitors from third countries, with a further loss of competitiveness and the consequent possible closure.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal for an objection for the Commission to withdraw the implementing act on the new methods of calculation of the Fuel Quality Directive. The calculation method proposed by the Commission does not adequately meet the needs for further information and traceability. It is necessary to indicate the intensity of greenhouse gas emissions, not for the overall product, but for each of the fuel components, so that, for each petrol, diesel, etc., to be used in the EU, its degree of contribution to greenhouse gas emissions is known and, therefore, , if the product meets the requirements and objectives of the Quality Directive (6 % less intensity by 2020) and other derived directives relating to emission limits.  The Commission must continue to work to find a measurement method that encourages the use of more sustainable fuels by production companies and the progressive abandonment of the most environmentally harmful crudes and unconventional fuels.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this motion to reject the new fuel-quality standards proposed this year by the European Commission. These watered-down proposals from the Commission have given into the heavy lobbying efforts of the Canadian Government and will risk a significant increase of oil derived from tar sands into the European Union. Tar sands are highly polluting and it is very disappointing to see the European Commission bow to oil industry pressure instead of prioritising the climate.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal for a directive because I think it goes in the right direction in order to protect our environment.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — The European Parliament has just voted by a very small majority on the 2014/0286 directive, which will not penalise the import of oil from the oil sands through a European tax. As you know, the exploitation of these deposits alone emits 23% more carbon than traditional hydrocarbons. In addition, oil sands techniques are highly water-intensive and have irreversible effects on soil destruction, particularly in Canada's boreal forest. An increase in imports facilitated under the CETA agreement will result in an increase in the production of this type of hydrocarbons. The adoption of this proposed directive relentlessly demonstrates that the European Union is sacrificing all its social, health and environmental standards on the altar of free trade with Canada and the United States. That is why I voted against the adoption of this text.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — I am voting against. Negative measure for the Italian economy. Among other things, EU refineries would see the cost of raw materials increase compared to competitors from third countries, with a further loss of competitiveness and the consequent possible closure.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. — The Commission's proposal is to measure the greenhouse gas emission intensity of the total sum of fuel components, so that for each petrol, diesel, etc. to be used in the EU, its level of contribution to greenhouse gas emissions is known and, therefore, , if the product meets the requirements and objectives of the Quality Directive (6% less intensity by 2020) and other derived emission limit directives. To this end, although the origin of each and every component of the product is degreased so that sensitive data such as the inclusion of material from bituminous sands is accessed, the method proposed by the Commission does not specify the quantity used in the product as a whole for each component. That is, generic use is recorded but not of the quantity used. Understanding that the Commission should work more on the calculation method before finally approving it, the Delegation supported, like the Group, the Resolution with objections to the Commission's proposal.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the draft Council directive laying down methods of calculation and reporting requirements on the quality of petrol and diesel fuel amending Council Regulation (EC) No 55/2008. I share the view expressed in the resolution, which opposes the adoption of the draft directive, considering that the draft is not compatible with the purpose of Directive 98/70/EC, and I call on the Commission to withdraw the draft and present another. In particular, I am convinced that we need a further review of the method used to calculate the levels of greenhouse gas emissions from fuels and other non-biological energy sources. This is to take into account the expected increase in the use of fuels with high levels of greenhouse gas intensity and fuels derived from other emerging raw materials.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on ‘Draft Council Directive .../.../EU laying down calculation methods and reporting requirements pursuant to Directive 98/70/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council relating to the quality of petrol and diesel fuels’. If passed, this motion could make it easier for fuel products from tar sands and shale (obtained from fracking) to enter the EU market.  Unconventional sources of fuel like tar sands, oil shale and coal-to-liquid have a higher GHG lifecycle intensity. This means that in order to make petrol or diesel from these kind of feedstocks, it will cost more energy and therefore emit more greenhouse gases.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — I voted against this objection. I believe that the members who raised it have put forward arguments which are spurious for the simple objective of combating a sector which, at the moment, produces energy for our daily needs and in particular for a large part of our travels. In my opinion, the demands of the objectors are excessive and not proportionate to the benefits they could possibly generate. If we want a more environmentally sustainable economy, the discourse needs to be much broader.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I support what Mr La Via said in the text of the resolution, namely to ask the Commission to withdraw the draft Council directive because it is not compatible with the aims and content of Directive 98/70/EC. The European Union has climate and energy targets to be achieved by 2050, including decarbonisation, i.e. the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. In order to overcome the problem of pollution, we should not only improve the quality of fuels but also develop a European strategy to encourage the use of new, sustainable, competitive and safe energy technologies.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because it precludes the adoption of the draft Council Directive, since I consider that this draft Directive is not compatible with the objective and content of Directive 98/70/EU. I believe that the Commission should withdraw its draft Council Directive and submit a new one to the Committee based on the obligation to declare the default average values for the intensity of greenhouse gas emissions broken down by types of raw materials in relation to petrol and diesel, while allowing suppliers to declare the actual values. Since the motion for a resolution calls for exactly this, I voted for it in favour.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on the Commission to withdraw the draft Council directive and to submit a new one to the committee, based on the requirement that disaggregated average default GHG intensity values be reported by feedstock types for petrol and diesel, while allowing suppliers to report actual values.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. — The Directive on the quality of gasoline and diesel fuels is, in particular, the result of an acceptable compromise found on methods for calculating greenhouse gas (GHG) emission intensity. That is why the EPP Group opposed the vote on a resolution which would have required a further revision of the directive. In the run-up to the Paris Climate Conference in 2015, this directive already shows the European Union's efforts to reduce GHGs. For example, it requires suppliers to reduce the lifetime GHG intensity of all fuels by 6% by December 31, 2020.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The European Union has set a target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 20% by 2020. From this perspective, the transport sector is concerned at 6%. The oil sands are one of the most polluting sources of energy supply, releasing 23% more carbon into the atmosphere than conventional fuels. By refusing to take into account the harmful effects of diesel, the Commission therefore contradicts the European objectives, emptying this draft directive of its substance. With less than a year to go until the COP21 climate change conference in Paris, this setback is a bad signal to the international community. I very much hope that this is only a temporary delay and that we can, as early as 2015, continue our efforts to combat warming.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Written. — The implementation of the Fuel Quality Directive is a thorny issue, which has been dragging on for a number of years. The 2020 deadline is getting closer and closer. A solution is therefore a question of resolution.  It is clear that the perfect solution does not exist, but the proposal put on the table by the European Commission and agreed with the Member States is undeniably a step forward.  The aim is to reduce the carbon content of road transport fuels by 6% by 2020. The Commission is committed to achieving this objective on the basis of the text before us. Moreover, the proposal ensures greater transparency and traceability by ensuring that specific requirements apply to reporting on crude oil imports, which is new. The Commission's proposal seems to us to be feasible, realistic and balanced. That is why the N-VA voted against the Committee on the Environment and therefore supported the European Commission's proposal. Nevertheless, the N-VA understands certain concerns about the proposal, but the overall balance sheet is rather positive.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. — The proposed resolution is built on an ideological vision of ecology by asking for the calculation of greenhouse gas emissions released during fuel production. I voted against this resolution, which would be to tighten the directive and increase the constraints on our industries and businesses, particularly in the oil sector, a burden synonymous with loss of competitiveness and low economic dynamism.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution because it opposes the adoption of the draft directive, which does not provide for a report on the origin of the raw materials used.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — Fuel suppliers shall report on greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions throughout the life cycle, per unit of fuel energy and energy supplied. It is well known that there are significant differences in ghg emission intensity between fuels such as traditional crude oil and non-conventional raw materials (e.g. bituminous sands), with emissions on average higher in the latter. However, the Commission makes a clear plank of these differences and assumes emission values common to different fuels. A clear favour to multinationals involved in the exploitation of non-conventional fuels, which grossly underestimates the GHG emissions associated with it. An inseparable favour of the free trade agreement that the European Commission is negotiating with Canada – a country with significant projects in the field of unconventional oil – and which aims to please the economic groups interested in this agreement. This resolution opposes the adoption of the draft Directive and calls on the Commission to withdraw and submit a new one, on the basis of the requirement to report average GHG intensity values by default, disaggregated by type of raw material, with regard to petrol and diesel fuel, while allowing suppliers to communicate real values. We voted in favour.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing — The revised Fuel Quality Directive obliges suppliers to submit an annual report on greenhouse gas emissions. As of 31 December 2020, the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by at least 6 % in each Member State is set. In its impact assessment, the European Commission assessed a range of other options, in addition to a basic reporting approach based on average standard ghg emissions by fuel type. However, in distinguishing fuels from unconventional sources, it has not taken into account the latest changes in infrastructure and the oil market, so it is important that the European Commission examine more thoroughly the method used to calculate the level of emissions and take into account the projected increase in the use of high-intensity greenhouse gas and fuel fuels obtained from new raw materials.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — (IT) I do not agree with the proposal because there would be too many burdens on individual distributors in Europe and our refineries would see the cost of raw materials increase compared with competitors from third countries, with a further loss of competitiveness and the consequent possible closure.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the proposal for a Council directive laying down calculation methods and reporting requirements in accordance with Directive 98/70/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council on the quality of petrol and diesel fuels (which opposes the adoption of the draft directive), as there is no provision for reporting on the origin of the raw materials used.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. — Today I abstained on the vote on the objection related to the FQD. The objectors oppose the draft Council directive on the grounds that it is not compatible with the aim and content of the basic instrument due to the methodology proposed in the measure being inappropriate for an accurate estimating and reporting of the volume, type, origin and life cycle greenhouse gas emissions of fuels supplied. However, apart from picking a few points out of the COM IA, the objectors fail to prove that the measure is incompatible with the aim and content of the basic act. Although it is not perfect, the new proposal provides a basic tracking system that will encourage the use of electricity in transport and incentivise oil producers to reduce emissions from highly polluting processes. Yes, we need to ensure that suppliers avoid high-carbon fuels, but we must minimise additional burdens in terms of reporting. With the Commission intent on removing the FQD from its post-2020 energy and climate framework, the adoption of this objection will only serve to undermine the credibility of this directive by forcing an additional institutional delay on a piece of legislation set to expire in six years.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - We voted in favour to prevent the use of bituminous sands and shale gas. The EU sticks to oil interests with the Commission's proposal to launch Article 7a of the Fuel Quality Directive, which does not discriminate against the consumption of the dirtiest fuels, therefore hindering the objective for which it was created: the reduction of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by 2020. Scientific studies say that unconventional oils cause higher GHG emissions than conventional oils: 23% more for bituminous sands, and 50% more for bituminous shale. US oil companies, as well as Repsol, together with the Governments of Canada and the US, opposed oil typology differentiation and the penalty of the most polluting ones head-on. After eight years of delays, due to pressures from Canada, the U.S. and large oil companies, a regulation is finally passed according to their interests. In this way, the EU puts trade agreements (AECG-ATCI) before its already uns ambitious climate commitments.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. —I voted against this motion for a resolution to reverse the compromise reached by the European Commission. The authors of the resolution would like to see a return to the crude oil from which it is derived, to give a sort of rating to each fuel according to its unit intensity of greenhouse gas emissions. This would be very expensive, especially for all SMEs in the oil sector that are located after the refining phase, and would be very difficult to set up. Refined products are indeed the subject of many blends and changes of owners. The system proposed by the European Commission to retain an average default value representing the unit intensity of greenhouse gas emissions per type of fuel is more balanced. It has the merit of not disadvantageing EU-made fuels in favour of imported products whose traceability is more difficult to ensure. In conclusion, it is better to have the compromise text proposed by the Commission, which is imperfect but satisfactory, than no text at all for years to come. The compromise that has been reached is the result of several years of negotiations.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because I do not believe that all fuel types should have the same average emissions value and to me that is crucial. Our purpose here is to determine how the 6% reduction target in greenhouse gas emissions from fossil fuels for transport can be calculated. There is no point in having a target if we cannot measure that target with reasonable accuracy. For example tar sands have a carbon intensity of 20% above the level of commercial fuels, while the carbon intensity of oil sand is even higher – approximately 40% above the level of conventional fuels. Yes, I understand there are issues in regard to Estonia and we should have some kind of transitional arrangement but an outcome of today’s vote could be that there now is an incentive to bring these high-emission fuels to the EU market instead of driving investments into more sustainable low-carbon alternatives.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. — Reducing greenhouse gas emissions from marketed fuels is an important element of the European Union's efforts to combat climate change. The European Union cannot afford not to meet its emission reduction targets. At the same time, we must achieve the objectives set in a sustainable manner, taking into account the interests of industry. We need to create regulations that minimise the bureaucratic burden on economic operators and effectively promote sustainable climate protection.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We voted in favour to prevent the use of bituminous sands and shale gas. The EU sticks to oil interests with the European Commission's proposal to launch Article 7a of the Fuel Quality Directive, which does not discriminate against the consumption of the dirtiest fuels, therefore hampering the objective for which it was created: the reduction of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by 2020. Scientific studies say that unconventional oils cause higher GHG emissions than conventional oils: 23% more for bituminous sands, and 50% more for bituminous shale. US oil companies, as well as Repsol, together with the Governments of Canada and the US, opposed oil typology differentiation and the penalty of the most polluting ones head-on. After eight years of delays, due to pressures from Canada, the U.S. and large oil companies, a regulation is finally passed according to their interests. In this way, the EU puts trade agreements (AECG-ATCI) before its already uns ambitious climate commitments.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted AGAINST the Resolution on the Commission's draft directive establishing the method of calculation and reporting requirements in accordance with Directive 98/70/EC on the quality of petrol and diesel fuels on the grounds that it asks for the draft Council directive to be withdrawn, which certainly does not meet the highest required environmental standards, but also aligns the need to reduce CO2 emissions with the current needs of the economic sector engaged in the production and distribution of fuels. The Directive also takes into account the non-compliance of the manufacturer's technology and also takes into account the practical implementation of future measures through the differentiation of fuel types. This allows for a directive to be implemented in the short term with a view to reducing CO2 by 6%. With the adoption of the Resolution, the procedure would be extended without precise deadlines and in the short term the damage to the environment would be greater.  During the vote, I also took into account the needs of the Croatian economy and the previous positions of the Croatian government, as well as the need of the Estonian oil industry, which would be put into trouble that would have political implications in addition to economic ones.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. — I voted against this resolution on the Council's proposal for a directive setting out calculation methods and reporting requirements under the Petrol and Diesel Fuels Quality Directive. This resolution called into question the compromise reached by the European Commission, which is to retain a default average value representing the unit intensity of greenhouse gas emissions by type of fuel.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: Writing. — I voted against the EP resolution on the rejection of the draft Council directive laying down calculation methods and reporting requirements in accordance with Directive 98/70/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council on the quality of petrol and diesel fuel. Having considered the pros and cons of this implementing act over a long period of time, I can conclude that rejection would have been a unilaterally biased decision that would harm Estonia's national economic interests and put a strain on social problems. Certainly, such a negative decision would not benefit from the spirit of constructive compromise on which the European Union is founded as a rule of action, seeking to take into account the interests of the various parties.  The rejection of the directive would have meant that the Commission should have started the development of a new fuel quality draft, which would have been very time-consuming. Such time and hesitation would have sent a negative signal to future investors in a situation where the new European Commission is trying to restore private sector confidence with all its powers and create a stable atmosphere of economic activity. In my opinion, this directive meets both the EU's greenhouse gas cap targets in the transport sector (-6%) and the need to strengthen energy security by providing a fair playing field for local energy resources and increasing the security of energy supplies to the EU energy market. In the case of Estonia, it is particularly important that there be a transition from burning oil shale to production of shale oil with a much lower oil production.  This can be done in a situation where investors are given confidence that the rules will not be changed lightly. I am pleased that the vast majority of my group (the Group of the European People's Party) voted against rejecting the directive.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I supported the resolution objecting to the Commission’s proposal, as I believe that it is detrimental to the overall aim of the directive, namely to reduce CO2 emissions and move towards a carbon-free energy supply in Europe.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted against the objection made by some colleagues to the proposal for a Council directive laying down methods of calculation and reporting obligations with regard to the quality of petrol and diesel fuel, because I believe that the methods used by the Commission are appropriate and in accordance with the objectives set out in Directive 98/70/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council governing precisely these aspects.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because it precludes the adoption of the draft Council Directive, since I consider that this draft Directive is not compatible with the objective and content of Directive 98/70/EU. I believe that the Commission should withdraw its draft Council Directive and submit a new one to the Committee based on the obligation to declare the default average values for the intensity of greenhouse gas emissions broken down by types of raw materials in relation to petrol and diesel, while allowing suppliers to declare the actual values. Since the motion for a resolution calls for exactly this, I voted for it in favour.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — The methods set out in this Report do not offer a clear and precise form for calculating greenhouse gas emissions into the environment. The reason is in the proposed documents from which the origin, extent, type and lifecycle of greenhouse gases cannot be accurately assessed. I call on the Commission to adopt implementing measures relating to the greenhouse gas monitoring and reduction mechanism. The Commission is currently considering a method for calculating greenhouse gas emissions generated from fuel and other energy from non-biologic sources. In this context, I believe that suppliers' annual reports need to be harmonised before they are submitted to the Member States and then Member States should do the same in the Commission reporting process, all for the purpose of quality and easy monitoring and reduction of greenhouse gas emissions in the Union. Because of all of the above, I did not support this Report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. — Fuel quality is an area on which the European Union is working and is being supplemented continuously. This is linked both to the protection of the environment and to the quality of life of people. I (as well as my political group) voted in favour, but the resolution was unfortunately rejected by a majority of MEPs. Let us continue to work on this!

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the draft Council Directive .../.../EU laying down calculation methods and reporting requirements in accordance with Directive 98/70/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council on the quality of petrol and diesel fuels, because it adequately regulates this issue.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. - The Commission's directive on calculation methods and reporting requirements relating to the quality of petrol and diesel fuel has as its ultimate objective a 6% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2020. It also sets out the methodology for calculating emissions, the exchange of information and the administrative burdens for Member States and fuel suppliers. I therefore consider the Commission's proposal to be satisfactory, which is why I voted against the motion for a resolution which seeks to withdraw the directive.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — Environmental protection is an important concern. By including transport routes and the extraction methods of raw materials, especially oil and the products derived from them, in the carbon footprint of the respective product, we create a fairer and more truthful life cycle assessment. That is why I voted in favour of the proposal. It also makes it more difficult to find ecologically questionable methods of extracting oil and gas in the European Union or to sell the products derived from these processes.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — The revised Directive 98/70/EC requires fuel suppliers to report annual greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions over the entire life cycle per unit of energy supplied in each Member State. The Council's proposed directive aims to establish the methods of calculating these GHGs. Parliament's report is highly critical of the method used. It does not allow for recent changes in infrastructure and the oil market, including the generalization of fuels from unconventional sources (tar sands, shale, liquefied coal,...) What is the point of setting 6% GHG reduction targets by 2020 if the methods of calculating emissions do not even measure the results achieved? I'm voting for this report.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — Directive 98/70/EU (revised) on the specifications of petrol and diesel requires suppliers to draw up an annual report on greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions over the life cycle, per unit of fuel and energy energy supplied in each Member State and reducing by at least 6 % the intensity of GHG emissions over the life cycle of fuels supplied by 31 December 2020 compared to the European lifetime emissions average per unit of energy produced from fossil fuels in 2010. I believe that the draft Council Directive is not compatible with the purpose and content of Directive 98/70/EU. It would therefore be important for the Commission to submit a proposal compatible with that Directive.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — I voted against this resolution because the Council directive obliges suppliers to reduce the life-cycle greenhouse gas intensity of fuel and other (electric) energy supplied for use in road vehicles and of fuel for use in non-road mobile machinery by the end of 2020 by 6%. This reduction would likely result from the wider use of biofuels and electricity and a drop in the flaring and venting of fossil fuels during their extraction, all of which are measures which overlap other environmental initiatives promoted by the EU. The creation of a calculation method is therefore required for these goals to be achieved.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I am in agreement with the report on quality of petrol and diesel fuels, which will contribute significantly to reducing the climate impact of transport.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The European Union introduces environmental standards for fuels to reduce greenhouse gases. Directive 98/70/EC aims to meet the commitment of Directive 94/12/EC, which provided for the subsequent implementation of target values contributing to a substantial reduction in polluting emissions from motor vehicles. With this motion for a resolution, we are asked to vote for five very technical and mathematical methods of calculation aimed at meeting ever stricter requirements, particularly on emissions, based on average values by default of the intensity of greenhouse gas emissions during production itself (which is undeniably impossible to assess). This proposal therefore introduces additional fuel standards and clauses that are far too restrictive and that ignore the public interest in favour of a shopkeeper's mind; I voted against it.

name: Alessandra MORETTI
text: in writing. — (IT) I regret the result of today's vote which led to the rejection of the objection made to the proposal put forward by the European Commission for the implementation of the fuel quality directive. The Commission's proposal does not, in fact, allow the differentiation between the intensity of greenhouse gases and different raw materials and, consequently, not even the communication of real emissions from individual fuels, with an average value that is 40% lower than that of the 2011 proposal for a directive, which was never adopted due to opposition from the Council. In particular, my group believes that the implementation proposal is detrimental to the overall objective of the directive, namely to reduce CO2 emissions and to move towards a carbon-free energy supply in Europe. I hope at least that the proposal, as adopted, will allow and facilitate the achievement of the target of a 6% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions for fuels by 2020.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. The stated aim of this resolution is to ask the Council to withdraw its proposal for a directive and to make a new proposal to Parliament. Indeed, this text considers that the Council's proposal runs counter to the objectives of the revised 98/70/EC Directive, which requires "fuel suppliers to report annual greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions produced over the entire life cycle per unit of energy supplied in each Member State and to reduce by 6 % by 31 December 2020 the life-cycle GHG emission intensity for all fuels supplied relative to the EU average value of GHG emissions over the entire life cycle per unit of energy attributed to fossil fuels in 2010."

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I voted against the draft because I consider the european Commission's draft directive to be reasonable. The directive is balanced and also takes into account the special situation in Estonia in terms of oil shale. The resolution would have significantly increased the ambiguity.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: In writing. "I voted against it. Very knowledgeable on the subject since my work on the biofuels directive in 2013, I believe that the revision of the Fuel Quality Directive threatens to strengthen the market share of oil from tar sands, which is de facto inciting increased production. We strongly opposed its adoption and we condemn the european Parliament's favourable vote. In the current and forthgoing trade negotiations, we will not compromise on European environmental standards: the fight against climate change is everywhere and all the time! We deplore the fact that a Conservative majority has supported the Commission in its lack of political courage, while the consequences on the climate will be catastrophic if the European Union does not take the necessary measures to reduce polluting emissions from transport.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Ladies and gentlemen, the revised Directive 98/70/EC on the quality of petrol and diesel fuel requires suppliers to report annually on life-cycle greenhouse gas emissions per unit of energy due to fuels and energy supplied in each Member State and to reduce by at least 6% by 31 December 2020, the intensity of greenhouse gases produced during the life cycle of fuels, provided in relation to the Community average of emissions per unit of energy produced during the life cycle of fossil fuels in 2010. The method used to calculate levels of greenhouse gas emissions from fuels and other non-biological energy sources should be further reviewed to take into account the expected increase in the use of fuels with high levels of greenhouse gas intensity and fuels derived from other emerging raw materials. For these reasons, I would vote against it.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. — I consider the current proposal for a directive to be wrong, as it is clearly contrary to the EU's objectives of reducing emissions and promoting a low-carbon economy. This proposal needs to be revised and I regret that a minority of Members blocked parliament's motion for a resolution, which called on the Commission to revise the draft directive. By adopting the proposal, the European Union would lower its environmental standards instead of encouraging other non-European states to promote cleaner transport. I fundamentally disagree with the link between the directive and the EU-Canada free trade agreement, as we have been presented, probably under pressure from a strong lobby, by some colleagues, e.g. the ECR Group.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — I voted against this resolution which opposes the adoption of the draft Council Directive establishing calculation methods and reporting requirements in accordance with the Directive of the European Parliament and the Council on the quality of petrol and diesel fuel. The fact that the appropriate measures for the calculation and to measure compliance with the already established targets of 6 % reduction in greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions are sufficient. In this context, the use of a standard average value to represent the GHG emission intensity unit per fuel type, as well as the annual reports drawn up by suppliers and Member States have created a viable and reliable basis for the Commission in order to comply with the existing Directive.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. — The European Parliament voted in plenary against a motion to reject the Council's draft method for calculating fuel quality. However, this proposal for a directive is in contrast to the direction the European Union should take in the fight for climate preservation. On the contrary, this project is in the interests of the oil lobby, and will favour the dirtiest hydrocarbons, such as the oil sands. At a time when we should all be united around the preparation of COP 21, and at a time when transport is among the most greenhouse gas-emitting sectors, the majority of MEPs have not wanted to take responsibility for future generations, who will suffer tomorrow the consequences of our shortcomings in climate protection. There is an urgent need for the European Union to finally work on a real energy transition policy, which favours alternative fuels, which are more environmentally friendly, and clean modes of transport.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. — The best is the enemy of the good: this is how we could sum up the attempt by some Members of the Environment Committee to change the method of calculation to reduce CO2 emissions in transport. The dossier is technical, but the answer is political: do we want to question five years of work done by the European Commission with the experts to put in place a method of calculation as envisaged by the directive of 98 on the quality of fuels? My answer this afternoon, like that given by 325 other MEPs, is NO.  For at least three reasons: - it is risky to draw a distinction in terms of CO2 emissions based on the origin of the oil used to make the fuels; - the calculation method proposed by the Commission meets the target of reducing CO2 emissions in transport by 6% by 2020.  And the argument for European energy security is important. By rejecting the Commission's proposal, we would have undermined the predictability of investment in the sensitive sector of the fuel industry. Where Europe instead needs to ensure secure channels for the supply of its energy.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal for an objection for the Commission to withdraw the implementing act on the new methods of calculation of the Fuel Quality Directive. The calculation method proposed by the Commission does not adequately meet the needs for further information and traceability. It is necessary to indicate the intensity of greenhouse gas emissions, not for the overall product, but for each of the fuel components, so that, for each petrol, diesel, etc., to be used in the EU, its degree of contribution to greenhouse gas emissions is known and, therefore, , if the product meets the requirements and objectives of the Quality Directive (6 % less intensity by 2020) and other derived directives relating to emission limits.  The Commission must continue to work to find a measurement method that encourages the use of more sustainable fuels by production companies and the progressive abandonment of the most environmentally harmful crudes and unconventional fuels.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - We voted in favour to prevent the use of bituminous sands and shale gas. The EU sticks to oil interests with the European Commission's proposal to launch Article 7a of the Fuel Quality Directive, which does not discriminate against the consumption of the dirtiest fuels, therefore hampering the objective for which it was created: the reduction of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by 2020. Scientific studies say that unconventional oils cause higher GHG emissions than conventional oils: 23% more for bituminous sands, and 50% more for bituminous shale. US oil companies, as well as Repsol, together with the Governments of Canada and the US, opposed oil typology differentiation and the penalty of the most polluting ones head-on. After eight years of delays, due to pressures from Canada, the U.S. and large oil companies, a regulation is finally passed according to their interests. In this way, the EU puts trade agreements (AECG-ATCI) before its already uns ambitious climate commitments.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution which calls on the Commission to withdraw its proposal for a Council directive and to submit a new proposal based on the requirement to report emissions according to average values by default of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions intensity, broken down by types of basic material for petrol and diesel fuel , while allowing suppliers to report actual values. The Commission's text had indeed seemed to me to be too weak and unacceptable because, moreover, the proposed method of calculating the carbon intensity of different types of road fuels did not encourage cleaner fuels and put on the same footing the oil sands, which were extremely polluting, and conventional crude oil. I further felt that the method of calculating GHG emissions from fuels and other forms of energy from non-biological sources should be further studied to take into account the expected increase in the use of fuels with high GHG intensity and fuels derived from other developing commodities.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. — I would like to support the proposal to support the draft directive. Fuel quality is a very important issue because it directly affects the air that we all breathe. However, the amendments tabled are minimal and will not have a significant ecological impact. On the other hand, the proposal will have a significant economic impact, as it will provide significant opportunities for a wider range of fuel sources. This is particularly important in view of the need to diversify fuel sources. It is also necessary not to undermine the competitiveness of EU economies such as Estonia, which has long been widely used for domestic shale hydrocarbons. I therefore call on my colleagues to vote unequivocally against the draft resolution drafted by the rapporteur calling for the Commission's proposal to be rejected.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote against because I believe that this measure creates more damage to the European petrochemical sector than the environmental benefits it seeks to achieve. In addition, EU refineries would see the cost of raw materials increase compared to competitors from third countries, with a further loss of competitiveness and the consequent possible closure.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - We voted in favour to prevent the use of bituminous sands and shale gas. The EU sticks to oil interests with the Commission's proposal to launch Article 7a of the Fuel Quality Directive, which does not discriminate against the consumption of the dirtiest fuels, therefore hindering the objective for which it was created: the reduction of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by 2020. Scientific studies say that unconventional oils cause higher GHG emissions than conventional oils: 23% more for bituminous sands, and 50% more for bituminous shale. US oil companies, as well as Repsol, together with the Governments of Canada and the US, opposed oil typology differentiation and the penalty of the most polluting ones head-on. After eight years of delays, due to pressures from Canada, the U.S. and large oil companies, a regulation is finally passed according to their interests. In this way, the EU puts trade agreements (AECG-ATCI) before its already uns ambitious climate commitments.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because it precludes the adoption of the draft Council Directive, since I consider that this draft Directive is not compatible with the objective and content of Directive 98/70/EU. I believe that the Commission should withdraw its draft Council Directive and submit a new one to the Committee based on the obligation to declare the default average values for the intensity of greenhouse gas emissions broken down by types of raw materials in relation to petrol and diesel, while allowing suppliers to declare the actual values. Since the motion for a resolution calls for exactly this, I voted for it in favour.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — While the proposal for this Directive seeks to reduce in principle the intensity of greenhouse gases, lays down a decarbonisation obligation, requires suppliers to calculate greenhouse gas emissions in life expectancy for biofuels, requires the use of the same average default values for all fossil raw materials, I consider that not all necessary parameters have been taken into account when establishing the method, which would be a guarantee for further emission reduction or preservation of environmental integrity, and I support the rollback of the draft Council directive. I agree to the submission of applications on broken average greenhouse gas intensity set values and on reporting by types of raw materials for petrol and diesel fuels, as well as allowing suppliers to report actual values. For these reasons, I did not support this proposal.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — The draft Directive on the quality of petrol and diesel fuels must provide for the submission of a report on the basis of the origin of the raw materials used.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution opposing the adoption of the draft directive, as the Commission does not distinguish between the different fuel materials in this draft. The Directive would introduce a uniform value for greenhouse gas emission intensity for all types of fuels. This means, among other things, that shale oil (or sand oil) will not be distinguished from conventional crude oil, although it is responsible for more greenhouse gas emissions. This makes it easier for unconventional fuels to reach Europe.   The draft was presented to Parliament after some five years of preparation, with the fundamental aim of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 6% by 2020. However, this draft does not seem to have fully fulfilled the expectations expressed. The representatives of the Socialists and Democrats in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety have united in their opposition to the draft. In my opinion, some elements of the draft are acceptable, but overall they do not work. With my vote, I wanted to encourage the European Commission to formulate another alternative proposal that removes these obstacles.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the Council's proposal for a directive setting out calculation methods and reporting requirements under the European Parliament and Council's Directive 98/70/EC on the quality of petrol and diesel fuels. Nevertheless, I note with great regret that this proposal was rejected because, once again, some elected officials preferred to defend their particular interests rather than the public interest.

name: Yana TOOM
text: in writing. — I did not support the resolution objecting to the adoption of the Implementing Act of the Fuel Quality Directive. In the Estonian context the Implementing Act would promote the usage of shale oil for the production of liquid fuels instead of electricity production. As a result, there will be positive impact on waste management and emission of pollutants. The development of the shale oil production industry has considerable influence on the gross domestic product of Estonia, its foreign trade balance and labour market, especially in the northern-eastern Ida-Viru County, inhabited by Russian-speaking minorities.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. — The resolution rejects a proposal for a directive and calls on the committee to present a more binding text which would have serious consequences for our industries and our businesses.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. — My vote in favour of this motion for a resolution is justified because I believe that it is necessary to criticise the methodology proposed by the Commission for the draft Directive on fuel quality, as it discourages the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions in the fossil fuel production chain.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. — This draft resolution calls on the Council to make a new proposal for a directive on calculation methods and reporting requirements under Directive 98/70/EC on the quality of petrol and diesel fuels. This proposal runs counter to European commitments to reduce greenhouse gas emissions as set out in this directive. It requires fuel suppliers to report their greenhouse gas emissions each year, with the aim of reducing them by 6% in 2020 compared to 2010. This directive is therefore a fundamental tool in the European fight against climate change. But with this proposal, the Commission is deliberately weakening it. By removing the ability to distinguish between the raw materials that cause the fuels used, it opens the door wide to the massive use of shale gas and the oil sands, much to the delight of the Canadian lobby whose influence we have seen in recent weeks. So I voted for this resolution. But this was rejected to my great regret, as the right-wing and far-right MPs, including French, including liberals, voted against it, paying attention to industrial and economic lobbies.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — We know that there are significant differences in ghg emission intensity between fuels such as traditional crude oil and non-conventional raw materials (e.g. bituminous sands), with emissions on average higher in the latter. The Commission makes a clear impact on these differences and assumes emission values common to different fuels, which is a clear favour for multinationals involved in the exploitation of non-conventional fuels, which grossly underestimates the GHG emissions associated with it. An inseparable favour of the free trade agreement that the European Commission is negotiating with Canada. This resolution opposes the adoption of the draft Directive and calls on the Commission to withdraw and submit a new one, on the basis of the requirement to report average GHG intensity values by default disaggregated by raw material type, with regard to petrol and diesel fuel, while allowing suppliers to communicate real values. We voted in favour.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — We are creating a fairer and more truthful life cycle assessment through the inclusion of transport routes and the extraction methods of raw materials, especially oil and the products derived from them, into the carbon footprint of the product in hand. Since environmental protection also offers me sustainability in the interests of the economy, and because this proposal also makes environmentally questionable methods of oil and gas extraction or sale in the European Union more difficult, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: Written. - (FI) Mr President, the Juncker Commission is now focusing its work programme heavily on stable regulation and a predictable environment for businesses. The vote on the implementation of this directive on fuel quality was about exactly the same thing – are we creating certainty for businesses in the future or not?  The Directive on fuel quality aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from transport by 6% by 2020. This is a good objective and a strong signal for biofuel companies: your investment has paid off and together we can work towards climate protection. By adopting the proposal made by ENVI, we would have wiped off the table five years of extensive preparatory work, which has produced a balanced result. This directive and its content have had broad support, both in the Member States and in stakeholders.  Companies producing transport biofuels must be assured of their operating and investment environment. This should also be borne in mind in the forthcoming votes on this industrial sector.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing — The Slovak Government, through the Permanent Representation of the Slovak Republic to the EU, asked Slovak MEPs to vote in favour of rejecting the proposal for a directive on the quality of petrol and diesel fuels. This proposal improves the conditions for diversifying fuel sources by facilitating the entry of fuels obtained from unconventional sources into the European market. It represents a compromise, which is also agreed by the processors of Russian oil producing lower CO2 emissions, and by the states in which oil production from unconventional sources producing higher emissions is carried out or prepared.  Nevertheless, the Slovak Government pushed for this compromise to be rejected. This would lead to a strengthening of the position for refineries of the so-called 'old' EU Member States in further negotiations. The result would be a new proposal that would further worsen the position of the only Slovak fuel producer on the European market. I therefore voted against the proposal tabled by the Committee on the Environment and am glad that it was rejected.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the proposal for a Directive laying down calculation methods and reporting requirements under Parliament's and Council's Directive 98/70/EC on the quality of petrol and diesel fuel because I believe that the European Union must have a consistent position in the fight against climate change, in promoting clean energy and in the energy transition to a sustainable growth model.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — Fuel suppliers shall report on greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions throughout the life cycle, per unit of fuel energy and energy supplied. It is known that there are significant differences in ghg emission intensity between fuels such as traditional crude oil and unconventional raw materials (e.g. bituminous sands), with emissions on average higher in the latter. However, the European Commission makes a clear plank of these differences and assumes emission values common to different fuels. A clear favour to multinationals involved in the exploitation of unconventional fuels, which grossly underestimates the GHG emissions associated with it. This resolution opposes the adoption of the draft Directive and calls on the Commission to withdraw and submit a new one, on the basis of the requirement to report average GHG intensity values by default disaggregated by raw material type, with regard to petrol and diesel fuel, while allowing suppliers to communicate real values. We voted in favour.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — The opinion of ccTEP scientists supports the idea of reducing the reference measure for cod in the Baltic Sea. Given that the measures of this species have been reduced, and therefore 35 centimetres already ripe, I voted against the ecR Group's motion for a Resolution to support the decision of the CCTEP and the Baltic Sea Advisory Council.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. - I voted against the motion for resolution on the ‘Commission delegated regulation of 20 October 2014 establishing a discard plan in the Baltic Sea’. A landing obligation means that all fish (up to a certain size – juveniles can be released again) that are caught need to be landed and counted against the fishermen's quota. The reason for having this is to conserve the fish stock that is left in this highly overfished sea and try to keep the cod species alive in the Baltic. This resolution objecting to the entry into force of the landing obligation on 1 January 2015 for the fisheries in the Baltic Sea, would be environmentally unsustainable and would put the industry in this region into jeopardy.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted against this resolution. Its aim is to suspend the adoption of the Commission Delegated Regulation establishing a plan to reduce discards for the Baltic Sea. This Commission Regulation aims to reduce the catches of cod in the Baltic Sea, which would allow fishermen to supply trade fish of at least 35 cm, which would contribute to unnecessarily reducing discards and increasing the conservation of the Baltic Sea resources. At present, the minimum size is 38 cm. I fully support the Commission's new proposal and reject the resolution that opposes it.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The aim of this motion for a resolution is to object to the Commission's delegated regulation establishing a discharge plan for the Baltic Sea, which includes reducing the conservation reference size for cod in the Baltic Sea, thereby impairing the stock's reproductive capacity. In addition, the regulation requires a reduction in the conservation reference size for cod from 38 cm to 35 cm. This regulation thus represents the technocratic vision of this European Union unable to understand the real concerns of fishermen through the imposition of fussy and counterproductive standards. That is why I voted for this proposal.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — The Commission presented a delegated act on the Baltic discard plan providing for the reduction of cod TMRC from the current 38 cm to 35 cm. The EC justifies this reduction on the basis that cod has a very high density in the Baltic Sea and is therefore suffering from certain problems of reduced growth, increased parasites, etc., therefore discards have increased and mature specimens have reduced in size. The proposal to reduce TMRC does not imply further mortality, because the characteristics of the allowed networks do not change. According to the CCTEP, this reduction does not affect fry, because the deoves occur below those 35 cm. The reduction will have a positive effect on the economic yields of cod fish, as current discards of between 30 and 35 cm account for 83% in number and weight.  The Baltic Member States and the Baltic RAF also support it. In addition, the reduction in size will bring coherence with other regions, for example with the North Sea, where it is already 35 cm. That is why I voted against the proposal put forward on the Commission's delegated act.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted against this resolution because it was intended to prevent the entry into force of a favourable Commission decision between the Baltic Sea and Lithuanian fishermen. The Commission adopted a decision as early as October to reduce the volume of cod supplied to trade from 38 cm to 35 cm. Such a Commission decision, which will enter into force as early as 1 January 2015, will allow fishermen to sell more already caught cod to the food industry and reduce the amount of fish already caught but still discarded. At the same time, according to scientists, such a change in fishing regulation will not harm the restocking of fish stocks in the Baltic Sea at all, thus, in principle, allowing more responsible and more environmentally friendly fishing in the Baltic Sea.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted against this proposal for a regulation proposal because I think it is absolutely not ambitious enough with regard to the big challenges the Baltic zone is facing.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — The aim of this motion for a resolution is to object to the Commission's delegated regulation setting out a discharge plan for the Baltic Sea. This plan includes reducing the conservation reference size (from 38 cm to 35 cm) for cod in the Baltic Sea, directly affecting the species' reproductive capacity. As a result of the European Union's technocratic thinking, this regulation completely ignores the real concerns and needs of fishermen and is just aimed at imposing ever more fussy and counterproductive standards on them. For these reasons, I voted against this proposal.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — Abstention. We need an accurate tenic assessment of the biological cycle of cod in the Baltic Sea. In general, a reduction in size (in this case the proposal is to increase from 38 to 35 cm) can "confuse" that market with that of juveniles, but there is no technical evaluation of the merits.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. — The European Commission has presented a delegated act on the Baltic Sea discard plan. The plan envisages the reduction of the MCRS (Minimun Conservation Reference Size) of cod from the current 38 centimeters to 35.  The EC justifies this reduction in the minimum conservation reference size on the basis of several aspects; the Spanish delegation was particularly interested in the point on reducing size, which would bring coherence with other regions, for example with the North Sea, where it was already 35 cm. This sets a precedent in the approval of the minimum sizes that Spain will benefit when it requests the same for other species, such as hake in future demersal plans for Northwest and Southwest waters.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. "I voted against the resolution of objection to the delegated act setting out a discharge plan for the Baltic Sea. In the light of scientific advice, the Commission proposes a reduction in the minimum reference size for cod conservation in the Baltic Sea. This decline is based and validated by scientific advice and does not pose a danger to the species. This resolution was therefore not justified. Firstly, this discharge plan for the Baltic Sea has been accepted by all relevant Member States and is based on sound scientific advice. Second, the objection would have delayed the implementation of the reform of the Common Fisheries Policy. Finally, the objection would also have been contrary to the regionalisation envisaged by the reform of the common fisheries policy. This delegated act must be adopted before the end of the year. It will give professionals and national authorities visibility into the implementation of the landing obligation and the de minimis exemption provided for in the reform of the Common Fisheries Policy.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. — I voted against the motion for resolution on the ‘Commission delegated regulation of 20 October 2014 establishing a discard plan in the Baltic Sea’. A landing obligation means that all fish (up to a certain size – juveniles can be released again) that are caught need to be landed and counted against the fishermen’s quota. The reason for having this is to conserve the fish stock that is left in this highly overfished sea and try to keep the cod species alive in the Baltic. This resolution objecting to the entry into force of the landing obligation on 1 January 2015 for the fisheries in the Baltic Sea would be environmentally unsustainable and would put the industry in this region into jeopardy.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) The Conservative Group, which tabled this resolution in order to object to an act by the Commission, had very good intentions, but they run counter to practice: the proposed reduction should not, according to the studies, have the environmental impact that our Conservative colleagues fear, and it is therefore not worth changing this rule which, on the contrary, allows businesses and consumers a secure food supply.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I disapprove of the text of the resolution on the Commission's delegated regulation establishing a discard plan in the Baltic Sea, because I believe that such a slight reduction in three centimetres of the minimum reference size for cod fishing cannot in any way put juveniles at risk, which is rightly subject to protection, nor that it can adversely affect European markets and consumption. In particular, the Scientific, Technical and Economic Committee for Fisheries (STECF), when questioned on this subject by the Commission, concluded that 'in order to reduce current discard levels, there may be good biological reasons for reducing the current minimum size by 38 cm'.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — EU legislation must retain high standards of sustainable fishing. This will require action that does not have the potential to undermine the reproductive capacity of the stock. Sustainable fishing benefits not only the public, but also the industry itself, making it possible for those entering the fishing industry in the future to be able to make a decent living.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — The opinion of ccTEP scientists supports the idea of reducing the reference measure for cod in the Baltic Sea. Given that the measures of this species have been reduced, and therefore 35 centimetres already ripe, I voted against the ecR Group's motion for a Resolution to support the decision of the CCTEP and the Baltic Sea Advisory Council.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. — The European Parliament voted in the last Parliament to reform the common fisheries policy, including a ban on discarding or landing obligations. The principle of landing obligation is a fundamental change for fishermen; therefore, this delegated act provides a necessary flexibility by providing that a certain percentage of catches can still be exceptionally rejected, and this on a temporary basis. Because I favour this approach, I support the proposal for a delegated regulation and I therefore voted against the motion for a resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. Ensuring the economic sustainability of the fishing sector while preserving the sustainability of fisheries resources is a crucial environmental and economic issue. The Council's decision to reduce the total allowable catch by 26% in the Celtic Sea and 22% in the Eastern Baltic for the cod stock in 2015 are measures that can protect the species. Therefore, it seemed to me that adding to these measures a reduction in the minimum conservation reference size for cod in the Baltic Sea would pose a substantial risk to the socio-economic balance of the fishing sector. That is why I have rejected this Commission's delegated regulation.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
