text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution because it seeks to reject the application of the delegated regulation, the application of which would have the effect of endangering the survival of fish species.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. "We are basically against fishing fish for fish that have never had time to play. For this reason, we have opposed the European Commission's proposal to reduce the measure from 38 to 35 centimetres for cod in the Baltic Sea. We believe that the European Commission should come back as soon as possible with a new proposal, which will include the recently negotiated landing obligation plan in the Baltic Sea, taking into account the major evaluation of the reality of cod in the Baltic Sea planned for spring 2015.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — The European Commission proposes to reduce the minimum reference size for baltic cod from 38 cm to 35 cm. There are relevant reasons for this. The data point to a reduction in the average size of cod in the Baltic (after ripening), which has led to an increase in discards in recent years. Reducing the minimum catch size will not increase mortality, as fishing gear will remain the same. The opinion of the Scientific, Technical and Economic Committee for Fisheries points to the absence of risks in the protection of juveniles, since sow occurs in lengths below 35 cm, due to the reduction in the average size. The 35 cm is already the minimum reference size of other fishing regions, such as the North Sea. In view of the new regulation of the Common Fisheries Policy, which prohibits discards, the non-reduction of the minimum size to 35 cm would mean that a considerable proportion of the landed fish could not enter the normal commercial circuit and had to be referred for processing for flour. Thus, there is a scientific basis, in addition to significant economic and social reasons, for the Commission's proposal. That is why we voted against the resolution which i wanted to object to this proposal.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the introduction of a discard plan in the Baltic Sea, as the application of the delegated regulation would have the effect of endangering the survival of fish species.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. — I voted for this resolution, but would like to point out that cod do not spawn until they are at least 55 cms.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. — I voted against the resolution on Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) establishing a discard plan in the Baltic Sea. I do support the idea of reducing the minimum conservation reference size for cod in the Baltic Sea from 38 cm to 35 cm as this would reduce the amount of disposable fish and would not harm the biological recovery. All in all, this would create better fishing conditions in the Baltic Sea.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I abstained from voting on the Commission's Delegated Regulation Resolution on the adoption of a discard plan in the Baltic Sea, as I am fundamentally opposed to fish catching of smaller sizes. Although the ALDE group was IN, I decided to be restrained because I am expressing my position that fishing of smaller sizes, especially in closed seas, is a serious problem.  I basically wanted to support the prohibition of codfish fishing in the Baltic Sea up to a size of 38 cm. Today, cod fishing is possible already when the fish grows to 35 cm. The difference of only 3 cm significantly affects the total size of cod. I have also expressed my attitude towards the protection of the sea and the fish population. In many conversations with Mr. Walter Dodich, I have come to the conclusion that premature fish catching significantly reduces fish stocks and causes irreversible damage in the long run.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. — (IT) I do not agree with Mr Marek Jozef Grobarczyk's proposal to abolish the delegated act for the reduction of the minimum size for the protection of cod in the Baltic Sea, for a number of reasons which I would like to list here. Firstly, I believe that the minimum reduction in the proposed size would not compromise the production capacity of the stock, nor would it be able to encourage the creation of a market for juveniles. Finally, I do not think it could stand in the way of implementing the improvements made in the use of reference equipment.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — The opinion of ccTEP scientists supports the idea of reducing the reference measure for cod in the Baltic Sea. Given that the measures of this species have been reduced, and therefore 35 centimetres already ripe, I voted against the ecR Group's motion for a Resolution to support the decision of the CCTEP and the Baltic Sea Advisory Council.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. — I voted this way because I believe that reducing the minimum reference size from 38 cm to 35 cm, as proposed by the Commission, for the purposes of preserving cod in the Baltic Sea could weaken the breeding capacity of this population, as well as incentivising the creation of a market for fry and eliminating a significant incentive to implement improvements in the use of more selective arts. In addition to all this, I take into account the Council Decision on total allowable catches (TACs) for cod stocks which in 2015 plans to reduce the quota (7% in the western Baltic and 22% in the eastern Baltic) in order to protect this species. I therefore voted favourably to raise those objections.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. — (DE) I think that my group colleague's resolution is the right one. The reduction in the catch size for cod leads to the catch of fish that have not yet been fully grown. It has not been shown that this type of fishing does not lead to the overexploitation of stocks and that it is compatible with sustainable management.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — One of the main objectives of the new Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) is to gradually abandon the practice of discarding catches in all EU fisheries by introducing a landing obligation. The intention is to make better use of the resources available and respond to public expectations to put an end to the practice of throwing marketable fish back into the sea. Large quantities of discards have been identified as an important reason for the lack of environmental sustainability of the Common Fisheries Policy and I have therefore supported this Report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. 1944 – The Socialist Political Group decided to vote against this resolution, but I abstained. The idea of a resolution: to protect cod in the Baltic Sea with a length of 37 cm. Now by the rules allowed length is 38 cm. I could not vote with the group against the resources of the Baltic Sea and protect them.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I voted against the motion for a resolution on the Commission's delegated regulation of 20 October establishing a rejection plan in the Baltic Sea, because it does not properly and adequately regulate this issue.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — (IT) In disagreement with the deletion of the delegated act for the reduction of the minimum reference size for cod conservation in the Baltic Sea, I have decided to vote against this resolution.   This minimum reduction does not, in my view, affect the production capacity of the stock, nor does it encourage the creation of a market for juveniles.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — (DE) I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because the delegated regulation presented by the Commission could have a potential impact on the reproductive capacity of the cod stock and this would not be justifiable. The minimum reference size should not be changed.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — A Commission's delegated regulation of 20 October 2014 aims to change the minimum conservation reference size for cod in the Baltic Sea. The resolution put to the vote opposes this amendment. Indeed, reducing the size from which a cod can be caught (from 38 to 35 cm) can potentially harm the reproduction of the stock by creating a market for juvenile fish. I vote for the resolution that opposes this ecological nonsense.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — I agree that the reduction of the minimum reference size for cod conservation purposes in the Baltic Sea, proposed by the Commission, could impair the reproductive capacity of stocks. I therefore vote in favour of this resolution, which aims to put an end to that claim.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I am not in agreement with the resolution on discard plan in the Baltic Sea.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The aim of this motion for a resolution is to object to the Commission's delegated regulation setting out a discharge plan for the Baltic Sea. This plan includes reducing the conservation reference size (from 38 cm to 35 cm) for cod in the Baltic Sea, which directly affects the species' reproductive capacity. As a result of the European Union's technocratic thinking, this regulation completely ignores the real concerns and needs of fishermen and is just aimed at imposing ever more fussy and counterproductive standards on them. For these reasons, I voted against this proposal.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I voted against the draft because I consider the sustainable protection of cod stocks in the Baltic Sea to be important.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Ladies and gentlemen, the reduction in the minimum reference size for cod conservation in the Baltic Sea, as proposed by the Commission, could potentially undermine the reproductive capacity of the stock. The Council decision on total allowable catches (TACs) for cod stocks in 2015 provides for quota cuts of 7% in the western Baltic and 22% in the eastern Baltic in order to protect the species. The reduction in the minimum reference size for cod conservation in the Baltic Sea removes an important incentive to make improvements in the use of more selective gear. For these reasons, I would vote against it.

name: Marit PAULSEN
text: Written. "We are, of course, opposed to fishing for fish that have never had time to spawn. For this reason, we have opposed the European Commission's proposal to reduce the measure from 38 to 35 centimetres for cod in the Baltic Sea. We believe that the European Commission should come back as soon as possible with a new proposal, which will include the recently negotiated landing obligation plan in the Baltic Sea, taking into account the major evaluation of the reality of cod in the Baltic Sea planned for spring 2015.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — The task of sustainable fishing is to bring under control the factors that can be controlled during fishing in order to keep sufficient numbers of individuals in the sea for the natural regeneration of the population. Factors that cannot be affected are population biomass increase and natural mortality, and they depend on environmental conditions and biological characteristics of a particular species (recruitment and growth). An important instrument in this context is certainly the specific total annual total allowable catch (TAC) quota. Since there are strong biological interactions between cod, herring and sprats, they are extremely important components of the Baltic ecosystem. Environmental conditions in the Baltic can have a strong impact on the productivity of Baltic fish stocks, in particular cod and sprats, so the Council's decision on total allowable catches aims to reduce quotas (7 % to the western part of the Baltic and 22 % eastern) with a view to preserving this species. This was regulated on 1 January 2014. Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council of 11 December 2013 on the Common Fisheries Policy. In this regard, I support the Commission's proposal to adopt a discard plan in the Baltic Sea. I believe that the sustainability of marine biological resource exploitation would be achieved more efficiently through a multiannual approach to fisheries management and should be based on transparent and objective criteria, including those of an environmental, social and economic nature.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I vote against this resolution because it appears, on reading the record, that the scientists involved in this matter do not consider that neither the species nor its environment are affected in such fishing conditions.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — I voted against this resolution establishing a discard plan for the Baltic Sea because I believe that reducing the minimum reference size for cod conservation purposes in the Baltic Sea will not impair the reproductive capacity of stocks, as the Council has taken the decision to make reductions in the quotas of total allowable catches (TACs) of 7 % in the western Baltic and 22 % in the eastern Baltic.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — The Commission presented a delegated act on the Baltic discard plan providing for the reduction of cod TMRC from the current 38 cm to 35 cm. The EC justifies this reduction on the basis that cod has a very high density in the Baltic Sea and is therefore suffering from certain problems of reduced growth, increased parasites, etc., therefore discards have increased and mature specimens have reduced in size. The proposal to reduce TMRC does not imply further mortality, because the characteristics of the allowed networks do not change. According to the CCTEP, this reduction does not affect juveniles, because the deoves occur below those 35 cm. The reduction will have a positive effect on the economic yields of cod fish, as current discards of between 30 and 35 cm account for 83% in number and weight.  The Baltic Member States and the Baltic RAF also support it. In addition, the reduction in size will bring coherence with other regions, for example, with the North Sea, where it is already 35 cm. That is why I voted against the proposal put forward on the Commission's delegated act.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. — (IT) I abstained because there is no careful assessment of the biological cycle of cod in the Baltic Sea, which would be essential for a decision on this matter.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - The opinion of ccTEP scientists supports the idea of reducing the reference measure for cod in the Baltic Sea. Given that the measures of this species have been reduced, and therefore 35 centimetres already ripe, I voted against the ecR Group's motion for a Resolution to support the decision of the CCTEP and the Baltic Sea Advisory Council.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — I did not support a regulation objecting to a plan adopted by the Commission concerning the rejection of catches in the Baltic Sea, as this plan could potentially jeopardise the reproductive capacity of this species, a worrying fact to which Parliament reacted. The Council decided to reduce the allowable catch quota, which would protect the species as there are currently fewer and fewer cod in the sea. The mere fact that the minimum reference size of cod from 38 cm to 35 cm has been reduced is sufficient to reconsider the Commission's plan, so it is necessary to change the current regulation in order to come to a more efficient and realistic plan and to minimise harm and protection of the species.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — Any action to promote the protection of the marine and aquatic world is in the right direction.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the Commission's Delegate Regulation (EU) setting out a discharge plan for the Baltic Sea. I have also accompanied a wider inquiry into the "zero rejection" and its implementation.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — The European Commission proposes, in this resolution, to reduce the minimum conservation reference size for Baltic cod from 38 to 35 cm. There are relevant reasons for this. The reduction in the minimum catch size will not increase mortality, as fishing gear will remain the same and the opinion of the Scientific, Technical and Economic Committee for Fisheries points to the absence of risks in the protection of juveniles, as sow occurs at lengths below 35 cm due to the reduction in the average size. In view of the new regulation of the Common Fisheries Policy, which prohibits discards, the non-reduction of the minimum size to 35 cm would mean that a considerable proportion of the landed fish could not enter the normal commercial circuit and had to be referred for processing for flour. Thus, there is a scientific basis, in addition to significant economic and social reasons, for the Commission's proposal. That is why we voted against the resolution which i wanted to object to this proposal.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — (DE) I fully supported this motion for a resolution, because the delegated regulation presented by the Commission could have a potential impact on the reproductive capacity of the cod stock and this would not be justifiable.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: Written. "We are basically against fishing fish for fish that have never had time to play. For this reason, we have opposed the European Commission's proposal to reduce the measure from 38 to 35 centimetres for cod in the Baltic Sea. We believe that the European Commission should come back as soon as possible with a new proposal, which will include the recently negotiated landing obligation plan in the Baltic Sea, taking into account the major evaluation of the reality of cod in the Baltic Sea planned for spring 2015.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — The European Commission proposes to reduce the minimum reference size for baltic cod from 38 cm to 35 cm. There are relevant reasons for this. The data point to a reduction in the average size of cod in the Baltic (after ripening), which has led to an increase in discards in recent years. The opinion of the Scientific, Technical and Economic Committee for Fisheries points to the absence of risks in the protection of juveniles, since snoot occurs in lengths below 35cm, due to the reduction in the average size. The 35 cm is already the minimum reference size of other fishing regions, such as the North Sea, so we voted against the resolution that sought to object to this proposal.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — The purpose of this motion for a Resolution is to object to the delegated act on Solvency II, which was adopted by the Commission on 10 October 2014. The main criticism is that the Commission's proposal favours the insurance industry and weakens efforts to reduce systemic insurance-related risks. All this is reflected in the motion for a resolution, so I voted in favour.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution on the Commission's delegated regulation of 10 October 2014 complementing the European Parliament and Council's 2009/138/EC Directive on Access to Insurance and Reinsurance activities and their exercise (solvency II) is opposed to this commission's delegated act, which weakens the effectiveness of legislation. The Commission is constantly revising down the risk weighting, and I have therefore spoken out in favour of this text, which objects to the delegated act.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this resolution, which takes up EIOPA's comments and calls on the Commission to respect its recommendations. On 10 October, in fact, the EU Executive adopted a delegated regulation on a number of powers conferred by Directive 2009/138/EC which, in several important cases, differs significantly from the technical opinions presented by EIOPA, with a calibration of the risk factors used in the standard formula for calculating the solvency capital requirement (SCR) much lower than that recommended by EIOPA.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — I voted against this motion for a Resolution on the Commission Delegated Regulation of 10 October 2014 supplementing Directive 2009/138/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council on life insurance, access to and exercise of insurance and reinsurance activity (Solvency II) (C(2014) 07230 – 2014/2893(DEA)), considering, like the majority of the House, that it is not appropriate to object to the Commission's Delegated Regulation, as this would prevent it from entering into force.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted against because this proposal was not protective enough for private persons.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — The Commission is constantly reducing the risk weighting, which obviously weakens the effectiveness of legislation. Since the resolution opposes this delegated act, I voted in favour.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. Article 101 of Directive 2009/138/EC provides that "all quantifiable risks to which an insurance or reinsurance undertaking is exposed" shall be taken into account and that the solvency capital requirement corresponds "to the risk value of the basic own funds of the insurance or reinsurance undertaking subject to a confidence level of 99.5% over a period of one year". The Directive gives the Commission the power to adopt delegated acts in a number of specific areas and the Commission has duly asked the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (EIOPA) to provide technical advice in these areas. EIOPA submitted final opinions to the Commission on Solvency II calibration (CEIOPS-SEC-40-10), the classification and eligibility of own funds (CP46), the calculation and calibration of the share risk subform (CP69), the treatment of future premiums (CP30) and the calculation of the risk margin (CP42).

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) This resolution, which has a very technical content, bases its objection to the Commission's act on the assumption that the opinion given by an advisory body would not have been followed. For the umpteenth time, therefore, we are faced with a pretext attempt to give the European Commission a go-between in its role as the EU's executive body. That is why I voted against the resolution.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - On the basis of the abovementioned article 101 of Directive 2009/138/EC and the work carried out by the Commission in drafting the delegated regulation, I consider it justifiable to adopt in part the solutions expressed by ceiops/eiopa technicians with regard to the quantification of the risks to which insurance and reinsurance undertakings are exposed and the criteria for judging solvency in relation to the risk value of own funds. In my opinion, the Commission has rightly critically examined the technical opinion of CEIOPS/EIOPA, respecting the spirit of the European Parliament's aforementioned directive.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — Considering that Article 290 TFEI states that the purpose of delegated acts is to supplement or amend certain non-essential elements of the legislative act or to lay down uniform conditions for the implementation of the provisions defined in legislative acts and whereas Article 101 of Directive 2009/138/EC provides that "all quantifiable risks to which a the insurance or reinsurance company" and that the solvency capital requirement corresponds to "the risk value of the basic own funds of the insurance or reinsurance company subject to a confidence level of 99.5 % over a period of one year", I voted in favour of the Green motion asking for objection to delegated acts of the Commission to regulate this specific matter.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — The purpose of this motion for a Resolution is to object to the delegated act on Solvency II, which was adopted by the Commission on 10 October 2014. The main criticism is that the Commission's proposal favours the insurance industry and weakens efforts to reduce systemic insurance-related risks. All this is reflected in the motion for a resolution, so I voted in favour.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which objects to the Commission delegated regulation covering many of the empowerments under the Directive on the taking-up and pursuit of the business of Insurance and Reinsurance which, in several important cases, deviate significantly from the technical advice submitted, resulting in significantly lower calibrations of risk factors used in the standard formula to calculate the Solvency Capital Requirement (SCR)

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. — The 2009/138/CE Directive ("Solvency II"), amended in 2014, will come into force on 1 January 2016 and will replace 14 existing directives. In line with the so-called "Basel II" requirements, its aim is to create a single Prudential Regime at European level for insurance and reinsurance companies in order to strengthen risk-taking and to require insurers to set aside sufficient capital to deal with these risks. Carried out during the last Parliament by Vice-President Michel BARNIER, this proposal aims to make our financial system more robust and capable of dealing with crises, better protecting our citizens from the vagaries of finance. Considering that the implementation of this legislation is of paramount importance, I vote against this resolution which, if adopted, would call into question the heart of this new European body of prudential rules for insurance and reinsurance companies in the Union.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The Solvency II Directive, which was voted in November 2009, is due to come into force on 1 January 2016. Applying to the insurance industry, this directive aims to encourage organizations to better understand and assess their risks, including by adapting regulatory requirements to the risks that companies incur in their business. The Commission's delegated regulation, which this motion for a resolution wants to reject, will follow the timetable and meets the framework of the basic legislative act. That's why I didn't want to be involved.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution, after objecting to the Commission's delegated regulation.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — This resolution serves to reject the Commission's delegated act with regard to the insurance and reinsurance activity and its exercise, in particular as regards the calibration of the risk factors used in the standard formula for calculating the solvency capital requirement, in particular the classification and eligibility of own funds, the structure and calibration of the shareholder risk sub-module, the treatment of future premiums and the calculation of the risk margin. The delegated act adopted by the Commission on 10 October, in addition to not taking into account the technical recommendations of CAESSPCR/EIOPA, results in a significantly lower calibration of the risk factors used in the standard formula for calculating the solvency capital requirement, which clearly works in favour of the insurance industry and is contrary to the interests of policyholders in the defence and protection of risks assumed by insurance companies. Reasons why we voted in favour.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing — Article 290 TFEU provides that delegated acts are to amend or amend certain elements or to lay down uniform conditions for the implementation of the provisions defined in legislative acts. Article 101 of Directive 2009/138/EC provides that, in the case of insurance and reinsurance, account shall be taken of all quantifiable risks to which insurance or reinsurance undertakings are exposed and that the Solvency Capital Requirement corresponds to a value in the risk of the basic own funds of an insurance or reinsurance undertaking with a 99,5 % confidence level over a period of one year. The European Commission has adopted a regulation involving the conferral of powers, which in a number of significant cases differ significantly from the technical recommendations submitted, leading to significantly lower calibrations of risk factors.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour of the measure because the Annex is linked to Article 101 of Directive 2009/138/EC, which provides that "all quantifiable risks to which an insurance or reinsurance undertaking is exposed shall be taken into account. "the risk value of the insurance or reinsurance undertaking's basic own funds subject to a confidence level of 99.5% over a period of one year".

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - We abstained in the vote. The motion for a Resolution proposes, like many of its kind and in this area, specific solutions that do not solve the structural problems faced by both our traditional industrial sectors and our increasingly fragile environment. On the one hand, the motion for a Resolution does not just specify concrete measures that impact on value-added generation (R&D&I) and that manage to preserve those industrial sectors that are strategic for Europe, taking precedence over energy efficiency and investment in appropriate technological developments. On the other hand, the motion for a Resolution does not meet the real challenge that Europe continues to present: the urgent need to reform the European environmental tax system so that real regulation is exercised on human activities and their impacts on health, ecosystems and also on local industrial fabrics.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the resolution, since it objects to the Commission's delegated regulation.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We abstained in the vote. The motion for a Resolution proposes, like many of its kind and in this area, specific solutions that do not solve the structural problems faced by both our traditional industrial sectors and our increasingly fragile environment. On the one hand, the motion for a Resolution does not just specify concrete measures that impact on value-added generation (R&D&I) and that manage to preserve those industrial sectors that are strategic for Europe, taking precedence over energy efficiency and investment in appropriate technological developments. On the other hand, the motion for a Resolution does not meet the real challenge that Europe continues to present: the urgent need to reform the European environmental tax system so that real regulation is exercised on human activities and their impacts on health, ecosystems and also on local industrial fabrics.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted AGAINST the Resolution on the Delegated Regulation of the Commission amending the Directive establishing and carrying out insurance and re-insurance activities, as the entire ALDE Group was against, although I am not entirely happy with the delegated act in force.  Since the agreement on the Delegated Act, which we call "Solvency II" was a very sensitive topic, I am of the opinion that the Delegated Act should have its ability to continue its action. In this way, after many years, the insurance sector will finally be able to implement the appropriate rules to create greater legal certainty and protection against insolvency risks.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I voted against this motion, as I believe that to reopen the package at this stage would put implementation back by years. The position reached is a carefully negotiated compromise between different Member States in order to allow us a version of the regulation which can be implemented on 1 January 2016.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. — (IT) I support the rapporteur's proposal because I believe that the European Commission has rightly assessed the technical opinion given by CEIOPS/EIOPA on the quantification of the risks to which insurance and reinsurance undertakings are exposed and the criteria for judging solvency in relation to the risk value of own funds.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — The purpose of this motion for a Resolution is to object to the delegated act on Solvency II, which was adopted by the Commission on 10 October 2014. The main criticism is that the Commission's proposal favours the insurance industry and weakens efforts to reduce systemic insurance-related risks. All this is reflected in the motion for a resolution, so I voted in favour.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — I consider that additional annexes to the Delegated Regulation are not necessary and for this reason I do not support this proposal.  Solvency II replaces and improves the existing 14 insurance directives and introduces for the first time new, tougher solvency, risk management and risk-based surveillance rules for all members. Solvency II will provide a modern, harmonised framework on the establishment of activities and supervision of insurance companies and re-insurance companies in the Union.  These new rules are essential for a safe and stable insurance sector that can offer sustainable insurance products and support the real economy through long-term investment and additional stability.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. - I voted 'abstaining', although most of my socialist colleagues in the Socialist Group were against.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the Annex to Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) supplementing Directive 2009/138/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council on the taking up and pursuit of insurance and reinsurance activities (Solvency II), because it adequately and appropriately regulates this issue.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — (IT) I think that the demands contained in the motion for a resolution put forward by the Greens, which essentially require that all quantifiable risks to which an insurance or reinsurance undertaking is exposed be taken into account", are not entirely acceptable.  That is why I have chosen to vote against the text.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this request because the Commission has departed from the opinion of the advisory bodies in a number of substantial parts. This was the case in technical and technical matters and leads to a low calibration of risk factors. In order to counteract this, I voted in favour of the motion.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — Solvency 2 regulates the insurance industry in terms of capital and risk-taking. In this context, the Commission has the power to adopt delegated acts. On 10 October 2014, the Commission adopted a delegated regulation which departs considerably from the technical opinions presented. In particular, it provides for a much lower calibration of the risk factors used to calculate the required solvency capital (CSR) in relation to the recommendations. This shows once again that the Commission is serving the financial markets rather than the citizens. The resolution before us is opposed to this delegated act which underestimates the risks. I'm voting for.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution which objects to the European Commission's delegated regulation supplementing the Directive on access to and exercise of insurance and reinsurance activity. I share the view that in several cases the Commission's position deviates from the technical recommendations formulated, resulting in a significantly lower calibration of the risk factors used in the standard formula for calculating the solvency capital requirement. However, the European Commission does not present any element justifying that these calibrations comply with Article 101, basing such considerations on political reasons to move away from the formula recommended by CAESSPCR/EIOPA. For this reason, I voted in favour of the European Parliament's position to report that this delegated regulation cannot enter into force.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — I voted against this resolution because the Commission is supplementing Directive 2009/138/EC in order to make the new capital requirements more risk-sensitive and more sophisticated than in the past. This in turn enables increased coverage of the real risks run by the insurer and also moves towards requirements that better fit the insurers’ risk profiles. A move away from a one-model-fits-all approach would increase insurers’ capability to operate within the internal market.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I am not in agreement with the resolution on the taking-up and pursuit of the business of Insurance and Reinsurance (Solvency II).

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. — In terms of the solvency of banking institutions, the rules put in place at European level fall short of the requirements of the Bale III agreements, in particular because of the poor consideration of the risk of default by a sovereign state or a public person. Once again, on the occasion of the implementation texts of the Solvency 2 Directive, concerning insurance companies, the Commission weakens the effectiveness of legislation and the prevention of risks. Parliament must ensure that delegated acts do not call into question the principles voted on at Level 1 and must, moreover, do everything possible to avoid a misjudgment of risks and a solvency crisis in the insurance sector. In this case, the technical committees seized for advice establish that the draft delegated act presented here constitutes a step backwards from these two points of view. The rejection of the Commission's delegated regulation should therefore be supported.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The Commission is constantly reducing the risk weighting, which obviously weakens the effectiveness of legislation. Since this resolution opposes this delegated act, I therefore voted in favour.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which objects to the Commission's delegated regulation on 'Solvency II', because it believes that the Commission has significantly departed from the technical opinions presented, and therefore provides for a far too low calibration of the risk factors used in the standard formula to calculate the required solvency capital in relation to the recommendations of ceCAPP/AEAPP.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Ladies and gentlemen, Article 101 of Directive 2009/138/EC provides that "all quantifiable risks to which an insurance or reinsurance undertaking is exposed" shall be taken into account and that the solvency capital requirement shall correspond to "the risk value of the basic own funds of the insurance or reinsurance undertaking subject to a confidence level of 99,5 % over a period of one year". The Directive gives the Commission the power to adopt delegated acts in a number of specific areas and the Commission has duly asked CEIOPS/EIOPA to provide technical advice in relation to these areas. On 10 October 2014, the Commission adopted a delegated regulation on a number of powers conferred by the Directive which, in several important cases, differs significantly from the technical opinions presented. For these reasons, I would vote against it.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — I voted against this motion for a resolution which opposes the Commission Delegated Regulation because it considers that the delegated act does not deviate from the technical recommendations made, and the classification and eligibility of own funds, the structure and calibration of the shareholder risk submodule, the treatment of future premiums and the calculation of the risk margin, as presented to the Commission by CAESSPCR/EIOPA, were taken into account in the process of drawing up the act.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. During the last campaign for the European elections on 25 May, the MR made a commitment to make a difference in the European Parliament in its efforts to revive struggling industrial sectors, such as the steel industry. A liberal and social approach dictated by the imperatives of results and not a purely protectionist approach that has shown its limits for more than 20 years. Because the reality is there, and it is twofold: worrying, if we refer to the 60,000 jobs lost in the sector since 2007, promising if we consider that the steel sector is 350,000 direct jobs and several million subcontractors concerned in the European Union. We know for a fact that European industry urgently needs a strong and competitive steel sector. The EU is the world's second largest producer of steel, with 11% of total production. It is with this in mind and the adoption by the plenary of amendments by the Liberal Group on research and development and the promotion of a low-carbon steel sector, also on the establishment of public-private partnerships in this strategic sector, that the MR delegation voted this lunchtime on the resolution on the future of steel in Europe.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - We abstained in the vote. The motion for a Resolution proposes, like many of its kind and in this area, specific solutions that do not solve the structural problems faced by both our traditional industrial sectors and our increasingly fragile environment. On the one hand, the motion for a Resolution does not just specify concrete measures that impact on value-added generation (R&D&I) and that manage to preserve those industrial sectors that are strategic for Europe, taking precedence over energy efficiency and investment in appropriate technological developments. On the other hand, the motion for a Resolution does not meet the real challenge that Europe continues to present: the urgent need to reform the European environmental tax system so that real regulation is exercised on human activities and their impacts on health, ecosystems and also on local industrial fabrics.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - We abstained in the vote. The motion for a Resolution proposes, like many of its kind and in this area, specific solutions that do not solve the structural problems faced by both our traditional industrial sectors and our increasingly fragile environment. On the one hand, the motion for a Resolution does not just specify concrete measures that impact on value-added generation (R&D&I) and that manage to preserve those industrial sectors that are strategic for Europe, taking precedence over energy efficiency and investment in appropriate technological developments. On the other hand, the motion for a Resolution does not meet the real challenge that Europe continues to present: the urgent need to reform the European environmental tax system so that real regulation is exercised on human activities and their impacts on health, ecosystems and also on local industrial fabrics.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - The purpose of this motion for a Resolution is to object to the delegated act on Solvency II, which was adopted by the Commission on 10 October 2014. The main criticism is that the Commission's proposal favours the insurance industry and weakens efforts to reduce systemic insurance-related risks. All this is reflected in the motion for a resolution, so I voted in favour.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. — I did not support this motion to object as the current position we have on Solvency II and the delegated regulation is a carefully negotiated compromise in order to allow implementation on 1 January 2016. The issues raised in this motion were not sufficiently important to policyholder security to warrant re-opening of the Delegated Act at this late stage. Solvency II and the Delegated Acts are a consumer protection measure so should be implemented as soon as possible. There will be a review within two years where any issues can be addressed if necessary.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — This Directive provides for the establishment of a modern and risk-measuring of the well-founded supervision of insurance and reossurance companies in the European Union and thus Croatia.  I believe that the proposal is good, but that it must take into account all the measurable risks to which insurance/reosurance companies are exposed and solvent capital that must correspond to the risk value of the company's core own resources with a confidence level of 99.5 per cent over a one-year period. I consider that annexes to the Commission's delegated regulation amending Directive 2009/138/EC of the European Parliament and the Council on the establishment and performance of insurance and reosurance activities do not adequately take into account all the risks faced by companies on the EU market today which is why I did not support this proposal.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — The Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs had not tabled such a resolution, with the result that Article 105(4) of the Regulation applies and applies in the case of a resolution tabled at the December 2014 plenary session, so the delegated regulation cannot enter into force.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the Commission's delegated regulation of 10 October 2014 complementing the European Parliament and Council's 2009/138/EC directive on access to insurance and reinsurance activities and their exercise (solvency II) and I, like my colleagues, have validated the annexes.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution as I believe that the Delegated Regulation on the bank solvency package known as Solvency II does not guarantee rigorous control of the risk of large entities and, at the same time, profoundly harms hundreds of small financial institutions which must contribute to a fund designed only for banks 'too big to drop'.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. Solvency II is a European reform whose official objective is "to better adapt the capital required of insurance and reinsurance companies with the risks they incur in their activity". The aim of better protecting policyholders is essentially aimed at creating a single insurance market in the EU and better controlling the activity of pan-European insurers (55 articles of the directive are devoted to groups). It penalizes, in fact, small and medium-sized structures and especially mutuals by once again denying their specificities. I had already opposed the adoption of such a directive last March and with its new proposal, the Commission wants to force its way through a delegated act, which gives it all power and takes away all control in Parliament. For me, it is not acceptable either in substance or form. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution which refused to give the Commission any power, and I therefore regret that it was rejected by a large majority by the EPP, S and D, ALDE and ECR groups.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — This resolution serves to reject the Commission's delegated act with regard to insurance and reinsurance activity and the calibration of risk factors used in the standard formula for calculating the capital requirement, in particular the classification and eligibility of own funds, the structure and calibration of the shareholder risk sub-module, the treatment of future premiums and the calculation of the risk margin. The delegated act adopted by the Commission on 10 October, in addition to not taking into account the technical recommendations of CAESSPCR/EIOPA, results in a significantly lower calibration of the risk factors used in the standard formula for calculating the solvency capital requirement, which clearly works in favour of the insurance industry and contrary to the interests of policyholders in the defence and protection of risks assumed by insurance companies.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — Since the Commission has departed from the opinion of the advisory bodies in a number of substantial parts, I have voted in favour of the request. Among other things, technical and technical issues have been the case, and this leads to a low calibration of risk factors.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe has a duty to make every effort to ensure that its citizens are as safe as possible. This guarantee inevitably depends on taking note of the security challenges to which our society is subjected on a daily basis. While we appreciate the European Union's commitment to meeting these challenges, we cannot help but denounce the timid attention paid to a phenomenon which, sometimes sneakily, and this is clearly the case, is rapidly spreading across the continent. I am referring to the spread of corruption, of the activities of criminal organisations, the first outlet for which in countries that think they are immune to it is money laundering. I believe that not enough has been done to combat the Mafia and that we need a collective awareness, leading us to adopt a holistic approach to these issues. The Commission's good reports must be followed by action. And so, let us begin to take all possible legislative initiatives, starting with the preventive confiscation of the illicit proceeds of criminal organizations and the regulation of the crime of association with mafia-type crimes up to the protection of whistleblowers to combat corruption.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the resolution reaffirms that freedom, security and justice are objectives to be pursued in parallel. The new strategy must ensure full respect for fundamental rights and principles, which have not always been guaranteed in the past, but it must also be an effective strategy and, of course, subject to comprehensive judicial protection. But above all it must be an effective strategy. To this end, and pending the Commission communication on the European Union's new internal security strategy, the resolution identifies a number of priorities that we support. These include combating trafficking in human beings, organised crime, money laundering and corruption, which must also be combated through closer cooperation in criminal matters between States and between EU agencies, making greater use of instruments such as joint investigation teams and improving the circulation of relevant information in accordance with the guarantees that will soon have to be enshrined in the Data Protection Directive. For these reasons, I supported the resolution.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I did not vote in favour of this motion for a Resolution which addresses the preparation of a new Internal Security Strategy for the next four years because it is raised on the same basis as before, basing security on a single repressive approach and obviating the radical approach, that is, at the root, on the causes that have generated these new threats. That's why I voted against it.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. — Taking into account today’s changing security environment and emerging new security threats, a timely and prompt revision of common EU internal security strategy (ISS) is needed. New threats are becoming, as never before, diversified, asymmetrical and international, meaning that international crime, radicalisation of religious and nationalistic groups, terrorism and cybercrime are on the rise and the traditional security measures and combat forms no longer serve as effective measures to tackle these challenges. Therefore, we must call upon the EP, the Council and Commission to work closely to make the ISS more coherent, univocal and targeted. Thus, a motion for the revised internal security strategy (ISS) including improved working methods and alternated structure is a very welcome and needed initiative. Only by implementing the new ISS will Europe be able to preserve its legal and political order and defend itself against the new challenges on the rise.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to update the internal security strategy. The SSS set for 2010-2014 will soon expire and it is necessary to re-establish the new VSS for the period 2015-2019. In recent years, the security situation in Europe has changed dramatically as a result of new conflicts in the EU's neighbourhood countries. I agree with the suggestions that, in the preparation of the new VSS, Europol must examine the security risks facing today and what threats lie ahead. The new VSS must be easily adapted to the changing situation. It is worrying that the number of EU citizens travelling to conflict zones with the aim of joining terrorist organisations and then returning to EU territory is growing rapidly. I therefore agree that appropriate measures must be taken to prevent recruitment, the provision of financial support to terrorist organisations and those wishing to join them, and to provide for prosecution. It is also important to provide adequate resources for the proper implementation of the VSS.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The will to renew the EU's internal security strategy will unfortunately not depend on these proposed measures, which are far too weak and out of all reality in the face of Member States' security problems. The fight against terrorism and jihadism will not be based on measures on tolerance or social cohesion, but on a proactive policy that dares to re-establish control at the EU's borders and abolish the Schengen agreements. It is becoming more than urgent to put an end to this policy of good feelings which endangers the security of the citizens of the Union. So I voted against it.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — The current security challenges in Europe are cross-border, so it is difficult for Member States to provide an individual response. In 2010, the EU Internal Security Strategy (ESI) was adopted, which sets guidelines for addressing security threats in Europe where the EU can add value: international cross-border criminality networks, terrorist attack prevention, cybersecurity, border security or natural disaster resistance. The Commission presented its new ESI proposal 2015-2019 in March. The adopted resolution recognises that the security situation in Europe has changed dramatically due to new conflicts and calls for more effective cooperation between Member States through greater use of valuable existing instruments, such as joint research teams. A forward-looking strategy that focuses on both existing and emerging threats is also called for, with a holistic approach that includes as many areas as possible, such as foreign fighters and cybersecurity threats. Always in accordance with fundamental rights and data protection. That is why I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because it aims to contribute in advance to the new EU internal security strategy, which will be in force for 2015-2019 and which the Commission plans to present in spring 2015. The future strategy is crucial due to the significant change in the security situation in Europe in recent years as a result of new conflicts and upheavals in the EU's immediate neighbourhood, the rapid development of new technologies and the increasing radicalisation that leads to violence and terrorism. In particular, in the new EU Internal Security Strategy, Parliament called on the Commission to properly reflect the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights and its values, as security measures must always be applied in accordance with the rule of law and with all fundamental rights. Parliament also called for the focus not only on existing security threats, but also on existing security threats, and for an integrated approach to areas such as cybersecurity, trafficking in human beings and the fight against terrorism, or inextricably linked topics such as organised crime, money laundering and corruption. Parliament also stressed in its resolution that the proper implementation of the new internal security strategy requires a clear allocation of tasks to be carried out within the EU and which will be carried out at national level.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution on the renewal of the Internal Security Strategy of the European Union because the measures envisaged here are ridiculously weak in the face of the serious problems faced by the Member States. To believe that a policy of "promoting political and religious tolerance, strengthening social cohesion and opening up to all and simplifying reintegration opportunities" will be effective in combating the rise of jihadism is the most culpable naivety because it endangers the peoples of the Member States. Only the restoration of national borders and serious controls will prevent licensed and future criminals from circulating freely. It has been proven that the EU is incapable of managing its borders, which are real colanders. We must therefore break with the Schengen agreements as a matter of urgency and re-establish our national borders.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — Vote in favour of renewing the internal security strategy. Actions concern organised crime, terrorism, cybercrime, border security and disasters.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. — The text recognises that the security situation in Europe has changed dramatically due to new conflicts and calls for more effective cooperation between Member States through greater use of valuable existing instruments, such as joint research teams. In addition, a forward-looking strategy is required that focuses on both existing and emerging threats, with a holistic approach that includes as many areas as possible, such as foreign fighters and cybersecurity threats. It is important to note that this is a balanced text which emphasizes the need to ensure that security measures are always carried out in accordance with fundamental rights and which refers in particular to the Court's Decision on data retention and the proposal for a Data Protection Directive. The motion for a Resolution and the oral question have been examined by all political groups and, after many negotiations, agreement has been reached on a text.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. — The EU's internal security strategy comes to an end this year. It is therefore essential to put in place a new strategy for the next four years that is better suited to the current security challenges. The problem of European nationals travelling to conflict zones to fight alongside terrorists must be addressed as a matter of priority. With this resolution, the European Parliament sets out to the Commission the various axes of a coherent internal security policy. I voted in favour of this resolution. The European Union was built to bring greater security to European citizens, so this principle must be guaranteed.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of this resolution because I welcome the preparation of a new internal security strategy (SSI) which must adapt to the new security threats that have emerged in recent years, applying an integrated approach to priority areas such as cybersecurity, trafficking in human beings, the fight against terrorism and organized crime, money laundering and corruption. It is essential that there is an in-depth analysis of the new and emerging security threats, which must be carried out by Europol in close cooperation with the other relevant EU bodies and with the Member States. I call on the Commission to carry out an assessment of the current instruments in the field of internal security and a corresponding analysis of existing shortcomings.  With regard to the worrying growth of EU citizens travelling to conflict areas to join terrorist organisations and then returning to EU territory, I am convinced that this phenomenon creates new risks for the Union's internal security, which must be tackled with determination through a multidimensional approach.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. - The ISS has traditionally been a very unilateral security-oriented instrument, with a sole focus on repression without taking stock of the already existing security measures within Member States, without virtually any account of fundamental rights, and without any involvement of civil society and relevant human rights organisations. It has been the basis for such instruments as the EU PNR, the Data Retention Directive, Europol’s Cybercrime Centre, the mandate for the strengthening of FRONTEX and the deployment of EUROSUR; all of which have been problematic. The actors in this field are generally non-accountable, and neither is their exact mandate very clear This resolution particularly asks for the new ISS to focus on the foreign fighters’ issues, and the Commission seems eager to make this point the focal point of its next ISS communication (perhaps to give a new boost to the already-defeated EU PNR Directive). I take security seriously but that this ISS is so unilaterally focused on immediate repression, without any look at broader geopolitical, socio-economic issues, that it is totally unbalanced and that is why I voted against this motion.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) The challenges we face at this time also see the EU as a model of something that in other parts of the world is seen as bad. It is therefore necessary for the efforts of individual Member States to ensure internal security to be coordinated and perhaps made synergistic by the common objective of preserving the safety of European citizens. I voted in favour of this resolution because it has been able to argue this simple principle.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. — The European Parliament adopted a resolution on renewing the EU’s Internal Security Strategy (ISS). Recent attacks in Pakistan and Australia show that security threats have become more varied, international, multiple and technologically advanced. As a group, the EPP insists on closer cross-border and inter-agency cooperation. The new Internal Security Strategy must also address the issue of European jihadists.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. — The Treaty of Lisbon has given the European Parliament powers in the field of internal security, in particular with regard to the Internal Security Strategy. At the end of the previous period, Parliament approves what it considers to be the priorities of the Internal Security Strategy for 2015-2019. The aim is to ensure democratic control and respect for fundamental rights, contributing to a genuine area of Freedom, Security and Justice.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - The current geopolitical scenario is of particular concern due to various conflicts and upheavals involving many countries close to the EU. In addition, many of today's security challenges have taken on a cross-border and cross-sectoral character, which exceed the immediate and effective response capacities of each Member State. I hope that the new Internal Security Strategy (SSI) for 2015-2019 will be forward-looking and strategic, easily adaptable to changing situations, but above all capable of taking effective action against the many emerging threats, such as the fight against terrorism, trafficking in human beings, organised crime, money laundering and corruption. I also hope that judicial cooperation in criminal matters will be developed, as will mutual trust between Member States. It should not be forgotten that the European Parliament, as a full player in the field of security policy and in accordance with the provisions of the Treaty of Lisbon, will have every right to express its position on the priorities and actions on the ground.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — It is regrettable that the Commission’s communication provides an insufficient analysis of the 2010-2014 Internal Security Strategy. It is important that a new strategy includes more effective cooperation among EU institutions. A new strategy requires better training for practitioners and a sharing of knowledge, and should encourage stakeholders’ networking, and promote further operational cooperation among Member States so as to create not just a common European law enforcement culture but also a European judicial culture. Any EU security policy must respect the values on which the EU is based, including that of respect for fundamental rights, the rule of law and solidarity. We need to act against social exclusion and economic inequalities, as these issues can be identified as both the cause and the consequence of global crime, radicalisation, organised crime and terrorism. Successful counter-terrorism policy can prevent radicalisation of citizens by involving social services, educators, community groups, and even families. At the same time we need to ensure that a European security strategy is respectful towards the dignity of victims.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — I did not vote in favour of this motion for a Resolution which addresses the preparation of a new Internal Security Strategy for the next four years because it is based on the same basis as before, basing security on a only repressive approach, ignoring the radical approach, that is, at the root, on the causes that have generated these new threats. That's why I voted against it.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, since I believe that the EU urgently needs a holistic approach in order to address the rapidly changing security threats facing Europe, including foreign fighters and cyber-security threats. The resolution marks the beginning of an extensive and informed debate in the area of internal security. Such a strategy needs to strike an appropriate balance between security and privacy rights. This is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. By this vote by a very large majority, it is more than a signal, it is a real injunction that has been made to the European Commission to adapt its internal security strategy to the new challenges facing Europeans. In particular, the EU must take a strong step to meet the challenge of European jihadists who have gone to join the ranks of Daesh in Iraq or Syria and are likely to return to European territory. We need a comprehensive internal security strategy, tailored to the priorities we have set for it, with effective legislative instruments and appropriate financial resources.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The new threats facing Europe today are much more diffuse and difficult to grasp. I am thinking in particular of the issue of foreign fighters and their radicalization, the international crime networks at the head of various traffickings or cyber attacks. These are threats that ignore the borders of states and now rely on new technologies to better evade police and judicial controls. In order to ensure the best security of our citizens, the Union must modernise its security strategy and focus on the underlying causes of violence, which are often intolerance and radicalisation, but also the sources of funding for criminal activities. This new strategy must be based on the pooling of Member States' resources and also go hand in hand with the development of a genuine common foreign and defence policy. In this context, Parliament will have to ensure that this new security strategy is fully in line with the European Charter of Fundamental Rights.

name: Diane DODDS
text: in writing. — I welcome the emphasis placed by this motion on the threat posed to the safety of people and communities across Europe by radicalisation leading to terrorism and the increasing dynamics of cross-border criminality. While this focus is right and proper, however, it should not be seen in any way, shape or form as a means to replace or integrate the sovereign actions of Member States and their armed forces in protecting citizens. Despite this, there does remain a role for EU to play in several aspects of security policy. First of all, Europe must encourage national governments to implement all crucial crime-fighting resources that they have at their disposal. In my own constituency, for instance, nationalist parties have prevented the successful National Crime Agency from tackling terrorism and organised crime in Northern Ireland. This is disgraceful and provides a safe haven for launderers and traffickers alike. The EU also has a role, given freedom of movement, to aid the detection of individuals that seek to further extremist causes or lead trafficking rings. Effective cooperation is key to this battle.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted against motion for a resolution B8-0350/2014 because it deprives the Member States of their national sovereignty.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — The reference to the establishment of the current Isis, new security threats have emerged, citing examples of cybersecurity, trafficking in human beings, the fight against terrorism and related issues, as well as organised crime, money laundering and corruption, is proof of the failure of the EU's political guidelines and the responsibilities of this same strategy in the period that now ends. It is necessary to disprove the hypocritical version of the security problem that conceals its own responsibilities. One example is human trafficking, a reality that continues to be a drama for thousands of human beings and in particular for immigrants who have been pushed into the hands of criminal organisations by the EU's repressive and criminalising policies of immigration. Another example is support for terrorist organizations through the provision of weapons, training and funding, aimed at destabilizing countries such as Syria. This resolution confirms that security problems will never be solved by them who have not only largely provoked them, but are preparing policies that will aggravate them.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing— the Treaty of Lisbon laid the foundations for the development of the European Union's security policy, in which it participates jointly with the Member States. It relies on the rule of law, respect for fundamental rights and solidarity and is subject to democratic oversight at European and national level. The security situation in Europe has changed significantly in recent years as a result of new conflicts and unrest in the immediate neighbourhood of the European Union, but also as a result of the rapid development of new technologies. Increasing radicalisation also leads to violence and terrorism. Most of these aspects and security challenges are cross-border in nature beyond the capacity of individual Member States and therefore require a common European approach. I therefore welcome the preparation of the internal security strategy for the next four years.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — I am against motion for a resolution B8-0350/2014, since it deprives the Member States of their national sovereignty, and I cannot trust the European Union in characterising it as radical, since it attributes this characterisation on the basis of political criteria.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it is mainly aimed at starting to reflect on the issues of migration in view of the tragedies that occur every day in the Mediterranean and which we continue to deplore. The status quo is no longer acceptable and current events show the urgency of developing a holistic approach that includes all aspects of migration. Thus, the strengthening of border controls and rescue operations at sea must be coupled with increased cooperation with third countries of transit and origin, more effective implementation of the common European asylum system and the establishment of legal migration routes. The resolution also urges Member States to impose sanctions on human trafficking and the smuggling of migrants, which remains an aspect that is too often overlooked. Finally, it is essential to strengthen solidarity and ensure a better sharing of responsibilities between Member States in order to define a genuine common migration policy.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this motion for resolution because I believe close involvement of Parliament in the development of the new internal security strategy is crucial. I find it severely disappointing that Parliament was barely involved in this process last time. The price was paid by citizens, who were subjected to secret surveillance by Member States and external parties, with the collaboration of private companies. Striking an appropriate balance between combating security threats and protecting fundamental rights can be difficult but is necessary. Take the battle against cybercrime, which is costing the global economy nearly USD 500 billion every year and could cause Europe to lose 150 000 jobs. Due to a lack of transparency, citizens’ calls for a renationalisation of communication structures are becoming louder. But only a collective EU response will allow us to tackle cybercrime.  The lesson is that a security strategy which itself becomes a threat to people is self-defeating. We need a coordinated approach to security that deserves the trust of our citizens.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. — (IT) It is the news that tells us about the urgent needs to be included as a priority in the new internal security strategy. I voted in favour of this resolution because, firstly, we need to improve the ability to analyze natural risks. The Union should work on a credible early warning mechanism. A special effort must also be made to combat violence against women and children: there are still too many cases of violence. And then it is clear that the threats are now global and do not concern the individual regions or even the Member States. Europe is the victim of external threats and, at the same time, we are witnessing more and more cases of European citizens marrying the causes of cross-border wars. Not forgetting that our citizens engaged in voluntary or humanitarian activities abroad are the first victims of terrible violence. We therefore need a truly effective action plan, taking into account the internal and external dimension of security. We must join forces: cooperation and dialogue between the European and national institutions are only the first step. Our citizens have the right to feel secure. It is the perception of security that our citizens have that we have to deal with. This is where mistrust or faith in Europe comes from.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. — The Council will formally adopt the new Internal Security Strategy (ISS); it is therefore crucial that the European Parliament affirms its priorities and reservations in terms of internal security, ahead of the presentation of the new ISS. The development of an EU internal security strategy is an ambitious programme and should lay the groundwork for a more multidisciplinary, coherent and long-term approach to the field. In this new exercise, however, the Commission must undertake a more critical assessment of the previous actions taken, as well as a more forward-looking analysis of emerging emerging threats. Another challenge awaits the Commission: it will have to shape the new ISS by effectively integrating measures to safeguard fundamental rights, and this in all the policies developed.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. — With the explosion in the number of would-be jihadists, which has increased by 116% since the beginning of the year, it is imperative that Europeans review their internal security strategy together to integrate these new forms of threats. The European Parliament is already positioning itself on the occasion of the European Commission's forth- proposal on the strategy for the period 2015-2019. However, Parliament is not free from confusion and ambiguity. I recall that a few weeks ago, the Liberals, supported by the Socialists and the National Front, passed a resolution that delays the entry into force of the PNR with Canada, a key partner in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.  The NRP is an agreement that allows passenger data to be transmitted to better detect suspicious behaviour. This is not Big Brother as we like to think in the collective imagination but a way for the authorized authorities to better protect citizens from possible attacks and attacks. The decision to delay this agreement negotiated for several years is reckless and certainly does not respond to citizens' requests to feel safe at home.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a resolution on the renewal of the EU Internal Security Strategy, which will enter into force for four years to come, as the current Internal Security Strategy (ISS) needs to be thoroughly evaluated and updated.  The new Strategy will cover existing security threats, but also any new ones that have not existed so far, which have also become present internationally and require better cooperation from Member States due to their complexity in order to adequately treat them. This is e.g. online security for children, but also for adults, data protection and privacy, human trafficking, the fight against organised crime, corruption, terrorism, money laundering, various crimes and more.  I believe that a future, updated Internal Security Strategy will better foster operational cooperation between Member States and a European law enforcement culture.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. — It is positive to see that the Parliament adopted the resolution on the Internal Security Strategy. I consider the renewal of the ISS a necessary step forward in order to better identify newly emerged security threats. The Schengen area, enabling free movement across the EU, brought internal security challenges that Member States may find difficult to deal with on their own. Therefore it is crucial for Member States to cooperate and seek to improve their ability to collectively respond to cross-border crime.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on the renewal of the EU's internal security strategy. As the current strategy comes to an end, the text believes that new threats have emerged and must be taken into account in renewing this strategy. Priority areas such as cybercrime, human trafficking, the fight against terrorism and the issue of "foreign combatants" eu nationals should be at the heart of the new internal security strategy. I welcome the broad adoption of this resolution.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. —I supported the resolution on the renewal of the European Union's internal security strategy. With the current strategy coming to an end, MEPs are calling on the Commission, through this resolution, to define an internal security strategy better adapted to the risks that European citizens today face, such as cybercrime, human trafficking, the fight against terrorism and the phenomenon of foreign fighters. In order to meet these new challenges, increased operational cooperation between Member States and the provision of appropriate financial resources will be needed.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution. The EP resolution on the review of the EU’s internal security strategy comes at the right time, just after the Commission has announced that it plans to work on the review in 2015. I call on the Commission to make cyber-security and cyber resilience the underlying principles of the new ISS. Only by fully mainstreaming cyber-security into all aspects of internal and external security can we build proper resilience and prevent crisis. Cyber-security will also be at the core of the fight against terrorism and detecting European jihadists and their possible actions.
