We clearly need very close cross-sectorial and cross-border cooperation in order to be effective in the early detection and rapid notification of threats and incidents. We have to break the traditional cluster-thinking when it comes to security, especially in the EU with open borders and open societies. Proper balance between privacy and security, ensuring that actions follow appropriate procedures, will enable states to prevent incidents, terrorism and crime and provide citizens with the security they are entitled to.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — The new strategy should be easily adaptable to evolving situations, with a joined-up approach across the Union to tackle the increasing problem of foreign fighters, cyber-security, human trafficking, organised crime, money laundering and corruption. The focus must be particularly on the rising number of EU nationals who join terrorist organisations in conflict areas. We must have a multidimensional approach to deal with underlying factors such as radicalisation and intolerance and disrupt financial support to terrorist organisations, preventing the recruitment and providing for legal prosecution where appropriate.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: in writing. — The Treaty of Lisbon gives our institution the role of a full player in the field of security policy, as well as the power to play an active part in setting priorities in order to achieve a comprehensive, targeted and effective EU security policy. With this resolution, Parliament notes that the security situation in Europe has changed radically in recent years and that the threats are more diverse than in the past. In the light of these considerations, we have pushed the Commission to ensure that the new internal security strategy for 2015-2019 is forward-looking and strategic and easily adaptable to changing situations. Therefore, not only focused on existing security threats but also on emerging ones such as cybersecurity, trafficking in human beings and the fight against terrorism and interconnected problems such as organised crime, money laundering and corruption. A fundamental point for us is respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms: all prevention policies and repressive measures must strike the right balance in order to preserve freedom, security and justice.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. — (IT) I am voting in favour of Claude Moraes' report because the motion for a resolution before us emphasises the need to carry out a detailed analysis of the current threats to European security, in order to provide adequate protection for all Community citizens. Specifically, the proposal presented calls for the new internal security strategy (SSI) to focus on both external and emerging threats within the EU's borders. Furthermore, I agree with the reference to the need to strike a fair balance between prevention and repressive policies in order to guarantee freedom, justice and security.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: Writing. — The threats of the 21st century go beyond traditional perception, threats become asymmetrical, wars, identified as hybrid, go into the information space. The Internal Security Strategy 2015-2019 requires a major review and identification of new threats. Cross-border and inter-agency cooperation, regular exchange of information, cooperation with third countries and continuous field of information monitoring are therefore necessary. The EU must be a flag in the fight against terrorism, crimes against humanity, and a proper assessment of the threats posed both in the immediate and distant neighbourhood. As far as the EU's neighbourhood is concerned, I would like to stress once again that no 'green man' can arbitrarily host in the territory of an independent state, and the EU must be prepared to respond appropriately to the actions of any aggressor.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. — The current security challenges in Europe are cross-border, so it is difficult for Member States to provide an individual response. In 2010, the EU Internal Security Strategy (ESI) was adopted, which sets guidelines for addressing security threats in Europe where the EU can add value: international cross-border criminality networks, terrorist attack prevention, cybersecurity, border security or natural disaster resistance. The Commission presented its new ESI proposal 2015-2019 in March. The adopted resolution recognises that the security situation in Europe has changed dramatically due to new conflicts and calls for more effective cooperation between Member States through greater use of valuable existing instruments, such as joint research teams. A forward-looking strategy that focuses on both existing and emerging threats is also called for, with a holistic approach that includes as many areas as possible, such as foreign fighters and cybersecurity threats. Always in accordance with fundamental rights and data protection. That is why I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — I did not vote in favour of this motion for a Resolution which addresses the preparation of a new Internal Security Strategy for the next four years because it is raised on the same basis as before, basing security on a single repressive approach and obviating the radical approach, that is, at the root, on the causes that have generated these new threats. That's why I voted against it.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. — I consider it vital that the new Internal Security Strategy (ESI) for 2015-2019 be thoroughly prepared. We must focus on both existing and emerging security threats, highlighting priority areas such as cybersecurity, trafficking in human beings and the fight against terrorism, and other related issues such as organized crime, money laundering and corruption.  The transit between Europe and conflict zones of European citizens who have joined terrorist groups poses a risk to the internal security of the EU. We must therefore establish mechanisms to analyse and counter this phenomenon, promoting political and religious tolerance, as well as promoting the development of social cohesion, inclusion and facilitating reintegration, and thus discouraging terrorism. In order to meet all these challenges, I believe it is imperative that there be greater interinstitutional and cross-border cooperation, in which the right balance between prevention policies and repressive measures is never harmed, since the purpose is to preserve freedom, security and justice. That is why I vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — The current internal security strategy of the European Union expires at the end of 2014. Accordingly, the Commission is due to issue a statement these days on the new internal security strategy for the period 2015-2019. I supported this Report because it covers all key security issues – the problem of human trafficking, the fight against terrorism, the security of European Union citizens travelling to third countries and countries affected by wars and others. The report calls for a comprehensive approach to ongoing threats to the security of Union citizens.  Furthermore, the emphasis of the new strategy is on protecting victims of war-affected areas. I call on the Commission to provide in the documents for adequate funding for the new security strategy 2015-2019, as well as the financial resources needed by european union security agencies, such as Europol.  Also, the strategy needs better co-ordination in terms of fighting serious crime. Democratic oversight of security strategies under the Treaty should be taken into account.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. - The European Union needs a dynamic and effective security system that can adapt quickly to international change. The dangers to the security of our countries come mainly from outside. The fight against terrorism and the constant threats of attacks unfortunately bring to the agenda of this House a subject that must make us reflect on possible solutions in a particular international context in which the EU certainly remains the safest place in the world. Security threats must therefore be addressed with a sound common strategy, which is why I support the renewal of the EU's internal security strategy.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — The Internal Security Strategy (SSI) for the period 2010-2014 is coming to an end. The new SSI, valid for the period 2015-2019, is being prepared. The motion for a resolution tabled by the Committee on Civil Rights, Justice and Home Affairs, of which I am a member, stresses the need to carry out an in-depth analysis of the current threats to European security, so as to offer all Community citizens adequate protection. The paper calls for the new SSI to focus not only on potential external threats, but also on emerging threats within EU borders. I particularly agree with the reference to the need to strike the right balance between prevention policies and repressive measures, so that freedom, security and justice are properly preserved. My vote in favour of the resolution stems from a full sharing of its content.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — I have received my support for the proposal to renew the EU's internal security strategy, as I believe that the current internal security strategy requires a thorough assessment, updating and modernisation. The current and probably future threat of international terrorism and various other threats require an adjustment of the security apparatus.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — The Internal Security Strategy (ISS) for 2010-2014 is coming to an end and a new ISS for the period 2015-2019 is being developed. The resolution proposes priority avenues for work: "cybersecurity, human trafficking or the fight against terrorism, and in closely related cases such as organised crime, money laundering and corruption". For this reason, the report proposes to "optimise synergies between instruments under the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) and those under justice and home affairs (JAI), including information exchange and police cooperation. This confusing mix of civil and military security is detrimental to citizens' freedoms and effectiveness against crime. All the more so since it is quasi-independent agencies that will be responsible for implementing this strategy. I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — The Treaty of Lisbon laid the foundations for the development of an EU security policy, closely shared by the EU and the Member States, based on the rule of law, respect for fundamental rights and solidarity, subject to democratic supervision at European and national level and, at the same time, respecting the principle of subsidiarity. The entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon gives the European Parliament the role of full-fledged security policy actor with a view to ensuring democratic control, and thus authorises Parliament to actively participate in the definition of priorities in this area and to engage with all relevant actors at EU and national level with a view to developing a comprehensive security policy , targeted and effective in the EU.  In view of the new challenges facing the EU, a new ESI needs to be developed for the next four years, taking into account all the new threats and challenges that arise. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — I welcome the renewal of an EU Internal Security Strategy (ISS) for the period 2015-2019, based on proper democratic oversight and accountability, whilst keeping in accordance with the principles of necessity and proportionality, and the respect for fundamental rights. Due to continuous developments and changes in the field of security, it is of great importance that the renewed ISS be ‘easily adaptable to evolving situations’, with the ability to focus on both existing threats, and emerging ones. The EU and its Member States are responsible for the safety of European citizens from growing radicalisation occurring in the EU’s immediate neighbourhood.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. In the face of new security challenges, Europe must adapt its responses. The use of technology and the rise of radicalisation leading to terrorism and violence require ambitious European responses in which the European Union must play a leading role. Therefore, it is essential that it review its internal security strategy. It should enable it to lay the groundwork for its own security thinking that encompasses issues both locally and internationally. It must also be a further step towards consolidating the European Union's security and justice space. However, it is imperative that the security component be fully accompanied by a counterpart based on scrupulous compliance with the Charter of Fundamental Rights.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of the resolution on Renewing the EU Internal Security Strategy in order to ensure safety, freedom and justice of EU citizens.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution on the renewal of the Internal Security Strategy of the European Union because the measures envisaged here are ridiculously weak in the face of the serious problems faced by the Member States. To believe that a policy of "promoting political and religious tolerance, strengthening social cohesion and opening up to all and simplifying reintegration opportunities" will be effective in combating the rise of jihadism is the most culpable naivety because it endangers the peoples of the Member States. Only the restoration of national borders and serious controls will prevent licensed and future criminals from circulating freely. It has been proven that the EU is incapable of managing its borders, which are real colanders. We must therefore break with the Schengen agreements as a matter of urgency and re-establish our national borders.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. — The EU desperately needs a holistic approach in order to address the rapidly changing security threats facing Europe, including foreign fighters and cyber-security threats. Importantly, fostering a joined-up approach will promote policies centred on fundamental rights such as the right to privacy. The resolution marks the beginning of an extensive and informed debate in the area of internal security.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the resolution on the renewal of the European Union's internal security strategy because I believe it is an excellent opportunity to reaffirm our priorities. Among these, I would like to stress the fight against trafficking in human beings and the fight against terrorism.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the motion for a resolution on the renewal of the internal security strategy. The internal security strategy must be born in cross-border cooperation and be guided by the latest policy and the security threats that have arisen. The new strategy must be forward-looking and easily applicable to changing circumstances.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — The Treaty of Lisbon laid the foundations for the development of an EU security policy closely shared by the EU and its Member States and therefore the EU and its Member States have a common responsibility to ensure the security and freedom of European citizens. In recent years, the security situation in Europe has changed radically due to new conflicts and upheavals in the EU's immediate neighbourhood. The Internal Security Strategy (SSI) for 2010-2014 is coming to an end and a new SSI is being prepared for the period 2015-2019. For these reasons, I would vote in favour.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — Following parliamentary questions addressed to the Commission and the Council at the last EP plenary session, I support the Resolution of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs on the renewal of the EU Internal Security Strategy.  The Internal Security Strategy adopted in 2010 identifies the main challenges and threats to the EU's internal security. Since then, circumstances have changed: the EU and the Member States face a number of new challenges, and Europe will face the consequences of instability in different parts of the world and in the immediate neighbourhood. Events such as the Arab Spring, the current crisis in Syria and the situation in Ukraine require adequate responses and a redefined Strategy covering existing and future threats and empowering the interaction between the internal and external dimensions of security policy.  As the current internal security strategy ends in 2014 and the European Commission has launched policy discussions and consultations to prepare for the development of a new internal security strategy for 2015-2019, I consider it important that the European Parliament presents a substanomatural resolution at this time on the priorities and activities to be included in the new strategy.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — Given that the current Internal Security Strategy (SSI/2010-2014) comes to an end and considering that in recent years we are facing a more complex security situation in Europe, mainly due to new conflicts and upheavals in the EU neighbourhood and increasing radicalisation leading to violence and terrorism, it is important – and I fully agree with the resolution – that the current SSI be assessed, updated and renewed in response to new security threats.  At the same time, full protection of the fundamental rights of EU citizens is a priority. I also hope that the new SSI will provide adequate financial resources for the proper implementation of the necessary measures, in particular for the proper functioning of EU agencies such as Europol and Eurojust.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. "I welcome this motion for a resolution on the security of the Union, whether internal or external. Indeed, a more coherent and coordinated Europe in its action would enable large savings of means and greater efficiency, especially in the fight against crime.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — Following the Treaty of Lisbon, which laid the foundations for the development of a European Union (EU) security policy and gave the European Parliament the role of full-fledged security policy player, authorising it to engage in dialogue with all actors, national and Community, with a view to developing a comprehensive, targeted and effective security policy in the EU. Whereas the security situation in Europe has changed radically in recent years due to the emergence of new conflicts, and is now a cross-border and cross-sectoral problem, and freedom, security and justice are objectives that have to be pursued in parallel. Given that the development of a new Internal Security Strategy (ISS) for the next four years should consider new security threats and the entry of the Charter of Fundamental Rights into EU law. Radicalisation and the rapid growth in the number of EU nationals joining terrorist organisations are worrying, and then return to Europe. Finally, stressing the need to ensure adequate financial resources for the proper implementation of the measures provided for in the ESI, I voted in favour of this resolution on the renewal of the ESI.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. " Through this resolution, to which I have supported, the European Parliament presents its contribution to the Union's new internal security strategy. As it faces increasing security threats, the European Union needs a comprehensive, coherent and forward-looking response to ensure the protection of its citizens. The increase in the number of European fighters who join terrorist organisations in conflict zones, and wish to return to Europe, poses an undeniable risk to our security. To deal with this worrying phenomenon, MEPs want the EU to take a cross-cutting approach, particularly addressing radicalisation and intolerance, sources of funding for terrorist organisations and recruitment. Cybercrime, human trafficking, organised crime, money laundering and corruption are all concerns that require coordinated action at European level, with the participation of all Member States. Finally, the European Parliament reminds us that security measures should always be guided by the balance between the protection of citizens and respect for their fundamental rights. This is an indispensable condition for preserving the integrity of the European area of freedom, security and justice.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. —I voted in favour of this report, which renews the European Union's internal security strategy (SSI) for the next four years. Indeed, since the introduction of the current ISS, adopted in December 2003, new security threats have emerged in Europe and elsewhere, threats that now call for a different political response. In fact, these security threats have become more varied, more international, more heterogeneous and more asymmetrical, which requires greater cooperation between different countries. It is also important to strengthen operational cooperation between Member States and to do so, to adopt more measures aimed at building trust. However, I still deplore the lack of a real legal dimension of the ISS. Indeed, in the spirit of the Stockholm programme, more work should be done to strengthen mutual trust through the gradual development of a European judicial culture, through European cooperation and regulation in this area and to strengthen judicial cooperation in criminal matters.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — At a time when we are witnessing, according to a recent assessment by Europol, an increase in serious and organised crime and, at the same time, threats to international peace and security caused by terrorist acts, I consider it extremely important, I would say fundamentally, that a renewal of the EU's Internal Security Strategy (ISS) be carried out for the next four years. I therefore highlight the relevance of the oral question which gave rise to this resolution, which I voted in favour of. I would also like to remind you that it is essential, in order to promote the effectiveness of the ESI, to carry out a full analysis of security threats, in close collaboration between Europol, other relevant EU bodies and the Member States, especially when the Treaty of Lisbon laid the foundations for the development of a security policy that is shared with the Member States.  A policy based on the rule of law, respect for fundamental rights and where the European Parliament takes on a full-fledged intervening role with a view to democratic control and the development of a comprehensive, effectively targeted and effective policy in the European Union.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. — The European Union's current internal security strategy is coming to an end and this resolution concerns the next internal security strategy to be published by the Commission in spring 2015. I supported this resolution, which calls for a comprehensive, integrated and comprehensive approach to priority areas such as cybercrime, human trafficking or the fight against terrorism. In addition, the focus is on the issue of "foreign fighters" and enhanced operational cooperation between Member States is called for.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I did not vote in favour of this motion for a Resolution which addresses the preparation of a new Internal Security Strategy for the next four years because it is raised on the same basis as before, basing security on a only repressive approach and obviating the radical approach, that is, at the root, on the causes that have generated these new threats. That's why I voted against it.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: in writing. - (IT) The internal security strategy and the proposed resolution seem to me to be a programme that imitates American counter-terrorism, in too many respects. It is self-legislative and managed by closed agencies (Europol essentially), without consulting the bodies responsible for defining threats to the Union: the Council, the national parliaments, the European Parliament. Furthermore, the resolution covers almost only measures of repression. There is almost nothing about prevention.  The word 'fundamental rights' barely appears in the 'declarative' paragraphs of the resolution and without mentioning specific articles of the Charter. Meanwhile, the Member States remain free to do what they want, with initiatives on an exclusively voluntary basis or apparently common actions such as 'Mos Maiorum', for which the Member States are not answerable to anyone.  For these reasons, I voted against this resolution.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — Security in every community, including in the European Union, is a basic condition of survival, both social and economic and is a fundamental value of society. New forms of safety protection must also be found with new hazards. Security is a fundamental human right and freedom. The European Union is obliged to protect its citizens, their lives and health and fundamental human rights. I welcome the new internal security strategy, which means upgrading the European Union in protecting citizens, better sharing of police service information, better fight against crime and a better asylum protection system that poses a major unresolved european union problem. We are all aware of the seriousness of the problems related to crime, terrorism and natural disasters that are a breeding ground for the development of serious crime. I hope that this renewal of the strategy will really contribute to the internal security of the entire European Union and its citizens.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — This proposal deprives the Member States of their national sovereignty.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of the text. I welcome the development of a new ISS for the next four years. Since the introduction of the current ISS, new security threats have emerged and others call for a different political response. We also reaffirm that with the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, the Charter of Fundamental Rights has been incorporated into EU law. I sincerely believe that the current ISS needs to be fully evaluated, updated and reorganized.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I believe that in the name of 'security' they are actually intended to weaken the rights of citizens and make it potentially suspicious.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. — The EU's first internal security strategy adopted in 2011 is coming to an end. In anticipation of a future proposal from the European Commission, the European Parliament (EP) has taken the initiative to propose its guidelines. But the resolution adopted by the majority of the EP is once again marked by a largely repressive approach focused mainly on the fight against terrorism without taking into account the numerous violations of fundamental rights that it has resulted from, as the US Senate report on the CIA's use of torture after the attacks of 11 September 2001 has just shown. I regret the rejection of the amendments I tabled on behalf of the GUE/NGL, which call for preventive measures, a multi-dimensional approach to security including the fight against inequality and discrimination, and an independent and contradictory assessment of the current strategy. I therefore voted against this resolution, which takes no assessment of the current policies which are increasingly infringing on fundamental rights without demonstrating their effectiveness.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — The reference to the establishment of the current ESI, new security threats have emerged, citing the examples of cybersecurity, trafficking in human beings, the fight against terrorism and interrelated issues, as well as organised crime, money laundering and corruption, is proof of the failure of the political guidelines of the majority of the EP and the responsibilities of this same strategy in the period that now ends. It is necessary to disprove the hypocritical version of the security problem. This approach is more of a target than concealing our own responsibilities.  This resolution confirms that security problems will never be solved by the same ones that not only provoked it but are preparing policies that will aggravate them.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. - I believe that the current internal security strategy requires both a thorough assessment and modernisation. The current and probably future threat of international terrorism and various other threats requires a corresponding adjustment of the security apparatus. I have therefore voted in favour of the motion.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — The reference to the establishment of the current ESI, new security threats have emerged, citing examples of cybersecurity, trafficking in human beings, the fight against terrorism, as well as organised crime, money laundering and corruption is proof of the failure of the political guidelines of the majority of the EP and its responsibilities in the period that now ends. It is necessary to disprove the hypocritical version of the security problem which, being important, is nothing more than concealing its own responsibilities. One example is trafficking in human beings, a reality that continues to be a drama for thousands of human beings and in particular for immigrants who find themselves pushed into the hands of criminal organisations by the EU's repressive and criminalising policies. Another example is the problem of citizens of EU Member States travelling to conflict zones and joining terrorist organisations, which serves to camouflage support for these terrorist organisations by providing weapons, training and financing, with a view to destabilising Syria. This resolution confirms that security problems will never be solved by them, who have not only provoked it but are preparing policies that will aggravate them.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that this is a very important day for this Parliament and we hope that it will also be a moment of radical change for the Palestinian resistance and for the Palestinian people, for the recognition of the State of Palestine, for the peace process, for security and for justice for both peoples.  135 states have already recognised the State of Palestine. I call on all my fellow Members to go to those areas, where they will be able to see for themselves the destruction that has caused the war that has brought the State of Israel to war in recent months as well. The Palestinians have always called for a mediating role for the European Union, a role different from that of the United States. I hope that this resolution will be a step in that direction. Indeed, I hope that this is an important moment for this Parliament and for the European Union as a whole to really work for peace and security for both peoples.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: Mr President, I voted in favour of the joint resolution as a principled step in the right direction. Recognition of the Palestinian State, its people and its borders is a long overdue international obligation and a positive step towards peace. Member States like Ireland must now formally recognise and must protect the space of the Palestinian State within the 1967 borders, with East Jerusalem as its capital.  Palestinian recognition is established in UN resolutions and was voted on in Leinster House in Dublin last week. The Palestinian people’s right to self-determination has been enshrined in international resolutions for 66 years. Sinn Féin calls on all parties to refrain from any actions which may undermine the viability and the prospects of the two-state solution. Therefore, settlements must end, the apartheid wall must be dismantled and attacks on holy sites – along with the demolition of Palestinian property – must stop immediately.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: Mr President, along with my colleagues, I supported the resolution in relation to Palestinian statehood. I believe that it is a very welcome first step by this Parliament, but I believe that this Parliament and Europe and our Member States need to do much more in relation to supporting the Palestinian people and ensuring that the Palestinian State is not only recognised but is in fact a viable and operational state.  Only last summer we saw unprecedented, illegal and absolutely outrageous attacks by Israel on the people of Gaza. We have a responsibility as people elected by Member States across the continent of Europe to ensure that those attacks do not happen again, and to ensure that we stand up as communities and nations to Israel, because its ongoing disregard for international law is unacceptable. I believe that today we have taken a first step, but it is only a very small step and lots more remains to be done.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: Mr President, this is not our resolution. This is not a perfect resolution. We miss, for example, a clear condemnation of Israel's continued violations of international legality. However, we voted for it. We voted in favour of it and, moreover, with some enthusiasm, quite excitedly, for the consensus it has generated. And above all, because without fissures or conditions it recognises the will of this Parliament — the will, therefore, of European citizenship — to support the construction of a Palestinian state. It recognizes the need and the right of the Palestinian people, who live secularly in their territories, to create a modern state, an homologable and internationally recognized state, in order to ensure the well-being, social justice and future of its people. And it also involves Europe again on the international front line. It involves Europe in this peace process, in which we were not heard for a long time, and it is time for us to go back to it.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Mr President, thank you for giving the word. I would like to express why I did not support the resolution concerning the process of recognition of a Palestinian state. I consider the recognition of a Palestinian state to be possible and desirable only as a result of a bilateral agreement. That is, joint agreements between Israel and Palestine and as a result of the peace process. The resolution that has been approved is not so clear-cut and can therefore be interpreted differently and therefore misused. I consider this to be a risk, especially at a time when there is an election campaign in Israel. Therefore, for these reasons, I could not support this resolution.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Mr President, we voted on the recognition of the Palestinian State. Although I think that the two-state solution might be one of the solutions, I had to vote against this resolution for the following reasons: first of all, supporting this resolution is a violation of the Oslo II Accord of 1995, Article 16.7, stressing that both sides will do nothing to change the status of the Palestinian Authorities pending the outcome of the permanent status negotiations. Even the EU signed this agreement as a witness, so it seems we can question this signature now. Furthermore, the recognition of the Palestinian State with its current government might seem to be a de facto recognition of the terrorist organisation Hamas, which is officially in government at the moment even though today I received an intriguing press release stating that the EU General Court is removing Hamas from the list of terrorist organisations on procedural grounds. This is intriguing after 13 years. Besides this, although I do recognise the rights of the Palestinians, recognition today will be an extra barrier to the peace negotiations. The statement calls it ‘in principle recognition’, but everyone will see it as a full recognition. For both Israel and Palestine, this would be a step back.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: The European Union has repeatedly expressed support for a peaceful solution to the Conflict between Palestine and Israel and has tried to find the best solution to stop practical daily violence. And that's actually been the last few decades. As early as 2012, the European Parliament stressed in its adopted resolution that a peaceful and non-violent way of accepting an agreement and dialogue between Palestine and Israel is the only possible and meaningful way of ing for a long-term settlement of the conflict.  And, of course, today we also hear reasons that speak in favor of or in favor of recognising Palestine as an independent state, but if recognition of Palestine were an obstacle to peace, it would have been concluded a long time ago. That is why, of course, I support this resolution and Palestine as an independent state, because in the 21st century this seems to me to be the only sensible and wise way and a step forward for a peaceful settlement of the conflict.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: Mr President, I am really pleased that today the European Parliament voted by a huge majority – with only 88 voting against – to recognise the State of Palestine. I am also pleased to see a reference in today’s resolution to votes in the Irish Parliament. So at last we have a common view from this Parliament that respects many of the sensitivities involved around the issue. When you see leaders from the EPP, the Socialists, the ECR, the Liberals, the Greens, largely in agreement – yes, there are some issues about timing – but they are largely in agreement, that is a step forward.  Yes, we know our vote today is symbolic but it clearly states the opinion of Parliament in favour of recognition of a Palestinian State and a two-state solution on the basis of the 1967 borders. There is real urgency about the current situation, and the continuing expansion of Israeli settlements. The Israelis need security, and the Palestinians need their own borders – their own state. I hope that today’s resolution will play some small role in delivering peace to that region.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Mr. President, I see the European Parliament's joint resolution on the principled recognition of Palestinian statehood as the beginning or continuation of a historically important process, not a stop or relativization of it. The resolution is a welcome compromise between the main political groups that share the same goal but differ in how to achieve it. It finally opens the space for a more engaged performance of European diplomacy in a part of the world that this year has been particularly raucous with old conflicts and new brutalities.  I do not see a future, independent Palestine as a new factor in the emergence of a protracted conflict, but as a new possibility for a more effective search, for a more lasting peace solution. I would quote an Israeli politician who recently said that Israel should not be exhausted by waiting for the ideal partner on the Palestinian side to conclude a lasting peace agreement. On the other hand, our resolution raises expectations for Palestinian representatives to responsibly exploit the trust of the European Parliament and contribute to the realisation of the concept of two states that cooperate in peace by giving up violence and terrorism.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: Mr President, I am proud today that I voted in favour of this resolution. It is a step in the right direction for Palestinian statehood, and although it is well overdue, resolutions such as this one are part of a growing movement across Europe to support a Palestinian State. This month the Dáil in Ireland added its voice to this growing movement by agreeing to the adoption of a Sinn Féin motion which called on the government to respect Palestinians’ right to self-determination and to recognise the state of Palestine. With Israeli actions such as the recent devastating war in Gaza and the aggressive expansion of illegal settlements in the West Bank having serious impacts on the progression of talks, it is essential that the international community underlines its support for Palestinian statehood. This resolution should send out a strong signal that Palestinian statehood is essential to progress a meaningful peace process.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Although this decision has undoubtedly been adopted by a very large proportion of the European Parliament, it is fitting that I might be able to speak for those who abstained in this vote. The reason for this abstention was that I wanted to express my reservations about the specific content of this decision, but most importantly its timing and its expected international impact. While those who believe that this decision is a step forward in terms of peace are right, I think it is most important that the European Union play a much stronger, more meaningful role than before in moving the Middle East peace process forward and working towards a lasting peace settlement resulting in a two-state solution resulting from the negotiations between the parties. To this end, The High Representative Mogherini's ambition to develop a united and targeted European position deserves all the support it can get, which, of course, requires time and meaningful cooperation from the European Parliament, the European institutions and the Member States. The push for unilateral recognition of a Palestinian state by the Member States in the absence of political conditions is, in my view, a hindrance to this important objective in the present situation, bearing in mind that recognition should be the result of a peace settlement, not a means of resettling it.

name: Karima DELLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let us not be ungrateful to ourselves. Many here have tried to prevent this vote for a month, both Eurosceptic and conservative. They would have preferred the European Parliament to stand on the sidelines and see the train of history pass once again. Well, no, no, Europe is, for once, in its rightful place in favour of peace and it writes it in black and white. Of course, there are shortcomings in this resolution: it does not condemn, for example, Israeli colonization, which is one of the major obstacles to peace and the two-state solution that we advocate in the text. I hope that the UN Security Council, which is due to rule soon on a motion calling for an end to the settlements by 2016, will have the courage to say "stop". Nevertheless, we can be proud to join our voices with those of the other national parliaments in the European Union, which have also called for recognition of the Palestinian state in recent weeks.  Today, our Palestinian friends and our Israeli friends know that, at this time, we stand with them. Let us hope that the wind of hope coming from Europe will help them to form the State of Palestine that they have long demanded.

name: Nathan GILL
text: Mr President, UKIP advocates the two-state solution. Personally speaking, I believe that recognition of Palestine would make it easier for the international community to bring the two-state solution into being. I am confident that, one day, Palestine will be recognised, but what we were asked to vote on today called on the Commission to act, and I have no faith in the Commission.  Just look at what EU interference has done in Ukraine, in Libya and in the former Yugoslavia. EU imperialism is a destructive and destabilising force in the world and I cannot and will not encourage it. Let us be in no doubt: recognising states is itself an act of statehood. My colleague, James Carver, put a question to the Commission on the recognition of Somaliland, and in reply the Commission confirmed that the EU does not have the competence to recognise states. For this reason I cannot countenance any request that the EU act as if it were a state.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: I have said in advance that I will not support this resolution because its text in its current form does not solve anything and I consider today's decision by the European Parliament to be very flawed. In view of what I have said before, I think there are anti-Semitic and anti-Israeli views again. I do not think that this resolution will help to calm the Palestinian-Israeli territory.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: My party NVA supported this resolution. For us, two things are paramount when it comes to the discussion around Palestine as a state, a discussion that is too complex to be conducted only in black-and-whitermen: mutual respect, which makes negotiations possible, and security. The road to a Palestinian state is therefore that of politics and diplomacy. According to the right of peoples to self-determination, we support the recognition of Palestine as a state and the two-state solution in principle, when parallel with peace negotiations between Israel and the Palestinian authorities, with international support, so that recognition becomes possible at the most appropriate time. That moment must be chosen on the basis of, among other things, the evolution of the consultations, the existence of a full-fledged Palestinian government with authority over the entire Palestinian territory, and the borders of the territory of the State of Palestine of 1967. This is the only way to create a lasting solution to the conflict in the Middle East.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Mr. President, I voted for this resolution because it reflects my position, as well as that of the European commoners on the establishment of two states to be reached through peace talks.  Namely, statehood requires a legal and orderly functioning that excludes support for organisations that may be called terrorists or governed by the principles of any form of fundamentalism including religious ones. Hamas' behaviour, their resistance to finding nonviolent solutions and supporting attacks on Israeli territory, and using their own people as a living shield are the biggest obstacle to the resumption of peace talks. The cessation of armed attacks by the Palestinian Authority and the resumption of peace talks are therefore a precondition for the recognition of a Palestinian state. Also, both sides must allow humanitarian organisations to deliver humanitarian aid to the people of Palestine undisturbed under the Geneva Convention.  On this occasion, I once again call on the opposing parties to continue the peace talks and find solutions that will ensure and enable Security for Israel, and for Palestine to have statehood and solutions that will ensure lasting peace in this area.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: Mr President, today's vote by the European Parliament on Palestine is undoubtedly a mistake. It's a mistake for two reasons.  Firstly, the European Parliament is once again sticking its nose into something that is none of its business. Unfortunately, the European Parliament has no powers, nor does the European Commission have any powers to recognise individual states. It is such a sensitive and delicate matter that we all know that the positions of the individual Member States of the European Union are different, and if the European Parliament insensitively tries to spark this into one template, then it is making a mistake and exuding this sensitive subject unnecessarily. Secondly, I fear that today's vote may also encourage radical elements on the Palestinian side. If today the European Court of Justice has taken Hamas off the list of terrorist organisations, even temporarily, then, combined with our vote today, this may act as support for those forces that we do not want and should not support – that is, those that do not stand up to violence and terrorism. And that's why, in my opinion, it's a big mistake.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: Mr President, I support a two-state solution, as does my party. However, how can this House vote to recognise statehood for one country, namely Palestine, when it has admitted that it does not have the jurisdiction to do so? My voters sent me here to stop you inflicting damage on my country, yet you are extending your damage beyond our borders when you have no right to do so at all.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: Mr President, I will not apologise for being repetitive but my colleagues Jim Carver and Nigel Farage request a point of order on why an e-mail of authority from the EU stated that they had no power, ability or right to recognise a Member State, yet today this was not the case. It seems that the right hand does not know what the left hand is doing. Does this mean that anything written by the EU has no substance? I believe so.

name: Diane JAMES
text: Mr President, recognition of Palestinian statehood was a very emotive subject here today. The intent may have been laudable but the process wholly deficient and hence my abstention. I could not endorse a motion for which the European Union has no agreed competence and thus no authority. EU interference could yet again undermine, not support, genuine attempts to resolve conflict in this area and if anything could heighten tensions. Symbolic pretence and retrospective justification for this motion is unacceptable, as is misleading citizens and raising the hopes of Palestinians totally and wholly reprehensible. Abstention on this basis was my chosen option and I stand by it.

name: David COBURN
text: Mr President, I voted against the Palestinian state as recognising a Palestinian state is not within the competence of this Parliament. On 3 October the Commission wrote to my UKIP colleague, James Carver MEP, to explain that the EU cannot recognise Somaliland, or any other state, and that this was the privilege of the nation states of the European Union. Therefore this so-called recognition of Palestine is illegal and the Commission has admitted it in writing. Mr President, you should have ruled against it but you did not.  Recognition of Palestine, or otherwise, should be left to nation states and the United Nations. No one in Great Britain voted for a European state; we voted only for a trading bloc. This House has got well above itself. If Pontius Pilate could not solve the problem in the Middle East with the threat of the galleys and crucifixion, how does this pathetic parliament think it can do better? It would be best left trying to sort out the deficit and the collapsing euro and not bothering with things it has no ability to deal with.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I shall reply to the honourable Member on matters for which I am responsible. I have read the tense of the resolution. It was very clear why there was no actual recognition, because it was a support for recognition. So a political document with no legislative effect. It was a political statement.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, after 67 years of pain, death and suffering, one of the longest and bloodiest conflicts in history is still a lanightly wound in the heart of the Middle East. As the Five Star Movement, we are aware that this resolution is far from being the culmination of the peace process that we all want. But it is still an important step in the direction of justice. I am pleased with the large majority expressed by this Parliament. We have finally clarified the distinction between recognition, which is the responsibility of the Member States – but which must be a harmonious recognition not a cacophony of voices, but a chorus on the part of our States, and this will be the work of High Representative Mogherini – and between the peace process that is the responsibility of Israel and Palestine, where we are mediators. But without a real COMMITMENT by the EU to building a Palestinian state that can guarantee security in the region, for both states, administer according to the rule of law and reconcile the different factions and achieve social justice, this recognition will be just a fig leaf to wash our consciences and blindness in recent decades. Money is not enough. We must therefore do everything in our power to prevent the opposite extremism in Israel and Palestine from prevailing. We have a lot of work ahead of us in the next few years. Let us not forget that.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Written. — (SV) Today the European Parliament voted on a joint resolution on the recognition of Palestine as a state. I voted against the resolution and instead supported the EPP motion for a resolution, which was far more balanced than the common text adopted by a majority of Members. There are several reasons why I voted against the joint resolution. See http://adaktusson.eu/kontraproduktivt-palestinabeslut-europaparlamentet/ for a detailed explanation of vote.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. — (IT) The European Parliament has adopted a resolution, which can be described as historic, on the recognition of the Palestinian State and which comes in the wake of the Decision of the Court of Justice to annul the Council's decision to include Hamas on the black list of organizations considered to be terrorists. With this resolution, the European Parliament recognises the State of Palestine for the first time on the basis of the borders established in 1967 and declares its support for a two-state solution with Jerusalem as the capital of both states, while at the same time calling for the resumption of peace negotiations. This is an historic position which could be a first step towards a stable solution to the thorny and unresolved Palestinian question. For these reasons, I have wholely voted in favour of the resolution. Now, however, the ball is in the individual Member States, which must work to make this act effective. We, as Members of the European Parliament, have done so: it is now up to the government of our country to act in accordance with what has been approved by members here in Strasbourg.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. — Recognition of the Palestinian state is a necessary but not sufficient step to achieve peace between Israel and Palestine. I believe that the only way to resolve this conflict is through the 1967 two-state border-based solution, with Jerusalem as the capital of both states. In this way, the State of Israel could live in peace and security with an independent, democratic and viable Palestinian state. I support this motion for a resolution as a compromise solution and because of the high value of both the broad consensus reached among all the groups in this Parliament and the important message we send with it. I would like to express my strong support for the recognition of a State of Palestine, as the right of Palestinians to have their own state is unquestionable as is Israel's right to exist within secure borders. I also value the leadership of High Representative Federica Mogherini in this process, as I believe that the EU should play a more effective and genuine role in the peace process, and I believe it is necessary for EU Member States to be united in supporting this legitimate process.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the motion for a Resolution on the recognition of the State of Palestine as a first step in the right direction. Recognition of the State of Palestine, its people, its borders and the end of the occupation is an international obligation and an important step towards peace. Member States must now formally recognize, and therefore protect, the space of the State of Palestine at the 1967 borders with East Jerusalem as its capital. The Palestinian people's right to self-determination has been recognized internationally for 66 years. We call on all parties not to take any action that could dynamite the feasibility of the two States' solution. Therefore, settlements must end, apartheid must be over, and the attack on sacred sites and the demolition of Palestinian property must cease immediately.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. After the adoption by many national parliaments of motions on the recognition of the Palestinian state in recent weeks, I am pleased that the European Parliament has drafted and voted on a resolution for the recognition of the State of Palestine. It is an act of justice and peace in order to make progress towards a definitive settlement of this conflict. The current political impasse reinforces the most radical elements and hate speech to the detriment of the innocent civilian population. The status quo is untenable and dangerous. This commitment is also a call for the resumption of negotiations and the unblocking of the peace process. It is part of the collective will to contribute to the international peace effort in the Middle East to put an end to the infernal cycle of violence. The Socialists have always supported this desire for reconciliation between the Israeli and Palestinian peoples, based, in accordance with UN resolutions, on the existence of two sovereign and democratic states living side by side in peace and security, on the basis of the 1967 lines, with Jerusalem as the capital of the two states.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. — The 'yes' vote, expressed by a large majority, to the recognition in principle of the statehood of Palestine is based on the two-state solution with the 1967 borders and Jerusalem as its capital. It is essential that this step goes hand in hand with the resumption of peace talks. I welcome this recognition because it is not only an important sign in the self-determination of the Palestinians, but also calls on both states to resume peace negotiations. The 'Parliamentarians for Peace' initiative, which aims to bring us MEPs together with colleagues from Israel and Palestine, is also extremely gratifying in order to set out an agenda for peace.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing. — The position now taken by the European Parliament, in all fair words, should, among other things, encourage greater involvement of the European Union in the process of resolving the Israel-Palestine conflict. The recognition of the right to establish a Palestinian state with the borders before the 1967 war is a symbolic act of the greatest importance. For all those who advocate the need for the coexistence of the two States, this moment is of particular importance.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: in writing. — Voted against. The European Commission has already stated that it does not have the authority to recognise states or otherwise, so this vote was technically illegal. A point of order raised by a UKIP colleague tried to raise this point, but was ignored by the President. It is for individual nations to set foreign policy, not the European Union. I will not vote for any motion that seeks to legitimise the presence of the EU on the world stage.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: Written. — The resolution is one-sided, for example, by mentioning only Israeli deaths and not Palestinian civilians, killed by the IDF!!. It does not explain the security of a future Palestinian state and has no time perspective for recognition. However, the resolution is important to support because, for the first time, we are separating peace negotiations and the recognition of a Palestinian state. It is important that a unified European Parliament gives its support to the two-state solution and clearly within the 67 border, with Jerusalem as its capital. The European Parliament is giving its support here to the momentum we have, with the parliaments of several and more Member States calling on their governments to be recognised and Palestine submitting its application to the United Nations. Although I would like to see a clearer resolution, it is important right now to show the Member States that a very broad majority in the European Parliament supports the unconditional recognition of Palestine.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. — Recognition of the Palestinian state is a necessary but not sufficient step to achieve peace between Israel and Palestine. I believe that the only way to resolve this conflict is through the 1967 two-state border-based solution, with Jerusalem as the capital of both states. In this way, the State of Israel could live in peace and security with an independent, democratic and viable Palestinian state. I support this motion for a resolution as a compromise solution and because of the high value of both the broad consensus reached among all the groups in this Parliament and the important message we send with it. I would like to express my strong support for the recognition of a State of Palestine, as the right of Palestinians to have their own state is unquestionable as is Israel's right to exist within secure borders. I also value the leadership of High Representative Federica Mogherini in this process, as I believe that the EU should play a more effective and genuine role in the peace process, and I believe it is necessary for EU Member States to be united in supporting this legitimate process.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution. The EU has repeatedly confirmed its support for an Israeli-Palestinian decision that respects the 1967 borders, Jerusalem would be the capital of both states and both states would be peacefully and securely side-by-side. I welcome the call for the political leaders of the countries to cooperate and to take action to alleviate the tense situation. I welcome the High Representative's commitment to actively promote a positive process aimed at enabling real progress in the peace process. I believe that the EU must become a more active player and mediator in the Middle East peace process and develop a comprehensive strategy for resolving the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I abstained because I denounce the hypocrisy of the European Union, which claims to recognise a state while it is constantly fighting the sovereignty of its Member States.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. — What the European Parliament voted on and approved today is NOT the recognition of Palestine as a State.  What the Eurochamber has approved today by an overwhelming majority is the realization of an express and valuable gesture of recognition of the two-state solution and the revival of the peace process. A process of which mutual recognition and the safe and peaceful coexistence of both states are an inexcusable part.  The European Parliament thus stands as a demanding supervisor of the implementation of this process and calls on the Commission for a single position which it has entrusted to Mrs Mogherini. The demand for democratic behaviour and respect for human rights is twofold: on the one hand, Israel, the only strong democracy in the Middle East, the EU's trade and strategic partner; and, on the other hand, Palestine, which must still be accredited and acted as a state, endowed with a single government, establish democratic practices and solvent institutions and condemn terrorism.  Yes. With all its shortcomings, this is a valuable gesture. That is why, despite the vagueness and infinite possibilities of interpretation which leads to an ambiguous and accommodating text, I voted in favour.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Resolution because it includes the recognition of the Palestinian State and the two-State solution on the 1967 borders, with Jerusalem as the capital of both: a safe and independent, democratic, contiguous and viable Palestinian State, living side by side in peace and security, on the basis of the right to self-determination and full respect for international law. Condemning all acts of terrorism and violence.  And because it defends the need for the development of peace negotiations. And thus consolidate the authority of the consensual Palestinian government by calling on all Palestinian factions, including Hamas, to end internal divisions. The Resolution reiterates that Israeli settlements are illegal under international law and I believe, in accordance with the Resolution, that the EU must become a facilitator of the Middle East peace process and that is why we call on Mrs Mogherini to facilitate the achievement of a common position in the Union for this purpose. The high representative needs significant support from Parliament for Europe to play the much-needed role.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the joint resolution on the recognition of the Palestinian State as a principled step in the right direction, although some parts of the resolution are not in line with my views. Recognition of the Palestinian State, its people and its borders, and the end of the occupation is a long-overdue international obligation and a positive step towards peace. Member States must now formally recognise and thus protect the space of the Palestinian State on the 1967 borders with East Jerusalem as the capital. Palestinian recognition is established in UN resolutions and a number of national parliaments of EU Member States have called on their respective governments to recognise this. The Palestinian people’s right to self-determination has been enshrined in international resolutions for 66 years. We call on all parties to refrain from any action which may undermine the viability and the prospects of the two-state solution.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I abstained on this vote of recognition of the Palestinian state since I consider, in fact, that only sovereign states can recognize another state. Despite my desire to see a free and independent Palestinian state recognized and a lasting peace in the deadly conflict with Israel, this text must not fall within the competence of this supranational entity, the EU.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — Recognition of the Palestinian state is a necessary but not sufficient step to achieve peace between Israel and Palestine. I believe that the only way to resolve this conflict is through the 1967 two-state border-based solution, with Jerusalem as the capital of both states. In this way, the State of Israel could live in peace and security with an independent, democratic and viable Palestinian state. I support this motion for a resolution as a compromise solution and because of the high value of both the broad consensus reached among all the groups in this Parliament and the important message we send with it. I would like to express my strong support for the recognition of a State of Palestine, as the right of Palestinians to have their own state is unquestionable as is Israel's right to exist within secure borders. I also value the leadership of High Representative Federica Mogherini in this process, as I believe that the EU should play a more effective and genuine role in the peace process, and I believe it is necessary for EU Member States to be united in supporting this legitimate process.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. — I supported the resolution on the recognition of Palestinian statehood, as I believe that the Middle East peace process has long been blocked and there is no indication that the situation will change any time soon. The introduction of new elements, such as international recognition of a Palestinian state, can give the necessary impulse to find a just solution and achieve lasting peace in the Middle East.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted for this resolution because I think the time has come to send a strong message for peace and reconciliation in the Middle East.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — The recognition of a third state, a prerogative of international law reserved for a sovereign state, should not be devolved to the European Union. It is therefore unacceptable to put to the vote of the European Parliament a text which violates international legality and custom to such an extent. However, I support the Palestinian Authority in its noble struggle for the recognition of a Palestinian state within the 1967 borders, as well as the placement of the Holy City of Jerusalem under international mandate. That is why I abstained on the vote of this resolution by the European Parliament.

name: Elmar BROK
text: in writing. - The European Parliament rejects unconditional recognition of Palestine  The EPP Group welcomes the fact that the European Parliament supported a resolution today on the recognition of Palestinian statehood and the two-state solution, but ‘hand in hand’ with the development of the peace talks. ‘With this vote, the European Parliament clearly rejected an unconditional recognition separated from the peace negotiations’, pointed out the EPP Group co-negotiator of the resolution and Chairman of Foreign Affairs, Elmar Brok MEP. ‘The EPP Group believes, as does the majority of the European Parliament, that early negotiations are necessary to make a secure Israel and a viable and democratic Palestinian State possible on the basis of the 1967 borders and under international law. Both sides must refrain from any actions that could jeopardise that goal. The European Parliament has rightly demanded that all Palestinian factions, including Hamas, recognise the existence of the State of Israel in accordance with the 1993 declaration of the Palestinian Liberation Organisation (PLO). The EPP Group supports the position of the European Parliament against Israeli settlement policy’, Brok explained. The EPP Group also welcomes the fact that the resolution rejects any form of violence and terrorism from all sides and warns against a potential religious dimension in the conflict. For EPP Group MEPs, the only sustainable solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict will be the one achieved by peaceful and non-violent means. ‘We are gravely concerned at the growing tension and increasing violence in the region, and we urge all parties to refrain from any action that would worsen the situation. The resolution voted today does not ask for an unconditional recognition of Palestine. On the contrary, the text insists upon the need to continue and advance the peace talks. Ultimately, the only true recognition of Palestine as state can be brought about by negotiations between the parties, in the framework of a comprehensive peace process that addresses all outstanding issues’, explained the EPP Group co-negotiator of the resolution and EPP Group spokesperson on Foreign Affairs, Cristian Preda MEP.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — I abstained. It is the most balanced position between positions that are too far apart from each other. The European Union is working to ensure the security of Israel and the area.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. — Parliament's plenary session is in favour of Member States recognizing the Palestinian state. We express our strong support for the recognition of a Palestinian state. We consider the Palestinians' right to self-determination and to have their own state unquestionable, as is Israel's right to exist within secure borders. We call on EU Member States to be united in their support of this legitimate process. We will continue our work to ensure that the European Union plays a more effective and genuine role in the peace process. We remain deeply convinced that a single European voice is a key factor in the search for a comprehensive solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. We believe that the only way to resolve the Israel-Palestine conflict is through the 1967 two-state border-based solution, with Jerusalem as the capital of both states. In this way, the State of Israel could live in peace and security together with an independent, democratic and viable state of Palestine.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. — The conflict in the Middle East persists despite efforts to negotiate a peace process for the region. The resolution in which I voted is a reminder of the value of mutual recognition and the need for two states based on the 1967 borders. These elements are the condition for an end to all violence. Indeed, we cannot tolerate an escalation of violence and terrorist acts as we have witnessed in recent months.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the resolution on the recognition of the Palestinian State. I believe that the implementation of the 'two states for two peoples' principle and mutual recognition between Palestine and Israel are two absolutely fundamental conditions for ensuring that the Palestinian and Israeli people can finally achieve peaceful coexistence and a security condition for peoples and states close to the crisis area. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the recognition of the Palestinian State by the European Parliament is a very important signal which, following the recognition already made by some Member States (Sweden, Spain, the United Kingdom and Ireland), can have a significant impact on the Middle East peace process. Today's vote gives a clear mandate to High Representative Mogherini to put in place all possible diplomatic initiatives so that it can be added in a 'very short time' to the effective recognition of the State of Palestine.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the joint resolution on the recognition of the Palestinian State as a principled step in the right direction. Recognition of the Palestinian State, its people and its borders, and the end of the occupation is a long-overdue international obligation and a positive step towards peace. Member States must now formally recognise and thus protect the space of the Palestinian State on the 1967 borders with East Jerusalem as the capital. Palestinian recognition is established in UN resolutions and a number of national parliaments of EU Member States have called on their respective governments to recognise this. The Palestinian People’s right to self-determination has been enshrined in international resolutions for 66 years. We call on all parties to refrain from any action which may undermine the viability and the prospects of the two-state solution. Therefore, settlements must end, the apartheid wall must be dismantled and attacks on Holy Sites, along with the demolition of Palestinian property, must stop immediately.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. — In my written question (E-006540/2014) that I submitted to the European Commission on 3/9/2014, I questioned the Commissions’ view on recognition for Somaliland. On 4/10/2014 the Commission replied stating: ‘The EU does not have the competency to recognise states, only individual member states do.’ In its capacity as an EU institution, the European Parliament does not, therefore, have the ability to deal with the question of recognition of any state. I believe that this resolution is inadmissible and, accordingly, I voted against it. However, I wish to clarify that I support a lasting and viable two-state solution for Israel and Palestine, but this must be built on trust and non-violence.  Accordingly, until Hamas revokes its call for the destruction of the Israeli State, I cannot support recognition for Palestine.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on the recognition of the Palestinian state in order to facilitate the acceleration of the peace process and the recognition of two states at the defined borders. It is a strong message in the violent times we are experiencing. It is also important to call on the peoples of Europe to fight against growing and alarming anti-Semitism and Islamophobia.

name: Lorenzo CESA
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the joint resolution of which I am one of the co-signatories of the GROUP of the European People's Party, because I firmly believe that this act will give greater impetus to the resumption of the direct peace talks between Israel and the PLO, which have been stalled for too long. But my vote is not unconditional: the PLO committed itself in 1993 to recognising the State of Israel and it is necessary for all the different Palestinian factions, including Hamas, to accept the commitments made by the PLO and to put an end to their internal divisions. Israel must be recognised and the two states can only coexist in conditions of peace and security, on the basis of the right to self-determination and in full respect of international law. That is why the peace negotiations must resume and Palestine must put an end to the acts of violence against Israel. Only in this way does the European Parliament support, in principle, the two-state solution with Jerusalem as the capital of both states, bearing in mind that the recognition of the State of Palestine is a matter for the States, while the European Union must be a facilitator of the peace process.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. "As a French patriot, I preferred to abstain on this text for several reasons. First of all, I would like to stress that I am in favour of the idea of two states, Palestine and Israel. However, I cannot recognize Hamas, an Islamist terrorist group, as a legitimate interlocutor. Moreover, with this resolution, the European Union shows its inconsistency by supporting, on the one hand, Palestinian sovereignty and denying, on the other, the sovereignty of the European peoples. I could therefore not vote in favour of this new will to interfere on the part of an organisation ready to deal with terrorists but refusing to allow the word of the citizens of its own Member States free.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — The title of this resolution deserves rivers and rivers of ink. I have chosen to abstain because the way in which this title has been declined seems to me to be inappropriate: the conditions set out in the text are absolutely unattainable at the present time, and, even if this text has no legislative ambitions, they do not make sense even in a mere political document. Furthermore, as a colleague from another political group rightly pointed out before the vote, the EU does not have the power to recognise states.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. — My sole goal in voting for this motion was the achievement of peace in the Middle East. As Israel continues with settlement expansion, the two-state-solution is quickly losing credibility. EU recognition sends a clear message to both Israel and Palestine that the EU is committed to peace, and that we support moderate voices in the region.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. — I voted against Palestinian Statehood as recognising a Palestinian State is not within the competence of this Parliament. On 3 October the EU Commission wrote to my UKIP colleague James Carver MEP to explain that the EU cannot recognise Somaliland or any other State and that this was the privilege of the various individual nation States. Therefore this so called recognition of Palestine is ultra vires and illegitimate. The President of the Parliament should have ruled against this motion as the Commission has admitted in writing that it was ultra vires. Recognition of Palestine or otherwise should be left to Nation States and the United Nations. If Pontus Pilate could not solve the Middle Eastern situation with threats of crucifixion and galleys how can this pathetic eunuch of a Parliament, which made such a mess of the Ukraine crisis, ever hope to solve this situation? The EU should sort out the catastrophic euro crisis it has created rather than try to destroy other nations.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. "There is an urgent need to put an end to the brutal violence that destroys lives in both Israel and Palestine. And it is essential to denounce and punish war crimes committed by both sides against innocent civilians or by destroying civilian infrastructure.
