The EP reiterates that there is no solution that does not go through the coexistence of two states, whose security is mutually respected, with the existing borders until 1967 and with Jerusalem as the capital of both States. I believe it is also fundamental to combat those who make radical readings of their religion and justify the legitimacy of killing in the name of God. There will be few things more despicable than invoking God to exercise violence, spread terror, and reap human lives.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — The EU must play a central role, together with other stakeholders, to bring about a peaceful resolution of the dispute that has tormented the lives of Palestinians and Israelis for generations. The little respect that this conflict has shown to human life is unacceptable. The two-state solution can start to provide Israelis and Palestinians with a life of peace in which children and families can thrive without fear of each other. Yet this solution requires the backing of the international community, of the EU as well as of its Member States: a commitment of seeking to bring both Israelis and Palestinians back to the negotiating table. The coexistence of two states, Palestine and Israel, will provide each with security as well as peaceful statehood. Both must believe in their aspirations and want to attain them through peaceful negotiations rather than through occupation, settlement construction and injuring civilians. Towards the end of attaining statehood, the EU must support Palestine in establishing and strengthening its institutions.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the motion for a Resolution on the recognition of the State of Palestine as a first step in the right direction. Recognition of the State of Palestine, its people, its borders and the end of the occupation is an international obligation and an important step towards peace. Member States must now formally recognize, and therefore protect, the space of the State of Palestine at the 1967 borders with East Jerusalem as its capital. The Palestinian people's right to self-determination has been recognized internationally for 66 years. We call on all parties not to take any action that could dynamite the feasibility of the two States' solution. Therefore, settlements must end, apartheid must be over, and the attack on sacred sites and the demolition of Palestinian property must cease immediately.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. - I abstained in the vote on the recognition of statehood in Palestine because I do not think the timing of the resolution is correct.  As far as the content of the resolution is concerned, I am a supporter of the two models of states, as the Union has repeatedly confirmed. The EU supports the 1967 border-based solution under which a secure State of Israel and an independent, democratic, territorially connected and viable State of Palestine coexist in peace and security, based on full respect for the right to self-determination and international law. I support the resumption of direct peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians, which requires the development of a trust-based environment, to which serious steps must be taken by both sides. However, I am convinced that the EP's resolution was not taken at the right time, because it is not fair to the upcoming Israeli elections. I believe that any resolution of this type is only fortunate to be adopted when both parties are not under campaign pressure, because doing so could negatively affect and distort the efforts and aspirations of the pro-peace parties.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution which focuses on the recognition of Palestinian statehood. This joint motion for a resolution is the result of a compromise between five political groups, among which the S&D Group. However, I preferred the text originally proposed by S&D on the official recognition of Palestinian statehood since it was stronger and in favour of recognising Palestinian statehood. I unreservedly and unconditionally support the recognition of Palestinian statehood.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. — The adoption by a very large majority of this resolution is the result of fruitful negotiations which have enabled the European Parliament to have a united position. I have thereby supported, in principle, the recognition of a Palestinian state and the two-state solution, which must be done concurrently with peace negotiations. The resolution, however, is apt reminder that, despite this political message from the European Parliament, it remains the competence of the Member States to recognise a Palestinian state.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution which supports the recognition in principle of the Palestinian State on the basis of the 1967 borders and with Jerusalem as its capital. I hope that Israel and Palestine will live side by side in conditions of peace and security, on the basis of the right to self-determination and full respect for international law.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The European Parliament voted by a very large majority, 498 in favour of the resolution on the recognition of the Palestinian state, against 88. This is a strong signal in favour of the two-state solution and in favour of peace. And this is the first time in its history that the European Parliament has expressed a balanced position vis-à-vis both sides. After the dramatic events experienced in recent months by israelis and Palestinians, with rising tensions and the inexorable rise of violence in this part of the world, we wanted this recognition to be inseparable from the need to urgently resume peace talks. As the resolution strongly stresses, it is essential that political leaders of all stripes work together to calm the situation, because only non-violent means and respect for human rights will achieve a lasting solution and a just peace between the two peoples. The resolution encourages Europe to take its full part in the peace process and to become an indispensable actor and mediator. It's only time!

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. — As a member of the Fidesz people's party delegation, I voted in favour of today's joint motion for a resolution on the recognition of the statehood of Palestine in today's plenary session, as the text adopted expressly states in paragraph F that recognition of the statehood of Palestine falls within the competence of the Member States.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. "I am very pleased to be a co-signer of this resolution, especially since it has been the subject of consensus among the main political groups in the European Parliament. I am one of those who believe that it was time, after 60 years of conflict that has caused so much suffering on both sides, that everyone put aside their preconceptions and that Parliament finally adopts a clear position. I am convinced that the recognition of the Palestinian State is a necessary step in resolving this conflict, by establishing state-to-state equality between Palestine and Israel. The European Parliament, through the adoption of this resolution, has given its full political support to Federica Mogherini, the Eu's High Representative for Foreign Affairs, so that the European Union can finally play an active and decisive role in resolving this conflict. I would also like to underline the courage of 800 Israeli citizens who have sent a letter to all Members of the European Parliament in which they strongly condemn the occupation and the settlements, and call for a vote in favour of the recognition of a Palestinian state within the borders of June 1967. This approach touched me deeply and determined me to support their courageous initiative.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. — As a member of the Fidesz people's party delegation, I voted in favour of today's joint motion for a resolution on the recognition of the statehood of Palestine in today's plenary session, as the text adopted expressly states in paragraph F that recognition of the statehood of Palestine falls within the competence of the Member States.

name: Diane DODDS
text: in writing. — I believe it is truly regrettable that this debate on Palestinian statehood has even reached this Chamber. It is my view that a Palestinian state can only derive from direct bilateral negotiations between Israel and Palestinian representatives. This is the position upheld by numerous international agreements, including the Oslo Accords and several UN resolutions – and it is why all unilateral efforts to gain this recognition external to substantive negotiations must be roundly condemned. Today’s vote also ignores the biggest obstacle to a Palestinian state – terrorism, which has at its core the aim of destroying Israel. Hamas do not accept a two-state solution and their acts of terror must stop before any talks start. This is a position that my party has stood up for in Northern Ireland in times past and it is equally right to do so in this situation.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. — The resolution proposed to Parliament is vague and offers no real prospect for the improvement of relations between the Hebrew State and the Palestinian territories. Moreover, the European Union cannot claim the right to decide the sovereignty of another state. Finally, the current borders of the Palestinian territories are not satisfactory to the interests of the Palestinians and are still being discussed. In these circumstances, it is wise and realistic not to intervene in this way. I have therefore decided to abstain for this vote.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution because I support the recognition of the Palestinian state entity and condemn the European Union's relationship with Israel, agreeing to the strict exclusion of the implementation of the EU-Israel agreements.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. — (IT) Today's vote is a very important step in the direction of resolving the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and I personally welcome the expression of this Parliament in favour of the recognition of the Palestinian State and the two-state solution, a recognition which calls for all the efforts necessary for the development of peace talks to be put into practice and for the only and possible direction for the peaceful and non-violent coexistence of peoples to be made. I also agree with the commitment to launch an initiative entitled 'Parliamentarians for Peace', aimed at bringing together MEPs, Israelis and Palestinians from various parties to help advance a peace agenda and complement the European Union's diplomatic efforts.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. " We have long been convinced of a two-state solution in which Israel and a future Palestinian state will be able to live side by side in peace and security. Such a lasting peace can only come about through negotiations between the parties and must be based on the parties recognising each other and respecting the agreements concluded. This resolution adds nothing of value that could help to move these talks forward because it is deliberately worded in a way that allows everyone to interpret the text in their own way. The only true result of this resolution is thus that, in an already complicated situation, we also have a lack of clarity as to whether the European Parliament now has or has not recognised a Palestinian state. For this reason, we cannot support the resolution.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. " We have long been convinced of a two-state solution in which Israel and a future Palestinian state will be able to live side by side in peace and security. Such a lasting peace can only come about through negotiations between the parties and must be based on the parties recognising each other and respecting the agreements concluded. This resolution adds nothing of value that could help to move these talks forward because it is deliberately worded in a way that allows everyone to interpret the text in their own way. The only true result of this resolution is thus that, in an already complicated situation, we also have a lack of clarity as to whether the European Parliament now has or has not recognised a Palestinian state. For this reason, we cannot support the resolution. Cecilia Wikström, Marit Paulsen and Fredrick Federley (ALDE).

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - For more than half a century, achieving a just and lasting peace between Israelis and Palestinians has been of great concern to the international community, including the European Union. It should be found that the United Nations General Assembly decided on 29 November 2012 to grant Palestine non-UN observer status. It should be noted that the recognition of the State of Palestine is the responsibility of the Member States. This does not mean that political resolutions on the subject cannot be issued. I therefore support the recognition of the Palestinian state and the solution to the coexistence of two states, believing that both sides must move alongside the deepening of the peace negotiations, which should progress. The solution to the coexistence of two States should be made on the basis of the borders of 1967 and Jerusalem as the capital of both, i.e. a secure State of Israel and an independent, democratic, territorially continuous and viable State of Palestine, living side by side in peace and security, which implies the recognition of the right to self-determination and full observance of international law.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. " We voted in favour of this resolution. Despite its shortcomings and limitations, it is a minimal sign of recognising the inalienable right of the Palestinian people to their state. We cannot fail to point out some negative aspects of the resolution, namely: - The insistence on security only applied to the state of Israel (as if Palestine did not need security), seeking to create the idea that the borders of the State of Palestine are drawn according to this objective; - the distinction between terrorism and violence and the condemnation of all violent protest, thereby denying the right to insurrection and resistance of palestinians to the Israeli occupation; - the absence of reference to UN resolutions (181, 194, 248, 332) or the withdrawal of occupied territories, which, in addition to other objectives, is a way of marginalising the UN in this process;  - A common EU position is called for, which, in the current context, when there are countries that, like Sweden, have already recognised Palestine, mean an attempt to limit the sovereign power of the Member States to decide on recognition, and a brake on countries that want to recognise the State of Palestine.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted against the resolution on the recognition of the Palestinian State, which I consider to be a serious political error for two reasons. Firstly, because we persist in putting on an equal footing a democracy such as the State of Israel and clearly un democratic realities, which still manifest, at best, equivocal, ambiguous and unclear behaviour with regard to the recognition of Israel's right to exist and live in the security of its citizens. Secondly, I consider linguistic wordings such as 'all acts of terrorism and violence...', 'both sides', etc. to be hypocritical and now frankly unacceptable. We are pretending not to see that there is a clear distinction, which does not allow opaque equality: on the one hand there are terrorist acts and on the other there is the exercise of the right to self-defence by a democratic country, the only one in the area that freely chooses government and parliament. It would be the duty of all democrats in the West to defend Israel without hypocrisy and subservie. From this defence, and therefore from the protection of the values of freedom and democracy, also passes the hope of the affirmation of the human rights of Palestinian women and men as well.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing — Repeated attacks on citizens of the State of Israel by Hamas and other militant groups and the constant escalation of violence, as well as the fact that any Palestinian Government gains its legitimacy by having to express its support for Hamas and Fatah does not give sufficient guarantees to recognise the existence of a state. It is unquestionable that the region urgently needs a solution to the situation and the Palestinians have been repeatedly recognised by the European Union for the right to self-determination. However, we would need much more time for an objective evaluation and decision on the recognition of a new Palestinian state.

name: Vicky FORD
text: in writing. - I have opted to abstain on this resolution on Palestine since the recognition of a state falls within the competence of the Member States. In my own Member State, the UK, the national parliament has voted in favour of recognising the State of Palestine. I have full respect for that decision. I hope that progress can urgently be made towards achieving this two-state solution and to an ending of violence and a just and lasting peace on all sides.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — I am in favour of supporting the Palestinian State entity and its security, condemning the European Union's relationship with Israel and agreeing to the strict exclusion of the implementation of the EU-Israel agreements. Furthermore, I sympath with the situation in the war zone and support the peace negotiations.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. — I voted against the recognition of Palestine. I do not believe that recognition at this time would benefit the peace process and would in fact hinder the negotiations for a genuine two-state solution. I am committed to the eventual recognition of a Palestinian state at a time more helpful to the peace process, as a two-state solution brought through negotiated agreement as the only way for Palestinian aspirations of statehood to be met on the ground. Additionally, this is a matter for national parliaments and not the European Parliament. The principle of subsidiarity should be applied to the recognition of new states as the EU has no competency in this area.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. — As a member of the Fidesz people's party delegation, I voted in favour of today's joint motion for a resolution on the recognition of the statehood of Palestine in today's plenary session, as the text adopted expressly states in paragraph F that recognition of the statehood of Palestine falls within the competence of the Member States.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. — As a member of the Fidesz people's party delegation, I voted in favour of this joint motion for a resolution in today's plenary session of the EP, as the text adopted express verbis states in paragraph F that recognition of the statehood of Palestine falls within the competence of the Member States and supports a solution based on the principle of two states and the borders of 1967. However, I would like to express my deep concern at the continuing increase in tensions and violence in the region. I also welcome the 'Members of Parliament for Peace' initiative, which aims to unite European, Israeli and Palestinian MPs, regardless of party affiliation, in order to promote the peace plan and complement EU efforts.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution motivated by the hope that this political gesture will help to unseal the peace process between the State of Israel and the Palestinian Authority. Acceptance by the United Nations of Palestine as an observer along with recognition by some EU Member States are steps towards the resumption of the Middle East peace process. It should never be perceived as an agreed decision against Israel, a state for which I have great respect. After so many years of conflict in the Middle East, the only possible solution is the peaceful and negotiated coexistence of two states, Israel and Palestine. This recognition should be the result of a negotiation process between the parties that guarantees peace and security for both sides. I am convinced that peaceful coexistence between Israel and Palestine is possible, but this end will only be achieved if negotiation and dialogue are given an opportunity. The past cannot mark the present and the future if lasting peace is to be achieved.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. — Recognition of the Palestinian state is a necessary but not sufficient step to achieve peace between Israel and Palestine. I believe that the only way to resolve this conflict is through the 1967 two-state border-based solution, with Jerusalem as the capital of both states. In this way, the State of Israel could live in peace and security with an independent, democratic and viable Palestinian state. I support this motion for a resolution as a compromise solution and because of the high value of both the broad consensus reached among all the groups in this Parliament and the important message we send with it. I would like to express my strong support for the recognition of a State of Palestine, as the right of Palestinians to have their own state is unquestionable as is Israel's right to exist within secure borders. I also value the leadership of High Representative Federica Mogherini in this process, as I believe that the EU should play a more effective and genuine role in the peace process, and I believe it is necessary for EU Member States to be united in supporting this legitimate process.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. — I supported this motion for a resolution because I am in favour of the recognition of the State of Palestine and the solution of two States on the basis of the 1967 borders (with Jerusalem as the capital of both States, with a safe State of Israel and an independent, democratic, contiguous and viable Palestinian State), living side by side in peace and security , on the basis of the right to self-determination and full respect for international law and, as we have pointed out in the EP, I believe that this process should go hand in hand with the development of the peace negotiations, which have to move forward. To this end, I approve the Parliamentary for Peace initiative to bring MEPs together with members of the Israeli and Palestinian Parliaments to support the Middle East peace process.  And of course, in this resolution we also condemn all acts of terrorism and violence. That's why I voted for it.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. — (IT) The Strasbourg Parliament adopted by a large majority a resolution signed by various groups which supports, in principle, the recognition of the State of Palestine on the basis of the 1967 borders, supports the two-state solution with Jerusalem and calls for the peace talks to resume. While acknowledging the work done by the PPE group to mitigate the positions of the European left, the Forza Italia delegation still has ambiguities and too many traces of the original version, starting with the title, with regard to the text of this resolution. That is why, precisely in order to mark our disagreement politically, we have chosen not to vote.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. — The EU does not have competence to recognise a nation state. Only nations can do this, as the EU Commission made clear in writing to my colleague James Carver when he asked them about recognising Somaliland. If the EU Parliament accepts the rule of law, and abides by it and its own rules, then it would not even be allowing the vote in the first place. I support the two-state solution, and recognising Palestine, while not requiring Hamas to lay down its arms or the recognition of the right for Israel to exist is a mistake. I cannot allow the EU to act as a nation state, when it is not, and will not support this. The UK as a sovereign nation should recognise Palestine as and when it sees fit.

name: Ana GOMES
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this joint resolution because I believe that the European Parliament should join the various national parliaments which have already called for the recognition of the State of Palestine. However, I refused to sing it on behalf of my political group because I felt that the compromise solution reflected in the first paragraph of this joint resolution falls short of what I believe should be the EP's position urging all Member States of the European Union to recognise the State of Palestine. To say that the European Parliament agrees with the principle of palestine's self-determination is nothing new, is a position stated numerous times by this Parliament in all resolutions in which it called for coexistence between the two States, the State of Israel and the State of Palestine. The movement for universal recognition of the State of Palestine is growing. In addition to the Palestinians, Israel needs existentially the establishment of an independent, democratic and secure state in its neighbourhood.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because we consider it a step forward for a majority of the European Parliament to be in favour of a basic claim such as the creation and international recognition of a Palestinian state with capital in Jerusalem. This only reaffirms what the UN already requests in its 1947 Resolution 181, paradoxically, the only one that Israel partially complies with, with regard to the partition of Palestine.  We further believe that recognition of the Palestinian State should be just one step in the process to achieve a just peace which, in the light of the demands of civil society itself, should include an end to occupation (in compliance with UN Resolution 242 of 1967), the right to return refugees (Resolution 194 of 1948) and a State that guarantees the full equality of all its citizens. We also believe that, in order to enforce the content of the Resolution, the EU should use pressure mechanisms, at least the suspension of the EU-Israel bilateral agreement, in compliance with Article 2 there, in the face of the flagrant violation of human rights involved in the continuation of the blockade of the Gaza Strip.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. — My Labour Party colleague, Richard Howitt, called for a debate on this issue in November to attempt to break the deadlock which currently exists in the peace talks.  I am committed to a negotiated two-state solution, with Israel safe, secure and recognised within its borders, living peacefully alongside a democratic and viable Palestinian state. I voted for recognition as I hope it will provide vital impetus to those who support peace on both sides of the conflict, and provide a message of hope that too many years of conflict can finally be ended; recognition is not an alternative to peace talks but could be a vital push to advancing them. I believe Palestinian recognition can help strengthen moderate voices among the Palestinians who want to pursue the path of politics, not the path of violence. I also welcome greater cooperation between the EU and Israel through trade as well as scientific and cultural exchanges. I believe now is the time to deepen, not weaken, our economic and cultural ties across the region. I welcome this vote and look forward to the EU helping to bring peace to the Middle East.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. — The search for a just and lasting peace between Israelis and Palestinians is a major concern for the international community, including the European Union. That is why I abstained on Wednesday morning from voting on the resolution on the recognition of the Palestinian state. It must not have immediate recognition of the Palestinian state without a fully assumed mutual peace process being initiated by both sides. The current situation is too serious, the violence too numerous and the risk of confusion too real. As the conditions were not met, I refused explicit support for this text, which was used by the left.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. I give my full support to this resolution. This is a strong symbolic act on the part of this House, all the more striking because it won the votes of two-thirds of parliamentarians. Peace talks between Israel and Palestine are now at an impasse. To make peace, one must consider the other as a legitimate interlocutor. That is not the case today. To change this situation, the interventions of the international community are essential. The European Union has a role to play in this process. The Union has repeatedly affirmed its support for the two-state solution, on the basis of the 1967 borders, with Jerusalem as the capital of both the State of Israel and an independent State of Palestine, living side by side in peace and security. The existence of a Palestinian state cannot be conditioned on peace but must instead be seen as one of the ways to achieve peace. We socialists and democrats in the European Parliament have always worked with this in mind. I hope that other similar initiatives will be taken in national parliaments in Europe. Finally, I hope that this movement will help to get the Israeli authorities to reconsider the question of the sovereignty of the Palestinian people.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. — Recognition of the Palestinian state is a necessary but not sufficient step to achieve peace between Israel and Palestine. I believe that the only way to resolve this conflict is through the 1967 two-state border-based solution, with Jerusalem as the capital of both states. In this way, the State of Israel could live in peace and security with an independent, democratic and viable Palestinian state. I support this motion for a resolution as a compromise solution and because of the high value of both the broad consensus reached among all the groups in this Parliament and the important message we send with it. I would like to express my strong support for the recognition of a State of Palestine, as the right of Palestinians to have their own state is unquestionable as is Israel's right to exist within secure borders. I also value the leadership of High Representative Federica Mogherini in this process, as I believe that the EU should play a more effective and genuine role in the peace process, and I believe it is necessary for EU Member States to be united in supporting this legitimate process.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. — As a member of the Fidesz people's party delegation, I voted in favour of today's joint motion for a resolution on the recognition of the statehood of Palestine in today's plenary session, as the text adopted expressly states in paragraph F that recognition of the statehood of Palestine falls within the competence of the Member States.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the joint resolution on the recognition of Palestinian State as a principled step in the right direction. Recognition of the Palestinian State, its people and its borders, and the end of the occupation, is a long-overdue international obligation and a positive step towards peace. Member States must now formally recognise and thus protect the space of the Palestinian State on the 1967 borders, with East Jerusalem as the capital. Palestinian Recognition is established in UN resolutions and a number of national parliaments of EU Member States have called on their respective governments to recognise. The Palestinian People's right to self-determination has been enshrined in international resolutions for 66 years. We call on all parties to refrain from any action which may undermine the viability and the prospects of the two-state solution. Therefore, settlements must end, the apartheid wall must be dismantled, and attacks on holy sites – along with the demolition of Palestinian property – must stop immediately.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this joint motion for resolution on the recognition of Palestinian Statehood because I believe that recognition of Palestinian statehood by the European Parliament is a crucial development in the progress of the peace process. There has been limited success in negotiations between the two parties, and I believe we can do more in the European Union to bring a lasting peace to fruition.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Written. — In the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, the Party for Animals is opting for a two-state solution, both the Palestinian and Israeli states deserve recognition. We condemn any action by any party that could undermine the viability and prospects for a two-state solution and a lasting, just peace. The Party for Animals rejects any form of violence. Acts that are contrary to international law cannot go unpunished and must have economic and political consequences. We assess proposals on the recognition of Palestine on the basis of these principles. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution, which recognises Palestine as a state.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. — I voted against the recognition of Palestine. I did not care at all whether Palestine should be recognised or not. Of course, there are good reasons for doing so, just as there are good reasons to do so. Recognising Israel's right to exist through Palestine as a precondition is just as right as it is right to recognise Palestine as a state. I voted against this proposal only because neither the EU, let alone the European Parliament, has a right to recognise countries, just as these European institutions do not have the right to refuse such recognition. Only countries have this right. If Sweden is in favour of recognition, that is up to Sweden. If Germany does not do so, it is a matter for Germany. The European Parliament's vote is an unacceptable presumption, as are many other presumptions. The EU is not a state. I am strongly opposed to the 'United States of Europe' being constituted through the back door. That's why I'm not.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. — As a member of the Fidesz people's party delegation, I voted in favour of today's joint motion for a resolution on the recognition of the statehood of Palestine in today's plenary session, as the text adopted expressly states in paragraph F that recognition of the statehood of Palestine falls within the competence of the Member States.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. — Today’s vote is an important symbolic act by this House. We join a number of national parliaments, including the Scottish parliament, in recognising the principle of Palestinian statehood.  The momentum towards statehood is growing and today’s resolution will hopefully contribute to finding a two-state solution.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because we consider it a step forward for a majority of the European Parliament to be in favour of a basic claim such as the creation and international recognition of a Palestinian state with capital in Jerusalem. This only reaffirms what the UN already requests in its 1947 Resolution 181, paradoxically, the only one that Israel partially complies with, with regard to the partition of Palestine.  We further believe that recognition of the Palestinian State should be just one step in the process to achieve a just peace which, in the light of the demands of civil society itself, should include an end to occupation (in compliance with UN Resolution 242 of 1967), the right to return refugees (Resolution 194 of 1948) and a State that guarantees the full equality of all its citizens. We also believe that, in order to enforce the content of the Resolution, the EU should use pressure mechanisms, at least the suspension of the EU-Israel bilateral agreement, in compliance with Article 2 there, in the face of the flagrant violation of human rights involved in the continuation of the blockade of the Gaza Strip.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a resolution recognising Palestinian statehood, as the resolution is highly balanced and gives the possibility of creating an area of peace in a decades-long unsettled Middle Eastern area. The existence of sovereign states of Israel and Palestine on the basis of mutual recognition and good interstate relations is a cornerstone of peace in the Middle East. It was important to me that over the last months many supporters of this resolution, who are prominent figures in Israel, have come forward, and that a debate has taken place within the ALDE Group and in the European Parliament. An additional motive was my desire for the European Union to be more strongly present in this long-standing conflict in political and security terms. I believe this is a direct interest of the European Union.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of the resolution on the recognition of Palestine. This text provided a balanced answer to this question by recalling its support for the two-state solution, on the basis of the 1967 borders, with Jerusalem as the capital of the two entities, namely the State of Israel whose security is assured and an independent, democratic, one-sided and viable State of Palestine, living side by side in peace and security in peace and security. , under the right to self-determination and in strict compliance with international law. The resolution therefore supports the principle of recognition of the Palestinian state while calling for an end to divisions between Palestinians and a reminder of the illegality of Israeli settlements. I welcome the adoption of this resolution.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: in writing. — EH Bildu voted in favour of the proposal for a Joint Resolution on the Recognition of the Palestinian State as a first step in the right direction. Recognition of the State of Palestine, its people and its borders, and the end of occupation, settlements, apartheid and attacks on the future of the Palestinian people is an international obligation and a positive step towards peace.  It is now the obligation of EU Member States, in compliance with what is expressed by the European Parliament and international resolutions, to formally recognise the Palestinian State.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. "I did not wish to vote in favour of this resolution because its title and several of its paragraphs remained ambiguous. It is not conceivable to unilaterally and unconditionally recognize the Palestinian state. The two-state solution must be the outcome of the peace process, not the precondition. Therefore, the European Union must strengthen its role in the Middle East and weigh in to restart peace talks in order to guarantee Israel's security and to make possible a democratic and viable Palestinian state on the basis of the 1967 borders with Jerusalem as the capital of both states.

name: Georgios KATROUGKALOS
text: in writing. — I abstained from the vote on the joint resolution on the recognition of the Palestinian State although I strongly support the recognition of the Palestinian State, its people and its borders as a precondition for peace in the region. Member States must formally recognise and thus protect the Space of the Palestinian State on the 1967 borders with East Jerusalem as the capital. However, the resolution fails to fully recognise the Palestinian people’s right to self-determination and demonstrate the responsibilities of the Israeli State for the continuation of the war and the humanitarian crisis in Palestine. Therefore, I could not vote in favour of it.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. — I decided to abstain in the vote on the resolution concerning Palestinian statehood. I welcome the fact that the EP has clearly rejected unconditional recognition of Palestinian statehood and expresses cautious support for the two-state solution. Whereas I agree that violence in the region needs to stop, I would like to make reminder that Israel lives under constant threat from almost all its neighbours, which are using the Palestine argument to question the very existence and legitimacy of Israel. I do not find it possible to recognise Palestine until we see also unconditional recognition of Israel by its neighbouring Muslim countries. Whereas I fully respect the rulings by the European Court of Justice, I also regret the decision to remove Hamas from the EU terrorist list, apparently on procedural grounds. I would like these procedural grounds to be made public as soon as possible, so that such rulings would not be possible in the future. I call on the EU to appeal against this ruling.  The very activities of Hamas, which continues to be a foreign-financed militant group that voices plans to destroy Israel and has sent thousands of rockets to  hit Israeli civilians, is a major obstacle to recognition of the Palestinian state in its present condition.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I very much welcome the resolution. This is truly a historic moment, not only for the Palestinians, who have suffered immensely for over 50 years, but for the whole of Europe. A strong message from all parties across Europe has shown its solidarity with those suffering in the Middle East and has demonstrated its will to get more actively involved in the peace process. We need to use this momentum to urge remaining EU countries to follow suit and particularly to support efforts in the UN to place a time limit on a final solution which is already long overdue, giving Palestine its rightful official recognition.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of the joint resolution on the recognition of a Palestinian state because, in principle, I consider it to be a first step in the right direction. Recognition of the Palestinian state, its people and its borders has long been an important international commitment and a necessary step towards peace. This recognition is also based on a number of UN resolutions. It should be recalled that even a number of national parliaments of EU member states have already called on their governments to officially recognise Palestine. Member States must therefore now formally recognise and protect the premises of a Palestinian state, on the basis of the 1967 borders, with East Jerusalem as the capital of that state. I therefore also call on all parties to refrain from any action that could undermine the viability and prospects of resolving this protracted problem. Disputes must end, daily bloodshed and loss of human life must be avoided immediately, the wall must be dismantled, and attacks on holy sites, along with the demolition of Palestinian property, must be stopped unconditionally.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. — As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP people's party delegation, I voted in favour of today's plenary session of the European Parliament in favour of a joint motion for a resolution on the recognition of the statehood of Palestine, as the text adopted expressly states in paragraph F that recognition of the statehood of Palestine falls within the competence of the Member States.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: in writing. — (IT) Today is an historic day which will be remembered on the long road to the suffering peace process in the Middle East. At the strong impetus of the European Parliament, we have today come out in favour of recognising the Palestinian State and the two-state solution, in the hope of giving impetus to a new world order based on peace. With this resolution we have not proclaimed the victory of one side, but an assumption of responsibility. It is the victory of hope for peace to soon be a reality. With this vote, we believe that Europe, on this basis, is now playing all its cards and influence in opening negotiations free from the mortgages of extremists and fundamentalists, which have made it impossible for decades to make progress in the peace process between Israel and Palestine. We want the dream to be a reality, the dream thus described in this resolution that we adopted: two states, Jerusalem as the capital of both states, with a secure State of Israel and an independent, democratic, territorially contiguous and capable of existence of autonomy, living side by side in conditions of peace and security, on the basis of the right to self-determination and full respect for international law.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the joint resolution on the recognition of the Palestinian State as a principled step in the right direction. Recognition of the Palestinian State, its people and its borders, and the end of the occupation is a long-overdue international obligation and a positive step towards peace. Member States must now formally recognise and thus protect the space of the Palestinian State within the 1967 borders, with East Jerusalem as the capital. Palestinian Recognition is established in UN Resolutions and by a number of the national parliaments of EU Member States have called on their respective governments to recognize. The Palestinian people's right to self-determination has been enshrined in international resolutions for 66 years. We call on all parties to refrain from any action which may undermine the viability and the prospects of the two-state solution. Therefore, settlements must end, the apartheid wall must be dismantled. Attacks on holy sites along with the demolition of Palestinian property must stop immediately. The MEPs instructed the President of the European Parliament to forward this resolution to the European Council, the European Commission, the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy/Vice-President of the European Commission, the governments and parliaments of the Member States, the Secretary-General of the United Nations, the Middle East Quartet Envoy, the Knesset and the Government of Israel, the President of the Palestinian Authority and the Palestinian Legislative Council.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. "I want to explain why I abstained on this resolution. After the votes of the French National Assembly and the Senate, as well as several other Parliaments in Europe in recent weeks, the European Parliament also wished to vote. But the resolution put to the vote is significantly different from those voted in the French Parliament. It is not a question of unilaterally recognising a Palestinian state. It is a joint resolution, the fruit of laborious negotiations, a resolution between political groups that proceeds from a double approach: the recognition of a Palestinian state, but also the guarantee of the security and stability of the State of Israel. It also calls for an urgent resumption of peace talks. However, although the resolution specifies that the recognition of a Palestinian state would only be possible with the emergence of a negotiated solution with Israel, the title of the report, "recognition of a Palestinian State", and some paragraphs do not fully satisfy me, and I have therefore chosen to abstain. In this regard, I would like to point out that neither my political group, the EPP, nor the UMP, are in favour of the unilateral recognition of a Palestinian state.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. "I abstained on the recognition of the Palestinian state, because I do not believe that it is the union's responsibility to recognise states. It is a prerogative of the states. This vote is therefore a further attack on the sovereignty of the Member States of the Union. On the substance of the problem, I indicate that I am in favour of the creation of a Palestinian state, provided that Israel's security is guaranteed.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "We have taken a historic decision as Parliament. We recognise two countries: Israel and Palestine. We expect this to facilitate peace negotiations and open a new chapter. The vote showed that Europe has a balanced approach to the problem and that the High Representative has a new, clear mandate to act.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. "Abstention." It is not for the European Parliament to take the initiative to recognise a state.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — Recognition of the Palestinian state is a necessary but not sufficient step to achieve peace between Israel and Palestine. I believe that the only way to resolve this conflict is through the 1967 two-state border-based solution, with Jerusalem as the capital of both states. In this way, the State of Israel could live in peace and security with an independent, democratic and viable Palestinian state. I support this motion for a resolution as a compromise solution and because of the high value of both the broad consensus reached among all the groups in this Parliament and the important message we send with it. I would like to express my strong support for the recognition of a State of Palestine, as the right of Palestinians to have their own state is unquestionable as is Israel's right to exist within secure borders. I also value the leadership of High Representative Federica Mogherini in this process, as I believe that the EU should play a more effective and genuine role in the peace process, and I believe it is necessary for EU Member States to be united in supporting this legitimate process.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the motion for a Resolution on the recognition of the State of Palestine as a first step in the right direction. Recognition of the State of Palestine, its people, its borders and the end of the occupation is an international obligation and an important step towards peace. Member States must now formally recognize, and therefore protect, the space of the State of Palestine at the 1967 borders with East Jerusalem as its capital. The Palestinian people's right to self-determination has been recognized internationally for 66 years. We call on all parties not to take any action that could dynamite the feasibility of the two States' solution. Therefore, settlements must end, apartheid must be over, and the attack on sacred sites and the demolition of Palestinian property must cease immediately.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. — I voted against the resolution, although I agree with the central point 1 (principle recognition of Palestine as a state, which is to take place as part of progress in peace negotiations). However, a peace solution should not be based on the 1967 borders. These borders are the random ceasefire lines of 1948; they have long been wastebecause of the large-scale construction of Israeli settlements beyond these borders. It seems obvious to me whether settlement activity on territory that no state has ever claimed for itself was contrary to international law, i cannot judge that it was politically unwise. Nevertheless, realities must be recognised, and therefore a peace solution should not be narrowed down to regulations in which tens of thousands of Israeli citizens become homeless. It also seems to me problematic to call for a two-state solution with Jerusalem as the capital of both states. This is countered by security concerns, which relate on the one hand to the well-being of the Jewish population of West Jerusalem and, on the other hand, to the vulnerability of the government institutions of both sides. Adequate security, even under a peace settlement, would probably only be ensured by a complete division of the city with a wall and barbed wire. As a former Berliner, I have little to gain from this. The EU should not set any guidance on the final peace settlement, but should leave its negotiations to the parties to the conflict.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — The Israeli-Palestinian conflict is a central conflict in the Middle East. Given the beginning of the conflict in 1948 and the fact that it never stopped, it is considered one of the most difficult conflicts of today. On the territory of Palestine and Israel, political perspectives and processes are lacking and the resumption of peace talks is a priority.  I support the resolution because it calls for peace and the resumption of peace talks that should also result in the recognition of a Palestinian state within the 1967 (so-called green line) borders with the capital, Jerusalem, as the joint capital of the two states. We recognise that the creation of such a state is a guarantor of lasting, just and sustainable peace and conflict resolution that has generated instability in that part of the world for decades. However, this does not mean that the state should be recognized without any obligations by the Palestinians and their self-government. The state is not only a right, but it is also a great obligation and responsibility. We need to be sure that the Palestinians will lead their state in the desired direction and maintain peace and that palestinians and Israelis will sit at the table, acknowledge each other and agree on all fundamental issues of conflict.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. — Today, a European Parliament resolution on the recognition of Palestinian statehood was adopted by 498 votes in question. In this important case, the text voted on should be seen as the starting point in the process of ending the turbulent relations between Israel and Palestine, not as the final phase of negotiations that have lasted more than 60 years, the last step of which would be the recognition of the State of Palestine. The most important conditions to be met are the warming of relations between the two countries, the development of more dynamic peace negotiations between them and their mutual recognition. It is my commitment as Bulgaria's representative to the EP to work to maintain a clear and stable parliamentary position. Therefore, my decision and that of my parliamentary group is driven by concerns about rising tensions and increased violence in the region. With its declaration, inter alia, the EP decided to launch the converging Parliamentarians for Peace initiative, bringing together members of the European, Israeli and Palestinian Parliaments and playing a contributing role in the implementation of a peace agenda and complementing the EU's diplomatic efforts.  I strongly believe that with the help of both sides, we can make the right decisions and apply timely action without hasty with the end result.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. 1999 – Today's vote on the recognition of Palestinian statehood in principle is an important step towards peace in the Middle East. I voted in favour with my members from the group because the resolution, thanks to the hard work of my British colleague Richard Howitt and a romanian colleague, Viktor Boštinaru, achieved its goal: the absolute majority of MEPs accepted this vector with their vote, with the time to establish a Palestinian state and, at the same time, to continue the peace talks.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the recognition of the statehood of Palestine, because this historic resolution initiates the recognition of the State of Palestine, which was a fair and lasting demand of the vast majority of world public opinion.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. — The European Union must first firmly support democracy and security in the Israeli-Palestinian area, as well as provide support to achieve a lasting resolution of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. I believe that the European Parliament should first express its concerns about how a Palestinian state can be created. The creation of a Palestinian state is much more important and difficult to achieve than the mere recognition of Palestine. Once the peace process is completed, a solution for political recognition of Palestine can be found.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the joint resolution on the principle of recognition of the Palestinian State because I believe that this is a step in the right direction. The recognition of the Palestinian State, its people and its borders, as well as the end of the occupation, is an obligation of the international community with a view to peace in the region. Member States must now formally recognise the Palestinian State, on the basis of the 1967 borders and with East Jerusalem as the capital. The right to self-determination of the Palestinian people has already been in a number of international resolutions for 66 years. We ask the parties involved to take action to enable the two-state solution, ending the occupation and illegal walls.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — I voted against the motion for a resolution because interference by the European Union in this conflict of interest is neither helpful nor appropriate until there is a consensus on which further negotiations can be based. Furthermore, I consider that an opinion by the European Union is completely misguided, as it has not been given any competence in this regard.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Finally, the European Union proposes a firm resolution on the recognition of the Palestinian state, 67 years after the UN sharing plan. This resolution recognizes the Palestinian state, within the 1967 borders and with Jerusalem as the capital of both states. This will be an important point of support for the representatives of the Palestinian people, especially in their referrals to international forums, to compel Israel to respect the national rights of the Palestinian people. I regret, however, that there is no mention of the blockade of Gaza, nor of the oppression of the Palestinians by the Israeli army. This is not a conflict between two equal parties, but a struggle between a colonized people and a colonist state. However, this resolution will be an additional combat tool in the hands of the representatives of the Palestinian people who approve it. I'm voting FOR.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — The recognition of the State of Palestine is a matter that has been dragging on for a long time.  Let us hope that this EP initiative will help to find a solution that is accepted by both sides.  It will only be possible to reach a definitive and lasting agreement when a properly negotiated solution between the parties is found and that allows both peoples to live in harmony, development and peace.  An effort by the Palestinian Authority is needed to negotiate these solutions with the Israeli State until a solution to the coexistence of two states, based on the 1967 borders and Jerusalem as the capital of both, i.e. a secure State of Israel and an independent, democratic, territorially contiguous and viable State of Palestine, living side by side in peace and security, is needed. I call for the resonant of direct peace talks between Israel and the Palestinian Authority. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — I support the resolution’s call for recognition of Palestinian statehood in principle, as well as a two-state solution. I have therefore voted in favour.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I fully recognize the Palestinian State, because I am convinced that only the solution of two independent states and respect for the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Palestine as well as that of Israel will achieve lasting peace and regional prosperity. It is time for the Union, which has been on the back burner for too long, to take responsibility and show political will. Our common position in the European Parliament will make a difference and will enable the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Federica Mogherini, to provide a legitimate response and play a significant and positive role in a peace agreement between Israel and Palestine.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I supported the resolution on the recognition of Palestine statehood, regardless of the fact that it does not support the immediate and unconditional recognition of Palestine which would be an essential element in this resolution.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. I abstained on this resolution despite my sincere desire to see a Palestinian state recognised, on the grounds that it is not for the European Union to recognise or not a state. This is not within its jurisdiction and only a sovereign state can recognize or not another sovereign state. It is therefore totally abnormal to put to a vote a text that is inherently illegal and illegitimate.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution to recognise the State of Palestine as I believe that a two-state solution based on mutual recognition can help to facilitate the peace process in the Middle East.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on the recognition of the Palestinian state jointly tabled by five political groups in the European Parliament. This just and necessary resolution, following the announcements of the Swedish Government and the House of Commons of the United Kingdom, was an essential step in the process of peace talks between the two states. For more than 50 years, the search for a lasting peace between Palestine and Israel, which has become vital today, has been a central concern of the European Union, which guarantees the rule of law, democracy and peace between nations. The current situation has become critical and highly worrying, and this resolution strongly condemns acts of violence on both sides endangering the lives and safety of the people. There is an urgent need for a climate of appeasement in order to engage and support peace and negotiation efforts, which are now extremely slow or even suspended. I proudly support the diplomatic actions that will be undertaken between the European Union, Israel and Palestine, contributing on a larger scale to the Middle East peace process.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. — (IT) We welcome the proposal to recognize the Palestinian State. This decision taken by the European Parliament, although it has no legal value, takes on a strong political significance because it highlights the European Union's willingness to play a leading role in the Middle East peace process. At such a sensitive time as this, the EU is in a position to make a fundamental contribution to the advancement of the peace process, pursuing the two-state solution on the basis of the borders established in 1967 and ensuring both security in the State of Israel and the existence of an independent and democratic Palestinian state.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. "I did not take part in the vote on this point for the simple reason that I do not agree with either the proposed text or the recognition of a Palestinian state. The situation in this region, the data of this conflict do not require this type of initiative but fingering and diplomacy. To abstain would have given the impression that I was refusing to take a position on this text; by not voting, I mean it was not the right tool.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. — (IT) I abstained on the vote on the resolution on the recognition of Palestine, because I believe that there may be a possibility that this initiative could interfere with the path of peace negotiations. At the same time, however, I reiterate my firm support for a two-state solution that live side by side in conditions of peace and security, putting an end once and for all to the acts of violence and terrorism that have struck, and still affect, both peoples.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. — My country recognized Palestine in 1988. In this spirit, too, I welcome the European Parliament's resolution. I think it is of the utmost importance that today we are not trying to resolve the situation in the Middle East by sweeping problems under the carpet, by dunking awkward questions, but by showing a clear path acceptable to the peoples living there, and to lend a helping hand to a peaceful settlement. All under the auspices of the 1967 Border Compromise and international law. Yes, we must recognise the statehood of Palestine, but this recognition is conditional on active participation in the peace process and in an assive to its achievements. Reconciliation is not a matter of a momentary decision, but a process that needs to be worked on by both sides and in which the international community can be of great help. Enough with the bloodshed, all the sacrifices. Both sides have lost too much over the decades. I believe that independent democratic statehood will help Palestine to participate responsibly in the peace process.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: in writing. — I am of the view that the way forward in this conflict is a two-state solution – with an independent, prosperous Palestinian state neighbouring a peaceful and secure Israel. I therefore am happy to support anything which would further that end. Unfortunately, this motion does not do that. A two-state solution can only come about after direct negotiations between the Israelis and the Palestinians whereby, at the very least, Israel’s right to exist and live in peace is explicitly recognised.  To put things into context, the current Palestinian ‘Unity’ government includes Hamas. This summer alone, Hamas launched 4 000 missiles into Israel, all aimed at civilian targets. That is why this motion was flawed. Hamas are a terrorist organisation – and are recognised as such by the EU. If the Parliament wishes to recognise Palestinian statehood unilaterally, they are effectively calling a proscribed organisation a legitimate authority in the Palestinian territories, while terror attacks upon Israelis are still taking place. Real progress will be made by getting the relevant parties back to the table. If we are actually serious about a two-state solution and a viable Palestinian state, we need to push for direct negotiation, not unilateral recognition.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: in writing. — The resolution is a compromise which ensured the approval of this document by an overwhelming majority of Members. I, too, supported it, even though it risks a significant misinterpretation of what Parliament has approved. I consider it necessary for the resolution to be interpreted only to the extent that it corresponds to its wording. Recognition of a Palestinian state is the end, not the beginning, of the process.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I believe that there can only be a solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict if the two actors can negotiate equally and the hypocrisy that leads to the permanent discrimination of the Palestinian people is stopped. Therefore, I voted in favour of the EU's recognition of the Palestinian state, which I believe will be an important step towards resolving this conflict and peace in the Middle East.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I abstained because the main thing is to reach a two-state solution as a result of the peace process between Israel and Palestine. Both sides must make an effort to do so. In the current situation, pressuring one party does not produce the desired result.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. — The European Parliament voted and approved by an overwhelming majority the realization of an express and valuable gesture of recognition of the solution of two States: Israel and Palestine. And the desire for them to serve for the revival of the peace process. Mutual recognition and the safe and peaceful coexistence of both are inexcusable. The European Parliament wishes to cooperate in the implementation of this process and calls on the Commission for a common European position which Commissioner Mogherini can manage. The European demand for democratic behaviour and respect for human rights is twofold: on the one hand, Israel and, on the other hand, Palestine, which must establish democratic practices and solvent institutions and condemn terrorism. The text contains ambiguities, but seeks to help remove a bogged down situation. I voted with voluntarism.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: in writing. - (IT) I agree with those who believe that recognising the State of Palestine is decisive in order to initiate a balanced peace process and to prevent any further conflicting developments in the area from giving rise to arbitrary management that is not regulated by international law. There is no doubt that the unresolved Palestinian question, due to its decades of static and the particular odiousness of the conflict events it entails, represents a point of obvious weakness for the credibility of the means of international legal theory, as well as for the prestige of the action of politicians and diplomats who, especially from the judgment of public opinion, receive the energy necessary to transform their virtuous insights into concrete and operational actions. I therefore voted in favour of the resolution on the recognition of the State of Palestine, as I consider the two-state solution bordering Jerusalem as the only viable way to achieve and consolidate peaceful coexistence in the area. I therefore fully support the European Parliament's resolution, in the hope that it will send out a signal that can be taken up in practice by all its Member States.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. — The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted with serious reservations on the resolution referring to the "principled recognition of the Palestinian State". The resolution leaves out the demands of the Palestinian people against the Israeli occupation of Palestinian territories and does not correspond to the laws of the Palestinian people. The resolution also cultivates the logic of equal distances, while restricting the right of the Palestinian people to fight in all forms. At the same time, the EU is embellished and illusions are sown about its role.    The Communist Party expresses its full support for the struggle of the Palestinian people and the continuation of its struggle by demanding: -The creation of an independent, viable, sovereign Palestinian state, on the 1967 border with East Jerusalem as its capital, next to Israel, the liberation of the Palestinian people from the occupation of Israel. -Recognition of the Palestinian State as a UN Member State; recognition by the Greek Parliament and the Greek Government. - The cessation of settlements and the departure of all settlers. - The tear down of the unacceptable wall in Jerusalem. -The return of all Palestinian refugees to their homes, based on relevant UN resolutions. -The lifting of all Palestinian blockades in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. -The immediate release of all Palestinians and other political prisoners from Israeli prisons.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this resolution. I was the originator of this motion for a resolution by the group and I believe that the compromise reached is a step forward in the search for peace between an Israeli state at peace and security and a future sovereign State of Palestine. Diplomatic pressure is important and the European Parliament is directly in its role here.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — (IT) In view of the sensitivity of the matter and the importance of the matter, I would prefer not to express a position, of course that negotiations will begin shortly so as to resolve the problem once and for all.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — The worrying situation in the Middle East does not cease to be a topic of our discussions due to rising tensions and violence in the region and an increase in the number of terrorist attacks. I congratulate all negotiators who constructively produced the compromise text of the joint resolution of the political groups voted on by the EP today, which I co-signed.  The key is the principled political message that goes towards meeting Israel's security and Palestinian aspirations for its statehood. In accordance with the views of the European People's Party, I agree with the concept of two states that would be based on the 1967 borders with Jerusalem as the capital, and which would live in peace and security side by side. In doing so, the EP's key message is that recognition of Palestine, as an entity of international law, can be reached through the progress of peace efforts and negotiations between the two sides.  The only way to realize this idea is to agree between the parties to the conflict, notably Israel and Palestine who must opt for coexistence and long-term agreement. The message of the resolution is that Hamas should also follow Fatah's position (i.e. the PLO's 1993 commitment) to recognising the state of Israel. The EU's main objective must be to resolve a conflict that would contribute to Israel's security and ensure an independent, democratic and sustainable Palestine and contribute to the establishment of peace in the Middle East region.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: in writing. — I abstained in today's vote on the joint resolution on the recognition of a Palestinian state because I consider the text of the motion for a joint resolution to be shifted from the view expressed by the original proposal of my parliamentary faction, of which I was a co-author. I believe that a Palestinian state can only be recognised on the basis of the peace process with Israel, but this is not explicitly expressed in the final text.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Writing. — We must be grateful to the authors of this motion: by agreeing to recognise Palestine as quickly and almost unconditionally as possible, almost all the political groups except ours and the EFDD, they show that they do not care as much about The security of Israel as possible. Although individual representatives of the united front to be found here are still wrestling with individual lip service, their actions also show their emptiness. For us as an alternative for Germany, the existence of Israel is not up for discussion. That is why we refuse to negotiate with Hamas and Fatah as representatives of a Palestinian state as long as they advocate the destruction of Israel. Before we recognize Palestine, Palestine must recognize Israel!

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because it reaffirms the principle of the coexistence of two States and encourages a future recognition of Palestine as a state, following the resumption and deepening of peace negotiations and the articulation of positions between EU Member States.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. — Thanks to the commitment of the European Socialists behind this initiative, the European Parliament adopted by a very large majority a resolution in favour of the recognition of the Palestinian state. Although the text could have been more ambitious in its formulation, this vote marks a turning point for the European Union, which has worked steadily throughout its history to work for a two-state solution. The European Parliament has thus chosen to join the voice of the other national parliaments which have adopted resolutions in favour of the recognition of the Palestinian state. With this vote, MEPs are sending a strong signal to European capitals and the Commission to recognise the right of Palestinians to have a state. They also send a message to the Palestinian and Israeli authorities to re-establish dialogue and restart peace negotiations. This resolution is a first step that fuels the breath of hope in Europe for recognition. It also accompanies the efforts of the EU's High Representative for External Affairs, Federica Mogherini, to make the European Union a driving force in the Middle East peace process again.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. "I am, of course, in favour of the two-state solution, and therefore of a Palestinian state. Resolutely. But not that way. A recognition of "principle", going hand in hand with the peace negotiations, a text so ambiguous that it could be signed by the Conservatives and... Communists! By multiplying the conditionals, the conditions sine qua non are not expressed. The European Parliament does not have to support unilateral and unconditional recognition, which will inevitably freeze any ability of the Palestinians to compromise afterwards. Nor is this recognition, today, of a state that is not one of them and whose entity is a terrorist movement. How can we justify granting this status to those who continue to swear the destruction of Israel? Not to mention the 1967 borders, which are no longer in line with the reality on the ground, a reality integrated by the negotiators. The whole thing is to know where you put the cursor and at what price. Recognition of the Palestinian state should not be "symbolic" but useful for peace. It was in that spirit that I abstained.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — Recognition of the Palestinian state is a necessary but not sufficient step to achieve peace between Israel and Palestine. I believe that the only way to resolve this conflict is through the 1967 two-state border-based solution, with Jerusalem as the capital of both states. In this way, the State of Israel could live in peace and security with an independent, democratic and viable Palestinian state. I support this motion for a resolution as a compromise solution and because of the high value of both the broad consensus reached among all the groups in this Parliament and the important message we send with it. I would like to express my strong support for the recognition of a Palestinian state, considering that the right of Palestinians to have their own state is unquestionable as is Israel's right to exist within secure borders. I also value the leadership of High Representative Federica Mogherini in this process, as I believe that the EU should play a more effective and genuine role in the peace process, and I believe it is necessary for EU Member States to be united in supporting this legitimate process.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because we consider it a step forward for a majority of the European Parliament to be in favour of a basic claim such as the creation and international recognition of a Palestinian state with capital in Jerusalem. This only reaffirms what the UN already requests in its 1947 Resolution 181, paradoxically, the only one that Israel partially complies with, with regard to the partition of Palestine.  We further believe that recognition of the Palestinian State should be just one step in the process to achieve a just peace which, in the light of the demands of civil society itself, should include an end to occupation (in compliance with UN Resolution 242 of 1967), the right to return refugees (Resolution 194 of 1948) and a State that guarantees the full equality of all its citizens. We also believe that, in order to enforce the content of the Resolution, the EU should use pressure mechanisms, at least the suspension of the EU-Israel bilateral agreement, in compliance with Article 2 there, in the face of the flagrant violation of human rights involved in the continuation of the blockade of the Gaza Strip.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. —I have co-signed the resolution in favour of the recognition of the Palestinian State because it is essential to restart the negotiations, just as it is unimaginable that one day a lasting settlement of the Middle East conflict will be achieved without the democratic and sovereign state of Palestine being recognized as is israel's.
