This resolution continues the movement in the parliaments of different Member States for a relaunch of the peace process. This part of the world needs clear borders so that local people can live in peace and security tomorrow. Such recognition by the European Parliament is intended to be a strong political and diplomatic signal to the international community and, in particular, to the Israeli and Palestinian authorities. It is high time that dialogue resumed in favour of a negotiated solution. In my support of this resolution, I protest against the rise of violence in the region and call for an end to settlements in the Palestinian territories, which are illegal under international law. Palestine must be recognized on the basis of the 1967 borders, with Jerusalem as the capital of two states, living side by side, and in mutual recognition.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — Recalling that the European Union has repeatedly reiterated the principle of a two-state solution, Israel and Palestine, living side by side in peace and security, calling on the parties to resolve all relevant issues through negotiations that must be resumed immediately, I voted in favour of this Resolution, as I agree with the recognition of the Palestinian State in a broader framework of recognition of the State of Israel by Palestine and the Arab world in general. In my view, we should focus on resuming the negotiations, stressing that the European Union and this Particular Parliament should play a central role in the future negotiations between the two parties, at the immediate end of the violence, on the return to the 1967 borders as a negotiating basis for the inevitable land exchanges that will take place later and at the immediate end of the expansion of the settlements. I would like to end by stressing that I believe that the way forward should be that pointed out by this Resolution and also by the resolution recently adopted by the Portuguese Parliament, in order for the recognition of Palestine by each Member State to be carried out in coordination with the European Union and in full compliance with the principles laid down by international law.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. — The European Parliament adopted by a large majority (498 votes in pros, 88 against and 111 abstentions) the joint resolution on the recognition of the Palestinian state. Having supported and co-signed this text, I call on the European Union to take its responsibilities and finally become a real player in the Middle East. The resolution also insists that Federica Mogherini, Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs, do everything possible to facilitate a common EU position on this issue. Finally, it should also be noted that the resolution calls for the creation of a "Parliamentary for Peace" initiative, which aims to bring European, Israeli and Palestinian parliamentarians closer together. This would help to advance discussions on the situation in the Middle East.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because we consider it a step forward for a majority of the European Parliament to be in favour of a basic claim such as the creation and international recognition of a Palestinian state with capital in Jerusalem. This only reaffirms what the UN already requests in its 1947 Resolution 181, paradoxically, the only one that Israel partially complies with, with regard to the partition of Palestine.  We further believe that recognition of the Palestinian State should be just one step in the process to achieve a just peace which, in the light of the demands of civil society itself, should include an end to occupation (in compliance with UN Resolution 242 of 1967), the right to return refugees (Resolution 194 of 1948) and a State that guarantees the full equality of all its citizens. We also believe that, in order to enforce the content of the Resolution, the EU should use pressure mechanisms, at least the suspension of the EU-Israel bilateral agreement, in compliance with Article 2 there, in the face of the flagrant violation of human rights involved in the continuation of the blockade of the Gaza Strip.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. — This is to declare that I voted for the resolution because it resulted from a compromise between the political groups, including the S&D, but that I unreservedly and unconditionally support recognition of Palestinian statehood.

name: György SCHÖPFLIN
text: in writing. — As a member of the EPP Hungarian delegation I voted in favour of the resolution on the eventual recognition of Palestinian statehood, given that the text adopted states expressis verbis in Recital F: ‘whereas the recognition of the State of Palestine falls in the competence of the Member States’.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the motion for a Resolution on the recognition of the State of Palestine as a first step in the right direction. Recognition of the State of Palestine, its people, its borders and the end of the occupation is an international obligation and an important step towards peace. Member States must now formally recognize, and therefore protect, the space of the State of Palestine at the 1967 borders with East Jerusalem as its capital. The Palestinian people's right to self-determination has been recognized internationally for 66 years. We call on all parties not to take any action that could dynamite the feasibility of the two States' solution. Therefore, settlements must end, apartheid must be over, and the attack on sacred sites and the demolition of Palestinian property must cease immediately.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. — I supported the recognition of Palestine because I sincerely hope and expect that the European Union's international recognition of Palestine will finally trigger a successful peace process. I also hope that it will encourage all participants, including civil society organisations in Israel, to launch independent bilateral negotiations aimed at a peaceful solution to the conflict.  All peoples in the Middle East have been present for millennia and have lived in peace until external influences that prevented peace and coexistence. The peace initiatives so far have not yielded by establishing lasting peace because they have not had equal participants in the table discussions. The EU has invested a lot of financial resources in infrastructure construction in Palestine to improve attempts to restore lasting peace through negotiations and weaken the influence of terrorist groups by normalising civilian life. Unfortunately, Israel's attacks often focus precisely on the systematic destruction of built infrastructure and thus undo the Efforts of the European Union. The Palestinian side has an obligation to prevent militant groups from acting against Israel, and both sides are obliged to respect international humanitarian and human rights. I believe that we should leave the decision of our own destiny to the people who live there, without "benevolent" mediators, but with the help of the international community led by the EU in order to establish a normal and quality life in lasting peace as quickly as possible.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — Today I supported the Resolution on recognition of Palestinian citizenship and the resolution of the dispute between the two countries, which must go together with the development of peace talks. With this vote, the European Parliament clearly rejected unconditional recognition separately from the peace talks.  I welcome a resolution that rejects any form of terrorism and violence from all sides and warns of the potential religious dimensions of conflict. The only and viable solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict will be one that will be achieved through nonviolent methods. The text insists on the need for the resumption of peace talks, the final real recognition of Palestine as a state can only be revealed through negotiations between the parties in the framework of the overall peace process that resolves the disputed items.  So, I voted for the resolution, but it is clear that real recognition will only come after the two sides in the dialogue have agreed.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing. — In today's vote on the resolution on the recognition of a Palestinian state, I voted against it because I believe that this unilateral challenge does not help to resolve the situation and, on the contrary, may cause its further escalation.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the joint resolution on the recognition of the Palestinian State as a principled step in the right direction. Recognition of the Palestinian State, its people and its borders and the end of the occupation is a long-overdue international obligation and a positive step towards peace. Member States must now formally recognise and thus protect the Space of the Palestinian State on the 1967 borders with East Jerusalem as the capital. Palestinian recognition is established in UN resolutions and a number of national parliaments of EU Member States have called on their respective governments to recognise it.  The Palestinian People’s right to self-determination has been enshrined in international resolutions for 66 years. We call on all parties to refrain from any action which may undermine the viability and the prospects of the two-state solution. Therefore, settlements must end, the apartheid wall must be dismantled and attacks on holy sites, along with the demolition of Palestinian property, must stop immediately.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — We support the Palestinian state entity and look forward to a safe and good proximity to Israel. Peaceful negotiations must be launched and a political solution must be found with respect for human rights and mutual understanding. Hostile and violent conflicts on both sides benefit no one and more benefit ordinary citizens

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. - As a member of the Fidesz people's party delegation, at today's plenary session of the EP, together with the members of the PP Group, I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the principles of recognition of the statehood of Palestine, as the text adopted express verbis in paragraph F states that recognition of the statehood of Palestine falls within the competence of the Member States. The decision has no consequences under public law.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. " This lunchtime, through a resolution passed by a majority, the European Parliament officially and unconditionally recognises the Palestinian state. This recognition by the European Parliament is meant to be a strong symbol! The resolution passed this afternoon demonstrates that there is broad consensus in Europe that recognition of the Palestinian state is a necessary contribution to peace and security. It is also a signal to The Member States to recognize the Palestinian state immediately and unambiguously. Finally, Belgium must unconditionally recognize the Palestinian state, as it did in 2012 at the United Nations.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. — As regards the resolution on Palestine statehood and the related voting I have abstained. While I can only appreciate the enormous effort of negotiating colleague MEPs of a number of political groups to arrive at a consensual resolution, I regret to state that the resulting wording provides for a number of interpretations of some of the provisions. The second main reason for which I could not vote in favour is the fact that there is no concrete provision expressing the expectation of recognition of Israel as a sovereign state. I firmly believe that the High Representative for CFSP should now come with concrete inputs into a possible EU common approach. Once this happens, I expect a thorough debate in the EP plenary.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: in writing. — I voted against the resolution mainly because it encroaches on the sphere of the Member States. Moreover, such ill-considered ingerence in the peace process can do more harm than good. Unfortunately, our faction's alternative resolution, which was politically balanced, was rejected by a majority of MEPs.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. - I have abstained from the ‘Recognition of Palestine statehood’ resolution as I don't believe it is useful or appropriate to do this now, nor will it contribute to peace talks. I am in favour of a two-state solution as a medium- and long-term solution, but before that, Hamas leaders and organisation should recognise the right of Israel to exist in its borders. Moreover, they should recognise the right of Israel to its security. You cannot ask Israel to recognise the Palestinian State without asking the same of its Palestinian counterpart. I feel the message of this resolution will be taken, of course, as a victory in the Arab world and will make Palestinians believe they do not have to negotiate with Israel, but just need to seek international recognitions through several parliaments’ vote. Furthermore, only one month ago, High Representative Mogherini came to debate the issue in this house. She said she would come back with a roadmap towards peace. We haven't seen anything yet, so why this rush now?

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. "I have given my vote in favour of the need for recognition of Palestine as a State in order to advance the peace process. Nevertheless, I recognize that the content of the adopted text is excessively moderate, for the sake of a broad consensus which I believe is necessary for the historical purpose of the moment.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: in writing. - I wish to see a negotiated two-state outcome to the Middle East Peace Process, resulting in a secure, universally recognised and essentially Jewish State of Israel, alongside a sovereign, viable, democratic, terrorist-free Palestinian State. I therefore voted against the joint resolution, which fails to identify the continued sources of terrorism in the Palestinian territories and fails to address the fundamental problem: the non-existence of a government whose writ runs throughout the Palestinian territories, including Gaza. The resolution seeks to enhance the role of the EU, ignoring the fact that the EU has little to show for 10 years of involvement, when the Quartet has not met for over a year, and the EU does not use its financial leverage to bring about an end to terrorism and a fresh start to negotiations. Contrary to its own admonitions, the resolution itself is an ‘incitement and provocation’. In any case, the EU does not have the right to confer recognition; this is the prerogative of our national governments.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the recognition of the Palestinian State; this decision was agreed today by a considerable majority in the Parliament thanks to the ongoing commitment of the Socialists and Democrats Group. This resolution stresses the conviction in Europe that the time has come to solve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict through the two-state solution based on the 1967 borders.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. — By adopting by a very large majority a resolution expressing its support for the recognition of the Palestinian state on 17 December, the European Parliament has undoubtedly cast a historic vote. It is the Member States that have jurisdiction in this area and not the EU, but it is nevertheless a more than symbolic vote in favour of peace. 135 countries, or 70% of undying member states, have already carried out this long-awaited recognition by the Palestinian people. Only 8 EU states have done the same, most recently Sweden or several national parliaments including French, British and Spanish. It is to the credit of the EP to go in this direction in the face of a conflict that has lasted too long and for which the "international community" has heavy responsibilities. The EU is encouraged to act using all means to put pressure on the State of Israel. This resolution should have been less conditional. Peace can only be built between two legally equal partners. The rights of Palestinians as they have been in UN resolutions for so many years must be recognized. The EP resolution recalls the main principles in this area. It is with great pride that I voted for this resolution.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. " We voted in favour of this resolution despite its partial alignment with Zionism. This resolution is a minimal sign of recognising the inalienable right of the Palestinian people to their state. We believe, however, that the insistence on security only applied to the State of Israel (as if Palestine did not need security) seeks to create the idea that the borders of the State of Palestine are drawn according to this objective. We note the distinction between terrorism and violence and the condemnation of all violent protest, thereby denying the right to insurrection and resistance of palestinians to the Israeli occupation. Finally, we note the lack of reference to UN resolutions (181, 194, 248, 332) or the withdrawal of occupied territories, which, in addition to other objectives, is a way of marginalising the UN in this process.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — Since this question is not within the EU's field of competence and, in my opinion, the first question is whether mutual acceptance between the State of Israel and the Palestinians allows Palestinian statehood at all – which cannot be established after the events of recent years and recent events – this question is therefore also now obsolete. I also find it very questionable, by recognising organisations such as Hamas, in their approach, by, among other things, removing them from the list of terrorist organisations.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: in writing. — Labour MEPs led the negotiations for this resolution expressing support, in principle, for the recognition of a Palestinian state. The resolution also makes clear that supporting the recognition of Palestinian statehood should go hand in hand with the development of peace talks, which should be advanced. Although we wanted the resolution to go further, I am pleased to see it pass by such a large majority. This vote should be seen as a step forward for the two-state solution, sending a message of European support for Palestinian statehood in the anticipated UN debate, and giving a new impetus to peace talks.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing — the European Union does not have the competence to recognise the existence of states. This competence lies solely with the EU Member States. This has also been confirmed by the European Commission. For this reason, I refused to take part in the vote on the motion for a resolution on the sovereignty of Palestine. By adopting this resolution, the European Parliament has made a political gesture that is, at best, unnecessary and, worse, counterproductive. However, it certainly does nothing to help in finding a peaceful solution to disputes between Arabs and the State of Israel.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. — The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted with serious reservations on the resolution referring to the "principled recognition of the Palestinian State". The resolution leaves out the demands of the Palestinian people against the Israeli occupation of Palestinian territories and does not correspond to the laws of the Palestinian people. The resolution also cultivates the logic of equal distances, while restricting the right of the Palestinian people to fight in all forms. At the same time, the EU is embellished and illusions are sown about its role.    The Communist Party expresses its full support for the struggle of the Palestinian people and the continuation of its struggle by demanding: -The creation of an independent, viable, sovereign Palestinian state, on the 1967 border with East Jerusalem as its capital, next to Israel, the liberation of the Palestinian people from the occupation of Israel. -Recognition of the Palestinian State as a UN Member State; recognition by the Greek Parliament and the Greek Government. - The cessation of settlements and the departure of all settlers. - The tear down of the unacceptable wall in Jerusalem. -The return of all Palestinian refugees to their homes, based on relevant UN resolutions. -The lifting of all Palestinian blockades in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. -The immediate release of all Palestinians and other political prisoners from Israeli prisons.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of this resolution because we believe that, despite being full of the vision a thousand times spread by Zionism, it is a minimal sign of recognising the inalienable right of the Palestinian people to their state. However, we cannot fail to point out some negative aspects, namely: - the insistence on security only applied to the state of Israel (as if Palestine did not need security), seeking to create the idea that the borders of the state of Palestine are drawn according to this objective; - the distinction between terrorism and violence and the condemnation of all violent protest, thereby denying the right to insurrection and resistance of palestinians to the Israeli occupation; - the absence of reference to UN resolutions (181, 194, 248, 332) or the withdrawal of occupied territories, which, in addition to other objectives, is a way of marginalising the UN in this process;  - a common EU position is called for, which, in the current context, when there are countries which, like Sweden, have already recognised Palestine, mean an attempt to limit the sovereign power of the Member States to decide on recognition, and a brake on countries that want to recognise the State of Palestine.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. - (IT) For too long, the Israeli-Palestinian conflict has bloodied the Middle East and has been a painful wound for the whole world. The European Union has repeatedly declared itself in favour of a two-state solution, guaranteeing security and stability for Israel and independence and democracy for the Palestinian people. In order to achieve this objective, it is necessary to create the conditions for a resumption of direct peace talks between the two sides, denying the use of any violent means. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution, which strongly condemns the acts of war and terrorism perpetrated by both sides and the warning that a political conflict should not turn into a religious conflict, with the result that it should be extended to other parties. Coexistence based on mutual recognition is the only solution that can guarantee peace and stability in the region, as well as the basis for erasing the climate of tension that is swirling throughout the region. I particularly welcome the call for the High Representative to commit himself to drawing up a common position: it is time for the EU to speak with one voice, showing that it really intends to engage, rather than making room for the particularities of national diplomacy.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as you know, the issue of steel is a very dear matter for us, not least in the case of the current events in the Italian steel industry: I am thinking of the terni, taranto and piombino plants. We have contributed to the debate in this Parliament on the subject of the steel plan, including by tabling an oral question on the basis of the Terni affair and by in dialogue with the workers' delegations who have come to Brussels and then to Strasbourg.  We have also worked to improve the text of a joint that we did not ultimately agree with because it seems to us to include the issue of steel in the connection with Juncker's investment package and in an ideology and representation of competitiveness, inside and outside Europe, which does not convince us.  We believe that steel should be preserved as a strategic element of production for Europe. We believe, however, that social dumping and environmental dumping must be combated and combated and that serious ecological conversions must be carried out for those establishments, such as Taranto, which continue to sow death and cancer.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: Mr President, I come from a steel town, Middlesbrough, in a region with thousands of jobs based in energy-intensive industries, including steel, which underpin our regional economy. In 2009–2010, our local community fought hard to save our steel and ensure a future for Redcar’s blast furnace. It was not just a fight to preserve our industrial infrastructure and assets; we need investment in upgrading them and in environmental improvement – this would create jobs in a sustainable industry long into the future – and we need to recognise that we need ultra-low-carbon steel.  I welcome the Teesside City deal focussed on building an industrial cluster around carbon capture and storage. This is set to create 4 000 new jobs and sustain 20 000 more in our local industries.  I co-signed and strongly supported today’s resolution, because it sends a clarion call to the Commission and Member States to involve the workforce and industry, and to finally implement the European Steel Action Plan.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the steel sector in Europe plays a fundamental role and is of vital importance to many Member States. It is therefore right that it should be a priority for industrial policy. It is precisely its size and its employment scope that make it central to social policy as well. The steel industry is attributable to 350 000 direct jobs. We must therefore talk about markets, competition, demand, competitiveness, imports and exports. But it is even more important, and perhaps a priority, to talk about protection and social responsibility. Everything that is functional to industry in order to start again at a time of crisis cannot be paid for by the workers. Restructuring, technological development and relocation cannot be a burden on workers. Our task, Mr President, is to ensure that the Commission, when it comes to industry, never forgets the social dialogue.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr. President! In recent years, more than 40 000 jobs have been lost in the European steel industry. And thousands more will follow, if you can believe the words of the President of the World Steel Federation, Mr Eder, who said this in a recent interview. Mr. Eder is the CEO of the largest Austrian steel company – Voestalpine AG. This company was very much in the media this year because it outsourced its production to the USA. The company cited the high tax burden in Austria, the high energy costs, the high environmental requirements and the lack of willingness to reform by the Federal Government as reasons for this outsourcing. In addition, the company has criticised the expensive and strict CO2 requirements as far as the EU is concerned. From 2020 alone, Voestalpine AG expects to receive EUR 230 million per year for the purchase of emission allowances. This situation is characteristic of the steel industry and of the energy-intensive industry in Europe as a whole, and is leading to the deindustrialisation of Europe. On the contrary, the American government is going into reindustrialization massively, incentivizing companies to settle. Unfortunately, this is not the case in Europe. It was not possible to agree on a degree of reindustrialisation. That is why I support this initiative, today's resolution on the European steel industry, and also the Commission's action plan to restore reindustrialisation to Europe.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, once again the technocrats in Brussels are feeding us good intentions. However, the steel industry, particularly in France, is devastated. Factories are closing and the few remaining companies are being bought by Indian or Chinese conglomerates. In France, production has fallen by almost 40% in thirty years while at the same time demand has increased. This situation is a direct consequence of the policy pursued by Brussels for decades: policy of abolishing customs protections, absolute free trade policy. The measures proposed by Brussels to try to plug the gaps of the sinking boat insult the hundreds of thousands of steel workers sent out to be unemployed for thirty years. They expect their leaders to finally pursue a policy at the service of the peoples, not in the service of high finance and capital.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: Mr President, I strongly believe that our economic recovery is highly dependent on a strong manufacturing industry and that the European steel industry must be a sustainable and profitable part of this. I co-signed this resolution to ask the Commission what it is doing to promote key industrial production in all Member States in order to safeguard jobs across the European Union.  The Commission needs to promote and protect higher social, economic and environmental standards across the EU, particularly working with our social partners. The Commission needs to keep in mind our urgent need to develop a sustainable and decarbonised economy using a suite of options, including carbon capture and storage. This is why I call on the Commission to commit to developing high-quality energy-efficient and innovative products and processes to promote growth and create quality jobs in a joined-up industrial policy.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: Mr President, we have defended the proposal for a Resolution of the Group of the European United Left because we understand that the serious situation in the steel sector in Europe is the result of selling the industry to the highest bidder and not an issue of 'competitiveness', as the majority groups intend to believe. In Spain, companies of high added value and territorial roots face threats of relocation by large multinational groups. These impose very tough adjustments that the European Union's policies only exacerbate.  On the one hand, Europe remains impassive in the face of serious abuses of energy and financial oligopolies that suffocate the industry. On the other hand, it encourages competition between Member States, reinforcing the tendency for higher value-added production to be concentrated in a few European regions. We believe that the response to the industrial crisis is, among others, about resurming public control of the strategic sectors on which the sector depends, betting on an investment and public aid programme that preserves employment in dynamic and efficient sectors such as Spanish steelmaking and auxiliary companies. From here, our solidarity with the workers of Alcoa, ThyssenKrupp, Elcogas and Bosal, who are currently fighting for their jobs, for their future and that of industry.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the steel sector has always been one of the main strategic economic sectors in Europe, and there is no doubt that this sector has played a central role in the past and which it still has today for European development and growth and economic recovery. However, the sector is in serious difficulties in almost all the countries of the European Union. The resolution that has just been voted on calls on the European Commission to draw up measures and adapt policies to relaunch the sector, making it competitive, in order to prevent companies operating in this sector from being relocated as a result of the effects of the prolonged crisis. We therefore call for a specific steel plan, with the utmost attention to worker safety and environmental protection, and a package of financial instruments that will enable the steel industry to return to an important role and to be competitive on the international stage. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Mr President, I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution, which I co-sign, because I want to support the jobs that steel creates in Europe, in Greece, in Eleusis, in Magnesia, in Thessaloniki. According to official data from the Hellenic SteelWorkers Association, total production in 2012 fell by 58% compared to 2007. Compared to pre-crisis levels, i.e. in 2007, domestic demand fell by 82%. It has returned to 1962 levels, while Greek steel exports have fallen by 59% in 2011-2014 alone. I want to tell you that at the same time the banking obligations for the three largest steel companies in Greece exceed EUR 1 billion. Euro. You understand that the situation is dramatic first and for all for the workers there. I therefore think it is necessary to exhaust all possibilities to reduce energy costs in order to reduce the distance in energy costs in the Member States, and also to ensure that a brand for fair steel products manufactured in Europe is created and promoted immediately.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — The serious situation of the steel sector in Europe is the result of selling the industry to the highest bidder and not an issue of competitiveness as advocated by the proposal for a Resolution of the majority groups. High value-added companies across the EU are constantly threatened by relocations by large multinational groups that impose tough adjustments that EU policies only exacerbate. On the one hand, Europe remains impassive in the face of the great abuses of energy and financial oligopolies that suffocate the industry. On the other hand, it encourages competition between Member States, reinforcing the tendency for higher value-added production to be concentrated in certain regions of the EU. The response to the industrial crisis is to retake public control of the strategic sectors on which the sector depends, betting on investment and public assistance that preserves employment in the sector. Since all this is not included in the Joint Resolution, I have not been able to vote in favour of it and abstained.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to promote policies to develop industrial production in all Member States in order to safeguard jobs in the EU. Today, the EU steel industry is facing a significant drop in demand, resulting in more job losses and declining competitiveness. Since 2007, the closure of factories in the dairy sector has resulted in 60 000 job losses and production from EUR 210 million in 2007 to EUR 210 million in 2007. decreased to EUR 166 million in 2007. tonnes in 2013 I believe that an industrial policy action plan is urgently needed to revitalise European industry on the global market. I support the proposals to the Commission to examine the strategic situation of the European steel industry in the world, to develop a comprehensive analysis of the steel market, to provide information on the balance between steel supply and demand and to report on the main challenges facing the European steel industry, taking into account social, economic and environmental aspects. It is essential that part of the new investment package be devoted to viable long-term infrastructure projects and innovations related to large-scale industrial projects.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This text does not seem to me to be satisfactory, but it has some positive points, in the sense of the draft of European protectionism.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Joint Resolution and not as my group voted because I regard the steel sector as a strategic sector of the European Union, which the EU must support to remove obstacles and threats to its competitiveness, increase its capacity and respond to changing conditions in Europe and the world by strengthening its support for innovation , technology and research through the Horizon 2020 and SPIRE Program, as well as with a more important role of the EI betting on riskier projects. We need to commit so that the sector can, through innovation, make quality and energy-efficient products possible.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. Since the debate on 26 November on the situation of the steel industry in Europe, it is clear that the Commission's declaration, full of fine formulas and wishful thinking, is only coming to fruition when the European Parliament's motions for a resolution are voted on. Your solutions do not provide concrete answers to the ills that affect this industry. Worse, your Europe of finance and free and undistorted competition will only make the situation worse. In addition, there are clear reports of unfair competition from emerging countries and increased trade-friendly measures, such as trade barriers. But to this, the European Union prefers to continue its flight forward by proposing ever fewer borders, more free trade and ever more standards... However, there is an urgent need to initiate a process of re-industrialization, which requires an end to the dogma of the single currency, the establishment of intelligent border protections and the restoration of the sovereignty of nation-states. Even if this text is generally imperfect, because it does not call into question ultraliberal policies, it is nevertheless a step forward and that is why I voted in favour.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — The Resolution underlines the role that the steel industry, recognised as one of the strategic sectors of European industry, must play in the re-industrialization of Europe. Affected by continued losses in competitiveness and employment, the Resolution urges the Commission to present as soon as possible the roadmap for Europe's industrial recovery and the engarce of the steel industry there.  Parliament calls on the Commission to relaunch the High-Level Steel Group and accelerate the implementation of the 40 steel plan measures, but it also requires it to prevent unfair competition from third countries. It also stresses the need to invest in research and development in both the European economy in general and the steel industry in particular.  In addition, broadening its sights on all energy-intensive enterprises, the Resolution urges the Commission to ensure that the current State aid system does not create distortions in the internal market and to ensure equal competition for companies, as industry needs a stable framework for its investments in order to maintain employment. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted on this resolution because it has been advocated by Parliament on the protection of workers and industry in the EU steel sector. In its resolution, Parliament pointed out that the steel industry in Europe is crucial for economic growth and prosperity, but is currently experiencing a significant drop in demand, resulting in more and more job losses and a decline in competitiveness, which unfortunately does not make the necessary recovery in the European economy. Parliament also called on the Commission to speed up work on the industrial policy action plan, which should be published in the first half of 2015, in order to revitalise the competitiveness of European industry on the global market and ensure an effective level playing field while ensuring high social and environmental standards in the EU.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. — (IT) The steel industry not only plays a central role in the process of European unification but still plays an important role in the productive fabric of our continent with over 350 000 direct jobs and several million employees in the related sector. It is a sector that has been severely affected by the crisis, with falling demand, job losses and declining competitiveness. In recent months, the Commission and Parliament have been discussing an "industrial renaissance", for a recovery in manufacturing that will bring the share of industry in the ILO to 20% by 2020. I support and am one of the signatories of this resolution which urges the EU to act with regard to the steel industry in order to begin to give shape to the commitments announced on the industrial front, including actions in areas such as competitiveness, economic and social costs of restructuring and mergers, management of the sector's weight to achieve the EU's climate and environmental objectives. I think it is important, as the resolution points out, that with regard to the steel sector, the Commission should pay particular attention to investments, future trade agreements, in terms of opportunities for market access, and to the risks of distortion present today on the internal market, caused, for example, by asymmetries in the compensation provided by the various Member States.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. — The European steel industry today employs 350,000 workers and provides millions of others indirectly with employment. That's a big number, but before the crisis, it was much higher. Official figures show that 65,000 employees have been laid off by steelworkers in recent years due to the crisis. Steel is the cornerstone of a European industrial chain with automotive, mechanical, electric and construction industries and as such is crucial for economic growth and job creation. Unfortunately, according to official estimates, a significant increase in domestic steel demand is not expected in the short term. At the same time, competition from countries such as China is investing in new plants and increasing steel production using a lower energy price and cheaper labour. In the long run , this will further reduce the production share of European steelworks in global production and worsen the EU 's trade balance . The European steel industry urgently needs assistance in the form of concrete measures and strategy. This resolution is a step in the right direction, but it is up to the Commission to come forward with proposals with executive and legislative strength as soon as possible.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the first, fifth and sixth amendments because I think there must be more protection for the workers inside the EU.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution, which has some interesting aspects, although I consider that it does not solve the serious more structural than cyclical difficulties faced by the steel industry in the European Union and France in particular. Difficulties related mainly to ultraliberal dogma and free and undistorted competition imposed directly by Brussels.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. — The Resolution underlines the role that the steel industry is called to play in the re-industrialization of Europe. In addition to requesting greater vigilance in the implementation of the competition rules, the text also calls on the Commission on how it intends to proceed with regard to the steel plan, in particular as regards its financing, timetable and implementation of the 40 planned actions. The Resolution addresses the competitiveness of the steel industry in the internal and global market, the need for investments in research and innovation, concrete measures to reduce the high energy costs facing the sector and the need to urgently modernise trade defence instruments to protect the European industry from social and environmental dumping by third countries. An amendment tabled by the Spanish Socialist Members of the ITRE committee has been incorporated calling for measures to be taken to ensure that the current scheme of State aid to energy-intensive industries does not create distortions in the internal market, so as to ensure a level playing field for businesses and that energy-intensive industries can have a stable framework for their investments and ensure employment.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. — Defending the European steel sector is crucial, especially at a time of economic and financial crisis. The sector represents about 350,000 workers and is a fundamental industrial base. We must do everything we can to make the European steel industry competitive with competition from the rest of the world. The re-industrialisation of the European economy must be a priority. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the resolution on the European steel industry. I believe that the EU needs to step up its efforts to help the steel industry out of the crisis. As a result of plant closures, the European steel industry has lost 60,000 jobs since 2007 and its production has fallen by a fifth. The Commission must therefore provide precise information on the balance between steel supply and demand at European and world level and must identify the greatest social, economic and environmental challenges in order to develop medium and long-term initiatives to support the steel industry in Europe. I am convinced that trade agreements must improve the export conditions for steel. Future agreements must therefore include provisions aimed at significantly improving export opportunities and market access for European steel and steel products. Finally, we need control over EU competition rules and State aid in order to avoid iniquity between European countries. The Commission must examine whether the application of the competition rules and the state aid rules has led to unfair solutions in the European steel market and, if so, corrective measures will be needed as soon as possible.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: In writing. — The steel sector is facing a very significant crisis; I was therefore keen to support employment by promoting investment, research, innovation and training for workers, especially as these professions make constant efforts to take into account the reduction of CO2 emissions.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) The resolution in favour of which I voted is not that of the Liberal Group but that proposed jointly by the People's Party, socialists and greens. The difference is, in my view, the ability to combine the efficiency that budgets certify with positive numbers, on the one hand, and the human aspects of work, on the other. The EU was created precisely to share steel (together with the prevailing source of energy at the time) and what it means: industry, and therefore work and well-being, but also the production of objects that have strategic value. More than company numbers, we need to be interested in social numbers.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. — It is crucial to defend a sector that represents 350,000 workers and that is the backbone of EU industry . The steel industry plays a key role in the European economy. We cannot stand by helpless while production is reduced and jobs are lost

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - The EU is currently the world's second largest steel producer, producing more than 177 million tonnes per year, or 11% of world production. The steel industry is also a sector which has a cross-border dimension because of the 500 production plants distributed in 23 Member States and which has close links with many industrial sectors such as construction, electronics, automobiles, mechanics and electromechanics. As a result of the economic crisis, this sector is experiencing a slowdown in production: many plants have ceased operations, resulting in job losses. High energy prices, the effects of low demand and overcapacity on a globalised steel market have also helped to hamper competitiveness. I hope that the Commission will be able to monitor the situations of many plants, including those in Piombino and Taranto, and that it will take into account the technological know-how of these high-tech industries, which should be protected, especially from attempts at relocation. Finally, I hope that the European competition rules will be revised, which unfortunately in many cases prove to be outdated and incapable of reflecting the evolution of the global context.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour as the steel industry is essential for growth and prosperity in Europe and in recent years it has faced challenges. The current crisis is creating enormous social hardship for the workers. The Commission needs to continue supporting and implementing the SustSteel initiative as it encompasses environmental, economic and social dimensions, as well as the concept of stewardship, the responsible management of resource use. We need to show that steel products from the EU meet as high social, environmental and economic standards as those from anywhere else.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — The serious situation of the steel sector in Europe is the result of selling the industry to the highest bidder and not an issue of competitiveness as advocated by the proposal for a Resolution of the majority groups. High value-added companies across the EU are constantly threatened by relocations by large multinational groups that impose tough adjustments that EU policies only exacerbate. On the one hand, Europe remains impassive in the face of the great abuses of energy and financial oligopolies that suffocate the industry. On the other hand, it encourages competition between Member States, reinforcing the tendency for higher value-added production to be concentrated in certain regions of the EU. The response to the industrial crisis is to retake public control of the strategic sectors on which the sector depends, betting on investment and public assistance that preserves employment in the sector. Since all this is not included in the Joint Resolution, I have not been able to vote in favour of it and abstained.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — Steel has been recognised as one of the strategic sectors of the European industry, and this resolution aims at highlighting the role this industry has to play in the re-industrialisation of Europe. Another important aspect that was brought up was how to render the EU stainless steel industry competitive both internally and globally. Hence I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: in writing. — (IT) A motion on the steel industry cannot be separated from the protection of health, the environment and local economies. While promoting training and social protection, research and innovation, the use of scrap and electric furnaces, the production of steam and energy from gas, on the other hand, we do not want to support environmental taxation, the participation of NGOs and environmental associations in decision-making processes, we are not committed to combating social and environmental dumping by adequately protecting our standards. There is no mention of the importance of compliance with European directives in the environmental field and in particular with the 'polluter pays' principle, the need to divest obsolete plants or some of them which pose a serious danger to the health of workers, the local population and the environment. Finally, there is no question of the possibility of a genuine industrial and economic conversion which will make greater use of local economies. For these reasons, I have decided not to support the joint motion for a resolution and to abstain.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. — Given that the European steel sector has played a significant role in the European integration process and is a solid European industrial base, I believe it is important to consider the possibility of reopening the temporarily closed compounds through certain training programmes for workers who would be employed within them, thereby ensuring the future development and competitiveness of the European steel sector.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted whole much in favour of the resolution on the EU steel sector: a strong resolution, which recalls the importance for Europe of returning to growth from a solid industrial and manufacturing base.  The European steel sector, in which there has been a loss of 60 000 jobs and a significant fall in production in recent years alone, must remain a backbone of the EU's industrial revival, which must now be translated into action and not remain a mere title of some of the European Commission's intentions. The priority is to make the European steel industry strategic, preserving its know-how and skills and relaunching its sustainability and innovation. The resolution also stresses the importance of protecting the European steel industry from unfair commercial practices, which can only be guaranteed by a modern and effective system of trade defence and by ad hoc provisions in international agreements.  This text therefore has the merit of putting an important industrial sector back at the centre of the European political agenda, which will have to be relaunched in order to ensure that companies specialising in Europe can remain competitive on international markets, thus preventing the creation of the conditions for new painful cases such as that of the "AST" steelworks in Terni.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. — The European steel industry is currently suffering from the simultaneous action of low demand and global overcapacity combined with high energy prices. This leads to a continued loss of jobs and competitiveness in the sector. It is essential, in the interests of the European Union as a whole, to maintain the activities that feed its industrial fabric and to ensure the security of energy supply through domestic production. Therefore, the mobilization of all the levers, at European level, in favour of the steel industry is necessary. This resolution calls on the European Commission to produce, in the short term, a clear picture of the situation regarding the major changes taking place in the steel industry in Europe and to attach greater importance to industrial policy in order to boost the competitiveness of European industry in the world market. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. In France, as in the rest of Europe, the steel industry is suffering from the combination of declining demand and strong international competition, which does not meet the same social and environmental demands. Since 2007, production has increased from 210 million tonnes to 166 million tonnes in 2013, resulting in the loss of 60,000 jobs. Through the vote on this resolution, I wanted to encourage the modernisation of the products and processes of the steel industry so that it would be more competitive, while inviting the European Commission to reflect on the strategic position of this industry and the establishment of an instrument for the analysis of the steel market.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: in writing. - Although European industrial competitiveness is very important to me, I voted against this resolution. I find that this resolution does not address the right causes for the difficult position which the steel sector is in today, nor does it come up with appropriate solutions to address these problems. The main problem is overcapacity in the global market, mainly driven by the high production by state-owned enterprises in large third countries that are being sold on the global market below production cost. The steel sector, which per definition operates on a global scale, is very vulnerable to this. One of the solutions to this problem could be more specialisation in high-quality, high-value-added steel production.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. Europe must not abandon its steel industry, which is competing internationally with cheaper production costs. We produce high-quality steel and we would be making a mistake, losing know-how and jobs if we did not give it the means to become competitive again. Of course, Europe must focus on the economic sectors in which it is already competitive and reinforce its comparative advantages, but deindustrialization poses a serious danger to its economy.  To avoid this, we must aim to ensure that our competition policy is in line with an ambitious European industrial policy and support major European sector programmes in the fields of innovation and research, particularly in favour of the steel industry.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. — Due to the severe economic situation, steel and the accompanying industry have lost their leading place in European economies. This is a key sector with its specific economic and social dimensions. However, I believe that our proposed draft resolution does not respond with its high intensity recommendations to protect and support this sector. It is appropriate to propose and implement measures in the medium and long term to support the sector's presence on the global market. We need to support the steel industry with measures to make it globally competitive. It is imperative that the Commission and Parliament consider, propose and introduce measures to protect European steel producers from dumped imports. It is necessary to propose and implement actions to limit the effects of competition on weak or poorly regulated external producers for Europe that do not apply the high production criteria established by the Commission.  Because of these arguments, having not seen sufficient concreation and understanding of their agenda, I voted against the motion for a resolution. I believe that the proposed project does not meet the actual needs of the sector and needs to be specified. Moreover, it is essential that we see real measures written.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted against the proposal, as it is a wish list, which does not indicate serious and credible solutions to the conscious deindustrialisation of the EU Member States and the social problems it entails.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. - (IT) I would like to highlight one aspect only marginally touched on by the resolution voted on today concerning the reform of the ETS. This system, which has failed to achieve a reduction in CO2 emissions, must be abandoned and therefore, as stated in the text of the resolution, it is appropriate to examine the feasibility of adjusting carbon at the border, i.e. the payment of ETS allowances for steel from third countries, in order to create a level playing field in terms of CO2 emissions, thereby putting an end to the phenomenon of carbon leakage and promoting fair trading conditions for the sector. european steel industry against strong competition from non-EU countries. The steel sector must therefore innovate in order to ensure compliance with environmental, health and safety standards, which are fundamental elements for a new era of sustainable reindustrialisation of Europe.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. - The EU needs a modern industrial policy consisting of measures that promote and provide incentives for the sustainable and competitive industries of the future. The EU is the world's second largest steel producer and, of course, the steel industry is an important part of the EU's industrial base. However, we believe that the way for a continued competitive European steel industry in a global context is through investment in, for example, research and innovation, regulatory simplification, incentives to switch to greener technologies and energy efficiency – not through protectionism and state aid.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing.— In June 2013, the European Commission presented an action plan for the European steel industry with the aim of helping the sector lay the foundations for future competitiveness, fostering innovation, generating growth and creating jobs. The European Commission was also committed to reducing costs for industry, especially those arising from EU regulations. The action plan also provided for specific measures to support employment in the sector in Europe. However, the action plan has not been implemented in specific Commission initiatives to date. I would like to stress the importance of the need for the Resolution which we have adopted today to have an effect on the need to achieve these objectives and that, at the initiative of the Socialist Group, the need for Europe to count as a stable European framework for support for energy-intensive industries to avoid distortions in the internal market, to accelerate the renewal of trade defence instruments combating unfair competition , continue to support CCS pilot projects and boost investments for the modernization of plants based in Europe.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — We agree that the steel sector and the steel industry have always been one of the foundations of industrial economies. We are surprised, therefore, that the resolution does not consider how wrong EU policy for the sector was, allowing such inequalities and transfers to the private sector to be dug in and between Member States, particularly in Portugal where the sector has already been developed and is now deeply coarctado. We follow the resolution when it advocates the development of industrial production in all Member States, alerting to energy prices and environmental issues or when it stresses the need for investment in research and innovation. However, we regret that there are no concrete suggestions on social issues that preserve existing jobs and prevent the creation of precarious work in the sector.  As far as State aid for energy-intensive industries is, it is argued that these should not create distortions of the internal market by ensuring a level playing field for businesses. In this chapter, the limitations imposed by the Treaties aim to prevent the necessary support for domestic production and companies by imposing the law of the strongest and the monopolistic concentration at EU level. Hence our abstention.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. - (IT) The European Parliament resolution on the steel sector represents the real challenge facing Europe in order to give a boost to the industrial policies of the European Union and the steel industry in particular. The steel industry, as in the past, can once again play an important role in the industrial revival of Europe. The challenge facing the sector, however, is very ambitious, in that it must combine, on the one hand, the protection of workers from pollution-related risks and, on the other, European companies from the competition that is pushing them back on the world stage and from the general decline in demand for steel due to the general reduction in investment. Europe must therefore draw up a road map to put the steel industry back at the centre of industrial policies and turn it into a sustainable and profitable sector. Therefore, the Commission needs to use part of its investment package to develop and disseminate the best available technologies, in order to implement large-scale industrial projects, including energy efficiency and low-carbon projects. The efficiency of steel production associated with the implementation of substantial investments could give a significant boost to steel demand in the European Union.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: writing — The steel industry is essential for the European economy and industry is currently suffering from a significant drop in demand, leading to constant job cuts and reduced competitiveness. It is the European Union's duty to support a policy of developing industrial production in all Member States, thereby protecting jobs in the European Union. Therefore, the European Union's objective in supporting steel must be to remove obstacles and threats to its competitiveness and to respond flexibly to changing conditions on European and non-European markets. One of the main objectives must be the creation of safe and quality jobs. For economic success, it is essential to involve employees in innovative and restructuring measures and to create a platform involving the social partners to advise on an action plan for the steel industry.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — I am voting against the motion for a resolution 'The steel industry in the EU: protecting workers and the industrial sectors', as it encourages the use of financial instruments and tax breaks to attract private capital, without much reference to the preservation of jobs.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. — I voted against this motion for a resolution on the steel sector in the EU: Protecting workers and industry. I recognise that the European steel industry is facing a significant structural crisis, coupled with weak demand and longstanding concern over energy prices. However, I cannot support this text as essentially it calls for reciprocity to apply for the steel import and export market as well as entering trade negotiations with a view to introducing quantitative restrictions. Closing our markets to others is not right the right approach to our long-term free trade and competition goals.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution bearing in mind that, although the steel industry is fundamental to growth and prosperity in Europe, it is a sector in crisis. The European steel industry has for years been an important source of wealth for the economies of the Member States and must remain competitive in European and non-European markets. The sector must continue to lose jobs, considering that it gives 350,000 direct jobs. The steel sector is a good example of how a long-standing economic sector has been able to adapt to new technologies, reducing its environmental impact. EU steel products respond to stricter social, environmental and economic standards than those elsewhere, so the sector must be protected by taking measures to prevent their outsourcing outside the EU territory. Similarly, another important aspect to consider is the need to take measures to reduce energy costs in the medium and long term, especially for energy-efficient industries, such as those in the steel sector.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. — (IT) After the debate at the last November part-session on the crisis in the steel sector in Europe, we have today voted on an important and politically very significant text, which once again reaffirms the priority that the steel sector represents for the real European economy. Compared with the debate three weeks ago, we can today note with great satisfaction the agreement reached on the AST-Terni dispute. We hope that the agreement will be an opportunity for Europe to implement in practice the Steel Plan which the European Commission emphatically presented a year ago. We need a coherent and organic approach to increase production and give the sector courage, starting with new regulatory instruments that modernise the rules of competition, that speed up social support and restructuring interventions, and that protect European competitiveness despite the necessary and necessary commitments to reduce CO2 emissions.

name: Adam GIEREK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — I voted in favour of the resolution because steel is still the main material for the reborn industry. The mass production of tangible products, which include steel metallurgy and its processing, usually requires long-term and expensive investments. Companies, especially those at risk of relocation to third countries where environmental requirements are not as restrictive as in the EU, have been heavily subjected to unfavourable destructive processes. Transnational corporations have not modernised their metallurgical and processing plants based on new innovative technologies for years. They focused on exploiting existing industrial infrastructure and then changing locations. Therefore, speaking today of preserving this production in Europe, it is essential to restore the priority place of steel in European research. Numerous targeted innovations are needed, both those that are modernising existing technological processes and those that are completely changing them. In my opinion, in view of the future policy of decarbonising EU industry, it is necessary to focus on research and development of hydrogen and melt metallurgy.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this resolution. The European steel sector needs special attention. That is why I would like member States to consider the introduction of measures that can reduce the burden of the high energy costs borne by the steel sector in Europe, compared to global competitors. I also want the Commission to continue to monitor concerns about carbon leakage and environmental dumping related to carbon dioxide, and to consider measures that could remedy this situation for the post-2020 energy-climate framework. Finally, I stress the importance of continuing investments in research into carbon capture and storage, as significant advances in this area could, in the longer term, significantly reduce overall emissions in the steel sector. Finally, I am pleased that the resolution insists on the introduction of a carbon tax at the borders and a complementary label 'made in Europe'.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution calling for a new industrial policy to help the European steel sector cope with the global market and protect its workers. Indeed, the steel industry, a major employer in the European Union, provides 350,000 direct jobs and several million others in related sectors. This text demonstrates the importance for this EU sector of achieving good environmental performance in the face of increasing global competition by improving access to raw materials, a major challenge when we know that competitors do not have to comply with identical standards and objectives. To do this, the European Parliament says that research and development activities are essential to find a way to reduce emissions, especially CO2. Several other proposals have been made, such as the importance of investing in workers' education and training or the promotion of a know-how transfer programme to enable skilled workers of a certain age to pass on their knowledge and skills to newly recruited staff in European steel plants.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. — Improving the business environment and creating competitive industry frameworks are key to the recovery of Steel demand in Europe. The development of this new framework is our most important task here in Parliament and in the other institutions.   I voted in favour of making reducing energy prices and regulating CO2 emissions a priority for the European Commission and for the Commission to speed up the preparation of the industrial roadmap, given the strategic importance of the steel industry, as the re-industrialisation of Europe can only be achieved as a result of coordinated measures.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. —I am always very attentive to initiatives that emphasize the importance of protecting our strategic interests and industry is one of them. Indeed, this resolution reaffirms the priority interest of re-industrialisation for Europe, in particular the role of the steel sector, which represents 350,000 direct jobs. It stresses the need to preserve European industries by developing a genuine industrial policy for Europe and welcomes the work carried out in this direction (action plan for the steel sector in 2013, working paper in 2014, high-level group on steel...). Factories in difficulty such as Gandrange and Florange in France prove that we can no longer witness the decomposition of our industrial fabric without reacting because it is entire families, companies that depend on it and entire regions that are destabilized. I hope that this resolution will be a shockwave and not yet another signal which will once again fall into the limbo of the European bureaucracy.

name: Robert Jarosław IWASZKIEWICZ
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — I voted against the joint resolution on the steel sector within the EU. Its basics were wrong. The biggest problem in this sector is the high costs of doing business and the huge costs of electricity necessary to maintain production. Instead of subsidising, reducing taxes, reducing corruption, let us withdraw from the idea of reducing CO2 emissions. So little is needed to boost growth in the steel sector. Unfortunately, the resolution continues to highlight the european Parliament's strange manoeu to combine green energy with economic growth. Unfortunately, there is no such correlation in this section. Green energy and reducing CO2 emissions are a tightening of the loop around the neck of the steel industry in Europe.  I support the provisions on the so-called carbon leakage. That's a big problem. However, its author is not an entrepreneur, but anyone who supports the development of the energy and climate package.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted NO because ALDE had its better resolution which more directly influenced better protection of the steel industry.  The accepted resolution does not include our group's proposals and does not include the proposals I made in the general debate. In fact, I am of the opinion that the European steel industry, and therefore workers, has come to a difficult situation because the European Commission has forgotten for years to protect end-users of steel products. The best example of this is the shipbuilding industry, which in Europe has been virtually decimated by bad policy. With the disappearance of shipbuilding in many European countries, the steel market disappeared, which was very large and physically close to the steel production itself.  I advocated a revision of the policy towards the shipbuilding industry and since this was not mentioned anywhere, I did not accept the offered proposal for the text.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on the steel sector in the European Union for the protection of workers and businesses. I believe that industry must be a pillar of our economies, providing stable and quality jobs in Europe. To this end, it is necessary not only to protect this sector from social and environmental dumping, but also to revitalise its competitiveness. In order to promote European production, I have notably spoken out in favour of the establishment of a complementary label "made in Europe".

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. — I welcome the vote of this resolution, which stresses the key role of the steel sector for European industry and economy. It is an innovative sector, important in terms of internal market and labour, but facing many challenges (rising energy and raw material prices, strong competition, restructuring and relocation). An action plan for a competitive and sustainable steel industry was launched in June 2013 and half of its actions have already been implemented. However, the EU's efforts in this area deserve to be continued to meet the challenges facing the sector. The high-level steel group set up to encourage dialogue between stakeholders and strengthen cooperation between Member States must propose solutions for sites undergoing restructuring (e.g. Florange). The Globalisation Adjustment Fund and the European Social Fund must be duly called upon to improve the resilience of the steel sector.

name: Jan KELLER
text: in writing. — In the context of addressing the EU's economic and social problems, the demand for the reindustrialisation of Europe is widely accepted. The situation remains unsustainable, with the meat of the workforce spilling over into the services sector after workers leave agriculture, while their share in the industrialised sector continues to shrink. Without modernised industry, European countries will become dependent on imports of strategic materials and products. Among them is steel. That is why I supported the resolution on the necessary revitalisation and protection of the European steel industry in the vote.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — Steel is one of the strategic sectors of the European industry that employs more than 350 000 people directly and millions of people in related industries. I therefore supported the motion calling to step up EU efforts to help the industry out of the crisis.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. - I would like to stress my support for resolution on the steel sector in the EU. The European Union is facing high unemployment and low economic growth. This results in a difficult social situation for citizens and it is our duty to change it. That is also why I am really glad that the amendment from the GUE/NGL which was mainly focused on the protection of the employees who have been dismissed, successfully passed through. The only way is to recover European industry, and the steel industry is one of its keystones. Therefore we must insist on steps that will help to raise industry to 20% of GDP by 2020.  One of the necessary steps is to ensure a level playing field in the negotiation of international treaties like TTIP. Citizens in other parts of the world deserve as high social and environmental standards as we have in the European Union. Another important issue is that the steel industry is one of the energy-intensive sectors, so that competitiveness very much depends on energy prices. We must have this in mind when we form energy policy, and ensure that energy will be produced for affordable prices. I consider the resolution important and its aims should be launched into policies of the European Union.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: in writing. — (IT) This vote shows that this House recognizes the importance of the manufacturing sector, which in Europe is still considered strategic for the future of our economy, both in terms of employment and with a view to defining the level of industrial competitiveness of the Union on world markets. The process of deindustrialisation and the expansion of the services sector as a result of globalisation require us to rethink the entire manufacturing sector. Within it, the European steel industry, in particular, is facing an unprecedented crisis. However, steel will play a key role in relation to new sustainable industrial solutions, especially in the urbanisation process. The steel sector in Europe has branches of excellence in technological know-how which must be protected, experiences which must be encouraged through new investments without competing on the back of wage dumping. That is why we strongly support the need to overcome the rivalries between Member States, which have manifested themselves in continuous processes of relocation. We need to invest in quality jobs and innovative products. We have therefore highlighted the need to invest in research and innovation, as essential elements for the revival and renewal of the European economy and, in particular, of the steel industry.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: Writing. — The EU steel sector is an important source of employment, creating 350 000 direct jobs and several million jobs in the industrial sectors concerned, including the supply chain for processed products.  Support for the steel sector is essential, including the strategic development of new key steel sectors such as energy, transport, construction.  I support this document, in particular because we are talking about the development and promotion of innovation, supporting not only research and development and knowledge transfer, but also market and innovation clusters, promoting public-private partnerships in strategic sectors such as the steel industry.

name: Constance LE GRIP
