text: In writing. — It is essential to preserve our interests in this key industrial sector, whether in terms of employment (350,000 workers in the EU) and because of its role vis-à-vis other sectors of the industry. We therefore wished to support this sector which has suffered greatly, and which, despite the many adaptations it has made, needs to be accompanied in its innovation and research and development efforts. I therefore approved the implementation of the 2013 Steel Action Plan. In particular, European steel mills must continue their innovation work to strengthen their competitiveness. This is a crucial step for the re-industrialisation of our continent, of which the EPP Group has made one of its political priorities. We believe that the European Union must remain a land of industrial production, comprising a heavy industry, modernised and adapted to the challenges of the 21st century.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. — The joint resolution on steel calls for a real relaunch of European industrial policy. This revival is particularly important in the steel sector, which has been deliberately forgotten since the end of the ECSC treaty. This joint resolution therefore calls for support and investment support in the sector and, more importantly, that competition rules do not "mortgage the economic viability of the various steel sites" as it has done in the past. This is important insofar as it is this competition policy that prohibits us from direct aid to the sector. The joint resolution does not include our mention of the Florange site, or of the need to maintain our production capacity for this strategic industry and upstream of many sectors. But its questioning of competition policy, its warning on the dangers of dumping through future trade agreements and its call for greater association of workers and their representatives in training programmes and, if necessary, restructuring could only be supported.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — The steel sector remains strategically important for the Union. Reindustrialisation as a concept must take into account steel production as a processing product. The machinery, construction, car manufacturing, etc. industry cannot do without steel. Protecting industry and workers in this industry is a wise, supportive position. Taking into account the protection of workers is worthy of all measure.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — The serious situation of the steel sector in Europe is the result of selling the industry to the highest bidder and not an issue of competitiveness as advocated by the proposal for a Resolution of the majority groups. High value-added companies across the EU are constantly threatened by relocations by large multinational groups that impose tough adjustments that EU policies only exacerbate. On the one hand, Europe remains impassive in the face of the great abuses of energy and financial oligopolies that suffocate the industry. On the other hand, it encourages competition between Member States, reinforcing the tendency for higher value-added production to be concentrated in certain regions of the EU. The response to the industrial crisis is to retake public control of the strategic sectors on which the sector depends, betting on investment and public assistance that preserves employment in the sector. Since all this is not included in the Joint Resolution, I have not been able to vote in favour of it and abstained.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - I supported the resolution on the protection of workers and the steel industry. It is crucial to halt the decline in steel demand in the Union by supporting the steel industry, removing obstacles and threats to its competitiveness and responding rapidly to changing market conditions. The ever-increasing costs associated with climate policy implementation, higher socio-environmental standards and high raw material and energy prices have made European producers less competitive with non-EU producers. In order to address this situation, it is important to step up efforts to prepare an industrial policy action plan, a sustainable European policy on climate, energy and trade and to create a roadmap for initiatives to support the steel sector in the short and long term. This map should be aimed at improving the business environment and regulatory framework for steel production in Europe. Investing in research and innovation, e.g. under Horizon 2020, which could contribute m.in to the development of new greener, more resource- and energy-efficient technologies, is also key to improving the competitiveness of the European steel industry.  It is also necessary to draw up multi-annual plans to maintain and increase employment in the steel sector. For example, in Poland, around 130 000 workers worked in this sector before the restructuring, and now the figure is only 20 000.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — Over the last few months, the Commission has received several questions concerning the state of the industrial zone in Terni, Italy, in particular as regards the Acciai Speciali Terni steelworks. The latest industrial restructuring plan submitted by ThyssenKrupp to the Italian government envisions laying off 550 employees and closing one of the staliner. This measure is described as necessary for the survival of the undertaking, but account should be taken of the fact that staff costs are only 4% of turnover and the main costs are energy, raw materials and transport. I supported this report because it should be borne in mind that the steel industry is one of the strategic sectors of industrial policy of the European Union. I call on the Commission to take action to reduce the high energy costs that are damaging the whole sector. Furthermore, the Commission needs to recognise that the steel industry in Europe needs to survive in a globalised world and accordingly there needs to be programmes and incentives to help steel companies survive on the market. It would protect workers from job losses accordingly. Parliament recently adopted an action plan for the European steel industry, but we now call for concrete measures to protect jobs and competitiveness.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. — It is important that, when it comes to economic growth in the EU, also to protect workers in the steel industry. The Social Democrats tabled a series of amendments in this context, and I voted in favour of them and in favour of the resolution as a whole.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I abstained from voting on the motion for a resolution 'Steel industry in the EU: protecting workers and industrial sectors', because, as I pointed out in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament, it does not protect workers' rights and does not provide support for the development of the European steel industry.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. — One of the eu's foundations is the Treaty establishing the European Coal and Steel Community. The EU must not lose sight of this base, but must continue to invest in the steel industry, which is essential for economic growth. This sector provides 350,000 direct jobs and several million related jobs. I believe that investing at EU level in high-tech industries and thus in the steel industry is becoming imperative in order to avoid their de-relocation outside the EU. I call on the Commission to ensure the competitiveness of European industry on the world market and to ensure fair real competition. This is possible by effectively using the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and the European Social Fund. The Commission must also use the European Regional Development Fund to make the necessary investments in research and innovation to revitalise this sector, in particular in the innovative production process and energy efficiency. Last but not least, I call on the Commission to closely monitor the situation of combinations in Romania in order to avoid further closures or sales to competitors from third countries.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. - (IT) I have signed and voted in favour of the resolution on the steel sector in the European Union in order to protect an entire industrial chain that is suffering greatly from the economic crisis. Steel is of fundamental importance to the entire manufacturing industry and involves a huge number of workers across Europe. In order to protect the steel industry, we must improve competitiveness in favour of investment, safeguard European companies to the detriment of companies from third countries, protect workers, as in the case of special steels in Terni, and urge the Commission to review European competition policies.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — The European steel industry plays an essential role in the European economy. However, it is currently suffering from a fall in demand, resulting in the loss of many jobs. My support for this resolution stems from the conviction that the European Union should be the author of a policy for the development of industrial production in all Member States. In particular, I supported the reference in the text to the need to speed up the preparation of the industrial policy roadmap planned for the first part of 2015, so that European industry can be relaunched on the world market, on the basis of a rational project.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — (DE) I have received my overall support for this motion, since there is a balance between the social and economic aspects of the steel industry and also of the workers. Concrete proposals for improving the work situation and safety at work make the proposal worthy of support.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — This non-binding resolution expresses good intentions towards the steel sector. It proposes that high European standards for climate and environmental protection should become global standards. It affirms the need for "full commitment of social partners at all levels." It is also a question of remedying the investment crisis in Europe, without specifying how. But at the end of the day, it is mainly a question of "removing the obstacles and risks to the competitiveness of the European steel sector". I abstain.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — The European economic recovery depends heavily on the existence of a solid manufacturing industry – in which the steel industry plays a central role – and that the manufacturing industry depends on domestic demand and supply.  It is therefore necessary to speed up the preparation of the set of industrial policy measures announced for the first part of 2015 in order to revive European industry on the world market, ensure a level playing field and ensure high-level social and environmental standards in the European Union, while strife for reciprocity by third countries.  An ambitious approach to reindustrialisation in the context of the mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy is of vital importance in achieving a genuine EU industrial policy and relaunching the EU's industrial competitiveness globally. A policy that encourages industrial production is essential to achieve job creation and economic growth. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — The manufacturing industry is a key sector in the EU’s economy, with high dependency being placed on its ability to perform well and in a competitive manner. I voted in favour of this resolution because of the need to safeguard this industry and the livelihoods that depend on it. The EU must invest in this sector, both from an R&D perspective, as well as with regard to the education of its workers. Continuous development in an innovative manner is the only way that this industry can survive in such a competitive international sphere.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing — The steel industry is one of the traditional European sectors that have contributed to Europe's growth and prosperity in the long term. At present, the steel industry provides direct employment to around 350 000 workers and millions more jobs in related industries are closely linked to it.  The steel industry faces many challenges in the current economic and geopolitical constellation. Restructuring and possible mergers often appear necessary in order to maintain efficient operation, but must be carried out in a socially responsible manner and taking into account the overall economic and social situation in the region concerned.  I agree with the request that the Commission follow current developments in order to protect the industrial heritage and the workforce concerned and create the conditions for revitalising the competitiveness of the European steel industry on world markets, which unfortunately the EU has been losing in recent years. Strong global competition must also be taken into account when applying the right to eu competition.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. During the last campaign for the European elections on 25 May, the MR made a commitment to make a difference in the European Parliament by promoting the renewal of struggling industrial sectors, such as the steel industry. A liberal and social approach dictated by the imperatives of results, not a purely protectionist approach, which has shown its limits for more than 20 years. Because the reality is there; it is twofold: worrying, if we refer to the 60,000 jobs lost in the sector since 2007, promising, if we consider that the steel sector is 350,000 direct jobs and several million subcontractors concerned in the European Union. We know for a fact that European industry urgently needs a strong and competitive steel sector. The EU is the world's second largest producer of steel, with 11% of total production. It is strong from this observation and the adoption by the plenary of amendments by the Liberal Group on research and development and the promotion of a low-carbon steel sector as well as on the establishment of public-private partnerships in this strategic sector that the MR delegation voted this lunchtime on the resolution on the future of steel in Europe.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of the resolution on the steel sector in the EU, which aims at highlighting the role that steel industry has to play in the re-industrialisation of Europe.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. — In the face of lowering global demand and an increasingly uneven global playing field, the steel industry, once the backbone of the European economy, is currently going through tough times. Heavy yearly reductions in production capacities, massive layoffs all over the continent and the looming threat of Europe switching from exporter to a net importer of steel, all form one depressing reality.  Given this state of affairs, my vote goes in favour of putting some action behind today’s political rhetoric calling for a European industrial renaissance. While not sacrificing environmental standards or the voice of our steel workers in the process, European steel needs a clear support plan to get back on the track of growth. Our Union’s long-term industrial competitiveness is clearly at stake here.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution, which has some interesting aspects, although I consider that it does not solve the serious more structural than cyclical difficulties faced by the steel industry in the European Union and France in particular. Difficulties related mainly to ultraliberal dogma and free and undistorted competition imposed directly by Brussels.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. — (IT) With the resolution on the steel sector in the European Union: protecting workers and industries, the European Parliament is sending a very clear message to the Commission: Europe can only emerge from the crisis if it returns to investing in the real economy. The recovery also depends on the revival of its strong manufacturing industry, in which the competitive and sustainable steel industry plays a crucial role. In fact, there are 350 000 direct jobs and several million more jobs in related industries. It is precisely because we have been witnessing a crisis in the sector for years that action is essential. Europe's high-tech steel industries are a model of know-how that must be protected and their presence must not be relocated outside the Union. We call on the Commission to speed up the preparation of the industrial policy roadmap planned for the first part of 2015, to launch the ambitious approach to European reindustrialisation, as part of the mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy, and for future trade agreements to improve export opportunities and market access for European steel and steel products. These are essential conditions for the global competitiveness of European industrial policy, while respecting the high social and environmental standards that the Union has set itself.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. — (IT) We welcome the motion for a resolution calling for a greater effort on the part of the European Union to help the steel industry out of the crisis. In particular, we call on the Commission to pay attention in trade agreements to improving the export conditions for steel and for there to be control over EU competition rules and State aid in order to avoid iniquity between European countries. We also call on the Commission to produce precise information on the balance between steel supply and demand at European and world level and to identify the greatest social, economic and environmental challenges so as to develop medium and long-term initiatives to support the steel industry in Europe.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. — Economic recovery in Europe depends to a large extent on a strong manufacturing industry, in which the steel industry must play a key role. We urge the Commission to speed up the preparation of the industrial policy roadmap announced for the first part of 2015 in order to revitalise European industry on the world market in order to ensure a level playing field, while guaranteeing high social and environmental standards in the EU. The Commission should also allocate part of its investment package to viable long-term infrastructure projects and innovation in industrial macro-projects, including energy efficiency and low-carbon projects, which could also significantly boost demand for steel in the EU.  I stress that investment in research and innovation is crucial for the recovery and recovery of the European economy in general and of the steel industry in particular. It is essential to support the steel sector, including through the strategic development of new key sectors using steel, thereby creating incentives for efficient production processes, strengthening the internal market and stimulating skills development.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because I support the action plan for steel which puts industry in general, and the steel industry in particular, at the centre of European political choices, particularly in the face of the critical situation of this sector in European countries, leading to relocation and unemployment.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the draft to improve the situation of the steel industry in europe in crisis. The steel industry plays an important role in the European economy. I believe that the European Union must increase competitiveness compared to the peaks in this area.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this resolution because I support fair trade through a border adjustment of CO2 emissions in the steel sector. This is the meaning of this resolution, which aims to rebalance competition between steel companies, particularly those that pollute the most with impunity.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Ladies and gentlemen, it is in the interests of the whole Of the European Union to maintain a sustainable, resource-efficient and competitive steel sector as the backbone for many important forms of industrial production. The European steel industry is currently subject, in many Member States, to a substantial decline in global demand and in some cases to competitive challenges, as well as increased costs. The EU steel industry is an important source of employment and the creation of a stable environment for private capital investment is crucial, together with the efficient use of EU resources. For these reasons, I would vote in favour.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. — The European Union was born as the European Coal and Steel Community. The steel sector is of historic importance in the process of European integration and is the basis of the industrial added value of the old continent. The steel industry, however, is suffering both from a substantial fall in demand and from very high energy costs, which have led to job losses and competitiveness. In order to cope with this moment, we need an action plan for a competitive and sustainable European steel industry. This resolution, for which I voted in favour and which I supported, lays the foundations for a European industrial policy that safeguards the value of our know-how, avoids the relocation of our companies, and invests in high technology in order to obtain high-quality, safe and sustainable products. A strategy that must have among the main players not only the institutions of the Member States and the top management of companies, but also, and above all, the workers themselves and the social partners. It will also have to create external conditions conducive to the development of the sector, such as lower energy costs. The European steel industry is an excellence, we cannot afford to be overtaken by countries that do not respect social, environmental and unfair competition standards.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — I support the adoption of a European Parliament resolution that sends a message on the importance of this sector for the whole EU. It is also proposed to the European Commission to take steps that could help revitalise the sector in the international market race. I believe that the EP is obliged to express its support for the STEEL sector in the EU, notably due to the fact that this industry employs 350 000 people and creates several million jobs in other related activities. I therefore believe that the European Commission should offer, as soon as possible, a picture of the situation and challenges for the steel industry in the EU. The reasons for the analysis of the situation in the steel industry are: poor competitiveness of the sector at international level, the need for a strategy for adaptation, restructuring and development of the steel and manufacturing sectors throughout the EU, as well as the goal of increasing investment in research and innovation. These challenges can be addressed by a comprehensive plan that would explore potential models of the functioning and competition of the steel sector on the international market. In conclusion, I would also like to point out from the resolution the recommendation that the funds of the European Globalisation Fund and the European Social Fund be used to minimise the consequences of uncompetitiveness and to address the market failures of steel companies. I also support the involvement of wider regional and local communities in tackling the steel sector.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. — The steel industry in the 1950s was at the very beginning of the process of European integration, it is still essential for the European economy. As one of the draftsmans of this resolution, I am glad that there has been agreement within the European Parliament on the need to help the steel industry find its way out of the current crisis, which has already had an impact on the loss of around 60 000 jobs in the sector. This crisis was caused both by the decline in demand for steel products and, above all, by developments in the global steel market. Europe can compete primarily with quality and innovation in a global market where many countries produce with far lower social and environmental standards. It is therefore necessary to support the steel industry not only from a medium-term perspective (export conditions contained in trade agreements or compliance with European competition rules by global players), but above all to address the long-term perspective of the sector, to invest in the education of employees in the sector and in research and development. Funding for education and research should be covered both by the EU institutions (eib and EU programmes, in particular Horizon 2020 and SPIRE) and by the private sector, ideally, for example, from profits from the sale of emission allowances.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Writing. — (DE) It is quite necessary to be of considerable arrogance and distance from the citizens in order to be able to understand the Commission's statement made here. While the European steel industry is being deprived of its breath, thousands of redundancies are taking place, sites and jobs are being relocated from Europe, the Commission is taking note of this, but it is not bothering to do so. As the steel industry is an energy-intensive sector, the Commission is glad to no longer know it in the territory of the EU member states. Just as it forgets European jobs, it does not seem to be aware that Europe is a leader in environmental protection. A steel plant in China, India or Brazil has a much deeper ecological footprint than a European one! The Commission's policy here is destructive: for workers, social systems, the environment and Europe's international competitiveness.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — The steel industry in Europe faces many challenges, including restructuring. I therefore vote in favour of this resolution, which supports coordinated action by Member States in a key area of European integration. It must also be able to benefit from the quality of the steel as it is made in Europe and its lower carbon impact. I therefore vote in favour of amendments recognising such qualities.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — The steel sector plays a key role for the economy and industry in Europe, securing more than 350 000 direct jobs and several million jobs in related industries, including the recycling supply chain. In recent years, the steel industry has faced some difficulties, caused, inter alia, by an investment crisis, by the decline in global demand, by the increase in the cost of energy and by the increase in the outsourcing of European production. It is therefore important to adopt measures to support this sector to remove obstacles and threats to its competitiveness, to promote its sustainability and to make it able to react to changing conditions in the European and non-European markets. This resolution contains a number of proposals aimed precisely at protecting the EU steel sector and its workers. Because I believe that the measures envisaged will generally contribute to making the EU steel sector more competitive at international level, I voted in favour.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Writing. — Manufacturing is the backbone of the European economy. The steel industry occupies a special position in this. The sustainable strengthening of the steel sector is essential for a new recovery in Europe, also in order to boost employment. However, the European steel industry has been under a great deal of competitive pressure for years and has been affected by many restructurings. I signed the resolution on the protection of workers and industries in the EU steel industry. Only if we succeed in maintaining and expanding steel production in Europe can we be able to boost economic growth. After all, many subcontractors and services are directly linked to the steel sector. This creates jobs in the EU and contributes to a strong European economy. It is also crucial to keep the quality of jobs high. The well-trained workers in the steel industry must also be protected and involved from the outset, even in the event of restructuring. The rights of information and consultation must therefore be strengthened.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. — In addition to the role it has played in the European construction project, the steel industry is of crucial importance to our economies. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, which puts forward a series of proposals to reform this sector and try to preserve the many jobs it still represents in Europe: investing in worker training as well as in research and innovation, in particular with a view to reducing the environmental impact of these activities, making the best use of available European resources (European Social Fund , European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and innovative financial instruments), engage social partners on changes to be adopted and take into account the interests of the sector within the framework of European trade and competition policies. Of course, many of these proposals should have been implemented a long time ago, but I believe it is not too late to save the steel soldier. Competition from emerging economies reminds us every day of the urgent need to evolve this sector.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, which rightly recalls the historic role of steel in the European construction project and calls on us to take action to help employees in this sector, which is bearing the brunt of the current economic crisis. In fact, 2013 saw an unprecedented decline in crude steel production in the European Union. Support for the European steel industry requires a response to the investment crisis in the sector, which is in dire need of training its workers and developing research and innovation in order to reduce its environmental impact and improve its competitiveness. The European Union has answers and this House is asking the Commission to do something about it.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — The Resolution underlines the role that the steel industry, recognised as one of the strategic sectors of European industry, must play in the re-industrialization of Europe. Affected by continued losses in competitiveness and jobs, the Resolution urges the Commission to present as soon as possible the roadmap for Europe's industrial recovery and the engarce of the steel industry there. Parliament calls on the Commission to relaunch the High-Level Steel Group and accelerate the implementation of the 40 steel plan measures, but it also requires it to prevent unfair competition from third countries. It also stresses the need to invest in research and development in both the European economy in general and the steel industry in particular. In addition, broadening its sights on all energy-intensive enterprises, the Resolution urges the Commission to ensure that the current State aid system does not create distortions in the domestic market and to ensure equal competition for companies, as industry needs a stable framework for its investments in each to maintain employment. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — The European steel sector has not been spared from the crisis, far from it. Many production capacities have either been permanently closed or cocooned without any technical possibility of restarting. Some industrialists have legitimized these closures by a structural overproduction of steel in Europe, an opinion which I do not share at all. Nevertheless, I think that we all share one observation: the necessary re-industrialisation of Europe requires a strong and competitive European steel industry. Other economic powers such as China have understood the strategic importance of the steel sector and have therefore not hesitated to support it. Three-quarters of steel production costs come from energy and raw materials. It is therefore essential to support research and development, but also investments to improve energy efficiency and material efficiency in this sector. The future of our industry as a whole is at stake. This resolution is timely.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal because I believe that the European Union needs a functional, competitive and secure steel industry that can contribute to growth and prosperity in Europe. It is true that this sector has suffered a sharp decline in demand, leading to increased unemployment, but it is also true that the EU must conserve the activities that make up its industrial fabric, ensuring the security of energy supply through domestic demand. As such, I support the Commission's steel sector action plan, while calling attention to the need to carry out an analysis report on the current situation of the steel industry on our continent, analysing its economic, social and environmental impact and reflecting on medium and long-term support initiatives. Finally, I draw attention to the need to frame this support within a broader framework of support for European manufacturing because this is the only way (in a solid way and investing in research, innovation, human resources qualification and energy efficiency, and possibly with the use of Community funds) does it ensure its competitiveness, stimulating its added value, and enhancing its important social role.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, which is part of the preparation of the European Commission's roadmap for industrial policy announced for the first half of 2015. Our European industry is a key element in the recovery of the European economy. It is important to return to a bold research and investment policy in order to develop our steel sites and their capacity for innovation. The know-how and expertise developed in important industrial hubs will ensure diversification, environmental protection and the development of innovative products.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - The serious situation of the steel sector in Europe is the result of selling the industry to the highest bidder and not an issue of competitiveness as advocated by the proposal for a Resolution of majority groups. High value-added companies across the EU are constantly threatened by relocations by large multinational groups that impose tough adjustments that EU policies only exacerbate. On the one hand, Europe remains impassive in the face of the great abuses of energy and financial oligopolies that suffocate the industry. On the other hand, it encourages competition between Member States, reinforcing the tendency for higher value-added production to be concentrated in certain regions of the EU. The response to the industrial crisis is to retake public control of the strategic sectors on which the sector depends, betting on investment and public assistance that preserves employment in the sector. Since all this is not included in the Joint Resolution, I have not been able to vote in favour of it and abstained.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing - I supported the resolution on the situation in the EU steel industry, with an emphasis on protecting workers and businesses. I see the situation in the steel industry very carefully. The steel giant USS in Košice, where I live, has long been one of the largest employers in eastern Slovakia. This company is still at risk of production cuts and redundancies. I therefore welcome the fact that, in the EP, we are dealing with the situation of companies in the steel industry and addressing the possibilities of their competitiveness, stabilisation and development. In the future, we can expect significant changes in the steel industry due to investments in research and innovation, resource efficiency, new technologies and expertise. That is why individual Member States need to better align education and training policies with the needs of the labour market in order to provide specialised professionals in the steel industry. In addition, the Commission should report as soon as possible on the main social, economic and environmental problems of the EU steel industry, so that we can respond flexibly with initiatives to support this sector in the EU.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — I support the European Parliament's resolution on the steel sector and the protection of workers and industry in order to keep the industry going and become competitive. Much of the European steel industry in most countries has seen a drop in demand, with costs such as energy costs rising . It is also very important to protect steel workers, as over 350 000 people are employed in the EU. I therefore support actions and plans to support this industry, which would stimulate the growth of the steel industry, maintain jobs, maintain economic and economic growth, reduce costs and take concrete environmental measures such as promoting low-carbon, low-impact steel production.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — We cannot rely on wishful meals without serious, worthwhile and credible solutions to the conscious deindustrialisation of EU Member States. This action will bring social problems that we must take seriously.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. — A number of amendments have been tabled to improve the initial plant, such as: mineral substitution by ferrous scrap; increase in the use of electric furnaces; replacement of coal by gas; social protection workers dismissed without just cause; border adjustment, i.e. payment of CO2 emission allowances for steel from non-EU countries (combating the relocation of emissions); investments in the low-carbon economy of the proceeds from the sale of free carbon allowances; no further investment in CSS; I use technologies that recycle waste energy for steam and electricity production. However, the resolution does not present turning points due to environmental and health problems, does not support economic activities other than steelworks that coexist with them territorially, does not take into account the changed globalized landscape and production overcapacity, and protects unsustainable and non-convertible plants. In particular: no amendments have been passed to protect health, the environment, the participation of NGOs in decision-making processes, surrounding local economies other than steel production, the 'polluter pays' principle; the Ilva of Taranto is one of the steelworks to be preserved whose maintenance of production capacity must be guaranteed; the failure of EU competition rules (AST Terni case) is not considered. I therefore abstained.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — I have, of course, voted in favour of this text stressing the importance of an industrial policy and smart regulation, together with measures that will revitalise the competitiveness of European industry in a global market, and ensure conditions that are truly the same for all economic agents, in order to protect European production from social and environmental dumping.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. — I have voted against the resolution as the resulting text does not come with a clear and conceptual approach addressing the real needs of this industry. I am sure that not only the steel industry in the Czech Republic would appreciate a resolution which would address these needs. I am of the firm opinion that the ALDE draft was much much closer to achieving this. Unfortunately our political partners opted for a more popular but inefficient approach.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: in writing. — Unfortunately, the resolution adopted contains some problematic points and, on the contrary, does not fully name the key ones, which is why I abstained. The steel industry and its downstream engineering is one of the main and indispensable activities of the European economy. But protectionism is not the recipe for worsening competitiveness on world markets. Steel products from Asia are not burdened by European regulations and the most expensive energy prices in the world. Alarmingly, Europe is constantly putting pressure on its own steel industry. The legislative conditions for steel production itself are being tightened. Current technology appears to have reached its limits and CO2 is unlikely to be reduced by 80-95% by 2050 as required. Energy-intensive sectors need to see a reduction in energy prices, a reduction or exemption from different charges for alternative sources, and an revised emissions trading scheme. This is the only way to preserve 400,000 jobs and remain the second largest steel producer in the world.

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: in writing. — Dear Colleagues, the economic recovery from the protracted crisis depends on the existence of a strong processing industry where steel plays a key role. I therefore welcome any action aimed at ending the crisis of the closure and transfer of companies from the steel industry out of Europe and the inevitable loss of thousands of jobs.  It is in our common interest to preserve steel production by not allowing technological "know-how" to be exported outside the European Union.  I call on the European Commission to take fixed-term measures to address the economic and social consequences of problems in the steel industry and to propose adequate initiatives to revive its competitiveness. Such measures may include a revision of competition rules or aimed at reducing the energy costs of energy-intensive industries. For example, the accelerated completion of the internal energy market would ensure competitive energy prices. The situation requires the EC to urgently convene a meeting of the High Level Group on Steel to take into account the recommendations of the EP and the interests of local authorities, especially from regions where steel making is a major population livelihood.  Last but not least, I believe that solid investment in research and innovation adequately funded by European funds and programmes is important for the revival of the steel industry.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. — The economic recovery of Europe is highly dependent on a strong manufacturing industry. The steel sector plays an essential role in Europe’s economy; industry is currently suffering from a substantial drop in demand, leading to a continuous loss of jobs and competitiveness which does not bode well for the necessary recovery of the European economy. I voted in favour of this resolution as it calls on the Commission to ensure that future trade agreements include provisions which significantly improve export opportunities and market access for European steel and steel-based products.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. — Steel is essential for European industry, but the European Union and its Member States are still unable to come up with a real plan for reviving the steel industry in crisis, including environmental issues. This resolution is in line with previous ones, when it is time to make proposals that meet both the economic and environmental needs of the sector and the expectations of employees, since social challenges cannot be met independently of the rest. It is true that there is a real challenge to be met... Worse, during the vote, the amendments tabled to recognise the need to preserve the know-how and expertise of the major industrial sectors were rejected on the grounds, in particular, that these sites are polluting. What about the interest of employees? The responsibility of public authorities and elected officials is to accompany them, to help them build proposals, not to condemn them outright. This resolution provides some guarantees for the protection of the environment of workers and their social rights and, although they are far below what might be expected, they have led me to abstain.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — The steel sector and the steel industry have always been one of the foundations of industrial economies. We are surprised, therefore, that in the Resolution there is no assessment of EU policy for the sector, which has allowed such inequalities and transfer to the private sector within and between Member States, particularly in Portugal, where the sector has already been very developed and is deeply depressed today. We agree with the Resolution when it advocates the development of industrial production in all Member States, alerting to energy prices and environmental issues, or when it stresses the need for investment in research and innovation. However, we regret that there are no concrete suggestions on social issues that preserve existing jobs and prevent the creation of precarious work in the sector.  As far as State aid for energy-intensive industries is, it is argued that these should not create distortions of the internal market by ensuring a level playing field for businesses. But let us not forget how unfair the rules of competition and the limitation of State aid are, when everyone is in sight of the urgent need to assist national production. Hence our abstention.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — Since there is a balance between the social and economic aspects of the steel industry, but also the workers, I voted in favour of the motion. Since there are also concrete proposals in this regard, this proposal is, in principle, a welcome one.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Writing. — (DE) I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution because it is necessary to promote a clean reindustrialisation of Europe in the coming years. We need an industry in the European Union based on innovation and employment. One of the biggest challenges of the near future will be to bring new, promising industries to Europe. The basis for this is the European steel industry. As a Linzer, I myself come from a steel region. Steel is synonymous with growth, innovation and employment and has always played an important role in the European economy. A functioning industry is a prerequisite for growth in Europe. The outsourcing of industrial jobs abroad will result in the loss of important jobs and the risk of a decline in the quality of products will also increase. In addition, it is important to reduce cheap imports from countries with low social and environmental standards. This motion for a resolution takes account of the social and environmental components as well as the economic aspects. In view of this balance, the motion for a resolution must be supported.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing. — (IT) Mr President, I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the EU steel sector because I see it as a first step in pushing the EU to support the steel industry, seeking to remove obstacles and threats to its competitiveness and ensuring that it is able to adapt to changing situations on European and non-European markets. That is why I am particularly pleased that the Commission is being asked to examine the feasibility of adjusting carbon at the border, through the payment of ETS allowances for steel from third countries, in order to create a level playing field in terms of CO2 emissions and to limit the phenomenon of leak carbonage.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. - (IT) I abstained on the final vote because, although I am aware of the importance of safeguarding jobs, our amendments were not taken into account, which aimed not so much at restoring heavy industry, but at ensuring that Europe's support aimed at the conversion of these plants, so as not to give priority to employment at the expense of serious health and environmental repercussions.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. — More than a year ago, following the Lampedusa tragedy, the EP adopted a Resolution on migration flows in the Mediterranean and the Council would set up a panel. Several Commission communications followed. Last month, the Council was taking steps to better manage migration flows and, in the past plenary, we expressed the need for a comprehensive EU approach to migration. Nevertheless, deaths have continued to occur and the desired shift in approach to immigration, a victim of a negative look that obviates the opportunities it offers and does not give alternatives to legal immigration, is not appreciated.  This Resolution sets out the elements that a comprehensive approach should contain and calls on the LIBE Commission for a strategic report on the subject. It also raises questions such as the exercise of solidarity and the equitable sharing of the burden imposed by Article 80 TFEU, obligations on rescue and mafia control, extension of Frontex's mandate, establishment of safe routes for immigration, improvement of resettlement and improvement of policies and management of immigration funds. That is why I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I have not been able to vote in favour of this motion for a resolution because its objective of giving a mandate to the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs in this House to launch a committee of inquiry into the situation of migration in the Mediterranean has been greatly diluted. But more importantly, the Resolution does not reject the fundamental pillar of EU immigration policy: Frontex. It is a migration policy that is based on a repressive view of it, ignoring the root causes of it: if there is the phenomenon of migration from the countries of the southern Mediterranean to the EU countries it is because from Europe we continue to expose the natural resources of those countries, thus preventing them from economic prosperity and a future for their peoples. If migrants continue to arrive from Africa on our shores, it is because we continue to encourage wars in their countries that push them to abandon them. That is why I voted against this motion for a resolution.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. — Almost every day, people migrate to the European Union out of necessity. Many of those seeking protection who come to Europe are taking the risky route across the Mediterranean, which is now the world's most dangerous border crossing. More than 3 000 people have lost their lives this year trying to cross the Mediterranean towards Europe.  The Mediterranean Member States are overwhelmed by this situation, which is why the European Parliament reiterated in its resolution this week that it is essential to take a holistic approach here and that the EU must play its fair share in terms of responsibilities and solidarity towards the member states of refuge.  However, in order to fulfil search and rescue obligations and thereby prevent further deaths at sea, this also means providing adequate financial support for this in the medium and long term.  It also encourages Member States to impose severe sanctions on people or groups exploiting vulnerable migrants in the EU and to draw attention to the dangers to all those who entrust their lives to traffickers and smugglers in wide-ranging information campaigns and to those who have fallen victim to traffickers.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. — More than a year ago, following the Lampedusa tragedy, the EP adopted a Resolution on migration flows in the Mediterranean and the Council would set up a panel. Several Commission communications followed. Last month, the Council was taking steps to better manage migration flows and, in the past plenary, we expressed the need for a comprehensive EU approach to migration. Nevertheless, deaths have continued to occur and the desired shift in approach to immigration, a victim of a negative look that obviates the opportunities it offers and does not give alternatives to legal immigration, is not appreciated.  This Resolution sets out the elements that a comprehensive approach should contain and calls on the LIBE Commission for a strategic report on the subject. It also raises questions such as the exercise of solidarity and the equitable sharing of the burden imposed by Article 80 TFEU, obligations on rescue and mafia control, extension of Frontex's mandate, establishment of safe routes for immigration, improvement of resettlement and improvement of policies and management of immigration funds. That is why I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to discuss strengthening EU border policy and security issues and to promote solidarity between Member States in the field of asylum. In the first nine months of 2014, at least 3 072 people died in the Mediterranean. This demonstrates once again the importance of Member States taking action to save the lives of people in danger and to fulfil their international maritime rescue obligations. I agree that the EU must take a fair share of its responsibility and solidarity with the Member States with the highest number of migrants and asylum seekers. It is also important to review the issues of strengthening border policy and security, as well as to consider how to improve the role of Frontex and the European Asylum Support Office in the future. I agree with the need for criminal sanctions against trafficking in human beings and smuggling of migrants and to examine the whole strategy of cooperation with third countries in terms of humanitarian, financial and political assistance.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted against this text, which proves once again the blindness of the European institutions to the real problems and the means to deal with them. Faced with the same kind of problems, massive illegal immigration by sea leading to tragedies, Australia decided to pursue a policy opposite to that of the European Union. Now, thanks to the operation aptly named "Sovereign Borders", NO immigrant arriving illegally by sea is welcomed in Australia, let alone "regularized". This message of firmness, relayed by an effective communication campaign, notably with video deterrence broadcast in the countries of origin of immigrants, has produced exceptional results. The European Union would do well to build on that.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. —I have obviously supported this motion for a resolution by which the European Parliament instructs the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs to examine a comprehensive EU migration strategy and to draw up a series of recommendations to strengthen it. The Mediterranean has already experienced too many tragedies. This comprehensive strategy must therefore be based on solidarity and respect for human dignity. The EU urgently needs to develop and secure safe and legal access routes to its territory and actively combat networks of people smugglers and traffickers. It must also develop greater solidarity with third countries in Africa.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. After Operation "Mare Nostrum" and now Operation Triton, the European Union is opening a boulevard for migration from Africa via the Mediterranean.  Thousands of migrants are risking their lives on makeshift boats and these rescue operations only encourage them to take the step towards the "European Eldorado". These operations are the result of nearly 150,000 illegal immigrants arriving in Europe each year, entering the Schengen area and travelling as they please. On Operation Triton, the British Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, Joyce Anelay, announced, very clearly, that Britain would not support the operation, stating: "We believe that (these operations) create an unintended 'pull factor', encouraging more migrants to attempt the dangerous crossing of the sea and thus leading to more tragic and unnecessary deaths." It is becoming more than urgent to be firm on immigration as is the case in Australia, to re-establish our borders, to fight criminal networks and to allow each state to decide its migration policy sovereignly. That is why I voted against this text.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — More than a year ago, following the Lampedusa tragedy, the EP adopted a Resolution on migration flows in the Mediterranean and the Council set up a panel. Several Commission communications followed. Last month, the Council was taking steps to better manage migration flows and, in the past plenary, we expressed the need for a comprehensive EU approach to migration. Nevertheless, deaths have continued to occur and the desired shift in approach to immigration, a victim of a negative look that obviates the opportunities it offers and does not give alternatives to legal immigration, is not appreciated.  This Resolution sets out the elements that a comprehensive approach should contain and calls on the LIBE Commission for a strategic report on the subject. It also raises issues such as the exercise of solidarity and the equitable sharing of the burden of Article 80 of the EOM, obligations on rescue and mafia control, extension of Frontex's mandate, establishment of safe routes for immigration, improvement of resettlement, improvement of policies and management of immigration funds. That is why I voted in favour of the Resolution.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: in writing. - I fully support the main conclusion of the resolution to task the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs with conducting an assessment of the current policies of asylum and migration, including additional resources to perform this task. However, I abstained in the final vote because the text also calls for swift processing in collaboration with third countries of transit and origin and of return for those who do not qualify for asylum and protection in the EU. This effectively means that decisions of asylum claims are prejudiced, thereby seriously undermining the whole asylum system. Processing of any claim for asylum should never be done in collaboration with the country of origin.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because it expressed its regret at the tragic deaths in the Mediterranean sea off Lampedusa, which killed at least 3 072 people in the Mediterranean in the first nine months of 2014. In its resolution, Parliament also calls on all EU Member States to take a fair share of their responsibility and solidarity with the Member States with the highest number of migrants and asylum seekers. The resolution also states the need to consider strengthening border policy and security issues and also to consider how to improve the role of Frontex and the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) in the future.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. — Data from the International Organisation for Migration for 2014 are clear. At least 3,072 deaths in the Mediterranean are estimated during the year. A number that, accompanied by the more than 150,000 rescues carried out by Operation Mare Nostrum, shows a dramatic picture. Europe and its Member States must conduct their fight against migrant smuggling and trafficking in human beings while respecting their international obligations in the field of rescue at sea. In recent months, operation Triton seems to be coming up with a long-awaited European response, although the commitments of individual Member States in the future are not yet clear. Saving lives in danger is not an option. For us Europeans, this is a strong point. I support this resolution calling on the European Union to take a unified and coordinated approach to immigration and border management. In particular, I consider the passage that the fair distribution of responsibilities and solidarity with the Member States that receive the greatest number of refugees and asylum seekers to be strengthened. Finally, it is a good thing that, aware of the recent tragedies in the Mediterranean and the costs of rescue and search operations, Parliament is calling for appropriate funding to be made available for this purpose.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. " This text "believes that it is necessary to think about strengthening security and border policy". It's about time! Finally, Brussels is becoming aware of the dangers of migratory flows! But its response is distressing: "improving the future mandate of Frontex and the European Asylum Office" and "asking Member States to continue to show solidarity and show their commitment by making a sufficient contribution to the budgets and operations of these agencies". So we're reassured! The peoples of Europe are scolding and the European institutions are still hopelessly deaf. It is high time to stop the aspiring pumps that attract guests that we are not able to accommodate.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — As an Italian MEP, directly concerned by these issues, I voted for this resolution, which goes in the right direction for having a common immigration policy.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — While the motion for a resolution seems less angelic than usual, it nevertheless supports Operation Triton, continues to demand the establishment of a European immigration policy and a strengthening of the common asylum system to better distribute the demand expressed by illegal migrants. On the other hand, we believe that Member States must leave the Schengen area at all costs and re-establish national borders. It should also be remembered that 3,072 people died in the Mediterranean Sea in the first nine months of 2014. These deaths are not the result of the so-called lack of generosity of Europeans, but rather of the hope of migrants to obtain hospitality that no Member State is able to offer anymore. That is why only a policy of firmness, like that of Australia, will prevent these human tragedies. That is why I voted against the motion for a resolution.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. The resolution is not controversial and calls for greater cooperation between Member States in addressing the problems of immigration in the Mediterranean. Furthermore, it goes in the direction that I want to see for a global approach, not just an Italian one, to the issue of immigration.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. — More than a year ago, and as a result of the Lampedusa tragedy, the EP adopted a Resolution on migration flows in the Mediterranean and the Council established the Mediterranean Panel, followed by several Communications from the Commission. In addition, last month the Council adopted conclusions on measures to better manage migration flows. However, many deaths have continued to occur in the Mediterranean ever since. The EP raised a number of issues in this regard: the solidarity and equitable sharing of the burden enshrined in Article 80 of the Treaty, the obligations on sea rescue and the fight against mafias, the desirability of extending Frontex's mandate, the need to establish safe and legal routes and routes for immigration , improving resettlement, managing immigration funds and improving immigration policies. The debate made clear the need to articulate a new integrated approach. The Resolution attempts to fix the elements that such an approach should contain. The most significant aspect is that it calls on the LIBE Commission to draw up a comprehensive strategic initiative report on this subject and requests additional means to carry it out.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. — The Mediterranean's migration policy must be the subject of particular attention. We must act in the face of the tragedies related to illegal immigration, such as the tragedy in Lampedusa. The text that has been approved by Parliament proposes a comprehensive approach to migration. I voted in favor. Indeed, the resolution mentions the importance of restoring responsibilities fairly between Member States and showing solidarity with the countries that receive the largest number of refugees and asylum seekers on their territory. The operational and financial strengthening of Frontex is also highlighted. We need to ensure that European citizens have optimal security at the EU's external borders.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a comprehensive EU approach to migration in the knowledge of the urgent need to implement the overall strategy of cooperation with third countries. In 2014, more than 3,000 people died in the Mediterranean in a desperate attempt to cross it into a better life. As if that were not enough, these flows have become a privileged ground for crime, which has given rise to a veritable trafficking in human beings aimed at exploiting irregular migration. The European Union must make every effort to save the lives of these human beings and to ensure that all Member States comply with international agreements on sea rescue, demonstrating humanitarian solidarity and concrete commitment, with the funding and contribution to the operations of the new joint Triton programme coordinated by Frontex.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) This text is very important for Italy and I voted in favour of it because it once again enshrines the principle of solidarity between States in the reception of migrants. Italy, as a protracted country on the main routes of migrants, has no human choice but to welcome. However, in a system of shared borders, it is right that everyone should do their part not only in terms of the resources provided but also in terms of the absorption of labour from other countries. This is an issue that must be closely monitored, so that successive legislative resolutions take due account of our position.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. — In 2013, more than 100,000 migrants have tried to cross the Mediterranean, of which more than 500 are estimated to have died or disappeared. According to the IOM, 2014 was the deadliest year for migrants, with an estimated 3,000,000 people having died trying to cross the Mediterranean. In fact, experts confirm that the likelihood of immigrants dying while making this crossing has been increasing in recent years.   This year, the new rules for Search and Rescue operations in joint FRONTEX operations, of which I was rapporteur, enter into force. However, this new instrument does not cover strictly national search and rescue operations. In the face of such migratory pressure in the Mediterranean, this duality of legal regimes may prove problematic.  A year after Parliament's resolution on the Lampedusa tragedy, this resolution is on the right track: we must tackle the root of the problems. However, we must also deal, and quickly, with what is going on in the Mediterranean. Or we risk it becoming a graveyard.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. How long is this going to last? How much longer will we see hundreds of men, women and children arrive on our shores or see hundreds of men, women and children die at sea? Italy has been shouting loudly for years for help. Reception centres are collapsing and landings are only increasing. On the other side of the Italian coast there are nothing but countries at the mercy of a very serious political instability. What is needed at this point is concrete action, firstly to provide for severe criminal sanctions against trafficking in human beings and the trafficking of migrants, both within and within the EU, and to launch resettlement programmes that can benefit from European funding. But that is not enough. We need a fair distribution of responsibilities, we need solidarity between Member States and we do not need to abandon the countries that are subject to landings, such as Italy, to bear all the responsibilities. I can only vote in favour of the motion for a resolution because it outlines a number of actions to be taken. But we are well aware that the problem to be solved is upstream: we need a strengthening of partnerships with transit countries, such as Libya, but above all it is necessary to contribute to the restoration of the stability and democracy of those countries still affected by serious conflicts.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of this resolution, even if I am disappointed with its content, which is more rhetorical than practical and often repeats what has already been said. The tragedies occurring in the Mediterranean need more action and less talk. The Commissioner for Migration, Home Affairs and Citizenship needs to take strong action that – at minimum – will effectively implement the suggestions incorporated in this resolution. In relation to human trafficking and smuggling, while ensuring strong criminal sanctions may be a deterrent, strong preventive measures, which include the identification of smuggling routes and trafficking gangs through closer cooperation between Member States and third countries, are necessary. The effectiveness of information campaigns addressed to those who end up being victims of trafficking or smuggling is dubious unless the causes that lead persons to become victims are seriously addressed. The resolution fails to mention the political unrest that has existed for a while in a number of third countries, not least in Libya. The consequences of continuous unrest in Libya will continue to make migration management within the Mediterranean unmanageable. The EU must ensure that operational support is provided to Member States such as Malta, which face a difficult challenge in managing immigration.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — According to data from the International Organization for Migration, at least 3072 people died in the Mediterranean in 2014. Every effort must be made to save the lives of those in danger and to ensure that Member States comply with their international obligations in the field of sea rescue, in order to prepare a comprehensive strategy of cooperation with third countries, in particular those of sub-Saharan Africa, North Africa and the Middle East, with regard to humanitarian assistance , financial and political, including in the area of law enforcement and to seek clarification on the role of policies on regional protection, resettlement and return, including migration management agreements in countries of origin and transit. In order to tackle the root causes of migration, I could only vote in favour of this resolution. I am voting in favour because third countries must respect international law with regard to the saving of human lives at sea and must guarantee the protection of refugees and respect for fundamental rights.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — I have not been able to vote in favour of this motion for a resolution because its objective of giving a mandate to the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs in this House to launch a committee of inquiry into the situation of migration in the Mediterranean has been greatly diluted. But more importantly, the Resolution does not reject the fundamental pillar of EU immigration policy: Frontex. It is a migration policy that is based on a repressive view of it, ignoring the root causes of it: if there is the phenomenon of migration from the countries of the southern Mediterranean to the EU countries it is because from Europe we continue to expose the natural resources of those countries, thus preventing them from economic prosperity and a future for their peoples. If migrants continue to arrive from Africa on our shores, it is because we continue to encourage wars in their countries that push them to abandon them. That is why I voted against this motion for a resolution.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. — In the first nine months of 2014, according to the International Organisation for Migration, at least 3,072 people lost their lives in the Mediterranean. It is known that human traffickers and members of the illegal immigration branch profit from illegal immigration. These networks pose a major risk to the lives of migrants and a problem for the EU.  Member States have a duty to comply with their international rescue obligations at sea. I believe that a global approach to the migration phenomenon, as well as a constructive assessment of the overall strategy for cooperation with third countries, including sub-Saharan Africa, North Africa and the Middle East, on humanitarian, financial and political assistance, is essential.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — I am glad to have followed this resolution from the very beginning, and glad for the LIBE Committee to focus on the Mediterranean as it is crucial that the momentum on this discussion is kept up on the European Parliament level. This resolution sets out the need for the EU to adopt a more holistic approach to migration, something which I have been harping on throughout previous plenary sessions. This resolution mentions a number of actions including legal entry systems; co-operation with third countries; more consistency between EU migration, development and foreign policies. This resolution can also give the tools needed to push Parliament into taking an ambitious step forward and finally examining all the interconnected areas of migration. Hence I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The management of migration flows in Europe is one of the main concerns of European citizens. With this resolution, we call for more solidarity between Member States, whether for the management of asylum applications or for the various operations to strengthen border controls. But we also call on the European Commission to listen to our demands for a strengthening of the Frontex agency, which is essential for the protection of external borders. A recent report by the Office of the High Commissioner for Refugees reported that nearly 3,500 migrants have died in the Mediterranean since the beginning of the year. In the face of this tragedy, let us act without further delay!

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. — At least 3,419 migrants have lost their lives in the Mediterranean Sea since January. With conflicts in Libya, Syria and Iraq, Europe has become the main destination for migrants by sea and the Mediterranean has become the "deadliest road in the world." I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I believe that the European Union must show greater solidarity with the Member States that receive the greatest number of refugees and asylum seekers and, at the same time, take the right share of responsibility for immigration in order to prevent further loss of life at sea.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. If there is one major question that requires a common European answer, it is the question of migration. It is really time for the Heads of State and Government to move forward to build a common immigration policy that must be based on four pillars. The first is real security and real surveillance - and protection - of our external borders, by air, by land, by sea with, among others, European coastguards. The second point is the corollary of this: we must have a regulated right of entry into the European Union with, why not, country quotas on immigration. The third point is probably the most urgent: we need a harmonisation of our right to asylum. We can no longer continue with delays of six months to five years depending on the country to get an answer. This is not reasonable. Fourth point: of course we need a development policy, a real partnership with the countries of origin and a foreign policy that contributes to the stability of the countries around us.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. — Dear Mr President, honourable Members, I supported the resolution because the situation in the Mediterranean caused by the huge migratory pressure is extremely worrying and severe. The so-called Arab Spring, funded and organized by global oil lobbies and intelligence agencies, has collapsed countries and ignited civil wars in Syria, Iraq, Egypt and Libya, allowing for a wide field of expression for extreme Islamic extremists from IS. This terrorist organization, funded and organized by Qatar, Saudi Arabia and Turkey, has taken terrorist action against Christians, Kurds, Yazidis, Shiites and other religious and ethnic communities that have lived peacefully in these territories for millennia.  This unheard-of terror of the Middle Ages forced hundreds of thousands of people to seek salvation in emigration. Separately, poverty, crime, lack of perspective, social decay and, most importantly, the "European welfare" is pushing hundreds of thousands of people from Africa towards the EU's borders. EU border countries are facing a tsunami of refugees and illegal migrants. The tension on these borders is growing enormously. There are days when the Bulgarian border is crossed illegally by hundreds of illegal migrants transferred from the Turkish state, in blatant violation of all international rules and agreements. The Bulgarian state cannot withstand this organizational and social burden. I insist on real, real European solidarity on the subject.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted against motion for a resolution B8-0362/2014, because the reasons for illegal immigration should also have been considered. Furthermore, I am opposed to the funding available for the implementation of migrant resettlement programmes in the Member States of the European Union.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: in writing. - I fully support the conclusion of the resolution to task the LIBE committee with conducting an assessment of the current policies of asylum and migration, including additional resources to perform this task.  However, I abstained in the final vote because the text also calls for swift processing. in collaboration with third countries of transit and origin, and of return for those who do not qualify for asylum and protection in the EU. This effectively means that decisions on asylum claims are prejudiced, thereby seriously undermining the whole asylum system. Processing of any claim for asylum should never be done in collaboration with the country of origin.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. — More than a year ago, following the Lampedusa tragedy, the EP adopted a Resolution on migration flows in the Mediterranean and the Council would set up a panel. Several Commission communications followed. Last month, the Council was taking steps to better manage migration flows and, in the past plenary, we expressed the need for a comprehensive EU approach to migration. Nevertheless, deaths have continued to occur and the desired shift in approach to immigration, a victim of a negative look that obviates the opportunities it offers and does not give alternatives to legal immigration, is not appreciated.  This Resolution sets out the elements that a comprehensive approach should contain and calls on the LIBE Commission for a strategic report on the subject. It also raises questions such as the exercise of solidarity and the equitable sharing of the burden imposed by Article 80 TFEU, obligations on rescue and mafia control, extension of Frontex's mandate, establishment of safe routes for immigration, improvement of resettlement and improvement of policies and management of immigration funds. That is why I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — This resolution insists on supporting an immigration policy that is responsible for the deaths of thousands of people in the Mediterranean, mostly young people seeking to flee wars, crime, unemployment, poverty and hunger, in the search for better living conditions for themselves and their families, despite the risks of crossing.
