Strengthening border and security policy and defending the improvement of FRONTEX's future role makes clear the intention to maintain and deepen a policy that has transformed the EU into a fortress where, in order to arrive, immigrants must submit to trafficking and criminal networks that proliferate in the shadow of repression and criminalisation of immigrants. And it insists on the direction of establishing agreements with transit or home countries to carry out the dirty role of repression and the impediment of arrival in the EU.  The defence of the deepening of these policies by the right and social democracy makes it possible to foresee the limits of the possible establishment of a committee of inquiry. We voted against it.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing — According to the International Organisation for Migration, more than 3000 people died in the Mediterranean in the first nine months of 2014. In addition, some reports speak of around 500 migrants killed after human traffickers attacked and sunk a boat to transport migrants from Egypt to the European Union. Italy's Rescue and Observation Operation Mare Nostrum has rescued more than 150 000 migrants in 364 days, but the Italian Government is no longer able to finance this operation on its own and it is now unclear what member states' contributions to Joint Operation Triton will be. It is therefore essential that the European Union redistributes responsibility and solidarity fairly to the Member States that are exposed to the highest number of refugees and asylum seekers.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — (IT) The resolution is not controversial and, on the contrary, goes in the direction we want a global approach, not just an Italian one, to the issue of immigration. I shall vote in favour, although it will most probably be absolutely useless, as this will be yet another appeal without a real response from the Member States.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — I am against motion for a resolution B8-0362/2014, because the reasons for illegal immigration should also have been considered. In addition, I am voting against the funding available for the implementation of migrant resettlement programmes in the Member States of the European Union.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it demonstrates our strong commitment and willingness to actively participate in the Commission's work on the renewal of the internal security strategy. This resolution emphasizes full compliance with the Charter of Fundamental Rights. While the safety of all people living in the Union is a priority, it cannot be ensured at the expense of their most basic rights. We also stress in this resolution the importance of identifying and combating new threats, including human trafficking, for which a comprehensive and integrated approach is needed. Finally, we recall the need to ensure consistency between the internal and external dimensions of security that are inextricably linked, as well as synergy between the various instruments at our disposal, particularly in the area of justice and home affairs and the common foreign and security policy.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the motion for a Resolution on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a holistic EU approach to represent a humanitarian drama that the EU must face to prevent a repeat of tragedies such as Lampedusa's. According to the International Organization for Migration in the first nine months of 2014, at least 3,072 people have died in the Mediterranean Sea while trying to reach the shores of Europe. We must put all our determination to end smugglers and human traffickers who exploit irregular immigration and pose a serious risk to the lives of migrants. The EU must be aware that irregular immigration is a problem affecting the whole Union, so it is essential to take a holistic approach to this problem. States should provide Frontex with the necessary means and work closely together for good control of EU borders, especially in the Mediterranean Sea. Similarly, further cooperation with countries of origin and transit is essential in order to address the causes of migration.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. — More than a year ago, following the Lampedusa tragedy, the EP adopted a Resolution on migration flows in the Mediterranean and the Council would set up a panel. Several Commission communications followed. Last month, the Council was taking steps to better manage migration flows and, in the past plenary, we expressed the need for a comprehensive EU approach to migration. Nevertheless, deaths have continued to occur and the desired shift in approach to immigration, a victim of a negative look that obviates the opportunities it offers and does not give alternatives to legal immigration, is not appreciated.  This Resolution sets out the elements that a comprehensive approach should contain and calls on the LIBE Commission for a strategic report on the subject. It also raises questions such as the exercise of solidarity and the equitable sharing of the burden imposed by Article 80 TFEU, obligations on rescue and mafia control, extension of Frontex's mandate, establishment of safe routes for immigration, improvement of resettlement and improvement of policies and management of immigration funds. That is why I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. — I strongly support this motion for a resolution because of its importance in favour of a Union strategy on immigration and for trying to prevent tragedies in the Mediterranean Sea. It highlights the elements that a comprehensive approach should contain, such as the importance of enhancing safe and legal routes of entry into the European Union (EU), the need to pay more attention to the criminal activity of smugglers, and the possibility of strengthening resettlement. It is also emphasized that the EU must share equal responsibility and solidarity towards Member States receiving the largest number of refugees and asylum seekers; the Union must ensure safe and legal access to its asylum system and explore legal immigration routes. The Civil Liberties Commission will need to analyse the various immigration policies in the EU and make recommendations which it will include in a strategic report it will present by the end of 2015.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this motion for resolution because a holistic approach to EU migration is disgracefully long overdue. President Juncker promised us yesterday the Commission would increase coordination and effectiveness in its work. The fact that over 3 500 people lost their lives this year trying to cross the Mediterranean is why it should lose no time fulfilling this promise. What we need is coordinated internal and external policies, and I am sad to say the idea of a migration policy that lowers the burden on both migrants and EU citizens seems to be lost on many governments, including the UK’s: how can we stop our citizens’ wages being undercut if prosecutions for illegal exploitation of migrant workers by gangmasters have dropped by 84%? Meanwhile, an additional 200 million people could be displaced due to climate change by 2050, yet some parties in the UK and elsewhere are trying to block the adoption of strong targets to tackle global warming. If we want to move forward on solving issues related to migration, a smart, coordinated and humane approach is the only way to go.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - I voted against it because the text does not address a number of crucial issues to address the dramatic and desperate situation in the Mediterranean that migrants trying to reach Europe live in. On the one hand, it is not agreed to launch a commission of inquiry, which is a priority for me. The text speaks of providing more resources for audiences and ad hoc delegations, which means an investment of those resources to have a theoretical approach through experts, but the creation of a commission of inquiry is not specified. On the other hand, the role of Frontex, which has been shown to have not served to curb the deaths of migrants in the Mediterranean, is emphasized. More police resources only criminalize migrants and do not recognise the shared responsibility of EU Member States and African countries. The idea of Europe as a fortress is therefore entrenched.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. — On Wednesday morning, I voted in favour of a European Parliament resolution on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a comprehensive approach to the issue of migration on the part of the European Union. According to the International Organization for Migration, 3,072 people died in the Mediterranean in the first nine months of 2014, illustrating once again that it is imperative that each Member State carry out its search and rescue operations in accordance with our moral and international obligations. However, I would like to stress that the European Union must also strengthen control of its borders in order to avoid, in particular, air calls which most often lead to dramatic situations.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in the Mediterranean and on the need for a comprehensive approach to the issue of migration on the part of the Union. While the European Commission and the Council have presented a series of actions to be taken, notably in the context of the Task Force for the Mediterranean, it is essential that Parliament adopts a more proactive strategy, does not merely react to the various commission communications or to the Council Conclusions, but affirms in the migration debate its role as a force for proposals. Building on the results and recommendations of this investigative work, Parliament must propose another migration policy for Europe that addresses these issues in a comprehensive and cross-cutting approach that includes: legal routes of migration, whether existing or to be promoted, effective access to asylum procedures and the development of alternatives for people seeking international protection, as well as a renewed partnership with third countries on the basis of equal cooperation and mutual interaction. profitable. In any case, it is the impetus and the reorientation that we socialists intend to defend in the European Parliament.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. — More than a year ago, following the Lampedusa tragedy, the EP adopted a Resolution on migration flows in the Mediterranean and the Council would set up a panel. Several Commission communications followed. Last month, the Council was taking steps to better manage migration flows and, in the past plenary, we expressed the need for a comprehensive EU approach to migration. Nevertheless, deaths have continued to occur and the desired shift in approach to immigration, a victim of a negative look that obviates the opportunities it offers and does not give alternatives to legal immigration, is not appreciated.  This Resolution sets out the elements that a comprehensive approach should contain and calls on the LIBE Commission for a strategic report on the subject. It also raises questions such as the exercise of solidarity and the equitable sharing of the burden imposed by Article 80 TFEU, obligations on rescue and mafia control, extension of Frontex's mandate, establishment of safe routes for immigration, improvement of resettlement and improvement of policies and management of immigration funds. That is why I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. — MEPs adopted a resolution on the situation in the Mediterranean on Wednesday calling for a comprehensive approach to migration. This resolution is a good initiative, but I regret that no significant progress has been made since the adoption of the European Pact for Immigration and Asylum, of which I was the architect in 2008. Since the pact, which had federated governments of the right, the left, including communist, what major initiatives have been carried out? I welcome the adoption of this resolution, which reiterates the urgent need to develop a comprehensive approach to better manage migration flows. However, this call from the European Parliament also reveals that Europe is now more in reaction than in action. The resolution proposes a fair distribution of responsibilities and more solidarity with the Member States receiving the largest number of refugees and asylum seekers, the financial and operational reinforcement of Frontex, a comprehensive strategy of cooperation with third countries, particularly in the area of resettlement and return, the penalisation of human trafficking and illegal immigration.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - I voted against it because the text does not address a number of crucial issues to address the dramatic and desperate situation in the Mediterranean that migrants trying to reach Europe live in. On the one hand, it is not agreed to launch a commission of inquiry, which is a priority for me. The text speaks of providing more resources for audiences and ad hoc delegations, which means an investment of those resources to have a theoretical approach through experts, but the creation of a commission of inquiry is not specified. On the other hand, the role of Frontex, which has been shown to have not served to curb the deaths of migrants in the Mediterranean, is emphasized. More police resources only criminalize migrants and do not recognise the shared responsibility of EU Member States and African countries. The idea of Europe as a fortress is therefore entrenched.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for the European Parliament's resolution on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a holistic EU approach to migration, as work needs to be done to address problems in the Mediterranean where there are major losses of human lives at sea.  I believe that the European Union and all Member States need to respond adequately and in a timely manner and impose strict sanctions on trafficking and human smuggling in the EU. Some Member States accept the largest number of refugees and asylum seekers, so the EU should take some responsibility and solidarity against them. I believe that border policy needs to be strengthened while protecting human rights for all migrants and ensuring safe and legal access to the European Union's asylum system.  Given the importance of the Mediterranean for the whole of Europe, I strongly support a holistic approach to migration and a necessary common strategy.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in the Mediterranean. In particular, the text calls for a fair distribution of responsibilities, greater solidarity with the Member States receiving the largest number of refugees and asylum seekers, and heavy criminal sanctions against human trafficking and illegal immigration. The resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: in writing. — EH Bildu voted against the Motion for a Resolution on the situation in the Mediterranean Sea and the need for a comprehensive Union approach to migration because this proposal expressly reinforces the role of the European frontex agency as guardian of the Union's external borders. In other words, it perpetuates the european Union's conception as a fortress and perceives the arrival of people seeking a better future and/or fleeing political, armed, or humanitarian crises as a matter of security, that is, as a threat. The EU aims to require third countries to respect basic principles which it itself certainly does not always apply, such as saving lives at sea, ensuring the protection of refugees and respecting fundamental rights.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. — Faced with the repetition of the human tragedies related to illegal immigration in the Mediterranean, the European response has long been delayed. I therefore welcome the vote on this resolution, which insists on a fair distribution of responsibilities and more solidarity with the Member States receiving the largest number of refugees and asylum seekers. It was also important to advocate the financial and operational strengthening of Frontex and the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) but also to call for heavy criminal sanctions against human trafficking and illegal immigration. In addition, the EU must engage in a comprehensive strategy of cooperation with third countries on aid, co-development and repression to discourage illegal immigration.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I supported the resolution as it can help the European Parliament to lay the foundations for a more proactive and flexible EU migration policy. The EU urgently needs to develop and safeguard legal routes into the EU for refugees and asylum seekers on the one hand, and for economic migrants on the other, as well as tackling criminal smugglers and human traffickers in the field of migration.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. - There is not a single word about the real causes and origins of migration, perhaps because then it would be necessary to reveal who, why and by what means they support the start of colour revolutions. Interestingly, African refugees did not flock to Italy as long as the Libyan leader was in place. The latest EU idea is for my country to take in as many refugees as possible from the south-west, while we are also not winning the supply of those brought directly to us by people smugglers. For this reason, the resolution is clearly unsupvocable. Our government should also act effectively to end the unsustainable situation.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: in writing. — (IT) The broad support of this House for the resolution confirms the need to develop a global approach to migration. It is our responsibility to ensure safe and legal access to the asylum system in our territories, while also trying to find new channels of legal migration. We have seen an exponential increase in deaths in the Mediterranean in recent years and have therefore called, in our full voice, for every effort to be made to prevent further tragedies at sea. Operation Mare Nostrum has been commendable and recognised by all Member States; On the other hand, the joint operation 'Triton' remains nebulous to most of us, both in terms of means and resources and in terms of mandate. We have also made it necessary for search and rescue obligations to be effectively met and for appropriate funding to be allocated for this purpose in the medium and long term. In the light of the recent scandals over the use of funds, including European funds, for emergency management, in particular for actions relating to migration and asylum, we have asked for a careful analysis of how these funds are spent, also in order to avoid a repetition in the future of scandalous and criminal forms of appropriation against the weakest groups.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour of the report by Mr Beazley on behalf of the Committee on The Claude Moraes because it fully reflects the idea that the European Union should implement a series of measures aimed at defining a holistic approach to the problem of illegal migration. Today's vote makes it clear that the position we have taken in recent months is widely shared by our fellow MEPs. The management of this policy must be shared between all eu states, and the results achieved during the Italian Presidency are proof of this. We cannot allow organised crime to kill other human beings during the crossings of hope.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: Writing. — The tragedy in Lampedusa revealed the flow and extent of immigration. Therefore, without stopping, we need to talk about legal migration and its ways, the implementation of asylum policy. Firstly, human life and its preservation, and member states must do everything possible to avoid other similar painful deaths at sea. According to the International Organisation for Migration, at least 3 072 people died in the Mediterranean in the first nine months of 2014, and we must do our utmost to reduce these numbers as much as possible and to work together for all Member States to manage migration flows.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. — More than a year ago, following the Lampedusa tragedy, the EP adopted a Resolution on migration flows in the Mediterranean and the Council would set up a panel. Several Commission communications followed. Last month, the Council was taking steps to better manage migration flows and, in the past plenary, we expressed the need for a comprehensive EU approach to migration. Nevertheless, deaths have continued to occur and the desired shift in approach to immigration, a victim of a negative look that obviates the opportunities it offers and does not give alternatives to legal immigration, is not appreciated.  This Resolution sets out the elements that a comprehensive approach should contain and calls on the LIBE Commission for a strategic report on the subject. It also raises questions such as the exercise of solidarity and the equitable sharing of the burden imposed by Article 80 TFEU, obligations on rescue and mafia control, extension of Frontex's mandate, establishment of safe routes for immigration, improvement of resettlement and improvement of policies and management of immigration funds. That is why I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — I have not been able to vote in favour of this motion for a resolution because its objective of giving a mandate to the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs in this House to launch a committee of inquiry into the situation of migration in the Mediterranean has been greatly diluted. But more importantly, the Resolution does not reject the fundamental pillar of EU immigration policy: Frontex. It is a migration policy that is based on a repressive view of it, ignoring the root causes of it: if there is the phenomenon of migration from the countries of the southern Mediterranean to the EU countries it is because from Europe we continue to expose the natural resources of those countries, thus preventing them from economic prosperity and a future for their peoples. If migrants continue to arrive from Africa on our shores, it is because we continue to encourage wars in their countries that push them to abandon them. That is why I voted against this motion for a resolution.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. — The competent committee is tasked with carrying out an analysis of how funds are spent for home affairs, including emergency funds, in particular for actions in the areas of migration and asylum, border control, the fight against border pins and traffickers, and return, as well as funds relating to EU foreign and development policy. And report to the plenary through a strategic initiative report before the end of 2015. Future initiatives should be explored to follow positive examples of resettlement, including the voluntary resettlement programme provided for in Article 17 of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council creating the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund to improve the Union's comprehensive approach to migration and to improve the situation in the Mediterranean Sea. For all these reasons, I welcome this motion for a resolution.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. — (DE) This resolution deals with a tragedy which must be brought to an end. There is no doubt that people in unseaworthy boats need to be rescued. There is also no doubt that the EU and the Mediterranean countries must not lack the resources to ensure this. But it is even more important, and this is a key point that was not sufficiently acknowledged in the resolution, that in future there will be no incentives to enter the EU by sea (and therefore illegally). As long as that hope exists, people will always risk their lives, and we cannot want that. It is therefore necessary to ensure that people apprehended at sea who hope to enter the EU illegally are immediately returned to a safe country outside the EU, from where these people can legally apply to enter the EU.  Only in this way will the flow of refugees by sea safely dry up and only in this way can further tragic deaths be prevented. I abstained on this resolution because this important point was only hinted at in the resolution. However, it is important to speak openly about the uncomfortable truths.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a holistic EU approach to migration. In line with the resolution, I believe that further possibilities for legal migration should be looked at. We must remember that European society is ageing and that there is already a shortage of workers in certain sectors and industries that we are unable to fill. Therefore, migration is, in a sense, an inevitable necessity, which we must use to fill gaps in the European labour market on the one hand and to help migrants seeking support in the European Union on the other. I am pleased that this approach is in line with President Juncker's priorities, which assumes that organising legal migration is in Europe's long-term interest. However, we need urgent action to reduce the tragedy of illegal immigrants trying to get into the Union at all costs and to combat criminal groups, human traffickers organising illegal people smuggling. Cooperation with third countries and transit on the causes of migration, protection, resettlement and return of migrants is also essential in developing a more coherent, comprehensive, coordinated EU approach to migration. The protection of human rights must be a key priority in the EU's cooperation with third countries on migrants' rights. Regardless of the legal status of migrants, all countries should respect their dignity and human rights.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — On the mediterranean situation and the need for a holistic approach, all groups within Parliament have agreed a compromise text that would include important issues such as sanctions on smugglers and human trafficking.  Furthermore, important issues such as defining a clear migration management agreement with third countries and strengthening the border policy of all member states and security in general are also included. The report also includes sections on legal migration and resettlement, followed by sections on the implementation of the Common European Asylum System with possible restrictive infringement procedures.  I supported this Report because I believe that there is a need to address migration and for a holistic approach of the European Union to the current situation. I call for the sharing of responsibilities and solidarity towards the countries receiving the largest number of refugees and asylum seekers, whether in absolute or proportionate conditions.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. — The European Union has long been unable to develop a common policy for migrants fleeing to the EU, most of whom die in the Mediterranean. I spoke to colleagues from Malta: this Member State is the first to accept the waves of migrants and is not able to fight it alone. We must help both the fleeing people, Malta, and develop a policy on legal and illegal immigration to the EU. I voted in favour.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the motions for resolutions on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a holistic EU approach to migration, because it initiates a first approach to the crucial issue of migration flows, despite the considerable reservations I have already expressed in my continued speeches to the plenary of the European Parliament.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — (IT) The tragedy of Lampedusa still weighs like a boulder on the conscience of public opinion and that of the political class. Despite the fact that more than a year has passed since that terrible event, the European Union is still struggling to provide a plausible response to the problem of immigration to the Community's coasts. My support for this resolution is a real act of conscience. It fully reflects the idea that speculation and exploitation linked to migration must be definitively averted, through the implementation of a shared and responsible strategy involving all the Member States of this Union. The resolution accurately reflects the need to act, in a coordinated and responsible manner, in the name of an end to an massacre of which civil society can no longer afford to be complicit. I particularly welcomed the reference in the document to the need to support Member States that take in more refugees and asylum seekers.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — I did not agree with the proposal for a holistic EU approach to migration. Some of the issues that have been developed are not fully thought out and require further review by the relevant committee. The situation in the Mediterranean is tense, but hasty decisions will not contribute to their relaxation.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. "This resolution was the result of a long battle against the right. The aim was not to reproduce the position adopted during the tragic events in Lampedusa, which centred on an exclusively police vision of migration. This time, more resources for the Committee on Migration Policy are obtained. It is proposed to "explore other routes of legal immigration", to ensure the reintegration of migrants or to improve the means of rescue at sea. However, this is no more than the international obligations to which Member States have adhered to require. This resolution seeks to remind us that migrants are victims of human traffickers and smugglers. But it does not remind us that they are also the victims of the EU's aggressive trade policies. I abstain so as not to prevent a text which has the merit of allocating a research mandate and funds to the Committee of Parliament to turn to another migration policy. It's a start.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — The situation in the Mediterranean with regard to immigrants is very worrying and must be addressed in a serious way. We must join forces, the whole EU, to end the deaths in that sea. Only with a comprehensive solution will we be able to be effective.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — As one of the EPP negotiators on this resolution, I voted in favour because it is my belief that the EU should step up its efforts as a whole to fulfil its international obligations. This resolution emphasises the need for a holistic approach to migration by the EU. This is the only way forward. The loss of life in the Mediterranean and the constant exploitation of innocent lives by trafficking networks are unacceptable and we need to step up our efforts in this regard.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. More than 3,000 people lost their lives in the Mediterranean in the first nine months of 2014. We must provide ambitious solutions to ensure that Member States respect their international obligations and save the lives of those at risk. An ambitious approach must be taken at European level to ensure effective control of migration while maintaining a human vision. In this context, it is imperative that the EU allocate additional resources to the European agency Frontex. More broadly, a reflection must be carried out in order to propose as soon as possible concrete actions to create an effective European asylum framework and legal migration routes.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of the resolution on the Situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a holistic EU approach to migration. A new comprehensive European migration policy, reflecting the beneficial power of migration, is a moral, economic and social imperative for the EU.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution. A holistic approach to migration is the only way to respond to the challenge that the EU currently faces on the issue of immigration. Migration flows are a structural problem within the EU.  The control of external borders and asylum policy have a major impact on the human rights of emigrants, and the situation in the Mediterranean reminds us all of this every day. We therefore urge that a new strategy on legal migration be put in place.  In this context, I warmly recommend that consideration be given to the Austrian Government's proposal for distribution, which is based on the principle of solidarity.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. — Migration pressure at Europe's borders has increased at an unprecedented rate since the beginning of the year. The lucrative smuggling channels exploit human misery, as do some unscrupulous employers. The European approach is balanced in the subject, between condemnation of these networks and the need to develop aid for return. Nevertheless, it has demonstrated in practice that the mass arrival of illegal immigrants is perceived as inevitable. The Union imposes on states a responsibility that can no longer be supported by economies already on the brink of social asphyxiation. In addition, the influx of illegal immigrants destabilizes political asylum procedures, which are hijacked for economic reasons. In the end, it is above all necessary to unite the forces of the member countries to fight with means without comparison with what they are today the mafias and show signs of firmness to the candidates for exile. The solution also lies in development aid and the cessation of support for corrupt regimes, more than in naïve and passive welcoming policies. Faced with demographic pressure from the African continent, Europe in recession cannot constantly take in more economic refugees.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The European Union's behaviour in the face of the situation of illegal immigration in the Mediterranean is completely unacceptable. With operations such as "Mare Nostrum" and now "Triton", which aim to recover migrants in the Mediterranean and bring them directly to European soil, the European Union has created an air appeal to applicants for illegal immigration. It also sent a signal of encouragement to unscrupulous smugglers, who do not hesitate to deliberately put boats in poor condition in order for the migrants to be rescued. Like Australia, which has just strengthened its migration policy, solutions must be national and firmly implemented. I obviously voted against this resolution.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. — The EU urgently needs to develop and safeguard legal routes into the EU for refugees and asylum seekers on the one hand, and for economic migrants on the other, as well as addressing the increasingly malevolent role played by criminal smugglers and human traffickers in the field of migration. This resolution lays the foundations for a more proactive and flexible EU migration policy.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. — (IT) We welcome the motion for a resolution calling for a unified approach at European level to immigration and a greater effort to prevent further loss of life at sea. It is now unreliable for all Member States to assume collective responsibility for a phenomenon of impressive proportions, which costs thousands of lives every year and which, until now, has been taken over as a matter of priority by the only European border states, such as Italy. In addition to a new shared approach to migration, we stress the need to examine the overall strategy for cooperation with third countries and the obligation for these countries to respect fundamental rights and ensure the protection of refugees.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a holistic approach by the European Union to the problem of migration. There is a need for a fair distribution of responsibility towards the Member States that receive the highest number of refugees and asylum seekers, and there is also a need to combat trafficking in human beings and establish a system of sanctions against trafficking and smuggling by the Member States.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. — The Mediterranean cannot become a graveyard – as Pope Francis pointed out in his November address to the European Parliament. We must therefore see the issue of migration responsibly in Europe, which is why I welcome the resolution that we have just adopted.  Thousands of people are not in high spirits, so that the good luck, trusting their own lives and those of their families, will reach the much-anticipated EU land. We have to deal with the root of the problems. Imposing heavy sanctions on irresponsible smuggling networks and agreeing concrete steps with the most affected third countries to choose a commonly acceptable and viable path. In the common migration policy, only human rights can be the policy. It is necessary to prevent criminal gangs from torturing people for profit, enslaving and, in many cases, killing. The EU needs a new, strong strategy, with all Member States able to line up and spread the burden of work responsibly among themselves.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. In the context of the plight of migration in the Mediterranean, this resolution is mainly aimed at setting up a commission of inquiry and invokes the need for more solidarity and responsibility on the part of the Member States of the Union. There is indeed an urgent need to improve the Union's sea rescue capabilities in order to prevent the Mediterranean from continuing to serve as a huge graveyard for refugees. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal because the European Union and the Member States must do their u to prevent the deaths of people at sea as refugees. More than 3,000 people have died in the Mediterranean in the first nine months of this year alone. A long-term action plan should be developed and security policy in the region should also be reviewed. Migration and asylum issues must also be seriously addressed.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. — The European Parliament resolution on the situation in the Mediterranean and the EU's migration policy seeks to strengthen the common anti-immigration policy of the EU and governments, frontex enforcement forces, by further funding it from the Member States. This policy has already led to the deaths of thousands of migrants and refugees, who, in their quest to escape poverty, hunger and imperialist interventions by the US, the EU and NATO in their home countries, are confronted with human trafficking rings and repressive forces. The increasing waves of migration are the result of imperialist interventions to control the resources and transport routes of energy, the capital's needs for a wealthy labour force.  We demand immediate measures here and now to accommodate, accommodate and relieve migrants and refugees; abolition of concentration camps and Dublin II and III regulations; travel documents to those wishing to move to other countries.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a comprehensive EU approach to migration, as I believe that migration promotes contact between different ethnic groups, religions and cultures. In the past, cultural differences between the two shores of the Mediterranean were perceived as a wealth that led to mutual contamination. Today, however, the Mediterranean is seen only as a border to be patrolled in order to prevent the risks of irregular and disorderly immigration. Migration should instead be seen as an opportunity, because there is a risk of demographic decline in european countries and the high birth rate of the populations on the southern shore of the Mediterranean is a wealth for Europe because it would make it possible to bridge the imbalance in our demographic pyramid. Europe needs immigrant labour because of its increasingly old demographic structure.  Concerted action is needed to make the most of the opportunity for migration. The burden must not be borne solely by the Member States at Europe's borders: an effective revision of the Dublin Agreement is necessary in order to overcome the individualistic approach which does not facilitate cooperation.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — (IT) Reiterating the importance of these policies in the Mediterranean and the need for a definitive solution, I am only in favour of the text if the amendments proposed by my group are accepted.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. — I supported the resolution on the situation in the Mediterranean and welcome the impetus it gives to further the European Union's holistic approach to the migration problem.   The International Organisation for Migration figures show that more than 3,000 immigrants lost their lives in the Mediterranean Sea this year, more than double the number of lives lost in a record 2011. In 2014, it became "the most devastating year for the Mediterranean" where the very most people died at the gates of the European Union seeking a better life.   I would like to reiterate Pope Francis' call during his visit to the European Parliament in November that "we must not allow the Mediterranean coast to become a great graveyard", and it is necessary to act decisively to prevent and repeat such human tragedies.  This long-lasting and complex challenge requires activity, both at Eu and Member State level, against trafficking and trafficking in human beings and criminal networks, ensuring the swift and sustainable return of immigrants in a human and dignified manner, and ensuring their right of access to the European asylum system, but also strengthening the management of the EU's external borders.  In particular, I call for support and solidarity with the Member States that accept the largest number of refugees and asylum seekers, thus facing a lot of pressure.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — I supported the Resolution of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a holistic EU approach to migration. The European Parliament's october 2013 session was marked by the tragedy in Lampedusa and a debate with the European Commission on how to improve refugee admissions to the EU and how Europe's migration policy needs to be changed. Many immigrants fleeing war zones continue to put pressure on Southeast European countries, and according to the United Nations, the number of people leaving their homelands in boats is increasing by the day. The alarming situation and tragic scenes with at least 3,072 deaths in the Mediterranean Sea in the first nine months of 2014 require a decisive and holistic approach to the European Union's migration policy, covering a wide range of topics, a strong interaction between the internal and external dimensions of EU policies, and cooperation between all actors within the EU institutions, Member States and third countries (transit countries and countries of origin). In particular, I welcome the imposition of severe criminal sanctions for trafficking and trafficking in human beings, and a recommendation on improving the role and actions of Frontex and Operation Triton. Protecting borders and protecting lives through the European External Border Control System is a key challenge for the EU.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — (IT) I welcome the resolution on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a holistic approach by the EU to the migration problem. It is a balanced text which we decided in the LIBE Committee following a constructive debate to which I have contributed.  The approach is humanitarian and pragmatic: the principle of solidarity and the fair distribution of responsibility to the Member States receiving the highest number of refugees and asylum seekers in absolute or relative terms are called for. I share my doubts about the joint 'Triton' operation coordinated by Frontex and operational since 1 November 2014, because it is not clear how Member States' contributions and exact competences are established. There is a need to combat trafficking in human beings and to establish a system of sanctions by Member States against trafficking and smuggling, as well as the need to establish cooperation with third countries affected by migration, in order to try to identify together the right return and asylum strategies. Finally – and it is important to emphasise this – there is a proposal to find concrete solutions in the field of resettlement, including flow management agreements.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Writing. — Not only, but particularly through the events before Lampedusa, the European public has been made clear that illegal migration leads to human tragedies. This is primarily due to the inhumane smuggling gangs, who take their last money from the people and take them across the Mediterranean in the most risky circumstances. But it is also the responsibility of those groups which, through their speeches, give the impression that Europe is capable of providing adequate care for thousands of economic migrants. It is bad enough that people want to leave their country because of economic difficulties. It must be said, however, that this is not and cannot be a reason for asylum. Because of the current wars in the Arab world – especially Syria – the EU must take in many people who truly deserve asylum. As long as governments open up emergency shelters to people without grounds for asylum, war refugees and persecuted people will continue to be unable to find the necessary protection in Europe that they need.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — The tragedies unfolding in the Mediterranean need to be the subject of more attention by the European Union, which must strengthen the coordinated action of its Member States. I therefore welcome this resolution, which also calls for an increase in Frontex's financial resources and the Union's cooperation with third countries on this issue.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — The different conflicts in the Middle East have intensified migration flows to the Member States of the European Union, and the various shipwreck dramas in the Mediterranean have warned of the outstanding humanitarian situation (more than 3000 killed in 2014). Considering that the Italian rescue operation, called Mare Nostrum, will be phased out and the contributions to the joint Triton operation are uncertain, it is important to reiterate the need for a coordinated policy at European level (through FRONTEX and THE EAsA) and, it is also important, that the EU takes its share of responsibility and solidarity with the Member States hosting the largest number of refugees. Similarly, voluntary return policies must be encouraged, while ensuring the protection of the rights of all migrants and providing safe and legal access to the EU asylum system. Finally, it is necessary to consider an analysis of how funds for home affairs are spent in this context, in particular in the fight against smuggling and trafficking. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution which calls for parliament to draw up, and before the end of 2015, a strategic own-initiative report.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. — On the eve of International Migrants Day, the European Parliament adopted a resolution on the situation in the Mediterranean which defends the need for a comprehensive European approach to migration. According to the UN High Commission for Refugees, the Mediterranean has become the deadliest road in the world for migrants. This sad finding calls for an urgent and coordinated response from the European Union and its Member States. MEPs defend a coherent and supportive migration policy, a more humane and protective policy towards migrants and asylum seekers. To avoid further loss of life, it is not enough to devote more resources to controlling our borders and combating organised crime. The awareness of European states must mainly involve greater financial commitments for search and rescue at sea and for the reception of migrants. Ensuring safe routes for refugees and asylum seekers to Europe and opening new legal channels of migration will also improve the situation in the long term. Faced with the challenge of migration, Europe must finally give itself all the means to succeed.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — More than a year ago, following the Lampedusa tragedy, the EP adopted a Resolution on migration flows in the Mediterranean and the Council would set up a panel. Several Commission communications followed. Last month, the Council was taking steps to better manage migration flows and, in the past plenary, we expressed the need for a comprehensive EU approach to migration. Nevertheless, deaths have continued to occur and the desired shift in approach to immigration, a victim of a negative look that obviates the opportunities it offers and does not give alternatives to legal immigration, is not appreciated.  This Resolution sets out the elements that a comprehensive approach should contain and calls on the LIBE Commission for a strategic report on the subject. It also raises questions such as the exercise of solidarity and the equitable sharing of the burden imposed by Article 80 TFEU, obligations on rescue and mafia control, extension of Frontex's mandate, establishment of safe routes for immigration, improvement of resettlement and improvement of policies and management of immigration funds. That is why I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - I voted against it because the text does not address a number of crucial issues to address the dramatic and desperate situation in the Mediterranean that migrants trying to reach Europe live in. On the one hand, it is not agreed to launch a commission of inquiry, which is a priority for me. The text speaks of providing more resources for audiences and ad hoc delegations, which means an investment of those resources to have a theoretical approach through experts, but the creation of a commission of inquiry is not specified. On the other hand, the role of Frontex, which has been shown to have not served to curb the deaths of migrants in the Mediterranean, is emphasized. More police resources only criminalize migrants and do not recognise the shared responsibility of EU Member States and African countries. The idea of Europe as a fortress is therefore entrenched.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — I voted for this resolution which calls for a comprehensive European approach in terms of migration and more efforts and financial and human resources to prevent further deaths at sea... at least 3,072 people lost their lives in the Mediterranean in the first nine months of 2014! I believe that the European Union should take more responsibility and show more solidarity with the Member States that receive the largest number of refugees and asylum seekers. This necessary solidarity, which I advocate and defend, also implies making a sufficient contribution to the budgets and operations of the European Border Control Agency, Frontex, and the European Asylum Office.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — I think it seems to me that there is a broad approach to migration, in particular economic migration and very specifically to migration routes through southern Europe, whether in the Mediterranean (including the Adriatic), via the Anatolian Peninsula or through the European Atlantic Islands. I would therefore stress the relevance of this oral question and the content of this resolution, which I voted in favour of leaving my congratulations to the rapporteur at the outheably. Given the rapid and frightening development of the situation, immediate action is required from the European Commission and the Member States, so I would like to underline the inclusion in the Commission's 2015 Work Programme of chapter A European agenda on migration, which aims to develop a new approach to legal migration to make the EU an attractive destination for talent and skills and improve the management of migration flows to the EU through a greater cooperation with third countries, solidarity between Member States and the fight against trafficking in human beings, as can be read in the text presented by the Commission here in Strasbourg on the 16th and which I now hope will be implemented in the coming year.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. — I supported this resolution, which is a first step towards a comprehensive European Union approach to the situation in the Mediterranean and the issue of migration. This comprehensive approach to migration will allow for a fair distribution of responsibilities and more solidarity with the Member States receiving the largest number of refugees and asylum seekers. It is also a matter of setting up a comprehensive strategy for cooperation with third countries and strengthening the funding and operation of the Frontex agency as well as the European Asylum Support Office. I welcome the adoption of this resolution; this comprehensive approach will affect all European citizens and could contribute in particular to the resolution of the situation in Calais.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. — I voted against it because the text does not address a number of crucial issues to address the dramatic and desperate situation in the Mediterranean that migrants trying to reach Europe live in. On the one hand, it is not agreed to launch a commission of inquiry, which is a priority for me. The text speaks of providing more resources for audiences and ad hoc delegations, which means an investment of those resources to have a theoretical approach through experts, but the creation of a commission of inquiry is not specified. On the other hand, the role of Frontex, which has been shown to have not served to curb the deaths of migrants in the Mediterranean, is emphasized. More police resources only criminalize migrants and do not recognise the shared responsibility of EU Member States and African countries. The idea of Europe as a fortress is therefore entrenched.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I have not been able to vote in favour of this motion for a resolution because its objective of giving a mandate to the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs in this House to launch a committee of inquiry into the situation of migration in the Mediterranean has been greatly diluted. But more importantly, the Resolution does not reject the fundamental pillar of EU immigration policy: Frontex. It is a migration policy that is based on a repressive view of it, ignoring the root causes of it: if there is the phenomenon of migration from the countries of the southern Mediterranean to the EU countries it is because from Europe we continue to expose the natural resources of those countries, thus preventing them from economic prosperity and a future for their peoples. If migrants continue to arrive from Africa on our shores, it is because we continue to encourage wars in their countries that push them to abandon them. That is why I voted against this motion for a resolution.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. — I supported this resolution because I believe that the European Union is obliged to protect human life and to be an example of the dignified treatment of refugees. More than 23,000 dead and missing migrants since 2000 are a tragic indicator of the need to establish an effective prevention mechanism. The greatest prevention strategies should be developed in the Mediterranean, given the fact that eight out of ten such tragic deaths occur at sea.  We must act in solidarity and compassion because the value of human life must not be determined by limits. The worrying number of migrants in Italy, Greece and Malta concerns not only these countries, but the entire European Union, and a fair distribution of responsibilities among members is a step towards achieving a sustainable migrant and asylum policy of the European Union. For this reason, I think Europe needs mechanisms to help refugees such as the Italian operation Mare Nostrum, which has rescued over 150,000 refugees in the Mediterranean.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing - What is happening as a result of the conflict in Syria, which happened near Lampedusa, that more than 3000 people died in the Mediterranean in nine months in 2014, that around 500 migrants were murdered after human traffickers apparently attacked and deliberately sunk a boat, I voted in favour of adopting the resolution. I consider the adoption of the resolution to be urgent and it is high time to make every effort to save the lives of people in danger and to prevent further loss of life at sea. In addition to the challenges that Frontex will face, I expect measures to be taken to ensure a common European asylum system, and I also expect a review of the overall strategy for cooperation with third countries in order to address the root causes of migration. The situation in the Mediterranean leaves no one indifferent, so I am glad that the Commission's priorities for 2015 include tackling migrants.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: in writing. - (IT) The resolution is born in a very difficult political and institutional context: the post-Stockholm Council programme and the initiatives proposed by the Commission focus on combating irregular immigration. Given the recent adoption of the asylum package (2013), there are no instruments or initiatives to review its shortcomings. It is at this point that several political groups (GUE/NGL, ALDE, S&D, GREENS and the 5 stars in the EFDD) have conceived the idea of a resolution on the Mediterranean that allows fundamental reflection on immigration and asylum issues, not just waiting for the (very weak or absent) reforms proposed by the Commission. The idea is to give the European Parliament real 'proactive' power in this area, giving the LIBE Commission a leading role and the financial resources to be able to play it. Hence the crucial importance of paragraph 12 of the motion: it is the paragraph that guarantees this role of Parliament and the LIBE Commission and it is the real objective that I think was worth achieving. I therefore voted abstaining, in view of the fact that the necessary saving of the paragraph still led to some heavy compromises with the PPE and the ECR.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — I support this resolution. Every year more and more people are trying to reach Europe. The situation of migration in the Mediterranean is one of the most important issues at the moment for the entire European Union. Because of our inappropriate attitude towards immigrants, both real and normative, we are witnessing major human accidents and irreparable losses.  In addition to the problem of migration, we also link the problems of the fight against human trafficking and smuggling. Therefore, immigration programmes should focus on respect for human dignity and on effectively addressing these issues based on solidarity and accountability. Some Member States bear a heavy burden on the migration problem, mainly countries with access to the sea, and these differences should also be taken into account when regulating this issue. The solution would be to prescribe different conditions for different Member States, depending on the situations in each country. While the European Union has developed mechanisms for addressing these problems, such as the European Asylum Support Office, and many agencies provide guidance and financial solidarity, there is room for improvement.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — I supported the resolution on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a comprehensive approach by the European Union on the issue of migration. It is necessary for the Union to strengthen solidarity and a fair sharing of responsibilities towards the Member States which receive the largest number of refugees and asylum seekers, both in absolute and relative terms, in accordance with Article 80 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. — My vote has been favourable as I believe that the EU-fortress migration policy must be changed immediately. That is why I am in favour of increasing efforts to solve problems in home societies.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of this report because it is important to develop a comprehensive approach to migration, strengthening the fair distribution of responsibilities and solidarity with the Member States that receive the largest number of refugees and asylum seekers. The EU and its Member States must make every effort to prevent further tragedies at sea and it is necessary to provide appropriate funding for search and rescue activities. It is essential to examine a possible comprehensive strategy for cooperation with third countries, in particular those of sub-Saharan Africa and the Middle East, with regard to humanitarian assistance, and an analysis of how funds are spent on actions relating to migration and asylum, border control, the fight against migrant trafficking and trafficking in human beings. , is essential in order to successfully target the Union's resources. Strict sanctions must be established against trafficking in human beings and migrants, both within and within the European Union, as well as against people or groups who exploit vulnerable migrants, finding new channels of legal migration.  For the reasons described, I therefore supported the report.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. — In the first nine months of 2014 at least 3 072 persons have died in the Mediterranean Sea according to the International Organisation for Migration. This statistic is unacceptable as it stands in stark contrast to our shared values and human rights within Europe. With this is in mind I voted in favour of this resolution as it stresses the need to examine the overall strategy on cooperation with third countries and ensure that resources are best utilised for those who require protection.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. " More and more migrants are dying in the Mediterranean. This year is one of the most dire in this regard: more than 3,200 people have died while crossing to Europe.  We can therefore only welcome the fact that several political groups in the European Parliament have mobilised to try to call for a commission of inquiry to take stock of this situation and propose a number of responses to this tragedy.  Unfortunately, the right of the Chamber has engaged in indecent blackmail to limit the scope of this resolution, trying to limit it always to the same rengaines: more cooperation with third countries, more return and readmission, strengthening the mandate of Frontex (and therefore ever more closing of borders). This resolution is therefore not as ambitious as we had requested, but it will allow further reflection in the European Parliament on these issues, in particular by giving more resources to its Committee on Civil Liberties.  By our abstention, we therefore wished to denounce this overly restrictive vision, while demonstrating our willingness to continue the work and the fight against these deadly policies.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — This resolution does not take a step back in its support for an EU immigration policy that is responsible for the deaths of thousands of people in the Mediterranean, mostly young people seeking to flee wars, crime, unemployment, poverty and hunger, in the search for better living conditions for themselves and their families, despite the risks of crossing.  The strengthening of FRONTEX makes clear the intention to maintain and deepen a policy that has transformed the EU into a fortress, where, in order to arrive, immigrants must submit to trafficking and criminal networks that proliferate in the shadow of repression and criminalisation of immigrants. And it insists on the direction of establishing agreements with transit or home countries to carry out the dirty role of repression and the impediment of arrival in the EU.  The defence of the deepening of these policies makes it possible to foresee the limits of the possible establishment of a committee of inquiry in the EP. It would be naïve to assume that the same majority who treat immigrants as criminals could lead a commission of inquiry into the establishment of different conclusions. Hence our vote against.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — The situation in the Mediterranean is extremely tragic because of the victims, who were knowingly put in danger, particularly by traffickers and smugglers, and who had to pay for it with death. Nevertheless, the strategy mentioned here, especially the further legal possibility of immigration, is to be firmly rejected, as it does not solve the problem in the first place. Since we also want to find ways of simply declaring the Dublin II Agreement null and void, and for the reasons mentioned above, I voted against this proposal.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution. A holistic EU approach to migration is urgently needed, because the longer we do not respond adequately, the more people die in the Mediterranean. We must not watch as people enter the hands of smugglers in desperation and drown right outside our borders. The demands, such as the call for solidarity in the distribution of refugees among member states, are urgently needed steps to achieve a swift, holistic approach by the EU. At the same time, there is a need to ensure long-term funding. Competent authorities and organisations must be provided with sufficient resources by the Member States for their operations. There is also a need for a different policy of action towards Africa and the Middle East. New forms of policy towards the countries of origin and a north-south political strategy for Europe are needed. We must react and find quick solutions to the dramatic situation.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. — (IT) With this resolution, the European Union seems to want at last to take note of the tragic situation regarding migratory flows in the Mediterranean Sea, which in the first nine months of 2014 alone has swallowed up at least three thousand lives due to desperate attempts to cross. Europe has by no means shown solidarity in its handling of this issue, leaving Italy alone to manage this humanitarian, social and criminal emergency. Immigration has also become a lucrative business, based on the absolute desperation of people willing to abandon everything (or the little) they had to look elsewhere for a better future. Hopes are often dashed, and are sometimes dashed along with the very existence of these individuals who are victims of injustice, cruelty and human greed. Resolving the situation is not easy, but surely the approach must be changed from the outset, as the path chosen so far has proved to be unsuccessful. Europe must be the protagonist in all this and cannot continue to pretend that these are national issues linked to a single country: this resolution should send out a signal, which I hope will not remain only on paper and in the registers of the European Parliament.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. — The European Parliament resolution on the situation in the Mediterranean and the EU's migration policy seeks to strengthen the common anti-immigration policy of the EU and governments, frontex enforcement forces, by further funding it from the Member States. This policy has already led to the deaths of thousands of migrants and refugees, who, in their quest to escape poverty, hunger and imperialist interventions by the US, the EU and NATO in their home countries, are confronted with human trafficking rings and repressive forces. The increasing waves of migration are the result of imperialist interventions to control the resources and transport routes of energy, the capital's needs for a wealthy labour force.  We demand immediate measures here and now to accommodate, accommodate and relieve migrants and refugees; abolition of concentration camps and Dublin II and III regulations; travel documents to those wishing to move to other countries.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — With this resolution, the majority of the EP does not take a step back in its support for an EU immigration policy, which is responsible for the deaths of thousands of people in the Mediterranean who are seeking better living conditions for themselves and their families despite the risks of crossing. Strengthening border and security policy and defending the improvement of FRONTEX's future role make clear the intention to maintain and deepen a policy that has transformed the EU into a fortress where immigrants must submit to trafficking and criminal networks that proliferate in the shadow of repression and criminalisation of immigrants. And it insists on the direction of establishing agreements with transit or home countries to carry out the dirty role of repression and the impediment of arrival in the EU.  The defence of the deepening of these policies by the right and social democracy makes it possible to foresee the limits of the possible establishment of a committee of inquiry in the EP. It would be naïve to assume that the same majority who treat immigrants as criminals could lead a commission of inquiry into the establishment of different conclusions. Hence our vote against.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. - Immigration, irregular in particular, should be an increasing cause for concern for the European Union. Not only because of the difficulty that Member States encounter in receiving migrants, but because of the migrants themselves who often fall victim to unscrupulous traffickers. I support the strong call to develop a global approach to the problem: it is not possible to let the coastal states bear the burden of the emergency without a mechanism for sharing responsibilities. This is borne out by the numbers of the disappointing operation 'Mare Nostrum', put in place by Italy: mistakes that we must not make again now that the operation – finally joint – 'Triton' has started, for which, however, it is not yet clear which and how many contributions will be allocated by the Member States. In this regard, I also agree with the call for an analysis to be carried out so that we can see how the funds allocated to internal affairs have been spent on actions relating to migration and asylum, border control, the fight against trafficking in human beings and repatriation. I hope that the competent national authorities will accept the call to 'show solidarity', contributing to prevention and support operations, in the full knowledge that we are talking about a 'European' problem.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on statements by the Council and the Commission on the report of the United States Senate on torture by the CIA (2014/2997(RSP)).

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the United States is an important partner for the European Union in the fight against terrorism. However, there have also been some serious concerns and differences regarding certain aspects of US counter-terrorism policies. The European Union has been in dialogue with the United States on these issues for several years. Today we are going to be discussing a Senate report on a previous US programme that formally ended almost six years ago. We share President Obama's view that these techniques are contrary to our values and not just useful in the fight against terrorism. It is important to ensure that this does not happen again. That is why we welcome the publication of the report as well as the subsequent public debate. This demonstrates both transparency and openness in learning from past mistakes. The Council has repeatedly stated that the fight against terrorism must take place in full compliance with international law, including human rights law, international humanitarian law, and the international law of refugees. Respect for international law is an essential element of the European Union's counter-terrorism strategy.  When the existence of the CIA's secret detention centres was revealed in 2006, the Council stressed that the European Union remained strongly committed to a total ban on torture, cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. It is clear from the Senate report that the legal justification has helped to authorise the various techniques mentioned in it. Since 2006, the European Union has initiated regular dialogue with US legal advisers on the international legal aspects of the fight against terrorism. This dialogue has enabled us to submit a number of issues and concerns to the United States and has given us the opportunity to insist on the need to respect international law and human rights. It is important to note that President Obama formally ended the CIA program just days after he took office. By decree, President Obama had then banned all forms of torture and ill-treatment, as well as so-called 'enhanced interrogation techniques' and secret detention. He had asked that the CIA no longer run detention centers and had banned the use of interrogation techniques. Subsequently, in a joint question issued in June 2009, the European Union and the United States welcomed ( and I quote) 'the thorough review of US policies on detention, transfer, trials and interrogation in the fight against terrorism and greater transparency on past practices in relation to these policies as well as the elimination of secret detention centres'.  We can only tackle terrorism if we live up to our fundamental values. The violation of human rights and the rule of law can, in themselves, give rise to resentment and even lead people to resort to terrorism, even if such acts can never be justified or excused in any way. These policies, although intended to combat terrorism, can in fact create conditions conducive to its spread. Over the years, the European Union has not only engaged in dialogue with states on these issues, but has also taken specific steps to promote changes in US policy: for example, in 2009, the European Union established a framework that facilitated the reception by EU Member States of former Guantanamo detainees in support of President Obama's goal of closing Guantánamo within a year. This support was provided as part of an in-depth review of US counter-terrorism policies, in line with the rule of law and international law, pending a solution to the underlying political issues. With the exception of specific armed conflicts such as in Afghanistan, Syria or Iraq, the European Union has adopted a criminal justice approach in the fight against terrorism. Terrorists should be properly investigated, prosecuted and convicted in accordance with the common rules of criminal law. The criminal and ordinary courts have a long history of handling terrorism-related cases. Law enforcement investigations are crucial to obtaining information about terrorist networks and to thwarting their plans. Fair trials before ordinary criminal courts have put hundreds of terrorists behind bars. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Treaties of the European Union national security remains the exclusive competence of each Member State. This means that the work of the member states' intelligence agencies is outside the remit of the European Union and its institutions. It follows that investigations into the alleged involvement of Member States in the CIA programme are the responsibility of the Member States and not of the European Union. In conclusion, the Member States and the European Union are bound by the European Convention on Human Rights and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. The actions taken to combat terrorism are monitored by the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg. In addition, since the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the European Court of Justice has had jurisdiction to review EU legislation on internal security. This provides a solid regulatory framework that provides an adequate framework within which we can and must combat the scourge of terrorism.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, the Commission, which I represent here today on this matter, is, like you, appalled by the findings of the United States Senate Select Committee on the intelligence study of the CIA’s detention and interrogation programme, part of which was released on 9 December. As you know, most of the inquiry remains classified. This report raises important questions as regards serious violations of fundamental rights by the US authorities and by other persons in the service of the CIA between late 2001 and January 2009.  As President Obama rightly said this week, the actions taken under the CIA programme were contrary to US values, recognising that one of the most effective tools to fight terrorism is to stay true to the values and ideals the United States stands for. This is what led him in 2009 to unequivocally ban torture – an act which we applauded. I recall this because this is the real point about torture: it is just wrong. Not only is it wrong, it is a crime – it is a criminal act – and it should never be used.  While shocking, the Senate Committee findings are not a complete surprise. The existence of secret detention facilities, rendition flights and the allegations of torture and ill-treatment of prisoners under CIA custody in the context of the fight against terrorism by the United States have been a concern since they became public some 10 years ago. Since then, several United Nations human rights bodies and special rapporteurs – as well as the Council of Europe and the European Court of Human Rights – have been unequivocal in condemning the practices now documented in the Senate Committee study. This House has been engaged in this issue since the start, with the decision to set up a committee of inquiry leading to two own-initiative reports in 2007 and in 2012 condemning the practices in question and voicing the need to promote and protect fundamental rights. As the European Union, we have raised these issues with the United States on several occasions, including in letters by the Presidency of the Council and in our regular dialogues on counter-terrorism and human rights.  The Senate Committee study is a positive step in confronting publicly and critically the way in which the CIA’s responsibilities were discharged in relation to the allegations of torture and ill-treatment against suspects in United States custody abroad. The Commission believes that full clarity should be brought to bear on those practices, in accordance with international standards, including as regards individual responsibilities for those facts.  The EU condemns all forms of torture and ill-treatment under any circumstances and works towards the prevention and eradication of all forms of torture and ill-treatment within the European Union and worldwide as a priority of its human rights policy.
