As the Commission has repeatedly underlined, efforts to combat terrorism should be conducted in a manner that conforms to the rule of law, respects our common values and complies with our respective obligations under international law – in particular, international human rights law, refugee law and humanitarian law.  The Commission has consistently stressed, since the beginning, that all concerned Member States should conduct in-depth, independent and impartial investigations to establish the facts with regard to CIA activities. They should have established responsibilities and enabled victims to obtain compensation for damages. This was recalled in a joint letter sent to all Member States in 2013 by then Vice-President Reding and Commissioner Malmström. We note that the judicial authorities of several Member States have in the past undertaken investigations and the prosecution of persons, including CIA agents involved in the abduction, rendition, illegal detention, torture and ill-treatment of suspects under the CIA detention and interrogation programme.  On the same day that the Senate Committee study was released, we learned in the press that the US military’s Bagram Detention Centre in Afghanistan had been closed. Two of the prisoners who have been turned over to the Afghan authorities had been in US custody since 2002, including several years under CIA detention without trial. However, 136 detainees still remain in the Guantánamo detention facility, including detainees who will not be brought to trial and have not been cleared for release. The European Union will keep monitoring the situation and keep raising the human rights-related aspects of the fight against terrorism with the United States.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, I greet the Presidency of the Council, ladies and gentlemen. The report presented by the United States Senate Committee is a frightening one. When President Obama says that the report shows a frightening action by the CIA, and that america's image in the world has been significantly damaged, I can only agree with that 100 per cent. It is actually a key question, which is: can we protect our ideals by flouting and destroying these very ideals? The answer to this question from the point of view of the PPE and from my personal point of view is: no, we cannot trample these ideals underfoot. The fundamental rights and dignity of a person are inviolable. Of course, a person's dignity also includes his security. But to preserve the safety of people, using every method, including torture and the most brutal interrogation methods, is not part of the catalogue of what is acceptable. Waterboarding: John McCain has accused the public of this from his personal point of view, which is very credible, by saying that The Americans once sentenced criminals to long prison terms for waterboarding. What they themselves have blamed others cannot be accepted for them, even if their own CIA does. I think it is a strength of American parliamentarianism that this report has become public in the first place. We will not see this in totalitarian states. I have respect for that, I have to say honestly. Not every state would be subject to such a discussion, and I also admire the parliamentarians who have done so. I hope and hope that the Americans will be strong enough to emerge stronger in democracy and to draw the necessary conclusions.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. Don't blame me for my immediams, but I think it's necessary.  The following examples remind you: the defendant was stuffed into an undersized cage, the cage was hung and left hanging, and the defendant died of sun or cold. The defendant was hanged and released over a kol that penetrated his anus or vagina. Water torture was popular.  If that's what you thought of the Middle School, the Inquisition, the executioners, the gloom, you're right, that's what we learned about at school. What do the following examples remind you of: during torture, the defendant died of hypothermia because he was handcuffed naked to the concrete floor, or he spent 13 years in a crate smaller than a coffin (the presiding officer interrupted the mp and asked him to speak more slowly because of his fellow Members and interpreters). If that's what reminded you of the Middle East, you're wrong. These are so-called special interrogation methods of the CIA, and that's what happened today.  There is another difference: in particular, in the last century, a number of conventions, charters, legal bases, the Constitution on human rights have been written and symbolically signed, you have mentioned, practically in all countries of the world. The US is a signatory to the Convention Against Torture, which explicitly prohibits torture even in emergency situations.  I deliberately made a very crude introduction, and I'm deliberately speaking in the plural, because we're complicit. It has been more than seven years since the adoption of the European Parliament's final report on CIA activities in Europe, I repeat, seven years. The countries of the European Union, however, have still not come out with the truth. Practically nothing happened. No one has been called to account.  The fight against terrorism and, do not laugh, respect for human rights is not mutually exclusive. And the victims of the war on terror deserve justice, too.  Torture is illegal, it is immoral and unacceptable. The involvement of Europe in any form, in any illegal CIA activity, is a disgraceful, unworthy democracy and the foundations and values on which the European Union has grown.  We therefore demand a full investigation and clear answers from the Member States. Impunity is unacceptable, as is the unacceptable preteaction, that nothing has happened and that we are not involved. We demand measures that ensure effective, democratic control over the work of intelligence agencies. We are asking for safeguards to ensure that nothing like this happens again in Europe.  Dear colleagues and colleagues! The truth is sometimes very difficult to accept, but we deserve it. And we have a duty to pass it on to our citizens and to ourselves. Because who, if not alone, can we ensure that tomorrow we won't be on the torture rack?

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as we all know, this House has always had a particular interest in the CIA's transfer and detention programme and the alleged transport and illegal detention of detainees in European countries under the CIA. Six resolutions have already been voted on in the last two parliamentary terms. The recent AMERICAN report has concerned European Member States admitting – I am thinking of Poland, which has admitted the existence of a secret detention site – that they were helping the CIA's practices. The transfer of terror suspects was considered ok by the intelligence services of certain European Member States too frivolously and too quickly. The value of the American report therefore lies mainly in the fact that it reflects our European practices. The European Union says it stands for standards and values of respect for human rights for third countries. Our European shared history is invariably cited here. But those principles also apply to ourselves and our allies, and not just useful in a human rights dialogue or human rights hearings. The fight against terrorism is indeed necessary and the balance between the protection of society and the infringements of personal freedoms must be correct. Today we see the consequences of the anti-terror policy that has been pursued. We see that extremists in Syria, Iraq, Afghanistan and Pakistan have been able to reunite and become bloodier and more powerful by the day. The reputational damage that Europe has suffered is considerable. Without wanting to undermine the need to fight terrorism, respect for human rights is an absolute prerequisite for ensuring the effectiveness of any anti-terror policy and, above all, to maintain citizens' confidence in the EU's democratic system. By uncritiquely cooperating with the CIA programme, the European Union has violated this trust. The use of diplomatic guarantees without preconditions, the systematic invocation of state secrecy and the way in which intelligence services thought they should play justice are at odds with the values on which Europe is built.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like this opportunity to thank Senator Feinstein for her perseverance and for seeing this report through before the change in the Senate.  I think this reminds us – and I think Ms Hohlmeier said it very rightly – that what sets a democracy apart from a dictatorship is accountability and moral authority. None of us around the world are immune to these tendencies. We all have this kind of violence in us, but what makes us different is that we have accountability and there is no impunity in a democracy. Therefore I am very pleased to hear all colleagues from all political groups insisting on accountability and on the need for Europe to come clean with regard to its role in this whole CIA programme, because we can point at the Americans, but Europe has supported the CIA counter-terrorism programme – all aspects of it.  I am glad that Poland finally made an admission, but let us not forget that there are a number of Member States that are close allies of the US – the Five Eyes and the Nine Eyes – and this Parliament has expressed itself several times. Therefore I am actually shocked to hear the commonplaces uttered by the Italian Presidency. Italy is the one country that has actually prosecuted CIA agents. You have convicted 24 CIA agents. Will Italy, will the Italian Presidency, insist on extradition by the United States and bring those people to trial, just as everyone else who is responsible for torture should be brought to trial? No, Mr Obama, we cannot draw a line under this until those responsible have been brought to justice. That is why we are a democracy and the others are not. I have another question: I read a statement in the press by the Head of INTCEN, the intelligence centre which is a kind of vague, unclear, embryonic European Union secret service. He said there is no way of knowing whether the intelligence that INTCEN receives was obtained through torture. Excuse me? This is an EU body paid for by EU money, processing information that may have been obtained from third countries, processing information that may have been obtained from torture? Well maybe he does not, but then we should know; we should finally get answers on the nature and the activities of INTCEN; answers we have asked for many times. We should have proper oversight over INTCEN. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: blue-card question. – Ms In ‘t Veld, would you agree with me that the words that we have heard from the Council today, whilst they sound very sweet, are in fact too little, too late? Back in 2005 I stood in this very Chamber and I raised with the Council Presidency on that day the fact that illegal detention centres were operating in Europe. We did not receive any words at that time that they would be investigated – a mere side-step by the Minister of the British Government who was present on the day. Would you therefore agree with me that further inquiries today should be conducted as to whether it is appropriate for any government minister who has knowledge simply to hide behind the façade of the Presidency of the Council and not share information with this Parliament?

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, I very much agree with you, it is not enough for the Council – and that is not just the Italian Minister, that is all the Member State governments – to make statements about the rule of law and human rights and all the conventions that they are bound to and the laws that we have. We had laws back then, but they were not respected. It is not good enough. Those who break the law, even if they are governments, should be brought to justice. So yes, I very much agree with you.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the 6,700 pages of horror, beatings, day-long sleep deprivation, overstretching of body parts, sexualized violence, sham executions, an inmate was prevented from sleeping for 138.5 hours in a row, waterboarding, forced rectal nutrition – are nampering with the worst dictatorships that we rightly criticise? Unlike these dictatorships, the US has published this report – and that is a good thing. I, too, appreciate that. But they are also signatories to the UN Convention on Torture. If a US government actually supports a torture programme and agrees that systematic torture should be allowed, it is a sign of a deep ethical and moral crisis in the United States as a whole, which allows such a thing. Torture doesn't work - nowhere. Those who use torture prevent the purported education. Torture is contempt for human beings and moral decay. That is why regret and criticism is not enough at all. Torture must be prohibited by law everywhere. We are calling for legal work, and I am glad that the leader of the Left Party in the German Bundestag, Gregor Gysi, has filed criminal charges against George Bush. We are also asking for legal consequences from the CIA's torture excesses in Poland and Lithuania. We are asking for information on the alleged involvement of European intelligence services, such as the British one, in these crimes. It is time to close Guantanamo. Stop it. Secret prisons must be disbanded and intelligence services must be deprived of judicial power.

name: Eva JOLY
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, Mr Secretary of State, Commissioner and dear colleagues; Commissioner, at your hearing before Parliament, to my astonishment, you said that you did not know the file. I am pleased to see that this is no different now. For, let us recognize it, there is no new fact in these 600 pages of the Senate report, but only confirmations! Confirmation of the cooperation of European governments and the existence of CIA prisons on European Union soil; confirmation of the futility of torture beyond its despicable character; confirmation that the actions of the secret services must be supervised and scrupulously controlled, their abuses punished; confirmation, above all, that the fundamental rights of citizens cannot be sacrificed in the name of the indispensable fight against terrorism. The publication of this report calls for a new stage in the mobilization for the building of true international justice. The scale of the crimes forces us to be imaginative and legally daring. Do you not think that it calls, also and above all, the European Union, whose leaders have directly collaborated on this programme, to transparency and action? The facts are there, the elements clear. The European Union and its Member States must assume their responsibilities and facilitate legal proceedings. The European Parliament must continue its work of investigating and reviving transparency so that the whole truth is clear: organising hearings and delegations of the LIBE committee on the premises of secret prisons is a bare minimum. Now that the facts have been confirmed, and we know that the fundamental rights of the Union have been violated, do you not think that Articles 6 and 7 of the Treaty of the European Union should be applied and the necessary sanctions implemented? Finally, let us remember that terrorists only want one thing: the destruction of the value regime represented by democracies. By fighting them by methods prohibited by law, we transform ourselves into involuntary auxiliaries of terrorist logic. Making all the transparency about complicity in this program, revealing the truth and doing justice will not make the bed of terrorism, as some fear. On the contrary, it is a fight for our values, and a struggle for a strengthened democracy.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there are two aspects to the US Senate report on the use of torture by the CIA, which I believe we need to reflect on. The first, which is certainly to be welcomed, is the ability of US democratic institutions to self-criticise and judge accurately and harshly, even on sensitive issues that could easily be declassricated as national security issues. This virtue, which is typical of the US legal system and the spirit of its institutions and its citizens, cannot, however, make it possible to ignore and consequently prevent us from denouncing and condemning any form of violence against human rights.  The words of those who have tried to justify torture on suspected terrorists as a useful tool for gathering information for national security are therefore unspeakable and unacceptable – and this is the second aspect of my reflection. There is nothing, neither in peace nor in war, to justify torture which, as we know, not only violates the inalienable right to integrity of the human being but which, moreover, cannot in any way be regarded as an instrument for the search for the truth. The US Senate report, in particular, highlights a number of abuses, lies and misapsreaches committed by the CIA. There is a kind of ambiguity on the part of the American authorities in this matter because, in the report, which seriously describes detailed facts, there are no initiatives or recommendations for the indictment of those responsible, whose names are disclosed. It is time for the European Union too to shed full light on the cooperation of the Member States in the actions carried out by the CIA on European territory and on any secret prisons or places, present in Europe and used by the American Intelligence Agency. Each Member State should carry out transparent investigations and investigations in this regard, leaving no room for impunity. European communion ... (The President withdrew the speaker)

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: Dear colleagues, I am very pleased that the European Parliament is so outraged again at the gross human rights violations of the United States. This time on prisoner torture and arbitrary detention without criminal proceedings. A few months ago, you and I were outraged by the secret surveillance scandal that came to the fore about Edward Snowden. There were killings with drones. We're outraged about that, too, killing civilians in the war, and they're very upset about that, too. Tell me one thing. If they are so outraged at the human rights violations of the United States, why do they want to be friends with this country so convulsively, because the European Union goes hand in hand with the United States on an economic line, they are constantly working on the development of a free trade agreement behind closed doors, and on the political line, the European Union is taking Europe to incitement to the United States and, on the side of the United States, into a Cold War. and potentially a real war against Russia. If you don't like these human rights violations so much, and I'm glad you don't like them, shouldn't you choose a better friend and, after all, protect Hungary, my country and the whole of Europe from the ignominious Cold War and any actual war?

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Mr President, the issue of the CIA's use of torture is a subject that has polarised public opinion in the United States for years. The publication of the Senate report last week confirmed the existing cleavage within the American political class. Democrats and Republicans are deeply divided on several issues, namely, whether this report correctly reflects what happened, then whether the procedure followed was itself correct and even if this report should have been published given its potential security implications. All these issues are being questioned and disputed in the United States. We don't have a unified point of view coming from the United States. Personally, I would like to point out that I feel very close to the position expressed by Republican Senator John McCain, who supported the publication of the report and criticized the CIA's practices that would, in his view, have caused harm to American security interests. I found Senator McCain's statement very wise: "we do it incorrectly, we make mistakes, we fix those mistakes, and we commit ourselves not to repeat them." No one can argue today that the practices highlighted by the CIA report continue. It's actually an episode that belongs to the past. President Obama ended the interrogation program in 2009. However, I would say that the desire to clarify things has been very clear in the United States, and I believe that this is the main lesson that we must remember. It is a healthy thing when a political regime seriously considers its own derives.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr. President! Anyone who has listened to the Council's words might get the impression that the world is in order with us – far from it! The torture of the CIA is a heinous crime in which EU states have been complicit. Systematically and against any international law, the CIA has tortured people all over the world, including in the EU. The CIA has always maintained that it has received such valuable information to prevent terrorist attacks. A lie.  But regardless of this, torture is not a means of combating crime, but a crime itself. Torture betrays the core of our value system. Human dignity is at the heart of our actions. This distinguishes us centrally from fundamentalist extremists. We must speak a different language than violence in the prevention and investigation of terrorist crimes, otherwise we will provide extremists with arguments to incite rejection and hatred against our democracies. This is not just a question of morality, but simply international law. Torture is never allowed. Torture must always be prosecuted by any state. It is a disgrace to Europe that the EU states turned a blind eye when it came to illegal transport of prisoners or the provision of prisons. As early as 2007, the European Parliament called for comprehensive clarification – to this day without any result. Who caused people, including EU citizens, to be kidnapped, transferred, arrested and tortured without charge, and who knew about it? Just last week, senior representatives of Poland and Romania confirmed the existence of secret torture camps. Will there be consequences? National governments alone seem unable to do so – they are too entangled in crime. That is why we need effective EU mechanisms to prevent our Member States from blatantly violating fundamental European values.  The CIA tortures show what happens when a terrorist regime emerges past the rule of law. No one is protected, but our democracies are threatened as a whole. It is up to us as Europeans to take a firm stand against this, and I can only hope that the Commission will actually stand by us in this.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking The fact that torture may have been used on the territory of Polish caused a stir and outrage among the Polish public, regardless of all the security reasons that these practices are trying to justify, and the fact that it was about the suspects of murdering many thousands of innocent people. Today, a letter from intellectuals and other public figures in Poland will be published condemning the use of torture in our country. However, I would like to draw attention to a slightly different aspect of this case. On double standards and on the issue of trust between allies. While respecting American law, the CIA did not conduct such interrogations in the US. However, no similar respect for Polish law has been shown. Some polish politicians at the time also had too little respect for Polish sovereignty and Polish values. The US was a symbol of freedom, democracy and the rule of law for us in Eastern Europe, which was dominated by communism. Unfortunately, our trust has now been abused, and this image of the US has suffered significant damage. Thank you very much.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul "Horrific" is the word that best captures the brutal inhumane torture methods used by the CIA against prisoners of war. "Despicable" is the word that best captures the way the lying CIA chiefs dismiss the accusations. What has come to light is a reminder of the existing impunity for the many terrible human rights violations that the United States justifies in the name of national security. However, as so many times before, when the effects of torture have been investigated, it has been shown that the method is meaningless.  However, notwithstanding the security of the kingdom or the results achieved, I say it again: torture is under no circumstances acceptable, and the international ban on torture is absolute. It applies to everyone and everywhere. The report shows that EU countries such as Sweden, the UK, Italy and Romania have cooperated with the CIA by handing over people to the US security services without guarantees that they will not be tortured.  And these countries, including my own country, Sweden, have allowed the CIA to fly people out in appalling and degrading conditions. Now the time of denial must be over. The truth can set us free, and the truth must come out. There must be an end to impunity, the perpetrators must be held accountable, the victims compensated and accountability demanded. (The speaker agreed to answer a question (blue card) in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: blue-card question. – I know you agree with me that torture is immoral, illegal and must always be condemned. Do you also accept that military expediency requires the possibility of proper interrogation? I refer in the UK to the words of Colonel Tim Collins, who said this: ‘Since I was serving, the rules on interrogations have been tightened up because of lawyers. We are no longer able to carry out tactical questioning. The effect of the ambulance-chasing lawyers and the play-it-safe judges is that we have got to the point where we have lost our operational capacity to do tactical questioning’.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: blue-card answer. – I will be happy to answer. The brutality of the methods used and how they have been justified is simply unacceptable and the European Member States must all come together to disclose the truth: what happened in your country as well as in my country. This is the truth and we need to see it now. It is time for impunity to come to an end, even in Europe.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: Mr President, the recent Senate report on CIA interrogation techniques exposes that American administrations sanction torture. Unfortunately this is not new. The five techniques were used by the British Government to torture 14 Irish men interned over 40 years ago. As a result, the Irish Government brought the British Government to the European Court of Human Rights, which was the first time a Member State took another to that Court. That happened in 1978 in a landmark Ireland vs UK case on the hooded men. However, the Court ruled that the five techniques amounted to inhumane and degrading treatment – not torture. The Bush administration justified the used of these torture techniques in Iraq, Afghanistan and Guantánamo Bay by quoting the EU Court ruling on the hooded men. However, information recently discovered by the Pat Finucane Centre shows that the British Government lied to the European Court of Human Rights on the effects of these techniques, and that the 14 hooded men were indeed tortured. These torture techniques were sanctioned at the highest level of government by the then British Minister of Defence, Lord Carrington. Only last week, the Irish Government confirmed it had referred the case of the hooded men back to the European Court of Human Rights to revise its judgment. Britain is guilty of torture. The British Government must apologise for the use of the five techniques in Ireland, just like it recently apologised for their use in Kenya, and the American Government must do likewise.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Can I remind colleagues that we have a topic on the agenda and that colleagues who are speaking should speak on the topic on the agenda.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: Mr President, I will stick to the subject of torture by the CIA. Feinstein's report also awakens us in the European Union. I am quite happy with that, because the Green Group has spent the last few months trying to get the report that was made earlier in this House on the CIA's extradition flights back on the agenda. These are European countries that were knowingly involved in kidnapping people and interrogating people in any way, not necessarily on American soil. Somehow the interest had subsided. "Sand over it," I had as a feeling at that debate. But i understand this debate here today as a new beginning of an investigation by the European Parliament into the involvement of European countries in CIA torture.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Cia torture doesn't surprise. The United States and its secret services to date have a rich history of imperialist interventions, juntas, coups, savage torture, cold-blooded killings of African Americans. The European Union goes a long way to portraying itself as the honoree of human rights. The common foreign security and defence policy, Europol, Eurojustice, all the repression mechanisms of the European Union and NATO are partners and allies of the CIA. The Member States of the European Union cooperate with the United States in many areas of repression of the labour movement. They also cooperate in state and industrial espionage, telephone and online surveillance, and cover up inhuman torture. All this is not a dissonance of the capitalist system but its true face. Their goal is to defend capitalist exploitation against the enemy people. This is the dictatorship of monopolies and peoples can make their own decisions to overthrow it with their own power. They have the power.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his work I think it is a great achievement by the American Senate, especially Senator Feinstein, to publish such a report. It shows that, unlike Russia and China, the United States of America is always able, when it has built crap, to put things right in a self-cleaning process. That is the big difference between a democracy and a dictatorship. For this, the democracies should not be insulted. However, it is true in substance: this procedure is not legally tenable, there is no reason to justify it, and it is completely lawless. It is inhumane and must be criticised. That is quite clear, and that is why I myself visited Guantanamo and have always been clear on this issue; since these practices are unacceptable and do not comply with international humanitarian law, this must be strongly criticised. But please do not hypocritically, as if the United States of America were the greatest perpetrator on earth. We must also see that this was a consequence, a consequence that cannot be regarded as an alibi, but a consequence of acts of terrorism carried out against American citizens, which are hardly named by anyone here. Because there is a history, which you have to express. I repeat, however, that the balance between freedom and security cannot be so misplaced that it destroys fundamental human rights. That is the criticism. The Americans are in the process of restoring the balance. And I think it's a crucial point to be critical of it, but to understand that connection. That is why I would like once again to congratulate Senator Feinstein and her people for having had this courage, with all the consequences and criticisms that have to do with it, and that makes the difference between the United States of America and many dictatorships. Mrs Ernst, you should also talk to your Stasi people in your party, who have also put people in prison and tortured them there. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Urmas PAET
text: blue card issue. – I share Mr Brok's views on this issue, and I have a question for him, which Mr Brok is now assessing the risks in the fight against terrorism, as a result of this report? Does he see whether there are any potential implications for the future fight against terrorism, as a result of this situation? Unfortunately, it was only yesterday that we saw a terrible event in Pakistan. What's his assessment?

name: Elmar BROK
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I have said that we must see the fight against terrorism, but that the violation of human rights cannot be justified by the fight against terror. That is why this American behaviour is wrong. This is criticised. But we still have to see the connection. (The speaker agreed to answer three questions under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: blue-card question. – I am glad that Mr Brok condemns the use of terror under any circumstances. Even if it was understandable, if it was the circumstances, etc., is it not true, Mr Brok, that many years have passed when people should have been brought to justice and when there should have been accountability, but every single opportunity was missed until today? Incidentally, when it comes to justice, the Americans did manage to lock up the people who actually disclosed the scandals – for example Mr John Kiriakou, a former CIA employee who spent time in prison – rather than the people responsible for terror. Do you not agree that there was plenty of time to repair the mistakes that were made?

name: Afzal KHAN
text: blue-card question. – Mr Brok, thank you for your contribution. As close friends of the US should we not now be asking them to close Guantánamo Bay?

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Brok, I would like to thank Mr Brok for his work, I agree with you on a few things. I am not holy at all. But I wanted to ask you the following question now: do you not think that legal measures are also needed to do this, that legal conclusions must also be drawn and, in fact, that people who are responsible for these human rights violations must also be brought to justice, and that this must also be prosecuted legally?

name: Elmar BROK
text: Answer to questions about the "blue card" procedure. Yes, this was a mistake in the past. Yes, we must do something about it. Yes, this must also be done in law if this has been proven in individual cases. But that does not change the arguments I have put forward before. Eight or ten years ago, I did not have to confirm that this should be done in a legal way and that Guantanamo should be dissolved. I have always been of that view. But we must also see, and this is the double-bodiedness that we have: which of our countries was prepared to take in Guantanamo prisoners when the Americans wanted to do so? We must first put our own house in our own house on this matter. There were only a few countries that were prepared to accept some. That is why one cannot proceed accordingly with a commandment of hypocrisy. Mrs Ernst, legal conclusion: Yes. I also believe that such proceedings should not even be subject to limitation periods, but also no political limitation periods, if such people, who have tormented their own compatriots in prison, now bear political responsibility in Germany today.

name: Claude MORAES
text: Mr President, one thing Mr Brok says accurately is that we both met Dianne Feinstein in the United States on the NSA inquiry. She was brave then, and she was brave on this subject. She faced huge pressure on the question of making this report happen. We should be very aware – and Mr Coelho will agree – that we have now been vindicated on our 2006 CIA rendition inquiry and our report, which were happening in a very different context in a very different time. I would remind colleagues that, in 2006, when we in this Parliament investigated with secondary sources – not the primary sources that the US Senate had – all of these terrible and horrific brutal torture methods, it was under severe pressure. We were investigating our own governments in that context in a very fragile way, but we have been vindicated, because many of the same conclusions were reached in this Parliament. That was a very difficult thing for us to do.  What conclusions did we come up with? We came up with what John McCain said. He was a Republican, a man who had been tortured, and someone who understood the difference between interrogation and brutal torture. What he said was that it was legally and morally wrong. But he also said that it brought no new information in the fight against terrorism. These are people who are not soft on terrorism. These are people who understand the qualitative difference between interrogation and torture, and the qualitative difference between having no information and bad information. That was John McCain, and that is why people are quoting him today. So let us understand that we were vindicated in our enquiry. This is not the end of the road. We have people languishing in Guantánamo Bay today who should be free, like Shaker Aamer. These are people whom our governments are requesting to be freed, who have been tortured and who have families, but who are actually languishing in prison. The story is not finished. It has only begun. These are our citizens – EU citizens. They are languishing in prison and they have been tortured repeatedly. We want them back and we should be representing them. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)

name: Afzal KHAN
text: blue-card question. – If I can ask for the sake of Members who were not here in 2006, you mentioned two things: you said that we were vindicated, and that it was difficult. Why do you say that?

name: Claude MORAES
text: blue-card answer. –  Thank you for the brevity of the question. Let me just say this to the House, and also to Mr Coelho who chaired that committee of inquiry very effectively – the rapporteur was Claudio Fava, an Italian MEP who is now a Member of the Italian Parliament. These were Members who took on a very difficult task and my assessment is that the three big inquiries of this Parliament, the Echelon inquiry, the inquiry into mass surveillance, and now the inquiry into CIA renditions, all said the same thing, which is that we have very inadequate parliamentary scrutiny of these kinds of actions. These inadequate parliamentary scrutinies allow inadequate scrutiny of the kinds of actions that we now see which allow this extreme kind of torture which ends up with the kind of Senate report that we see today. We must correct this, and that would be my point as to why the new Members of this Parliament should take an interest in what is happening today. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: blue-card question. – Thank you, Mr Moraes, for the work that you have done on this issue over a number of years. One of the biggest challenges that we have had has actually been getting information from our own governments: do you feel satisfied that we have had full disclosure from our Member State governments? If we have not, how can any of us be satisfied that any of our citizens will not have to face such a thing ever again?

name: Claude MORAES
text: blue-card answer. – Of course we do not have full disclosure and that is why I described Dianne Feinstein as a brave person. When Elmar Brok and I met her, we were aware that we were before a brave senator.  We are parliamentarians, and when we were doing the CIA inquiry in the European Parliament and people were denigrating that inquiry, we were aware that we were dealing with our own governments – sometimes we were Members of Parliament with our own government in office – and we were investigating them. Of course there is not full disclosure. We have to be brave in those situations and try and get as much information as possible. Sometimes that will be second-hand and in a secondary way, as I said at the beginning, but we have to do it because without that accountability we cannot get the truth.  But let me say finally that we still have European Union citizens in prison today who are completely innocent and they should be free. That is why this is such a vital and important issue and all parliamentarians should be representing them if nothing else.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Mr. President! As a long-standing member of Amnesty International, I, like all of us here, am appalled and outraged by what has happened in the United States. But I would also like to take this opportunity to remind you that it was the Americans themselves who made this public – it was the Senate, by the way. And there, as here, there is a critical debate about what previous American governments have done. What surprises me a little is that we are once again taking on the Americans. I would also very much like to have such a debate on what the Russian secret service is doing. I missed that.  As co-rapporteur on the report on the human rights situation last year, I have also noticed that in these reports we always deal with things that, strangely enough, are mostly or very often directed against the Americans. It would be nice if we would also do just as much to deal with human rights violations in other countries.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: Mr President, we are not talking about something new, but we still all look surprised. The CIA started torturing people in 2001, and in 2006 we discovered that the agency was also responsible for the illegal detention and transfer of prisoners in Europe. Besides being a terrible human rights violation, this in fact created a vicious circle, giving the terrorists one more reason to continue their fight and their propaganda.  Now that the US Senate has come up with this report it is time that we all put the spotlight on things that have happened inside the European Union. EU Member States are not innocent, as my colleagues Sophia in ’t Veld and Cecilia Wikström mentioned. Many EU Member States were aware of the CIA’s practices; some actually tolerated, if not supported them. As has already been mentioned, Poland has finally admitted it; others are still fighting the claims. The EU should also follow the US example and investigate the level of participation. Practices like those we have just heard about are unworthy of the European Union. I therefore call on the Member States to set up national parliamentary inquiries in order to establish the extent of the involvement in or knowledge of CIA torture.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: The inhumane practices used by the CIA under President Bush to interrogate detainees are evidence of the lack of genuine respect for human rights that distinguishes the dominant political forces in the United States. On the one hand, they pretend to be the nurses, issuing reports every year on the situation of fundamental rights in third countries, while on the other hand, they themselves are flagrantly in breach of the Convention against Torture which they signed in 1994. But the Union's behaviour is also very little different. While the European Union proclaims that it has been protecting fundamental rights, in practice, in recent years, it has systematically trampled on them, in particular social rights through the imposition of exterminating austerity policies. Long-term unemployment, lack of health care, inability to heat houses in winter constitute economic torture. European governments have promised the people paradise and are serving hell. Change course before you destroy Europe!

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: Mr President, like others I welcome the Senate report but regret that both of the main political parties did not participate in the full process. As others have said, it is clear that torture is forbidden. We know the mental and physical scars that are left and we have had Members in this Parliament who have suffered torture in their lives and can testify to the effects. I would also raise again in this House, as others have, the case of those still in Guantánamo, such as London resident Shaker Aamer held prisoner, tortured in Bagram, still held after twelve years in Guantánamo, cleared for transfer in 2007. The British Government has said it will have him back to rejoin his British wife and children. I think we fail to understand how he can still be in Guantánamo when two democratic governments have agreed he should be returned. The use of torture demeans our demands regarding human rights from others elsewhere in the world and our reputation can only be rescued if the perpetrators and those complicit are brought to justice.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Unlike all my colleagues, I say that the CIA was right to do what it did, because we must remember 11 September 2001. There's too much hypocrisy here. If Islamic terrorism does what it did in 2001, killing thousands of people in New York, as it did with beheadings recently, as it did in Pakistan the other day, as it did in Australia: but where do we live? Torture must take place in order to ensure that there is peace of mind for Europe too. Because if those are terrorists, those are beasts. Those who commit such serious crimes are beasts, they are terrorists to fight, and Guantánamo must remain open, because we must fight. If those who behead people beheaded some of your children, some of your relatives, would you still talk like that?  In Islamic law there is still the law of the cut. Jesus changed it 2000 years ago! In Islamic law the "tooth for tooth, eye for an eye" remains. But do you realize? Islamic policy is a terrorist policy. The Islamic religion is violent. Netanyahu told us today that we are hypocrites. Europe is hypocritical on certain aspects, such as the vote on Palestine: six million deaths in Europe and we are talking about Palestine! (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Blue card question. Mr President, I would like to ask my fellow Member whether he realises, in his words, that he has implicitly attacked practically a number of articles of the Fundamental Charter of Human Rights and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and that he is saying things that, in this House, are not acceptable, because in this Parliament, parliament of European democracies, we are against torture and even the murderer is not called a beast. I would like to ask you, Mr President, if you are aware of what you have said?

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Answer to a blue card question. Mr President, I am pleased with the hypocritical applause of those who, however, sit in the heat, in here and do not go to fight for democracy where they have to fight. All I am saying is that those who have committed such serious crimes cannot think of being treated in caviar and champagne. Clearly, in order to combat certain phenomena, we must be prepared to do certain things. Otherwise, terrorism will never be combated. In Italy, too, there has been terrorism: the Red Brigades. You fought how? With imprisonment, of course, but also with the repentant, with those who tried to say things. He made sure he did something. Of course, on even more serious matters, it is clear, I repeat, that the Americans have only done well and if others do so, I say to combat Islamic terrorism, everything is fine, as long as everything is defeated.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, in 2007 and 2006 this Parliament investigated this case through a committee to which I had the honour of chairing. Some said at the time that it was impossible for a rule of law like the United States of America to commit the illegal acts assigned to them. U.S. authorities claimed the allegations were unfounded. Lied! In September 2006 we had a witness that we had not asked for: George W. Bush, then President of the United States of America, confirmed to the world the extraordinary renditions program and acknowledged that kidnappings, the non-subjection of detainees to a court, the existence of secret prisons, were not subjected to torture. He lied once again, as seen by the now published U.S. Senate report. This Senate report leaves us with four important messages. First, it takes courage to have moral authority, as Senator Feinstein pointed out, and well, only an adult democracy is able to review its own mistakes and help prevent them from repeating themselves in the future. Second, we can't give up on bringing the truth to the fore. Without us being it, it is not clear that the truth always comes to the fore, especially when national governments create obstacles to what has happened. I reiterate what I have said more than once in this House: under no circumstances can state secrecy be overstood with inalienable fundamental rights. This Parliament must continue its efforts and contribute to the full clarification of what has happened in the European Union. Thirdly, the ends do not justify the means. Torture is not morally acceptable, condemned by international law and is not even effective, as this report proves and, moreover, has already been stated by Senator McCain. And finally, there is a deficit in democratic control of the secret services. The report is proof that for several years democratic control over the secret services has not worked. The secret services must be subject to greater democratic control and this must also happen in the European Union.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – I agree with what is being said in here. If we have inquiries into torture and these obscene practices, would you agree with me that it would be no good if these inquiries just finished with individual security officers being sacrificed and put forward as scapegoats while the men at the top – the politicians who gave the orders – still roam free, free from penalty? Would you agree that this would be wrong and we need to go to the top with this?

name: Carlos COELHO
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. I'm certainly in agreement with you. The added value of the investigation is not just to ascertain responsibilities. This is important, but, as I said and well, we must ascertain the responsibilities of everyone, those who have done so and those who have authorised it or those who have silenced. But above all, the added value of the survey is to ensure that we learn from the past and that we learn from the lessons so as not to repeat the same mistakes in the future.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr. President! Freedom is the foundation of the Western community of values, and protecting it is a priority for any state that feels it belongs to it. There is no doubt that, in certain situations and under certain conditions, restrictions on these rights may also be necessary. September 11 was such a situation.  Unfortunately, the CIA report confirmed the concerns of many at the time that these measures were not merely thought of in a case-by-case and proportionate way, but rather overdrafted and ultimately turned into their opposite. There was a paradigm shift in Western security policy: more control, more surveillance, and more repression. At times, it seems that the West wants to move to a permanent state of emergency. With little success, by the way. The threat of terrorism has rather increased.  A German magazine said these days: "Perhaps this was Osama Bin Laden's greatest triumph: "[...] that America now stands as an unjust state." One must agree with this, but with the addition that the handling of these inglorious events by the majority in the American Senate shows just as impressively that the United States does not want to be an unjust state. This is an important piece of knowledge.  However, this knowledge must not lead us to complacency and self-righteousness. On the contrary, we must consistently continue along the path of dealing with the critical points, particularly with regard to the role of individual Member States of the European Union. Crimes as such must also be punished by the courts – basta! That is the mandate that this report gives us.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: It is undeniable that the disclosure of these facts and circumstances in the US administration's report on its abductions, interrogations, torture and other similar human rights violations is extremely outrageous. They show that the country that most claims to protect the rights of its citizens and human rights in general around the world is, in fact, systematically and consistently violating them. And here one thing should be clear - it is impossible, and there is no way with a simple excuse to justify these actions. That would mean any mass murderer asking that he be acquitted when he apologizes. The United States owes the world and society a serious investigation and owes prosecution to those responsible for these human rights violations, violations of international law, to all legal norms.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: Let me start by saying that I was pleased with your performance and your assessment.  However, I would like to say that, in the event of the terrorist attack on the World Trade Centre, we have expressed solidarity with the United States of America, and that solidarity is still in force.  Unfortunately, the so-called war on terror in the following years has triggered a series of responses and methods with which we cannot agree. The CIA not only shamed its country, but also damaged the reputation of European countries that offered hospitality for its scandalous actions.  The US cannot deny the fact that they are among the 156 countries that have signed the Convention against Torture and that they are therefore obliged to bring those responsible for these crimes to justice. In the event that the military or civil justice system of the United States of America decides not to act and thus to leave torture and responsible politicians with impunity, a complementary clause of the International Court of Criminal Justice (ICC) can be invoked immediately. That clause allows the court to take the case into its own hands any time that governments or states are unwilling to act. The ICC may also issue a warrant for the arrest of all persons responsible for these crimes and give them a verdict.  By publishing the torture report, the US has so far only completed part of its mission in demonstrating its commitment to human rights and international law. Let us not forget, however, that Guantanamo is still in office.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: Mr President, to introduce food and objects for the anus of the detainee; spill hot liquid onto the detainee's penis; keep the detainee 104 hours in a row without sleeping; threatening the detainee with raping his mother; make the detainee hear the cries of a disabled relative. These are some of the procedural practices we have known from that report. The problem is not that there are human beings who are able to do this to other human beings: there will always be dogs willing to follow the orders of their loved ones. The problem is not that there are fascist deputies who defend the practice of torture in this House. The problem is, those amos wear jackets and ties and take democrats' consideration. The problem is that, in this House, some of your dignified ladies and gentlemen, such as some Members of the Socialist Party and the People's Party of my country, participated in governments that collaborated with the CIA in the transfer of detainees who were to be tortured. That's the problem, ladies and gentlemen.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: Mr President, Mr Brok and Mr Iglesias have it absolutely wrong. Democracy is a tyranny of the majority and the majority do not care for the principles of freedom and human rights, the majority wants safety and to obtain it, it will agree to torture, to kill, to almost everything. I move the European Parliament to create an investigation committee, at least on the Polish case, which is the most characteristic case of CIA prisoners in Europe because the Polish Government was denying everything and we have been denying what we can deny, and men who stubbornly denied the extent of torture in Poland now occupy prominent positions in the present Parliament. The main suspect is a man who as Polish Prime Minister was the chief negotiator of the accession treaties at exactly the same time that he was negotiating with the CIA. The dog is buried much deeper but I have no time to explain it now. I advise you to create an investigation committee. Mr Etheridge surely agrees with me.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: Mr President, the attacks of 11 September 2001 in the United States of America, as well as those in Madrid, London and Boston, have shown us that there are no safe nations, and terrorism can strike anywhere, anytime and with unimaginable powers, with the lives of millions of people always at risk. These things have led nations around the world – and not just the United States – to unite their efforts in a common endeavour, abandon their defensive attitudes and react. Today's situation, when Islamic State manages to recruit more and more of its true estrets, perhaps also because of a polarisation of society, shows us that the peace, security and safety of the citizen are always at risk. Innocent people fall prey to ferocious acts of terrorism every day, and recent tragedies show us that these threats take a domestic form, in other words they come from European passport holders.  Detention centres have emerged as a consequence of the fact that terrorism does not take into account borders and, at the same time, the need to identify its causes and, in particular, to find answers to what is to be done in order to remove or at least diminish the phenomenon. That is why I believe that excessive politicisation of this phenomenon is of no benefit to anyone. However, and I stress 'however', we will never be able to agree to the inhumane means of obtaining information. Torture, inhuman and degrading treatment must be rejected regardless of the circumstances. To do otherwise would do nothing but turn the victims into a man, and their guilt would be no less. The common objectives of all nations must be to respect international human rights standards and at the same time we must be concerned about the safety of our citizens, no matter where they are.

name: Ana GOMES
text: The Senate report confirms all that the reports of the European Parliament and the Council of Europe had already exposed since 2007, but adds new details, both on torture and other crimes committed by the CIA in the extraordinary renditions program, or on the network of secret prisons to relocate and subcontract the torture of Assad, Gaddafi or Mubarak , either on the extent of the lie and the omission of the CIA and the Bush Administration to deceive Congress and American and global public opinion. Several European governments may also have been misled, but others knew and were in cooperating with the CIA operation. It is up to this Parliament to set out what they are. Some of the accomplices did not merely authorize overflights of airplanes to transport the prisoners. The Senate confirms that there have been secret prisons in Europe. Poland, Lithuania and Romania have already had to admit what they have denied to this Parliament. The European Parliament has a duty to reinstate a mechanism for investigating the participation of Member States of the European Union in this programme carried out by the United States. It is essential to end impunity.  Throughout my country, Portugal, the first flights that transported suspected terrorists to Guantanamo on November 11, 2002. Between flyovers, flights, stopovers, technical stops, between 2002 and 2007 are more than a hundred times in which the CIA used the Portuguese territory in the process of committing these crimes. But it remains to be clarified whether the Portuguese authorities were only toline and incompetent and deceived by the United States or if they were accomplices and active participants in this program? It is still unclear whether the scales involved detention and torture on national soil, for example at the base of the Lages in the Azores. The government of my party - I say with shame and bitterness - from 2006, has done everything to obstruct the knowledge of the truth by preventing a parliamentary inquiry, hindering a judicial inquiry, preventing scrutiny of the secret services, and withholding from the European Parliament and the national parliament lists of authorized flights to and from Guantanamo that I have obtained and handed over to this Parliament's committee of inquiry. I end by saying that all these efforts were to cover up their own responsibilities and not to compromise the chances of re-leading the leadership of the European Commission, the former Prime Minister of Portugal, Mr Barroso, who, between 2002 and 2005, was an active accomplice to this CIA programme. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8))

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: It asks according to the procedure "blue card". – Madam President, Dear Colleague, do you think that we can believe in public discourse in favour of human rights by entities that set up concentration camps such as Guantanamo or that allow the clandestine practice of acts of torture such as those of Abu Ghraib and those that are now denounced by the Us Senate? Do you think that the European authorities, the European countries that have allowed torture by the CIA on their territory, should be sanctioned by the institutions of the European Union?

name: Ana GOMES
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – Democracies make mistakes and the great democracies admit that they make mistakes and, of course, that is what the Us Senate has done, but that is also what the European Parliament has already done and that is exactly why I think we have to continue the work now, we have to find out who were responsible for Europeans, we have to bring them to trial. Crime can't go unpunished. The law is for everyone, and it is for those who were agents on the ground and it is also for those who were the payers of this barbarity committed by the CIA, with European complicity.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Mr. President! Of the 6,200 pages of the US torture report, 525 pages have now become public, and they note that the US has been brutally tortured, and that a death has been documented. And the report states that torture was also useless. But the futility does not matter, torture is always forbidden. The end does not justify the means. Article 5 of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights states that no one should be subjected to torture. First of all, torture belongs to the Middle Ages or to the unjust states, but not to the rule of law of the 21st century. Secondly, anyone who tortures is punished. The perpetrators must be put before national courts or the International Criminal Court. Thirdly, it is therefore high time that the United States also recognised the International Criminal Court and stopped instalyciting crime and protecting criminals.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: Mr President, it is a descent into hell to know the details of the 'advanced interrogation techniques', the euphemism used by the CIA for torture, torture, torture... You have to repeat it many times. This is not the first information we have on this in the European Parliament. A 2012 resolution called for an investigation into the involvement in the detention and torture programme of European countries, and also discussed obstacles to judicial and parliamentary investigations. I am ashamed to know that my country collaborated in these facts, in the abduction and torture of human beings; exactly like the secret prisons of Romania, Poland or Lithuania, or the eighteen Member States that collaborated. The resolution to be adopted must demand condemnation but, above all, an investigation identifying the culprits, the collaborators, and bringing them into the hands of justice. Convictions are not served if repetition is not avoided by chasing the culprits. If not, this European Parliament will have to stop talking about human rights.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Mr President, the report that has just been published reveals that the CIA has been torture for several years. These revelations are not surprising: many examples show that the United States has become an aggressive power that we must be wary of. The WikiLeaks scandal told us in 2013 that the NSA carried out large-scale espionage, even at the expense of allied heads of state or government, such as François Hollande or Angela Merkel. In 1996, the U.S. Congress decided to impose the Helms-Burton and Amato-Kennedy laws on the world, in violation of public international law. In line with these laws, the United States in 2014 imposed a fine of 6.5 billion euros on a French bank, BNP Paribas, simply guilty of working with states on their blacklist. Also in 2014, they deliberately destabilized Ukraine, at the risk of provoking a war with Russia. How many more provocations and humiliations will the European Union endure before it understands that it is time to react by refusing to sign the transatlantic treaty?

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: It is certainly commendable that such a report could have been published in the United States, stating that cia agents had pulled information from suspects using methods incompatible with human rights. However, we must finish the words of praise here, because I am outraged by the relevant practice of the CIA, even though the US President says that the procedure is a thing of the past. Of course, we cannot rule out that other countries are using similar methods, but there is concern that it could happen in the United States: when their interests so require, they put the protection of human rights in brackets. Although the judiciary in the rule of law is sometimes slow and cumberberful, I believe that it is precisely respect for this that distinguishes freedom and justice democracies from other parts of the world. If, in some cases, we do not a respect our own standards, then we have understood nothing of the lessons of the 20th century.

name: Kati PIRI
text: Mr President, the US Senate report has shown that prisoners were tortured on a large scale by the CIA in the period after 9/11. These suspicions were always there, of course, but now it has been proven beyond doubt. And while this has caused a lot of dust on the other side of the ocean, here in Europe it remains anxiously silent. The report does not explicitly refer to it, but it is no secret that European Member States have cooperated in these practices. This Parliament, together with the Council of Europe, played a crucial role a few years ago in highlighting the evidence that, unfortunately, our governments were also involved in illegal shipments, the provision of European safe havens for torture flights and even the inclusion of illegal detention centres on European territory. The same European Union that rightly promotes the rule of law and fundamental rights as a crucial part of our community of values has itself participated in gross human rights violations in the heyday of the fight against international terrorism. The report calls on the U.S. government to deal with the past and learn lessons for the future. I would like to take this opportunity to ask the European Member States the same. It is now really time to be open about working with the CIA. Moreover, it is crucial to the EU's credibility as a champion of global human rights that we come clean with this black page in our recent history. That is why I am also calling on the Commission to launch an investigation into violations of international law on European soil as a result of cooperation with THE US intelligence service. The European Parliament has called for this several times, but this has been refused every time so far. In a democracy, it works in such a way that governments must also be accountable.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: Mr President, this Feinstein report and the extracts from it have cast a dark cloud over the US’s reputation as a defender of democracy and freedom. It has cast a shadow over security services that are supposed to protect the citizens of the world and, as President Obama said himself, the image of the US has been tarnished. Indeed the report has thrown up many questions for European citizens, as well as European governments.  When you condone the use of torture and extreme methods of interrogation, and when you ignore the very values that you are trying to defend, you give fuel to those extremists who are looking for weaknesses. The fight against terrorism is a fight about values and acting contrary to those values is therefore not just wrong but is counterproductive.  The justification of ISIS and similar terror groups is that they are fighting a just war against a powerful tyrant. Torture to the extent that it was spelled out in this report gives fuel to that notion. What message does it send to those who are intent on killing innocent civilians, beheading charity workers and killing aimlessly? The message we send is that there are no limits to depravity. Not only do we fail in our standards of humanity, but we encourage others to disregard human life and suffering. We may now face a scenario whereby seemingly dangerous men and women who are currently detained can use this report to prove that they were tortured to the point of becoming psychologically unstable and their admissions and evidence can no longer be relied on. One could question how many other ongoing trials will face disruption due to the revelations in this report. There are those who argue that the end justifies the means when it comes to protecting our lives. Indeed the Washington Post reported that a new poll shows that 51 % of Americans described the CIA torture methods as justified in that they gleaned information that prevented terrorist attacks. We have the Geneva Convention, the UN Convention on Human Rights and torture conventions. We must not allow these conventions that have been ratified by nearly every country in the world, including the United States, to be set aside and to be rewritten to serve an end. We must not allow standards of humanity at times of conflict to be neglected. We must show leadership in democratic states. We should all lead by example and not stoop to the depraved levels of some terrorist organisations. Justice must be seen to be done from this report. The courts must be allowed to respond and to deal with the findings of this report.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne KAUFMANN
text: Mr. President! Kidnappings, disappearances, days of sleep deprivation, imprisonment in small boxes, sexual abuse, waterboarding – the list of CIA torture practices is long, and it's just creepy. I can only agree with the courageous chairman of the US Senate Intelligence Committee, Dianne Feinstein. But from more than 6,000 pages of secret u.s. Senate report, only 500 have been published, and much of it has been blackened. In other words, the full truth about what happened under the guise of the fight against terrorism is still in the dark.  As a former member of the Temporary Committee, which, as early as 2006, investigated the CIA practices and the involvement of European states in the massive violation of human rights and called for comprehensive clarification, I would like to stress once again today that no end justifies the terrible means used by the CIA. Any use of torture blatantly violates our values.  But pointing the finger at the US is not enough. Whether the motivation was misunderstood loyalty to the alliance or even money flowed, who in Europe was partly responsible for the illegal CIA practices, must be held accountable. We owe that to the victims and to our own credibility. Poland's former president, Kwa niewski, and the former head of Romania's intelligence service, Talpea, have now only now, after the publication of the US Senate report, admitted that US secret prisons existed in their countries. The British government, it was reported in the German press, had urged, before the publication of the Senate report, that evidence of British involvement in the CIA torture programme be blackened. Ducking away, holding, obscuring and denying – the cover-up strategy of governments must finally stop. All EU states have ratified the European Convention on Human Rights, which states in Article 3: 'No one shall be subjected to torture or inhuman or degrading punishment or treatment'. There must be no impunity or speechlessness in the European Union in matters of torture.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Mr President, the report by the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence is a terrible summary of what the CIA did to its 119 prisoners between 2001 and 2009. A number of terrible examples have already been mentioned here today, from waterboarding to 180 hours of sleep and the rectal insertion of food. We rightly express our disgust at this today. There are really no words to express our disgust, but we try to do so anyway. At the same time, many members have rightly pointed out that it is a very important step for this Senate committee to bring out this report, a very important first step towards transparency and self-reflection. This self-reflection is essential if we are to prevent such excesses in the future. It would therefore be good if the full report of the Senate Committee were to be available quickly. I also call on EU countries to take steps in terms of transparency and self-reflection in order to be able to offer such safeguards in Europe as well. In addition, it is interesting to note that this report is only about the 119 prisoners who were tortured on the so-called black sites. What about the tens of thousands of prisoners who have been detained and subjected to the same treatment, for example, in countries such as Afghanistan or Iraq? It would be good if we could also get more information and more transparency on this. Finally, one final point. We live in times with unprecedented and unknown threats and intelligence services are important to ensure our safety and the safety of our citizens. But we can never subordinate human rights to that important work. So let us not get bogged down in a discussion that Dick Cheney and the CIA might like to have about the effectiveness of torture. Torture is unacceptable.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: Mr President, this Parliament must reopen the committee of inquiry which, during 2006 and 2007, tried to establish what happened to CIA flights. The end does not justify the means and democracies must account for both the purposes and the means. We recognize the exemplary work that the U.S. Senate has done, but we can't be left alone in recognizing that exemplary work. This Parliament investigated in 2006 and 2007 – I was a member of that non-permanent committee – with many difficulties, the CIA's flight programme. In the light of the US Senate report, this report by the European Parliament is no longer of use to us. That is why we must reopen that committee of inquiry. We must do this, as the Us Senate has done, without fear of knowing the truth, to purge the responsibilities that arise from it. We owe it to this House, which, I insist, worked with many difficulties. And we owe it to the European citizens, who look at us. You will see, ladies and gentlemen, in order to give lessons — as we are going to do this week — on human rights to Sudan, Mauritania, Venezuela and Egypt, we must first be able to set an example. And this debate, today's, must be the beginning — not the end — of a work that this Parliament has to conclude, which began in 2006 and could not finish. That is what we asked for from the Socialist Group. We need to reopen the commission of inquiry. I'm sorry Mr. Brok's gone. We have to close Guantanamo. Beyond countries welcoming Guantanamo prisoners or not. Because when they opened Guantanamo, they didn't ask anyone's permission.

name: Michał BONI
text: Mr President, justice, freedom and security are the basis of our values. There is no space for torture. We need a responsible assessment of the tools used by the CIA and an evaluation of their consequences. In 2002, the Polish authorities allowed the detention of CIA prisoners suspected of terrorism, but not the use of torture. Although the authorities at that time demanded and requested special memoranda relating to the rules of the functioning of that prison, there was no answer from the US side. In 2009, we signed an agreement with the US on some rules, particularly as regards subjecting American officers in service in Poland to Polish jurisdiction. The Polish Prosecutor is in the process of investigating.  The US Senate report was, and is, the internal duty of the American authorities, but the answer to the question of whether people in my country were tortured is my country’s obligation. However, we should learn our lesson. Anybody can be confronted with the problem of how to ensure the security of our citizens and how to avoid the use of destructive tools when we have a duty to fight with the real threats, namely terrorism, as we have been reminded by what happened in the last two days.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the recent report by the US Senate on the use of torture by the CIA raises many questions about human rights violations and does not weaken its drama simply because it confronts a programme that has been shut down by President Obama. We learn about the technique of water boarding, of defined techniques of total control over the prisoner. These events do not deserve comment but only pity for the prisoner, whoever he is. It is believed that the delays with which the information was made can be of medicine to the heinousness. It was said "they are dated events, past events now". But that's not the case. If we are to set an example of civilisation, we must have the courage to condemn in no uncertain terms the gestures of this kind, which in the mortification of the other human being challenge the principles of European democracy and transcendence, the inspiration of our deeds to something higher than man himself. The European Union must condemn all forms of torture and ill-treatment of detainees in all circumstances, including when it comes to the fight against terrorism. Human life cannot be considered collateral damage, they point to a dusty map, existential statistics.

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: Mr President, days ago the Pope stood in this very Chamber and told us that when Europe is not anchored to its values it sets itself adrift. It is very easy to point the finger at this Chamber and say: you are being soft on terrorism and terrorists.
