But I stand as somebody who has faced the machine guns of the Taliban and survived, and faced far-right extremists as well. Those who attack us attack us because they want to take our values away from us. Do not allow them to take from us through our reaction what they could never take from us through their actions.  I do not just stand in criticism of the USA today. I stand to criticise all those who stood by and watched silently – that includes some of our governments. Others went further and facilitated these illegal methods also. Today we have no guarantees that any of our citizens could not face such acts again and our governments are still concealing facts. We have a choice, colleagues: either we unite behind our values or we divide and face the consequences.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: Mr. President, I fully support the very clear positions of the Commission, the Council regarding respect for the law, respect for international law and respect for human rights and general democratic values in general. I am glad that this was more or less unanimous in the European Parliament, there were some lonely voices who spoke differently, but there are countries, countries of the developed democratic world where it is not so self-visible that in relation to the security of citizens and the protection of human rights, human rights is so clearly set aside.  That is why it is important to emphasize what Mr. President Obama did, his administration and of course parts of the Senate, that is, some senators who said it was a violation of American values and who prohibited torture, which is bringing European political culture closer to American political culture and this should certainly be welcomed.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: Mr President, the issue is the use of torture by the CIA, but it links directly with Member States of the European Union, both because of its complicity with the CIA detention centre plan in Europe and because here in the European Union it is also tortured. The Commissioner recalled this by stressing that the European Commission is fighting for the eradication of torture both in the European Union and in the rest of the world. And he has also talked about prosecuting the culprits—that it doesn't happen as in the United States, where President Obama has just given official certificate to impunity. Here in Europe, at a political trial in Madrid against 28 young Basques, the Spanish State has been found, based on the implementation of the Istanbul Protocol, that they were tortured and, just two months ago, the European Court of Human Rights once again condemned the Spanish State for not investigating allegations of torture brought by Basque or Catalan citizens.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on 11 January 2002, the first US military aircraft landed in Guantanamo Bay with a cargo of more than 200 suspected terrorists. The suspected terrorists were waiting for 18 months of isolation, less than an hour a day outside the cell, methods of interrogation worthy of the most inhumane Middle Ages. For 13 years, there have been thousands of complaints from journalists, non-governmental organisations and insiders in various secret PRISONS across the United States around the world. The European Parliament has also discussed the subject on several occasions and expressed its concerns through resolutions. But many Member States, at the same time, cooperated with the CIA and its brutal methods, regardless of human rights. Obama, on the campaign trail, had openly sided against certain CIA practices and the Guantanamo center, but he probably also suffers from short memory. European states should condemn and never endorse or support the horrific torture practised by the American Government.

name: Δημήτρης Αβραμόπουλος
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, the debate in this area on the Senate report has brought to light, together with the evidence given to us in the report, a harsh reality, a harsh truth and puts all of us truly before our responsibilities. And it is worth welcoming this report. I note that all the forces of the democratic arc in this area strongly condemn torture and any practice that moves outside the limits of the rule of law, respect for human rights, the principles and values on which the European edifice is founded. I said in my recommendation that torture is a crime and those who are accountable are the responsibility of the states themselves to punish them. But there has also been criticism in this area: that Europe has in many cases tolerated them. I want to assure you that Europe has never adopted these practices that offend democracy and human rights. In fact, for the short time I have been with you, what I see in front of me every day is our obligation to protect them. The work of today's assembly as well as the investigation of the United States Senate Committee demonstrate the fundamental role played by democratic control, democratic oversight of national security and law enforcement. The practices that have emerged through the debate and that we have discussed here today show that the defence and promotion of fundamental rights require constant efforts and vigilance. And, yes, I will agree with you that the responsibility is shared by everyone – and by the Member States. And I am sure that the President-in-Office of the European Council, who is here today, will take Parliament's concerns and concerns to the Member States. But I would remind you of something very important – because some aphorisms have also been heard: that the investigation of the Committee of the United States Senate is the result of democratic and parliamentary scrutiny. We welcome it as a mature reaction of a democratic society and remind ing that democracy has the institutions, it has the strength and the will to protect people and their rights. At this point I would like to make a reference to something important, in my opinion, that President Obama said, who, as you know, banned torture when he took over as President: "Today's report can help us leave these techniques where they belong - in the past." Some of the Members referred to Guantánamo. You have heard the Commission's position at the beginning, and I repeat it. And our position is clear and consistent. Yes, we're calling for the closure of Guantánamo. We have consistently adhered to this attitude not only with regard to the indefinite detention of terrorism suspects at Guantánamo but – I remind you – also to the death penalty, the imprisonment of minors and other important human rights issues. Reference was also made to counter-terrorism cooperation between the European Union and the United States of America. This cooperation is very important for European security and the protection of our peoples. At European Union level we have concluded agreements with the United States of America on a number of initiatives that facilitate this cooperation and make it more effective and always in line with fundamental rights. The European Union and its Member States as well as the United States of America have a shared responsibility to ensure that their counter-terrorism cooperation fully respects fundamental rights and the rule of law and, where appropriate, international humanitarian and refugee law. We, and I would like to assure you of this, will continue to raise and discuss these issues with the United States of America and, where necessary, express our concerns and concerns and our proposals for situations that are contrary to the values and principles on which the European Union is founded, to the same values and principles on which the American democratic structure is based. The particular attention paid by the European Parliament to these issues gives us political support and democratic control, to ensure that all concerns are addressed in a balanced and correct manner, which at the same time does not allow us to rest. The main conclusion from this debate today is that the European Union and its democratic institutions are the guardians of our fundamental human rights, human dignity and democratic conquests.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for this frank and open exchange of views. As I have already said, it is important to ensure that the abuses referred to in the US Senate report – and which have been mentioned today – never happen again and that human rights are fully respected in the fight against terrorism. I believe that the European Parliament has an important role to play in the transatlantic debate on counter-terrorism and international law and human rights. It is important for you to be able to address members of the US Congress to express your views on counter-terrorism policy and we have already seen that the concerns expressed by allies may influence the policy of the United States of America. Congress is now discussing the important issue of surveillance and data protection and respect for privacy. Congress voted against a bill that would reform one of several programs that fundamentally affected Americans. It will be important for the European Parliament to express its views in the UNITED States Congress, to respect the protection of the privacy of the citizens of the European Union. The European Parliament could also play an important role vis-à-vis the parliaments of the countries of the Middle East and North Africa, in particular those involved in security reforms, so that effective control mechanisms are put in place in these countries. As I said at the beginning, cooperation between the European Union and the United States of America on counter-terrorism is and remains essential. The European Parliament has an important role to play with regard to the relevant instruments: the terrorist finance tracking programme and the passenger name record between the European Union and the United States and the Safe Harbour Agreement. It is important to have effective instruments to protect privacy and fundamental rights. Both the European Union and the United States of America are facing a serious terrorist threat today, particularly from ISIL and foreign fighters. We also need sophisticated data tools to deal with the threat in a way that respects human rights. I am sure that this debate on counter-terrorism and human rights will continue between the two sides of the Atlantic in this Parliament.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Minister, if you want to intervene in the form of a yellow card, you cannot. Representatives of the Commission and the Council may not be questioned in this form. If you want to talk about something else, you have the word.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: Mr President, this concerns the agenda because we asked the Council to make a statement about the matter that we have been discussing here all afternoon. I note that neither in its introduction, nor in its concluding remarks, has the Council said anything about its role. So I consider there has not been a statement from the Council about when they discussed the CIA strategy at the time and discussed supporting it. So I consider that the Council was not here, has not responded and did not make a statement.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The motions for resolutions to be submitted in accordance with Article 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure shall be announced at a later date. The debate has been closed. The vote will take place during the February i. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. Once again, we suddenly discover the clear evidence that the American secret services are torturing prisoners, not only at home but also at home. This is not the first time this has happened, it seems rather to be a cyclical path, a déjà-vu: unclear operations are brought to light, a scapegoat is identified, the CIA sprinkles its head with ash and then after some time we start all over again. Always to the outrage of the press and world public opinion, but without identifying the real culprits. A sterile and hypocritical tiritera.  We condemn without ifs and buts the use of these techniques unworthy of a democracy. Indeed, Europe must remind its friend and historical ally that no kind of torture can be tolerated: it is unacceptable that these brutalities have been used, and even more so on the territory of the Union. Longtime friends must have the frankness to reproach each other when they make mistakes, otherwise they are no longer friends. They're accomplices.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: in writing. – The topic of CIA secret prisons and practices during the ʽwar on terrorʼ keeps regularly surfacing. Most of the times, that re-surfacing is due to journalistic investigation based on ʽundisclosedʼ sources which, because of their anonymity, cannot be challenged. The difference this time is that the report is authored by the US Senate, until recently dominated by the Democrats. Consequently, the report has come under heavy attack from an array of personalities and institutions – many directly linked to the political and security sectors – for political bias and incorrectness. Romania was a ʽtargetʼ from the very beginning, although the site of the so-called secret detention facility kept circling around – the MK Air Base, Bucharest, Dobrogea, etc. Even if the US Senate Report does not mention any country, journalistic articles were capable of ʽidentifyingʼ it, again based exclusively on ʽjournalistic sourcesʼ linked to the Washington Post newspaper! It is clear that, under the circumstances, the report is being used as an opportunity to name countries which otherwise are not named. If torture and illegal practices against anybody, including notorious criminals who have the blood of thousands on their hands, are unacceptable, than pure political speculation is equally unacceptable.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: in writing. – The US Senate Report documenting CIA torture of alleged terrorists raises a number of fundamental questions about the nature and operations of the vast secret police networks which span the globe. The report details harsh CIA interrogation techniques, including CIA officers threatening to hurt, rape, and kill family members of detainees, but it omits the wider scope of violent activity in which the CIA continues to be involved. This is simply unacceptable. It is also disgraceful that, despite over 6 000 pages of documents and testimony, recording crimes against humanity, the report is unlikely to trigger any trials or resignations. The Scottish Government is demanding answers from the UK and if we, in this Chamber, represent countries that were directly or indirectly involved in these shameful practices it is our responsibility to put pressure on our respective governments and to conduct a thorough inquiry at the EU level. Member States’ agencies should not have been in the business of kidnapping and ‘rendering’ and I urge my colleagues from countries like Poland, Romania, Lithuania and others to press for judicial inquiries, as we need a full explanation of what happened in our name on our soil.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Writing. – The modern international and European legal arsenal is undoubtedly based on an unwavering central axis: the absolute protection of human rights, including an explicit ban on the use of torture for any reason. Unfortunately, this debate opens on the occasion of an unpleasant revelation, such as that European territory was recently used by the C.I.A. to torture terrorist suspects in order to confess. Although the European Union, through its institutional and legal tools, has often condemned such behaviour, one can reasonably wonder what is going on behind closed doors, especially given the intensified fight against terrorism and the effort to prevent any terrorist attack in Europe. Not to mention modern forms of torture, which we hear professionals inventing and applying to this end on the altar of high profit. It therefore seems that despite our strict legal tradition, which is vertically opposed to such practices, we must also be vigilant in the EU about the self-evident right to protection against all forms of state or police violence, which can ultimately be exercised under our tolerance or ignorance, but thus making us accomplices. In the Europe of Justice, torture cannot be allowed or even forgiven.

name: Yana TOOM
text: in writing. –  The US Senate’s report on post-9/11 CIA torture revealed shocking truths about the ‘enhanced interrogation techniques’ (in fact torture) used against foreign prisoners in overseas prisons, including, inter alia, rectal rehydration, sleep deprivation, standing for long periods and threats to family members of prisoners. Several countries hosted US detention centres, including three EU Member States – Poland, Romania and Lithuania. These activities cannot be justified at all. According to the UN Convention against Torture (1984), no exceptional circumstances may be invoked as a justification for torture (Article 2). It is very worrying that the ‘techniques’ were previously authorised by US authorities. I welcome the publication of the Senate’s report. Regrettably, former high-ranking officials in the US still try to justify these ‘techniques’ that have proved to be largely ineffective. The fight against terrorism, the democratic image of both the US and EU, the positive character of US-EU cooperation are heavily compromised. It is appropriate to insist on punishment of public officials in the US and EU responsible for systemic and outrageous breaches of fundamental rights. Europe cannot serve as a beacon of democracy if no appropriate measures are taken in Poland, Romania and Lithuania – all three countries were actively involved in moulding European Neighbourhood Policy.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. – This report only demonstrates what has already been known – that the US is an imperialist power that considers itself above any legal obligation, which disrespects international law and which, ironically, has been continuously occupying several sovereign countries in the name of defending human rights. The torture practices revealed in this report are brutal, but were evidently not unknown to the US government, as it was President Bush himself who approved the CIA's Detention and Interrogation Program with enhanced interrogation techniques. President Obama, despite all the regrets he has now uttered, did not end the illegal Guantánamo prison and has appointed as CIA Director one of the most staunch advocates of torture in the Bush era, John Brennan, which reveals not a cut, but a continuity, in the cia's action. , through the kidnappings, arrests and illegal transport of these prisoners who were tortured. What is required is that justice be done and that, at the national level, as well as at THE LEVEL of the United Nations, those responsible and compensated for the victims should be condemned.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the Statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on freedom of expression in Turkey: the recent arrests of journalists and media executives and the systematic pressure exerted against the media. (2014/3011(RSP))

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking on behalf of the High Representative/Vice-President.  Last Sunday, raids by the Turkish police led to the arrest of numerous journalists and members of the media in Turkey. We have all followed this matter very closely. The High Representative/Vice-President, Mr Mogherini, and Commissioner Hahn issued a statement on Sunday afternoon, stressing unequivocally that the attacks and arrests that have taken place are incompatible with the freedom of the press, a fundamental principle of democracy. The declaration also expressed the hope that the principle of the presumption of innocence would be respected and recalled the inviolable right to an independent and transparent investigation, in the event of alleged wrongdoing, in full respect of the right of defence of the persons concerned.  Obviously, illegal acts must be punished, but always within the framework of the rule of law and respecting the principle of proportionality. Yesterday, the Council also discussed the situation and adopted clear and decisive conclusions on the expectations of the European Union and Turkey's obligations as a candidate country.  The Council of Europe's Commissioner for Human Rights, Nils Muižnieks, expressed deep concern about Sunday's events as a serious step backwards for media freedom in that country. This Parliament has also made its voice heard, and there are many of you, together with President Schulz, who have expressed your concerns about the latest developments, and this debate must enable us to strengthen the message we want to send to Turkey. We all agree that Turkey, as a candidate country, must aspire to the highest levels of democratic guarantees in terms of both standards and practices. This includes full respect for freedom of expression, which is essential for the real and exercise of a number of other human rights, including freedom of association and assembly and freedom of thought and religion or belief. Democracy cannot exist without these freedoms. In its 2014 progress report on Turkey, the Commission welcomed the positive developments in turkey, such as the democratisation package, the action plan against human rights violations, the rulings of the Turkish Constitutional Court and the active efforts to find a solution to the Kurdish question. At the same time, the report expressed concern about a number of developments which, on the other hand, threaten, in particular, the independence of the judiciary and freedom of expression. The problems with freedom of the press and freedom of expression in Turkey are not new: we have seen repression against journalists and social media, following the protests at Gezi Park. During the recent political dialogue and in bilateral meetings, the European Union reiterated that the accession process remains the keystone of relations between the European Union and Turkey and, at the same time, expressed its concern about the rule of law and fundamental freedoms, in particular freedom of expression, stressing that the main driving force behind this process is developments on the ground in Turkey in the first place, with regard to the rule of law and fundamental rights. During their recent visit to Turkey together with Commissioner Stylianides, High Representative/Vice-President Mogherini and Commissioner Hahn stressed that the rule of law and fundamental freedoms are essential areas in which Turkey must make progress. All turkish interlocutors reaffirmed the importance of relations between the European Union and Turkey and welcomed the joint visit. They have all expressed their commitment to the process of accession to the European Union and the strong political will to take it forward and to advance political reforms. High Representative Mogherini and Commissioners Hahn and Stylianides reaffirmed that this strong commitment to the European Union expressed by our Turkish counterparts during the visit must be translated into action. The Member States of the European Union have repeatedly stressed that Turkey is an essential partner and agree that it is important to send a clear message to it on the need to advance reforms aimed at establishing appropriate checks and balances in order to fully protect freedom, which includes freedom of thought, expression and the press. The Member States also recalled that the progress of the accession negotiations depends on respect for the rule of law and fundamental rights. The European Union stands ready to support Turkey's efforts in this area. We believe that the accession process remains the best framework for advancing and support reforms in Turkey. The European Union's position on this point is very clear and has been conveyed to the Turkish interlocutors with absolute clarity and consistency. The European Union has the right and the duty to follow issues of this kind closely in a candidate country and we now await a constructive engagement on the part of Turkey with regard to these concerns. In my opinion, this means continuing in good faith on the road to accession, we must make the most of the instruments we have and Turkey needs to cooperate with us. I hope that the Turkish Government's commitment to the European Union will bear fruit. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, allow me to assure you once again that this issue is a priority for the European Union and that we will continue to follow it closely. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your attention and I look forward to hearing your views in the debate.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to say at the outset that I speak as a friend of Turkey. I am not, in other words, one of those politicians who are building a career by opposing this candidate country to the Union. Just as a friend I must say that I am concerned, I am very concerned about the recent wave of arrests and the general attitude towards the media in Turkey. At this point it seems to me that the intention of Turkish politicians to join the Union and build a democratic society is no longer at all clear, and I ask them directly the question: 'where in this regard?'. Those who have remained, I believe, the main supporters of accession, the Turkish businessmen, are also extremely concerned and this, of course, must raise a question mark first and foremost with the authorities in Turkey. As far as I am concerned, I continue to support the setting of benchmarks for the opening of negotiating chapters 23 and 24. It is a position that has already been voted on in the last resolution on the progress report on Turkey. I believe that in this way we could contribute to the debate taking place in Turkey on these subjects. I conclude by saying that the European Union does not send a clear message if it will continue to negotiate with a country that has so many problems, such as Turkey, taking apart from discussions about the candidacy of a country like Moldova, which is a stable country and which is much more advanced now than Turkey.

name: Kati PIRI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, at the core of the accession process is the respect for the rule of law and fundamental rights. Free and pluralistic media are an essential component of any democracy. I am therefore deeply concerned about what happened last Sunday when media outlets were raided by the Turkish police and critical journalists were arrested. At times when Turkey was already coming in for criticism about press freedom and judicial independence, this counts as another blow. Should the detainees be charged with alleged wrongdoings, we expect that a due process will be conducted whereby the principle of presumption of innocence will prevail, and an independent, transparent investigation will be conducted. Last week I visited Turkey as the European Parliament’s rapporteur. There was a clear understanding from the side of the government that further reforms are needed. Therefore I welcomed the statement by the government that the EU accession process, further democratisation and the Kurdish settlement process are its first priorities. The fact that we are concerned about the deteriorating situation of fundamental rights and the rule of law in the country actually shows our commitment to the accession process. But in the end it is the Turkish Government which sits behind the steering wheel. The events of 14 December caused serious concerns in the EU about Turkish willingness to make progress in the field of democratic reforms. In the weeks to come, therefore, it is up to Ankara to convince us that it is still truly committed to moving closer to the EU and its core values. The accession process is a unique opportunity for Turkey to develop a strong pluralistic democratic system with solid institutions for the benefit of all citizens of Turkey. However, a crackdown on critical media is moving Turkey further away from these core European values, and that is bad news for anyone who is a friend of Turkey.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, whatever our views on the policies of the Turkish government, we must acknowledge Turkey’s importance as a country. But ever since acquiring EU candidate status in 2005, the accession process was always going to be a challenging one for such a large, relatively poor country, with a very different heritage from Western Europe’s. So far, only one chapter of 33 has been opened and closed, as Turkey still refuses to recognise the Republic of Cyprus. The decline of secular Turkey and the rise to power of the Islamist AKP has posed new challenges as President Erdoğan’s increasingly erratic authoritarian approach takes on the students, the army, journalists and now the rival Islamist group, the Gülenists, who have dared challenge the corruption and obstruction of justice in that country. Erdoğan has also backtracked on the PKK ceasefire negotiations, and only under huge NATO pressure has he finally agreed to allow support for beleaguered Kurdish forces in Kobani, as he sees brutal ISIS as less of a threat to Turkish interests than the secular PKK.  There has also been Western alarm about Turkey’s alleged support to ihadists in Egypt, Iraq and Syria, but despite all this, we all still hope that Turkey may still change course towards a more Western path it once held.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, our dream of a European Turkey has turned into a nightmare and it is time for a wake-up call. I was among those critical friends of Turkey who argued that an ongoing membership process helps reforms, but reality suggests the opposite. Last weekend’s arrest of journalists is part of a trend of government-led breaches of fundamental freedoms and the rule of law in Turkey. Only a week after a high-level EU delegation visited Ankara, relations have now hit another low point. There was reason for concern before. After corruption allegations included Erdoğan – then Prime Minister, now President – and key members of his Cabinet, hundreds of police officers and prosecutors were relocated and threatened with prosecution. Those threats have now materialised and are also being used on journalists, while Turkey already held the world record for imprisoned journalists. The obvious question is why the EU would act firmly only now. It comes down to our fears of Turkey sliding ever further away from democracy if the negotiations were to stop. Yet too many watershed moments have passed without serious criticism from Europe, from the banning of an unpublished book by Ahmet Şik to mass arrests and trials without due process. The witch-hunt of Gülen supporters is only the latest in a long list of rule of law violations. Members of the Fethullah Gülen Hizmet Movement and the AKP have created monsters together by helping each other in a coalition that long turned against everything on their combined path. Now they are turning against each other, leading to even more violations of the rule of law. Today there are masses of people in Turkey who live in fear for their future – women, academics, artists, business leaders and, frankly, anyone who is critical of the government. Losing a job or a licence, receiving a tax fine or even being prosecuted for attempting to overthrow the government have become common tools to punish opponents, while laws were passed placing members of the security establishment and government officials above those laws. It is time to tell the AKP government that it is not business as usual. Europe has to show that there is an end to the violations of the rule of law.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, the problem we are discussing cannot be seen as an isolated issue. Something is wrong in the kingdom of Turkey and we must recognise that. So it is not just the recent arrests; it is not just the violation of freedom of speech. They are the runs in Gezi Park; is Turkey's attitude to Kobani; is Turkey's attitude towards Kurdish; is the country's attitude towards Cyprus, the casus belli against Greece; is attitudes towards women and minorities; is Mr Erdogan's attitude, an attitude of obsolescence towards the decisions of the European Parliament; An attitude that says our resolutions will take the lead on the wastebasket. We, as Cypriot MEPs, are not happy about them at all. We want a democratic neighbour, a country that respects human rights, its neighbours and the principles of international law. I absolutely believe that Turkey must get a clear and hard message from the European Union; and a clear message means sanctions for her behaviour. The caresses and caresses won't help at all. They will either understand which way to go or continue the work. I am sure that, without this measure, the sanctions measure, and this debate and the possible resolution that will follow, will take the familiar path of the cane. A clear message means sanctions, but it also means honesty on our part about its accession path. I call on you to rein in this unjust behavior. I call on you to stand up to Mr Erdogan's caliphate.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to say one thing in advance: I believe that we should all realise in this debate – this is also an appeal to the Davutoglu Government and to President Erdogan – that Turkey and the European Union share major challenges along Turkey's borders. The war in Syria, but also ISIS, these are challenges that we must continue to face together, as well as the huge humanitarian catastrophe, the avalanche of refugees in the region. This must not be forgotten in this debate as common challenges. Nevertheless, it is right to be critical, very critical, about what happened last weekend. We must place the arrests and charges against journalists and policemen, as well as the searches of editorial offices, politically in things that have happened before and which are likely to continue to happen if we do not intervene more vehemently. For some time now, the government has seen all the activities of opponents – including not just the Gülen movement and its media – as preparation for the conspiracy against the state or as a preparation for the coup against President Erdogan and his majority government. I think it is completely unhealthy that in Turkey the Gezi protests, demonstrations against ISIS, demonstrations for the victims of Kobane, funerals, all of this is now seen as part of a great conspiracy. If we now criticise what happened last weekend, then we really need to address this as a whole as a problem that arises between the majority that the government represents and the minorities. There is no longer any respect for minority rights, criticism is seen as a call to a coup. We cannot tolerate this.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: On the other: The EFDD Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Turkey is once again trampling on freedom of expression. Journalists are arrested and the media are constantly subjected to pressure and censorship. No country has been convicted as often in the European Court of Human Rights for violations of freedom of expression as Turkey. It is a clear repressive policy, but it is wrapped in beautiful covers and sounding words. Despite pressure from the EUROPEAN Union, Turkey has not changed its mind, and I welcome the fact that the Commission is protesting against these systematic crimes to which Turkey is subjecting its citizens.  Some previous events worth mentioning are the newspaper Azadiya Welat which has been closed as many as 8 times. The former editor-in-chief of vedat Kurşun newspaper is serving a 166-year prison sentence and nine journalists from the same newspaper are in prison. A few years ago, the reporter Ersin Çelik was sentenced to 6 years in prison, and at the same time the journalist Metin Alataş from said Azadiya Welat was found hanged in a tree.  Moreover, the EU is pouring money into this sham democracy. In 2013, more than EUR 900 million from the EU budget went to Turkey. Money that Turkey received against a promise to, among other things, improve its abysmal rule of law, its non-existent freedom of expression and its rampant corruption. Was this money well spent? It is clear to me that Turkey will probably never be able to meet the Copenhagen criteria.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is incredible how we have been trying to bring Turkey to Europe for 15 years. A state that has been militarily occupying part of Cyprus for 40 years, which is a Member State of the European Union, , having destroyed churches and made them in all colours. A reality that does not recognise the genocide of the Armenians: one million dead. I recommend to our friends in Turkey the reading of "The Lark Farm", to give away, for this Christmas. And we, despite this, are now surprised because they have arrested about twenty journalists. Are we really kidding? Turkey is not Europe: it can never be Europe in this respect. We could think about it, we could have trade relations, we could have economic relations, we could have strategic relations. Let's keep paying them! Well, that's what I don't understand. A state that has been militarily occupying another Member State of the European Union for 40 years, which does not recognise that it has massacred a million people – and next April will be the centenary of the Armenian genocide; I would like to see whether this building will remember the centenary of the Armenian genocide – and yet we continue to give it eur 600 million a year. Italy and Europe are giving Turkey 600 million this year, short manus, cash with no-go, 600 million: 600 million next year, 600 million in two years' time, 600 million in three years' time, and they are using this money in return to arrest journalists and compete with our companies. Let us face it once and for all that Turkey will never be Europe and we will all be more serious. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Blue card question. I wanted to hear from Mr Beazley whether he is not in a Salvini considers the same things he said about Turkey even compared to Putin's Russia. He spoke of the occupation of territory: I am thinking of the illegal annexation of Crimea, the clashes that are there in the east of the country in Ukraine; he spoke of a violation of rights: I wonder what he thinks about Russia in this regard.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: Answer to a blue card question. I imagine that this is a joke, I imagine it is a joke, given that in Crimea they voted in a referendum where 95% of citizens, complete with international observers, decided to be Crimea. I therefore take the honourable Member's speech as a nice pre-Christmas provocation, bearing in mind that we give Turkey EUR 600 million a year; we are giving Russia economic sanctions that are bringing a country to its knees against our own interests. So I take it as a joke and avoid answering.

name: Renate SOMMER
text: Mr. President! The restrictions on freedom of expression and the press in Turkey, which is really not new, we have had for years. Critics are silenced, arrested, convicted under the Anti-Terrorism Act, and a caricature is enough to be silenced accordingly. Social media has been shut down and now the latest act: last Sunday's raid and arrests.  But this is, of course, incompatible with our fundamental values in the EU. Freedom of expression and freedom of the press are indispensable in a democracy, as we obviously cannot say enough to Turkey. A state that so arbitrarily restricts these fundamental rights and freedoms is undemocratic and can never become a member of the European Union. However, Turkey does not meet the other Copenhagen political pre-accession criteria on any single point. This is also evident, for example, in the prevention of the investigation of allegations of corruption against the political elite, against members of the government a year ago. Files were confiscated, officers who investigated, transferred or dismissed in the police and jurisdiction. To this day, there is no enlightenment, because President Erdogan does not want it. After all, his son is also under suspicion. So the rule of law does not exist in Turkey either, only the self-aggrandism of President Erdogan. This country is undergoing a dramatic regression, and I do not think we can allow that to happen. We must protest against this. As the European Union, we must finally abandon our naivety towards the country, finally consider what sanctions we can impose.  Finally, Mr President, allow me to do so: I appeal to the Turkish Constitutional Court to put a stop to this development. Such continuous violations of fundamental rights may not be permitted.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: Mr President, nobody is safe in Turkey right now. Those are the words of a human rights defender speaking to me on the phone earlier from the front line in Turkey. Why are they not safe? As Federica Mogherini and Commissioner Hahn said in their joint statements, the police raids and arrests of a number of journalists and media representatives in Turkey today are incompatible with freedom of the media, which is a core principle of democracy. Human rights activists, ordinary journalists and people opposing the government are deeply worried by a pattern of curtailment of media freedoms and questions being raised about the independence of the judiciary.  This week’s wave of harassment, under accusations of founding a terror organisation seeking to overthrow the government, indicates the problems with Turkey’s broad based anti-terrorism law, as these accusations are some of the most serious charges which can be levelled under the country’s penal code. Human rights activists in Turkey have told me that those arrested are not clear of what charges they are being arrested under; they are being arrested and detained, and I quote: ‘without concrete evidence, under vague charges and without a clear indictment’. This is clearly in contravention of the European Convention, Articles 5 and 6: the right to liberty and to a fair trial.  I appreciate that Volkan Bozkır, the Minister of EU Affairs, provided assurances to the Commission – as he has done to us – that Turkey seeks to uphold the rule of law. It is right that Turkey, with its geographical and political role in the on-going fight against terrorism, has anti-terrorism legislation. However, if it is correct – as widely reported – that members of the opposition and journalists are getting arrested and having to prove their innocence while prosecutors fail to provide evidence of any criminal activity, then Turkey may be talking about the rule of law, but failing to uphold it in practice. Finally, Mr President, for those who have queued up to use this yet again to make threats about the accession process, the lesson in this for me is more engagement with Turkey not less. Let us have our resolution in January condemning, in strong terms, the treatment of journalists, but let our rapporteur do her job in committee to draw up a resolution in the interests of Turkey as a country and of the Turkish people. (The speaker agreed to take two blue-card questions under Rule 162(8))

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: blue-card question. –  Richard Howitt, you have a reputation of being a strong friend of Turkey – indeed you founded the Friends of Turkey in the previous Parliament. Of course, it is interesting to me to hear what you have to say today, in a very critical tone, on the subject of human rights, democracy and the rule of law in Turkey. Would you join me in agreeing that if these breaches persist, we should be in this Parliament reviewing the hundreds of millions of euros of taxpayers’ money from the European Union going towards EPA funding for Turkey? Otherwise, what sanctions do we have against a candidate country undergoing the accession process?

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: "blue card" question. – I would like you to tell me what you think – after expressing your opinion on Turkey, which we all know violates human rights and persecutes political thought – about the persecutions taking place in Greece against the Golden Dawn People's League? Our leader and eight Members are on remand on unsubstantiated charges and it is so hypocritical that no one in this house is dealing with this issue.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: blue-card answer to two questions. – Mr Fountoulis, I absolutely agree that all breaches of human rights must be condemned equally and fairly and objectively, but what worried me about this debate is that I have heard people who are all too willing to queue up to criticise Turkey but who then, in relation to other countries in other situations, have prejudices which lead them to fail to do so. Let us be consistent ourselves in upholding human rights. To my friend Mr Tannock, other than wishing him Happy Christmas, I think it is fair to say that whilst I am a friend of Turkey – and I am happy to be described as such, I love the country, I want it to join the European Union – that is why I do not like what I see there today. It is fair to say that he has a different point of view and he would probably have that point of view irrespective of what has happened over the weekend. I was talking to Commissioner Hahn today and said to him that we do not want pre-emptive action in relation to accession, and Commissioner Hahn told me that he was of a similar mind. Let us condemn what is happening in Turkey, but then let us reflect on how we can best help the situation there.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: Mr President! There is reason to remind the Turkish Government of the old word: that you can cheat a part of the population and that you might be able to cheat the whole population part of the time, but you can never cheat the whole population all the time! This should be borne in mind in Ankara, where it seems to believe that one can be completely uncompromisingly and unscrupulously deceived its own citizens into believing that Turkey can become a member of the European Union, even if it does not want to meet the criteria and, moreover, behaves a regular bully both externally and internally. You think you can deceive the European Union by luring you to be the so-called 'bridge of the Middle East', but the truth is that, in all the time it has been negotiating with Turkey, Turkey has moved in exactly the opposite direction of what the intention was. Turkey is moving further and further away from the EU; Turkey does not belong in the EUROPEAN Union! That is why there is reason to look at alternatives, to stop the membership negotiations and to focus on what is actually possible: free trade cooperation and joint technical cooperation in trade, the environment, exchange students, what do I know! But membership – it's obvious to everyone – it's completely unrealistic!

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: . Mr President, Minister, what happened in Turkey last Sunday is akin to a meticulously prepared round-up against independent journalists who are listened to by the general public. In thirteen cities of the country, journalists, editors of publications, the president of a television channel were arrested. Their only wrong is to investigate the regime's policies and tell the truth about corruption. And now, according to reports, 150 journalists are threatened with arrest by the end of this month. The European authorities must be extremely firm in the face of these serious violations of freedom of information. There is no democracy without it and I believe, Minister, on behalf of the Council, that you should not accept Mr Erdogan's morgue. Now we need to step up the pressure to release all journalists imprisoned or in police custody and to stop these attacks on press freedom. Let us put our institutions at the service of journalists under threat and forcefully denounce the interference and pressure exerted by the Turkish authorities on the judiciary. The European Union must stop placing its trade or foreign policy above the fundamental principle of freedom and the right to inform and be informed and that of the independence of the judiciary; on the contrary, it must use this lever of influence so that states that are considered our partners respect human rights and freedoms above all. For us, human rights come before the law of markets.

name: Ska KELLER
text: Mr. President! What is happening in Turkey at the moment is nothing but a poorly concealed attack on freedom of the press and freedom of expression. Journalists are accused and abducted on absurd charges. People who took to the streets during the Gezi protests are also now being charged for allegedly making coup attempts, while police forces who have used violence are not being prosecuted. President Erdogan is obviously trying to keep any criticism of him quiet and to prevent it. But this is completely the wrong way to go about an emerging democracy. Turkey can only benefit from a vibrant civil society and a critical press. I hope that Erdogan will finally see this. Without the rule of law and without democratic standards, Turkey will not make progress. But the EU, and the Member States in particular, have also done something wrong here. Because if Member States always block the accession process, close chapters, when they say that Turkey cannot join anyway, no matter what it does, no matter what standards it complies with, then we are not helping civil society, then we are not helping the critical voices, but we are preventing us from having a lever now, for example, to really have serious talks with Turkey. In this way, we take the instruments out of our hands. We need to improve on that. In general, human rights and justice should be at the forefront of an accession process, much more than any rules from the internal market. We must do the same for the future.

name: James CARVER
text: Mr President, I add my voice of support to the widespread condemnation of the attitude of Turkey towards imprisoning journalists and, like many, abhor this blatant attempt to curb freedom of expression.  President  and his AKP Party, one of whose members recently called for a ban on women being able to laugh in the street are, of course, allied to the British Conservatives. is undermining the secular identity of the Turkish State to the extent that Kemal Atatürk must now be turning in his grave. However, what I find really confusing is the fact that in my country it is only UKIP that opposes Turkish entry into the EU. The idea that the free movement of 83 million Turkish citizens will not impact on an already pestiferous immigration debate in my country is clearly lost on the British Conservative, Labour and Liberal Democratic parties. EU membership would allow unemployed people in Turkey to travel freely to and seek work in any other Member State. With an official figure of 2.98 million unemployed, unofficial estimates as high as 5.5 million, any flow of migration would inevitably be towards job-creating economies such as the UK. Turkey is currently home to some 1.6 million refugees – many from Syria and Iraq. As a new Member State she might well become a new gateway to Europe for an unprecedented number of refugees fleeing conflict in the Middle East. As a Member State there would be very little possibility of stopping these refugees from moving freely within a passportless Europe. The Prime Minister’s pledge on Turkey joining the EU quite frankly needs stopping. It only leaves me to wish my colleagues, irrespective of our differences, a happy Hanukkah and a merry Christmas and a happy New Year.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Erdogan recently said he does not accept lessons in democracy from Europe. Once a farmer, in the winter, found an icy snake, gutted it, took it and put it on its horn. The snake at one point, after it warmed up and recovered, stung its benefactor. Psyching out, he said, "Well, I'm going to get hurt, since I felt sorry for a bad guy." The aforementioned fairy tale is from the Myths of Aesop. But it fully corresponds to today's reality. Imagine the European Union as a farmer and Turkey as a snake and think about how foolish it is to try to reach out to Turkey and join the European family; a country that is highly authoritarian, that does not respect the rights of people and states and ignores decisions of international organisations! So do not be surprised by the lack of freedom of expression in Turkey and the persecution of the media and journalists. The blood of the anti-government protests in Istanbul's Taksim Square has not yet dried up. Ask, read, investigate and realize: illegal invasion and occupation of part of Cyprus, a member country of the European Union, and show aggression in its EEZ; genocide of the Pontians and Armenians; persecution against the Kurds; attempt at ex-Turkishisation and Islamisation in the Bosnia-Albania-Macedonia-Bulgaria arc; tolerance and assistance to Islamic State criminals.  You must understand that by your tolerance towards Turkish attitudes you are strengthening and rearing its Turkish provocation and authoritarianism. (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: Mr President, first of all let me say that it is very simple: the Turkish Government must release all journalists and stop fighting free media. This is relevant regardless of what we say about Turkey’s future in Europe. This is about Turkey being a member of the Council of Europe, but it is also about the requirement that all states in the world must respect free media, democracy and the rule of law.  Secondly, I think we need to do what we can in order to support developments which would turn Turkey into a modern society with rule of law, an open society and a democracy with equal rights for men and women. It is that Turkey of the future that we can discuss becoming a member of the European Union. It has never been a point of discussion that the Turkey of today should be a member. But for different reasons – maybe because some Europeans have tried to close the door and maybe because some Turkish politicians want to close the door – the problem is that Mr Erdoğan is moving his country in the wrong direction. Not only away from possible membership but also away from being a solid, respectable open society. We need to call for a change in Turkey. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: "blue card" question. Mr Hökmark, I have a very simple question for you: I come from Cyprus, I am a European MEP and I am from the occupied part of Cyprus. I ask you directly: With what Turkey has done to date and does not recognise the Republic of Cyprus, if your country were the Republic of Cyprus, would you tolerate not recognising you until now? Would you put up with everything he does? And not to be misunderstood, I am the first to want Turkey to have a European perspective for us to survive. If for you this is a political vision, for us it's a matter of survival. But answer the question about the Republic of Cyprus.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: blue-card answer. – Of course the issue about the divide in Cyprus must be solved. That is part of what was happening in the negotiations and political agreements making it possible for Turkey to have a European perspective and become a Member. But let us also see the fact that the Turkey that is orienting itself towards Europe and doing the right things will also do the right thing regarding Cyprus.  A Turkey that is turning away to Russia or whatever will not do it. So I think we have a common interest in doing what we can in order to support a decent and good development in Turkey, because that is good for Europe.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: Madam President, the actions committed against journalists and the free press in Turkey deserve all our condemnation, as is happening in this Parliament, not only because they are an attack on freedom of expression, but because they send a message that we like nothing about where Erdogan is taking his country. Increasingly, the opposition space and the space of protesting people is narrower in Turkey, and even government rhetoric is becoming increasingly intolerant. The Socialist Group in this House and, of course, the Spanish Socialists have always defended the need for a European Turkey. We think that would be the good thing and that we could find common ground. It would be good for Europe, it would be good for Turkey, it would be good for that whole region of the world that is so important to our stability. But that also means that the Turkish Government is taking its side and throwing out any doubts, any doubts that may fall on its willingness to undertake democratic reforms, and lately it is generating a great deal of doubt. Every crime must be convicted, but within the framework of the rule of law, and we will have to follow very closely the actions of the Government of Erdogan. We need a European Turkey, but it gives us the impression that Turkey is moving away from Europe.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: In June last year, ladies and gentlemen, this Parliament adopted another resolution on the crackdown on civil protests in Gezi Park. At the time, we criticised the absolute lack of media freedom in Turkey. Today we are not one step further, quite the contrary. The arrests of journalists and the brutality with which this goes with it show that the Turkish rule of law has a huge problem. Democratic states respect freedom of expression. In a previous life, I was a passionate professional journalist. For me, erasing the essence was a guarantee of objectivity and quality. The fact that Turkish colleagues, under the guise of national security, are going to jail for this, that makes me angry! Freedom of the press is the immune system of a healthy society. But Ankara seems to want to take a fundamentally different path and is slowly but surely adopting the undemocratic practices of authoritarian regimes. If democracy in Turkey is nothing more than a mask behind which the state and its leaders once again show their true faces, then conclusions must be drawn.

name: Curzio MALTESE
text: Mr President, I believe that this debate has emerged that, in the face of the authoritarian drift of the Erdogan government, certain hypocrisies and so many doubts must be put to one side. We are facing a country that has the highest number of journalists in jail in the world, a country that is 154th out of 180 in the reporters sans frontières rankings and is committed to climbing even the last places to the bottom. Journalists accused of being close to Imam Gülen have been arrested. journalists of all political, religious, right, left, liberal, nationalist and pro-kurdish backgrounds had previously been accused, because now in Turkey – it must be noted – even a simple journalistic reportage (a profession That I have been doing for 35 years) on corruption is considered by the government and the police authorities as an act of terrorism. Then president Erdogan's kind of arrogant reaction to the criticisms made by our Commissioners Mogherini and Hahn also signals that the policy that the Eu ropean Union has used towards Turkey in recent years is clearly the wrong policy. We have helped them to be more democratic with this system of blandness, aid and negotiation: no! We must find a resolve with regard to Turkey, which has never been found before, and act in such a way as to help our colleagues in prison as much as possible.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: Madam President, a very serious case of corruption, of high corruption, of high corruption emerged in Turkey just one year ago. A few days ago, hours after the new Security Law was passed in the Turkish Parliament, a massive police operation was deployed against a very specific communication group and against former police officers. It is clear evidence of the will for full control of society that the Turkish Presidency seems to seek. Europe must take a clear position. But we must distinguish between the general interest of Turkish society and the actions of its institutions, which are entirely incompatible with any real progress in the negotiations with the European Union, the success of which we too wish. To this end, from a clear criterion of friendship with Turkey, yes, we propose: first, to ask the Turkish Minister for the European Union to appear immediately before the Joint Parliamentary Committee to contrast information on these facts; secondly, to hold the accession talks including, why not, the opening of the critical Chapters 23 and 24 to, precisely, in this scenario, express the greatest demand for respect for the rules and criteria in force in the Treaties of the European Union.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in a blitz worthy of the typical authoritarian states, the Turkish police arrested last Sunday 24 journalists who were guilty of writing for newspapers that were not complacent to the Erdogan government, denouncing countless cases of corruption in Turkey. It is a real dragnet in line with the decisions that marked the actions of the former prime minister, the current President of the Republic, who since 2002 has started a fight against internal dissent. In the 12 years he has been in charge of the government, Erdogan has conducted a series of expropriations of many TV channels, radio and newspapers that have had financial problems and that to be saved have passed into the hands of family members of government members to people very close to the President himself, who over the years has completed a real cleansing among the top of the police and judiciary , replacing those considered close to his greatest opponent, Gülen.  Not forgetting more recent measures that temporarily banned some social networks, such as Twitter or Youtube, because they were considered means of spreading dissent during the protests of Gezi Park and Taksim Square. To the positions of the European Union, which, moreover, funds Turkey, Erdogan thought he was arrogantly replying that the European Union should only do its own. This attitude clearly runs counter to European values and the standards to which Turkey itself aspires to be a candidate country. I agree with what my Cypriot colleague said at the beginning and left: the only way to put an end to these undemocratic attitudes is through economic sanctions.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: . Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, once again you have proof that Turkey is not a democratic country. Once again, the press is muzzled by the Erdogan system. We are, together with Turkey, experiencing a police system. Nothing seems to be stopping Erdogan today. At least he is the one who arrests, who puts in prison. Ten years ago, we did open negotiations with Turkey. As a member of the delegation for relations with Turkey, I have two options: to end visa liberalisation on the one hand and, on the other hand, to all negotiations on Turkey's entry into the European Union.

name: Artis PABRIKS
text: Madam President, it seems that this discussion brings together the opponents and supporters of Turkey in the European Union. I would like to say that we are all very much concerned by what is happening and by what the Turkish Government is doing. It seems that the Turkish Government is leaning more and more towards what we can see happening already in Russia. But in talking about this, we should distinguish between Turkey as a state, Turkish society and the Turkish Government. If we take a very negative stance – as some here propose, by stopping the negotiations and starting economic sanctions – then we are actually leaving behind a very large number of liberal, democratic, EU-oriented Turkish people, and in vain. Millions of them share our values.  I suggest that we actually have to find instruments with which we can influence the Turkish Government. Firstly, we have to see how we can better target the assistance that we are giving to Turkey as an accession country. Secondly, we definitely have to work it out together with Mrs Mogherini’s office and Commissioner Hahn’s office. Finally, I would like to say that we also have made our own mistakes, because by closing the 23rd and 24th Chapters we are actually drifting away and we find ourselves incapable of influencing the Turkish Government when we need to do so.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: Madam President, I will start by reiterate disreconously: freedom of the press is an essential value of the European Union and of any democratic state. Sunday's arrests are unacceptable and unacceptable because they call into question the observance of this freedom in Turkey. Our relationship with Turkey, a candidate country, must be honest, open and direct. We Socialists and Democrats retain our attachment to the enlargement of the European Union to Turkey. That is why it is fundamental to the success of this process to talk in parallel about progress and obstacles. This is not the first time that we have faced the issue of press freedom in Turkey; that is why we are deeply concerned that the situation of the press is getting worse, that President Erdogan has chosen a direction that is dangerous for Turkey, and that is why I invite him to take the leadership responsibility and ensure Turkey's democratic stability.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Madam President! The events in Turkey are more than just worrying. The regime led by President Erdogan is cracking down on the media and cold-hearted journalists. As an East German, I have developed a good sense of gait, synchronisation and non-freedom, and I notice when state arbitrariness arises. The behaviour of the Turkish Government is totally unacceptable and violates all fundamental rights of the European Union. Can such a country ever become a member of the European Union, which has no respect for the rule of law and fundamental rights? I mean, no. Democracy does not mean that elections are held every few years and that a government can do what it wants in between. Democracy means that the state and society must adhere to human rights and values such as freedom of expression and pluralism. With the arrest of the journalists, the Erdogan government has once again shown its true face. This government is moving further and further away from Europe and from any basic democratic understanding. It began with the crushing of the peaceful demonstrators in Gezi Park and continues with this arrest by Erdogan's political vicarious agents. Erdogan seems to believe that the EU and the international community let him go through everything. Mrs Mogherini and the Commission must now send out a strong signal. As a final consequence, the termination of the accession negotiations must not be a taboo subject.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which A quick look at history: I think in September 2005 was the culmination of EU-Turkey relations, when this House opened the accession negotiations here. Exactly a year ago today, there was the largest corruption raid in Turkey's history, when four ministers were subsequently forced to resign. The preliminary low point in EU-Turkey relations was last Sunday, when many journalists were arrested on suspicion and without any circumstantial evidence. That is why I would like to remind you once again that Turkey has only been strong if it has aligned itself with the EU. For example, between 2005 and 2008, it had an average economic output of 6% per year. Last year it was just over 3%, and that is not necessarily just about the great depression. Hence my explicit appeal to the ACP Government: stop the personal campaign of revenge against other thinking and, ultimately, align your laws with the EU.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Mr President, for a country that imprisons journalists in this way and on this scale, there is no place in the European Union. We all agree on that. It is actually very special that, in the history of the European Union, Turkey is the only candidate country that is not making progress but is making a decline in approaching the Copenhagen criteria and the values on which the EU is built. And that is also something new for the European Union. We have to ask ourselves how to respond to that. It goes without saying that we must strongly condemn these actions in the January resolution. But we also have to ask ourselves whether we can still justify leaving it alone in words. This morning, the Dutch Parliament called on the European Council to freeze or reduce pre-accession funds. But I also agree with Mr Pabriks that it would be important to use these pre-accession funds more specifically to give extra support to civil society and liberal forces in Turkish society.  So my question to the European Council is: do you see the possibility of using these pre-accession funds to send a strong signal to Turkey and at the same time giving an extra heart to the people of Turkey who believe in Europe and european values?

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Madam President, I would like to condemn the recent operation to gag the press and strengthen internet control by the Turkish Government. These practices affect the fundamental principles of freedom of speech, but above all they affect democracy itself. Having consistently supported Turkey's European perspective, I am concerned about this development, which is a sign of regression, violating human rights, and the rule of law. Last year we had the violent suppression of demonstrations in the centre of Istanbul; more recently we have encountered the ambivalent attitude of the Turkish Government with regard to the international coalition's fight against ISIS jihadists; only last month we condemned the violation of the sovereignty of Cyprus, one of our Member States, by the Turkish armed forces and again today, in yet another plenary session, we are discussing a new blow against press freedom in Turkey. Unfortunately, all this is evidence that Erdogan is driving Turkey away from the principles and values of the European Union.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: Madam President, despite the illusions of some, Turkey is not a democratic country. It systematically violates the human rights of millions of citizens and press freedom is rushed every day. In addition, Turkey holds a military part of the Republic of Cyprus. The latest arrests of Turkish journalists by the Erdogan regime, who continue similar practices in the past, show that Erdogan was serious when he said on the campaign trail that he would "melt down" all those who opposed him. The other day he told us that Europe should not interfere with his own house. No one wants Turkey in the European Union. That is why accession talks and pre-accession aid to Turkey must be interrupted until it proves in practice that it respects Europe's political morality. Economic transactions with Turkey are huge, but we must also defend our principles and values, which are systematically violated by that country. Moreover, if the European Union is not ready to defend its principles and values in Cyprus, as it does in Ukraine and, as some have told us, within Turkey, it will not escape decline.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: Madam President, respect for fundamental freedoms and individual rights, over the past two years in particular, has suffered a serious deterioration in Turkey, and the latest episode with journalists - last week - is just one more case. One more case within a situation, in the State of Turkey, where corruption is not being reasonably confronted by the judiciary — a judiciary of which, increasingly, we have more doubts that it will be independent — where freedom of the press is being attacked day after day, and where, moreover, we see, by some political leaders, that freedom of association and political freedom are also under attack. In the face of that, what should we do? The European Union must condemn the events that have passed in the last week. We must use a propositional attitude, not with the Government, but with our capacity to influence what happens in Turkey's future. That is our obligation, not to the Government, but to the citizens of Turkey.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: Madam President, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, the recent arrests already mentioned in Turkey lead us to question the true state of press freedom in this country that is a candidate for the European Union. We remind you that the rule of law and the independence of the judicial system, along with the above-mentioned freedom of the press, are three of the fundamental pillars on which European democracies are based and in particular our rights, freedoms and guarantees as citizens. As Turkey is a candidate country for accession, It seems clear to me that these principles are complied with. Therefore, dear representative of the Italian Presidency, we expect you to follow up closely with the progress of these arrests, in particular the knowledge of the specific accusations to each of the citizens concerned. We also demand that this candidate State for our Union carry out judicial investigations in an independent, transparent and discourteous manner. And I end by stressing that, contrary to what Was said by President Erdogan last Sunday, it seems legitimate to me that this Parliament should make these demands.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Turkey over the years has shown us that one thing it knows how to do right and does so consistently: to disregard over time all the resolutions adopted, to systematically and temporally violate human rights, and not only within Turkey but also outside Turkey, to cause problems, to be the troublemaker of the region, to have expansive and aggressive attitudes towards all. Turkey is doing all this, and it has proved it in practice, because everyone has shown tolerance. Turkey does not understand resolutions and debates. And if there are no sanctions and measures coming out of this debate, which we, as the European Union, must do primarily for our dignity, for our credibility and for our self-respect, know that it will still be a debate in so many that we have done that will have no effect. Turkey has had the opportunity and the opportunity in practice to prove that it has been on a pro-European path for years and not only has it not done so but is only taking the Money of the European Union, mocking the European Union and Mr Erdogan challenging us and telling us to do our job. Yes, the only way to do our job is one: Today we decide and call on Europe to take action and impose economic sanctions. That is all Turkey understands. Otherwise, every couple of months we'll be here discussing the same things.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Madam President, I only wanted to respond to some of the speeches that have been made here, which have just concerned speeches by Members from Greece. Some were very correct, but unfortunately some of the non-included Members tried to use them to promote their national vested interests. I consider this to be a bit bold even in the context of this subject, which is otherwise very serious. I myself want to declare myself a friend of Turkey, but human rights violations cannot be tolerated. It is essential that Europe supports those states that share its values. Therefore, given that Turkey is an acceding candidate country, the Council should indeed clearly name these matters and ask Turkey for redress.

name: Alessandra MORETTI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the blitzes that led to the arrest of two police chiefs and at least 24 journalists, including the editor of the newspaper Zaman and the director of a major Turkish broadcaster, cannot go unnoticed and we in the European Parliament must ask the Turkish authorities, with force and urgency, to ensure that their actions do not infringe Turkey's own key values and democratic foundations. Freedom of the media, regular trials and the independence of the judiciary are key elements in any healthy democracy and are provided for in the Turkish constitution, and these arrests, as Mogherini and Pittella have said, are incompatible with the freedom of the press, which is the foundation of democracy, and are also contrary to the values and standards of Europe, to which Turkey aspires to be a part. It is therefore unacceptable for a democratic and modern country which intends to join the European family to make these mass arrests.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, Turkey continues its well-known tactic: it brutally violates the democratic rights of citizens and minorities. Once again he unleashed pogroms of persecution against journalists and the media. It is therefore confirmed once again that this country does not respect the basic democratic principles of modern Europe. But when a regime is not democratic, it is also expressed in its foreign policy. Thus Turkey illegally maintains the casus belli against Greece to the extent that my country applies – listen, listen – international law of the sea and extends its territorial waters to 12 nautical miles. In recent times, Turkey has been conducting seismographic surveys of hydrocarbons in Turkey's EEZ. Turkey must receive the message from the European Parliament and be called upon to immediately withdraw Turkish occupying troops from Cyprus and respect international law. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a 'blue card' (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: blue-card question. – Madam President, I just wanted to ask my distinguished colleague whether it would not be better if we, Europe, had an active stand vis-à-vis Turkey. I can remember how long it took for Greece to join the European Union. I think the European Union is making a mistake by not opening any chapter and not progressing in its relations with Turkey. The question is: do you not think that it would be better to take an active stance rather than waiting passively for the democratisation of Turkey?

name: Notis MARIAS
text: "blue card" answer. – Turkey has shown all this time, for decades, that it does not respect either international law or democratic rights. The time has come for the European Union to say: 'at the end of the day!'. We cannot tolerate Turkish occupation troops in Cyprus. That's clear. Do you understand what that means? Violation of the sovereignty of a Member State of the European Union.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, I wonder why we are surprised at the attitude of Turkey, one Turkey which owns half of Cyprus, one Turkey which persecutes the Kurds, one Turkey which takes away the basic democratic rights of its own citizens. The message from the European Union must be clear: in order to join Europe it must be in line with the principles and values of the European Union itself and not have the demand that Europe give in to its own principles. And when we talk about Turkey, we are talking about the Erdogan regime, which brings out its neo-Ottoman face in any case.
