We want Turkey in the European Union, but respect for Europe's democracy, principles and values.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: For anyone who is interested and engaged with Turkey is not a surprise what has happened in recent days. The practice of violating human rights, imprisoning journalists, depriving journalists of freedom of speech is an old practice of the regime of Recep Tayyip Erdogan, Davutoglu and their entire government. I will only remind you that Erdogan's party is neo-Ottoman, fighting to rebuild the Ottoman Empire, initially in its economic and possibly political borders. There have been repeated talk here of how Turkey has still occupied Cyprus, how it supports Hamas in Palestine, how it supports Islamic State against the Kurds in syria's civil war and that in Iraq. Only one thing can be expected from the Erdogan regime – violence on freedom of speech, revocation of rights and freedoms. These are not democratic regimes, and if we want to defend the values of the European Union, as we say they should be, we should really think about sanctions for this behavior of Turkey.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, once again I find myself talking painfully about Turkey. This time, 27 people were arrested in 13 cities as part of an operation targeting media hostile to Erdogan. The target, the country's most-read newspaper, Zaman, and a number of other newspapers and figures from the Samanyolu media empire, near Fethullah Gülen, the self-exiled preacher in the United States in 1999 who, after being an ally of Erdogan, launched a campaign against him. More and more alternative voices to those of the government are being extinguished in Turkey; increasingly, freedom of expression and opinion in this country, once a beacon of the Islamic world, ends up disappearing. Unfortunately, I fear that the Turkish Government has made the choice and is not a choice towards the rule of law, let alone towards the European Union. How long will it take, ladies and gentlemen, before we draw the necessary conclusions and give the necessary answers?

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Madam President, as I understand it, in one minute I will give a brief analysis. In this European Parliament there are two approaches: one that says that we should finally give a clear message to Turkey demanding certain things and the other that says that we should maintain contact with Turkey by opening up some chapters, giving it space. But, ladies and gentlemen, and I am also addressing the Commission, it is not so much what we think here but how this is interpreted by Erdogan himself in Turkey. The movements, the good intentions, the reach of the hand by us is interpreted as a reward by Erdogan before his public opinion, that is to say we support by system an arbitrary regime. If that's what we want, let's say it. If not, take the first option with strict measures.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, with the latest wave of arrests of journalists, I believe that the Government in Ankara has made a mistake, the only result of which may be to strengthen its opponents. These arrests are incompatible with the freedom of the press, which is the fundamental principle of democracy. These arrests run counter to European values, the standards that Turkey will have to adhere to if it actually aspires to join the European Union.  It is unacceptable that a democratic and modern country which aims to be part of the European family should be able to make mass arrests of journalists and members of the media. There are currently more than 70 journalists in Turkish prisons, including many Kurdish journalists detained for terrorism. I hope that the principles of the presumption of innocence will prevail and that the inalienable right to a fair and independent investigation, with full respect for the rights of the defence, will be respected. It is sad to say so, but I think that what has happened is taking Turkey in the wrong direction, away from Europe. This situation could have negative consequences for Turkey in terms of political and economic cooperation with the European Union. Europe absolutely must react firmly and decisively.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members who have spoken and participated in this debate, not only because of the relevance of the speeches and the arguments expressed and because of the concerns expressed which, I believe, are to a large extent absolutely common concern. It was appropriate to take this opportunity to take note of the serious concerns about the most recent events in order to formulate an unambiguous position and to convey it with absolute clarity and consistency to our Turkish interlocutors. We must continue to monitor the situation very closely. The European Union must continue to promote freedom of expression, opinion, assembly and association, both online and offline, because a democracy cannot exist without these rights. Turkey is a privileged partner with which we are negotiating accession; we can and must communicate with her frankly. As President Schulz said, the relationship with the candidate countries must be honest and open. I just wanted to pick up on the points that have been raised that relating to funding, which is certainly a point that deserves attention. The European Union does not finance the Turkish budget but mainly NGOs and institutions that promote the rule of law and human rights, mainly through two instruments, namely the pre-accession instrument and the European Instrument for Human Rights. The Commission is examining how to make this form of intervention more effective, and I would stress, among other things, that the per capita allocates to Turkey are, in any case, the lowest among the candidate countries. The framework for enlargement is the right one to engage in the process of deepening and consolidating democratic reforms. Further commitment in the context of Chapter 3 would be an important encouragement. We have done a great deal to step up this engagement with Turkey, a candidate country and partner of the European Union. We must continue along this path.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place during the next session. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Writing. – Suspicion of corruption against AKP politicians, mass arrests of journalists, new laws that are incompatible with European fundamental values and the disregard for workers' rights and trade unions - all this unfortunately became a political everyday life in Turkey under the AKP government! Just a few days ago, 24 journalists critical of the government were imprisoned in a nationwide raid – so President Erdogan has once again muzzled the press! I strongly condemn these methods of intimidation and call for the release of all journalists wrongly imprisoned. Europe must provide an unequivocal response to the restriction of freedom of the press. I would also like to speak about Soma. Six months after the mine disaster that killed more than 300 people, 2,800 miners were sent a text message two weeks ago. The company that operated the accident mine was unable to pay the wages. This approach is outrageous, and workers' rights are being trampled underfoot. The Turkish trade union is calling for the mine to be re-routed and the mine to continue operations, but there are no initiatives from the government. There are virtually no other employment opportunities in the region. Once again, profits have been privatised and losses socialised at the expense of society.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Writing. I too condemn the current developments in Turkey. The actions of the security forces on Sunday show once again that the Turkish government does not care about fundamental values or the rule of law. We must not forget that these actions are just the latest step in a long-running campaign against the press, opposition and unwelcome officials. As part of a corruption investigation, the police and prosecutors carried out judicially legitimate raids and arrests of AKP government members in December 2013. Until July 2014, the police officers and judges involved were transferred, arrested or otherwise silenced. The work of non-governmental organisations is also hampered. Kimse Yok Mu, a non-governmental organization with UN advisory status, has not been allowed to collect donations since October 2014, and the organization's accounts have since been suspended without a court order. The Turkish Government is unimpressed by the contrary decision of the Turkish Council of State, i.e. the Supreme Administrative Court. If an internationally active NGO is so hindered in its work, one can imagine how smaller NGOs are being dealt with. Under Erdogan, Turkey is threatening to abandon the path of the rule of law, pluralist democracy, and fundamental rights. As a European community of values, we must demand respect for the Turkish Constitution and, therefore, respect for human rights.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for a joint discussion on: - the recommendation of Andrejs Mamikins, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, on the one hand, and Georgia, on the other hand (09827/2014 - C8-0129/2014 - 2014/0086 (NLE)) (A8-0041/2014), and - Andrej's report Mamikins, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, containing a proposal for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision approving the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, on the one hand , and Georgia, on the other hand (2014/2816 (INI) (A8-0042/2014).

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Rapporteur. - Ladies and gentlemen, it is a great honour for me to draw the attention of the European Parliament and to ask for the agreement to be given to the ratification of the Association Agreement between the European Parliament and Georgia. Today, we are taking a very important step towards showing new opportunities for Georgia and its people to build a stable, successful and successful future for Europe. Georgia has always been a European country, but Georgian culture is an important part of European culture. According to a recent survey, 69% of the Georgian people support the signing of the Association Agreement. Such strong aid places a great deal of responsibility on the authorities, the executors of this agreement. Today's ratification of tomorrow is a logical follow-up to the work launched by the European Union and Georgia initiating an EU-Georgia action plan eight years ago. Five years ago, the European Union and its partners launched the Eastern Partnership programme, in which many projects were successfully implemented. At the outset, the full realisation of these plans seemed too optimistic, but the example of Georgia shows that the road will not be done by those who talk about the difficulties, but those who are focused and persistent in doing their job. I was pleasantly surprised, colleagues, to see how much the Georgian Government and the Georgian people did. It was not easy to make changes in so many areas of society and the economy in such a short period of time. It is very difficult to convince the public, entrepreneurs and political elite that rapid but sometimes painful reforms are needed. Similar reforms in western European countries had been carried out over the decades, but Georgia had to do so within a few years. Colleagues, much work has been done in the previous period, but there are many issues that require increased attention in the future – such as the continued political polarisation of Georgian society, the fight against corruption, problems with the territories of abkhazia and Chinvali and South Ossetia, and other important issues. The Association Agreement imposes responsibility on both parties. The European Union must help Georgia fight corruption, continue to build an independent judicial system, strengthen media freedom, protect minorities and do everything to ensure that the Georgian people receive all the benefits of their European choices. Honourable colleagues, I would particularly like to note that, thanks to the Association Agreement, Georgia could hope for a series of positive changes. These include: increasing trade, creating new jobs, facilitating the visual regime and, in the perspective, inwardvising visa-free travel, improving investment opportunities, and many other positive moments. The European Union, for its part, can receive the opportunity to carry out joint sustainable projects in trade, energy, transport and other sectors. European entrepreneurs will be given new opportunities in Georgia, where they will be able to invest their funds safely, buy or sell their goods and services. To conclude, I would like to thank all my colleagues who have taken part in the preparation of this report and in the implementation of the ratification of this treaty, especially shadow reporters from all the political groups, those Members who tabled their proposals. I very much hope, dear colleagues, for a constructive discussion and a positive vote. Honourable colleagues, I would like to say to each of you that the georgian people deserve positive change, and I hope that we MePs will vote for them. Thank you very much!

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, honourable Members, let me first of all thank Mr Andrejs Mamikins for his report, which contains many important recommendations and shows that we have a high degree of consensus on our policy with Georgia. The European Parliament’s strong support will be an important message for the reinforcement of our ties with Georgia and it will create excellent conditions for closer cooperation with Georgia.  Georgia is one of the frontrunners of the European Union’s Eastern Partnership policy. The Association Agreement before you today is the result of Georgia’s European aspirations. It is also the result of our determination to promote building a democratic, stable and prosperous country in a region that is of key strategic importance to us. Georgia will transform itself as we implement our joint agenda. Georgia will, as a result, move closer to the European Union, deepening its political association and economic integration with the EU. Georgia will introduce reforms that will build into its public life core European values such as a pluralist democracy and a deeper respect for due process and the rule of law. Following the signature and the provisions of application of the agreement, we have had our first EU-Georgia Association Council under the agreement exactly one month ago in Brussels – the first step for the implementation of this agreement. On the same day we concluded that Georgia meets the first phase requirements of the visa dialogue and that the second implementation phase of the action plan could be launched. This was yet another important step in the process that will bring Georgia closer to its goal of a visa-free regime with the European Union.  It is difficult to say that Georgia has made important progress in its democratic development following parliamentary and presidential elections in 2012 and 2013 as well as local elections in 2014. But this message was also given and was well received. The political climate in the country needs improving. Political confrontation and polarisation should be avoided and space for opposition and cross-party dialogue needs to be ensured. In the same vein, Georgia needs to continue efforts to reform the judiciary and ensure the rule of law. I am pleased to report that the provisional application of the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area of the Association Agreement since 1 December is already showing first results. Trade statistics for September are positive and stable. The effect of the agreement is yet to be confirmed but the September 2014 figures indicate a 50% increase in imports from Georgia into the European Union, mainly in nuts and mineral products. The European Union will further assist reforms in Georgia and help small and medium enterprises adapt to the new regulatory framework with a EUR 51 million programme under the Annual Action Programme of this year. Let me now turn to the most recent developments in the Georgian breakaway regions, mainly the so-called Strategic Partnership Treaty between the Russian Federation and the Abkhazia de facto authorities. Reports on a similar undertaking with the South Ossetian de facto authorities are equally disconcerting. Just like earlier agreements signed between the Russian Federation and Abkhazia, this so-called treaty questions the sovereignty and integrity of Georgia. It is also detrimental to ongoing efforts to stabilise the security situation in the region, and it does not contribute to de-escalation. It also contradicts principles of international law and commitments taken by the Russian Federation. Let me reconfirm the European Union’s unwavering support for Georgia’s territorial integrity. We remain fully committed to supporting conflict resolution in Georgia including through our co-chairmanship of the Geneva International Talks and our monitoring mission in Georgia. Let me also, again, underline our appreciation for Georgia’s contribution to the European Union’s mission in the Central African Republic on the basis of our framework agreement for Georgia’s participation in the European Union’s Common Security and Defence Policy missions. To conclude, let me say that the partnership between the European Union and Georgia is a strong one. It will become even stronger with the European Parliament’s verification of our Association Agreement.

name: Olli REHN
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. - Madam President, Georgia has been a reliable partner and pursued closer political and economic ties with the European Union, despite significant pressure from Russia. For a small state like Georgia, the choice of free trade has served the country well. In the last decade, foreign trade turnover has increased five- to six-fold. The growth has been driven by the liberal trade regime of Georgia. Moreover, as the Commissioner said, following the provisional application of the DCFTA as of September, the preliminary statistics indicate a close to 50% increase in Georgia’s exports to the EU, thus improving its trade balance with the Union. In fact, of our Eastern partners, Georgia has done the most in reforming its economy and deserves this agreement and its ratification. The next step is implementation. We support Georgia in this endeavour and wish it the best of success.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, we are taking a step towards ratifying the European Union's association agreement with Georgia. After Ukraine and Moldova for the third ratification of the Association Agreement in this parliamentary term. The draft resolution before you is the result of the patient work of the representatives of the factions to whom it belongs thanks. We've been through many pitfalls, let me mention two of them. First of all, when processing text, we tried to call things by their real names. Let's go back 25 years. Russia annexed Abkhazi. Two years later, the Chechen war began, killing 80,000 civilians. In 2008, Russia's 58th army occupied South Ossetia. It was the same army that killed in Chechnya. This year, the Russian Federation again grossly violated international law twice. It occupied Crimea and started a hybrid war in eastern Ukraine. We did not use euphemisms to formulate our draft resolution, and we clearly called the occupation an occupation. I think that the position of the European Parliament and of the entire European Union must reflect the possibility that the Russian Federation will continue to violate international law and that the Russian military will commit war crimes. If we do not take a clear position, we may bear some of the blame. If Europe had clearly condemned the aggression in Chechia and Abkhazia, there would have been no aggression in Ukraine. This is also evidenced by the fact that the Russian Federation has concluded a new agreement with Abkhazia, which may lead to the direct annexation of certain parts of Georgian territory and their integration into the territory of the Russian Federation.  In the Tex negotiations, we have not neglected to point out that georgia's new regime, even though elected democratically after many decades, criminalizes members of the former political class. Ladies and gentlemen, please give the green light to this very important resolution.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We Social Democrats welcome the free trade agreement and, of course, the association agreement and look forward to close cooperation with Georgia. We also say quite clearly that the Russian attempts to create unrest and uncertainty through the treaties with the occupied territories will not deter us. I would like to take this opportunity to thank the Georgian Government for its very calm and wise way of handling this conflict. Economic cooperation will benefit both sides. Political cooperation will help to reform and stabilise the country. The people of Georgia will realise that an independent judiciary, the rule of law, the fight against corruption, a transparent administration and much more will benefit them. It is good that in future we will have a cooperation committee, following the example of Ukraine and Moldova now also with Georgia. This is important in order to promote dialogue and to bind us more closely together. However, we would also have to think again about what that means for the committee, as it has been up to now. Because then the EU sits on one side and Armenia and Aerbeidsh on the other. This is going to be a pretty difficult task for us.

name: Marek JUREK
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The debate that we are taking today and the decisions we will take tomorrow seem to be a few years late. We should have presented the invitation of the Georgians to the association and the opening of the road to the European Union in 2008, immediately after the Russian raid on Georgia. This would be a clear, strong and peaceful response to aggression. A clear sign that attempts to prevent countries in eastern Europe from cooperating with the West will only strengthen our solidarity and have the opposite effect on the aggressor's intentions. Our unequivocal response at that time could have prevented today's tragedy in Ukraine. It is a pity, but we have a proverb in Poland: "Better late than never". Someone will say: well, but it has not been possible to abstract from European standards in recent years. Consent, but also time for us to understand – and Pope Francis recently told us in this House – that they are giving us no less than we can give them. , but also in our own safety. If solidarity is not to be an empty word, it is time for us to realise that we have a duty to systematically support the independence of the states that regained it after the dissolution of the Soviet Union. It is good that our resolution makes this clear.

name: Javier NART
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, this is a strategic, fundamental and important agreement, because we are saying a number of things.  First of all, that Georgia is Europe.  Secondly, like Europe, you absolutely have the right to decide what your wishes, criteria and national objectives are, including full partnership with the European Union, in accordance with Article 49 of our Treaty. Third, it is not a complacent statement. It is not a statement that simply determines the goodness of the Georgian state. Very specific warnings are made to certain misuses by the current Georgian Government of selective justice and for use not appropriate to the criteria and standards of the European Union. It is a resolution that establishes respect for peace, a fundamental issue which means respect for borders and, consequently, condemns any act that means an attack on peace and security, specifically invasions, or alleged annexations, in this case of Abkhazia, and the presence of South Ossetia as a secession zone with a Russian presence. It's also something that's fundamental. It is not against anyone, it does not mean any contradiction with what are the legitimate interests of any country, and in this case – let us say it by name – of a great country, which is Russia, which has to be more than just a great neighbor: it has to be a great friend too, a great friend of Europe. Because Russia is Also Europe. And, consequently, this is one more material that builds the unity of Europe and is directed for peace, not for contradiction against anyone.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Today's debate, for all the complexity of the agreements mentioned, misses the essential issues of the life perspective of the Georgian people.  With over 35% unemployment and an average wage of EUR 350, more than a third of the population has left the country in the meantime. With the Association Agreement, the hopes of the Georgian people now have a clear address. But no one has yet explained how these hopes are to be fulfilled.  I therefore believe that the Commission must explain in the short term how it intends to meet the expectations of independent, socially just and economic development and good jobs as the basis for a dignified life in a democratic state. And we in this House, too, must show their colours. One more thing: Georgia has chosen the path of association. That is why we should immediately stop undermining Georgia's hitherto flexible policy in the interests of balancing it with Russia as a partner. If we force Georgia into sanctions policy, we will soon have to discuss compensating for the resulting losses by means of EU funds. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: blue card issue. – I have a question to Mr Schulz: 'Do you really believe that georgia's move away from the European Union would help solve the economic problems that Georgia, of course, has? You really believe that georgian isolation will be the right objective that we can set ourselves as Members of the European Parliament and, in general, as the European Union?" Thank you!

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. The Economic Agreement and the Free Trade Agreement are, of course, subject to certain conditions. At the same time, we must also consider how economic cooperation with Georgia itself will enable Georgia itself to open up a new perspective in the diversification of its economy and in cooperation with other trading partners.

name: Tamás MESZERICS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, first of all let me thank our rapporteur, our colleague Mr Andrejs Mamikins, for a balanced report which contains many important and good recommendations from which both the Georgian Government and anyone in Georgia interested in politics and interested in a European future could profit. Now certainly this is the time first of all to celebrate. Association agreements, if they are meant to be serious agreements, are to be celebrated and I propose that we do that tomorrow and I ask all of you to support the Association Agreement and report with your vote. We need to pause for a moment and congratulate the Georgian authorities who went through considerable changes already. Of course there is much to be done. The report contains many of those important elements and the Commissioner has already mentioned many of them so I am not going to repeat them. Ultimately, however, I want to highlight that I do not mean to contest the statistics cited by the Commissioner, but we should bear in mind that free trade agreements are not unmitigated benefits. There are social costs to them, so I warn both the Commission, the Georgian authorities and this House that we should follow very closely what happens at the regional level to the Georgian economy and to the Georgian social fabric and year by year we should return to this question.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a fine metaphor for international politics is 'a glass above a table crowded with many people'. Everyone's choices represent a sip of water poured or removed inside the glass. In theory, whoever gets to fill it with the last sip without dropping a single drop of water wins. If someone makes a risky move, the glass overflows and floods the table, but not with water, with blood. What is Europe doing around this table today? I'm afraid he's pouring water copiously, with a carefreeness and superficiality that make me shiver. I would like to clear up any misunderstanding: we in the Five Star Movement are in favour of a European perspective for each country that meets the Copenhagen criteria, provided that this is also the unequivocal will of their partners and our peoples. This also applies, of course, to Moldova, Ukraine and our friends in Georgia. We are not asking ourselves whether but how and when: we have enormous doubts about them, and that is why we will not vote in favour but will abstain. Both the Eu ropean Union and Russia are getting closer and closer to the red line. NATO shows its muscles in the Baltic in Poland with nine intervention forces and the Russians, who obviously have very heavy responsibilities, respond blow by blow, relaunching. The chasm is getting closer and closer, seemingly for no reason. Are we really sure? In a statement on November 14, 2013, Victoria Nuland, deputy US Secretary of State, openly mentions a link between the Eastern Partnership and TTIP, a treaty that has huge risks and dubious benefits for us. A treaty that is more devoted to the exclusion of those outside than to the inclusion of those inside. And it is no coincidence that TTIP has been called the "NATO of the economy": the continuation or rather the anticipation of a hypothetical conflict by other means, paraphrasing von Clausewitz. So what are we voting on today? Are we voting for our safety and well-being in Georgia, or will many of us on the other side of the Atlantic be thinking exclusively of millions of new consumers for our markets, whatever the cost? To accept a terrible risk to the lives of millions of people, in order to increase the turnover of the large defence multinationals? The enemy's rhetoric may be convenient at times, but we are by no means Putin's supporters of Russia, quite the contrary. But we are also realistic and we are indignant when principles are only remembered when it suits us. The sanctions imposed so far are damaging all the parties involved, but strangely little for the United States. We must not follow President Obama's line calling for further reinforcement. Twenty-five years ago, the Berlin Wall collapsed and nato's original assumptions were being thosed; now the European Union and the United States are evolving another one further east. I do not know who will win what Kissinger rightly called 'a fatal mistake' but I am painfully convinced that in any case we as Europeans will lose. Perhaps we still have time to change our minds, change it and avoid it.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, with this association agreement, the European Union is crossing a new threshold on the scale of unreason. Its record, both in terms of enlargement and association agreements, can be summed up in two points. First, it is about the impoverishment of the European Union. No country that has joined the EU since 2004 had a GDP per capita above the EU average of 28 in 2014. The transition in 2007 from EU 15 to the EU 28 represents a relative loss of 12 percentage points of GDP per capita, which means that a US citizen now has one and a half times more purchasing power than a citizen of the European Union. It is therefore clear that your desire to association with Georgia, as with Ukraine or Moldova, will only exacerbate the impoverishment of the European Union.  Secondly, this is your record in terms of widening the divide between the European Union and Russia. We live alongside Russia, which has its own interests and sphere of influence. The strategic aggression against this neighbour that is THE continued expansion of NATO is a mistake we are paying for today. Of course, it is the Ukrainians, Moldovans and Georgians who must determine their future, but you know that their country's strategic orientation - towards NATO or towards Russia - is a cause of heartbreak that can lead to civil wars. Therefore, true to our constant line guided by the interests of France, but also by the concern for peace in Europe, we will vote against this project. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: blue card issue. – I would like to ask my French colleague: 'When it comes to the cost of enlargement and how poor the European Union has become, he is also aware that the european union's overall market increased by almost 100 million, which enabled both French entrepreneurs and entrepreneurs from other European countries to earn significantly in this market?' Thank you!

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, I am particularly aware of the deindustrialization and losses of the French economy and many more developed countries. It is clear that by integrating more poor countries, and by integrating countries whose upgrades are very expensive, as it had cost Germany to upgrade following its reunification, we are putting a very heavy cost on the citizens of the richest Europe. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation)

name: Marek JUREK
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Mr President, do you not realise that the European Union itself attaches a bullet to its feet in the form of a utopia of monetary union, and that its costs are much greater than enlargement? And do you not realise that French exports to central European countries have increased six-fold after the adoption of Polish and other countries? You really benefit from it, so sometimes think about it.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, first of all, I consider that Georgia's identity is indeed European, and there is no doubt about that, but I think there were many relations before free trade. We are not obliged to sign association or free trade agreements developed to exchange. I am simply saying that we must protect our economy today for the countries of Western and Central Europe, which are Member States. The monetary cost is of course very high as well, but we have also fought it.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Madam President, I am always surprised to hear here - as happened yesterday - the view of Moscow, expressed with great rhetorical enthusiasm. In particular, you are mistaken, Mr Chauprade, about the relations of the countries you mentioned with NATO: Moldova does not want to join NATO. You are making a story, which is that of your friends, who, as I understand it from reading the press, have also given you money to your party. Isn't it? The National Front - as we have all seen in the press - is funded by Moscow. From that point of view, we are really shocked. I know, you will say that borrowing is impossible in Europe, we also know your answers. But do you imagine Mr Chauprade that, in Georgia as in Moldova, as in Kiev, in Ukraine, people must choose between, on the one hand, a society of freedom and free trade and, on the other hand, Soviet authority. Apparently, you like this kind of Soviet authority, under which we decide for others. Georgians, Moldovans and Ukrainians want to decide for themselves, not that Moscow decides for them, and they have the right to consider this European perspective. If you now want to wage war on poor Georgians, Moldovans and Ukrainians, excuse me, this is not the place to do this. We are really following a logic of solidarity here and that is why the EPP Group will vote enthusiastically on the Association Agreement, as it has done for Moldova and for Ukraine. (The speaker agrees to answer two "blue card" questions (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: "blue card" question. "Dear sir, we must not misinform your colleagues. We did not receive any money from Moscow: we took out a loan from a private bank because we are perfectly free to do so. A loan, until proven otherwise, is not a gift. It's important. We have to pay that money back to a private bank. Second, sir, when you are defending an American strategic direction, I am not accusing you of being an agent of Washington. You have the right to have your opinion and I have the right to have mine. We speak on behalf of interests, from our point of view, of France and of the European Union.

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: blue-card question. – Mr Preda, I am obliged to you for accepting my blue card question. You raise a very important point. There is clearly a pattern of rhetoric coming from some of our far-right extremist groups which is anti-European in the first instance. They then go on to the Russian media and say anti-NATO things, even speaking against their own Member States, and then it moves on to becoming pro-Putin. We clearly have a pattern. Then, at the end of that course of action, you see money changing hands from Russia across to these groups. There is not just one party leader who has done that – there is more than one in this House. Should we not now be carrying out investigations?

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, I will not answer Mr Chauprade because I told him, from the outset, to send his questions to Putin or his friends in this private bank. On the other hand, I will respond to what our British colleague has just said: we are of course concerned that such operations are also carried out with the National Front in Moldova, with a Moldovan party that campaigned with Russian money from a private bank. This is unacceptable! Our House, the European Parliament, whether here in Strasbourg or in Brussels, is not the place where Moscow has to express itself.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: Mr President, sometimes we get the feeling here that we are listening to 'Govorit Moskva', but that is another story.  Mr President, the signing of the Association Agreement with Georgia is not an award, but a recognition of the merits and progress made by this friendly country and the strong pro-European support of the Georgian people. In view of the complex situation in the Black Sea area, we have a duty for the Union to support Georgia in all ways, politically and economically, and to counterbalance the systematic destabilisation effort on the part of Russia. At the same time, I call on Georgian friends to build strong bipartisan support for the success of pro-European reforms. Colleagues, I invite you to reflect on Georgia as part of the puzzle and see the whole picture of the Black Sea where, after the annexation of Crimea, Russia recently concluded the so-called strategic partnership agreement with Abkhazia, an explicit confirmation of its role in creating the frozen conflict and then in occupying this province by the typical means of Moscow. Finally, I would like to mention that this Association Agreement is the beginning of a difficult but necessary effort for the friendly country and for this region which is so strategically important for the European Union.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: Mr President, while the ECR deeply regrets Russia’s continued occupation of Georgian territory, condemns the numerous cases of prosecution of former government members, and has concerns about selective justice – particularly against the former President – it has nevertheless been an exciting year in terms of closer Eastern Partnership relations between the EU and Georgia. We, as a Group, fully support and welcome the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement and the Association Agreement, as it provides for Georgia’s political association with the European Union in addition to the country’s economic integration into the world’s largest economic market. By signing the Agreement, Georgia has assumed Treaty obligations to consolidate the rule of law, including independence of its judiciary, to pursue legislative reforms, to strengthen respect for fundamental human rights and freedoms, and to reinforce democratic institutions. A further aspect of the Agreement is that it will substantially enhance the political dialogue between Georgia and the EU, increase the involvement of civil society and promote tolerance for its minorities.  Far from being merely a set of rules and regulations, this really is a good trade agreement as it brings Georgia closer to the European Union and helps it resist Russian revanchist pressures.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: Mr President, tomorrow’s ratification will mark an historic move for future Georgia-EU relations. The country which is furthest to the East remains committed to its European choice, made back in 2003. I would also like to emphasise the remarkable trust in the EU by the Georgian people. A lasting commitment to a European course is of utmost importance in overcoming the remaining pressures from Russia. The so-called Russian-Abkhazian Partnership Alliance is yet another attempt to legalise the annexation of Georgian territory. It has to be deplored.  The ratification of the Association Agreement is not a Christmas gift for Georgia. It is a huge task that will require both good skills and solid speed from the Georgian authorities. For instance, in 2015 the legal harmonisation will embark on some 72 legislative initiatives. Equally, Georgia is expected to continue with democratic reforms, strengthen the market economy, and increase the living standards of its people. We also expect the Georgian judicial system to pass the test of being transparent and independent, and it must not be misused against political opponents. Georgia needs national reconciliation no less than it needs legal approximation. Here too, Europe is going to be both a cooperative and a demanding partner. I wish Georgia a Happy New Year.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Mr President, we can congratulate Georgia on making a free choice and up to 69% of Georgians want an association agreement to be reached. We have almost a consensus in this house that this is what we really want to do. Considerable progress has been made in Georgia in the independence of the judiciary, but I would like to stress that this work still needs to be continued. All charges must be free from the political process, and I believe that Georgia also wants to move in this direction. We want to be concerned about trade relations that may be disrupted by the fact that different countries in this area are making different decisions. Some turn to the European Union, others to the Eurasian Economic Union. It is up to us to ensure that trade can continue in different directions for Georgia as well. Finally, I would like to say that, at a time when there have been some cracks in the political process in Georgia recently in government cooperation, perhaps this offers an opportunity for all pro-European forces from the government and the opposition to engage in new forms of cooperation.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr. President! Today we are debating the third association of a former CIS state this year, about beautiful Georgia. The country has made remarkable progress in recent years, for example in the area of internal security. In my recitals to this association, we have also highlighted Georgia's active commitment to freedom and democracy.  But what about democracy in this House, in our Parliament? There comes a colleague and argues in a nasty way against people who allow themselves to have a different opinion. This colleague should be more concerned with the mood of european citizens, and anyone who listens to the citizens knows full well that they are tired of enlargement and association. Our aim – back to objectivity – should be to intervene mediating in the region, to act with restraint and to make peace, instead of constantly issuing new blank cheques, as the financial disaster in Ukraine will prove to us. Almost missionaryly, under the guise of self-determination, one state after another is associated and we consider ourselves to be the guarantors of the prosperity and security of these states. We overestimate ourselves, which is irresponsible and unforgivable to the citizens.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: Mr President, tomorrow we are going to ratify the Association Agreement. I would like to reiterate that we concluded this Association Agreement with the whole of Georgia, including its occupied territories of Abkhazia and the Tskhinvali region, and once again we clearly call on Russia to end its occupation of these territories. In a society which overwhelmingly supports integration of the country into western institutions, including the EU, it must be the duty of the main political forces to work in the spirit of consensus for implementation of reforms which stem from the Association Agreement.  Therefore Georgia’s Government needs to ensure, by all means possible, that the ongoing investigations into alleged abuses do not selectively and unfairly target its political opponents. We all know that the opposition of today is the government of tomorrow. This is a consistently repeated message which applies equally to the previous and current governments of Georgia. Our resolution also states that Georgia, like any other European state, has a European perspective and may apply to become a member of the Union. I am hopeful that the day will come when Georgia will become a part of the EU enlargement process. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: blue card issue. – Mr President, dear Mrs Kalniete, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Kalniete, for her excellent work. I understood this from your speech that you want to contrast one possibility against another: either the country has some contacts with Russia, or she is cooperating with the European Union. You could imagine a situation where a Member State associated with the European Union is both well integrated into the European Union and, at the same time, maintaining good economic contacts with Russia? Thank you!

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: answer to the blue card question. "Mr. Mamikina! Of course, choosing European integration and bringing europe closer to Europe does not mean concluding itself from the rest of the world. For example, Serbia, which currently has candidate status with the European Union, also has a free trade agreement with Russia. This is, of course, a matter for each country's own choice and, of course, it is also a matter of choice for the partner country concerned. The way in which Russia influences its neighbours by making them stand firmly on one side or the other is wrong and unacceptable.

name: Kati PIRI
text: Mr President, I would like to express my full support for the adoption of the association agreement with Georgia. It is a logical and necessary step towards achieving economic, social and political reforms that the Georgian people are clearly calling for. This, as far as I am concerned, is not the end, but the beginning of further cooperation with the EU. I therefore call for early ratification by the Member States so that deeper political cooperation and economic integration can be translated into action. This underlines that the involvement of the European Member States is serious and that the expectations of reforms are not just paper. The agreement anchors Georgia's european course when it comes to shared values. A multiform political system, responsible governance, independent justice and protection of fundamental rights. There is a government that is willing to work hard for a prosperous future. The task of them is therefore to combat polarisation. Civil society also plays an important role in this, in a supportive sense, but also as a watchdog on the necessary reforms. Finally, I would like to express my concern about the recent integration agreement between Russia and Abkhazia, which may be followed by an agreement with South Ossetia. The increasing influence of Russia in the border conflicts is a reality for which we can no longer turn a blind eye. It is therefore a good thing that the EU Monitoring Mission in Georgia will be extended by two years.

name: Bas BELDER
text: Mr President, an exciting question for next year 2015 will certainly be the outcome of the international negotiations on the Iranian nuclear programme. But what does this global issue of the first order actually have to do with our current debate on EU-Georgia relations? Let me be brief and clear in my reply: the activities of, allegedly, hundreds of Iranian companies on Georgian territory point to illegal acts that directly undermine the international sanctions regime against Tehran and strengthen Iran's controversial nuclear programme. My simple but urgent question to the Commission is: what steps is the EU taking in close cooperation with the Georgian authorities against these ongoing Iranian nuclear proliferation attempts? After all, how else is Brussels keeping the pressure on Tehran in the final crucial phase of negotiations?

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr President, as my Green colleagues have already said, the Greens support and welcome this Association Agreement, especially because it is something supported by opposition and government in Georgia and also almost 70% of the population is in favour. I think this consensus in favour of the EU could pave the way to defusing the current polarisation that we have in the political landscape and create the necessary conditions for a constructive dialogue between majority and minority forces, hopefully also doing away with the potential use of the judicial system to fight political opponents. I am glad the resolution includes a denunciation of the violent outbreaks of Islamophobia and homophobia that have taken place in the country, and the failure of the prosecution services and the judiciary to bring the perpetrators to justice in an effective way.  Let me end by asking the Commission one question: will you assist and monitor closely the Georgian authorities in their investment programme on hydropower plants, urging them to comply fully with EU standards and norms, in particular to the environmental impact assessment of larger plants?

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Mr. Vice-President, I have supported the persistent work of our rapporteur, Colleague Mamikins, on the report leading up to tomorrow's vote on the ratification of the Association Agreement with Georgia, as well as a series of discussions we have had on this topic at the Foreign Affairs Committee and on other committees of the European Parliament.  Tomorrow's event is extremely important for georgia's European path. It represents the beginning of a new phase of relations with the European Union, it represents a confirmation of the European orientation of the Georgian people, Georgia, which is part of our Eastern Partnership policy, a policy in which two more countries have taken the path of accession over the past few months, and Ukraine and Moldova and here is Georgia. Unfortunately, all these three countries are in the context of frozen conflicts, conflicts of this wider or close neighbourhood of Russia, where it seeks to position its influence strongly towards the freely decided orientation of these countries to join the European Union. In this context, the Association Agreement will not only strengthen our political relations, help economic relations, but also help the security of Georgia and the other two countries I mentioned.  It is also important that we use this instrument to strengthen systemic issues such as the rule of law, the functioning of the legal state, such as the functioning of the administration in Georgia, but also the independence of the judiciary, in particular state attorneys' offices. In this regard, I advise our Georgian colleagues to hire both special advisers in the reform process by both the Commission and the Member States who would give legitimacy and additional expertise to their reforms, as it is not good for Georgia to be perceived as a country where the judiciary is used selectively and further for political showdowns. Therefore, full support for our Georgian friends tomorrow, and resolve systemic problems honestly and hand in hand with Member States and with the Commission.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: Mr President, it has been a long and complex day, but this has been an extremely significant debate and sets the tone for a new chapter in EU-Georgia relations. It is clear that the deep and comprehensive free trade area will have a long-term beneficial effect on Georgia’s economy and its citizens and their lives. Already nearly one-third of trade in Georgia is with us in Europe. That will massively increase following this agreement. I want also to give credit for the reforms that have started there. I met the Chair of the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Georgian Parliament today and was able to celebrate with him some important steps towards – if I may say so – social democracy, under the lead of the current government, the Georgian Dream coalition, including a labour code and anti-discrimination law and reform of the prison system. He told me, and asked me to tell the House, that this agreement is about us dealing with the country of Georgia and not being involved with, or creating any internal differences between, individual political parties within Georgia. This Parliament has my own Group’s commitment on that. Potential worries remain, of course, in particular in relation to the areas of justice and concerns about selective justice. Clearly there must be avoidance of using the judicial system in any sort of political way.  Let me finish by saying that Croatia is the tenth Member State to have ratified the Agreement, but my country has not. I hope my country will get rid of its mealy-mouthed approach and ratify as quickly as possible.

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: Mr President, as Chair of the South Caucasus delegation, I am particularly pleased to see that the rapporteur has set out in the report, in very clear terms, Georgia’s assured European future. Georgians must know that they can be assured of our European solidarity. The extension of our monitoring mission is just one indication of that. The Georgian Government has a clearly signposted road ahead. Now it is time to implement the many reforms envisaged by the Association Agreement. We recognise the real political challenges these changes present, but they must be delivered.  Monitoring implementation of the Association Agreement, and the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement, sits of course with the Joint Parliamentary Committee. This Parliamentary scrutiny of our joint agenda should remain always constructive and ready to adapt to any further future challenges posed by the Russian Federation. I hope tomorrow we have a decisive and clear vote that sets out the entirety of this Parliament’s position in terms of Georgia.   (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card question. – Mr Karim, your party leader, the British Prime Minister, has called for a European Union to stretch from the Atlantic to the Urals. This, he said, is his dream. Obviously we are now talking about Georgia. How far to the East do you see the Prime Minister's wish going?

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: blue-card answer. – A European Union which is based upon our values is a European Union which will serve not only the people of Europe, but also the world. The fact that we – my country and my government – certainly have a vision of a European Union which is strong and united and is made up of countries that share our values, is one that this Parliament can stand united behind, so I endorse my Prime Minister’s position on that.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul In recent years, the Georgian Parliament has taken a position on a large number of proposals for new legislation and reforms to allow for more in-depth cooperation with the EU. The decision to approve the EU-Georgia Association Agreement is the result of this endeavour and an historic step on Georgia's path to freedom.  Georgia has chosen the European route. Georgia has chosen this route despite Russian threats, and despite pressure. Russia recognises the importance of this agreement, and so does Ukraine. The Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko earlier this year called the approval of his country's Association Agreement the most important moment in Ukraine's history since the fall of the Soviet Union.  For Georgia, the association agreement is a crucial issue for the future. This is an important crossroads: should Georgia be allowed to move closer to the EU or should the Georgian people be governed by the men of power in Moscow? Those of us who choose to vote in favour of the association agreement are on the right side of history. Those who choose to vote 'no' deliberately choose the path that is That of Vladimir Putin.  When the European Parliament voted on the association agreement with Ukraine, the EFDD Group, including its representatives from my country, Sweden, chose to vote with Putin. I think there are many of us in this House who are wondering what will happen this time? Will the EFDD Group, or parts of it, continue to vote for Putin or will it vote for Georgia's right to shape its own future?

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking First of all, I would like to congratulate rapporteur Mamikins on such a report, which is of historical importance, because this is a historic moment that we will talk about in a dozen years' time: this debate has started, here in the European Union. To all those who doubt the Union, they are expressing very different strange views, and I would like to make you aware: look, this is another country for which the European Union is the target, which wants to adopt our values, which it wants to introduce the legal system, the order that we have here in the European Union. For Georgia itself, this is the beginning of a great work. I know how much work needs to be done, how to join the European Union, but this warning has been made clear. They must start by avoiding selective justice. There is no dilemma here as to whether we choose Putin or the European Union here. It is georgians who have chosen the direction of the European Union, but they must take care of cooperation with Russia themselves, and we can help them. Thank you very much.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Commissioner, the Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia contributes to the European course of that country. But Georgia's approach to Europe must be based on respect for fundamental rights, the rule of law and the rights of minorities. I would therefore like to take this step to call on the competent authorities of Georgia to fully respect the rights of the Greek minority, who have lived and worked in Georgia for hundreds of years. In this context, the Georgian authorities must ensure: firstly, that those Greek Pontians who wish to return to their homes are returned to their homes; secondly, for the supply to them of their homes, which have been illegally occupied by third parties; thirdly, to protect the right to property, which has been unlawfully withssed. I expect decisive action from you, Mr. Avramopoulos. After all, you have served as Minister for Foreign Affairs and you are aware of this.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: Mr President, the year 2014 should be seen as an unprecedented year in Georgia’s advance towards the European Union. Signature of the Association Agreement has materialised, despite the volatile situation in the region and external pressures from Russia. We should welcome above all, however, the strong consensus among Georgian political parties and in the population of Georgia on pursuing the European path. Once such strong pro-European conviction has been demonstrated, it is our duty to support the country in its strategic orientation – even more so in the situation where the main external pressure comes from Russia, which continues to occupy the Georgian regions of Abkhazia and South Ossetia.  Georgia’s biggest neighbour might be countering the efforts for reforms in the country, and with the recent developments in Abkhazia we need to reassure Georgia, really convincingly, that we stand by it.  The Association Agreement is the first important step and visa liberalisation should, and I hope will, be the next one. We should make sure that no obstacles stand in Georgia’s way. Yes, there is a substantial reform process ahead of Georgia. It will be long, difficult and complicated. But it can definitely be facilitated through its commitment to European engagement, of course with our active support and participation.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: Mr President, tomorrow Parliament will decide on the ratification of the third new-generation Association Agreement after those with Ukraine and the Republic of Moldova – that of Georgia. The ratification not only constitutes a strong recognition of the progress made but also acknowledges Georgiaʼs ambition and commitment to a European path. The signing of the agreements between the European Union and Georgia, the Republic of Moldova and Ukraine all took place in Brussels on the very same day. Tomorrowʼs decision on the Association Agreement with Georgia follows the ratification this Parliament voted for earlier this year for Ukraine and Moldova. This vote finalises a process in this House while also opening a new chapter in relation to the desire and determination of these three countries to come closer to the European Union, in line with their citizensʼ aspirations. I am confident that we will confirm the strong majority we witnessed in the vote of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. I call on Member States to follow and proceed swiftly with their own ratification process.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. The decision of the European authorities and the reports submitted by the European Parliament meet the expectations of the Georgian public. As we point out in the resolution, there is widespread and supranational agreement in Georgia on integration with the West, including the EU and NATO. It should be recalled that the path to this act was paved in 2008 by European leaders – Saint Polish Lech Kaczynski and French President Nicolas Sarkozy, who saved georgian statehood. While ing satisfaction and approval of the Georgian partnership, as before from Ukraine, I believe that in my document we are unduly restricting Georgia, as in the 45th paragraph of the resolution, calling on it to fully respect the Union's environmental standards when building energy infrastructure. In preparing to work closely with this young democracy, the EU should behave more flexibly towards it.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: Mr President, this is, as a lot of speakers before have told us, an historic step. It means that we are extending opportunities and a stable framework to the people in Georgia and we are doing it to a country that is under an ongoing Russian threat, with soldiers occupying parts of Georgia. We will, of course, see renewed pressure after this, and it is important to state and clarify that any aggression towards Georgia from Russia is just as unacceptable as the moves we see from Russia towards Ukraine today. It is important also to see that this is an opportunity that must be used by Georgia and the Georgian Government. It opens up free trade, investment and cooperation on a number of other levels and dimensions. This means that the Georgian Government must reform and proceed with the reforms in Georgia. It means that the selective justice we see the Georgian Government using against its opposition today is not acceptable. At the same time as Georgia is now moving closer to Europe the Georgian Government must ensure that its society is moving closer to European democracy. It is about strengthening the citizens of Georgia but also about utilising and benefiting from all the opportunities that this agreement offers. It is historic, but it is a challenge to the Georgian Government to stop selective justice, and it is important to say to Russia: ʽstay out of Georgiaʼ.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Mr. President, congratulations to my colleague Maminkis. Georgia needs the support of the European Union today, not only to foster further internal, democratic and economic development, but also to message that the European Union supports Georgia's territorial integrity against external pressures and separatist projects. However, the partnership between Brussels and Tbilisi should be made by both sides. As Georgia faces serious judicial reform and its independence from politics, the fight against corruption and a higher degree of political tolerance, the European Union needs to continue consolidating eastern partnership policies at a critical time of dealing with Russian interests.  The association agreement with Georgia, following the validation of similar agreements with Ukraine and Moldova, creates a space of cooperation with democracies on the shores of the Black Sea, which is unfortunately increasingly becoming a space of confrontation, especially after the annexation of Crimea and growing doubts about the stretching of new supply lines for energy. And this cooperation is extremely important for the overall European project, because the Black Sea, Caucasian area has not had the good fortune to be previously involved in mainstream European integration as the Baltics or the Balkans.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Mr. President! The integration of other European states into the EU's internal market is fundamentally positive, especially if reforms are achieved in the partner country and commitments to freedom, democracy, the rule of law, human rights, etc., or strategically interesting access to oil and gas supply chains on the Black Sea. But I would like to ask why the most ambitious free trade agreement between the European Union and Georgia contains phrases such as 'concerning Georgia's integration into NATO', which not only mention a country that is not involved in this agreement, namely Russia, but discuss its role in the South Caucasus and its position on international law, which, in a free trade agreement between the European Union and Georgia, address a country that is not involved in this agreement with Georgia? Why does the European Union express in this agreement its astonishment at Russia's view of this agreement as a threat to its economic and political interests, even though a few points were previously called for Georgia's participation in crisis management operations within the framework of European defence policy and the wish to invite Georgia to training and training?

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have the impression, from the debate that has taken place, that some people think that we are making agreements almost to spite Russia: let us go and sign agreements with Ukraine, with Georgia. It's not like that. The European Union is made up of 28 countries but is not just a Union of the 28 countries. It is a territory where free trade takes place and a territory that needs to be enlarged, that needs to be developed, and that is why the European Union today opens up its capacity for agreement to a country which, by its very nature, is Western and which has intelligently set out on the road to democracy. We need only recall the elections that took place in this country in 2012 and 2013, regular and 'Western' elections, which helped to make the country reliable and able to maintain the agreements it will sign. It is clear that georgia still has a long way to go to make itself reliable with the European Union. But, I'd say we opened up a lot of credit to this country. We did so because we believe in the possibility of expanding the market and we believe in the validity of the agreements that we are going to conclude with that country. I repeat: we do not do this at all because we intend to act out of spite, as some have imagined could happen. Let us therefore continue along this path, let us move forward with the enlargement of the European Union, let us involve all the countries in the East, in order to enlarge the Union still further and to make this Union a union of peoples even more.

name: Clare MOODY
text: Mr President, in a letter from the Georgian Prime Minister this week Mr Garibashvili referred to our shared values. These shared values extend so much further than simply trade. I welcome the Association Agreement and the continuing positive relationship between Georgia and the EU, a relationship that aims to improve peopleʼs lives in both communities.  Through the wider cooperation framework of the Association Agreement we need to work together with the Georgian Government to develop its social model. The government is already doing great work to engage its citizens and civil society in the democratic process and in delivering social policy, a good example being the recent anti-discrimination law. It is only the Georgian Government that can ultimately deliver a deeper social model, but I look forward to working with them to provide the support needed to deliver on those shared values.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: Mr President, tomorrow, with the ratification of the Association Agreement with Georgia, the EU marks the final step towards the commitment it gave more than a year ago at the Vilnius Summit. The European Union promised that the three countries that matched the criteria would be able to come one step closer to the EU: Georgia was one of the first and most active countries from the region to set itself on the European path, and it has paid a steep price for its choice. Despite everything today, we should proudly rejoice that we have reached this important landmark.   However, there are still some alarming developments. People who laid the foundation for the Georgia-Euro-Atlantic path are being persecuted on political motives, and Georgia is increasingly demonstrating indications of selective justice. The current government should note that this has been taken into account very seriously here in Parliament. Georgia has to stay on the reform track, while not allowing the erosion of democratic achievements which took it a considerable number of years to reach. It should be clear that the political elite of the country has to stay united when it comes to Euro-Atlantic integration, the rule of law and the independence of the judicial system. Only when these conditions are met can the real Georgian Dream come true and not evaporate as an empty promise.

name: Michał BONI
text: Georgia's path towards the values of the West and the rationality of the Union's economic model does not begin today. It lasts a long time, is embedded in history, was built by previous governments and continues. Reforms are already being carried out. Its strength is the public belief in the importance of this choice – towards Europe.  Today is an opportunity to mobilise the new energy needed in the next stages for membership of the Union. Energy that unites people and politics. The association process is the alignment of national law with EU standards, including by ensuring fairness and stability of the principle of law as an overarching principle. This builds on the transparency of the state. The key to a functioning state is not only the efficiency of public services, but also the power of civil society. I believe that georgia will make the next leap in this area and in the conditions for economic development. On Georgia's way to the West, the European Union cannot be just an official. He must be a generous adviser who, after assessing, for example, visa liberalisation readiness or the quality of offers to use European neighbourhood tools, will launch projects whose benefits will be quickly felt by Georgian families. But on Georgia's way to Europe, something else is needed: a clear choice, visible and understandable to all partners and observers, including those who are hostile, like Russia. Dear friends of Georgia, you are strong with your identity and wisdom, no worries, we will do it!

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: First of all, I would like to congratulate my colleague, Mr Mamikins, on a very serious document. Georgia became the third country in the Eastern Partnership after Ukraine and Moldova, which concluded an association agreement with the European Union. This is a very important step forward in relations between the European Union and Georgia, and this Association Agreement consolidates Georgia's commitment to the path of political and economic integration. We all know that the Eastern Partnership countries have, and still have, many difficulties with their self-determination, and I therefore congratulate Georgia on choosing the path of European integration despite the difficulties and pressures it is experiencing. This agreement will be mutually beneficial and, in the long term, stronger political and economic ties will ensure greater stability, security and a better life for the Georgian people.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Mr President, I strongly support Georgiaʼs path towards the European Union, and the ratification of the Association Agreement is a big step forward. Implementation, of course, will certainly be a big task for Georgia. I hope that at the Riga Summit in 2015 we can talk more clearly about further European perspectives for Georgia and other most advanced Eastern Partnership countries. Successful implementation of the visa liberalisation action plan is also important and hopefully this could be one of the deliverables of the Riga Summit.  It is important to support the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Georgia as well as its full right to make independent decisions regarding foreign and security policy. The so-called treaty on alliance and integration between Russia and the de facto authorities of Abkhazia is a cause for great concern. There is a threat that such activities could lead to the annexation by Russia of part of the territory of Georgia.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, having listened to the whole debate between my fellow Members, I wanted to reflect on this free trade and association agreement with Georgia. We often talk about free trade agreements – today with Georgia, first with Moldova and Ukraine – and I hear so many colleagues talking about 'historic steps', 'important moments' and, probably, they are. We too are very much in favour of the principles of the European Union being respected and taken on by other countries. However, the fact remains that I always feel a little acrimony and bitterness towards Russia, as if we wanted to spite it and did not want it. Martusciello but that's the feeling. In my opinion, however, we should exercise that great peace-keeping force that has united nations that have waged war for hundreds of years also against Russia. That would be the most important thing to do.

name: József NAGY
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. Georgia's approach to the European Union is also strategically important for the stability of the region and a desirable partnership for us, so I support this Association Treaty. However, I would like to draw attention to one important issue, which I believe has received little care during the negotiations. The situation of minorities in Georgia can be a key issue for the future of the country. Although there have been positives about laws affecting minorities since Georgia became independent, even today the relationship between the majority and the minority is characterised more by mistrust and inconsistent minority policy. This can also be decisive for Georgia's territorial unity, but the need for reconciliation also manifests itself from time to time. We do not need to look far in time or space at the dangers of underestimating minority issues. The case of Ukraine clearly shows that it is in the interest of both sides to settle the conditions of coexistence in a way acceptable to both the majority and the minority.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Like Mr Masood, I too would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. Corrao wanted to make a few brief comments, having listened to the debate, which was very interesting. I was struck by the fact that an Italian colleague from the PPE, Mr Syley, was not a member of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats. Mr Martusciello referred to the fact that this choice of association agreement should not be seen as a spite of Russia. This seems to me to be a speech that I have also heard echoed in other speeches, but I believe that this is a very ill-handled issue. We must not raise the issue of the association agreement with Georgia in this way, but with a view to building our own of greater strength and presence in the area as the European Union. We cannot expect only the United States and Russia to exert influence in the Black Sea, the Caucasus and Georgia. It is important for the European Union to be able to play a role and the association agreement allows it, including through the economy, to play a political role.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, let me start by expressing my thanks to the Members of this Parliament for their interest and pointed comments. Our discussion has confirmed that we agree on the need to continue to strongly support Georgia moving closer to the European Union. We also all welcome Georgiaʼs political commitment to continue with the necessary reforms, in particular regarding the acceleration of reforms in the field of justice, the rule of law and respect for the fundamental rights of all citizens without discrimination. Prosecutions should be transparent, proportionate, free of political motivation and expediency, and should adhere strictly to due process.
