A positive track record of implementing the Association Agreement, which is only a first step, and our support, will be the best way for Georgia to reach our common objective: to build a democratic, stable and prosperous country. Let me now turn to Greek in order to honour our President. In conclusion, I would like to emphasise that the adoption tomorrow of the European Union-Georgia Association Agreement opens up the European perspective of a country which, on the basis of its history and geostrategic role, is sure to also play an important role in shaping an environment of peace, cooperation and progress for Georgia and for the wider region. It paves the way for a modern, European Republic of Georgia based on the principle of the rule of law, respect for fundamental rights and democratic values, which meets the expectations of a people who are leaving behind difficult times and moving towards a more optimistic European future.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, dear colleagues, dear Mr Avramopoulos, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Avramopoulos, for his excellent work. Today's debate is, personally, confirmation that the European Parliament supports further political and economic reforms in Georgia. The Association Agreement also opens up new opportunities for both Georgia and the European Union. It is also a sign of solidarity with the Georgian people, because it is precisely the idea of solidarity that is very close to us, the Social Democrats, at the very foundations of the European Union. I would like to underline that the relationship between Georgia and the European Union is not directed against third countries: the aim is to extend positive cooperation. This is very important, and this cooperation will benefit not only the European Union and Georgia, but also the whole region and all georgia's neighbours. I would like to thank once again the colleagues who took part in the preparation of this report and those who have now taken part in the debate. I look forward to a very positive vote at tomorrow's meeting and your support for Georgia and the Georgian people and i have to say that the President of Georgia will come to this chamber tomorrow, and we, colleagues, will see how important the ratification of this treaty is to the Georgian people. Thank you again for the debate.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate.  The vote will take place on Thursday 18 December 2014. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The EU-Georgia Association Agreement is the third agreement, following the ratification of agreements with Ukraine and the Republic of Moldova, with eastern partnership countries. The resulting deep and comprehensive free trade area offers an opportunity to modernise associated economies and the flow of investment from the EU.  However, the aim of the Association Agreement with Georgia is not only to integrate Georgia into the single market, but also to cooperate in the framework of foreign and security policy and justice. Georgia's efforts in recent years to approximate the rules and ratify the Association Agreement in June 2014 are of great importance for the country's future as they deepen the process of its inclusion in the European legal, economic, social and political mainstream. One of the effects of the agreement is that Georgia will proceed to the next stage of visa liberalisation with the aim of introducing visa-free travel. The EU's borders should be open to the citizens of our Eastern Partnership eastern neighbours so that trade, science and society can take place without unnecessary obstacles and action for the benefit of both sides.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the Council and Commission statements on the Khartoum Process and the forthcoming 'Horn of Africa-EU Migration Route Initiative' (2014/3001(RSP)).

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am particularly pleased to respond to the request for a Council statement on the 'European Union and Horn of Africa' initiative on migration routes, the so-called Khartoum Process and in particular on the results of the Ministerial Conference held in Rome on 28 November 2014. I would like to express my personal satisfaction and that of the Presidency for the active participation of the European Union and its Member States, which has been crucial in ensuring its success. We all agree that cooperation with the countries of origin and transit of migrants, in a spirit of dialogue, partnership and shared responsibility, is essential for the effective management of migratory flows. The Khartoum Process, set up by the Ministerial Conference in Rome, is a particularly valuable framework within which we can discuss immigration and related issues with various important partners in East Africa. After a series of unsuccessful attempts, this is the first time that the European Union and its Member States have been able to start cooperation on immigration in this way. This also means that we would be able to have a regular dialogue with the countries of the Horn of Africa and East Africa, regions of origin and transit of significant migratory flows to the European Union. The significant increase in migrant arrivals from the central Mediterranean area is largely related to the pressure that originates in those regions or stems from existing routes in the region used for transit purposes. At this early stage, cooperation will focus on the fight against trafficking in human beings and trafficking in migrants. The declaration adopted by the Ministerial Conference identifies a number of concrete operational measures to be implemented and we are all aware of the need to take urgent measures to prosecute smugglers and traffickers and dismantle their criminal networks. They constitute a serious threat to the lives of the migrants themselves. In the medium term, as clearly underlined in the declaration, the aim is to broaden the framework and achieve a dialogue that includes all four areas covered by the global approach to migration and mobility: legal migration and mobility, irregular migration, migration development and international protection. I would like to take this opportunity to emphasise that the Declaration recognises the promotion and respect of human rights as a cross-cutting issue in our cooperation. It also expressly recognises the need to respect and fully implement the principles of international protection with a clear reference to the 1951 Geneva Convention. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have established a new framework for cooperation for the Khartoum process, and I believe that this is a good start. Now, starting from this base, it's time to move on to a more active phase. My call on the European Union and its Member States to contribute actively to the development and implementation of this new process. This Parliament's support for the Khartoum process will be crucial to the success of its implementation.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, honourable Members, today you have taken me on a journey from the United States to Georgia and from Georgia to the Horn of Africa. I hope that the travelling will end early tonight, Mr President, as we are all exhausted, but this issue is of great importance, it is true. This House has witnessed many debates on the need to save lives along the perilous migration route to Europe. It is also in this House that I have heard repeated calls to the Commission and the Member States to make practical responses to the critical reality of migrant smuggling and human trafficking from the Horn of Africa. To achieve these objectives we needed a framework for dialogue and for implementing concrete action together with the countries in that region.  This is what the Horn of Africa Migration Initiative is – a political process on migration with the countries of the Horn of Africa, along with the main Mediterranean transit countries, covering countries of origin, transit and destination along the migratory route from the Horn of Africa to Europe. More specifically, it should bring together Djibouti, Egypt, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Kenya, Somalia, South Sudan and Sudan as well as Libya and Tunisia. Beyond political declarations, we will assist partner countries in providing better responses to migrants in vulnerable situations, enhancing the ability of the law enforcement and judicial authorities in the European Union and African partner countries to fight traffickers and smugglers in a more effective way.  We must not forget that migration flows do not only bring challenges, but also bring opportunities both for countries of origin and for countries of destination. This is why I strongly believe that our cooperation with the partner countries in this process should not stop at fighting irregular migration. We must set out high ambitions and look together at the root causes of the migratory phenomenon. You, the honourable Members of this Parliament, have called several times for effective cooperation with third countries, both of origin and transit, for this very purpose. The Horn of Africa Migration Initiative is one of the responses to these calls. In line with the declaration on migration mobility adopted by the Heads of State and Governments at their fourth EU-Africa Summit, we must look at expanding our dialogue to include development and legal migration opportunities, as well as catering for effective international protection of those in need. The Horn of Africa Migration Initiative can also help us to better understand each other and to identify the common challenges we face across our continents and look for solutions in a spirit of shared responsibility. I know that many in this House will have questions about how the human rights they mention are integrated in this process, especially with countries where democratic values are not respected. I can reassure you that promotion of human rights remains an absolute priority for our migration policy and its external dimension, and this is fully reflected in this framework of dialogue.  On that basis, we can continue developing this process and ensure that it stays continuously adapted to our political objectives – objectives that are shared, fully accepted and voluntary. I look forward to the swift launch of practical action and projects to put this dialogue into practice and to achieving tangible results soon.  Concerning the two main themes, we would firstly, on the issue of stranded migrants, mainly aim at developing regional frameworks and national strategies for voluntary returns and the reintegration of migrants. I am glad to announce that for this purpose initial funding of EUR 5 million has already been identified from the European Union development cooperation instrument.  Secondly, on the issue of the development of national and regional strategies to fight organised crime, in particular smuggling and trafficking in human beings, we have set aside EUR 750 000 from the International Security Fund to finance this action. The individual projects are currently being developed by the Commission, and their implementation will start next year. We will encourage our African partners to consider these proposals and to engage in putting them into practice. Member States have expressed their interest in taking the lead in implementing initiatives in relation to these two areas. The peer-to-peer exchanges that these activities will foster are essential for strengthening ties and identifying durable solutions. To conclude, improving the current dramatic situation lies in our hands. I strongly believe that establishing a sustainable dialogue and implementing it through concrete cooperation on the ground is part of the solution. We must act now and we must act together. Only by joining forces as a European Union can we, the Commission, the European External Action Service and the EU Member States, seize this unique opportunity. The Commission is counting on Parliament’s political support for this process.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: f'isem group PPE. – Sur President, Sur Kummissarju, irrid nibda dan id-diskors billi nilqa' l-Pro大ess ta' Khartoum li tnieda ftit tal-ġimgħat beauty. Dan il-pro大ess hu mmirat biex nindirizzaw it-traffikar tal-immigranti bejn il-Qarn tal-Afrika u l-Ewropa.Dan il-Pro大ess wassal biex pajjiżi finalment jersqu u jpoġġu fuq il-mejda tad-diskussjoni u għalhekk, bir-raġun, li għandna nkunu ottimisti.  Kif sostnejna diversi drabi u ntennu llum, l-unika triq 'il quddiem biex il-politika Ewropea dwar l-immigrazzjoni tkun ta' su大大ess hi li jkollna soluzzjiejonit olistiikei. Li jieħdu inkunsiderazzjoni hawk aspett. Wieħed minn dawn l-aspetti l-aktar kru大jali huwa li nassiguraw li jkun hemm kooperazzjoni sħiħa ma' pajjiżi terzi fl-Afrika, b'mod partikolari minn pajjiżi fejn jitilqu l-immigranti u pajjiżi ta' tranżitu. Dawn iridu jiġu megħjuna fl-isforzi collha kontra kull attività illegali li ssir minn fuq dawk li huma l-aktar vulnerabbli. Irridu ngħinu wkoll biex jiġu indirizzati r-raġunijiet - l-għeruq ta' dak li jwassal għal persuni biex jitilqu minn pajjiżhom. Il-pro大ess huwa estensiv, imma hu importanti li se jservi wkoll biex jingħata appoġġ lill-vittmi ta' din l-attività illegali - it-traffikar tan-nies – filwaqt li l-pro大ess irid jipproteġi d-drittijiet tal-bniedem, tal-immigranti, ta' dawk li jkunu nqabdu fil-morsa tat-traffikar. Issa huwa importanti li jkun hemm fund biżżejjed biex dan il-Pro大ess iħalli l-frott. Ma jistax ikun li dan il-Pro大ess jitħalla fuq l-ixkaffa. Għandna nsibu soluzzjonijiet biex dan il-pro大ess jagħtina riżultati. (Il-kelliem qabel li jwieġeb għal mistoqsija "karta blu" skont l-Artikolu 162(8) tar-Regoli ta' Pro大edura).

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, Mrs Metsola, I would like to know if you know the situation of the countries of the Horn of Africa, and if you know what role these countries play in human trafficking in this part of the world?

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: tweġiba map blu. – Iva Madame Vergiat, mhux talli naf is-sitwazzjoni f'dawk il-pajjiżi, imma jiena ngħix f'pajjiż fejn il-persuni li jiġu għall-għajnuna in jitolb l-stretched fil-pajjiż tiegħi huma propreju minn dawk il-pajjiżi. In hu għalhekk aħna għidna, kif għidna wkoll fir-riżoluzzjoni li aħna vvotajna dwarha dalgħodu, li għandna jkollna kull sforz kontra kull proèess ta' traffikar tal-bnedmin biex incunu nistgħu nipproteġu lil dawk vulnerabbli.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Combating the causes of flight is undeniably important. And yet the Khartoum process currently offers many unanswered questions. The fight against criminal smugglers and traffickers seems to be a higher priority than the immediate protection of people fleeing war and political persecution. The final priority of the conclusion mentions support for the creation of reception centres. Some call them detention centres, and the German Minister of the Interior even speaks of welcome centres. But who should feel welcome where exactly for how long? And what is to be done there? Access to asylum procedures will also be granted there. But what does "access" mean here? And who should determine a right to asylum according to what criteria? The UNHCR, the Member States, the transit countries concerned? Or should even complete asylum procedures be carried out there? By what standards? And does this not mean, after all, a foreclosure of Europe? Yes! We need safe and legal routes to Europe. However, the individual right to asylum must not be restricted, and we, as Europeans, must not simply buy ourselves free. The projects of this process must therefore be questioned very critically by us. And even if there are approaches that we all welcome, would all states actually participate? Finally, what is the specific role of the Commission in the Khartoum process? Do the member states want to develop ideas, but then please finance them from the EU budget? And how should the European Parliament be informed and involved? Many unanswered questions – I hope that the Commission and the Council can provide at least a few answers today.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: On the other: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr More migrants than ever are now making their way to Europe to have the chance to make a life, quite simply. Many are fleeing war and persecution, and since there are no legal and safe ways to come to Europe to seek asylum here, most have no choice but to become dependent on completely ruthless people smugglers to get in a boat and make a deadly journey to one of our countries.  This year alone, the lives of 3419 people have been lost in the Mediterranean, according to a unhcr report last week. The Mediterranean is becoming a sea of death, a huge burial ground for people without names united only by this single one: to save the lives of their own children and to seek a life of peace and freedom.  Now the Presidency has initiated the Khartoum process – cooperation between the EU and a number of regimes in the Horn of Africa, with the aim of preventing asylum seekers from entering countries such as Libya in order to make these dangerous journeys here from there. Political initiatives are needed, and I obviously welcome this, but no country can do this on its own, and I think we should never imagine that regimes in the Horn of Africa that oppress and harm their people so badly that they have to flee, will cooperate with europe on this.  I mention Sudan, Somalia and the absolutely harsh dictatorship of Eritrea, where the eu's only prisoner of conscience, Dawit Isaak, is currently in prison after more than 4000 days in prison without trial. Are these the countries we are going to work with? I question it, and I do it vigorously. I think we should look into this, and the Commission needs to better define its own role in this. The challenges are great, but we must never rely on dictatorships to find solutions to our migration issues. (The speaker agreed to answer a question (blue card) in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card question. – I heard your comments with regard to dictatorships. Do you share my disgust and dismay that one of the root causes, one of the terrible dictatorships, was in Ethiopia – the Derg – and yet former President Mengistu, at the age of 77, lives in political luxury, having claimed asylum in Zimbabwe. Would you join me in condemnation of President Mugabe and join my call to have Mengistu extradited back to Ethiopia where, of course, he has been convicted of crimes of genocide?

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: blue-card answer. – Your question is extremely important. What we need to do at this point is say that we will never accept dictators setting the rules for us as European free democracies, as the European Union. We must keep in mind that it is, for example, one of our citizens, Dawit Isaak, who has been kept in prison for more than 4 000 days in Eritrea, which is one of the harshest dictatorships in the world. Are these the people that we are going to collaborate with? Should we trust them to save human beings’ lives?  Let me tell you that frankly I doubt it.  It is our responsibility, and we can never shrug it off on to those regimes in the countries in the Khartoum process. I welcome the initiative, but I deem it to be a failure from the beginning, because we cannot speak with double tongues; we need to speak with one clear voice on freedom of speech, human rights, democracy and the rule of law.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, the purpose of the Khartoum process is to normalise the relations of the Member States of the European Union with the countries of the Horn of Africa. It's commonplace, it's normal. We are in dialogue with dictatorships that blithely flout human rights and whose nationals migrate to escape repression. The Italian Presidency wants, among other things, to promote the full integration of Eritrea as a responsible actor and full member of the international community. You, Commissioner, want to lay the foundations for substantial political cooperation with these countries of origin and the Council has just told us the same thing. You even told me in committee that if the problem was in the name of the process, we could change it. It would just be a problem of countries of origin, of transit countries. The aim would be to prevent migrants from fleeing their country, by allowing their government to repress them with impunity. What dialogue can we have with these governments, which are just seeking international legitimacy - the legitimacy that you are giving them - and who are involved , I say and repeating - of all the trafficking in the region? How can you tell us that human rights are at the heart of this process and that they remain a priority? How can you tell us that this will save lives?

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. Mr President, that must have been a separate meeting there in Rome with representatives of Sudan and South Sudan, Egypt, Ethiopia, Eritrea. I don't see Libya on the list and I think that's because we don't know who we should be asking to represent a government in Libya. I remember a few years ago debating in this House about the deal that the Government of Italy had made with Libya so that Libya would keep the migrants at home. And I remember the moment when Mrs. Malmström, Mr. Avramopoulos's predecessor, had to go to Libya to ensure that 250 Eritreans who had been sent back to Libya from Europe (Italy) would not be sent back to Eritrea, because that would kill them. We sat here at the table to talk about 'how do you keep your migrants at home?' with regimes that kill people! Because that's what it comes down to. And we want to 'lend a hand' to those regimes that kill people through official money for development cooperation. It is not just the name of the Khartoum process, although I do wonder how you were able to start that process in the capital of Sudan. I am concerned about the rejection of this proposal and the way in which Europe packages the return of migrants as development aid with dictatorial regimes.

name: James CARVER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, we all want to help desperate and brave people escape the terror of war, conflict and extreme poverty, but any such help must be workable, practical and in everyone’s best interests, and must not encourage a bad situation to get worse.  We must address the causes of migration if we are to dissuade people from trying to cross the Mediterranean in small boats, and this is what both the international community and nation states are failing to do. Not content with the free movement of half a billion people, the European Union now wishes to take control of refugee policy. There is a desperate issue of 4.3 million internally-displaced people in Sudan, South Sudan, Somalia, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Kenya and Uganda. Instead of extending EU powers into refugee policy, we should consider the impact of other EU policies on Africa.  How about the Common Agricultural Policy? This is not only a waste for British tax payers, but also dumps over-subsidised food into African economies, increasing unemployment and poverty. Or fishing? EU policy has destroyed fish stocks off the coast of Somalia, ruining people’s livelihoods and driving them into poverty or piracy. Then there is the issue of trade. Why do we not stop imposing grossly high trade barriers, thus allowing all to benefit from the increased economic activity and cheaper food prices?  The EU has inflicted untold damage on the Horn of Africa, which only asked to be treated with dignity and respect. We must lift the barriers imposed by the EU and address the root causes of migration.  Then there is the question of why the international community continues to oppose the recognition of Somaliland. Surely, now, what the Horn of Africa needs is a strong, stable and friendly state, capable of providing for its own citizens and of trading its way in the wider world.  Only by highlighting and encouraging the success story of Somaliland can we set an example of hope for this troubled region. In this season of goodwill, why not give out presents? Give the Horn of Africa hope and it can begin to help itself.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Mr President, 200 000 people, most of them young people, have emigrated in recent years persecuted by their country's regime. Economic migrants on the edge of poverty, unemployed, without decent health care, leave behind homes at risk of foreclosure by the banks. This country is not Sudan nor does it belong to Sub-Saharan Africa. It is Greece, a Member State of the European Union. But unfortunately he has a lot in common with the country you're thinking of helping today. These 200,000 Greeks, who emigrated due to the crisis, are young scientists up to 40 years old. Bright minds with an appetite for work but no future in my country Greece. Certainly, migration from Africa to the countries of Europe is a major problem. We know this better, because we are dealing with it ourselves, facing the European Union, which requires us to accept illegal immigrants in our country, as laid down in the Dublin II Treaty. But it is foolish for the European Union to fund programmes to restrict migrants from Africa when it is not interested in curbing internal migration caused by its bad policies. The internal migration flow shows that the countries of the sturdy North, condemning the countries of the South to economic decline and impoverishment, attract the most remarkable manpower.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Mr President, the need to tackle the migration problem structurally should be clear to us by now. Part of a holistic approach to migration, as we voted in our resolution this morning, also means more integration of the European Union's domestic and foreign policy. It is good that the Commissioner is also looking beyond Europe's borders to seek cooperation with third countries. But if you look at the map of Africa and the countries participating in the Khartoum process, there is a white spot between Tunisia and Egypt and that is Libya. Libya is also not participating in the Rome Declaration as part of the Rabat process. But Libya is the biggest country of origin for people who want to cross the Mediterranean, and I wonder how we can make a European policy in this area without taking into account in any way what is happening in Libya. How are you going to solve this, including in the context of the Khartoum process?

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: Mr President, every year armed conflicts, persecution, a lack of economic prospects, human rights violations and natural disasters force millions of people to leave their homes in the Horn of Africa to embark on dangerous journeys through multiple countries and to cross the Mediterranean Sea in their efforts to reach Europe. During their journey, their hopes for personal safety and for a better future are often destroyed by organised criminal gangs of smugglers and traffickers, by lack of food and water and by unsafe transportation while travelling. Once here in Europe they are often welcomed with racism, exploitation and exclusion.  However, if we step up efforts, our policies will change the lives of millions of people. Our decisions will improve the well-being and the living conditions of immigrants. To do this we must first make sure that our development policies address the root causes of immigration. If we support governments, civil organisations and individual citizens in developing countries to implement good governance and to create a more prosperous society that gives a chance to its citizens, then migration finally becomes a free personal choice.  Secondly, we must remember the benefits that well-protected and integrated migrants have for development, in fuelling growth, innovation and entrepreneurship both in the countries that the people come from and in those they move to. Well-managed migration can reduce poverty in the countries of origin by remittance transfers. Job opportunities can motivate young people to acquire appropriate skills. There will be a rise in the exchange of goods, capital and knowledge. We are all aware of the fact that migration will only rise in the future, but if we can make it clear in our own minds and to the general public that there is an undeniable positive interconnection between migration and development, then migration will cease to be another world problem and will start being part of the solution. Luckily, the interconnection was made clear in the Council conclusions adopted last Friday on migration in EU development cooperation. This is a necessary first step, and I look forward to hearing how the European Commission will implement these conclusions. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Blue card question. I agree, Mr McKenna, that we must get to the root of the problems, but I would like to ask you when you say that we must help and support the governments from which migrants come – and this is the root of the problem – and the states from which migrants come, I would like to ask you whether you are aware of the countries from which these migrants are fleeing? They are fleeing war, hunger and atrocious dictatorships. Because it's not like they come like this, because there's not enough development there. They come because otherwise they end up in jail.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card answer. –  Yes, I know very well which country I am talking about. As you know, there are programmes of the European Union for some of those countries as well, and under all these programmes those countries’ governments should be subject to some requirements from us to implement more laws and rules to protect human rights and democracy and to implement, if possible, a market economy, etc. We have to help those countries to give their citizens a reason to live in their country. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card question. – Does my colleague share my passion for an independent Somaliland to be recognised across the United Nations and by the international community, and does he agree with me that South Sudan, which is of course the newest country recognised by the United Nations, was probably a less likely and less viable option for recognition? Does he share my support for recognition of Somaliland in the international community?

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card answer. – This is not the subject of today’s debate. You know, all the countries at present are supporting the country of Somalia. It was recognised internationally but, once again, your question is not part of today’s debate.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: Mr President, I think we really need to move forward on these issues in Europe and we need a real common immigration policy, which is not the case today in Europe, where immigration is a national responsibility, with the excesses that we are seeing. A real immigration policy cannot be done without a real partnership with Africa. I do not deny at all - I hear quite what is being said on all these benches - the contacts that can be had with certain governments and I think that, in these cases, it is better to have contacts with the opposition, NGOs or civil society. In all cases, there is a need for a substantive partnership with Africa. The objectives, we know them, are to work, of course, for human rights - as has been said, I do not want to go back to this point, which is vital, crucial, essential - and to act for economic development and to do so in a structured way. This requires stopping the sending of EU-subsidised products, which compete with farmers, and working for the self-sufficiency of a number of countries. We are talking about substantive reforms. We must also be able in Europe to cooperate, with Africa, in the fight against all human trafficking and we must also reform and harmonize our right to asylum. It is not normal for a person who is under political pressure in his country to be forced to come to us to apply for political refugee status and may not be able to do so at a European Union embassy in his country of origin. We must therefore reform and harmonize the right of asylum, open a legal path to immigration, with quotas by country, and, finally, better monitor and control our borders.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am going to speak on behalf of many associations denouncing the Khartoum process and the outsourcing of border controls with a view to rejecting them contrary to European law. Above all, they fear agreements with the Eritrean dictatorship, from which 30% of the 150 000 refugees who have arrived in Italy are now fleeing.  We have already seen how the export of democracy is a disaster, a sham. The export of migrants to concentration camps in Eritrea or Sudan will also lead to disasters and impostures. The Khartoum process is described by the Italian Presidency as a historic leap forward. The leap is being made towards new agreements with transit countries to block departures, on the pretext of outsourcing the right of asylum. This right is not already guaranteed in those countries even on the basis of the most restrictive provisions of the Geneva Convention.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Khartoum Process reveals the pitfalls and hypocrisies of difficult cooperation based on a fragile scaffolding. The strategy that we would like to adopt to control migratory flows from East Africa seems to be lacking in the protection of human rights. On the one hand, it declares its desire to combat the activity of criminal networks that profit from migrants and trafficking in human beings; on the other hand, repressive, bloodthirsty and liberticidal regimes are involved, which are the main cause of migratory flows. We need only think of the case of Eritrea, a de facto military dictatorship, with thousands of political opponents imprisoned or the case of Sudan, where genocide and crimes against humanity have been committed for decades. Other governments, such as the Egyptian government, Egypt and Somalia, have also shown that they do not shine for respect for human rights. Eritrea and Libya have never ratified the 1951 Geneva Convention on the Status of Refugees, despite the fact that it has stated that it wishes to promote cooperation in the field of asylum and international protection on the basis of the principles of international law, referring to the Convention itself. Libya, one of the countries where thousands of migrants are concentrated trying to reach Europe, did not even attend the meeting in Rome on 28 November. On that occasion, the joint declaration of the Khartoum Process was signed, with a view to establishing reception centres outside Europe' s borders. The cases of asylum seekers should be examined here with a view to subsequent resettlement in Europe. More than fighting the causes of immigration, it seems that the goal is to find agreements on how to fight migrants before they arrive in Europe, risking repeating the experience of the Libyan-Italian agreement between Gaddafi and Berlusconi. There is a fear that reception centres, if set up in countries where there is a serious democratic and civil emergency, in the absence of adequate controls, may become ghettos and refugee camps where the protection of human rights cannot be guaranteed. We need a comprehensive approach to immigration, which is based not only on cooperation without hypocrisy with third countries, but also on ensuring safe and legal access routes and the amendment of European legislation on the right of asylum, with particular regard to the most vulnerable, such as children.

name: Frank ENGEL
text: Signor Presidente, onorevoli colleghi, volevo cominciare dicendo alla signora Spinelli che, se lei parla di tutti coloro che fuggono dal Corno d'Africa dalla galera, in un paese come la Somalia non ci sono abbastanza galere. Perché questa gente non fugge la galera ma fugge l'assenza di Stato. Noi facciamo come ci fosse ancora uno Stato somalo mentre la Somalia non esiste più.  This leads me to something that my colleague Mr Carver is probably going to appreciate. Yes, I believe that we need to do something on Somaliland, and I believe that we need to do it soon. Because this is about the only territory in the whole region which is not only democratically constituted now, but which might actually also constitute a refuge for a significant number of people in the area who have nowhere else to go, and for whom this would be the closest safest haven they could reach.  But my point, to conclude, to the Commissioner, is this: we have taken over the name of this process from an initiative of the African Union. In the name of coherence of policies which we so often extol, and which I feel bound by, we should indeed try to follow up on initiatives taken by the African Union itself in order to contain phenomena that we want to contain. So therefore, even if we have to talk to dictatorships, even if we have to engage with dictatorships, this might not be the most nice and most agreeable thing to do, but at times it is just what we have to do in order to achieve an aim.

name: Ana GOMES
text: Mr President, we cannot expect dictatorships that remain in power at the expense of the brutal repression of their peoples to fulfil their obligations to the rights of thousands of migrants and refugees who risk their lives by land and sea at the mercy of criminal traffickers. The governments of the criminals Omar al-Bashir in Sudan, of Isaias in Eritrea, which arrests the citizen Dawit Isaak and thousands of other Eritreans, from Desalegn in Ethiopia, which arrests british citizen Andargachew Tsege and thousands of Ethiopians, are manufacturers of refugees and migrants, are the cause why thousands of their citizens flee from poverty and oppression. If the European Union wants to stop migration in the Horn of Africa, it has to help the peoples of this region gain the capacity to get rid of the dictatorships that oppress them, instead of paying these dictatorships to keep up, with development aid money and in the context of processes such as this saying from Khartoum that is doomed to ignominy and failure , as was the case with the agreement on migration that Italy and the European Union sought to establish with Gaddafi's Libya. If we want to stop irregular migration and trafficking in migrants and refugees, we need the European Union's judicious commitment to end the war in Syria, to make peace between Israel and Palestine, because Gaza is today where many of the migrants come from, and also European strategic commitment to the security and governance of Libya, now plunged into chaos , which is the country through which the overwhelming majority of migrants and refugees fleeing poverty and oppression in the Horn of Africa pass.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: Mr President, the European signatories who have committed themselves to launching the Khartoum process, especially those who live the drama of the beachers and the tragedy of the Mediterranean from afar, must assume that the problem is everyone's. I hope that the Rome meeting on 28 November will help the Commissioner for the Interior and Mrs Mogherini to articulate a common immigration policy based on solidarity, collaboration and loyalty.  38 countries, including African countries, have participated, matching obvious issues such as cooperation and development, collaboration with the governments of the area, pacification, stabilization and democratization, and only in this way will we achieve more than shifting the drama of Mediterranean waters to the coasts of North Africa. But I think we can do more. Denis Mukgewe, our Sakharov Prize, explained here clearly what pushes so many people to leave their homes. They are often wars provoked by business that seem to depend on the will of a tyrant with which to negotiate. President Roosevelt, speaking of Anastasio Somoza, said, "Maybe it's a...". It's not going to be politically correct for me to say what he said. let's leave him in that he said he was a tyrant, but that he was "our tyrant." And let's be ashamed of the photos of some of our leaders with renowned tyrants. Let's make a list of the beneficiaries of "our tyrants" and prevent businesses that can cause so much blood and desolation. So we will be credible, because "even if the tyrant is seen in silk, tyrant stays".

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Thank you very much for softening President Roosevelt's speech in a significant way.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul Yes, the EU has devoted resources to building fortress Europe stone by stone, and now we are going to devote resources to building a moat. That is totally unacceptable. In addition, aid money is to be used for that, and I call that nothing more than embezzlement. The overall objective is to control refugee flows, to send back refugees and to condition cooperation. Imagine if the starting point had been quite different, namely to increase the survival rate of all those people who are trying to escape war and conflict. Then the initiative would have been completely different.  In fact, I am tired of my colleagues such as Frank Engel and others in the right-wing groups who always, when it suits them, have another objective that is superior to human rights and the right to seek asylum. It could be that you want free trade, it could be that you want to control the flow of refugees, and then you can even.m. No, now is the time, not a single initiative that does not put people's right to seek asylum first.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Mr. President, nearly 40,000 immigrants including refugees and asylum seekers arrived in Europe in 2013, and according to the International Organization for Migration, more than 3,000 migrants have lost their lives in the Mediterranean Sea this year. Unfortunately, in 2014 it became the most devastating for the Mediterranean, where it was the most people who lost their lives at the gates of the European Union.  Most of the migrants lost their lives drowning, starving and freezing, and were from Africa and the Middle East. The Cardima process should be welcomed, as its objective is to establish dialogue and effective cooperation between European and African countries to combat the smuggling and trafficking of immigrants, which is almost in 80% of cases the cause of these journeys. But it is not enough just to form coalitions, to set up financial funds, because in this way it seems as if politicians think that money will wash away the guilty conscience because they have not done what they should have done in time.  I would remind that everyone's human dignity is just as important as Pope Francis spoke about 3 weeks ago, here in the European Parliament calling for answers on migration to be united, because we cannot allow the Mediterranean coast to become a great graveyard.  The Pope said Europe would only be able to face immigration problems if it was able to clearly establish its cultural identity and make adequate laws to protect the rights of European citizens and to ensure the acceptance of immigrants.  Therefore, dear colleagues, we must take action against the cause, not just the effects.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the huge influx of migrants in the face of the status of migrants, as Europe makes it necessary to adopt new mechanisms for multilateral cooperation with the countries of departure and transit of migrants, towards proposals that should be sustainable and lasting. No state, no organization can provide effective responses on its own. It is necessary to base a plan on dialogue between states and on common resources, but above all on political will, also in order to remove thousands of migrants from the hands of merchants of death. We will never really be able to tackle the causes of this flow of refugees until we forcefully raise the issue of respect for human rights in the countries of origin of migrants and, above all, within the framework of a global and holistic approach to immigration. That is why I have reservations about the last conclusion outlined in the Khartoum process. I am referring to the possibility of setting up refugee camps, intended for possible reception or perhaps detention – and here we need clarity – of the asylum seeker, which must always be accompanied by a process of monitoring respect for human rights and, above all, by adherence to all international conventions. What will be the role of the European Parliament? The memory of Libya's agreements with the Italian Government is still alive. Under no circumstances would we be prepared to accept such a violation of human rights. Today we all know what gaddafi's government has been called.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the Khartoum process brings cause for luctuous episodes which we regularly regret, also in this Parliament. The lampedusa episode, with almost 400 dead and, consequently, the call to the urgency of establishing channels of dialogue and cooperation with countries of emission, reception or transit of this tragic smuggling of human beings, of such tragic consequences. Well, the objective must be sustained even in the Horn of Africa, but without losing sight of a second which, when we talk about Eritrea, Somalia and Ethiopia, we are talking about countries that often host failed states, without responsible administration, without any guarantee of respect for fundamental rights. Therefore, in the effort to establish this route of cooperation, it is absolutely imperative that the European Union continues to respect its own standards of respect for fundamental rights. Avoid human trafficking? Yes. Avoid smuggling? Yes. Keep the dialogue process alive? Also. But with the greatest demand that every euro invested in financing mechanisms, in the reparation of these enormous injustices, entails a step forward in ensuring respect for fundamental rights, especially of the most vulnerable people: women and minors brought to these illicit traffickings, with such tragic consequences, that we have lamented, time and time again , in this European Parliament.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, a comprehensive and coherent European migration policy requires constant dialogue with the countries of origin and transit of migrants. The Khartoum process between the European Union and the countries of the Horn of Africa contributes to this goal. The signatory states place the fight against irregular emigration at the top of the agenda of this initiative by tackling smuggling networks and targeting the causes of migration. Let us not, however, make this ambition a pretext for erecting new barriers to migration. Every individual has the right to leave their country to seek asylum or seek a better future. Ensuring safe and legal entry routes into Europe for migrants and asylum seekers remains the most appropriate solution to put an end to the tragedies in the Mediterranean. The discussion on legal migration, presented as the next step in the Khartoum dialogue, cannot go unheeded. To have real added value, this process cannot be limited to a declaration of intent that is not followed by effect. It will only make sense if it is accompanied by concrete measures, with full respect for the fundamental rights of migrants and asylum seekers. However, projects from the Khartoum process will be implemented on a voluntary basis, creating no obligation under international law. Can we really expect tangible results and real added value? In the face of this unprescriptive declaration, how can we ensure the protection of migrants and the full respect of their fundamental rights?

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Commissioner, in order to limit migration flows from the countries belonging to the Horn of Africa, the root causes of this problem, which force people to leave these areas, must be eliminated. And of course, the first and most important thing is to overthrow the dictatorial regimes that exist in the countries belonging to the Horn of Africa, to bring democracy back and support there, to stop persecution, to protect human rights. Secondly, there must be peace in the region, because, as long as we have a war situation at various points, problems arise and, obviously, people have to leave, they have to save their lives. There should then be financial support from the European Union to develop these regions; of course to hit the slave trade networks and circuits; finally, Dublin III, which turns the countries of the European South into a repository of souls, is being abolished, as thousands of political refugees are trapped there. And finally, to do what you said: to develop a comprehensive approach and approach to the issue of immigration policy.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: I'm going to keep thinking about my colleague Marias and tell you this. In the hall so far, I have listened to how migration is a useful thing and it needs to be supported and encouraged. But let's be honest – for us, for the countries that border this problem, for Bulgaria, for Greece, for Spain, for Italy – migration is more of a problem than it is a solution. Our countries are becoming their own kind of refugee camps, in territories where there are an awful lot of people who can't find work, who are culturally different, different in the way they sign up. This is a big problem for us, and when we talk about migration, we have to be mindful of the following thing – where is the cause of this migration, and it should be searched where these people come from. And here comes the following question, the question of who is behind these dictators, the question of who is destroying the states, who destroyed Libya, who destroyed Egypt, who destroyed all these countries, Somalia, what is the reason for all these processes happening? This is where the solution should be sought, not in turning Europe into a large refugee camp, because africa's population is more than a billion.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I firmly believe that it is essential to establish a continuous and balanced dialogue with the countries of the Horn of Africa. The question is not whether or not we should cooperate with these countries, but how we can do so in order to prevent migrants from falling victim to the networks that facilitate their smuggled entry into Europe by sea. The Khartoum process is only one part of a comprehensive strategy. I share your concerns about the objectives of this initiative. Nevertheless, I want to make it clear that our policy does not legalize regimes in the region: the aim is to engage states and hold them accountable for saving lives and combating those responsible for human trafficking. They must keep their word and their commitments. I assure you that we will be following this process closely. On the other hand, one of my priorities is to strengthen the links between the internal and external policies of the European Union, in order to deal, in a coherent and comprehensive way, with the migratory pressures we are facing. I want to expand on this point in the European agenda on migration which was launched yesterday as part of the Commission's work programme for 2015. There is also no doubt that we must offer safer solutions to those who need international protection to reach Europe. The Commission is currently exploring all possibilities, including the development of a common approach to issuing visas on a humanitarian basis so that refugees can come to Europe and apply for asylum. At the moment, the relocation of refugees is the main route to legally enter Europe. This is an act of solidarity that the Commission encourages because for every refugee welcomed into Europe, it is a life saved. I am pleased that the total number of places offered by the Member States has increased this year. Regional development and protection programmes are the other instrument at our disposal. In this context, the European Union is supporting African countries to welcome refugees in the best possible conditions. In any case, as I said earlier, we will be closely monitoring the evolution of this process and the application of its terms.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank those of you who have spoken and who have had the opportunity, for which the Presidency is nevertheless grateful, to express their assessments and also your concerns about implementation in the Khartoum process. I wanted to pick up on a subject that has been raised in several speeches, which is the objectives and risks in the field of human rights. The Khartoum process is intended, yes, to develop technical cooperation with the authorities of the Countries of East Africa and the Horn of Africa and, as the Commissioner said, it is certainly not and certainly wants to be an endorsement of the regimes of those countries, but technical cooperation, focusing at this stage on two issues: trafficking in human beings and trafficking in migrants. There is no doubt that we must make all the necessary efforts to try to save the lives of migrants who face dangerous journeys to cross the Mediterranean. In order to achieve this, our priority should be to take action to prevent and stop the horrific crime of trafficking in human beings and to combat the trafficking of migrants. That is the objective. In the development and implementation of this cooperation, which could be extended to other areas, in line with the global approach to migration and mobility, the European Union will be consistent with the fundamental principle of full respect for migrants' rights, which is at the heart of the European Union's migration policy. I believe that facilitating contacts with the authorities of a number of countries with which the European Union and the Member States had not so far been able to enter into a dialogue could have a positive impact on raising these countries' awareness of the promotion and respect of human rights. Another point to stress is that the declaration repeatedly and unequivocally reiterates the need for full respect for the principles of international protection. It stresses the importance of offering protection to refugees, asylum seekers and assistance to migrants in vulnerable situations. It also stresses the need to ensure effective protection for refugees, asylum seekers and internally displaced persons and to provide for due access to asylum procedures, in line with international law. I have heard the expression of many concerns, to which the Presidency is far from insensitive, but I repeat what the objective is and I repeat that in this objective the protection of the human rights of migrants is central. The Presidency believes that this is a good initiative which must be followed up and, in doing so, of course, the principles laid down in the Rome Declaration must be fully respected. For the success of the initiative and also to avoid the risks that have been feared, I believe that it is essential to support the institutions of the European Union, as well as the active participation of the Member States, and I would like to stress that this Parliament has an important role to play and I would like to assure you that you will be kept informed of developments in the process.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate.
